The group is working on several redevelopment projects, including 31 Jervois Road and 205 Jalan Eunos, and plans to increase occupancy of its investment properties in Singapore.

site_title: Samudera FY18 profit falls 22% on higher costs; to pay out 0.75 S cent/share
summary: Samudera Shipping Line's net profit fell 21.5% to US$8.3 million in 2018 due to higher costs and expenses, despite a 9.8% revenue rise to US$422.3 million. The company's earnings per share declined to 1.54 US cents from 1.96 US cents in the previous year. A final dividend of 0.75 Singapore cent per share is being declared, the same as last year. The company faces uncertain prospects for 2019 due to regional container shipping industry challenges.

site_title: February ends with geopolitical tensions
summary: Global equities and currency markets were buffeted by various fundamental theme drivers in February, with US-China trade tensions and geopolitical tensions between India and Pakistan contributing to market volatility. The Straits Times Index in Singapore dropped 1.2% on the last trading day of February, while other Asian markets were mixed. Global growth slowdown was also suggested by weak economic data releases from China, Japan, and South Korea, but some counters such as Ascendas Hospitality Trust posted strong performances.

site_title: Trade talks, interest rate outlook lift Feb market
summary: Singapore's stock market ended February with a 0.7% gain, driven by positive sentiment from the US Federal Reserve's rate decision and the delayed China tariff deadline. The Straits Times Index rose 0.7% to S$926.2 billion, with DBS Group, ThaiBev, and Jardine Strategic Holdings being the top gainers. OCBC Bank, Jardine C&C, and Genting Singapore were the biggest losers. Analysts expect traders to focus on global politics and policies in the coming months.

site_title: CAO Q4 net profit rises 23.9% to US$18.7m on higher oil prices
summary: China Aviation Oil (CAO) reported a 23.9% increase in Q4 net profit to US$18.7 million, driven by higher oil prices. Revenue rose 7.8% to US$4.38 billion, despite a 16.8% decrease in total supply and trading volume. For the full year, net profit rose 10.5% to US$93.9 million, and revenue increased 26.7% to US$20.61 billion. CEO Wang Yanjun expects the company to expand its global integrated value chain and diversify its strategy amid ongoing economic and geopolitical uncertainties.

site_title: US: Wall St dips at open as US-North Korea summit ends early
summary: US stocks opened lower on Thursday after a US-North Korea summit ended early without a deal. The S&P 500, Nasdaq, and Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.15%, 0.28%, and 0% respectively. Despite this, the American economy's fourth-quarter slowdown was less severe than expected.

site_title: Coming into bloom
summary: Flowerbx, a four-year-old florist in London, has become the go-to florist for the fashion set in Europe. Founded by Whitney Bromberg Hawkings, the company offers bespoke flower arrangements and has gained a reputation for its high-quality, affordable blooms. With clients including Louis Vuitton, Dior, and Victoria and David Beckham, Flowerbx aims to expand globally, with plans to open a shop in New York and become the first international flower brand. The company's unique approach, which involves cutting flowers in Holland and delivering them directly to customers, has resulted in significant sales growth, with a goal of reaching $30 million in revenue by 2021.

site_title: Coffee business may leave Olam with bitter taste in 1H 2019
summary: Olam International, a Singapore-based agri-food giant, expects its coffee business to remain under stress in the first half of 2019 due to a supply glut and bad weather. The company's CEO, Sunny Verghese, cited a global coffee surplus of five million bags, down from nine million, and lower crop yields in South and Central America. Despite this, Verghese noted that the Brazilian real's direction could support coffee prices, and the company plans to invest more in coffee under its six-year strategic plan.

site_title: Jardine Strategic full-year profit down 57% to US$1.84b
summary: Jardine Strategic Holdings' full-year profit fell 57% to US$1.84 billion due to restructuring costs and fair-value investment losses. Excluding these factors, underlying profit increased 14% to US$1.78 billion. Revenue rose 11% to US$34.09 billion, while gross revenue grew 11% to US$92.35 billion. Jardine Matheson Holdings' profits slid 56% to US$1.73 billion, but the group expects to benefit from the sale of its interest in Jardine Lloyd Thompson, valued at US$2 billion.

site_title: Cordlife CEO resigns to pursue other interests
summary: Cordlife Group's CEO Michael Steven Weiss has resigned to pursue other interests, replacing Tan Poh Lan as group chief operating officer and executive director. Weiss had taken a sabbatical leave from January to May. The company reported a net profit of S$5.5 million for the financial year ended December 31, reversing a loss of S$1.19 million in the previous 18 months. Cordlife shares remained unchanged at S$0.39 following the announcement.

site_title: Latest Earnings
summary: NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer received 9.8 times oversubscription. Creative Technology warned of potential H2 revenue below target and operating loss similar to H1. London's Heathrow plans to increase fees for a £10b upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case. OCBC appointed Tan Teck Long, a former DBS veteran, as its new CEO. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and People's Bank of China (PBOC) agreed to deepen cooperation in green and transition finance, ahead of Singapore's GDP data release.

site_title: DBS launches robo-investment platform to woo non-investors
summary: DBS has launched DBS digiPortfolio, a robo-investment platform that combines expertise of portfolio managers with robo-technology. The platform offers two portfolios with varying management fees and access to securities. The Global Portfolio requires a S$1,000 minimum investment, while the Global Portfolio Plus requires S$10,000. The platform is available to DBS Treasures clients with S$350,000 in assets, and will be rolled out to all retail investors by the end of 2019. No sales charge, platform fee, or lock-in period applies.

site_title: Centurion Q4 net profit soars to S$53.1m on net fair-valuation gains
summary: Centurion Corp reported a net profit of S$53.1 million in its fiscal fourth quarter, driven by S$48.6 million in net fair-valuation gains from its UK student accommodation. Excluding one-off items, core business profit was S$9.5 million, down S$1.3 million from the previous year. Revenue fell 6.7% to S$31.3 million, mainly due to the lease expiry of Westlite Tuas. The group saw a 63% increase in earnings per share to 6.32 Singapore cents. Net profit for the full fiscal year rose to S$79.3 million, with a final dividend of one Singapore cent per share recommended.

site_title: Geopolitical tensions weigh as Singapore shares lose 1.2% on Thursday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index dropped 1.2% to 3,212.69 on Thursday, weighed down by geopolitical tensions. The US-North Korea summit was cut short, and expectations for a US-China trade deal were scaled back. India-Pakistan tensions also contributed to the decline. In the bourse, Thomson Medical Group rose 1.3%, while Genting Singapore fell 1.9% and Jardine Cycle & Carriage lost 9%. Financials including DBS Group Holdings, OCBC Bank, and United Overseas Bank also declined, with DBS falling 1.2% and OCBC dropping 1.1%.

site_title: Straco Corp posts 12.4% fall in FY2018 earnings on Singapore Flyer suspension
summary: Straco Corp reported a 12.4% drop in FY2018 earnings to S$41.8 million, primarily due to the two-month suspension of the Singapore Flyer. Revenue fell 8.2% to S$117.9 million, mainly affected by lower contributions from the Singapore Flyer and Chinese aquariums. The company expects China's domestic tourism to remain positive, with a focus on quality-oriented development. Straco will pay a special dividend of one Singapore cent per share, citing its strong net cash balance of S$163.8 million.

site_title: Government project quotation cap raised to S$90,000
summary: The Singapore government has raised the upper limit for quotations in government procurement projects to S$90,000, making it easier for small firms to capture higher-value projects. This change aims to benefit smaller companies and startups without Government Supplier Registration. The Companies Act will also be reviewed to allow for digital meetings and interactions with stakeholders.

site_title: Pakistan says it will return captured Indian pilot
summary: Pakistan's Prime Minister Imran Khan announced that a captured Indian pilot, Wing Commander Abhinandan Varthaman, will be released as a peace gesture to India. The pilot was held in custody after being downed by Indian jets in a disputed border region. The move comes amid efforts by the US to defuse a crisis between the two nuclear powers. Four Pakistani civilians were killed in Indian firing across the border in Kashmir. The pilot's release is set to take place on Friday.

site_title: Academia-industry alliance can boost accountancy in Laos
summary: Laos has been strengthening its economy through an academia-industry alliance, aiming to turn itself from a landlocked to a land-linked country. The country has been opening up to the world, with Singapore being one of its key partners. However, despite Singapore's presence since the late 1980s, it remains a relatively small foreign investor in Laos. The Laos government's efforts are part of its broader economic development plans, which include increasing links with neighboring countries such as Singapore.

site_title: Straits Trading Q4 net profit more than doubles to S$14.1m
summary: Straits Trading's Q4 net profit more than doubled to S$14.1 million, driven by a 43.7% increase in fair value of its investment properties. Revenue dipped 1.7% to S$104.7 million due to a 7.8% fall in tin mining revenue. The company has proposed an unchanged interim dividend of six Singapore cents per share. Despite a challenging business environment due to geopolitical uncertainties and rising interest rates, Straits Trading remains cautious and selective in its investment opportunities.

site_title: Dairy Farm posts 5.2% rise in FY18 underlying net profit, but incurs US$453m restructuring charge
summary: Dairy Farm International Holdings reported a 5.2% increase in underlying net profit to US$424 million in FY18, despite a US$453m restructuring charge. Revenue rose 4.1% to US$11.75 billion. The company's Supermarket and Hypermarket business saw lower sales and profit due to intensified market competition, while Convenience stores and Health and Beauty saw growth. The board recommended an unchanged final dividend of 21 US cents per share. Despite challenges, Chairman Ben Keswick expressed confidence in the company's customer-focused strategy and long-term sustainable growth.

site_title: British Airways chooses Boeing 777 to replace 747s
summary: British Airways has ordered up to 42 Boeing 777 jets, valued at up to $18.6 billion, to replace its aging 747 fleet. The airline will take 18 of the largest 777-9 version, and IAG also took options on an additional 24. The order is seen as a victory for Boeing over rival Airbus, and is expected to boost sales of the 777X program ahead of its factory roll-out and first flight this year.

images.alt_text: British Airways on Feb 28, 2019 announced a multi-billion dollar deal to buy up to 42 Boeing 777 fuel-efficient passenger jets, after Airbus said it would no longer make the A380 superjumbo.

site_title: Inside the dying moments of the Trump-Kim summit at a Hanoi hotel
summary: US President Donald Trump and North Korean leader Kim Jong Un's summit at the Metropole hotel in Hanoi ended without a deal or lunch, contrary to initial expectations. The working lunch was cancelled just hours after both leaders expressed optimism about progress. The cancellation marked the dying moment of a deal aimed at dismantling North Korea's nuclear program. The White House announced the cancellation without explanation, leaving the fate of the delicately prepared meal of foie gras, snowfish, and candied ginseng uncertain.

site_title: Market Capitalisation
summary: NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer received 9.8 times oversubscription. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and similar operating loss for the second half of the year. London's Heathrow plans to increase fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a graft case involving 285 trillion rupiah. Tan Teck Long, former DBS veteran, is set to become OCBC's new CEO. MAS and PBOC are expanding green and transition finance cooperation. Singapore stocks experienced a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data release.

site_title: Sias urges Hyflux's senior creditors to consider giving up more for perp, pref holders
summary: Sias urges Hyflux's senior creditors to consider an alternative restructuring plan that could see retail perp and pref shareholders recover more of their principal, if senior creditors agree to give up some of their share. The present plan is deemed "not acceptable" to PnPs, who face a 10.7% recovery rate with only 3% paid in cash. In contrast, senior creditors are promised a minimum 24.5% recovery rate under the same scheme.

site_title: China Sunsine Chemical Q4 net profit falls 17.7% to 108.6m yuan
summary: China Sunsine Chemical Holdings reported a 17.7% decline in fourth-quarter net profit to 108.6 million yuan due to a 11.8% fall in revenue and lower average selling prices. Earnings per share dropped to 22.11 RMB cents from 26.85 RMB cents in the previous year. The decline in revenue was attributed to the fall in average selling prices.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: The government of Singapore has yet to decide on the timing of increasing the Goods and Services Tax (GST) to 9%, with Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat stating that care will be taken. In other news, Singapore's fintech investments more than doubled to US$365m in 2018, and a real estate fund was acquired by Frasers Centrepoint Trust for S$342.5m. Meanwhile, the Singapore Stock Exchange dropped 1.2% due to geopolitical tensions. Globally, Vietnam was surprised by a US tariff announcement, and China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers.

site_title: EU Brexit negotiator says UK 'decision more important than extra time'
summary: EU Brexit negotiator Michel Barnier emphasized the need for a decision from the UK on its withdrawal deal, stating it's more important than seeking extra time. He warned that any postponement would come with conditions and linked the duration of an extension to resolving the withdrawal deal. Austrian Chancellor Sebastian Kurz also expressed concerns that a country leaving the EU would not be eligible to participate in European elections, highlighting the need for an orderly exit.

images.alt_text: The European Union's chief Brexit negotiator Michel Barnier on Thursday repeated a call for a decision from London on its withdrawal deal, rather than seeking a delay.

site_title: German carmakers team up to tackle 21st Century challenges
summary: German luxury car giants BMW and Daimler are forming a partnership to catch up with US and Chinese competitors in electric cars and self-driving technology. The collaboration will focus on developing automated driving and driver assistance systems, aiming to improve their position in the global luxury car market. This move comes after years of competition between the two companies, with BMW and Daimler previously locked in a sales chart battle. The partnership aims to enhance their capabilities in electric and autonomous vehicles, helping them stay competitive in the rapidly evolving automotive industry.

images.alt_text: German high-end car giants BMW and Mercedes-Benz maker Daimler are banding together to catch up with American and Chinese competitors, with new cooperation on multiple fronts including electric cars and self-driving technology.

site_title: Hongkong Land full-year 2018 earnings rise 9% to US$1.04b
summary: Hongkong Land, a member of the Jardine Matheson Group, reported a 9% increase in full-year earnings to US$1.04 billion in 2018, driven by higher property rents and development profits in China and Singapore. The group's investment properties benefited from higher average rents, while development profits in Singapore increased. The directors recommended a final dividend of 16 US cents per share, totaling 22 US cents for the year. The company expects stable profit contributions from investment properties, but higher profits from China's development business.

site_title: Mandarin Oriental underlying bottom line rises 18.6% to US$65.1m for fiscal year 2018
summary: Mandarin Oriental International reported a 18.6% increase in underlying net profit to US$65.1 million for fiscal year 2018, driven by revenue growth from owned properties in Hong Kong and Singapore, as well as one-off fees from terminated management contracts. Revenue per average room rose 9% on a like-for-like basis, with RevPAR increasing 9%, 14%, and 4% in Asia, Europe, and the US, respectively. The company's chairman expects a positive outlook for 2019, but notes that the planned closure of The Excelsior will substantially reduce underlying profit.

site_title: Social media fake news fans tension between India and Pakistan
summary: India and Pakistan are experiencing heightened tension after an air strike by India, with false videos and images circulating on social media platforms such as Twitter and Facebook. The fake news attempts to mislead millions, including a video of an injured pilot and images from a 2005 earthquake. The false information comes after India launched an air strike in Pakistan, which Pakistan denies had any casualties. The spread of fake news has sparked anger in both countries, adding to the already tense situation.

site_title: Jardine C&C shares slump on earnings miss; 'slower growth' outlook
summary: Jardine Cycle & Carriage (JCC) shares plummeted 10.7% after missing full-year earnings estimates. The group reported a core profit of US$858 million, up 11.5% from 2017, but cautioned on "slower growth" in 2019 due to macroeconomic and commercial headwinds. Astra International, JCC's main profit contributor, saw lower operating margins despite higher automotive sales, while direct motor interests and other strategic interests are expected to experience slower growth.

site_title: Geo Energy swings into Q4 loss of US$5m, proposes dividend
summary: Geo Energy Resources reported a Q4 net loss of US$5.0 million, down from a year-ago profit of US$3.4 million, due to lower coal sales volume and prices. Revenue fell 39% to US$56.2 million, and the company proposes a final cash dividend of 0.4 Singapore cent per share, resulting in a 7.4% dividend yield. The company attributes the loss to weaker coal prices, particularly in November, and plans to review its production quota in six months to increase output if needed.

site_title: Malaysia's CIMB logs 5.4% bump in Q4 profit on commercial banking boost
summary: Malaysia's CIMB Group Holdings Bhd posted a 5.4% increase in Q4 net profit, driven by its commercial banking and group funding businesses. The lender achieved record quarterly profit in 2018 and surpassed analyst estimates. Revenue declined 9.8%, while the commercial banking segment swung to a profit of 190 million ringgit. CIMB expects loan growth of 6% for 2019 and a relatively stable net interest margin of 2.5%. The bank remains cautious due to external headwinds, including elections and political developments in Indonesia and Thailand.

site_title: Neuron Mobility charged with providing e-scooter sharing service without licence
summary: Neuron Mobility, an e-scooter sharing startup, was charged with providing its services at public places without a required licence or exemption. As of Monday, 144 of its personal mobility devices were impounded by the Land Transport Authority (LTA) after repeated warnings. The startup's CEO, Zachary Wang, attributed the issue to user confusion, while LTA reiterated its stance on assessing licence applications based on companies' compliance with the law. Neuron's licence application with LTA remains pending, and the startup may consider growing elsewhere if it fails to obtain the licence.

site_title: UOB, OctoRocket tie up to provide SME loans across Asean
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) and OctoRocket.asia have signed a memorandum of understanding to provide small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) in Southeast Asia with financing options through OctoRocket's platform. UOB will assess SMEs' creditworthiness based on transactional data, using a credit assessment engine backed by artificial intelligence and machine learning, reducing loan approval times from 2.5 days to 15 minutes. This partnership aims to support e-commerce buyers and sellers in quickly seizing business opportunities, particularly in the packaged food industry.

images.alt_text: UOB head of group business banking Lawrence Loh (left) and OctoRocket chairman Julian Tan sign an MOU to help small businesses in Asean apply for financing. Mr Tan is also chief of digital business at SPH.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed lower on Thursday, with the Hang Seng Index falling 0.43% to 28,633.18, amid tempered optimism over China-US trade talks and the abrupt end of the Donald Trump-Kim Jong Un nuclear summit. The Shanghai Composite Index also declined 0.44%, while the Shenzhen Composite Index rose 0.35%. The decline was attributed to uncertainty surrounding the US-China trade talks and concerns about the global economy.

site_title: Australian shares close higher, post best Feb in 4 years; NZ gains
summary: Australian shares ended the day higher, posting their best February performance since 2015, with the S&P/ASX 200 index rising 0.3% to 6,169.0. Financials and mining stocks drove the gains, with lenders Westpac and National Australia Bank increasing 1% and 1.3% respectively. New Zealand shares also rose, with the benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index gaining 0.5% to 9,325.03.

site_title: China Gaoxian receives SGX delisting notice, must provide exit offer
summary: China Gaoxian Fibre Fabric Holdings' stock is set to be delisted from the Singapore Exchange (SGX) due to failure to meet profitability and market capitalization requirements. The stock will remain suspended until an exit offer is made. The company had previously been placed on the watch-list in 2016 due to consecutive years of pre-tax losses and a low market capitalization. SGX has rejected the company's request for a 12-month extension to exit the watch-list, setting a March 2 deadline for a "reasonable" exit offer proposal.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets fall at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets fell at the start of trading on Thursday, with London's FTSE 100 index down 0.5% and eurozone indices dropping 0.4-0.5%. The decline followed a mixed US market, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edging to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty. Investors' focus shifted to US-EU trade talks and the Federal Reserve's split views on monetary policy.

images.alt_text: Europe's main stock markets fell at the start of trading on Thursday, with London's benchmark FTSE 100 index down 0.5 per cent at 7,069.89 points.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks fall as Trump-Kim summit fails to yield agreement
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index plummeted 1.76% on Thursday, its largest daily percentage loss since October 2018, as the Trump-Kim summit failed to produce an agreement. The Korean won weakened, and foreigners sold 257.5 billion won worth of shares. The summit's failure has heightened geopolitical risk, leading to profit-taking and a decline in the benchmark bond yield. The Kospi has risen 7.82% this year, but the current price-to-earnings ratio is 12.10, and the market capitalization is 1,242.04 trillion won.

site_title: Halcyon Agri posts Q4 net loss of US$7.4m on poor economic outlook, falling rubber prices
summary: Halcyon Agri Corporation reported a net loss of US$7.4 million in its fourth quarter, down from a net profit of US$11.4 million in the previous year. Revenue rose 5.1% to US$538.3 million due to a 15.5% increase in sales volume, but was partially offset by lower revenue per tonne. The company posted a loss per share of 0.46 US cents, from earnings per share of 0.72 US cents in the previous year.

site_title: Redeeming preference shares with IPO proceeds was priority from the start: Sim Leisure Group
summary: Sim Leisure Group prioritized redeeming its outstanding redeemable convertible preference shares with IPO proceeds, accounting for 96.45% of the IPO funds. This order of priority was stated in the preliminary prospectus. The company will debut on the stock market on Friday, allowing investors to express their opinions on the allocation of funds.

site_title: Development charge rates cut for non-landed residential use, but raised for hotel, commercial uses
summary: The government has reduced development charge (DC) rates for non-landed residential projects by 5.5% on average, contrasting with a 9.8% increase in September last year. The change aims to boost the development of non-landed residential projects. However, DC rates for hotel and commercial uses have been raised. This move is expected to encourage developers to enhance and expand their projects, potentially leading to more affordable housing options for Singaporeans.

site_title: Frasers Centrepoint Trust to buy 17.1% stake in PGIM Real Estate Fund for S$342.5m
summary: Frasers Centrepoint Trust (FCT) has agreed to acquire a 17.1% stake in the PGIM Real Estate Asia Retail Fund Ltd for approximately S$342.5 million. The acquisition is subject to board approval and Bermuda Monetary Authority consent. FCT's wholly owned subsidiary, FCT Holdings (Sigma), will purchase 90,346 shares representing the stake. The deal is expected to increase distribution per unit for FCT unitholders. The acquisition is separate from a similar deal proposed by Frasers Property on Feb 18.

site_title: Ex-Nissan chief Carlos Ghosn makes fresh bail request
summary: Former Nissan chief Carlos Ghosn's lawyers filed a fresh bail request for the 64-year-old auto titan after three months of detention on charges of financial misconduct. Ghosn, who has denied all allegations, has tried repeatedly without success to secure bail. His lawyers argue that he poses no flight risk and can be monitored through a tracking bracelet. The court has previously justified his detention due to a risk of concealing evidence, but Ghosn's lawyers claim this is not the case. A new bail request has been filed, marking a fresh attempt to secure his release.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares ended lower on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 5.72 points to 1,707.73. Losers outnumbered gainers 702 to 241, and volume was 2.6 billion lots worth RM3 billion.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close lower on reduced US-China trade hopes
summary: Tokyo stocks declined on Thursday as US-China trade negotiations lost momentum, according to US chief trade negotiator Robert Lighthizer. The Nikkei 225 index fell 0.79% to 21,385.16, while the Topix index dropped 0.79% to 1,607.66. The decline was attributed to reduced market optimism and investors' cautious outlook amid ongoing US-North Korea summit and US-EU trade talks.

site_title: Trump-Kim summit ended abruptly over North Korea sanctions
summary: US President Donald Trump's summit with North Korean leader Kim Jong Un ended without an agreement due to disagreements over lifting sanctions on North Korea. Trump stated that he was not willing to lift all sanctions, and the two leaders failed to sign a joint statement. Despite "very good and constructive meetings" on denuclearization and economic concepts, no agreement was reached, and critics described the outcome as a "major failure" and a limit of summitry.

site_title: Tourists stranded as Thai Airways cancels flights over Pakistan
summary: Thousands of tourists were stranded in Bangkok after Thai Airways cancelled all flights over Pakistan due to Islamabad's sudden closure of its airspace amid rising tensions with India. 27 flights, mostly to European routes, were cancelled, leaving nearly 5,000 passengers stranded, including 4,000 from European flights and 700-800 from flights to Pakistan. Stranded passengers were put up in hotels at Thai Airways' expense. The cancellations caused frustration among tourists, with some waiting for 11 hours without food or assistance. Thai Airways is now contacting China for permission to fly over its airspace.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Thursday afternoon at 3,230.28, down 0.6% on day
summary: Singapore stocks resumed trading on Thursday at 3,230.28, down 0.6% from the previous day. The Straits Times Index lost 19.74 points, with about 771 million securities worth S$685.2 million changing hands. Losers outnumbered gainers 196 to 133, with Thomson Medical Group being the most actively traded stock.

site_title: Kim says would welcome US liaison office in North Korea
summary: North Korean leader Kim Jong Un has expressed willingness to welcome a US liaison office in Pyongyang, a key step in normalizing relations between the two countries. US President Donald Trump described the idea as a "great thing" and said he was in "no rush" for a major breakthrough. The two leaders met in Hanoi for their second summit, aiming to agree on concrete steps towards complete nuclear disarmament of the Korean peninsula. A declaration is expected to be signed after the meetings, with Trump holding a press conference before leaving Vietnam.

site_title: Asian markets down as Kim-Trump summit ends abruptly
summary: Asian markets declined on February 28, 2019, as a summit between Donald Trump and Kim Jong Un ended abruptly without an agreement. This led to a downturn in Seoul, with other markets following suit. The unexpected cancellation occurred despite tempered optimism over China-US trade talks and weak factory data from Beijing. Geopolitical tensions in Kashmir also weighed on investor sentiment. The abrupt end to the summit led to a sharp decline in equities, reflecting the uncertainty surrounding the US-North Korea relationship.

site_title: Investors should stick to their (accounting) principles
summary: Sea Ltd., a South-east Asian internet company, reports its fourth-quarter results using non-GAAP (Generally Accepted Accounting Principles) financial metrics, which differ significantly from its GAAP (Generally Accepted Accounting Principles) numbers. The company's adjusted revenue is 37% higher than its GAAP figure, with a 76% difference in digital entertainment revenue. Sea advises investors to focus on its preferred method, rather than the standard GAAP, to accurately assess its performance. This approach is not unique to Sea, as 277 S&P 500 companies use their own formulas to guide investors.

site_title: Australia suffers hottest summer on record, little relief in sight
summary: Australia has experienced its hottest summer on record, with temperatures averaging 2 deg C higher than long-term averages. The Bureau of Meteorology attributes this to a record hot December and January. Forecasts indicate the southern autumn will also be drier and warmer than average, with the final summer temperature figures expected to be released on Friday. This marks a significant shift in climate patterns, with the summer being the warmest on record for the first time.

images.alt_text: Australia suffered its hottest summer on record from December through February and forecasts show the southern autumn will continue to be drier and warmer than average, the government said Thursday.

site_title: Australian home lending now weakest since Reagan-Thatcher era
summary: Australian home lending has slowed to its weakest level since the 1980s, with a 0.2% increase in January, according to the Reserve Bank. This is due to a combination of factors including stratospheric property prices, tighter lending standards, and new supply. The Reserve Bank has kept interest rates at a record-low 1.5% to spur economic growth, but has shifted its bias towards easing as consumers cut spending amid falling house prices. This is reflected in a 2.8% drop in credit for personal purchases and a decline in rentals in New South Wales.

images.alt_text: Australian home lending slowed to the weakest since President Ronald Reagan and Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher dominated the global arena in the 1980s.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened higher on Thursday, rising 2.00 points to 1,715.45. The FTSE index saw 72.86 million lots traded worth RM30.32 million. Gainers outpaced losers 115 to 105.

site_title: Asia: Markets swing on tempered trade hopes, weak data
summary: Asian markets fluctuated Thursday as optimism over China-US trade talks was tempered by US Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer's comments, stating "real progress" had been made but work remained to be done. Weak Chinese factory data and fresh geopolitical tensions in Kashmir also influenced markets. Despite this, some markets, such as Hong Kong and Shanghai, gained, while others, like Singapore and Seoul, declined. Investors remain cautious amid uncertainty, with analysts noting the need for a mutually face-saving path to de-escalate tensions in Kashmir.

site_title: Grow better, not faster, to build an international business
summary: Singapore's Minister for Finance Heng Swee Keat emphasizes the importance of scaling up and venturing into new markets for ambitious businesses. However, international expansion requires a deep understanding of local customers, prioritizing growth over speed, and adopting a customer-obsessed approach. Successful businesses like Starbucks, which failed to adapt to Australian tastes, demonstrate the challenges of international expansion. To succeed, businesses should identify areas of demand through inbound marketing, assess market potential holistically, and prioritize sustainable growth over rapid expansion.

site_title: Government yet to decide on exact timing of GST increase to 9%: Heng Swee Keat
summary: Singapore's government has yet to decide on the exact timing of a planned 2% increase in the Goods and Services Tax (GST) to 9%, with Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat emphasizing the need to monitor economic conditions and revenues. The hike is necessary to support increased healthcare spending, as well as other critical needs like pre-school education and security. The planned increase is expected to raise Singapore's GDP by 0.7 percentage point, and will be implemented between 2021 and 2025.

site_title: Singapore fintech investments more than double to US$365m in 2018 amid global surge: Accenture
summary: Fintech investments in Singapore more than doubled to US$365 million in 2018, ranking among the top five fintech markets in the Asia Pacific. The number of deals rose 16% to 71, with 28% of funds going to lending, 26% to payments, and 20% to insurtech. Globally, fintech investments surged to US$55.3 billion, led by China's nine-fold increase to US$25.5 billion, driven by funding for Ant Financial and Alibaba Group.

images.alt_text: Fintech investments in Singapore more than doubled to hit US$365 million in 2018, up from US$180 million in the previous year, placing it among the top five fintech markets by funds raised in the Asia Pacific last year, according to an analysis by Accenture. Within the region, Singapore lags behind Australia, China, India and Japan.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks down at start of trade
summary: Hong Kong stocks began the day down, with the Hang Seng Index shedding 0.13% to 28,719.71, following data showing a further contraction in China's manufacturing sector in February. The Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indexes also eased, with the latter slipping 0.08%. The declines were attributed to global market uncertainty, including US-China trade tensions.

site_title: Ocean Sky International warns of fiscal 2018 net loss
summary: Ocean Sky International, a civil engineering company, expects to report a net loss for the financial year ended Dec 31, 2018, due to an impairment of goodwill and the absence of an one-off gain from the disposal of an investment property. The company's unaudited results will be announced on or before March 1, with shares dropping 2.27% to 4.3 cents apiece.

site_title: Industry body unveils fintech accelerator and mentorship programme for asset managers
summary: The Investment Management Association of Singapore (IMAS) has launched the Digital Accelerator Programme (DAP), a fintech accelerator and mentorship initiative for asset managers. The programme aims to help firms reduce costs, increase investment returns, and deliver differentiated experiences through digital solutions. Up to 10 fintech startups will participate in the initial programme, with the shortlisted firms presenting their solutions to a panel of judges at the IMAS Bloomberg Investment Conference 2019. Winners will receive a four-week acceleration programme, funding, and access to professional mentors. Applications are open until April 8.

site_title: CAO Q4 net profit rises 23.9% to US$18.7m on higher oil prices
summary: China Aviation Oil (Singapore) Corp's fourth-quarter net profit rose 23.9% to US$18.7 million, driven by higher oil prices. Revenue increased 7.8% to US$4.38 billion despite a 16.8% decrease in total supply and trading volume. Full-year net profit rose 10.5% to US$93.9 million, and revenue increased 26.7% to US$20.61 billion. The company plans to pay a first and final dividend of 4.5 Singapore cents per share. CEO Wang Yanjun expects the company to expand its global integrated value chain despite slower economic growth and geopolitical uncertainties.

site_title: Amara Holdings posts 35% jump in FY2018 profit
summary: Amara Holdings reported a 35% increase in FY2018 profit to S$32.0 million, driven by a 16% rise in revenue to S$104.2 million. Earnings per share rose to 5.56 Singapore cents, with a final dividend of one Singapore cent and a special dividend of one Singapore cent declared. This growth is attributed to higher revenue in its hotel investment and management segment.

site_title: Vietnam still an attractive market, with more FDI expected: HSBC
summary: HSBC analysts predict Vietnam will remain an attractive market due to strong economic growth, stable currency, and contained inflation. They expect 6.5% growth this year and a boost to the equity market. Long-term fundamentals are strong, with supply chain shifts and manufacturing growth expected to increase investment and exports. However, risks include legacy banking issues, potential trade slowdowns, and capital flight from emerging markets. The analysts urge Vietnam to encourage long-term infrastructure investors to avoid lagging infrastructure development.

site_title: Attilan unable to meet fund investor's S$2m put
summary: Attilan Group, a Singapore-listed investment firm, is unable to redeem S$2 million of preference shares in its TAP Venture Fund I (TAPVF) after another investor exercised a put option. This is the second round of put redemptions this year, following a previous round in January where S$5 million of redemptions were also met by the company through settlement. Attilan has until June 1, 2019, to complete the redemption and will engage the investor for a settlement. Shares of Attilan are currently suspended.

site_title: URA launches tender for Clementi Avenue 1 residential site
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) has launched a public tender for a 99-year residential site at Clementi Avenue 1, with a permissible gross floor area of 57,900 sq m. The site can potentially yield up to 640 residential units and must include a child care centre with a minimum GFA of 700 sq m. The tender will close on July 3, 2019, and the project completion period is set at 60 months. The site has a gross plot ratio of about 3.5 times and a maximum building height of 140m.

site_title: Asean to continue their domestic reflation policies: DBS
summary: ASEAN countries will maintain their domestic reflation policies despite a challenging external environment. Analysts from DBS note that Vietnam is expected to benefit from the Trump-Kim meeting and supply chain diversions due to the China-US trade war. Thailand's upcoming elections are seen as positive for consumer confidence, policy continuity, and foreign investments. Indonesia's presidential election may pose risks, but analysts believe near-term drivers will support consumer and banking stocks. Malaysia's domestic strength is underestimated, and an economic recession is unlikely due to its strong growth and liquidity.

site_title: Sunpower Group fiscal 2018 profit doubles to 320.5m yuan
summary: SunPower Group's fiscal 2018 net profit more than doubled to 320.5 million yuan, driven by expansion into green investments and the acquisition of Yongxing Plant. Earnings per share rose to 41.87 fen from 19.76 fen a year prior. The company proposes a first and final dividend of 0.19 Singapore cent, up from 0.12 cent the previous year.

site_title: Key Asia-Europe air route closed as India-Pakistan tensions rise
summary: Pakistan closed its airspace following a military clash with India, blocking a key air route between Asia Pacific and Europe. Global airlines diverted or canceled flights, including Singapore Airlines, Qantas Airways, and Thai Airways. The closure affected about 220 daily services between Europe and Southeast Asia, with flights to India, Pakistan, and Thailand impacted. Airlines re-routed flights, adding extra time to journeys, and some airports in northern India were initially shut before restrictions were lifted. The move was in response to India's military action, which Pakistan retaliated to with the downing of an Indian jet and the capture of a pilot.

site_title: Institutional investors slightly less cautious in February: State Street
summary: State Street's global investor confidence index showed a slight improvement in February, rising 1.5 points to 70.9, from January's revised reading of 69.4. Institutional investors remained cautious, with lingering growth and trade policy uncertainty contributing to the cautious stance. The index, which measures investor confidence by analyzing actual buying and selling patterns, indicates that investors are neither increasing nor decreasing their long-term allocations to risky assets. The reading is 29.1 points below the neutral level of 100.

site_title: Australian sales fall but profit up for retailer Harvey Norman
summary: Harvey Norman Holdings, Australia's largest electronics retailer, reported a 7.3% rise in half-year profit to A$222.8 million, despite a 1.7% fall in domestic sales. The profit was driven by increases in sales at international stores and property value gains. The company's Australian franchise stores face challenges, with sales expected to worsen, amid a broader economic slowdown. The central bank is closely watching spending indicators, which may prompt interest rate cuts. The result contrasts with rival JB Hi-Fi, which defied the downturn to lift sales.

site_title: Apple self-driving car layoffs give hints to division's direction
summary: Apple plans to lay off 190 employees in its self-driving car program, Project Titan, as of April 16, affecting 7 facilities in Santa Clara, California. The layoffs include at least 2 dozen software engineers, 40 hardware engineers, and 3 product design engineers. The move appears to be under new leadership, Vice President of Special Projects Doug Field, who returned to Apple last year. Despite the layoffs, Apple has ramped up testing on California roads, logging nearly 128,750km of testing in 2018, but still trails Alphabet's Waymo unit in mileage.

site_title: China's factory downturn deepens though upside signs appear
summary: China's manufacturing sector contracted further in February, with the manufacturing purchasing managers index falling to 49.2, indicating a contraction. New orders improved, while export orders declined. The non-manufacturing PMI also fell to 54.3. Despite a possible trade deal with the US, uncertainty and a global slowdown remain. Experts suggest that the economy may stabilize, but the impact of rising input prices and weak demand from the global economy is still a concern.

site_title: Bank of Korea holds rates as growth risks rise, to sit tight for while
summary: South Korea's central bank, the Bank of Korea, held interest rates steady at 1.75% amid growing economic concerns. Policymakers are cautious due to weakening exports and slowing global growth, with the US Federal Reserve also signaling a pause to its rate hikes. The BOK's decision mirrors a shift by global counterparts, and analysts expect the bank to stay on hold for the rest of the year. The economy faces pressure from a slowdown in China, the Sino-US trade war, and a decline in inflation, leading to a forecasted growth rate of 2.6% for this year.

site_title: Moya back in the black with S$2.3m Q4 earnings
summary: Moya Holdings Asia reported a net profit of S$2.33 million for the fourth quarter, reversing a loss of S$380,000 from the same period last year. Earnings per share rose to 0.06 Singapore cent, up from a loss of 0.01 cent in 2017. Revenue fell 6% to S$47.3 million, primarily due to lower service concession construction revenue and finance income from BOT projects.

site_title: Indofood Agri Resources sinks into the red with Q4 loss of 211.7b rupiah
summary: Indofood Agri Resources reported a net loss of 211.70 billion rupiah (S$20.4 million) in Q4 2018, down from a net profit of 76.94 billion rupiah the year before. The loss was mainly due to weak commodity prices and lower sales in its plantation division. However, the edible oils and fats division performed strongly. The company recommended a final dividend, subject to shareholder approval, and expects to pay out 0.7 Singapore cent per share. Revenue decreased 6.5% to 3.80 trillion rupiah, while financial expenses increased 26.7% to 198.88 billion rupiah.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Olam, Indofood Agri, Hong Leong Finance, Banyan Tree, M1, IHH Healthcare, Jardine C&C
summary:
Here's a summary of the article in 100 words or less:

Several Singaporean companies released financial results on Thursday, with varying outcomes. Olam International posted a 71.6% drop in net profit, while Indofood Agri Resources recorded a net loss. Hong Leong Finance reported a 38.1% increase in net profit, and Banyan Tree Holdings' fourth-quarter net profit rose 44%. M1 lost its free float and will be delisted after a voluntary conditional general offer. Other companies, including IHH Healthcare and Jardine Cycle & Carriage, reported strong financial performances. The Straits Times Index rose 0.4% on Thursday, driven by investor positivity despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Banyan Tree Q4 profit grows 44% on property sales, one-offs; to pay out 1.05 S cent/share
summary: Banyan Tree Holdings' Q4 profit rose 44% to S$5.6 million, driven by property sales and one-off gains. Earnings per share increased to 0.67 Singapore cent, and the company declared a final cash dividend of 1.05 Singapore cent per share. Revenue gained 4% to S$92.8 million, with hotel investments revenue declining due to Thailand hotel sales and the disposal of the Seychelles hotel. The company expects to open seven new resorts and launch eight spas in the next 12 months.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on Thursday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Thursday due to US Chief Trade Negotiator Robert Lighthizer's comments that "much still needs to be done" on US-China trade negotiations, sparking market pessimism. The Nikkei 225 index slipped 0.44% to 21,462.08, while the Topix index fell 0.40%. The downturn follows a rally in Singapore stocks and a record close for the S&P 500 and Nasdaq in the US.

site_title: Best World rises 1.19% after results release
summary: Best World International shares rose 1.19% after releasing fourth-quarter results, with a net profit of S$28.1 million, a 28.9% increase from the same period last year. Revenue surged 78.6% to S$127.7 million, driven by sales of premium skincare products in China. The company proposed a dividend of five Singapore cents per share, up from 2.6 cents per share last year. Analysts expressed confidence in the company's franchisee model and willingness to engage professionals to ensure regulatory compliance.

site_title: Sitra to jointly develop Bintan resort project in deal with CEO's family
summary: Sitra Holdings (International) will acquire a 54% stake in Mapur Rocky Resort, a Bintan resort in Indonesia, from the family of CEO George Chew for S$3.51 million. The deal includes a call-and-put option agreement that could raise an additional S$2.81 million for Sitra. The acquisition aims to diversify Sitra's business and improve financial performance, as its core business has been loss-making since 2008. The deal requires shareholders' approval due to its interested-person nature.

site_title: Women granted only three quarters of men's legal rights: World Bank
summary: The World Bank found that women globally hold only three-quarters of the legal rights enjoyed by men, hindering job opportunities and business ownership. Despite progress, 2.7 billion women are still barred from equal job choices. The 2019 study, based on 187 countries, showed a 5-point increase in the gender disparities index from 70 to 75. 131 countries have enacted reforms, with 6 nations scoring a perfect 100, and the Middle-East and North Africa posting the lowest score of 47.37.

site_title: Singapore shares decline at Thursday's open; STI down 0.11% to 3,246.50
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index declined 0.11% to 3,246.50 at open on Thursday, following weak opens in Australia and Japan amid US-China trade talks. Gainers outnumbered losers 61-48, with Singtel advancing 0.3% and Thomson Medical rising 1.3%. Active index stocks included OCBC Bank down 0.6% and DBS Group Holdings up 0.2%. The decline comes despite a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data and amid mixed global market sentiment.

site_title: Novo Tellus subscribes for 6.4% stake in ISDN at S$0.20 per share
summary: Novo Tellus, a private equity fund, has agreed to invest S$5.3 million in ISDN Holdings, a precision and motion control engineering firm, by subscribing for 27 million new shares at S$0.20 per share. The investment represents a 6.4% stake in ISDN's enlarged share capital. Novo Tellus aims to finance ISDN's growth strategy in Asia's advanced manufacturing and clean energy sectors, and the investment is expected to close in April. The deal will see Novo Tellus take a seat on ISDN's board.

site_title: CPF Board and SIM get new chief executives
summary: The Central Provident Fund Board (CPF Board) and Singapore Institute of Management (SIM) are set to receive new chiefs. Augustin Lee, deputy secretary of the Ministry of Manpower, will become the new CEO of the CPF Board on April 1, replacing Ng Chee Peng. Seah Chin Siong will start as the new president and CEO of SIM on May 1, taking over from his current role at Singapore Pools. Both appointments aim to enhance digital transformation and engagement with members.

site_title: MindChamps Q4 profit rises 67%
summary: MindChamps Preschool reported a 67% increase in fourth-quarter net profit to S$3.7 million, driven by growth in international student numbers and franchise development. Earnings per share rose to 1.52 Singapore cents, up from 1.18 cents a year earlier. Shares closed at 56 Singapore cents, up 2.78% or two Singapore cents.

site_title: Air New Zealand interim profit takes a nosedive as demand falls
summary: Air New Zealand reported a 34% decline in interim net profit to NZ$152 million for the six months to December 31, due to high fuel prices and falling domestic demand. The airline attributed the decline to slowing domestic growth, similar to other developed markets. Air New Zealand is reviewing its operations, including network, fleet, and cost base, with an update expected by March. Despite this, operating revenue increased 7.1% to NZ$2.9 billion, and the airline reaffirmed a full-year earnings before tax estimate of NZ$340-400 million.

site_title: Luxury watchmaker Philippe Charriol killed in car accident
summary: French luxury watchmaker Philippe Charriol, founder of the eponymous brand, was killed in a car accident at the Le Castellet racing track in southeast France on February 27, 2019. Charriol, 77, received emergency treatment but succumbed to his injuries. The company, based in Geneva, has a global presence of 285 shops and 3,800 sales points. Charriol was a racing enthusiast and had frequently attended major racing circuits. He founded the brand in 1983, specializing in luxury watches and jewelry.

site_title: Japan's factory output posts biggest fall in a year, outlook sags
summary: Japan's factory output declined 3.7% in January, the largest drop in a year, as slowing Chinese demand and the Sino-US trade war took a toll on the country's manufacturing sector. This marks the third straight month of contraction, with manufacturers expecting a 5.0% rebound in February but a 1.6% decrease in March. The Ministry of Economy, Trade and Industry described the output as "stalling," raising concerns about economic growth. The decline in factory output is attributed to a sharp drop in demand from China due to the trade war, which has cost both countries billions of dollars.

site_title: Hong Leong Finance full-year profit up 38.1% to S$118.3m on higher net interest income
summary: Hong Leong Finance reported a 38.1% increase in full-year net profit to S$118.3 million, driven by higher net interest income. Earnings per share rose to 26.56 Singapore cents. The company also recommended a final dividend of 10 Singapore cents per share, up from 9 cents previously. Net interest income grew 20.9% to S$212.1 million, while loans and advances increased 3.1% to S$10.3 billion. Despite expected growth momentum to wane in 2019, Hong Leong Finance remains cautiously optimistic about growth due to strong domestic demand.

site_title: MPs back May's new Brexit strategy as EU warns of delay conditions
summary: British MPs voted 502-20 to support Prime Minister Theresa May's new Brexit strategy, which includes giving her more time to work on her EU withdrawal deal if necessary. EU leaders warned that any delay would come with conditions, while French President Emmanuel Macron expressed skepticism about the plan's effectiveness. The UK government has promised to delay Brexit if necessary, but opposition parties, including Labour, have expressed concerns about the potential for a "no deal" Brexit and are pushing for alternative options, including a second referendum.

site_title: Trump ex-lawyer has no proof of Russia collusion but 'suspicions'
summary: Michael Cohen, Trump's former lawyer, testified before Congress that he has no direct evidence of Russia collusion, but "suspicions" about his former boss's involvement. Cohen provided examples of dealings between Trump and Moscow during the 2016 campaign, including a June meeting with Russians offering "dirt" on Hillary Clinton. Cohen claims Trump had advance knowledge of the meeting and directed negotiations for a Trump Tower in Moscow, despite denying business ties with Russia. His testimony contradicts Trump's denials of collusion and raises suspicions about the Trump campaign's ties to Russia.

site_title: New tech taking telemedicine to the next level
summary: New technologies are revolutionizing telemedicine by allowing doctors to remotely monitor patients' vital signs, perform X-rays, and assist with operations from hundreds of miles away. Companies such as Health for Humanity and Forrester predict that virtual visits to healthcare providers will surpass in-person visits by the end of 2020. The arrival of 5G wireless networks enables real-time guidance and reduces latency, paving the way for remote surgeries and improved healthcare outcomes, particularly in developing nations.

site_title: Surprising slide in 4Q construction spending in Australia
summary: Construction spending in Australia declined 3.1% in the December quarter, missing forecasts of a 0.4% gain, and marking the second straight quarter of sharp falls. Home building was a major drag, with residential construction sinking 3.6% and the outlook for more pain as approvals for new building have tumbled. The Reserve Bank of Australia's growth forecast is now at risk, with economists warning of a struggling economy.

site_title: Oil rises 2% as US crude stocks plunge, Opec brushes off Trump
summary: Oil prices rose 2% on Wednesday after US crude inventories unexpectedly plummeted 8.6 million barrels, defying expectations of an increase. Saudi Arabia's Energy Minister Khalid al-Falih stated that Opec is taking a "very slow and measured approach" to production cuts, despite US President Donald Trump's tweet urging the group to "relax" on production cuts. US crude futures rose to $56.94 a barrel, while Brent crude futures rose to $66.39 a barrel, the largest daily percentage rise in nearly four weeks.

site_title: Steel, aluminum tariffs holding up trade deal ratification: Canada official
summary: Canada is delaying ratification of the US-Mexico-Canada Agreement due to ongoing steel and aluminum tariffs imposed by the US. A senior Canadian official warned that the tariffs make it difficult to ratify the deal, which is scheduled to be finalized before the current parliamentary session ends on June 6. Canadian lawmakers need to ratify the agreement before the general election in October. The US tariffs were imposed last year, citing national security concerns, and Canada is urging the US to remove them to move forward with the agreement.

images.alt_text: Canada stepped up pressure on Washington to remove steel and aluminum tariffs, warning on Wednesday that it won't ratify a continental trade deal while the irritant remains and that time was running out.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Influence: Kenneth Lou, CEO, Seedly
summary: Kenneth Lou, CEO of Seedly, discusses how users can track their personal finances by syncing their bank and credit card accounts to the personal Web app. This allows users to monitor their expenditure easily.

site_title: No more 'lucky' beards; Japan's sumo wrestlers hit by whisker ban
summary: Japan's sumo wrestlers face new grooming rules, including a ban on beards deemed "indecent" and long nails. The Japan Sumo Association has introduced stricter regulations to clean up the image of the sport, following scandals and controversies in recent years. The rules, effective immediately, also bar tattoos and prohibit officials and referees from seeing "unsightly" conditions. The move aims to restore the sport's image and preserve its "sacred" atmosphere.

site_title: Dozens buried in Indonesia gold mine collapse
summary: Dozens of people are believed to be trapped in an Indonesian gold mine that collapsed, killing at least three and leaving 14 survivors. The disaster occurred in North Sulawesi, where unstable soil conditions and steep terrain hindered rescue efforts. Local officials and environmentalists have called for stricter safety regulations and enforcement, citing a history of unlicensed mining sites and previous accidents. Rescuers continue to search for survivors, with hopes of finding more people alive.

site_title: Air strikes won't fix India's Pakistan problem
summary: India's airstrikes in Pakistan are unlikely to prevent future attacks in Kashmir or the ensuing need for retaliation, as the underlying issues remain unresolved. The strikes targeted a Jaish-e-Mohammed training camp but may not have significantly impacted the terrorist group's operations. India should instead adopt a sustained and sophisticated approach to pressure Pakistan, including a gentler approach towards Kashmir and leveraging international organizations such as the Financial Action Task Force to counter terrorist financing.

site_title: Europe: Shares snap 3-day winning streak as Beiersdorf, Air France sink
summary: European shares snapped a three-day winning streak, falling 0.3% amid growing India-Pakistan tensions and a warning from Beiersdorf that the consumer goods industry is in "turmoil". Air France-KLM suffered its worst day in over a decade after the Dutch government took a 14% stake in the airline. Beiersdorf also plummeted 9.8% after issuing a shock warning on its 2019 operating margins. Bayer was a bright spot, rising 4.2% after delivering better-than-expected results.

images.alt_text: European shares fell in early deals on Wednesday, snapping a three-day winning streak amid growing India-Pakistan tensions, and a warning from Beiersdorf hammered consumer staples stocks while Air France-KLM and Marks & Spencer sank.

site_title: Hong Leong Finance's net profit rises 38% to S$118m
summary: Hong Leong Finance reported a 38.1% increase in net profit to S$118.3 million for the fiscal year ended Dec 31, 2018, driven by a rise in net interest margin and loan growth. Net interest income rose 20.9% to S$212.1 million, while loans and advances increased 3.1% to S$10.3 billion. The group also paid out a final dividend of 10 Singapore cents per share. Despite expected weakening of the manufacturing sector in 2019, Hong Leong Finance remains cautiously optimistic about growth due to strong domestic demand.

site_title: Trump branded a 'conman' as ex-lawyer Cohen savages him in Congress
summary: In a dramatic congressional appearance, former Trump lawyer Michael Cohen called President Trump a "conman" and "inveterate liar" who engaged in possibly illegal conduct while in office. Cohen testified that Trump directed him to lie about hush payments to a porn actress, and that Trump knew in advance that WikiLeaks would publish emails stolen from Hillary Clinton's campaign. Despite no fresh evidence of collusion with Russia, Cohen's testimony drew a damning portrait of Trump as a morally corrupt figure who forces staff to lie for him and cares only about himself.

images.alt_text: Donald Trump's longtime lawyer Michael Cohen turned on his former boss in a dramatic congressional appearance on Wednesday, calling the US president a conman and inveterate liar who engaged in possibly illegal conduct while in office.

site_title: IHH to hold back snapping up assets after buyout binge
summary: IHH Healthcare, Asia's largest private hospital operator, is shifting focus from aggressive asset acquisition to building a stable platform in existing markets. Following a major buyout of Fortis Healthcare, CEO Tan See Leng said the company will prioritize integrating assets before making further acquisitions. Despite a significant acquisition, IHH's net profit jumped fourfold to RM509 million in the fourth quarter, driven by operational performance and foreign exchange gains. The company's net gearing stands at 0.10 times, with a cash position of RM7.8 billion.

site_title: Making AGMs more meaningful: the corporate edition
summary: Companies and their officers have a greater duty to provide a meaningful exchange at annual general meetings (AGMs) with shareholders. Recent changes to the Singapore Exchange Listing Rules and the Code of Corporate Governance emphasize the importance of open and cordial discussions, thorough preparation, and accessibility. Companies must ensure their directors are present and prepared, and the chairman takes charge to promote an atmosphere of openness and debate. Key changes include providing longer notice for meetings, avoiding peak periods, and providing necessary information for informed voting.

site_title: StanChart opens new 'human-centred' branch at Takashimaya
summary: Standard Chartered Bank has opened a new 'human-centred' branch at Takashimaya Shopping Centre in Singapore, featuring accessible service counters and automated deposit machines. The branch was designed based on staff and client interviews, prioritizing personable services amidst a preference for digital banking. The new facility aims to provide an efficient and convenient banking experience, complementing online and mobile services. The branch was attended by Standard Chartered executives, including CEO Bill Winters and regional CEO Judy Hsu.

site_title: US activist investor Elliott calls for Hyundai shareholder support
summary: US activist investor Elliott Management Corp urged Hyundai Mobis shareholders to vote for proposals for higher dividends and new board members, following the conglomerate's rejection of its demands. The proposal aims to transform governance and right-size the company's overcapitalized balance sheet. Hyundai Motor and Hyundai Mobis shares rose 5.3% and 3.8% respectively, as investors await the outcome of the upcoming shareholder meeting. Elliott's pressure led to Hyundai Motor's decision to drop a plan to overhaul its ownership structure last year, and the group is likely to present a revised restructuring plan in April or May.

site_title: Kim, Trump get down to business over North Korean nukes
summary: US President Donald Trump and North Korean leader Kim Jong Un held formal summit talks in Hanoi, aiming to break the deadlock over Pyongyang's nuclear programme. The two leaders displayed signs of an unlikely diplomatic bromance, but analysts warn that the talks need to produce more substance than their initial historic meeting in Singapore. Trump vowed to help North Korea achieve its economic potential, while Kim sought relief from sanctions and security guarantees. The talks focused on denuclearization, with possible outcomes including the declaration of an end to the Korean War and the destruction of North Korea's Yongbyon nuclear complex.

site_title: US: Stocks end mostly down as health insurers slump
summary: US stocks ended the day mostly lower, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average dropping 0.3% to 25,985.16. The S&P 500 slipped 0.1% to 2,792.38, while the Nasdaq Composite Index edged up 0.1% to 7,554.51. Health insurers fell, with UnitedHealth Group and Humana losing nearly 5% each, after a "Medicare for all" bill was introduced. Meanwhile, Best Buy surged 14.1% after reporting better-than-expected fourth quarter profits. Analysts attribute the market's pause to a retreat after nearly two months of strong gains.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Golden Agri-Resources' Q4 earnings reversed into the red, with a FY2018 core net loss of US$91.3 million, significantly below expectations. The company expects earnings to recover in 2019 after an extremely weak 2018, with a focus on aggressive replanting and cost management. Meanwhile, Koufu Group is maintained as a "Buy" with a target price of S$0.80, driven by strong cashflow generation and defensive earnings.

site_title: Spain probes North Korea embassy incident
summary: Spain is investigating an incident at the North Korean embassy in Madrid, where people allegedly broke in, tied up and gagged employees, and stole computers. The incident occurred near the embassy, with mild injuries reported to a North Korean citizen. The embassy has not filed an official complaint, and the investigation is ongoing.

site_title: Twitter to liaise with India's election body ahead of polls
summary: Twitter plans to hire an officer to liaise with India's Election Commission ahead of the general elections in May, following concerns about political misuse of social media. The company's global head of public policy, Colin Crowell, said Twitter is committed to ensuring a free and fair vote. Twitter is also hiring a country head for India and has committed to investing in personnel and platform improvements. The move comes as India steps up scrutiny of social media firms to curb fake news and prevent foreign interference in the election.

site_title: US consumer regulator forms task force to monitor big tech
summary: The Federal Trade Commission (FTC) has formed a task force to monitor big tech companies, including Alphabet's Google and Facebook, for anticompetitive conduct. The task force will consult on tech-related merger reviews and investigations, with 17 staff attorneys. FTC Chairman Joe Simons said the goal is to ensure consumers benefit from free and fair competition. The move comes amid pressure to investigate anticompetitive behavior, including Facebook's alleged violation of a 2011 consent decree. The task force's creation may lead to unwinding of consummated deals if anticompetitive behavior is found.

site_title: Short-term rental platforms move to enforce rental caps in France
summary: Short-term rental platforms, including Airbnb, TripAdvisor, and HomeAway, have implemented a measure to enforce rental caps in France, where 18 cities have limited rentals to 120 days per year. The platforms now disable booking calendars after the 120-day limit is reached, preventing homeowners from renting out properties beyond the allowed period. This measure aims to combat issues such as rising rents, housing shortages, and cultural authenticity loss. The rule applies to most cities, except those with second homes or room leases.

site_title: Session of two halves ends with STI dip
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) closed 11.64 points lower at 3,250.02, despite a positive start to the session, as escalating tensions between India and Pakistan led to a midday dip. The market saw a mix of gains and losses, with the Jardine group and Sembcorp Marine among the top performers. The oil-price rebound helped Sembcorp Marine outperform the benchmark index, while Venture Corp and Best World International also saw significant gains.

site_title: Bobblehead museum in Wisconsin draws nods of approval
summary: A new National Bobblehead Hall of Fame and Museum in Milwaukee, Wisconsin, has opened its doors, showcasing the world's largest collection of over 6,500 bobbleheads. The museum, founded by Phil Sklar and Brad Novak, features a diverse range of bobbleheads from sports, pop culture, history, and politics, including rare and unique figures. Visitors can explore the exhibits, take part in scavenger hunts, and even purchase custom bobbleheads. The museum aims to educate and entertain, with its unique blend of nostalgia and fun.

site_title: Flights axed, diverted as India-Pakistan tensions soar
summary: India and Pakistan have escalated tensions, with numerous flights cancelled or diverted due to airspace closures by both countries. Pakistan shot down two Indian Air Force planes, while India claimed to have downed a Pakistani fighter jet. The air traffic disruption affects Western holiday routes, with several airlines suspending services to Pakistan. The situation has been eased by Pakistan's Prime Minister Imran Khan's call for talks with India, warning of a catastrophe if the conflict escalates. China has also urged restraint and dialogue between the two nuclear-armed rivals.

site_title: Haw Par to dole out bumper S$1.15 a share in dividends for FY2018
summary: Haw Par Corporation, the company behind Tiger Balm, is proposing a special dividend of 85 cents per share to mark its 50th anniversary. The one-time payout aims to reward shareholders for their support over the years.

site_title: No end in sight to Brexit brinksmanship
summary: Theresa May announced a potential Brexit extension to the end of June, allowing the UK to consider an Article 50 extension if her withdrawal deal is rejected in a second meaningful vote by March 12. This move comes as opposition leader Jeremy Corbyn signals support for a second Brexit referendum if May's softer Brexit stance is not adopted. The UK Parliament is likely to reject a "no-deal" Brexit, and an extension of Article 50 is possible, with the EU-27 potentially offering concessions on the Irish backstop to avoid a chaotic "no-deal" Brexit.

site_title: China plans new state pipeline firm in massive energy reshuffle
summary: China plans to form a national oil and gas pipeline group, combining the long-distance pipeline assets of state-owned energy companies. The move, approved by the National Development and Reform Commission, aims to remove a key bottleneck in the market and allow producers and consumers equal access to infrastructure. The new entity will be the fourth state-controlled energy company, alongside Sinopec, PetroChina, and China National Offshore Oil Corp. The plan is seen as the largest energy market reshuffle in two decades, with PetroChina, which controls 70% of China's oil pipelines, expected to be impacted the most.

site_title: Dublin cashes in on Brexit jitters
summary: Dublin is emerging as a new financial hub due to Brexit uncertainty, with 27 firms committing to relocate staff or operations to the city since 2016. Barclays and Bank of America Merrill Lynch have already set up new offices, and Hermes Investment Management is planning to expand its operations. Ireland's low corporate tax rate, English-speaking EU status, and proximity to London make it an attractive destination for financial firms. The city's "Brexit dividend" is seen as a welcome boost to the country's economy, with the Irish government positioning itself as a solution for UK firms facing Brexit difficulties.

site_title: Malaysia's flying car plan sparks flood of mockery
summary: Malaysia plans to launch a flying car prototype later this year, using local technology and costing RM1 million (S$331,300) to develop. The vehicle will fly at low altitudes, but the project has sparked mockery, with many questioning its feasibility and wisdom, given the country's struggling automotive industry and lack of success with previous car projects. Critics have also expressed skepticism about the project's viability, with some calling it a "harebrained scheme" and a waste of resources.

site_title: Yen, Swiss franc gain after Pakistan shoots down Indian jets
summary: Pakistan's downing of two Indian jets led to a surge in the Japanese yen and Swiss franc, with investors seeking safer assets amid heightened tensions. The yen reached a 110.355 level, its strongest since February 15, while the Swiss franc hit a three-week high of 0.9967 against the US dollar. Investors also kept an eye on the US dollar, which hovered near a three-week low, and the euro, which moved higher to a three-week high of US$1.1399. The US-North Korea summit also drew attention, with investors watching for developments in the nuclear talks.

site_title: Green energy back in vogue in South Africa amid state utility woes
summary: South Africa's state electricity utility, Eskom, faces financial struggles and plans to split into generation, transmission, and distribution units to improve efficiency. The government is courting independent renewable energy producers to meet demand, citing falling costs and environmental considerations. Renewable energy companies are skeptical due to past stalling of projects, but experts believe the outlook is improving. The government aims to achieve 24,370 megawatts of generating capacity from wind, natural gas, solar, and hydropower plants by 2030, with the tumbling cost of renewable energy making it more attractive.

site_title: Spring ... into fashion, books, dining, adventure
summary: Fashion brands unveil their spring lineups, focusing on investment pieces, vintage-inspired bags, and "casual couture." Ermenegildo Zegna's artistic director Alessandro Sartori discusses his vision of "casual couture" in luxury menswear. Meanwhile, independent chefs minimize food waste by upcycling leftovers into haute cuisine. Adventure traveller Kenneth Koh shares his account of hiking the Pacific Crest Trail. The Singapore International Festival of Arts and Singapore Design Week highlight the impact of design on daily life.

site_title: Vietnamese carriers sign US$21b in deals with US firms
summary: US President Donald Trump met with top Vietnamese leaders in Hanoi, where three Vietnamese carriers, Vietnam Air, Vietjet, and Bamboo Airways, signed $21 billion in aviation deals with US firms. Deals include 100 Boeing 737 jets worth $12.7 billion, 10 787 Dreamliners, and maintenance contracts. The deals are expected to support over 83,000 American jobs and provide increased safety for Vietnamese travelers. The agreements come ahead of Trump's summit with North Korea's Kim Jong Un.

site_title: French vineyards say they are ready to end glyphosate addiction
summary: French vineyards aim to end their reliance on glyphosate, a widely used weedkiller considered "probably cancerogenic" by the World Health Organization. President Emmanuel Macron has challenged the industry to stop using the herbicide faster than anyone else, with 80% of cases expected to transition by 2020. Many winemakers acknowledge the need to move away from glyphosate, citing growing demand for natural and organic food and wine, but warn that without state aid, the transition may be slower.

site_title: Rivals out in force to woo remisiers on news of DBS Vickers' revamp
summary: Four leading brokerages in Singapore, PhillipCapital, OCBC Securities, CGS CIMB Securities, and UOB Kay Hian, are actively recruiting remisiers and dealers who will be affected by DBS Vickers' transfer of retail equity trading to the bank by year-end. The brokerages are offering referral schemes and promising to build up their sales forces, with some promising higher salaries and referral fees. The move has sparked public support for the remisiers, with some arguing that they still play a vital role in the securities market and are not merely order-takers.

site_title: Fiat Chrysler plans Michigan investment with 6,500 jobs
summary: Fiat Chrysler Automobiles plans a $4.5 billion investment over three years to update Detroit plants and create 6,500 new jobs. The company will retool an engine plant to produce Jeeps and update several plants to make the Jeep Grand Cherokee and other SUVs. This move aims to capitalize on the growing demand for SUVs, despite forecasted declines in US vehicle sales. Fiat Chrysler also plans to cut 1,400 jobs at an Illinois plant. The company's CEO, Mike Manley, is confident in the US economy's growth prospects.

site_title: Golden Agri back in the black in Q4 with US$79.3m net profit
summary: Golden Agri-Resources (GAR) posted a net profit of US$79.3 million in Q4 2018, reversing a loss of US$29.1 million in the same period the previous year. A stronger palm and laurics business offset lower crude palm oil prices. Revenue declined 14.1% to US$1.65 billion, while underlying profit sank 28.8%. The company expects demand growth for crude palm oil to remain stable, supported by global food and energy demand. GAR proposed a final dividend of 0.58 Singapore cent per share.

site_title: Both leaders say they expect talks to be successful
summary: US President Donald Trump and North Korean leader Kim Jong Un met for a second summit in Vietnam, with both leaders expressing optimism about the talks' success. Trump said he expected a "very successful" outcome and was not "walking back" on denuclearization, while Kim praised Trump's "courageous decision" to begin dialogue.
