The two leaders will hold a series of meetings on Thursday, with no venue announced. Trump has indicated a more flexible stance on denuclearization, offering sanctions relief if North Korea takes "meaningful" steps.

site_title: The shrinking stock market and remisiers
summary: A Singaporean letter writer warns that the shrinking stock market and decline of remisiers are interconnected issues, with the latter being a result of the former. The writer argues that a healthy securities market is crucial for allocating risk capital to deserving companies, promoting entrepreneurship, and generating value-add to the economy. He criticizes the government for not taking proactive steps to preserve or strengthen the securities industry, which has led to the disappearance of stockbroking and securities houses, and the subsequent decline of the stock market.

site_title: Hong Kong hands out reliefs as Q4 growth halves due to trade war
summary: Hong Kong's fiscal year 2019/20 budget was unveiled with a less expansionary plan, amid economic uncertainty and trade tensions. Annual growth halved in the fourth quarter to 1.3%, the weakest since 2016, and the outlook for the financial hub remains clouded. Relief measures include waived business registration fees and tax cuts, while increased spending on public hospitals and healthcare coupons were announced. The government also maintained cooling measures for the property market, despite concerns of rising prices.

site_title: Singtel snags Axiata e-wallet for regional payments network
summary: Singtel has acquired Boost Malaysia's e-wallet for its regional payments network, VIA. Boost's 3.7 million customers and 66,000 merchant outlets will be able to transact with other wallets in the VIA alliance. This partnership gives Singtel presence in a new market and expands its cross-border mobile payments capabilities. Arthur Lang, Singtel's international group chief, stated that the deal "gives us presence in an important new market" and shows potential for growth in cross-border mobile payments.

site_title: Restoring an avenue in Paris meant for kings
summary: Paris is investing millions of dollars in renovations to the Champs-Élysées, a historic avenue built for royalty, ahead of the 2024 Olympics. The area, once cluttered with cars and abandoned scooters, is being revitalized with new retail tenants, including Apple and WeWork, and historic monument restorations. The project aims to re-establish the Champs-Élysées as a world-class destination, but faces challenges in balancing commercial activity with local character, as the area is known for its high rents and strict regulations.

site_title: Developers re-issuing options amid cooling market, launch bonanza
summary: Developers in Singapore are re-issuing options for private housing units that lapsed due to the cooling market. In December, two-thirds of options sold by developers expired without being exercised, distorting the reported sales figure. This practice, known as "returned units" or "lapsed options," has been observed since July's cooling measures. Developers are re-issuing options to give buyers more time to secure financing, while also locking in buyers and maintaining sales momentum. The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) is adjusting its data releases to account for these lapsed options, aiming for more accurate market data.

site_title: Wingardium Leviosa! Harry Potter magic helps Lego lift sales
summary: Lego reported a 3% increase in global sales and a 4% rise in total revenue to 36.4 billion Danish crowns in 2018, ending a decade-long decline. The company credited Harry Potter and Star Wars building sets, as well as strong sales in China, for the growth. China's double-digit growth was driven by plans to open 140 new stores this year, while the US and Western Europe saw low-single digit growth. Lego aims to expand its presence in new markets, including India, and remains committed to physical stores to provide children with a "magic experience."

site_title: HKEX sets profit record after IPOs and turnover surge
summary: Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing (HKEX) reported a 26% surge in net profit to HK$9.31 billion in 2018, beating analyst estimates, driven by fees from mega IPOs, clearing fees, and strong trading. The exchange operator revised its listing regime to increase competitiveness, allowing IPOs by companies with dual-class share structures and biotech startups without revenue. HKEX's revenue from listing fees rose 63% and trading fees rose 64%, with trading turnover hitting a record high. The exchange will announce a three-year strategy to broaden its focus and continue transforming into a leading global exchange.

site_title: Market decline drags CPFIS-included funds into losses in 2018
summary: Singapore's CPFIS-included funds experienced losses in 2018, with unit trusts posting a 9% decline and investment-linked products down 7.27%. The fourth quarter showed a negative 7.45% average return, the worst since 2011. Despite this, three-year cumulative returns were positive, with unit trusts generating 12.39% and ILPs 11.67%. Uncertainty over global growth and trade tensions contributed to the market decline, but recent market trends suggest a reversal, with year-to-date returns for the S&P 500, MSCI World, and Asia ex-Japan index at 11.45%, 11%, and 10.3%, respectively.

site_title: Remisiers have multiple value-added roles before, after share transactions
summary: DBS is set to merge retail equities trading into the bank by year-end, contrary to the misconception that remisiers are "middlemen" and "slowly becoming a dying breed." Remisiers have evolved into value-added professionals, offering financial products, acting as private bankers, and managing risk for clients. Despite DBS Vickers' plan to phase out its remisier pool, four brokerages have placed recruiting notices for remisiers, highlighting their ongoing demand. The remisier profession has proven resilient, with a rare entrepreneurial spirit that will enable it to continue thriving.

site_title: Singapore fintech startup Rely raises seven-figure pre-series A funding
summary: Singapore fintech startup Rely has raised a seven-figure pre-series A funding led by Goldbell Financial Services, with additional investors from Singapore's Octava and the financial and technology sectors. The funds will be used for regional expansion, team scaling, and supporting retail partnerships. Rely's "buy now pay later" service has seen a 20-40% increase in conversion rates and order values, particularly among millennials, who make up 75% of transactions. The startup partners with e-commerce retailers like Zalora and Zilingo, aiming to cater to millennials' spending habits.

site_title: Jardine C&C's underlying net profit climbs 11.4%
summary: Jardine C&C's underlying net profit rose 11.4% to US$858 million in its full financial year, driven by higher revenue from its majority stake in Indonesian conglomerate Astra International. Revenue increased 9.5% to US$18.99 billion, with Astra's businesses contributing US$719 million to the group's underlying profit. However, the group also reported net non-trading losses of US$438 million. The company raised its dividend per share to 87 US cents and announced changes to its board, including the retirement of a director and the appointment of a new independent director.

site_title: Splicing innovation into corporate DNA
summary: Companies must balance innovation and efficiency to compete in today's globalized world. A structured approach is needed to seed an innovation mindset into their DNA, combining infrastructure and culture. This involves setting up innovation hubs, rethinking performance indicators, and promoting an experimental culture. Successful companies like Fujifilm, Keppel Integrated Engineering, and Zhenhua Heavy Industries have built innovation into their DNA by embracing experimentation and failure. To achieve sustainable innovation, companies must acquire the skills of startups and think like entrepreneurs, with frameworks such as DBS Bank's pre-accelerator programme and Viki Inc's crowdsourced translation services.

images.alt_text: Singapore-based DBS Bank launched a pre-accelerator programme with the explicit purpose of developing the entrepreneurial ecosystem not only inside the bank but also in the region. This programme exists in addition to their innovation hub and permeates all departments.

site_title: Has China replaced the kowtow with a red carpet?
summary: China's foreign policy has shifted from a hierarchical approach to a more equal one, as evidenced by its acceptance of nations' sovereignty and participation in global organizations. However, this notion is not reflected in its behavior, particularly in questioning the universality of human rights and the Universal Declaration of Human Rights. This apparent disparity suggests that China's actions continue to prioritize its own interests, even if it claims to accept the equality of other nations.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: M1 telco has lost its free float and will be delisted after its voluntary conditional general offer closes on March 18. China Everbright Water submitted draft application proofs for a Hong Kong dual listing, while Alliance Mineral Assets' CFO Shaun Menezes resigned to pursue other opportunities. Perennial Real Estate Holdings appointed Khoo Chow Huat as chief operating officer in China, replacing Liak Teng Lit.

site_title: MAS: Current settings for exchange rate still 'appropriate'
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has maintained its monetary policy, citing an appropriate trade-weighted exchange rate and a slowdown in GDP growth to 2.5% this year. Managing Director Ravi Menon expects inflation to remain within the central bank's forecast range of 1.5-2.5%. The MAS is also exercising patience and flexibility due to global growth uncertainties, but warns of potential risks from high leverage in various economies.

site_title: Tax cuts should boost India real estate demand, but problems persist
summary: India's tax cut on under-construction residential houses is expected to boost home sales, with a 7% reduction in sales tax to 5% for non-affordable projects and 1% for affordable housing. However, developers worry that the relief will be short-lived due to a funding crunch, which could hinder their ability to recover from losses. The tax cut aims to alleviate the housing sector's struggles, but more measures are needed to address the underlying issues. The impact of the tax cut remains to be seen, and its effectiveness in reviving demand in the Indian real estate market is uncertain.

site_title: Bombardier to expand Singapore service centre by 2020
summary: Bombardier is investing S$85 million to expand its Singapore service centre by 2020, quadrupling its space to 40,000 sq m. The centre will employ up to 300 staff and support over 2,000 visits annually. The expansion is driven by growing demand for business aviation in Asia and will include a paint facility, advanced interior finishing, and component repair services. The investment is expected to add to the vibrancy of Seletar Aerospace Park, solidifying Singapore's position as an aerospace hub in the Asia-Pacific region.

images.alt_text: Canadian aerospace giant Bombardier is investing S$85 million to quadruple its Singapore service centre to 40,000 sq m by 2020, the company announced at a groundbreaking ceremony on Wednesday.

site_title: Impact of diesel tax hike, foreign labour leads debate
summary: Singapore MPs debated the impact of a diesel tax hike and tightening of foreign manpower quotas on businesses, particularly small and medium-sized enterprises. Concerns were raised about the lack of warning and the potential "domino effect" of rising prices across the economy. MPs also questioned the government's decision to reduce the dependency ratio ceiling for the healthcare sector, which could impact voluntary welfare organizations and hospitals. The government maintained its stance on foreign manpower policy, stating that it will monitor the situation and adjust the employment pass criteria as local wages rise.

site_title: CapitaLand closes real estate debt fund with 75% of capital raised
summary: CapitaLand has closed its real estate debt fund, Credo I China, with 75% of its target capital of $750 million raised, exceeding initial expectations. The fund will invest in offshore US dollar-denominated subordinated instruments for real estate in China's first- and second-tier cities, focusing on loans and securities of high-quality properties. With a 10% stake, CapitaLand is poised to be one of China's largest real estate debt funds. The fund's launch comes at a time of increased credit availability and reduced borrowing costs in China, with the fund expected to add to CapitaLand's business in the country.

site_title: US pending home sales increase 4.6% in January
summary: US pending home sales increased 4.6% in January to a reading of 103.2, surpassing economists' forecast of a 0.4% rise. This indicates a moderate improvement in the housing market, but existing home sales fell to their lowest level in over three years, and house prices rose modestly. Compared to the same period last year, pending sales were down 2.3%. The increase in pending home sales suggests a potential rebound in the housing market, but overall market conditions remain cautious.

site_title: Marks & Spencer seals deal with partner for full online food delivery
summary: Marks & Spencer (M&S) has agreed to a joint venture with online supermarket Ocado, buying a 50% share of Ocado's UK retail business for up to £750m. This deal will give M&S a full online food delivery service for the first time. The partnership aims to expand M&S' online presence and provide customers with a wider range of food options.

site_title: Malaysia's AirAsia falls to first quarterly loss since 2015 as fuel costs rise
summary: Malaysia's AirAsia reported its first quarterly loss in over three years, with a net loss of 395 million ringgit (S$130.8 million) in the fourth quarter. Higher fuel costs, operating lease expenses, and lower passenger load factor contributed to the loss. Revenue grew 6.2% to 2.82 billion ringgit, driven by a 16% increase in total passengers carried. AirAsia aims to boost revenue by selling more travel services on its website and has signed a memorandum of cooperation with Vietnamese partners to set up a low-cost carrier.

site_title: Much to be done on China trade: US Trade Rep Lighthizer
summary: US Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer said there is still much to be done in reaching a new trade agreement with China, despite "real progress" made in negotiations. The US has accused China of unfair trade practices, including state intervention and subsidies, while China has offered to increase purchases of American farm goods and energy exports. A new agreement is uncertain, and analysts say fundamental changes in China's industrial policy could weaken the communist party's power.

site_title: Warren Buffett joins the crowd struggling to understand Oracle
summary: Warren Buffett, billionaire investor, expressed his difficulty in understanding Oracle Corp's cloud transition efforts, despite owning a $2.1 billion stake in the company. Oracle's limited financial disclosures make it hard for investors to grasp the company's progress, with analysts citing the need for more granular data points. Buffett cited Amazon and Microsoft's success in cloud computing, but acknowledged he doesn't fully comprehend the business. Analysts believe Oracle's cloud success is uncertain, particularly in its database division, which is the company's key source of profits.

site_title: Local barramundi farm scales up with S$2m nursery extension
summary: Barramundi Asia, a Singaporean fish farm, has expanded its operations with a S$2 million nursery extension, increasing its fish production threefold to almost 1.8 million fish per year. The farm now has 1,200 sq m more space and eight giant tanks, raising its production capacity to 150,000 fish a month. The expansion aims to boost Singapore's domestic food security and reduce dependence on imports. The farm plans to implement new technologies, including automation, to achieve cost reduction and economy of scale.

site_title: Timely to diversify Singapore's funding sources for major infrastructure
summary: Singapore's government has decided to borrow to partly fund long-term infrastructure investments, despite a slowing global economy and trade tensions, to diversify funding sources. This move is seen as timely and financially prudent, as it allows the government to tap into private financing and reduce borrowing costs. The decision may also boost the domestic capital market and commercial lending space, potentially leading to more green and social loan products. Singapore's structurally robust fiscal position and triple A rating by international rating agencies make it well-positioned to handle the added debt.

site_title: India builds bunkers to protect families along Pakistan border
summary: India is building over 14,000 family shelters along its border with Pakistan in the Kashmir region, aiming to keep families safe from artillery shells. The move comes after a recent escalation of tensions, including Pakistan's shelling of Indian villages and India's retaliatory airstrikes. The shelters, costing up to $60 million, are designed to withstand shelling and are being constructed in villages near the Line of Control. The initiative aims to reduce fear and prevent families from fleeing their homes, which have seen frequent exchanges of fire in recent months.

site_title: Volvo's Polestar joins electric car race with rival to Tesla 3
summary: Volvo's luxury performance brand Polestar has unveiled its first fully electric sedan, the Polestar 2, priced at around $91,855 with a driving range of 275 miles. The car rivals Tesla's Model 3 and is cheaper than most electric models launched by traditional premium carmakers. Polestar aims to sell 50,000 units annually within two to three years, with production capacity dependent on market conditions. The car is initially sold in China, the US, Canada, and six European markets, with a planned Netflix-style subscription model for insurance and maintenance costs.

site_title: Pakistan state media publishes video of captured Indian pilot
summary: Pakistan state media has released a video showing a captured Indian fighter pilot being interrogated after his jet was shot down in Kashmir. The video, confirmed by two Pakistani security sources, shows the pilot identifying himself and refusing to disclose further information. Pakistan claims to have downed two Indian jets and captured two pilots, while India says only one plane was shot down. The Indian foreign ministry has demanded the safe return of the captured pilot, warning Pakistan against any harm to Indian defense personnel in its custody.

site_title: Reality bites in Vietnam's march towards privatisation
summary: Vietnam's government is proceeding slowly with its privatisation program, with only a few large-cap state-owned companies planning to stage initial public offerings (IPOs) or return to the market this year. Despite uncertainty and unpreparedness among major companies, optimism remains, with the government aiming to retain 100% ownership in sensitive sectors. Major SOEs slated for listing include Mobifone, Vietnam Posts and Telecommunications Group, and Agribank. The Vietnamese bourse is expected to remain the top market for IPOs in Southeast Asia, with a forecasted 7% economic growth and low valuations.

images.alt_text: Much is expected of the Vietnamese bourse, which became South-east Asia's top market for IPOs in 2018, said the consultancy EY. Vietnam took the honours by raising US$2.6 billion from just five IPOs, primarily because the government began pushing for the privatisation of state-owned enterprises (SOEs).

site_title: CPF Board names Augustin Lee CEO as Ng Chee Peng exits public service after 30 years
summary: The Central Provident Fund Board (CPF Board) has announced the departure of CEO Ng Chee Peng, who is stepping down after 30 years in the Singapore public service. Augustin Lee, deputy secretary of the Ministry of Manpower, will take over the role on April 1, 2019. During Ng's tenure, the CPF Board implemented policy initiatives to enhance members' retirement savings and experience, and led the board's digital transformation journey. Ng's leadership was praised by the Ministry of Manpower for providing greater assurance and improved services to CPF members.

site_title: Mirror image: Trump, Kim mind their body language with handshake of equals
summary: US President Donald Trump and North Korea's Kim Jong Un attempted to project a sense of rapport in their Hanoi meeting, using mirroring body language to show improved relations. Trump walked towards Kim with his palm upturned, while Kim extended his hand with confidence. Experts noted that Trump seemed to be taking a more conciliatory approach, while Kim appeared more familiar and at ease. Despite signs of tension, both leaders smiled only when expected to, suggesting a performance of their relationship. The two will hold meetings on Thursday to discuss a deal on the Korean peninsula's denuclearization.

site_title: Thomson Medical returns to profit, announces dividend
summary: Thomson Medical Group returned to profit in 2018, with a net profit of S$2.2 million, after a net loss of S$22.3 million in 2017. The company's healthcare revenue grew 7% to S$215.6 million, driven by hospital operations and specialized services. Thomson Medical announced a final special dividend of 0.025 cents per share and plans to use a potential S$750 million from maturing warrants to fund healthcare research and education. The company is also expanding into the digital space with its SmartParents platform and plans to roll out e-commerce and electronic medical records.

site_title: Indian, Pakistan markets rattled as Kashmir tensions rise
summary: Tensions between India and Pakistan have escalated, with both countries ordering air strikes and exchanging ground fire, marking the first time two nuclear-armed powers have done so. Indian and Pakistani shares fell, with the NSE index down 0.26% and the BSE index down 0.19%. Markets remain volatile, with foreign investors expected to trim their positions due to the uncertainty.

site_title: US goods trade deficit widens sharply in December
summary: The US goods trade deficit widened 12.8% to $79.5 billion in December, driven by slowing global demand and a strong dollar. Exports declined 2.8% and imports rose 2.4% in the same period. This data may prompt economists to cut fourth-quarter GDP estimates, currently around a 2.0% annualized rate. The delayed release of the advance December data due to the federal government shutdown may also impact future economic reports.

images.alt_text: The US goods trade deficit widened sharply in December as slowing global demand and a strong dollar weighed on exports, another sign that economic growth slowed in the fourth quarter.

site_title: Nearly 50% of transport pollution deaths linked to diesel: study
summary: A US study found that nearly 50% of transport pollution deaths worldwide, or approximately 385,000 people, were linked to diesel engines in 2015. Diesel vehicles were responsible for 47% of these deaths, with figures as high as 66% in France, Germany, Italy, and India. The study estimated that the global transportation sector caused 11% of 3.4 million premature deaths annually due to air pollution. The health burden from transport pollution costs the global economy $1 trillion annually, with the worst affected countries being China, India, and Germany.

site_title: Kampong Bahru Road shophouses up for sale
summary: A pair of freehold conservation shophouses at 69 and 71 Kampong Bahru Road in Singapore are up for sale with a guide price of S$13 million to S$13.65 million. The properties, with a total land area of 2,343 sq ft, are zoned "commercial" and offer strong capital and rental upside opportunities. Foreigners are eligible to buy, and there are no additional buyer's stamp duty or seller's stamp duty. The upper floor leases are on a year-to-year basis, allowing for potential owner-occupiers to acquire a prominent property. The expression of interest closes on April 4.

images.alt_text: The shophouses, which come with attics, have a guide price of S$13 million to S$13.65 million, or S$2,200 to S$2,300 psf.

site_title: India-Pakistan tensions send Singapore shares down 0.4% on Wednesday
summary: India-Pakistan tensions escalated on Wednesday, prompting a 0.4% decline in Singapore shares. The Straits Times Index closed at 3,250.02 after Pakistan shot down two Indian jets in its territory. Trading was heavy, with Pennies and KrisEnergy experiencing significant losses. However, Best World International shares rose 8.3% after posting a 28.9% increase in fourth-quarter net profit.

site_title: IHH Healthcare Q4 net profit jumps fivefold on forex gains
summary: IHH Healthcare, Asia's largest private hospital operator, reported a fivefold jump in Q4 net profit to RM509 million, driven by stronger operational performance and foreign exchange gains. Revenue improved 10% to RM3.17 billion, with earnings before interest, tax, depreciation, and amortization rising 18% to RM724 million. The company attributed the weaker full-year net profit to higher net forex losses, despite a record high profit after tax and minority interest of RM1.03 billion for the year.

site_title: South Korean golfers ready to rock at 'Asia's Major'
summary: The HSBC Women's World Championships, held at Sentosa's New Tanjong course, is set to tee off with 14 South Korean golfers among the 63 world's leading players. South Korea has dominated the event, winning it four times since its inception in 2008. This year, world No 4 So Yeon Ryu and other top South Korean players, including Inbee Park and Park Sung Hyun, are vying for the championship. With 13 South Koreans in the top 30, the country's chances of winning are high, but the field remains competitive with other top players, including Michelle Wie and Ariya Jutanugarn.

site_title: Nintendo to release two Pokemon titles for Switch console in late 2019
summary: Nintendo plans to release two Pokémon role-playing titles, "Pokémon Sword" and "Pokémon Shield", for its Switch console in late 2019. The games will feature new Pokémon, including Grookey and Scorbunny, and are expected to drive sales growth. The success of these titles will be crucial for the Switch console, following a 29% loss in Nintendo's value last year due to concerns about its appeal beyond hardcore gamers. The announcement comes as Nintendo's shares are up 7% this year and the company has recently announced a share buyback.

site_title: Axiata mobile wallet joins Singtel's e-payment network
summary: Singtel's e-payment network VIA has expanded with Axiata Digital's Boost Malaysia wallet, adding 3.7 million customers and 66,000 merchant outlets. Boost will join VIA alongside Singtel's Dash e-wallet and Thai telco AIS's Global Pay, allowing for cross-border payments between the three. The partnership aims to drive revenue growth for merchants and enhance regional e-payments.

site_title: M1 loses free float, to be delisted
summary: M1 Ltd. has lost its free float and will be delisted after the close of a voluntary conditional general offer. Konnectivity, owned by Keppel and Singapore Press Holdings (SPH), now controls 90.15% of the company's shares, with less than 10% held by the public. Axiata Group Bhd, a long-term shareholder, accepted the joint offer of S$2.06 per share for its entire stake of 28.6%.

site_title: Indian airlines halt service to north Indian cities amid tensions
summary: Indian airlines suspended flights to six cities in northern India due to airspace restrictions and airport closures amid escalating tensions with Pakistan. The airlines, including IndiGo and Jet Airways, cited Pakistani warplanes crossing the disputed border into Kashmir as the reason. The move followed an Indian airstrike on a militant camp in Pakistan the previous day. Several airports in Amritsar, Chandigarh, Dehradun, Jammu, Leh, and Srinagar were closed or suspended, with hundreds of passengers affected. The tensions between the two countries have raised the risk of conflict.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's services sector revenue grew 4.1% in Q4, easing from 7.2% in Q3. The country reported its slowest year-on-year economic growth in the fourth quarter and its biggest fall in exports and factory output in over two years. Axiata's mobile wallet joined Singtel's e-payment network, while NTUC's e2i plans to launch a survey to address skill gaps in the food and beverage industry. The Singapore market declined 0.4% due to escalating India-Pakistan tensions.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end with losses
summary: Hong Kong stocks ended lower on February 27, 2019, after Pakistan shot down two Indian jets, fueling fears of an escalating confrontation between the nuclear-armed neighbours. The Hang Seng Index declined 0.05% to 28,757.44, while the Shanghai Composite Index gained 0.42% and the Shenzhen Composite Index lost 0.57%. The losses reversed earlier gains as investors reacted to the heightened tensions.

site_title: Sri Lankan police drop case in discredited assassination plot
summary: Sri Lankan police have dropped a case against an Indian national, Marsili Thomas, over a discredited assassination plot against President Maithripala Sirisena due to lack of evidence. The plot led to the removal of the prime minister and parliament dissolution in November, which was later ruled unconstitutional and reversed in December. Thomas was arrested in September but will remain in custody for two weeks to face another allegation of overstaying his visa. The move brings an end to a political drama that had significant implications for Sri Lanka's government and international relations.

site_title: US: Wall St opens lower as Trump-Kim summit begins, India-Pakistan tensions flare
summary: US stocks opened lower on Wednesday as the second US-North Korean nuclear summit began, with the Dow Jones falling 62.38 points, or 0.24%, to 25,995.60. Tensions also flared between India and Pakistan. Meanwhile, Asia's markets continued their rally, with Singapore stocks rising 0.4% and the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edging to fresh records despite US trade uncertainty.

images.alt_text: US stocks opened slightly lower on Wednesday, as the second US-North Korean nuclear summit kicked off and tensions flared up between nuclear-armed neighbors India and Pakistan.

site_title: Kone to supply lifts, escalators for MRT system's Thomson-East Coast Line
summary: Kone has secured an order to supply 218 lifts and 183 escalators for stages four and five of Singapore's Thomson-East Coast Line MRT system and pedestrian overhead bridges. The contract, valued by Kone, includes lifts for nine new stations, three new Circle Line stations, and an upcoming multi-level complex. The works are expected to be completed by 2025.

site_title: UK approved to rejoin US$1.7t WTO procurement deal
summary: The UK has gained approval to rejoin a $1.7 trillion World Trade Organisation (WTO) procurement deal, allowing UK-based contractors to retain preferential access to foreign public procurement opportunities if Britain leaves the European Union without a withdrawal accord. The agreement, which includes 46 nations including the US and Japan, ensures the UK's £67 billion public procurement marketplace remains accessible. The UK's accession to the Government Procurement Agreement (GPA) will take effect 30 days after the UK government submits its instrument of acceptance to the WTO.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index fell 5.55 points to 1,713.45 on Wednesday, closing lower. Volume reached 2.2 billion lots worth RM2.1 billion, with losers outnumbering gainers 481 to 364.

site_title: Europe: Main stock markets fall at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets fell at the start of trading on Wednesday, with London's FTSE 100 index down 0.4% and the eurozone's DAX 30 and Paris CAC 40 indices also dropping 0.4%. The decline follows a five-day rally in Singapore stocks and comes as US-EU trade talks are in focus. Meanwhile, the S&P 500 and Nasdaq in the US edged to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty and the Fed's split views on interest rates.

site_title: Soilbuild remains in the red with S$4.1m Q4 net loss on arbitration payout
summary: Soilbuild Construction Group reported a net loss of S$4.1 million in Q4, widening from S$2.7 million in the previous year, due to higher cost of sales from an arbitration payout. Revenue surged 46.9% to S$78.2 million, and the group's order book stands at S$400.7 million. Despite the loss, Soilbuild expects the demand for construction activities to remain competitive, with efforts to tender for new projects and secure supply-and-delivery contracts.

site_title: Plastoform able to operate as going concern, company tells SGX
summary: Plastoform Holdings, an audio-speaker maker, stated that it believes it can operate as a going concern despite being in a negative equity position of HK$0.89 million and having negative working capital of HK$1.35 million as of December 31. The company is exploring fundraising options, including a rights issue exercise, and may borrow money if needed. It also expects its license business with Monster Inc to lead to new product types and brands in the future.

site_title: Pair of Kampong Bahru Road shophouses up for sale with S$13m to S$13.65m guide price
summary: A pair of freehold conservation shophouses at 69 and 71 Kampong Bahru Road in Singapore are up for sale with a guide price of S$13m to S$13.65m. The 2,343 sq ft properties have an estimated gross floor area of 5,947 sq ft and are zoned "commercial", allowing foreigners to buy. The shophouses are located within the Blair Plain Conservation Area and have leases to a convenience stall, pub, and office tenants. The sale presents a "compelling shophouses investment opportunity" with potential for strong capital and rental growth.

site_title: Stocks turn negative as India-Pakistan tensions worsen
summary: India-Pakistan tensions escalated, with Pakistan shooting down two Indian jets, prompting investors to flee riskier markets and seek safe-haven assets. Asian shares and US stock futures turned negative, while the yen gained. The US dollar hit a three-week low due to the Federal Reserve's "patient" policy approach. The news also weighed on European markets, with the euro and pound rising. The US-North Korea summit began, and oil futures rose slightly.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares end higher on dovish Fed chief
summary: Tokyo stocks ended higher on Wednesday, with the Nikkei 225 index adding 0.50% to 21,556.51, driven by dovish comments from Federal Reserve boss Jerome Powell. Investors welcomed the comments, which put Tokyo shares in higher ranges. Regional shares, including Chinese and Hong Kong markets, also rose, while the dollar fell to 110.51 yen. Notable gains were seen in Uniqlo operator Fast Retailing and Sony, while SoftBank Group and Toyota declined. The market's upward momentum was limited by a lack of fresh news, with other regional shares trimming earlier gains.

site_title: Jardine Cycle & Carriage FY underlying net profit rises 12% to US$858m
summary: Jardine Cycle & Carriage (Jardine C&C) reported a 12% increase in underlying net profit to US$858 million for its full financial year, driven by a 50% stake in Indonesian conglomerate Astra International. Revenue rose 9.5% to US$18.99 billion, with Astra contributing US$719 million to the group's underlying profit. However, the group also reported net non-trading losses of US$438 million due to unrealised fair-value losses. The company announced several changes, including the retirement of a director and the appointment of a new independent director and group finance director.

site_title: NTUC's e2i to launch survey to address barista and chef skill gaps
summary: NTUC's e2i is launching an industry-wide survey to identify gaps in chef and barista training, aiming to transform their roles to meet Industry 4.0 demands. The research, led by Novitee and Addpetizer, will involve a public survey and in-depth interviews with 100 companies and individuals. The goal is to develop training programmes and nurture relevant skills, such as kitchen management, digital and automation skills, to support the adoption of Industry 4.0 technologies in the food and beverage industry in Singapore.

site_title: Cohen to accuse Trump over WikiLeaks, Moscow project, hush payments
summary: Michael Cohen, former Trump fixer, plans to testify before a House of Representatives committee that Trump knew about a 2016 presidential election email leak that hurt Hillary Clinton. Cohen alleges Trump directed negotiations on a Moscow real estate project despite claiming no business interests in Russia. He also claims Trump ordered him to pay Stormy Daniels $130,000 to cover up an affair and lied about it to Melania Trump. Cohen calls Trump a "racist", "conman", and "cheat" and plans to hand over documents to support his claims.

site_title: Japan's Nisshin Seifun to buy Australia's Allied Mills in overseas expansion drive
summary: Japan's Nisshin Seifun to acquire Australia's Allied Mills for A$574 million, expanding its overseas flour businesses. The acquisition is part of a push to offset Japan's shrinking local market, driven by an ageing population. Nisshin Seifun has previously acquired firms in the US, New Zealand, and Thailand. Allied Mills has a leading position in Australia's flour market, and the deal aims to increase Nisshin Seifun's global presence.

site_title: Hyundai plans US$40b in spending as car industry transforms
summary: Hyundai Motor plans to invest US$40 billion over the next five years to develop new models and technologies for electrified and autonomous vehicles, as well as transportation services. The investment, a 58% increase from the past five years, aims to lead the "paradigm change" in the automotive industry. Hyundai aims to achieve an operating profit margin of 7% by 2022, surpassing its profitability in the past four years. The move comes as the industry faces cooling demand and technology shifts, such as the rise of ride-hailing services.

site_title: Latest Earnings
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was oversubscribed 9.8 times. Creative Technology warned its H2 revenue may be below target due to operating loss similar to H1. London's Heathrow plans to increase fees for a £10b upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case. OCBC's incoming CEO is Tan Teck Long, a former DBS veteran. Singapore stocks rallied for a 5-day period ahead of GDP data. The Monetary Authority of Singapore and PBOC announced deeper cooperation in green and transition finance. Meta invested $3.5 billion in an eyewear maker for AI glasses.

site_title: Malaysia's flying car plan jets into controversy
summary: Malaysia plans to launch a flying car prototype later this year, with a development cost of about one million ringgit (S$331,256). The vehicle, which uses local technology, will fly at low altitudes. However, the project has sparked criticism, with many questioning the wisdom of investing in a flying car when the national car industry is already facing problems. Previous car projects in Malaysia have not been successful, and some have expressed skepticism about the feasibility of the flying car project.

images.alt_text: The prototype of the vehicle, which uses local technology, will be unveiled later this year, said Entrepreneur Development Minister Redzuan Mohamad Yusof.

site_title: Alliance Mineral Assets CFO resigned in January
summary: Alliance Mineral Assets' CFO Shaun Menezes resigned in January to pursue other career opportunities, citing no material reasons for the departure. Despite seven key personnel cessations in the past year, the company's sponsor PrimePartners Corporate Finance is satisfied with the situation. Menezes, responsible for finance and accounting functions, will be replaced by Craig Hasson, CFO of Tawana Resources NL. The company's shares traded flat at 20 Singapore cents apiece following the announcement.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks end higher on dovish Fed, won flat
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index rose 8.19 points, or 0.37%, to 2,234.79 points, ending higher after the US Federal Reserve reaffirmed its dovish stance. The won was steady against the US dollar, while the benchmark bond yield fell. Shares of Hyundai Motor and Hyundai Mobis added 5.3% and 3.8%, respectively, after US activist investor Elliott Management demanded higher dividend payouts. The won has lost 0.3% against the US dollar this year, and South Korea's central bank is expected to keep its policy rate unchanged at its meeting on Thursday.

site_title: Trump meets N Korea's Kim in Vietnam for second nuclear summit
summary: US President Donald Trump met with North Korean leader Kim Jong Un in Hanoi, Vietnam, for their second nuclear summit. Trump stated he was not walking back on US demands for North Korea's denuclearization. The meeting took place at the Metropole hotel in Hanoi, where Kim and Trump briefly shook hands and smiled in front of their countries' flags. The outcome of the talks was not immediately clear, but Trump expressed optimism about the success of the meeting.

images.alt_text: Kim and Trump shook hands and smiled briefly in front of a row of their countries' flags at the Metropole hotel in the Vietnamese capital, Hanoi.

site_title: OUE fiscal 2018 earnings tumble 89.4% to S$10m
summary: OUE Limited's net profit for FY2018 dropped 89.4% to S$10m, primarily due to lower net fair value gains and impairment of goodwill. Revenue declined 14.7% to S$642.9m, mainly attributed to lower contributions from development and healthcare divisions. However, investment properties and hospitality divisions saw increases in revenue. The company has proposed a final dividend of 1c per share and a special dividend of 11c per share, totaling 13c per share.

site_title: China plans new state pipeline company in massive energy reshuffle
summary: China plans to form a national oil and gas pipeline group, combining the long-distance pipeline assets of state-owned energy companies, in its largest energy reshuffle in two decades. The National Development and Reform Commission approved the plan, which will create a fourth state-controlled energy company. The new entity will control 70% of China's oil pipelines and nearly 80% of major gas pipelines, effectively removing a key bottleneck in the market and allowing producers and consumers equal access to infrastructure. Final approval from China's State Council is pending.

site_title: Singapore Pools CEO Seah Chin Siong heads to SIM
summary: Singapore Institute of Management (SIM) has appointed Seah Chin Siong as its new president and CEO, effective May 1. Seah, who has held the CEO position at Singapore Pools since 2015, brings 25 years of experience in technology, business development, and strategy formulation. His appointment aims to leverage technology for continuous learning and equip workers with lifelong deep skills training, according to SIM's governing council chairman Euleen Goh.

site_title: My SME Story Ep 3: Bandwagon
summary: Singaporean music media company Bandwagon, founded by Clarence Chan, is featured in the third episode of "My SME Story". The company, which started as a music blog, has expanded into events and concert promotion with a regional presence. Bandwagon aims to spotlight and champion music in Asia, including Singapore. The episode highlights Chan's journey from teaching himself to code to building the company. The series, supported by the Info-communications Media Development Authority, will run from January to April and be available on various platforms.

site_title: Sea Ltd: Losses of 95 cents announced for fourth quarter
summary: Sea Ltd reported a wider-than-expected loss of -95 US cents per share in its fourth quarter, 9 cents lower than the same quarter last year. Revenue rose to US$389.29 million, higher than the estimated US$293.3 million. This is an increase from US$164.52 million in the same quarter last year. The loss was wider than the Refinitiv mean estimate of -68 US cents per share.

site_title: Bombardier investing S$85m to quadruple size of Singapore aircraft maintenance centre
summary: Bombardier is investing S$85 million to expand its Singapore aircraft maintenance centre, quadrupling its size to 40,000 square metres by 2020. The centre will offer a range of maintenance services, including complex retrofit works and heavy structural repair capabilities. The expansion will support over 2,000 visits annually and solidify Bombardier's position as a leader in aftermarket services in the Asia-Pacific region. The investment will also add to the vibrancy of Seletar Aerospace Park, making it the largest business aviation maintenance facility in Asia owned by an original equipment manufacturer.

site_title: Kuroda says inflation to miss BOJ's target in fiscal 2020
summary: Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda stated that inflation is unlikely to reach the central bank's 2% target by the end of fiscal 2021. Kuroda also defended the BOJ's ETF purchases as part of its stimulus program, saying they will be scrutinized for benefits and costs.

site_title: Growth in Singapore services sector revenue eases to 4.1% in Q4
summary: Singapore's services sector revenue grew 4.1% in Q4 2018, slower than the 7.2% growth in Q3. This brings full-year revenue growth to 6.8%, matching the 2017 level. Finance and insurance drove the growth, with all service industries reporting higher turnover.

site_title: China Everbright Water files proofs for HK dual listing
summary: China Everbright Water has submitted draft application proofs for a dual listing in Hong Kong, following its acquisition of HanKore in 2014. The company, which builds and manages water treatment plants, has shown high growth rates in revenue and net profit compared to similar Hong Kong-listed companies. The joint sponsors for the Hong Kong listing are China International Capital Corporation Hong Kong Securities and China Everbright Capital. The expected listing details will be disclosed after the final prospectus is registered.

site_title: Singapore fintech startup Rely raises seven-figure pre-series A funding
summary: Singapore fintech startup Rely has raised a seven-figure pre-series A funding led by Goldbell Financial Services, with Octava and other investors also participating. The funds will be used for regional expansion, team scaling, and supporting retail partnerships. Rely's "buy now pay later" service allows shoppers to split payments into three interest-free monthly instalments, utilizing AI to determine repayment capabilities. Retailers have seen a 20-40% increase in conversion rates and order values, with millennials making up 75% of transactions, and partnerships with e-commerce retailers like Zalora and Zilingo.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Wednesday afternoon at 3,279.46, up 0.55%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.55% on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index reaching 3,279.46. Gainers outnumbered losers 186 to 144, led by RHT HealthTrust and Genting Singapore. Active index stocks like DBS advanced 0.83%. The rally follows a 5-day streak, ahead of GDP data release, and despite US tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Pakistan says it shot down Indian jets, carried out airstrikes in Kashmir
summary: Pakistan and India have engaged in a series of military actions, including airstrikes and ground clashes, in the disputed Kashmir region. Pakistan shot down two Indian jets and carried out airstrikes, while India launched an air strike on a militant training base, killing a large number of fighters. The exchanges have raised tensions between the two nuclear-armed nations, prompting international leaders to urge restraint. The US, China, and European Union have all called for a de-escalation of the conflict, which has resulted in the deaths of at least 40 Indian paramilitary police and has disrupted trade and commerce in the region.

site_title: The 600t rupiah race to fix Jakarta's choking traffic
summary: Jakarta, Indonesia is set to launch its first Mass Rapid Transit (MRT) rail line in March, aiming to alleviate the city's notorious traffic congestion. The $1.2 billion, 16km line will connect the south of the city to the business district, moving 170,000 passengers a day for 10,000 rupiah (S$0.96) or less. The project is part of President Joko Widodo's US$350 billion infrastructure drive, but experts warn that more needs to be done to address the city's urban sprawl and chronic underinvestment in infrastructure.

images.alt_text: Heavy traffic during the afternoon rush hour in Jakarta, Indonesia, on Feb 21, 2019.

site_title: Hong Kong's economic growth slows to 3% in 2018
summary: Hong Kong's economy experienced a slowdown in 2018, growing 3% compared to the forecasted 2-3% and actual 1.3% in the fourth quarter. The trade war between the US and China poses greater risks to the city's economy this year. Financial Secretary Paul Chan revised his forecast, citing a weaker fourth quarter. This slowdown is attributed to the ongoing trade tensions, which have impacted Hong Kong's economy.

site_title: How to make 19,267% and lose it all in 24 hours trading China
summary: China's options market experienced extreme volatility, with a Shanghai-listed ETF posting its biggest single-day gain since August 2015, resulting in a 19,267% gain in one trading session. However, the ETF plummeted 3.1% the next day, wiping out nearly all the gains. This extreme volatility is a result of the nation's stock market, which has seen price swings five times larger than those of the S&P 500 Index over the past 10 days.

site_title: China considers tax breaks to draw in global funds, fend off tax havens
summary: China is considering tax breaks to attract global funds and reduce outflows to international tax havens. The Ministry of Finance is conducting due diligence ahead of a potential feasibility study on a capital gains tax exemption for foreign funds. The move aims to build a more institutionally driven financial system and ease regulatory hurdles. If implemented, the tax break could reduce the use of offshore tax havens and increase access to domestic investors. The tax break would only apply to private funds investing in foreign currency outside China.

site_title: Singapore shares decline at Wednesday's open; STI down 0.04% to 3,260.44
summary: Singapore stocks declined 0.04% at Wednesday's open, with the Straits Times Index reaching 3,260.44. Gainers outnumbered losers 55 to 40, driven by Best World International's 4.3% increase. Meanwhile, KrisEnergy fell 11.1% and DBS Group Holdings dropped 0.5%. The decline follows a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Cromwell E-Reit posts 13-month DPU below forecast at 4.1 euro cents
summary: Cromwell E-Reit posted a 13-month distribution per unit (DPU) of 4.10 euro cents, below its forecast of 4.64 euro cents. Excluding a 2018 rights issue, the DPU would have been 4.70 euro cents, 1.4% higher than projected. The Reit's net property income was 90.2 million euros, 3.7% higher than forecast, driven by its light industrial/logistics portfolio's strong performance, with occupancy increasing to 86.6%.

site_title: Indonesia says at least three killed, 60 feared buried in illegal mine landslide
summary: Indonesia's disaster agency reported that at least three people were killed and 60 feared buried in a landslide at an illegal gold mine on Sulawesi island. Rescue efforts continued through the night, with 15 people rescued and multiple survivors pulled from the muddy hillside. The mine collapse occurred due to unstable land and numerous mining shafts, highlighting the risks of unregulated small-scale mining in Indonesia.

site_title: Plastic found in deepest ocean animals
summary: A British research team discovered plastic fragments in the digestive tracts of tiny shrimp living in six of the world's deepest ocean trenches. The study found that 100% of animals in the Mariana Trench had plastic fibers, while 72% of the 90 individual creatures analyzed contained at least one plastic microparticle. The plastics, mostly from clothes fabrics, were several years old and likely originated from the surface, suggesting that plastic pollution has reached extreme depths in the ocean, contaminating bottom-dwelling species and raising concerns about the impact on their health.

site_title: Handset makers look to gamers for sales boost
summary: Smartphone manufacturers are seeking to boost sales by targeting gamers, but analysts warn that handsets lack the power and screen size to appeal to hardcore players. Video games on smartphones have become increasingly popular, accounting for nearly half of the global video game market in 2018. However, most games don't require high-powered devices, making specialized gaming devices less necessary. Manufacturers such as Samsung and Huawei have introduced features like large screens and cooling systems to cater to gamers, but few have created dedicated gaming devices.

site_title: CNMC Goldmine profit down 2.5% for Q4
summary: CNMC Goldmine reported a 2.5% decrease in net profit to US$1.25 million for the fourth quarter, primarily due to unrealised foreign-exchange losses and higher tax expenses. Revenue surged 2.6 times to US$12.6 million, driven by a surge in fine gold sales volume. The average realised gold price fell to US$1,236 per ounce, while all-in costs of production decreased to US$945 per ounce. Net profit margin narrowed to 15.5% from 33.3% in the same period last year.

site_title: Australia dollar slips on disappointing data, kiwi near 2-1/2 week highs
summary: The Australian dollar slipped 0.1% to US$0.7180 after fourth-quarter construction spending unexpectedly fell 3.1%, challenging the Reserve Bank of Australia's optimism for economic growth. This marked the second straight quarter of sharp falls, adding to evidence of slowing domestic economic momentum. The New Zealand dollar hovered near a 2-1/2 week peak, boosted by progress in the Sino-US trade dispute.

site_title: MAS chief Menon says policy 'appropriate' but monitoring data
summary: MAS chief Ravi Menon says Singapore's monetary policy stance remains "appropriate" despite a disappointing run of recent economic data, including a slowest year-on-year economic growth in the fourth quarter. The central bank has tightened monetary settings in the past, but Menon suggests it may wait until the next policy decision in April to reassess. Core inflation rose within forecast range, but Menon terms it "well within the range" and "pretty well behaved". The central bank is monitoring data and following the state of the economy in Asia, where trade tensions and a slowing global economy have pushed central banks toward monetary easing.

site_title: Asia: Markets up on lingering trade hopes, sterling holds gains
summary: Asian markets rose on lingering hopes for a China-US trade deal, with investors optimistic about the prospects for a deal despite limited catalysts. The pound maintained its gains as fears of a no-deal Brexit recede. US stocks, including the S&P 500 and Nasdaq, edged to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty. The Singapore Stock Index (STI) rose 0.4% on Thursday, driven by investors' positivity despite tariff uncertainty and split Federal Reserve views.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open higher on Wednesday
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.21% on Wednesday, following broader Asian gains, driven by optimism over a China-US trade pact. The Hang Seng Index reached 28,544.77, while the Shanghai Composite Index edged down 0.05%.

site_title: US House strikes down Trump's border wall emergency, now goes to Senate
summary: The US House of Representatives has approved a resolution blocking President Donald Trump's national emergency declaration to fund a Mexican border wall, sending it to the Senate for consideration. The measure, which would override Trump's veto, was approved by a 245-182 vote. The resolution, backed by 13 Republicans, was seen as a rebuke to the president's power grab and a violation of the Constitution. The Senate's prospects for passing the measure are uncertain, but at least two Republicans have expressed support for the resolution, and several others have reservations about the emergency declaration.

site_title: Golden Agri back in the black in Q4 with US$79.3m profit on fair value gains
summary: Golden Agri-Resources (GAR) has posted a net profit of US$79.3 million in the fourth quarter, reversing a year-earlier loss, driven by stronger palm and laurics business and fair value gains. Revenue fell 14.1% to US$1.65 billion, while underlying profit sank 28.8% due to weaker palm oil prices. The company expects stable demand growth for crude palm oil, supported by global food and energy demand. A final dividend of 0.58 Singapore cent per share has been proposed, up from a 28.3% decline in 2018.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on Wednesday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Wednesday, with the Nikkei 225 index edging up 0.23% and the Topix index up 0.15%. Investors engaged in bargain-hunting following a lack of fresh events to support the market, which had seen recent declines in US shares.

images.alt_text: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Wednesday in cautious trade as investors were seen bargain-hunting with a lack of fresh events to support the market after slides in US shares.

site_title: Hot stock: Best World jumps 8.3% on higher earnings and dividends
summary: Best World International shares surged 8.3% on Wednesday after the direct selling group posted a fourth-quarter net profit of S$28.1 million, up 28.9% from the same period last year. Revenue rose 78.6% to S$127.7 million, driven by a 120.5% jump in revenue from China. The company announced a final dividend of 4.2 Singapore cents per share and a special dividend of 0.8 Singapore cent per share. Despite concerns over the lack of clarity on its franchisees' operations in China, management expects top and bottom line growth for FY2019.

site_title: CapitaLand's first closing of property debt fund raises over 70% of US$750m target
summary: CapitaLand has successfully closed its first discretionary real estate debt fund, Credo I China, with over 70% of its US$750m target, raising US$556 million. The fund will invest in offshore US dollar-denominated subordinated instruments for real estate in China's first and second-tier cities, focusing on loans and securities of high-quality properties. CapitaLand holds a 10% stake in the fund, set to be one of China's largest real estate debt funds. The fund's launch comes as China's commercial real estate loans are due for refinancing, with tightened credit availability.

site_title: Hot stock: KrisEnergy shares down 6.2% after wider Q4 loss
summary: KrisEnergy shares plummeted 6.2% to 7.6 Singapore cents after the company reported a wider fourth-quarter net loss of US$97.33 million, up from US$87.57 million in the same period last year. The company is over-geared and underequitized, and has appointed advisers to evaluate and implement viable options. Revenue fell 47.7% to US$17.41 million due to depressed sales volume. KrisEnergy's total debt rose to US$459.1 million, with gearing at 99.9%. The company remains over-geared and underequitized, with significant non-cash expenditures affecting its equity.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Best World, OUE, Golden Agri-Resources, Olam, Keppel, UOL
summary: Best World reported a 28.9% rise in net profit for its fourth quarter, driven by revenue and higher gross margins. OUE's net profit dropped 89.4% to S$10 million due to lower net fair value gains and impairment of goodwill. Golden Agri-Resources posted a net profit of US$79.3 million for the fourth quarter, reversing from a loss a year earlier. Olam International bought 85% of cocoa processing firm YTS Holdings for US$90 million. Keppel Corporation will partner with Golar LNG to develop a floating liquefied natural gas facility. UOL Group's net profit dropped 51% to S$433.7 million.

site_title: GS Holdings narrows full-year loss by 8% to S$3.6m
summary: GS Holdings narrowed its full-year net loss by 8% to S$3.55 million, despite a 15% decline in revenue. The company attributed the reduction to lower cost of sales and administrative expenses, as well as additional government grants. Revenue fell to S$8.45 million due to contract expirations, sales returns, and a key customer's liquidation. The company expects revenue boosts from the opening of Changi Airport's Terminal Four and the Jewel project, as well as a new hawker centre contract.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Olam International acquired 85% of cocoa processing firm YTS Holdings for US$90 million to expand its platform in Asia. KrisEnergy appointed advisers to evaluate and implement options amid a loss-making status and underequipped capital. Singtel signed a master services agreement with China Mobile to accelerate IoT adoption in the Asia-Pacific region. Bumitama Agri recorded a 43% decrease in net profit for the fourth quarter due to weakening commodity prices.

site_title: Nam Cheong swings to RM6.3m Q4 profit from RM899m loss on waiver of debts
summary: Malaysian offshore vessel builder Nam Cheong reported a net profit of RM6.3 million in the fourth quarter, a significant turnaround from a loss of RM899.5 million in the same period last year, due to the waiver of debts. Revenue rose 39% to RM99.44 million, driven by a 147% increase in vessel chartering income. The company's full-year net profit was RM959.6 million, reversing from a net loss of RM3 billion in FY2017. CEO Leong Seng Keat expects continued growth momentum in the vessel chartering segment.

site_title: Abundance International widens fiscal 2018 loss to US$743,000
summary: Abundance International reported a widened fiscal 2018 loss of US$743,000, compared to a net loss of US$536,000 in the previous year. The company attributed the increase to exchange losses, increased write-downs of inventories, and non-cash interest expenses. Revenue decreased 21.1% to US$413.6 million, while the chemical trading business remained profitable. The company's net asset value decreased to 3.22 US cents, and no dividend was declared for the year. The group aims to increase profit margins by leveraging its supply and distribution network.

site_title: Trump, trade and the advantage of autocrats
summary: US President Donald Trump's trade policies appear to be driven by personal vendettas rather than genuine national interests. A potential trade war with China may be on hold, but one with Europe is looming, despite the Europeans' adherence to global trade rules. Trump's administration has imposed tariffs on Chinese products, and a report from the US Commerce Department suggests that European car imports pose a threat to national security, giving the president the authority to impose tariffs. This trade conflict could have devastating consequences, including harming the US economy and jobs.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 1.41 points to 1,717.59 at 9am. Volume was 43.88 million lots worth RM20.5 million, with 85 gainers beating 80 losers.

site_title: Today's enterprising entrepreneurs build ecosystems, not products
summary: Entrepreneurs are shifting their focus from creating individual products to building entire ecosystems that meet customers' needs. Companies like Netflix and Razer have successfully done this by diversifying into new areas such as content aggregation and software services. By understanding customers' lifestyles rather than just their immediate needs, businesses can create a seamless experience and grow exponentially. This approach allows entrepreneurs to think big, anticipate lifestyle needs, and have patience, ultimately deepening their relationship with customers.

site_title: Chaswood Resources expects to narrow FY2018 loss
summary: Chaswood Resources Holdings, a Malaysian casual dining operator, expects to narrow its full-year net loss for fiscal year 2018 due to lower administrative expenses, cost cutting, and lower marketing costs. Despite this, the company attributes the loss to challenging market conditions and lower revenue. The company will release its unaudited full-year results on or before March 1, providing further details on its performance.

site_title: Tech startup Veo Robotics gets ready to roll out factory robots
summary: Veo Robotics Inc, a Tokyo-based startup, has raised $15 million in funding to roll out its factory robot technology in May. The company's proprietary lidar sensor technology enables industrial robots to work safely alongside humans, addressing a major obstacle in the development of collaborative robots. With over 2 million industrial robots in operation worldwide, Veo aims to revolutionize factory work by increasing productivity and reducing costs. The technology will allow robots to handle complex tasks and heavier loads, paving the way for more efficient and automated manufacturing processes.

site_title: New York proposes financing subway with toll to enter Manhattan
summary: New York's mayor and governor propose a congestion zone in central Manhattan to finance a subway overhaul. The plan, which must be approved by the state legislature, would charge electronic tolls to vehicles entering the "central business district" based on congestion levels. Revenue from the tolls and a new internet sales tax would be used to revamp the subway. The system, similar to London's, aims to raise $1 billion annually and reduce greenhouse gas pollution by 80% by 2050. The plan is set to go into effect by January 2020, pending legislative approval.

site_title: Federal Reserve's Powell: US inflation to fall further below 2% target
summary: Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell stated that US inflation will likely fall further below the 2% target, at least for a time, due to declining energy prices. The Fed's recent "patient" stance on interest rate changes was reinforced, with no expected increase this year. Powell emphasized the need for careful consideration of incoming data and evolving economic outlook, citing potential risks from slowing global growth and trade tensions.

site_title: US pushes UN to demand aid be allowed into Venezuela
summary: The US is pushing the UN Security Council to adopt a draft resolution demanding that humanitarian aid be allowed into Venezuela, amid a dire economic crisis. US envoy Elliott Abrams says a vote is expected this week, despite potential veto from Russia. The resolution aims to address the "corrupt, fraudulent and incompetent reign" of President Nicolas Maduro, who has accused the US of using aid as a political tool. The move is in support of opposition leader Juan Guaido, recognized by about 50 countries, and comes after clashes over the weekend on Venezuela's borders.

site_title: Cohen is ready to accuse Trump of deceit, racist comments, sources say
summary: Michael Cohen, former President Donald Trump's personal attorney, is set to testify before Congress, depicting Trump as a liar and possible criminal who manipulated financial statements and made racist remarks. Cohen will present documents supporting his claims of Trump's improper business practices and crude comments. Despite being disbarred and facing prison, Cohen will face questions from Democrats about Trump's business deals and hush-money payments, and from Republicans about his credibility. Cohen's testimony may shed light on Trump Organization practices and expose potential improprieties.

site_title: Dutch government to buy stake in Air France-KLM: minister
summary: The Dutch government plans to buy a 12.68% stake in Air France-KLM, aiming to strengthen its influence in the airline. Finance minister Wopke Hoekstra stated the goal is to reach a position equal to that of the French state. This move is part of a broader effort to address Air France-KLM's financial struggles. The exact terms of the deal have not been disclosed.

site_title: UK PM opens way to three-month Brexit delay
summary: UK Prime Minister Theresa May has announced a possible three-month delay to Brexit, allowing parliament to delay the UK's departure from the European Union by up to March 30. The move comes after threats of mass resignations from her ministers and calls for a second referendum from the main opposition Labour Party. May's proposal includes a three-step procedure, with a vote on her Brexit proposals by March 12, followed by a deadline extension if rejected. The EU would need to unanimously approve a delay by March 29.

site_title: Fiat Chrysler's US$4.5b US push includes new Detroit plant
summary: Fiat Chrysler (FCA) announced a $4.5 billion investment in the US, including a new Detroit plant, its first in nearly three decades. The project will create 3,850 new jobs at the Mack engine plant and 1,100 at the Jefferson North factory. The Detroit expansion will also require additional land and tax abatements. The move is seen as a positive for Michigan, which has been hit by auto industry shifts. While FCA's announcement is a boost, economists note it's a one-off and uncertainty over tariffs may hinder future investments.

site_title: British Airways owner IAG falls after MSCI ditches it from global indices
summary: IAG, the owner of British Airways, fell 3.3% after MSCI removed it from global indices due to a decision to cap foreign ownership of its shares at 47.5%. This move aims to maintain IAG's status as a European-owned airline. As Brexit approaches, IAG's decision may further complicate its situation, potentially affecting its right to fly within the EU. Despite this, FTSE Russell stated that IAG's move to limit foreign ownership won't impact its membership in the FTSE 100 index.

site_title: Clash over S$2.7b of debt at Hyflux heats up
summary: Singapore's water treatment company Hyflux is facing a debt crisis, with creditors set to file proof of obligations totaling S$2.7 billion. The company proposes a 75-90% haircut on unsecured creditors, sparking anger among investors, including 34,000 mom-and-pop investors. Some have called for state rescue, despite the government's stance that it's a commercial matter. Hyflux's key asset, the Tuaspring desalination plant, is secured against loans, but the company's net debt to Ebitda has surged to 165 times, down from 3.9 times a year earlier.

images.alt_text: Singapore's troubled water treatment company Hyflux, formerly celebrated as a hallmark of entrepreneurship in better times, is set for a humbling week.

site_title: US: Stocks edge down as Federal Reserve stays dovish on rates
summary: US stocks declined 0.1% on Tuesday as Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell reiterated a dovish approach to interest rate hikes, citing inflation falling below the Fed's 2% target. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 26,057.98, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also lost 0.1%. Consumer confidence rebounded in February, and some analysts believe the market may struggle to rise further without a positive catalyst, such as a final trade deal between the US and China.

site_title: Four climate tipping points shaping markets today
summary: Climate change is approaching multiple tipping points, affecting politics, society, economy, and investments. The IPCC's 1.5°C warning report highlights the urgent need for drastic economic and policy changes to reduce carbon emissions by 45% by 2030. Four tipping points are imminent: political inaction, social unrest, economic shifts, and investor demand for ESG considerations. These tipping points will reshape markets, with climate refugees and social unrest on the horizon. Investors should capitalize on opportunities while protecting portfolios from adverse consequences.

site_title: Co-living company Hmlet expands into Australia
summary: Hmlet, a Singapore-based co-living company, is expanding into the Australian market with the launch of two properties in Sydney in March. The company aims to quadruple its number of members in Asia-Pacific by the end of 2019, with plans to expand to Melbourne and Brisbane. Hmlet offers community-based living options, catering to the growing demand for flexible and social housing in urban cities. The company's entry into Australia follows a successful expansion in Singapore and Hong Kong.

site_title: StanChart's makeover still has a long way to go
summary: Standard Chartered's transformation efforts are still in its early stages, with costs accounting for nearly 70% of income and a return on tangible equity of 5.1%. Despite curbing bad debts and improving capital, the bank's profit growth was restrained due to regulatory fines. CEO Bill Winters aims to cut costs and double return on tangible equity to 10% by 2021, but faces challenges in scaling back less profitable businesses and generating returns in key markets like India and Indonesia.

site_title: Farewell to the freight forwarder?
summary: Global e-commerce is leading a major shake-up in international shipping, with the introduction of containers revolutionizing the industry since the 1950s. According to David Jinks, head of consumer research at ParcelHero, Amazon and Alibaba are creating the biggest revolution in shipping for 60 years, forcing shipping lines to either integrate with their platforms or risk being submerged. Shipping lines must adapt to survive, with companies like Maersk attempting to integrate with Alibaba's One Touch booking program and autonomous ships on the horizon.

site_title: Labour crunch takes centre stage in the House
summary: Singapore's ageing workforce is projected to start shrinking next year, prompting a focus on addressing the labour shortage. MPs proposed various solutions, including increased investment in skills training and technology, retention of older workers, and recruitment of stay-at-home caregivers. The government is also exploring ways to make better use of the local population, such as placement and training opportunities for flexible work. The debate highlights the need for a tripartite effort to address the zero net local workforce growth challenge.

site_title: New US antitrust task force could unwind tech mergers
summary: The US Federal Trade Commission (FTC) has launched an antitrust task force to focus on competition in the tech sector, particularly with dominant platforms like Google, Facebook, and Amazon. The task force, which includes 17 staff attorneys, will review tie-ups and mergers, including those already completed, to address "competitive harm." The FTC aims to consider remedies such as breakups or divestments to ensure free and fair competition, with an eye toward unwinding or divesting tech mergers.

site_title: Top gadgets at Mobile World Congress
summary:
Here's a 100-word summary of the article content:

At the Mobile World Congress in Barcelona, various tech companies showcased innovative gadgets. Xiaomi unveiled a smart light bulb that can control color and brightness via an app or Alexa. Torooc presented a tiny robot called Liku that can express emotions and take poses when pointed at with a camera. Dinbeat showcased a dog monitoring harness and PurrSong displayed an automatic litter box for cats. Travis introduced earbuds that can translate conversations in real-time across 105 languages. These devices aim to make life easier and more convenient for users, offering unique solutions for various needs and interests.

site_title: 'Patient' policy still warranted despite 'solid' growth: Powell
summary: Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell stated that despite soft data and rising risks, the US economy is expected to expand at a "solid pace" in 2019, with the job market remaining strong. The Fed will maintain a "patient" stance on interest rate hikes, citing favorable economic conditions and a 2% inflation target. Powell acknowledged the impact of the recent partial government shutdown but expects it to have a "fairly modest" impact on the economy. The Fed is also debating its balance sheet and may need to increase it to fight future economic downturns.

site_title: No hard feelings; consumers may soon switch banks with ease
summary: Singapore's Personal Data Protection Commission and Competition and Consumer Commission issued a discussion paper on data portability, allowing consumers to easily switch between competing banks. The move aims to boost competition for consumers' benefit, reducing switching costs and enhancing financial planning. Regulators are studying the introduction of a data portability requirement, which would enable individuals to request and transfer their data to another organisation. This could lead to a reduction in switching costs and increase competition among banks, ultimately benefiting consumers.

site_title: Robinson Crusoe island sets example in conservation
summary: The remote Robinson Crusoe island in the Juan Fernandez archipelago, off the Pacific coast of Chile, has set an example in conservation. The island chain, a biosphere reserve since 1977, has become one of the largest protected zones in the Pacific, covering 262,000 square kilometers of ocean. The local population, NGOs, and the environment ministry are working together to protect the island's unique wildlife, including the Juan Fernandez firecrown and pink-footed shearwater, and to promote sustainable fishing practices. The archipelago aims to eradicate plastic by 2020 and has already implemented measures to reduce waste and protect the environment.

site_title: Best World Q4 gain up on 78% gross margin; proposes higher payout
summary: Best World reported a 28.9% rise in net profit for its fourth quarter, driven by a 78.6% surge in revenue and higher gross margins of 78.2%. The company expects gross profit margin to normalize between 75% and 80% and proposes a higher payout, including a 4.2 Singapore cents per share final dividend and a 0.8 Singapore cents per share special dividend. This comes as the company transitions from an export model to a franchise model in its China market, amid concerns over its business practices.

site_title: Why minority shareholders don't stand a chance
summary: A Singapore-listed company, Datapulse Technology (DT), has exposed the inadequacies of the country's listing rules in protecting minority investors. The company breached rules on "Interested Person Transactions" and "Acquisitions and Realisations" without being caught. DT withheld material information from shareholders before selling its property, which could have affected the outcome of an EGM. The company's controlling shareholder and CEO, Ng Cheow Chye, engaged in questionable transactions, including selling his stake at a premium price. Regulators have failed to take action, allowing the company to break rules with impunity.

site_title: Europe: Wall Street lifts shares, FTSE lags on strong pound
