summary: Europe's pan-European Stoxx 600 closed up 0.5% as the US-China trade talks weighed on sentiment, but a rising Wall Street lifted European shares. The FTSE 100 lost 0.45% due to a stronger sterling, while the FTSE 250 rose 0.15%. In individual news, Metro Bank fell 15%, while Travis Perkins and Ocado rose 12.5% and 11.7%, respectively. Meanwhile, BASF rose 2.3% after delivering slightly better-than-expected profits, and Peugeot owner PSA lost 3% after record results.

site_title: Koufu posts 3.7% rise in Q4 profit
summary: Koufu Group, a Singapore-based food court operator, reported a 3.7% increase in its fourth-quarter net profit to S$7.51 million, driven by higher sales and revenue from new food courts. The company's revenue rose 5.3% to S$57.05 million, with contributions from new outlets and mall management. Net profit for the full year decreased 8.8% to S$24.51 million due to higher depreciation charges and property rentals. The board proposed a final dividend of 1.2 Singapore cents per share.

site_title: Private banks continue to expand amid challenging markets
summary: Private banks continued to grow in 2018 despite challenging markets, with some reporting double-digit revenue growth. UBS, Credit Suisse, BNP Paribas, and HSBC shared their strategies for navigating the market volatility, focusing on client acquisition, diversification, and sustainable investing. The industry expects a synchronized deceleration in economic growth in 2019, but not a recession, with emerging economies potentially taking up the slack. Key sectors to watch include Asian equities, value and secular growth stories, healthcare, and emerging markets.

site_title: HSBC revamps branch network in Singapore
summary: HSBC is revamping its branch network in Singapore, including refurbishments and new locations. The bank's flagship Claymore branch will reopen on March 4, featuring a new Jade Centre for high net worth customers. A second Jade Centre at Jewel Changi Airport will open in the first half of 2019. The changes aim to enhance customer experience and grow market share, with a focus on delivering physical and digital channels. The move is part of HSBC's strategic intent to achieve growth across customer segments in Singapore.

site_title: Temasek leads US$85m investment round for gene therapy startup
summary: Gracell Biotechnologies, a gene therapy startup, has secured US$85 million in funding through a Series B round led by Temasek Holdings, with additional investors including Lilly Asia Ventures and Kington Capital. This investment will support the company's development of immune cell gene therapy.

site_title: Why Thailand's women are so successful in business but not politics
summary: Thailand stands out as a country where women excel in business, holding 37% of leadership roles globally, with 40% of chief executives and 34% of chief financial officers. Women's involvement in family businesses and access to education are key factors. Unlike other Asian countries, Thai women are more likely to work alongside men in industries like finance and insurance, allowing them to pursue corporate careers. This culture, combined with the ability to balance work and family obligations, enables women to rise to leadership positions, as illustrated by women like Kamonwan Wipulakorn, who became CEO of a major real estate company.

site_title: Sinarmas Land's Q4 net profit dives 75%
summary: Sinarmas Land's Q4 net profit plummeted 74.9% to S$58.6 million due to the absence of land sales in its Indonesia division and a one-off gain from divestment. Revenue fell 52.7% to S$276.2 million, and the group's net asset value per share slipped to 48 Singapore cents. The company will adopt a cautious approach to geographical expansion and earnings diversification amidst uncertainties in the external environment.

site_title: Keppel unit partners LNG shipping firm to build floating liquefied natural gas facility
summary: Keppel Corporation has partnered with Golar LNG to develop, construct, and operate a floating liquefied natural gas (FLNG) facility on the Mauritania and Senegal maritime border. Keppel will invest 30% in Gimi MS Corporation, while Golar will hold 70%. The project, valued at approximately $1.3 billion, will utilize the existing Moss LNG carrier Gimi, which will be converted into an FLNG vessel by Keppel Shipyard. The partnership aims to capitalize on growing LNG opportunities and provide attractive risk-adjusted returns for Keppel.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Chasing Cars: Mistakes to avoid
summary: Claressa Monteiro and Julian Kho from sgcarmart discuss common mistakes to avoid when buying a car on the Money FM podcast "Chasing Cars." The duo highlights five mistakes, including not researching the market, not knowing the car's history, and not considering long-term costs. They also emphasize the importance of test driving and inspecting the vehicle before making a purchase. The podcast aims to provide listeners with valuable insights to ensure a successful car-buying experience.

site_title: Paris fashion week begins under Lagerfeld's shadow
summary: Paris Fashion Week kicked off under the shadow of Karl Lagerfeld's death, with Virginie Viard presenting his final collection at Chanel on March 5. Lagerfeld, who died last week at 85, had leaned heavily on Viard in his final months, and it is unclear how much of the collection was completed by him. The week's shows featured a mix of tributes to Lagerfeld and new designs from emerging and established brands, including Ottolinger, Rok Hwang, and Louise Trotter for Lacoste. A farewell ceremony for Lagerfeld will take place at a later date.

site_title: Strong FDI flows to Singapore and rest of S-E Asia despite US tax reforms
summary: Singapore and the rest of South-east Asia saw strong foreign direct investment (FDI) flows in 2018, despite US tax reforms. FDI in Singapore jumped to an estimated US$77 billion, while the region's total FDI rose 11% to a new high of US$145 billion. Global FDI slipped for a third consecutive year, but FDI into developing economies remained resilient. The US remained the biggest recipient of FDI, but many of the top 10 host economies were developing economies. UNCTAD expects a rebound in global FDI this year, but notes underlying trends remain weak due to risks from trade tensions and policy uncertainty.

site_title: Expect a roller-coaster ride in 2019
summary: Investors face a volatile 2019 due to uncertainty at an all-time high, with global economic policy uncertainty index at a record high. Despite poor performance in 2018, the global economy is expected to recover, with European and Asian markets offering attractive entry points. Investors should focus on high-quality stocks, cross-sector themes, and geographical diversification, particularly in emerging markets. Fixed income markets may show improvement, and commodities remain under pressure, while gold is expected to be a positive investment.

site_title: Chope partners with MeiTuan Dianping to target China tourists
summary: Chope, a Singapore-based dining platform, has partnered with MeiTuan Dianping, a Chinese lifestyle service giant, to enable Chinese tourists to book tables at Chope restaurants for free through MeiTuan's platform. The partnership, which began in mid-January, has seen over 3,000 reservations made by Chinese travelers at 60 Chope restaurants. Chope aims to tap into the growing Chinese tourist market in Singapore and expand the partnership to incorporate more restaurants across its cities in the coming months.

site_title: Soilbuild flags Q4, FY loss on arbitration award against unit
summary: Soilbuild Construction Group has flagged a Q4 and FY loss due to an arbitration award against its subsidiary, Soil-Build (Pte) Ltd, which was awarded S$1.4m by an arbitrator. The award was against a sub-contractor for project delays, but the arbitrator ruled that the sub-contractor is not liable to pay damages. Instead, Soil-Build must pay the sub-contractor the remaining amount, approximately S$1.4m. This will be recognized as an additional cost of sales for Q4 and FY 2018.

site_title: WeWork said to be in advanced talks to lease 100,000 sq ft in MYP Centre
summary: WeWork is in advanced talks to lease 100,000 sq ft at MYP Centre in Singapore, potentially making it one of the company's largest spaces in the city-state. The co-working space provider is expanding its operations in Singapore, with plans to open two new locations in the second quarter of the year. WeWork now operates in nine locations across Singapore, serving around 400,000 members globally, including enterprises, SMEs, startups, and freelancers.

site_title: Trump's positive rhetoric on China not matched by crude, LNG, coal trade
summary: US President Donald Trump's positive rhetoric on a potential deal with China was not matched by China's actual trade data. China's imports of US crude oil were zero for a second month in January, down 25% from 2018. The trade tariffs imposed by Trump resulted in a significant decrease in US oil exports to China, making it difficult to reverse the flow once interrupted. This highlights the challenges of reversing trade disruptions, even in commodities not subject to retaliatory measures.

site_title: How to navigate a volatile 2019
summary: Investors should focus on building portfolios with defensive and secular growth ideas to navigate the volatile 2019 market. The year is expected to see a synchronized slowdown in global economic growth, but with emerging markets forecasted to grow. Risks include interest rate hikes, trade tensions, and recession probabilities, but opportunities exist in sectors such as technology, emerging markets, and demographics. BNP Paribas Wealth Management recommends a barbell approach, combining defensive and growth assets, and suggests adding to themes like Industry 4.0, cyber security, and mobility when market opportunities present themselves.

site_title: Time for UK MPs to eschew narrow interests on Brexit for nation's sake
summary: The UK is set to leave the EU on March 29, with a no-deal Brexit becoming increasingly likely due to a lack of progress on alternative deals. Foreign multinationals are scaling back operations, and businesses are stockpiling goods in anticipation of post-Brexit chaos. The UK's gridlock in Westminster has hindered a solution, with Prime Minister Theresa May's vision of a soft Brexit facing opposition from hard Brexiteers and Remainers. The situation has become a "lesson in how incompetent politicians have hijacked the welfare of an entire nation," with the country's citizens paying the price.

site_title: STI slides on slow output, trade worries
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index declined 0.33% or 10.69 points to 3,261.66, with losers outnumbering gainers 215 to 185. The decline was attributed to investor uncertainty over US-China trade talks, with US President Donald Trump saying a deal "might not happen at all." Industrial stocks, including ST Engineering and Sembcorp Industries, were among the top losers, while financials also saw losses. However, analysts at RHB Research Institute remain overweight on the local banking sector, citing potential for net interest margin expansion and attractive dividend yields.

site_title: Ex-DBS CFO Jeanette Wong tipped to join UBS board
summary: UBS plans to add Jeanette Wong, former DBS CFO, and William Dudley, former New York Federal Reserve chief, to its board, set to take place at an annual general meeting on May 2. Wong brings over 30 years of experience in the financial industry, while Dudley has served as CEO of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. UBS chairman Axel Weber says the nominees will strengthen the board with their expertise in Asia-Pacific and the US, key growth markets for the bank. Two current board members, Ann Godbehere and Michel Demaré, will not be re-elected due to term limits.

site_title: Beijing city plans RMB10 billion fund in tech push; aims to rival Shenzhen
summary: Beijing city plans to raise over RMB10 billion (S$2 billion) in its first tech-focused fund, aiming to rival Shenzhen as a hub for innovative technology and industrial upgrading projects. The fund, backed by the Beijing city government, will invest in sectors such as semiconductors, artificial intelligence, and electric vehicles. This move underscores China's push to develop its technology sector, following a trade stand-off with the US. Beijing's move comes as Shenzhen has been a major tech hub for 20 years, with Shenzhen Capital Group investing in the tech sector since 2005.

site_title: How Hong Kong's property slump could clobber the economy
summary: Hong Kong's property market is experiencing a significant slump, with home values falling about 9% from their August peak due to the China-US trade war and potential rate hikes. The government's reliance on land sales, which generated a large amount of revenue in 2018, is expected to shrink by 63% in fiscal 2019. This downturn could weigh on the broader economy, reducing consumer spending and increasing pressure on borrowing, potentially leading to a budget deficit of over HK$40 billion.

site_title: Industry transformation is an ongoing effort for companies, workers
summary: Singapore's Budget 2019 aims to propel the country towards achieving industry transformation goals through measures such as the Bicentennial Bonus, Merdeka Generation Package, and enhanced Professional Conversion Programmes. While initial metrics show progress, including a 3.6% annual growth in productivity and real median income, the journey is far from over. The government must continually review and enhance its initiatives to address the evolving needs of businesses and workers, including the adoption of emerging technologies and lifelong learning. The upcoming Committee of Supply debate will shed further clarity on the way forward.

site_title: SEC asks judge to hold Elon Musk in contempt for violating settlement deal
summary: The SEC has asked a federal judge to hold Tesla CEO Elon Musk in contempt for violating a settlement agreement regarding his pre-approval of market-moving tweets about the company. Musk tweeted that Tesla would produce around 500,000 cars this year, then clarified the statement, and the SEC claims the tweets were not pre-approved. This is the latest escalation in the battle between the SEC and Musk, who has openly taunted the regulator and called it the "Shortseller Enrichment Commission." The SEC's motion could lead to severe consequences for Musk, who is already under pressure to repay hundreds of millions of dollars of loans.

site_title: US housing outlook stuck in a lull as economy dulls: poll
summary: US housing prices are forecast to rise 4% this year, the slowest pace in over half a decade, due to a lack of single-family homes and higher mortgage rates. The US Federal Reserve's rate guidance has not boosted the outlook, and housing market growth is unlikely to contribute to the economy's expansion. Existing home sales are expected to average 5.3 million units, below the 2005 peak, and affordability remains a concern, with 85% of analysts expecting housing turnover to remain steady or fall.

site_title: Crisis, what crisis? Qatari love of luxury going strong
summary: In Qatar, luxury goods continue to thrive despite a nearly two-year-old diplomatic crisis. The Doha Jewellery and Watches Exhibition drew large crowds, with attendees including Qatari dignitaries and Bollywood star Aishwarya Rai Bachchan. Luxury brands showcased high-end watches, cars, and jewelry, with sales reportedly doubling since the crisis. The country's wealth and love for luxury timepieces are on full display, with interest in watches even surpassing 45% among female customers. Despite regional tensions, Qatar's luxury market remains strong, with Hublot's regional director attributing the sales surge to Qatari consumers buying in Qatar rather than abroad.

site_title: ECB determined to push forward its payment system - Mersch
summary: The European Central Bank is determined to push forward its instant payment system, TARGET Instant Payment Settlement (TIPS), if industry collaboration fails. The system, launched last year, allows for fast and secure euro transfers within seconds, challenging US firms like PayPal and China's Alibaba and Tencent, which dominate similar services in Europe. ECB board member Yves Mersch stated that the bank will use either collaborative efforts or regulatory capacity to make the system a success.

site_title: Hanoi tours offer visitors taste of summit action
summary: US President Donald Trump and North Korean leader Kim Jong Un met in Hanoi, Vietnam, for their second summit. Visitors, including British student Lee Parry, joined a tour group to witness the event, with stops at the Ho Chi Minh mausoleum and the Melia Hotel where Kim is expected to stay. The trip, offered by travel company Young Pioneer Tours, allowed participants to experience the summit's flurry, with some hoping for a successful outcome. Vietnam also unveiled a special stamp collection to mark the event, and the country's national railway service offered free train travel to journalists.

site_title: Improving outlook for SIA but downside risks lurk
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) reported weaker profits in its third quarter, but analysts expect an improved performance in Q4FY18/19 and FY20 due to stronger-than-expected passenger yields and lower fuel costs. The airline's shares have risen to S$10.10, with an average 12-month target price of S$11.01 from 16 analysts. Downside risks include a slowdown in the cargo industry and uncertainties surrounding the US-China trade war and Brexit, which could impact passenger demand.

site_title: Beer drinkers in China set to be big losers from trade tensions
summary: China's trade tensions may lead to a 20% increase in high-grade barley prices used to produce malt for beer and whiskey, affecting consumers and global brewers. The price rise is attributed to global trade tensions and tightening supplies due to a probe into Australian barley imports. Despite this, Chinese brewers may not be significantly impacted in the short term, as they have sufficient barley supply for the next three to six months. The country relies heavily on imports to meet domestic demand, with 80% of its barley consumption projected to be sourced from overseas.

site_title: Kim visits North Korean embassy in Hanoi
summary: North Korean leader Kim Jong Un visited the North Korean embassy in Hanoi, Vietnam, on Tuesday, hours after arriving for his summit with US President Donald Trump. The visit was seen as a routine stop, with Kim accompanied by his sister Kim Yo Jong and other aides. This is not the first time Kim has visited an embassy, as he previously dropped in to the North Korean mission in Beijing in June last year. The visit comes ahead of the highly anticipated summit between Kim and Trump.

site_title: Money is top stressor for Singaporeans: BlackRock survey
summary: A BlackRock survey found that money remains the top source of stress for Singaporeans, with 53% citing it as a major concern. However, those who have started retirement planning report a higher sense of well-being. Millennials and women face challenges in preparing for retirement due to a declining use of financial advisers and a preference for technology over human interaction in investing. Only 60% of women have started saving for retirement, and they rely heavily on cash and personal savings rather than investment tools.

site_title: Tech firms lead charge among Singapore's fastest-growing companies
summary: Singapore's fastest-growing companies, as identified in a study by Straits Times and Statista, have seen an average compound annual growth rate of 49% between 2014 and 2017. BR Metals, a recycling company, topped the list with a 250% growth rate, followed by Nuffield Dental with a 180% growth rate and V-Key with a 150% growth rate. The study highlights tech companies, healthcare providers, and small to medium-sized enterprises as the driving force behind Singapore's economic growth, challenging traditional business models and serving customers in new ways.

site_title: Investors look to Powell's testimony for clues
summary: US Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell's testimony on Tuesday may boost risk appetite, with investors trimming bets on further rate hikes and betting on rate cuts by 2020. The dollar holds near a one-week low, and risky assets, such as the British pound, have seen gains. However, market participants caution that it's too early to call an end to the US rate hike cycle, and trade tensions may dissipate, potentially giving a boost to the US economy.

site_title: Traders brace for market chaos in no-deal Brexit
summary: Traders are bracing for market chaos as the UK's potential no-deal Brexit comes into focus. The EU's energy market, linked to Norway's natural gas, is complex and vulnerable to disruptions. The expiration of futures for next month's energy contracts heightens concerns. The Big Six utilities, led by Centrica, are already feeling the strain from tariff caps and increased competition from smaller firms. A no-deal Brexit could exacerbate these issues, threatening the stability of the energy market.

site_title: UK will leave EU without deal only if lawmakers agree: May
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May told parliament that the UK will leave the EU without a deal on March 29 if lawmakers agree to her withdrawal deal. If not, she will give parliament a vote on a no-deal Brexit. May said a delay would prolong uncertainties and that her deal is better than no deal, raising the chances of its success. This move isolates Brexit no-deal zealots, who may be forced to support May's deal to avoid a delay, potentially leading to a May deal victory.

site_title: Structuring for success
summary: Families should focus on structuring for the "business family" rather than the "family business" in succession planning. This approach allows capable family members to create wealth and make a difference, rather than trying to manage existing family businesses. Three common misconceptions about succession planning include focusing solely on fiscal efficiency, structuring for business succession, and structuring for everything. Successful families instead structure their wealth to preserve their legacy, allowing future generations to make their own decisions and find their own entrepreneurial paths. This approach can lead to a more enduring legacy, with material wealth reinforcing non-material wealth over time.

site_title: A wealth of investment opportunities in healthcare
summary: The healthcare sector is experiencing unprecedented change driven by global demographic trends and innovation in disease treatment and service delivery. With an aging population expected to double by 2050, and emerging middle classes in developing countries driving demand for better healthcare, the industry is undergoing a major shift. This shift is driving innovation, including precision medicine, gene editing, and immunotherapy, and is expected to create significant investment opportunities in companies with dominant market share positions, innovative technology, and holistic service offerings.

site_title: Gojek partners Gigacover to launch earnings protection insurance scheme for its drivers
summary: Gojek has partnered with Gigacover to launch an earnings protection insurance scheme for its drivers in Singapore. The scheme, starting April 1, 2019, provides drivers with up to S$80 per day in earnings protection coverage, with "top active drivers" receiving free coverage paid by Gojek. Drivers can pay a subsidised monthly rate to Gigacover, and the partnership aims to provide peace of mind for drivers. The move is seen as a growing effort by transport operators to protect self-employed drivers, with the Ministry of Manpower welcoming the initiative.

site_title: UOL targeting two launches in Q2
summary: UOL Group, a Singapore property developer, is set to launch two residential projects in Q2 2019. The first project, MeyerHouse, is a 56-unit freehold condo on Meyer Road with large format units, while the second project, Avenue South Residence, is a 56-storey 99-year leasehold project on Silat Avenue with 1,074 units. Despite a 51% drop in net profit in FY2018, UOL Group CEO Liam Wee Sin expects "healthy take-up" for the projects, citing land price advantages and strong product differentiation.

site_title: Impossible Foods to launch product in 8 Singapore restaurants on March 7
summary: Impossible Foods, backed by Temasek, is launching its plant-based meat in 8 Singapore restaurants on March 7. The product will also be made available to local restaurants through Classic Fine Foods. This marks the company's expansion into Singapore, following its launch in Asia last year. Impossible Foods CEO Pat Brown plans to consider manufacturing the product in Singapore and conducting product research there, although it will initially be shipped from the US.

site_title: Kentish Green, St Thomas Ville try for collective sale again
summary: Kentish Green, a 122-unit freehold property in District 9, Singapore, has been put up for collective sale with a S$200 million reserve price. St Thomas Ville, a 23-unit freehold property in the same district, is also up for sale with a S$58 million reserve price. Both properties have the potential for increased development parameters, including plot ratio and height, according to the Urban Redevelopment Authority. The collective sale tenders for both properties will close on March 28 and March 27, respectively.

site_title: US lawmakers kick off debate over online privacy
summary: US lawmakers began debating online privacy legislation, following revelations about tech firms' data handling. Companies have expressed willingness to accept new federal regulations. Lawmakers must decide on a model, with options including the European Union's GDPR or California's strict rules. Key differences exist on how tightly tech firms should be regulated, with some advocating for greater transparency and enforcement, while others argue for a more balanced approach that promotes innovation and prosperity.

site_title: This stock market rally has everything, except investors
summary: US corporations are buying back shares at an extraordinary clip, despite pension funds, mutual funds, and other investors selling stock. Since the market rally began in 2009, the S&P 500 has risen over 300%, but many investors are selling, fearing low returns or a bear market. Corporations, however, are using buybacks to return cash to shareholders, boost share prices, and improve earnings-per-share. So far this year, companies have announced plans to repurchase over $190 billion of their own shares, with the trend expected to continue.

site_title: Peugeot-maker PSA lifts profit goal after record 2018
summary: PSA Group, the French carmaker, raised its medium-term profit guidance after reporting record full-year sales and earnings. The company's recurring operating income jumped 43% to 5.69 billion euros, with a 7.7% profit margin, driven by successful SUV models like Peugeot 3008 and 5008. PSA aims to achieve a 4.5% average margin goal for 2019-2021, including the less profitable Opel-Vauxhall division, and plans to expand its sales outside Europe.

site_title: US: Wall Street dips at open
summary: US stocks declined at the open on Tuesday, with the Dow Jones falling 0.15% to 26,051.61, the S&P 500 down 0.13% to 2,792.36, and the Nasdaq Composite 0.25% to 7,535.29. The declines were attributed to losses in Home Depot and Caterpillar, while investors awaited Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell's testimony on monetary policy.

site_title: Diabetics stock up on insulin over Brexit fears
summary: Diabetics in Britain are stockpiling insulin in anticipation of a potential no-deal Brexit, which could lead to delays at the border and shortages of the crucial medicine. With 3.7 million diabetics relying on imports from continental Europe, suppliers are exceeding government recommendations to have enough inventory. Companies like Novo Nordisk and Sanofi have doubled their reserves, while US firm Eli Lilly warns of potential disruptions. Diabetes UK and JDRF have called on the government to provide more details on its preparations, citing the need for emergency medicine deliveries and stockpiling of other essential products.

site_title: Spreading disinformation since the 18th century
summary: The article explores the history of disinformation and its impact on society, tracing its roots to the 18th century. During this time, pamphlets played a significant role in shaping public opinion and influencing historical events. The American Revolution saw both the British and American sides employing spies and propaganda to sway Dutch public opinion. Today, the rise of social media and cable news channels has created a breeding ground for disinformation, with competing outlets spreading biased news to please their audience. To combat disinformation, the article suggests prioritizing education and critical thinking, promoting a free press, and fostering a culture of healthy skepticism.

site_title: A new approach to manage your wealth
summary: UBS introduces the "3Ls" framework to help investors navigate a volatile investment landscape in 2019. The framework consists of Liquidity, Longevity, and Legacy strategies, which guide investors to plan for their long-term financial goals. The Liquidity strategy funds expenses and debts over 2-5 years, the Longevity strategy funds retirement goals, and the Legacy strategy invests surplus funds for future generations. This approach can help investors stick to their plans, avoid emotional biases, and frame risk in terms of personal ambitions, ultimately moving closer to meeting their goals.

site_title: Koh Brothers' Eco Engineering says worksite accident kills site supervisor
summary: A construction worker at Koh Brothers' Eco Engineering's Changi East worksite was killed when a tipper truck hit and ran over him in a stockpile area. The incident occurred on February 26, 2019. Investigations are underway by the Ministry of Manpower and the police, with the driver of the tipper truck arrested and released on bail. All tipper truck operations and works at the stockpile area have been suspended. The company will provide assistance to the site supervisor's family.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Two Singaporean companies, Sheng Siong Group and AEM Holdings, received buy ratings with target prices of S$1.25 and S$1.24, respectively. Sheng Siong's growth is driven by new store openings and cost efficiencies, while AEM Holdings' slowdown in HDMT test handlers sales is expected to recover in FY20 due to new orders and capacity expansion. Online grocery retail is not seen as a threat to Sheng Siong, and AEM Holdings may become a takeover target for online players. Key risks include revenue growth led by new store openings and excessive discounts.

site_title: January output shrinks for first time in a year
summary: Singapore's manufacturing sector contracted in January for the first time since December 2017, with factory output declining 3.1% from a year ago. Economists attribute the weakness to factors such as high base effects, the fading electronics cycle, and uncertainties from the trade war. While some sectors, like transport engineering, saw growth, economists warn that the contraction may persist and manufacturing could remain lacklustre for the rest of the year, with some cutting their growth outlook for 2019.

images.alt_text: Singapore's manufacturing sector started the year on shaky footing, with factory output contracting for the first time since December 2017.

site_title: Best World posts 29% higher Q4 net profit on transition to franchise model
summary: Best World reported a 28.9% increase in Q4 net profit to S$28.1 million, driven by a surge in revenue and higher gross margins. The company attributed the growth to its transition to a franchise model in China, with revenue jumping 78.6% to S$127.7 million. Gross profit more than doubled to S$99.77 million, but the net profit margin fell to 22% due to increased distribution costs. The board proposed a final dividend of 4.2 cents per share and a special dividend of 0.8 cents per share.

site_title: Trump lands in Vietnam for second summit with North Korea's Kim
summary: US President Donald Trump and North Korean leader Kim Jong Un arrived in Vietnam for their second summit, set to discuss implementing North Korea's pledge to give up its nuclear weapons. Trump landed at Hanoi's capital, while Kim arrived by train after a 3,000 km journey from Pyongyang. The two leaders will meet for a brief one-on-one conversation, followed by a dinner, before discussing the denuclearization of the Korean peninsula. Trump's critics warn against a deal that does little to curb North Korea's nuclear ambitions, while Kim seeks significant US concessions.

site_title: US home construction plunges in December
summary: US home construction fell 11.2% in December to its lowest level in over two years, with single-family home starts declining for the fourth straight month. Despite this, construction permits rose to 1.33 million, driven by a surge in apartment building permits. Economists expect demand to recover in the coming months as mortgage prices fall. The weakness in the housing sector has raised concerns about US economic growth, but analysts believe the rebound in the market will translate to a rebound in construction activity.

site_title: US appeals court says AT&T deal to buy Time Warner is legal
summary: A US appeals court upheld a lower court ruling that AT&T's $85.4 billion acquisition of Time Warner is legal under antitrust law. The three-judge panel ruled unanimously in favor of the deal, dismissing the Justice Department's arguments that AT&T would use its ownership of Time Warner's content to raise prices for consumers. The decision allows the deal to proceed, with AT&T shares rising 0.5% in morning trade.

images.alt_text: A US appeals court upheld on Tuesday a lower court ruling that wireless and satellite TV provider AT&T Inc's deal to buy content maker Time Warner for US$85.4 billion was legal under antitrust law.

site_title: US says Europe getting its message on "deceitful" Huawei
summary: US officials say European governments are listening to their concerns about China's Huawei exposing telecoms networks to security risks, with US Ambassador Robert Strayer stating that people are "understanding our point" about the inherent risks in the technology. The US warns that 5G equipment could be exploited for spying if supplied by Huawei, while the company denies any security risks. Several Western countries have restricted Huawei's access to their markets, and a British government report found technical issues with Huawei equipment exposing national telecoms networks to new security risks.

images.alt_text: "People are understanding our point that we are making about the security risks that are inherent in this technology coming from China," said Robert  Strayer, US State Department ambassador for cyber and international communications.

site_title: EU urges 'maximum restraint' from India, Pakistan after air strike
summary: The EU has urged India and Pakistan to exercise "maximum restraint" following an air strike by Indian warplanes on a militant camp in Pakistan, killing a "very large number" of militants. The attack occurred after a February 14 suicide bombing claimed by the Jaish-e-Mohammad group in Indian Kashmir. Pakistan has condemned the attack as "uncalled for aggression" but reported no damage or casualties. The escalation has heightened tensions between the nuclear-armed arch-rivals, who have fought three wars since independence from Britain in 1947.

site_title: Little India heritage site valued at some S$70.6m goes up for tender
summary: A 25,865 square foot two-storey bungalow, known as the former House of Tan Teng Niah, is up for tender in Singapore's Little India area. Valued at S$70.6 million, the property is believed to be the last remaining Chinese villa in Little India, built in 1900. The building, a hybrid of Southern Chinese and European architectural influences, is part of the core Little India Conservation Area and is directly across from Tekka Market. The tender closes on April 2, and the sale is expected to attract investors and high net-worth individuals due to its historical value.

site_title: Why Thailand's women are so successful in business
summary: Thailand ranks high in women's leadership roles, with 37% holding leadership positions globally, 40% as chief executives, and 34% as chief financial officers. The country also boasts the highest enrollment of women in higher education, with 1.41 women for every man. This success far surpasses other Asian countries and is a notable achievement globally.

site_title: EU wants a Brexit delay but governments at odds over length
summary: The European Union wants a Brexit delay, but EU governments are divided over the length of the extension. Prime Minister Theresa May has promised a vote on a "short" delay if her deal is not approved by March 12. EU officials are seeking a clear plan for the additional period, but there's no unified position among EU countries on how long an extension should be. Some governments favor a 21-month extension, while others prefer a one-year delay, with the EU potentially agreeing to a short delay despite opposition.

site_title: Samsung, Huawei price folding phones around US$2,000
summary: Samsung and Huawei have priced their folding phones at nearly double the cost of Apple's latest iPhones, with the Samsung Galaxy Fold at US$1,980 and the Huawei Mate X at US$2,600. This trend of high-priced smartphones follows Apple's lead, which initially sparked record iPhone sales but later saw stagnant unit sales and declining revenue. Industry experts suggest that the demand for these high-priced devices will depend on whether the folding-screen phenomenon becomes a lasting trend.

site_title: Tech, medical and security companies among Singapore's fastest growing firms: survey
summary: Singapore's fastest-growing companies between 2014 and 2017 had an average compound annual growth rate of 49%. Tech companies dominate the list, with BR Metals leading the pack at over 250% growth. Other notable companies include Nuffield Dental, V-Key, and OneCare Medical, which achieved growth rates of 180%, 150%, and 113% respectively. The survey highlights the importance of innovation, strategic planning, and adapting to changing market conditions in driving growth.

site_title: Koufu posts 3.7% rise in Q4 net profit on higher sales
summary: Koufu, a food court operator, reported a 3.7% increase in Q4 net profit to S$7.51 million, driven by higher sales of 5.3%. Revenue from its outlet and mall management segment rose 5.3% due to new food courts and coffee shops opening in 2018. However, revenue from its F&B retail business segment decreased by S$0.4 million due to closures. The company proposed a final dividend of 1.2 Singapore cents per share.

site_title: Keppel partners LNG shipping firm to build FLNG facility
summary: Keppel Corporation has partnered with Golar LNG to develop, construct, and operate a floating liquefied natural gas (FLNG) facility on the Mauritania and Senegal maritime border. Keppel will hold 30% of Gimi MS Corporation, while Golar holds the remaining 70%. The project, valued at approximately $1.3 billion, will be built on the existing Moss LNG carrier, converted into an FLNG vessel by Keppel Shipyard. The facility will be leased to BP for 20 years. The partnership aims to capitalize on growing LNG opportunities and provide attractive risk-adjusted returns for Keppel.

site_title: Thailand's TMB and Thanachart bank sign 140b baht merger MOU
summary: Thailand's TMB Bank and Thanachart Bank signed a non-binding agreement to merge in a deal worth up to 140 billion baht (S$6.03 billion), making the new entity the sixth largest bank in the country. The merger follows government approval of tax incentives for bank mergers. TMB will finance the deal through debt and equity, issuing new shares worth 70% of the total. The planned merger aims to help the banks better compete with larger regional rivals.

site_title: British PM to rule out no-deal Brexit
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May will rule out a no-deal Brexit in a bid to avoid a rebellion by lawmakers, according to reports. This move comes after the UK parliament voted against her deal in January, and amid warnings that a no-deal Brexit could lead to economic turmoil. May's proposal, set to be announced on Tuesday, could lead to a delay in the UK's March 29 exit date, giving lawmakers more time to negotiate changes to the separation package. This move aims to prevent a potentially disorderly no-deal Brexit.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's manufacturing sector contracted 3.1% in January, marking its first drop in output since 2017. The Straits Times Index fell 0.33% on Tuesday, with Singapore shares closing lower. Meanwhile, Singapore shares collaborated with China Mobile on IoT, and Singtel signed a master services agreement. Corporate news included former DBS CFO Jeanette Wong joining UBS board, and Singapore stocks fell. Internationally, Vietnam was surprised by a US tariff announcement, and China's GDP growth is expected to slow.

site_title: US business lobby says most firms favour tariffs while China trade talks underway
summary: US business lobby, the American Chamber of Commerce in China, says most of its member companies favor retaining tariffs on Chinese goods while trade talks continue. About 10% of members want to increase tariffs from 10% to 25%, while 43% advocate maintaining the current rate and delaying the increase. The chamber also found that 47% of members want the US government to push for a level playing field for US businesses in China. US President Trump has expressed optimism about reaching a deal with Chinese President Xi Jinping, but some industry groups are concerned that a deal may not address China's underlying trade practices.

site_title: Bank of England prepares cash access boost before Brexit
summary: The Bank of England is preparing to give lenders greater access to cash borrowing ahead of Brexit, increasing the frequency of sterling cash loans from monthly to weekly from March to April. This move aims to provide additional flexibility in liquidity insurance and is part of the central bank's financial stability objective. Governor Mark Carney stated that the announcement is part of normal contingency planning and that commercial banks are functioning well, with no liquidity stresses in the market.

site_title: No-deal Brexit or "short" delay? May offers lawmakers a choice
summary: Theresa May offers UK lawmakers a vote on delaying Brexit or pursuing a no-deal exit if her divorce deal fails. The deadline for approving the deal is March 12, and if it's not met, lawmakers will vote on a short delay on March 13 or a no-deal Brexit on March 29. May rules out a no-deal Brexit, but warns that she will make a success of it if needed. A delay increases the chances of reversing Brexit, with the opposition Labour Party supporting another referendum.

site_title: Tesla's Musk calls SEC "broken" in new Twitter spat
summary: Elon Musk, Tesla's CEO, clashed with the US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) in a Twitter spat, accusing the regulator of being "broken" in its oversight. The SEC accused Musk of violating a fraud settlement by posting an unapproved tweet last week, which claimed Tesla produced 0 cars in 2011. Musk's shares dipped 3% in response, with analysts warning of potential consequences, including his removal as CEO and a drop in shares. Musk's actions have raised concerns among investors and analysts, with some predicting a worst-case scenario of a $50 decline in shares.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Tuesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 5.58 points to 1,719.00. Losers outnumbered gainers 674 to 285, and volume reached 2.6 billion lots worth RM2.2 billion.

site_title: Olam buys 85% of Indonesia's largest cocoa processor for US$90m
summary: Olam International has acquired 85% of YTS Holdings, a cocoa processing firm in Indonesia, for US$90 million. YTS owns PT Bumitangerang Mesindotama (BT Cocoa), Indonesia's largest cocoa processor. The remaining 15% stake will be held by BT Cocoa's founding members. The deal aims to expand Olam's cocoa platform in Asia. Shares of Olam closed at S$1.98, down four Singapore cents, following the announcement.

site_title: Singapore shares fall 0.3% on Tuesday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index fell 0.33% to 3,261.66 on Tuesday, with losers outnumbering gainers 215 to 185. Technology-linked counters saw significant gains, including AEM Holdings and Hi-P International. Local banks OCBC, United Overseas Bank, and DBS Group also closed in the red.

site_title: KrisEnergy appoints advisers over debt burden, widens Q4 net loss
summary: KrisEnergy appoints advisers to evaluate and implement options to address debt burden and underequitisation. The loss-making firm reported a widened net loss for the fourth quarter, amid lower revenue, asset impairment, and higher depreciation-related costs. Total debt stood at US$459.1 million, with gearing at 99.9%. The company's total equity declined to US$10.1 million, down from US$159.7 million in 2018. KrisEnergy aims to improve liquidity through organic means, but has been unable to do so due to debt service obligations.

site_title: Spain's Iberdrola to speed up investment programme
summary: Iberdrola, Spain's leading global wind producer, plans to accelerate its investment program, with 34 billion euros to be spent from 2020 to 2022. The majority will be allocated to networks and renewables businesses, with 47% for the regulated network business and 40% for green assets. Iberdrola expects core profit to exceed 12 billion euros in 2022, with a projected net profit range of 3.7-3.9 billion euros. The company also maintains its dividend floor at 0.40 euros per share for 2022.

site_title: Europe: Stocks drop as London hit by Brexit delay speculation
summary: European stocks declined in initial trade on Tuesday, with London's FTSE 100 index down 0.7% due to speculation over a possible Brexit delay. The stronger pound weighed on London-listed multinationals, while the eurozone's Frankfurt and Paris indices also fell 0.5% and 0.4%, respectively.

site_title: Sinarmas Land Q4 net profit dives 75%
summary: Sinarmas Land Limited reported a 74.9% drop in Q4 net profit to S$58.6 million, mainly due to the absence of land sales in its Indonesia division and a one-off gain from the divestment of Orchard Towers. Revenue fell 52.7% to S$276.2 million, and earnings per share declined to 1.38 cents. For the full year, net profit decreased 66.4% to S$119 million, and revenue dropped 35.9% to S$864.1 million. The company attributed the decline to one-off sales and the weakening Indonesian rupiah.

site_title: Peugeot makes a comeback in North America
summary: Peugeot is set to make a comeback in North America, with the company planning to start sales by 2026. This move aims to reduce PSA Group's dependence on Europe, where it delivers 80% of its cars. However, the US market is highly competitive, and analysts recommend partnering with an existing brand to succeed. Despite this, PSA has already started engineering its future models to meet US safety and emissions rules, and the company aims to achieve an average automotive return on sales of 4.5% from 2019 to 2021.

site_title: Acma warns of net loss for fiscal 2018
summary: ACMA Ltd expects to report a net loss for the financial year ended Dec 31, 2018, primarily due to a challenging business environment and impairment provisions, mainly related to goodwill. Further details will be provided when the company announces its unaudited results.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end with losses
summary: Hong Kong stocks ended lower on Tuesday, with the Hang Seng Index shedding 0.65% to 28,772.06, following a previous surge. The decline was attributed to investors awaiting fresh developments in the China-US trade standoff. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also fell, with losses of 0.67% and 0.49%, respectively. The market volatility is a result of the ongoing trade tensions between the US and China, affecting global stock markets.

site_title: Diabetics stock up on insulin over Brexit fears
summary: Diabetics in Britain are stockpiling insulin in preparation for a potential no-deal Brexit, which could lead to delays at the border and shortages of the life-saving hormone. With the UK's departure date looming in March, suppliers such as Novo Nordisk and Sanofi have doubled their reserves to ensure a steady supply. Diabetes UK and other groups are urging the government to provide more details on its preparations, as patients fear the consequences of a no-deal Brexit, which could have devastating effects on their health.

site_title: AstraZeneca's Lynparza meets main goal in late-stage pancreatic cancer study
summary: AstraZeneca's cancer drug Lynparza met its primary goal in a late-stage study for a rare type of pancreatic cancer. The study showed that Lynparza delayed the progression of the disease in patients with germline BRCA-mutated metastatic adenocarcinoma of the pancreas. Lynparza, used for ovarian and breast cancers, was successful as a first-line maintenance treatment, potentially leading to higher sales for AstraZeneca. The company plans to discuss the results with regulators worldwide.

site_title: British chemicals firm Croda stockpiling, reviewing ports ahead of Brexit
summary: Croda International Plc, a British specialty chemicals maker, is stockpiling goods in continental Europe ahead of Britain's exit from the European Union. The company is reviewing ports and re-registering UK products sold in the EU to ensure compliance with EU regulations. Despite a 3.8% drop in shares, Croda expects an orderly transition to be manageable, citing 96% of sales and 80% of production outside the UK. Adjusted profit before tax rose 3.5% to £331.85 million, but missed analyst estimates.

site_title: Two men arrested for suspected involvement in Genneva gold buyback scheme
summary: Two men, including the former general manager of Genneva Pte Ltd, have been arrested for their suspected involvement in a gold buyback scheme from 2008 to 2012. The scheme sold gold bars to customers with promised returns of up to 36% per annum, but the company failed to return approximately 640 kg of gold, valued at S$45 million, to its customers. Both men face charges of fraudulent trading and could face up to seven years in prison or a fine of up to S$15,000 if convicted.

site_title: UOL full-year net profit slips 51% on one-off gain in previous year
summary: UOL Group posted a 51% drop in group net profit to S$433.7 million for FY2018, mainly due to a one-off gain from consolidating United Industrial Corporation in FY2017. Excluding this gain, net profit would have risen 26%. Revenue from property development eased 15% and revenue from hotel ownership and operations expanded 29%. The company proposed a 17.5 cents per share dividend for FY2018 and expects land prices to moderate due to property cooling measures.

site_title: Former DBS CFO Jeanette Wong to join UBS board
summary: UBS has announced its board of directors will nominate former DBS CFO Jeanette Wong and former New York Federal Reserve chief William Dudley for election to the board at its annual general meeting on May 2. Past nominees who have joined the board include former private equity adviser Julie Richardson and Hong Kong Monetary Authority CEO Joseph Yam. This nomination marks Wong's entry into the UBS board, following a successful tenure as DBS CFO.

site_title: Aussie, NZ shares end lower as markets seek clarity on Sino-US talks
summary: Australian shares fell 0.9% to 6,128.40, ending a three-session winning streak, due to uncertainty over Sino-US trade talks. Financial stocks led losses, with the big four banks down 0.5-1.2%. Mining stocks also declined, pressured by Chinese demand. New Zealand shares fell 0.2% to 9,323.13, with Westpac and ANZ Banking down 0.6-1%. US President Trump expressed caution over trade talks, stating a deal "could happen fairly soon or not at all".

site_title: French rail bosses allay Eurostar Brexit fears
summary: French rail boss Guillaume Pepy has reassured customers that Eurostar links between France and Britain will remain unaffected by a potential no-deal Brexit. Despite fears of losing automatic validity for UK train licenses, Pepy said "fundamentals" for running Eurostar will remain in place. He acknowledged that "details" need to be ironed out for cross-border formalities, but emphasized that Eurostar will be able to operate correctly regardless of the Brexit scenario.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks dip ahead of Trump-Kim summit; won gains
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index fell 0.27% on Tuesday ahead of the Trump-Kim summit in Hanoi, closing at 2,226.60 points. The won strengthened, and foreigners were net buyers of 20.9 billion won worth of shares. The MSCI's Asia-Pacific shares outside Japan rose 0.91%, while US stocks gained in the previous session.

site_title: European Union mulls new rules on payments in challenge to Visa, Mastercard
summary: The European Commission is considering new rules to speed up the adoption of the European Central Bank's TARGET Instant Payment Settlement (TIPS) system, a European instant payment system launched last year. The system allows for instant transfers of euros, regardless of bank hours, and aims to challenge card firms like Visa and Mastercard. EU Commission Vice-President Valdis Dombrovskis stated that a stronger regulatory push may be needed to accelerate the process.

site_title: A new challenger enters the high-stakes battle for China's coffee drinkers
summary: Tim Hortons, a Canadian coffee-and-doughnut chain, has entered the Chinese market, joining other foreign and local players in a battle for coffee drinkers. The chain, known for its "everyday value" focus, aims to compete with Starbucks and other established brands. Despite the market's relatively small size, with only a third of Chinese consumers buying hot coffee in 2017, Tim Hortons is opening its first Chinese shop in Shanghai. Other chains, including Dunkin', Costa Coffee, and local startup Luckin Coffee, are also vying for market share.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Tuesday afternoon at 3,265.21, down 0.22%
summary: Singapore stocks dropped 0.22% on Tuesday, closing at 3,265.21, with 613.85 million securities changing hands. Genting Singapore fell 0.94% and OCBC Bank declined 0.79%. Best World reversed recent losses, rising 9.05%. The Straits Times Index (STI) has now resumed trading after a brief halt.

site_title: Crisis, what crisis? Qatari love of luxury going strong
summary: Qatari luxury enthusiasts continued to flaunt their wealth at the Doha Jewellery and Watches Exhibition, with many purchasing high-end items despite a regional diplomatic crisis. The event saw over 50,000 attendees, including Bollywood star Aishwarya Rai Bachchan, and featured luxury brands such as Rolex and Vacheron Constantin. Despite concerns over the crisis, sales of luxury watches and jewelry have almost doubled in Qatar, with the country ranking as the top market for luxury watches.

site_title: StanChart aiming for US$700m in cost cuts by 2021
summary: Standard Chartered CEO Bill Winters announced a three-year plan to reduce costs by US$700 million, aiming to turn around the lender and soothe investor concerns. The bank aims to achieve a return on tangible equity of at least 10% by 2021, control risk, and maintain cost growth below inflation. Operations in markets including India and South Korea will be restructured as part of the plan.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks end lower after recent gains
summary: Tokyo stocks closed lower on Tuesday, slipping 0.37% and 0.23% for the Nikkei 225 and Topix indices, respectively. Recent gains fueled by China-US trade optimism were reversed after reports of Indian air strikes in Pakistan-controlled Kashmir. Shares in Sony, Uniqlo, and Fanuc Corp fell, while Toyota and Nissan rose. The dollar fell to 110.80 yen, down from 111.05 yen in New York on Monday. The decline follows a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks and fresh records in the US S&P 500 and Nasdaq.

site_title: Mindfulness may help middle managers avoid burnout: study
summary: A new study found that mindfulness training programs can help middle managers cope with stress and emotional exhaustion, common issues in their jobs. Conducted by an international team of researchers, the study involved 130 middle managers in Finland and found that those who completed an eight-week mindfulness program reported significant reductions in stress levels and emotional exhaustion. Participants also showed increased levels of psychological detachment, suggesting improved well-being. The researchers recommend that organizations offer mindfulness training to prevent chronic stress and burnout, which can have significant costs.

site_title: Singapore factory output shrinks 3.1% in January, first drop in a year
summary: Singapore's manufacturing sector experienced its first contraction in output since December 2017, with a 3.1% decline in January from a year ago. The electronics and precision engineering sectors, key drivers of growth, fell 13.7% and 15.7% respectively. However, the transport engineering cluster showed an increase of 20.2%, driven by growth in the marine and offshore engineering segments. Biomedical manufacturing, which has been a strong performer, rose 10% in January.

site_title: Oxford Road's Kentish Green, District 9's St Thomas Ville try for collective sales again
summary: Kentish Green in District 9 has been put up for collective sale with a S$200 million reserve price. St Thomas Ville, also in District 9, is seeking S$58 million. The sites have potential for increased development parameters, including plot ratio and height, with estimated premiums to top up leases. Tenders for both sites open on Feb 28 and March 27, respectively.

images.alt_text: Kentish Green at 20 Oxford Road has been put up for collective sale with a S$200 million reserve price. Its owners had previously asked for at least S$230 million for the site.

site_title: Beer drinkers set to be next losers from China's trade wars
summary: China's trade probe into barley imports from Australia is expected to lead to a 20% price increase in high-grade barley used to produce malt for beer and whiskey in China this year, according to an equity analyst. This will likely affect beer drinkers in China and globally, particularly those consuming brands like Tsingtao. The price rise is attributed to global trade tensions and reduced supplies due to the probe.

images.alt_text: Beer drinkers in China -- and in Chinese restaurants around the globe that sell brands like Tsingtao -- may end up bearing the cost of a trade probe that's shaking the barley market.

site_title: Car industry will be big 5G customer down the road, says SEAT
summary: SEAT, a Volkswagen-owned carmaker, predicts the automotive industry will be a significant customer for 5G networks, justifying investment in the technology. The company's CEO, Luca de Meo, believes 5G will facilitate innovations such as autonomous driving, car-sharing platforms, and smart traffic management. SEAT plans to develop 5G-connected concept cars and test systems like thermal cameras in traffic lights. The company expects 5G to help develop autonomous driving, with a market worth US$95 billion in 2020, but notes that ethical and infrastructure challenges must be addressed before the market takes off.

site_title: Singtel shares networks with China Mobile in IoT collaboration, partners Microsoft on IoT network cloud services
summary: Singtel has signed a master services agreement with China Mobile International to accelerate enterprise adoption of IoT in the Asia-Pacific region. The partnership will enable seamless deployment of IoT devices across China and Singapore, providing a common management platform and simplified billing. Additionally, Singtel has partnered Microsoft to launch an AI-powered IoT network on the Microsoft Azure cloud computing platform, offering a unified and programmable platform for IoT applications.

site_title: JTC launches tender of Tampines North industrial site
summary: JTC has launched a tender for a 0.48-hectare industrial site in Tampines North Drive 3 under the 2019 Industrial Government Land Sales Programme. The site has a gross plot ratio of 2.5 and a 20-year tenure, zoned for heavy industries with a greater environmental impact. The tender will close on April 23 at 11am, as part of the government's efforts to offer more industrial development choices. This is the second of five confirmed list sites for the first half of the 2019 programme.

site_title: Hot stock: Shares of Hi-P International surge as brokers signal confidence
summary: Shares of Hi-P International surged 13.71% as brokers upgraded their confidence in the stock amid the US-China trade war. Following Maybank Kim Eng's "hold" and DBS's "hold" upgrades with higher target prices, the company's Q4 2018 results showed stronger-than-expected performance. Analysts attributed Hi-P's ability to secure more projects and mitigate pricing pressure to its success in the mobile and consumer electronics segments, leading to increased earnings estimates for FY2019-2020.

site_title: How Hong Kong's property slump could clobber the economy
summary: Hong Kong's property market is experiencing a slump, with home values falling 9% from their August peak due to the China-U.S. trade war and potential rate hikes. Experts forecast a further 15% drop in 2019. The downturn could have a significant impact on the city's economy, with concerns about consumer confidence and potential effects on the overall market. If the downturn worsens, it could have far-reaching consequences, including decreased investment and spending.

site_title: Maybank beats view with highest quarterly profit in 2 years
summary: Malayan Banking Bhd (Maybank) reported a 9.1% rise in quarterly net profit to RM2.33 billion, its highest profit in two years, beating analyst estimates. The bank's net interest income rose 2.85% and Islamic banking income surged 21.4%. Revenue increased 3.7% to RM12.23 billion, driven by higher net earned insurance premiums. Maybank attributed its performance to moderating global growth and a focus on corporate lending growth in Indonesia. The bank plans to maintain its balance sheet expansion in line with forecast economic growth.

images.alt_text: Malayan Banking Bhd (Maybank) beat expectations with a 9.1 per cent rise in quarterly net profit, its highest profit in two years, as Islamic banking income soared and net interest income grew for Malaysia's largest lender.

site_title: Samsung and Huawei double down on Apple's high-price phone strategy
summary: Samsung and Huawei have joined forces with Apple in pricing high-end smartphones above $1,000. The latest premium iPhones from Apple cost up to $1,450, while Samsung's folding phone costs $1,980 and Huawei's costs $2,600. This strategy, dubbed "price squeezing," aims to maximize cash from stagnant unit sales, but has hurt Apple, which reported a 15% decline in iPhone revenue in the first fiscal quarter. The trend may push phone prices beyond laptop costs, further increasing the gap between premium and budget devices.

site_title: Co-living company Hmlet expanding into Sydney, Australia
summary: Hmlet, a Singapore-based co-living company, is expanding into Sydney, Australia with the launch of two co-living properties in Newtown and Marrickville. The properties will accommodate 20 and 70 members, respectively, and feature co-working spaces, communal living and kitchen areas. Hmlet aims to quadruple its number of members across Asia-Pacific by the end of 2019, following a US$6.5 million funding round. The move follows growing demand for flexible, community-based living options in Australian cities, where millennials are increasingly seeking hassle-free living arrangements.

site_title: Australian, New Zealand dollars hold gains as Sino-US talks advance
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars consolidated gains as signs of progress in the Sino-US trade dispute boosted the Chinese economy and commodity prices. The Aussie dollar hovered at US$0.7164, while the kiwi dollar was firm at US$0.6880. US President Donald Trump said he may soon sign a deal to end the trade war, causing markets to rally. Chinese shares climbed 6% and commodities, including copper, reached their highest in nearly eight months.

site_title: British opposition raises prospect of second Brexit referendum
summary: The UK's main opposition Labour Party has expressed support for a second Brexit referendum, potentially changing the country's exit from the European Union. The move comes as the European Union considers postponing the March 29 deadline, amid concerns about a no-deal Brexit. Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn stated that if the party's plan to stay in the EU customs union is rejected, it will support an amendment for a second referendum. This development could further deepen divisions in the country and prolong Brexit uncertainty.

site_title: How many pushups can you do? It may be a good predictor of heart health
summary: A new study published in JAMA Network Open suggests that pushup ability may be a reliable predictor of heart health in men. Researchers analyzed data from over 1,500 Indiana firefighters and found that those who could complete 40 or more pushups had a 96% lower risk of heart problems in the next decade compared to those who could complete 10 or fewer. The study's findings indicate that pushup capability may be a simple and effective way to assess cardiovascular health, potentially serving as a DIY method for evaluating heart health.

site_title: Air New Zealand slashes domestic fares to address softening market
summary: Air New Zealand slashes its domestic fares by up to 50% on 41 routes, effective March 25, to address a softening travel market. The move aims to increase bookings and revenue growth. The airline's CEO, Christopher Luxon, described it as the biggest overhaul of its domestic pricing structure in over a decade. The price cut will see over 750,000 seats a year priced under NZ$50. The move comes after Air New Zealand lowered its profit outlook by 30% last month due to weaker tourism and domestic leisure travel.

site_title: Trump, Kim summit to cover two days: White House
summary: US President Donald Trump and North Korean leader Kim Jong Un will meet for dinner on Wednesday in Hanoi, Vietnam, before their talks on Thursday. The two-day summit aims to persuade Kim to scrap his nuclear capability. Trump will be accompanied by Secretary of State Mike Pompeo and acting chief of staff Mick Mulvaney, while Kim will be accompanied by two of his officials. The meeting is part of Trump's diplomatic mission to end the half-century standoff with North Korea.

site_title: American businesses in China see gloomy year ahead
summary: US businesses in China forecast a gloomy year ahead due to deteriorating bilateral trade ties and nearly a quarter delaying investments. 89% of businesses reported a pessimistic view on the US-China trade relationship, citing tariffs, increased costs, and regulatory scrutiny. Nearly two-thirds said tensions affected their market plans, causing 25% to delay further investments. Market access and intellectual property protection remain concerns, with 3/4 of companies citing market access as a problem.

site_title: Grinning Kim arrives in Hanoi for summit
summary: North Korean leader Kim Jong Un arrived in Hanoi on Tuesday, marking his first visit to Vietnam and the first time a North Korean leader has visited since Kim Il Sung in 1964. Kim, accompanied by his sister Kim Yo Jong and aide Kim Chang Son, was greeted with a military band and press at Dong Dang train station, before being whisked away to a waiting black Mercedes-Benz. The visit is seen as a message of unity with his grandfather, who was a close ally of Vietnam's revolutionary leader Ho Chi Minh, and aims to strengthen economic ties with Vietnam.

site_title: Chinese county halts shale gas mining amid quake fears: Xinhua
summary: A county in southwestern China's Sichuan province has halted shale gas mining amid concerns it may have contributed to an earthquake that killed two people and injured 12 others. The magnitude 4.9 quake occurred in Rongxian county on Monday, damaging thousands of buildings and affecting over 13,000 people. Experts suggest natural causes may have triggered the earthquake, but industrial mining could not be ruled out. The county government suspended mining work due to safety concerns, following protests by residents who demanded a halt to shale gas exploitation.

site_title: Sinjia Land narrows full-year loss to S$3.5m
summary: Sinjia Land narrowed its full-year net loss to S$3.5 million from S$7.7 million in the previous year, driven by higher revenue and the absence of losses from discontinued operations. Revenue rose 11% to S$526,000, mainly due to increased visitor arrivals. Despite this, the company reported a gross loss of S$21,000, mainly due to increased labor costs. The firm remains cautious about market challenges in fiscal 2019 and will focus on its property-related businesses.

site_title: Guinea's untapped iron ore riches are back in the spotlight
summary: Guinea's iron ore riches are poised for development after a seven-year-old dispute with billionaire Beny Steinmetz over the Simandou iron ore project is resolved. The project, if successful, could produce 150 million tons of high-quality iron ore per year, catapulting Guinea into the top ranks. The estimated $20 billion project would be built with a 650-kilometer railway to export iron ore from a local port. This could mark a huge comeback for mining veteran Mick Davis, who has been unsuccessful in developing other projects in the country.

site_title: Gojek partners Gigacover to launch earnings protection insurance scheme for its drivers
summary: Gojek has partnered with Gigacover to launch an earnings protection insurance scheme for its drivers in Singapore. The scheme, set to take effect on April 1, 2019, provides drivers with coverage of S$80 per day for up to 21 days of medical leave and 84 days of hospitalization leave. Drivers can qualify by paying a subsidised monthly rate to Gigacover, with "top active drivers" receiving free coverage paid for by Gojek. The partnership aims to provide peace of mind for drivers and is part of Gojek's efforts to support its driver-partners.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 0.58 points to 1,725.16 at 9am on Tuesday, with a trading volume of 47.1 million lots worth RM22.81 million. Losers beat gainers 107 to 76, marking a mixed session.

site_title: Asia: Markets down after trade-fuelled surge, sterling gains
summary: Asian markets declined on Tuesday, following a day of gains driven by trade talks, after investors struggled to maintain momentum. The pound rose further after reports of a possible Brexit delay, while oil prices dropped due to US President Donald Trump's calls for Opec to cut prices. Analysts warn that a deal may not be reached, and that a failure to meet market expectations could lead to a sharp drop in global equities. Markets in Shanghai, Hong Kong, and Tokyo also fell, with Sydney and Singapore experiencing significant declines.

site_title: Amazon to offer more than 1,000 apprenticeships in Britain
summary: Amazon plans to create over 1,000 apprenticeships in Britain over the next two years, adding to its 27,500 permanent employees. The move comes despite concerns about Brexit's impact on the country's retailers. The apprentices will work across various Amazon sites, including its UK head office and development centers, focusing on innovations like Alexa and Prime Air. This investment indicates Amazon's commitment to the UK despite uncertainty surrounding the country's departure from the European Union.

site_title: Shanghai: Stocks build on rally at open
summary: Shanghai stocks rose 0.26% at the open, extending the previous day's 5.60% surge on optimism about China-US trade talks. The Shanghai Composite Index gained 7.82 points to 2,969.10, while Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index edged up 11.93 points to 28,971.23. The rally was seen as a positive sign for markets despite ongoing trade tensions, with investors focusing on potential progress in US-China talks.

site_title: Trump departs US for Vietnam, summit with North Korea's Kim
summary: US President Donald Trump departed Washington on Monday for a second historic summit with North Korean leader Kim Jong Un in Vietnam, aiming to push for Korean denuclearization. Trump described the summit as "very tremendous" and emphasized the importance of denuclearization, while also stating that sanctions would remain in place. The two leaders last met in Singapore eight months ago, where they signed a largely symbolic joint agreement. Trump expressed optimism that the summit would lead to something "very good," despite tempered expectations of a major breakthrough.

site_title: Singapore shares decline at Tuesday's open; STI down 0.11% to 3,268.67
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index fell 0.11% to 3,268.67 on Tuesday, as the market opened lower. The decline was attributed to a decrease in Oceanus Group's shares, while other stocks like DBS Group Holdings and United Overseas Bank rose. The evenly matched gains and losses were driven by 23.5 million securities worth S$48.9 million changing hands.

site_title: World's largest Nutella factory reopens after 'quality defect'
summary: The world's largest Nutella factory in Normandy, France, reopened after a five-day pause due to a suspected quality defect. The factory, which produces around 600,000 jars of Nutella daily, had stopped production on Wednesday. The issue was found to be a problem with grinding and roasting hazelnuts, but no products currently on the market were impacted. Ferrero France, the owner, assured that the supply to customers continued without interruption, and the factory is now at 100% production capacity.

site_title: US financial regulatory agency says Musk violated deal
summary: The US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) has accused Tesla founder Elon Musk of violating a court-endorsed deal, which required his tweets to be reviewed prior to publication. Musk's tweet on Tesla's 2019 production levels, which stated the company made 0 cars in 2011 but would make 500,000 in 2019, was deemed inaccurate and disseminated to over 24 million people without pre-approval. The SEC alleges Musk's tweet violates the deal, which was agreed upon in a previous court case.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on trade talks progress, cheaper yen
summary: Tokyo stocks rose on Tuesday, tracking overseas market gains, following optimism over US-China trade talks. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index added 0.10% and the Topix index gained 0.04% after US President Donald Trump said discussions were in an "advanced stage." The dollar fetched 111.04 yen, a cheaper rate, supporting Japanese stocks. Investors are optimistic that the dispute will not escalate immediately, boosting global markets.

site_title: Flower sector fears Brexit could nip exports in the bud
summary: A UK flower sector business owner, Sam Taylor, expresses concerns about potential Brexit delays affecting imports and exports, particularly his fresh flower shipments to the Netherlands. Taylor fears delays could cause his flowers to spoil, resulting in lost sales and potentially ending his imports of bulbs from Europe. With Brexit set to occur in less than five weeks, Taylor calls for clarity from British MPs to avoid disruptions to his business.

site_title: Sinwa to distribute special dividend totalling S$64.8m after assets selloff
summary: Sinwa, a marine supply and logistics company, announced it will distribute a special dividend of S$64.8 million after selling six subsidiaries for S$74.9 million. The company made a profit of S$15.2 million from the sale, using the funds to pay the dividend. With most assets being cash, Sinwa is now classified as a cash company by Singapore Exchange rules. The company reported a net profit of S$10.2 million and revenue of S$80,000 in its 2018 full-year results.

site_title: JEP Holdings fiscal 2018 profit up 2.7 times to S$2.2m on lower administrative costs
summary: JEP Holdings reported a net profit of S$2.2 million for fiscal 2018, up 2.7 times from S$825,000 the previous year, driven by lower administrative expenses. Revenue declined 0.3% to S$85.9 million, but the precision manufacturing segment saw higher revenue. Administrative expenses decreased 27.5% to S$6.3 million, and cost of sales decreased 3.8% to S$73.2 million. The company remains optimistic about its aerospace segment, while the oil and gas segment is uncertain.

site_title: After abuse summit, victims press Vatican for action
summary: Victims of child sexual abuse by Catholic priests are pressuring the Vatican for concrete action following a historic summit on the issue. Pope Francis promised an "all-out battle" against the scourge, but victims' groups say his words were insufficient and demanded more tangible progress. Campaigners have outlined a 21-point plan of action, including permanent removal from the priesthood for abusers and public lists of past and present offenders. The Vatican has announced an interministerial meeting on protecting minors, but critics say more needs to be done to address the Church's reputation and protect vulnerable children.

site_title: Iran's foreign minister, architect of nuclear deal, says he is resigning
summary: Iran's Foreign Minister Mohammad Javad Zarif has announced his resignation, citing "shortcomings" during his service. Zarif, a key architect of the 2015 nuclear deal, had been a vocal critic of US President Donald Trump's withdrawal from the agreement. His resignation, which must be accepted by President Hassan Rouhani, comes amid escalating tensions between hard-liners and Rouhani. The move is seen as a potential blow to Rouhani's job, as Zarif was a key diplomat in negotiations with the West.

site_title: ISEC Healthcare Q4 profit up 10%; declares special dividend of 0.98 S cent/share
summary: ISEC Healthcare reported a 10% rise in Q4 net profit to $2.3 million, driven by strong demand for specialist eye care services. Revenue increased 10% to $10.5 million, while earnings per share rose 10% to 0.45 Singapore cents. For the full year, earnings rose 6% to $8.4 million and revenue climbed 9% to $40.44 million. The company announced a special dividend of 0.98 Singapore cent per share, subject to shareholder approval at its annual general meeting on April 24.

site_title: Immune cell gene therapy startup Gracell raises US$85m in Temasek-led series B round
summary: Gracell Biotechnologies, an immune cell gene therapy startup, has raised US$85 million in a series B round led by Temasek Holdings.
