The funds will be used to enter clinical trials for several next-generation candidates. Gracell has already completed pre-clinical development of low-cost CAR T therapy products and plans to advance several products to Investigational New Drug filings. The company aims to develop high-quality, low-cost cellular gene therapies for cancer patients, with a goal to overcome industry-wide technical difficulties.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Sheng Siong, Procurri, Propnex, JEP, Bumitama Agri, UE, ISEC Healthcare
summary: Stocks to watch on Tuesday included Aspial Corp's net profit of S$28.35 million for the three months ended Dec 31, Bumitama Agri's 43% fall in fourth-quarter net profit, Ho Bee Land's 20.5% fall in fourth-quarter net profit due to a S$20.3 million tax provision, ISEC Healthcare's 6% increase in full-year net profit, JEP Holdings' net profit of S$2.2 million for the full year, Procurri Corp's reversal into the black for its fourth-quarter net profit, PropNex's near 58% year-on-year drop in fourth-quarter net profit, and Sheng Siong Group's 4.2% increase in fourth-quarter net profit.

site_title: Paris fashion week begins under Lagerfeld's shadow
summary: Paris fashion week began on Monday, with a somber mood following Karl Lagerfeld's death last week. Virginie Viard, his right-hand woman at Chanel, will present her final collection on March 5, although it's unclear how much of the collection was created by Lagerfeld. The show marks a significant change in leadership, with Viard taking the reins at the iconic label. The event comes as fashionistas and industry professionals pay tribute to Lagerfeld's legacy, with Viard's collection serving as a tribute to his work.

site_title: Two US Navy ships sail through Taiwan Strait
summary: The US Navy sailed two ships, the USS Stethem destroyer and the USNS Cesar Chavez cargo ship, through the Taiwan Strait on Sunday, in a "routine transit" that has upset China. The US views the route as international waters, while China sees Taiwan as part of its territory. This is the latest in a series of US Navy ship transits through the strait, which Beijing considers a breach of sovereignty. The US has committed to flying, sailing, and operating in the region in accordance with international law.

site_title: ECB fines Russia's Sberbank over risk exposure
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) has fined Sberbank Europe AG, a Russian lender's European arm, 630,000 euros for breaching limits on risk exposure. The bank exceeded the 25% limit on risk linked to one client or group of clients, as per the large exposure requirement. The bank has two months to appeal the decision. This is the ECB's first fine on a major financial institution since 2014, following a post-crisis overhaul of EU banking rules.

site_title: Bank of America drops 'Merrill Lynch' name in rebranding effort
summary: Bank of America is dropping the "Merrill Lynch" name from some of its businesses as part of a multi-year rebranding effort. The investment bank and capital markets business will become BofA Securities, while wealth management businesses will be called "Merrill." Individual units will retain their names, and the firm will launch a new marketing campaign featuring the "Merrill" brand. The change aims to boost morale in the investment bank, which has faced declining market share and revenue, as well as senior departures.

site_title: Forging tomorrow's new global enterprise
summary: Singapore's Budget 2019 aims to catalyze the growth of global, differentiated, and competitive SMEs in the face of global uncertainty. The government has set aside S$19 billion for a five-year Research, Innovation, and Enterprise 2020 plan to support innovation and digitalization. SMEs will also have access to the "SMEs Go Digital" programme and Professional Conversion Programmes to upskill manpower. The government recognizes the importance of partnerships in gaining wider domestic and global market access, and SMEs can tap into the Local Enterprise and Association Development (LEAD) and Partnerships for Capability Transformation (PACT) programmes to strike up partnerships.

site_title: India lowers tax on new home sales ahead of general election
summary: India's GST Council has reduced tax rates on new home sales, cutting the rate to 5% for non-affordable housing projects and 1% for affordable housing. The move aims to stimulate the economy ahead of the general election by May. The change is effective from April 1, and it also alters the definition of affordable housing for secondary cities. The goal is to boost housing consumption and provide relief to home buyers.

site_title: US: Stocks rise on China trade talks progress
summary: US stocks rose on Monday, closing 0.2% higher on renewed optimism about a potential US-China trade deal. The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished at 26,091.95, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index edged up 0.1% and 0.4% respectively. US President Donald Trump extended the March 1 deadline for a trade deal, postponing a sharp increase in tariffs on Chinese goods. Optimism over a trade accord has lifted the S&P 500 19% since December 24.

site_title: Europe: Trade tariff reprieve triggers relief in shares
summary: US President Donald Trump delays a tariff increase on Chinese goods, triggering relief in European shares. The Stoxx 600 rose 0.3% and Germany's DAX climbed 0.4%. Auto shares jumped 2.1% as carmakers benefited from the reprieve. However, some investors remain cautious, citing concerns about the overall deal. Disappointing earnings reports and mergers also affected shares, with Bank of Ireland and Covestro falling 3.1% and 3.2% respectively.

site_title: Lima Group urges ICC to declare Venezuela aid blockade 'crime against humanity'
summary: The Lima Group, comprising 14 Latin American countries and Canada, has urged the International Criminal Court to declare Venezuela President Nicolas Maduro's refusal to allow humanitarian aid a "crime against humanity." The group, led by opposition leader Juan Guaido, rejected the use of force for a democratic transition and instead advocated for a peaceful transition supported by international law. The move comes amid a severe humanitarian crisis in Venezuela, with shortages of food and medicine exacerbated by hyperinflation. The group also condemned "serious and credible threats" against Guaido.

site_title: Paris gets in breakdance groove ahead of 2024 Olympic bow
summary: Paris has welcomed the world of breakdancing with a 4,000-strong crowd at the Battle Pro event, ahead of its Olympic debut at the 2024 Paris Games. The breakdancing community hopes the Olympic inclusion will dispel negative stereotypes, showcasing its artistic and athletic side. Paris 2024 chief Tony Estanguet announced the sport's inclusion last Thursday, joining skateboarding, sport climbing, and surfing on the Olympic program. The International Olympic Committee will still need to rubberstamp the choice, but breakdancing has already made a splash at the 2018 Youth Olympics.

site_title: Markets rally on news of tariff delay
summary: Global markets rallied on news of a tariff delay between the US and China, with China, Japan, and Australia ending the day higher. However, the rally was short-lived in some markets, including South Korea and Singapore, which closed flat. Analysts attribute the muted reaction to regional markets to skepticism over trade issues and the possibility that a trade resolution may not benefit peripheral countries as much as China. Key economic data releases this week may also impact the Singapore Stock Exchange (STI).

site_title: Best World shares fall 18.45% in heavy volume as trading resumes
summary: Best World International shares plummeted 18.45% in heavy trading to close at S$2.21 on Monday, following a five-day halt. The company, which has been expanding rapidly in China, will conduct an independent review of its business and accounting practices amid questions from The Business Times about its franchisee operations in China. Best World has denied any wrongdoing and will release its fourth-quarter results on Tuesday.

site_title: Acra to overhaul portal after rogue agents misused services
summary: The Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority (Acra) in Singapore is overhauling its corporate services platform after breaches involving unauthorised access to business information. Registered filing agents had wide-ranging access to the BizFile+ database, allowing them to view or lodge documents for companies not their clients. Despite this, there were only two confirmed cases of breaches since 2015. Acra will introduce measures in the second half of the year to restrict access to only their clients.

images.alt_text: The Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority (Acra) will introduce measures in the second half of the year to ensure that registered filing agents carry out transactions on behalf of only their own clients, a spokesperson told The Business Times.

site_title: Bumitama Agri Q4 earnings down 43% to 207b rupiah
summary: Bumitama Agri Ltd reported a 43% decline in Q4 net profit to 207.37 billion rupiah, mainly due to weakening agriculture commodity prices. Despite a 7% increase in revenue, foreign exchange losses and losses on fair value changes contributed to the decline. The company expects higher CPO prices to mitigate lower production in the first quarter, and will focus on strengthening business strategies and cost management.

site_title: Oil falls more than 3% as Trump blames Opec for 'too high' prices
summary: US President Donald Trump's tweet calling on Opec to ease efforts to boost crude prices led to a 3% drop in oil prices, with Brent crude futures falling $2.36 to $64.76 a barrel and US crude falling $1.78 to $55.48 a barrel. The comments halted momentum from Friday's session, where oil prices reached three-month highs. Trump's tweet was seen as an attempt to micromanage oil production, while Opec members may view it as emboldening their efforts to reduce supply.

site_title: UK bank CEOs paid 120 times their staff's median pay
summary: UK bank CEOs are paid an average of 120 times more than their median UK employees, with Lloyds Banking Group's CEO Antonio Horta-Osorio earning £6.3 million, 169 times the median employee's £37,058. HSBC's new CEO John Flint received £4.6 million, 118 times the median employee's pay. The pay disparities are under scrutiny, with new reporting requirements coming into force next year. Despite this, Lloyds has announced a minimum salary of £17,500 for full-time staff, a 9.9% raise.

site_title: HMD Global launches Nokia smartphone with 5-camera array
summary: HMD Global has launched the Nokia 9 PureView, a smartphone featuring a 5-camera array, targeting camera enthusiasts. The device, priced at $699, is part of a range of new smartphones announced, including entry-level and mid-level handsets with Android One operating system. The company aims to appeal to users in emerging markets with devices offering good value and simplicity. Analysts predict Nokia's affordable prices and innovative features will attract hundreds of millions of smartphone buyers in India and China.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Brokers upgraded Hutchison Port Holdings Trust to "hold" from "sell" due to a potential US-China trade deal, which could boost investor sentiment and reduce throughput volume decline risks. HRNetGroup Ltd maintained its "buy" rating, citing an attractive ex-cash price/earnings ratio, despite slower economic growth forecasts. Both companies' target prices remain unchanged at US$0.22 and S$1.05, respectively.

site_title: Soilbuild flags Q4, full-year loss from S$1.4m arbitration award against unit
summary: Soilbuild Construction Group has flagged a loss for its fourth-quarter and financial year ended Dec 31, mainly due to an arbitration award of S$1.4 million against its wholly-owned subsidiary, Soil-Build (Pte) Ltd. The arbitrator ruled the subcontractor is not liable for damages, instead, Soil-Build must pay the subcontractor the remaining amount. This will be recognized as an additional cost of sales for the quarter and year, and the company is assessing other associated project costs. Further details on its financial performance will be disclosed in its unaudited consolidated financial results on Feb 27.

site_title: United Engineers full-year net profit falls 36% on weaker revenue
summary: United Engineers reported a 36% fall in full-year net profit to S$55.76 million due to weaker revenue, down 29% to S$374.9 million. The firm attributed the decline to lower revenue from property development and the absence of contribution from a divested business. The company proposed a lower dividend per ordinary share of three Singapore cents, compared to four cents previously. It also flagged potential impacts from US-China trade tensions and Singapore's property cooling measures on its business.

site_title: In pursuit of Services 4.0 - a Singapore perspective
summary: Singapore's services sector, which accounts for 72% of the nation's GDP, is evolving towards "Services 4.0," a concept that combines emerging technologies such as AI, Mixed Reality, and blockchain to create seamless, empathic, and anticipatory customer experiences. To thrive in this ecosystem, businesses must re-engineer their service delivery model and work with machines to unlock new value. The government has launched a roadmap to achieve Services 4.0, with nine innovative approaches to be implemented over the next three to five years, including shortening value chains and harnessing network effects.

site_title: Frasers Property associate makes 19.75b baht offer for Golden Land
summary: Frasers Property (Thailand) Public Company is making a conditional voluntary tender offer for all issued securities of Golden Land Property Development for approximately 19.75 billion baht, with an offer price of 8.50 baht per share. The move is part of Frasers Property's strategy to expand into adjacent businesses and build an integrated real estate platform. The acquisition is expected to generate revenue in excess of 20 billion baht and total assets in excess of 80 billion baht post-transaction. The combined platform will have multi-segment capabilities across logistics, industrial, and commercial space value chains.

site_title: Voter rolls updated, open for checking till March 11
summary: Singapore's voter rolls have been updated and are now open for public inspection until March 11. Eligible citizens can check their particulars online or in person at various locations. Those who have been omitted or want to update their details can submit claims, while those who wish to have their names removed can submit objections. The registers will be revised every three years, with the next update due before the 2021 general election.

site_title: Chinese firm behind the 'Amazon Coat' hits jackpot in US
summary: Chinese firm Orolay, behind the popular "Amazon Coat" puffer jacket, has seen significant success with sales reaching $5 million in January and expected to reach $30-$40 million this year. The company's success is attributed to Amazon's measures allowing overseas vendors to sell on its site, despite concerns from US sellers about being undercut by Chinese merchants. Orolay's prices range from $80 to $139, making them a competitor to premium brand Canada Goose, which starts at $575.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: ST Engineering signed a $600 million contract with a North American operator for aircraft heavy maintenance services starting in 2020 for 10 years. Sheng Siong Group posted a 4.2% increase in fourth-quarter net profit to $17.53 million. Ryobi Kiso failed to reach an agreement with creditors over proposed schemes of arrangement for the group's liabilities and business. TEE International entered into a term sheet with Top Capital Securities for the sale of a 28% stake in its subsidiary TEE Land at an indicative price of $0.179-$0.201 per share.

site_title: EGM to oust Pine Capital directors to take place at later date
summary: The board of Pine Capital, a Catalist-listed investment firm, stated that a requisition notice from three shareholders to oust its directors was not duly served and is invalid. The notice sought to convene an EGM to remove executive chairman Tan Choon Wee and independent directors Roy Ling Chung Yee and Chong Chee Hoong. The requisitioning shareholders own 51.94% of Pine Capital's shares, but the board claims the notice was not properly served, rendering it invalid. The EGM is now expected to take place at a later date.

site_title: Aspial full-year profit jumps on property sales
summary: Aspial Corporation's full-year net profit jumped to S$28.35 million, a 1,215% increase from the previous year, driven by a surge in revenue from its real estate business. Revenue from the real estate segment rose 84% to S$898.5 million, mainly due to the recognition of sales from the CityGate project and the settlement of completed residential units in Melbourne. The company expects the real estate business to contribute significantly to revenue and profitability in 2019 and 2020.

site_title: Corporate bond markets haunted by elevated risks: OECD
summary: The Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) warns that corporate bond markets are haunted by elevated risks and vulnerabilities due to a decade of cheap money policies. The amount of corporate bonds in circulation has doubled to $13 trillion, with $4 trillion in repayments or refinancing needed over the next three years. This coincides with a slowing global economy, changing monetary policy, and record sovereign debt borrowing, potentially creating a vicious circle that could amplify the effects of a downturn. Ratings for investment-grade bonds have fallen to historical lows.

site_title: Biden biding his time
summary: Former US Vice President Joe Biden may run for the 2020 Democratic presidential nomination, potentially altering the outcome of the 2016 election. Many believe he would have won the nomination and the presidency, preventing Donald Trump's election. Biden's down-to-earth persona and ability to connect with working-class Americans could have reversed the "deplorables" in key rust-belt states like Pennsylvania, Michigan, and Ohio. If true, this would have changed the course of US history, with Biden occupying the White House instead of Trump.

images.alt_text: Mr Biden, who once said that he would "beat the hell" out of The Donald if they were both in high school now, has the best chance of trouncing Mr Trump.

site_title: Raffles Medical's full-year earnings rise 0.4% to S$71.1m
summary: Raffles Medical Group reported a net profit of S$71.1 million for 2018, up 0.4% from 2017. Revenue rose 2.4% to S$489.1 million, driven by a 6% increase in healthcare services revenue. The group proposed a final dividend of 2.5 Singapore cents per share, down from 4.02 Singapore cents in 2017. Raffles Medical Group expects to grow revenue and remain profitable in 2019, despite the anticipated startup loss for Raffles Hospital Chongqing.

site_title: Sembmarine bags deals worth S$175m for vessel construction, repair and upgrades
summary: Sembcorp Marine has secured S$175 million worth of contracts for designing and constructing a liquefied natural gas (LNG) bunker vessel and repairing 13 cruise ships. The LNG vessel will be built in Singapore and will have a capacity of 12,000 cubic meters. The contracts are expected to contribute positively to the company's earnings but are not expected to impact its net tangible assets and earnings per share for the year. The company has also completed 115 cruise ship refits in the past decade.

site_title: Green Book denies Netflix top Oscar
summary: Green Book won the Oscar for Best Picture, denying Netflix its first major Hollywood victory. The film, a road trip movie about an unlikely friendship between a black pianist and his white driver, won four Oscars, including Best Director for Alfonso Cuaron's Roma, which won two other Oscars. Olivia Colman won Best Actress for her role in The Favourite, while Rami Malek won Best Actor for Bohemian Rhapsody. The ceremony also saw wins for Lady Gaga's song "Shallow" and a diverse group of winners, including Mahershala Ali, Regina King, and Spike Lee.

site_title: China has met debt control target as it ramps up economic support
summary: China has met its debt control target, stabilizing its leverage level after a 10% average annual growth in 2018. The country's banking regulator has urged banks to increase lending to smaller firms, aiming to revive weak credit growth and avoid a sharper economic slowdown. To achieve this, the regulator has ordered banks to sharply increase lending to private companies, with a 30% increase in loans to smaller firms for state-owned banks. This move aims to contain financial risks and promote economic growth.

site_title: Changing hands
summary: NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed. US stocks opened lower following President Trump's fresh tariff salvo on Canada. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and operating loss in H2, similar to H1. London's Heathrow is considering higher fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case. OCBC announced Tan Teck Long as its incoming CEO, replacing a DBS veteran. MAS and PBOC are expanding cooperation on green and transition finance, ahead of Singapore's GDP data release.

site_title: Thai AirAsia owner in talks to buy stake in rival Nok Air
summary: Thai AirAsia owner, Asia Aviation PCL, is in talks to buy a stake in rival Nok Airlines PCL, amid a tourism boom in Thailand that has increased competition among carriers. The potential deal comes after Nok Air reported a loss in its last profitable quarter in 2015. Asia Aviation's CEO has not specified how much of Nok Air it would buy, but the move is seen as an attempt to stem the decline in the airline industry.

site_title: Peace Centre/Peace Mansion in 5th attempt at collective sale
summary: The owners of Peace Centre/Peace Mansion in Singapore have put the prime mixed development site up for tender for the fifth time, with a reserve price of S$688 million (S$1,474 per square foot per plot ratio). The site, zoned for commercial use, has a verified gross plot ratio of 7.89 and may be redeveloped up to 55 meters above mean sea level. A new development could yield 362,747 sq ft of retail/commercial space and 241,831 sq ft of residential units, with a lease top-up application expected to be approved soon.

site_title: Fiat's late CEO Marchionne given US$54m in pay, perks for year he died
summary: Fiat Chrysler Automobile NV's late CEO Sergio Marchionne received a total of US$54 million in compensation, perks, and shares in 2018, the year he died. The majority of the payment came from 2.8 million shares granted under a performance-based award, totaling US$42 million. He also received a US$5.2 million bonus for 2017 and US$2.3 million in salary, but not a bonus for 2018. Additionally, Fiat Chrysler paid US$5 million for Marchionne's insurance and tax-related expenses.

site_title: Unilever, L'Oreal, Danone deemed most ready for climate change
summary: Unilever, L'Oreal, and Danone, the world's largest consumer companies, are best prepared for climate change, according to a report by the CDP. The companies ranked high in measures including exposure to emissions, water use, and climate governance. The report assumes businesses will adjust to climate change effects to protect their bottom line and appeal to concerned consumers.

site_title: The Fed will hike again - because it can
summary: The US Federal Reserve is expected to hike interest rates again due to its ability to do so, rather than concerns about financial stability. Despite recent financial market volatility, inflation remains under control, and household savings rates remain high, indicating consumers are less vulnerable to market fluctuations. The Fed can afford to wait before normalizing monetary policy, and its decision to pause rate hikes may be a precursor to further increases. The author believes the Fed will deliver two more rate hikes in the coming months due to resilient economic fundamentals.

site_title: Intel aiming beyond phones with 5G technology
summary: Intel announces plans to expand its 5G technology beyond selling modems to phone makers, targeting carmakers and manufacturers for connected vehicles and industrial equipment. The company aims to sell its chips in various networking gear, including modules and gateways for industrial equipment, and has reached deals with network gear makers and Ericsson and ZTE Corp to use its processors in 5G base stations. Intel's CEO, Bob Swan, believes the company has caught up with its competitors and is now poised for growth in the 5G market.

site_title: CapitaLand tops out Raffles City Chongqing
summary: CapitaLand has topped out the 1.12 million sq m Raffles City Chongqing project in China, marking a milestone for the 250-metre high sky bridge, The Crystal, the world's highest. The development, located on the historic Chaotianmen site, is on track to open in the second half of 2019. As of now, 72% of the 772 residential units have been sold, and the five-storey shopping mall has secured 450 retailers. The project will feature 150,000 sq m of Grade A office space, an Ascott serviced residence, and an InterContinental hotel.

site_title: Ho Bee Land's Q4 net profit falls 20.5% to S$81.4m
summary: Ho Bee Land's Q4 net profit fell 20.5% to S$81.4m due to a provision for a potential tax liability of S$20.3m related to the sale of Hotel Windsor in 2013. Revenue jumped 22.8% to S$147.9m, driven by higher rental revenue and a net fair value gain of S$93m on investment properties. The company is recommending a 10 cents per share dividend and warned of headwinds from global economic uncertainty, including the US-China trade war and Brexit.

site_title: Vietnam Air may buy up to 100 Boeing 737 Max jets
summary: Vietnam Airlines is considering ordering 50-100 Boeing 737 Max jets to replace its aging fleet, with deliveries set to occur between 2020 and 2030. The airline may also purchase long-range jets to facilitate flights to Los Angeles or San Francisco. CEO Duong Tri Thanh stated that the order will be submitted to the government, with a potential value of $6.1 billion to $12.2 billion. Vietnam Airlines aims to begin US services in 2020, with initial flights including stops in Japan and Taiwan before non-stop service in 2022.

site_title: Property bust rattles Australia's surging economy
summary: Australia's surging economy is being rattled by a property bust, with house prices in freefall after a surge in 2017. Authorities have partly engineered the drop to improve affordability. The bust has led to 61 apartments in Sydney's Epping being sold off to recoup creditors' funds, with prices falling more than 20% from their peak. The construction industry is also feeling the impact, with monthly insolvencies hitting a three-year high and profit downgrades at businesses. The central bank has opened the door to a rate cut, and experts warn of a ripple effect on the economy, with potential impacts on spending and company earnings.

site_title: Trump expects 'signing summit' after extending tariff deadline
summary: US President Donald Trump expects a "signing summit" with China on trade after extending a tariff deadline, citing "substantial progress" in negotiations. The talks are close to a deal on structural issues, including intellectual property protection, technology transfer, and currency. Trump plans to meet with China's President Xi Jinping at his Mar-a-Lago resort in Florida to conclude an agreement, pending further negotiations. The delay of tariffs will help soothe investor worries about a trade war's impact on the global economy.

site_title: Healthway narrows FY2018 loss on absence of S$25 million impairment loss
summary: Healthway Medical Corporation reported a narrower full-year net loss of S$5.81 million for FY2018, compared to S$34.79 million the previous year. The absence of a S$25 million impairment loss on intangible assets contributed to the improvement. Total operating costs decreased by 12.7% to S$120.2 million, while full-year turnover increased by 7.5% to S$112.7 million.

site_title: Closure of Honda's UK hub in Swindon sums up Britain's Brexit-era angst
summary: Honda's UK hub in Swindon is set to close, affecting 3,500 employees and marking another decline in British manufacturing. The factory, which has been in operation since the 19th century, cited changing global trends and slowing demand as the reason for its closure. The move is seen as a significant blow to the town, which has experienced low unemployment and economic growth in recent years. Locals are concerned about the impact on their jobs and the town's economy, with many families relying on the factory for income.

site_title: Historic breakthrough or empty promises?
summary: US President Donald Trump is set to meet with North Korean leader Kim Jong Un in Vietnam for a second summit, with observers predicting a range of possible outcomes. The US seeks "verifiable and irreversible" denuclearization, while North Korea defines it as an end to nuclear weapons on the Korean peninsula. A repeat of the Singapore declaration would be seen as a defeat for Trump, while a step-by-step agreement with verifiable inspections would be the best outcome for the US. The summit's success will depend on the two leaders' ability to deliver concrete actions, rather than just vague statements.

site_title: Irrelevance, thy name is telco bundling
summary: Singtel and StarHub reported lower profits due to declining pay television subscriber numbers and revenue. Mobile ARPUs continued to decline annually. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall in H2, with similar operating losses to H1. Meanwhile, the US Justice Department approved T-Mobile's $4.4 billion acquisition of UScellular. Huawei sought AI chip customers in the Middle East and Southeast Asia, while Meta acquired an Apple engineer with a $200 million pay package.

site_title: Corn, poultry, beef 'on the table' at China talks: US Agriculture Secretary
summary: US Agriculture Secretary Sonny Perdue expects China to make its next round of 10 million-tonne soya bean purchases "relatively quickly". This comes after China committed to buying an additional 10 million tonnes of US soya beans, a sign of progress in trade talks between the two countries. Corn, ethanol, beef, and poultry are also being discussed as part of the trade talks, with any potential sales dependent on a final US-China trade deal.

site_title: How to Train Your Dragon soars to top of US box office
summary: Universal's animated film "How to Train Your Dragon: The Hidden World" took the top spot at the US box office with a three-day estimate of $55.5 million, surpassing the previous two installments in the trilogy. This marks the top domestic opener of the year so far, beating the previous record.

images.alt_text: The female Light Fury dragon, left, and her Night Fury paramour Toothless in How To Train Your Dragon: The Hidden World.

site_title: Validus raises S$20.5m in Series B funding led by Dutch bank FMO
summary: Validus Capital, a Singapore-based peer-to-peer lending platform, has secured S$20.5 million in Series B funding led by Dutch development bank FMO. The funding will support regional expansion, starting with Indonesia in the second quarter of 2019 and Vietnam later on. Validus will partner with the Rachmat family, owners of agribusiness and mining conglomerate Triputra Group, to break into the Indonesian market. Despite regulatory challenges and data gaps, Validus believes its partnership will open doors to the market.

site_title: Zimbabwe struggles to convince doubters as it launches new currency
summary: Zimbabwe has launched its new currency, the Real Time Gross Settlement (RTGS) dollar, in an effort to reverse chronic cash shortages and alleviate economic woes. The move has been met with skepticism by businesspeople and economists, who question the government's ability to control inflation and manage the currency. The RTGS dollar is pegged to the US dollar and has been devalued by 60% since its introduction, with analysts warning of a potential return to hyperinflation if the currency continues to weaken. The government's commitment to fiscal discipline and monetary control remains uncertain, casting doubt on the currency's success.

site_title: Firms that do not change will hit 'dead end': Heng Swee Keat
summary: Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat emphasized the need for companies to transform their operations through technology and upgrade workers to cope with changes, warning that failing to do so will lead to a "dead end." He cited ST Engineering Aerospace as a model for transformation, with the company investing in automation and training its workforce to stay competitive. Heng stressed that making changes now is crucial, as it will be "much harder" later, and highlighted the government's $4.6 billion investment over three years to support firms and workers in this transition.

images.alt_text: Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat watches as a robot (the arm structure) works on a booster vane assembly during his tour of ST Engineering's aerospace facility on Monday.

site_title: Payoffs in productivity, engagement and creativity make flexi-work a worthwhile goal
summary: A survey of 1,700 business and technology decision makers in the Asia-Pacific and Japan region found that 93% of Singaporean organizations offer flexible work options, but only 21% offer it across the entire organization. Flexible work needs to be implemented broadly, rather than restricted to certain teams or senior management, to maximize its benefits. A robust cloud-based infrastructure is key to delivering personalized access to systems and tools, promoting productivity and creativity. Organizations adopting cloud technology, such as SaaS solutions, are more likely to adopt a hybrid multi-cloud model, which will continue to grow in the next few years.

site_title: Jokowi puts economy at heart of re-election pitch
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo has emphasized job creation and economic growth as key to alleviating poverty in his re-election pitch. In a speech, he highlighted progress in infrastructure development and outlined policy objectives to boost purchasing power and reduce poverty. Despite a narrowing gap in polls, Widodo's lead remains strong, with his campaign focusing on unity and development. His economic record has been criticized, but he has managed to keep inflation low and the jobless rate near a 20-year low.

images.alt_text: "I am optimistic that hard work will transform the lives of the Indonesian people," says Mr Joko.

site_title: Bank of Japan has four options for more easing: Kuroda
summary: Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda stated the central bank is prepared to consider four options for extra easing if inflation loses momentum towards its 2% target, including lowering the negative short-term rate or cutting the long-term yield target below zero. Kuroda emphasized the bank's readiness to act, but maintained price momentum was maintained. The options include buying more assets or increasing the pace of expansion of the monetary base, with the aim of minimizing side effects.

site_title: Building for the future - from the ground up
summary: Singapore's Budget 2019 aims to boost domestic spending and support small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), with a focus on driving growth in areas like social services, health, and infrastructure. The budget allocates S$100 million to the SME Co-Investment Fund and expands the Go Digital programme to help SMEs scale up and improve productivity. It also streamlines trade processes and encourages innovation collaboration with universities to attract multinational investment. The measures are seen as crucial in capturing intra-regional opportunities in the Asean market, where export headwinds are expected in 2019.

site_title: See each Budget as a building block towards national priorities
summary: Singapore's 2019 Budget, unveiled by Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat, was met with mixed reactions, with some quarters disappointed by the lack of significant tax changes and others criticizing the absence of measures to address pressing issues like the demographic challenge. However, the Budget reflects the country's spending priorities on key areas like security, economy, and healthcare, and should be viewed as a building block towards national priorities rather than an annual handout. Each year's Budget builds on past ones, with multi-year schemes and long-term fiscal planning in place.

site_title: German company snapping up properties at a pre-Brexit bargain
summary: German real estate company Grand City Properties is buying up properties in London at discounted prices, defying pessimistic forecasts on the impact of Brexit. The company has purchased over 800 apartments, with prices averaging £620 per square foot, 20-40% below market prices. This suggests that true London prices may be softer than publicly advertised, and that even a smooth Brexit transition will not lift London real estate prices anytime soon. Experts say the discounts indicate a weak market, with sales volumes down 50% since 2015 and many properties remaining unsold for months.

site_title: Pine Grove a litmus test for developers' en bloc appetite
summary: A Singaporean condominium, Pine Grove, is up for collective sale with a reserve price of S$1.86 billion. The 660-unit HUDC project could yield over 2,000 units upon redevelopment, making it a test for developers' appetite for billion-dollar deals. The tender, which closes on April 23, follows a series of failed en bloc attempts and comes amid a cautious market. The sale of Pine Grove could provide insight into the en bloc market's resilience, with other high-profile projects, such as Grange Heights, also on the market.

images.alt_text: The reserve price for the 660-unit privatised condo was actually bumped up from an earlier S$1.72 billion to S$1.86 billion in order to entice at least 80 per cent of its homeowners to sign up.

site_title: Forecast for 2019 headline inflation trimmed as Jan reading eases to 0.4%
summary: Singapore's headline inflation forecast for 2019 has been trimmed to 0.5-1.5% due to the oil price slump, down from 0.5-2% previously. Core inflation expectations remain unchanged at 1.5-2.5%. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) attributed the decrease to a downward revision in electricity tariffs and the nationwide roll-out of the Open Electricity Market scheme. Despite a slowdown in oil prices, the MAS still expects global oil prices to be lower this year compared to 2018, and may cap overall price increases due to greater market competition.

site_title: Buying abroad, with a logo
summary: Many Americans are buying luxury residences in brand-name resort properties, mainly in the Caribbean and Latin America, with over 400 branded residences available worldwide. This trend is driven by the convenience of accessing resort facilities, 24-hour security, and maintenance, as well as the assurance of a global brand's reputation and quality. Brands like Four Seasons, Marriott, and Ritz-Carlton are popular, with international buyers snapping up easy-to-lock-up-and-leave, high-rise residences in cities worldwide. The model is expected to grow, with Four Seasons' portfolio set to reach over 7,000 homes in the next five years.

site_title: Xiaomi unveils 599-euro 5G smartphone
summary: Xiaomi unveiled a 599-euro 5G smartphone at the Mobile World Congress in Barcelona, targeting normal consumers with affordable prices. The company's senior vice-president, Xiang Wang, stated that the goal is to drive 5G adoption among a broader audience. This move comes after Samsung and Huawei announced high-end 5G devices with prices over $1,900. Xiaomi initially targeted Asian markets, but now plans to expand into Africa, where it sees growth potential. The company aims to learn the market and serve customers before expanding its product offerings.

site_title: What's driving iron ore's price spike?
summary: A recent Vale SA dam disaster in Brazil has led to fears of a potential 40 million metric ton shortage of iron ore, prompting a 8.4% price surge in Singapore iron ore futures. Chinese traders, who dominate the iron ore market, have largely avoided physical delivery, allowing traders to speculate on cash-settled contracts. This has raised concerns about the impact of mainland Chinese dominance on global price discovery. However, experts suggest the current price spike may be a short-term squeeze due to supply concerns, and the market may return to normal once the Brazilian supply issues are resolved.

site_title: United Engineers full-year net profit falls 36% on weaker revenue
summary: United Engineers reported a 36% fall in full-year net profit to S$55.76 million due to weaker revenue, down 29% to S$374.9 million. The decline was attributed to lower revenue from property development and the absence of contribution from a divested business. The company proposed a lower dividend of three Singapore cents per ordinary share, down from four cents a year ago.

site_title: PropNex launches new HDB Auction service; Q4 profit slides on cooling measures
summary: PropNex Realty launches an auction service for HDB flats, allowing flat owners to sell to the highest bidder subject to a reserve price. The service aims to increase transparency and speed up negotiations, particularly for properties under estates where trustees are tasked with selling the property. The company reported a 58% year-on-year drop in Q4FY18 net profit due to cooling measures, but expects the HDB Auction service to contribute to the growth of the HDB resale market.

site_title: Trump, Kim may declare end of war at summit, South Korea says
summary: US President Donald Trump and North Korea's leader Kim Jong Un may agree on a joint political statement declaring an end to the 1950-53 Korean War during their Hanoi summit meeting. South Korean officials say the possibility is open, but the format of the declaration is still unclear. The declaration aims to build trust between North Korea and the US, and could encourage North Korea to give up its nuclear weapons. The meeting comes after North Korea offered to dismantle its nuclear complex in Yongbyon, but wants corresponding trust-building measures from the US.

site_title: Procurri returns to black in Q4 on stronger gross profit margins
summary: Procurri Corporation, an enterprise hardware supplier, reported a net profit of S$1.67 million in its fourth-quarter 2018, reversing a net loss of S$1.26 million from the same period last year. Revenue rose 7% to S$52.07 million, driven by a 4.9 percentage point increase in gross profit margin to 38.9%. Staff costs decreased 6.3% year-on-year, contributing to the improved profit.

site_title: Yuan hits 7-month high; Aussie, Kiwi also gain
summary: China's yuan reached a 7-month high against the US dollar, rising to 6.6737 per dollar, after US President Donald Trump confirmed a delay in planned tariffs on Chinese imports. This move boosted Chinese equities and other commodity-linked currencies, including the Australian and New Zealand dollars. The offshore yuan has strengthened 2.7% against the US dollar in 2019, reversing some of last year's 5.5% loss. Market experts attribute the surge to reduced China-US trade tensions and a pricing out of a huge risk premium in the renminbi.

site_title: Trump says he sees 'signing summit' with China on trade
summary: US President Donald Trump expects a "signing summit" with China on trade, with negotiators close to a deal. He cited progress in talks on structural issues like intellectual property protection and technology transfer. Trump will delay raising tariffs on Chinese goods beyond March 1, citing substantial progress. A meeting at Trump's Mar-a-Lago resort in Florida is possible to conclude the agreement, but details are unclear. China's official Xinhua News Agency also reported "substantial progress."

site_title: Khaw Boon Wan fractures arm in fall; on medical leave
summary: Singapore's Coordinating Minister for Infrastructure and Transport Khaw Boon Wan, 66, is on extended medical leave after fracturing his left arm in a fall. Foreign Minister Vivian Balakrishnan has been appointed Acting Minister for Transport, ensuring continuity in bilateral negotiations with Malaysia on transport matters, including maritime borders and water prices. Khaw is expected to resume duties after several weeks, with senior ministers assisting Balakrishnan.

site_title: BBR Holdings swings to loss on lower sales, absence of profits from Lakelife condo
summary: BBR Holdings, a construction and property firm, reported a full-year net loss of S$3.36 million in 2018, reversing from a net profit of S$10.4 million in the previous year. Revenue fell 39.7% to S$118 million, primarily due to lower sales from its general construction and engineering segments. The company also failed to recognize development profits from the sale of Lakelife Executive Condominium, which were substantial in the previous year.

site_title: RHT Health Trust makes changes to board following Fortis sale
summary: RHT Health Trust announced a reconstitution of its board following the sale of its healthcare assets to Fortis Healthcare for S$895.55 million. The current board members have stepped down, and the trust appointed new directors, including Tan Bong Lin as non-executive chairman and independent director. The changes follow the completion of the sale, which was announced in January.

site_title: Downside risks remain if Trump-Kim talks end up a mirage
summary: US President Donald Trump and North Korean leader Kim Jong-Un are set to meet in Vietnam for their second summit, with significant uncertainty surrounding the outcome. Despite Trump's claims of diplomatic success, Kim has made few concrete concessions, and North Korea continues to enrich uranium and produce missiles. The summit has led to a shift in global geopolitics, with key powers engaging with Kim and the Pyongyang regime, but downside risks remain if the talks break down, potentially leading to rising tensions on the peninsula.

images.alt_text: T-shirts printed with portraits of of US President Donald Trump and North Korean leader Kim Jong Un on display in a Hanoi shop ahead of their summit in Vietnam this week, following the one in Singapore last year.

site_title: India's FDI inflows fall amid pre-election uncertainty
summary: India's foreign direct investment (FDI) inflows have dropped 7% to $33.5 billion in the nine months between April and December 2018, the first full-year decline since Prime Minister Narendra Modi came to power in 2014. The decline is attributed to uncertainty about the general election result and the government's protectionist policies, including moves to tighten rules on foreign-controlled online retailers. Investors are waiting to see who forms the next government after the election, which must be held by early May.

site_title: Aspial sees jump in net profit from property segment
summary: ASPIAL Corporation reported a significant jump in its full-year net profit, driven by a surge in revenue from its property segment. Net profit for the three months ended Dec 31, 2018, was S$28.35 million, a 1,212% increase from the same period last year. Revenue surged 84% to S$898.5 million, with a notable increase in revenue from its real estate business, primarily due to the recognition of sales from the CityGate project in Singapore and the settlement of completed residential units in Melbourne, Australia.

site_title: Trump calls on Opec to 'relax,' says oil prices are too high
summary: US President Donald Trump expressed concern over oil prices, calling on Opec to "relax" and keep prices steady, citing the impact on the global economy. Trump tweeted that high oil prices are "too high" and "fragile," amid increased anxiety over the global economy and record US exports. Opec members and non-Opec producers are leading efforts to rebalance the market and support oil prices. Trump has repeatedly tweeted about oil prices and Opec, airing complaints about higher prices ahead of the organization's meeting in December.

site_title: EU's Tusk says Brexit delay would be "rational"
summary: European Council President Donald Tusk said a Brexit delay beyond March 29 would be a "rational solution" due to a lack of majority in the British parliament to approve a divorce deal. Tusk stated that an extension would be more likely the closer the deadline, but Prime Minister May believes she can avoid it. May argued that delaying the exit doesn't deliver a deal, merely delaying the decision. Tusk and May discussed a potential extension, with Tusk emphasizing that no decision can be reached without a majority in the House of Commons.

site_title: Canada's Barrick Gold in hostile bid for rival Newmont
summary: Canadian mining company Barrick Gold launched a hostile bid worth around US$18 billion for American rival Newmont Mining, aiming to create a global gold and copper giant. The proposed all-share transaction would give Barrick 55.9% ownership of the combined entity. The move follows Newmont's recent US$10 billion acquisition of Goldcorp and Barrick's own US$5.4 billion deal for Randgold Resources. Industry consolidation is driven by depleted gold mines and rising costs, with the merger seen as a logical step to create the unrivalled leader in the gold sector.

site_title: UK and US strike post-Brexit financial trades deal
summary: Britain and the US agreed to maintain post-Brexit financial trades, ensuring continuity of derivatives trading and clearing activities between the two countries. The deal aims to avoid market uncertainty after the UK leaves the EU. The UK and US carry out $2.4 trillion daily trades in derivatives, with 97% of the centrally cleared interest rate derivatives market located in London. The agreement provides a regulatory framework for derivatives trading and clearing, with London remaining a global center for derivatives trading and clearing.

site_title: Sheng Siong posts 4.2% rise in Q4 net profit on higher sales
summary: Sheng Siong Group, a Singaporean supermarket chain, reported a 4.2% increase in Q4 net profit to S$17.53 million, driven by higher sales and gross profit. Revenue rose 10.7% to S$221.8 million, while gross profit increased 9.2% to S$60.19 million. The company attributed its success to its expansion into new HDB residential areas and its strategy to compete with online players. Despite the increase in net profit, shares of Sheng Siong closed unchanged at S$1.08.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher after Trump delays tariff deadline
summary: US stocks opened higher on Monday after President Donald Trump delayed a hike in tariffs on Chinese imports, fueling hopes of a trade resolution. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 94.34 points, or 0.36%, to 26,126.15, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also gained ground. The delay has lifted investor sentiment, despite ongoing trade uncertainty.

images.alt_text: US stocks opened higher on Monday, led by industrial and technology shares, fueled by hopes of a trade resolution between the United States and China after President Donald Trump said he would delay a hike in tariffs on Chinese imports.

site_title: 5G is coming: what can we expect?
summary: The telecoms industry is transitioning to 5G networks, promising nearly instantaneous data transfers and major changes to consumer and health products. The first 5G compatible phones will be available mid-2019, but initial speeds won't be noticeably faster due to limited coverage. Analysts predict it will take at least two years for the network to become extensive enough to use 5G phones without relying on 4G. 5G is expected to enable self-driving cars, augmented reality, and other tasks with lower latency, and will have a significant impact on industries such as manufacturing and healthcare.

site_title: Britain should 'rapidly' give up Chagos Islands: UN court
summary: The International Court of Justice has advised Britain to "rapidly" give up control of the Chagos Islands, citing the country's illegal split from Mauritius in the 1960s. The court ruled that Britain's administration of the islands is not lawfully completed, and that Mauritius should have the opportunity to complete its decolonization. The decision comes as a blow to Britain, which has maintained control over the islands since their separation from Mauritius, and could impact the country's exit from the European Union.

site_title: SembMarine snags S$175m in contracts to build LNG vessel, repair and upgrade cruise ships
summary: SembCorp Marine secured S$175m in contracts for designing and building a liquefied natural gas (LNG) bunker vessel and repairing 13 cruise ships. The LNG vessel, to be built in Singapore, will have a capacity of 12,000-cubic-metre tanks and is the largest of its kind in Singapore. The company also expects a positive contribution to its earnings from the contracts, although they are not expected to impact its net tangible assets and earnings per share.

site_title: Novartis aims to pump up cardio business with Ionis deal
summary: Novartis has licensed an RNA-targeting cardiovascular drug, TQJ230, from Ionis Pharmaceuticals to treat an inherited form of cardiovascular disease. The Phase 3 trial will assess the treatment's efficacy against elevated lipoprotein (a) levels. Novartis aims to augment its heart-disease portfolio, which has grown after years of stagnation, following patent expirations on its blockbusters. The deal is part of a three-year collaboration between Novartis and Ionis, which also developed Biogen's spinal muscular atrophy drug Spinraza. If successful, TQJ230 could become the leading treatment option for this condition.

site_title: Datapulse served writ from former directors over alleged missed payment
summary: Datapulse Technology has been sued by its former executive directors, Ng Cheow Chye, Ng Cheow Leng, and Si Yok Fong, who claim the company owes them S$751,118 from a profit-sharing arrangement. Datapulse has paid S$589,000 but disputes the alleged balance payment of S$161,308. The company's shares closed at S$0.275, up half a Singapore cent, on the day the lawsuit was announced.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed higher on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 3.16 points to 1,724.58. The index saw 2.6 billion lots worth RM2.2 billion, with losers outnumbering gainers 480 to 386.

site_title: Ferragamo chairman rules out sale of iconic brand
summary: Ferruccio Ferragamo, chairman of luxury clothing brand Salvatore Ferragamo SpA, has ruled out a sale of the iconic brand, stating he is "in love" with the company. The company has promoted Paul Andrew as creative director to boost visibility and create a more immersive experience for customers, with a focus on revitalizing the brand's online presence and attracting younger luxury shoppers. Shares rose 1.2% after the announcement, following a 43% decline since 2015.

site_title: Hong Kong's CLP aims to start building LNG terminal at year-end
summary: CLP Power, a Hong Kong utility group, plans to start building the city's first offshore liquefied natural gas (LNG) receiving terminal by the end of 2019. The terminal, which aims to increase natural gas use to 50% by 2020, gained an environmental permit in October but a final investment decision has not been made. The project is part of Hong Kong's shift from coal to natural gas for electric power generation. CLP's chief executive, Richard Lancaster, is working on final permits and approvals while gearing up for the awarding contract aspects.

site_title: Ryobi Kiso fails to get creditors' nod for proposed restructuring
summary: Ryobi Kiso, a ground engineering solutions firm, failed to reach an agreement with creditors over its proposed restructuring scheme, despite extensive negotiations. Two creditors had filed winding-up petitions in 2018, totaling S$2.73 million, which are now set to be heard on March 1, 2019. The creditors, who hold sufficient voting rights, did not support the company's scheme proposals, leading to the suspension of trading in its stock.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares end the day higher
summary: Hong Kong shares ended the day 0.50% higher at 28,959.30, despite reports that US President Donald Trump would delay increased tariffs on Chinese goods following "substantial progress" in trade talks. China's stock markets surged, with the Shanghai Composite Index rising 5.60% and the Shenzhen Composite Index 5.42%. US stocks also edged to fresh records, despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Ho Bee Land Q4 net profit down 20.5% to S$81.4m
summary: Ho Bee Land's Q4 net profit fell 20.5% to S$81.4m due to a S$20.3m provision for a potential tax liability. Revenue jumped 22.8% to S$147.9m, driven by higher rental revenue and a net fair value gain of S$93m on investment properties in the UK and Singapore. Earnings per share declined to 12.24 cents, while the group recommends a S$0.10 dividend per share. Ho Bee is monitoring global economic challenges, including the US-China trade war and Brexit, and will adapt its business strategies accordingly.

site_title: Singapore shares end flat on Monday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index closed flat on Monday, rising 0.07% to 3,272.35, with 1.61 billion securities worth S$1.27 billion changing hands. Losers outnumbered gainers 233 to 173. Key index stocks like Genting Singapore and ThaiBev ended flat. The market's performance followed a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, with investors bracing for US-EU trade talks and tariff uncertainty.

site_title: ST Engineering unit wins US$600m aircraft maintenance contract
summary: ST Engineering's aerospace unit has secured a US$600 million contract to provide aircraft maintenance services to a major North American operator. The 10-year agreement, starting in 2020, covers over 160 wide-body and narrow-body aircraft. The firm will offer a fleet reliability programme to monitor aircraft health and recommend maintenance actions. This long-term strategic alliance is expected to support the operator's operational reliability.

site_title: Pine Grove launches collective sale at reserve price of S$1.86b
summary: Pine Grove, a 660-unit condominium in Singapore, is launching a collective sale at a reserve price of S$1.86 billion. This translates to a land rate of S$1,307 per sq ft per plot ratio. The site, with a 99-year leasehold, has a gross plot ratio of 2.1 and can be redeveloped into a residential landmark of up to 24 storeys. The tender will close on April 23, allowing property owners to vote on the sale.

images.alt_text: PROPERTY owners of Pine Grove will launch on Tuesday the long-awaited collective sale for the 660-unit condominium located in the Holland Road cluster at a reserve price of S$1.86 billion.

site_title: Bye-bye Beverley: Credits roll for Paris's last porn cinema
summary: Paris's last remaining pornographic cinema, the Beverley, has closed after a final screening. The cinema, which operated since 1975, was sold to a property developer and owner Maurice Laroche, 75, is retiring. With rising rents and changing social norms, the cinema's clientele has dwindled, and it is now the only X-rated cinema remaining in France. Only one cinema specializing in pornography remains, the Vox in Grenoble, and most now show films on phones. Laroche will sell remaining memorabilia and leave with memories of the cinema's past.

images.alt_text: People look at posters and reels of pornographic cinema displayed at the Beverley cinema, the last pornographic cinema of Paris, on Feb 24, 2019 during a sale as the movie theatre definitely closes its door.

site_title: Rami Malek wins best actor Oscar for 'Bohemian Rhapsody'
summary: Rami Malek won the Oscar for Best Actor for his portrayal of Freddie Mercury in "Bohemian Rhapsody." The 37-year-old actor took home the award on Sunday, following his wins at the Golden Globe, Screen Actors Guild, and British BAFTA awards. Malek credited the film's portrayal of Mercury's struggles with identity and finding his voice as proof that audiences are longing for such stories. He also thanked the original members of Queen, Brian May and Roger Taylor, and the film's filmmakers for their work on the film, which earned Oscars for editing, sound editing, and sound mixing.

site_title: Vodafone boss: US needs to share any Huawei evidence with Europe
summary: Vodafone CEO Nick Read urged the US to share evidence about Huawei's technology with European authorities, stating that a fact-based risk-assessment review is necessary. The US has warned allies not to use Huawei's technology due to fears of Chinese spy operations. Vodafone paused Huawei's equipment deployment in European core networks until governments provide clarity on risks. Read emphasized the need for a unified European stance on Huawei's technology to avoid damaging the industry and economic growth.

site_title: First Emirati set to head to space in Sept: UAE
summary: The United Arab Emirates announced that its first astronaut, either Hazza al-Mansouri or Sultan al-Neyadi, will blast off on a mission to the International Space Station on September 25. The two Emirati astronauts are among 4,000 applicants selected for the ambitious space program, aiming to explore Mars. The decision on which astronaut will take the Russian Soyuz spacecraft will be made in May. This marks the UAE's step towards becoming a global leader in space exploration, with plans to send an unmanned probe to Mars by 2021 and establish a human settlement on the red planet by 2117.

site_title: Sterling rallies on talk UK government considering Brexit delay
summary: Sterling rallies as traders consider a potential Brexit delay, with the pound rising 2% over the last seven trading sessions. The UK government is weighing its options, including delaying Brexit, if parliament fails to approve Prime Minister Theresa May's withdrawal agreement. A vote on Brexit amendments is set for Wednesday, with opposition lawmakers pushing for a no-deal Brexit prevention amendment. The EU has expressed willingness to consider an extension to the Brexit process, but only if Britain can offer evidence of parliamentary deadlock. The pound reached a high of $1.3099 on Monday, up 0.3% on the day.

site_title: PropNex Q4FY18 profit down 58%; declares dividends of 3.5 S cents per share
summary: PropNex reported a 58% year-on-year drop in Q4 FY2018 net profit to S$1.83 million due to cooling measures. Revenue decreased 16% to S$83 million, and earnings per share fell to 0.49 Singapore cents. For FY2018, net profit rose 19.3% to S$19.41 million, and revenue jumped 30% to S$431.54 million. PropNex declared a final dividend of 1.5 cents and a special dividend of 2 cents per share. The company launched a new HDB Auction service to increase transparency and curb long negotiation periods.

site_title: Roche to buy US gene therapy group Spark for US$4.3b
summary: Swiss pharmaceutical giant Roche has agreed to acquire US gene therapy group Spark Therapeutics for $4.3 billion. Spark specializes in gene therapies for genetic diseases such as blindness, haemophilia, and neurodegenerative diseases. The deal was approved by both company boards, offering a premium of 122% to Spark's closing price. Spark's treatments, including Luxturna, the first approved gene therapy in the US, will accelerate development under Roche's worldwide reach and extensive resources.

site_title: Peace Centre/Peace Mansion makes 5th attempt at collective sale with S$688m reserve price
summary: The owners of Peace Centre/Peace Mansion in Singapore have launched a fifth attempt at a collective sale with a reserve price of S$688 million (S$1,474 per square foot per plot ratio). The 76,617 square feet site has a gross floor area of over 600,000 sq ft and is zoned for commercial use. An outline planning permission has been obtained for a mixed commercial and residential project, which could yield 362,747 sq ft of retail/commercial space and 241,831 sq ft of residential units. The tender closes on April 11.

site_title: Primark owner AB Foods forecasts flat first-half earnings
summary: Associated British Foods (AB Foods) forecasts flat first-half earnings despite expecting revenue growth in all businesses except sugar. Primark's first-half sales are expected to be up 4% with increased selling space offsetting a 2% decline in like-for-like sales. The company's adjusted operating profit and earnings per share are expected to be in line with the previous year. AB Foods attributes the flat earnings outlook to lower net financial expenses.

site_title: Europe: Trade tariff reprieve boosts European shares
summary: US President Trump's decision to delay an increase in tariffs on Chinese goods boosted European shares, with the pan-European STOXX 600 rising 0.2% to its highest level since October 10. Carmakers and miners rallied, while Bank of Ireland slumped after its results. The delay helped drive gains in the sector, with shares in carmakers and miners reaching their highest levels in months. The positive impact on European shares came despite ongoing US-EU trade talks and uncertainty surrounding tariffs.

site_title: Singapore C-suite execs, finance staff believe business decisions were based on inaccurate data: poll
summary: A survey of 579 C-level and 575 finance professionals in Singapore found that over 70% believe business decisions were made based on inaccurate data, with 45% expressing concern over errors they are not aware of. 74% of respondents believe they or their CEO has made a significant decision based on out-of-date or incorrect data, with 18% stating it has occurred in their organisation. The survey highlights the need for better data accuracy and visibility to prevent reputational damage and financial misreporting.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's inflation forecast for 2019 has been cut to 2.5% due to a slower increase in electricity and gas costs, outweighing the price hike in services. The country's collective sale market saw a notable launch at Pine Grove, with a reserve price of S$1.86 billion. Validus raised S$20.5 million in Series B funds and partnered with the Rachmat family in Indonesia. Meanwhile, a poll found that 74% of Singapore's C-suite executives believe business decisions were based on inaccurate data. The Straits Times Index ended flat on Monday, closing at 3,272.35.

site_title: Charisma Energy warns of losses for Q4, fiscal 2018
summary: Charisma Energy expects to report a net loss for its fourth quarter and fiscal 2018 due to a challenging operating environment. The company is transitioning from the marine and offshore oil and gas industry to renewable energy and is finalizing an assessment of asset impairment. A preliminary review indicates significant losses, but the company will provide more details when it announces its unaudited financial results on March 1, 2019.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks shrug off Trump's tariff hike delay
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index rose 2.06 points, or 0.09%, to 2,232.56 points, shrugging off US President Donald Trump's delay of tariff hikes on Chinese goods. The won rose against the dollar, while foreign investors sold 128.8 billion won worth of shares. Despite the US stocks' gains, Kospi's upside resilience was limited, and the market has risen 9.38% so far this year.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Monday afternoon at 3,263.25, down 0.2% on day
summary: Singapore stocks declined 0.2% to 3,263.25 at 1:03pm on Monday, with the Straits Times Index down 6.65 points. Losers outnumbered gainers 213 to 124, driven by Best World International's 19.9% drop. About 814.76 million securities worth S$615.87 million changed hands.

site_title: Miners lead Australian shares higher on China trade optimism; NZ rises
summary: Australian shares rose 0.3% to 6,186.30, driven by optimism over China trade talks, with mining stocks led by BHP Group and Rio Tinto. Fortescue Metals Group surged 2% after US President Donald Trump announced a delay in planned tariff hikes. New Zealand shares also gained, with energy retailer Meridian Energy up 2.3% and Synlait Milk 4.1%. The positive sentiment was tempered by a proposed Australian government plan to curb energy costs for consumers, which could hit energy retailers AGL Energy and Origin Energy.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close higher on US-China trade deal hopes
summary: Tokyo stocks rose moderately on Monday, supported by optimism over a US-China trade deal. The Nikkei 225 index gained 0.48% to close at 21,528.23, while the Topix index rose 0.71% to 1,620.87. US President Donald Trump announced "substantial progress" in trade talks with China, delaying a planned tariff increase on Chinese exports. A summit between Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping is planned to ink a deal, boosting market sentiment.

site_title: Indonesia President Joko Widodo puts economy at heart of re-election pitch
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo is focusing on the economy in his re-election bid, highlighting job creation, boosting purchasing power, and reducing poverty. He outlined key policy objectives, including expanding a scheme of free food cards and increasing funding for the village fund programme. Despite a narrowing lead in polls, Widodo remains optimistic about his chances, citing progress made in infrastructure development and a near 20-year low jobless rate. His opponent, Prabowo Subianto, has campaigned aggressively, potentially threatening Widodo's lead.

site_title: Malaysia anti-graft agency's probe into Jawala unit still ongoing
summary: Malaysia's anti-graft agency, the Malaysian Anti-Corruption Commission (MACC), continues its investigation into Jawala Inc. regarding the suspension of its subsidiary's bank accounts. Jawala Inc. stated it has not received any formal notification from the MACC and will cooperate fully in the investigation. Despite the suspension, JPI's business continues to operate normally, and directors are unaware of any investigation or proceedings. The investigation began after CIMB and Public Bank Berhad froze JPI's bank accounts in November 2018.

site_title: Corn, poultry 'on table' during China talks, says US Agriculture Secretary Perdue
summary: US Agriculture Secretary Sonny Perdue says China is expected to make its next round of US soybean purchases "relatively quickly", with an additional 10 million tonnes expected. Other US agricultural goods, including corn, ethanol, beef, and poultry, are also part of trade discussions. The purchases are seen as a "good-faith effort" by China, with Perdue noting that US inventories are expected to double this year amid rising yields and a drop in exports to China.

images.alt_text: China is expected to make its next round of American soybean purchases "relatively quickly," while corn, ethanol, beef and poultry also have been part of trade discussions between the two countries, according to US Agriculture Secretary Sonny Perdue.

site_title: Mercuria crude-trading boss retires with a warning for industry
summary: Kurt Chapman, the head of crude-trading at Mercuria Energy Group, is retiring after 29 years, citing the physical and mental rigors of the job. He expresses concerns that the industry's rapid growth and increasing financialization of the Brent benchmark will draw more regulatory scrutiny. Chapman warns that the surge in electronic trading, led by hedge funds, is disconnecting futures markets from actual cargo trades, making it difficult for traders to understand the real business. He believes the industry's expansion into oil exploration and production, as well as energy infrastructure assets, will continue to attract more scrutiny.

site_title: Trump tariff delay doesn't mean trade war is over, analysts say
summary: US President Donald Trump announced a delay of higher tariffs on Chinese shipments, citing "substantial progress" in trade talks. Analysts welcomed the move but noted it doesn't signal the end of the trade war, with many predicting a deal will be reached in late March, suspending tariffs and marking the beginning of a "post-trade-war" era. However, underlying tensions on technology, industrial policies, and China's rise are unlikely to subside, and enforcement mechanisms remain a concern.

site_title: Australian dollar boosted by risk rally, kiwi climbs on solid data
summary: The Australian dollar rose 0.3% to US$0.7146 on Monday, boosted by improved risk sentiment and comments from US President Donald Trump that a trade deal with China is nearing. The New Zealand dollar also gained 0.4% to US$0.6865, following solid economic data showing a 1.7% increase in retail sales volumes. Market analysts attribute the gains to easing anxiety over the US-China trade war and a shift in focus towards US-Sino trade talks.

site_title: UAE light oil posts longest discount run since 2017 as Asian buyers switch
summary: Abu Dhabi's flagship Murban crude has sold at a discount to its official selling price for four consecutive months, the longest stretch in nearly two years, due to Asian buyers opting for cheaper US and European supplies. Discounts ranged from 5 cents to 40 cents per barrel, despite the producer cutting the benchmark price for four months. The influx of cheaper light oil from the US is expected to continue, putting pressure on Murban prices, with refining margins for light distillates remaining weak.

site_title: Hot stock: Best World shares plunge as much as 25.8% as trading resumes
summary: Best World International shares plummeted 25.8% on Monday before recovering as trading resumed, following a five-day halt. The direct-selling company will conduct an independent review of its business and accounting practices amid questions from The Business Times about its Chinese franchisees. Best World stated it has operated ethically and in compliance with laws, but is not responsible for its franchisees' records. The stock gapped down to open at S$2.60, down 11 cents or 4.06% from its last traded price.

site_title: Video creation platform 90 Seconds raises US$20m in Series B funding
summary: Video creation platform 90 Seconds has secured US$20 million in Series B funding from new and existing investors, including SIG and Sequoia India. The funds will be used to enhance automation and personalization on the platform, expanding its reach to more regions and locations. Since its Series A funding in 2016, 90 Seconds has worked with over 3,000 brands in 160 countries, and plans to deepen relationships with media platforms like Google and Facebook.

site_title: HMD Global launches Nokia 9 PureView smartphone with five-camera array
summary: HMD Global launched the Nokia 9 PureView smartphone with a five-camera array, appealing to camera enthusiasts. The device features two 12-megapixel color sensors and three 12-megapixel monochrome sensors. The Nokia 9 PureView will be available from March at $699, while the Nokia 3.2 and 4.2 will be available in April at $139 and $169, respectively. The company aims to serve users in emerging markets with devices ranging from feature phones to mid-market options, offering good value and simplicity.

site_title: Asia cheered as Trump delays tariff deadline
summary: US President Donald Trump announced a delay in planned tariffs on Chinese imports, citing "substantial progress" in trade talks. This move lifted Asian share markets, with the Australian dollar and yuan gaining. China's Shanghai blue chips have risen 17% this year, while US stocks have posted their highest close since November. The delay is seen as a positive step for the US-China trade standoff, with hopes for a potential deal.

site_title: APTT posts 81.5% drop in Q4 DPU to 0.3 Singapore cent
summary: ASIAN Pay Television Trust (APTT) announced a 81.5% drop in Q4 distribution per unit (DPU) to 0.3 Singapore cents, down from 1.625 Singapore cents in the previous year. The trust expects to continue paying 0.3 Singapore cent per unit quarterly through to 2020 as part of its debt management programme, which also includes refinancing and interest rate swaps. The lower distribution may allow for future unit buybacks, and the distribution level could be adjusted after 2020.

site_title: Validus raises S$20.5m in Series B funds, partners Triputra's Rachmat family in Indonesia
summary: Validus Capital, a peer-to-peer lending platform, has secured S$20.5 million in Series B funding led by Dutch development bank FMO. The platform, which connects accredited and institutional investors with small and medium enterprises (SMEs) in need of credit, will use the funds for regional expansion in Indonesia and Vietnam. Validus has partnered with the Rachmat family, owners of the Triputra Group, in Indonesia, and has a joint venture with the family to operate in the country. The partnership aligns with FMO's mandate to support SMEs in emerging markets.

site_title: 'Green Book' steals best picture Oscar, Colman and Malek are best actors
summary: "Green Book" won the Oscar for Best Picture, while Olivia Colman took home the Best Actress award for her role in "The Favourite." Rami Malek won Best Actor for his portrayal of Freddie Mercury in "Bohemian Rhapsody." "Roma" won two Oscars, including Best Director for Alfonso Cuaron and Best Foreign Language Film. Despite being a Netflix film, "Green Book" took home two Oscars, including Best Original Screenplay and Best Supporting Actor for Mahershala Ali. The ceremony also featured powerful performances by Lady Gaga and Queen.

site_title: Kim Jong Un impersonator deported from Vietnam ahead of summit
summary: A Kim Jong Un impersonator, Howard X, was deported from Vietnam ahead of the planned summit between North Korean leader Kim Jong Un and US President Donald Trump in Hanoi. X was stopped by police on Friday and informed he would be deported to Hong Kong, where he lives. His visa was deemed "invalid," but X claimed he was targeted because of his resemblance to Kim Jong Un, saying "Satire is a powerful weapon against any dictatorship." X will be allowed to stay in Hanoi but must stop appearing in costume.

site_title: Vietnam Airlines considers buying up to 100 Boeing 737 Max jets
summary: Vietnam Airlines considers ordering 50-100 Boeing 737 Max jets to replace its ageing fleet, with deliveries between 2020 and 2030. The carrier plans to operate these planes to California, with initial stops in Japan and Taiwan, and may also buy long-range jets, including Boeing 777x or Airbus A350-1000. The airline expects to remain unprofitable on the route for 5-10 years, requiring government subsidies, and faces increased competition from Bamboo Airways, which recently ordered 10 Boeing planes.

site_title: Ping An plans IPO of fintech unit at US$8b value
summary: Ping An Insurance plans to list its fintech unit OneConnect in Hong Kong, valuing the financial management portal at around $8 billion. The IPO is expected to raise approximately $1 billion and could happen in the second half of this year. The listing is part of Ping An's strategy to transform itself into a financial technology powerhouse.
