OneConnect provides cloud computing services to over 460 banks and 1,800 financial services firms, and its valuation has been tempered due to weaker-than-expected business performance. The IPO would be one of the highest-profile deals in Hong Kong this year.

site_title: Hong Kong, Shanghai: Stocks rise after Trump announces tariff delay
summary: Hong Kong and mainland Chinese shares rose at the open of trade Monday after US President Donald Trump announced a delay in hiking tariffs on Chinese imports, citing "substantial progress" in trade talks. The Hang Seng Index rose 0.55%, the Shanghai Composite Index jumped 1.22%, and the Shenzhen Composite Index gained 1.53%. The delayed tariffs and improving trade talks lifted investor sentiment, driving up shares in both Hong Kong and mainland China.

site_title: Singapore cuts 2019 headline inflation forecast as January reading eases to 0.4%
summary: Singapore's inflation forecast for 2019 has been cut by half a percentage point to 0.5-1.5% due to a slowdown in electricity and gas costs. January's headline inflation rate eased to 0.4% from 0.5% in December, while core inflation remained steady at 1.5-2.5%. Despite a 1.7% increase in services and 3.2% education fees, overall inflation remains under control. Economists expect the Monetary Authority of Singapore to maintain its current stance, but some analysts predict a possible tightening of monetary policy in the near future.

site_title: Thai AirAsia owner in talks to buy stake in rival Nok Air
summary: Thai AirAsia's owner, Asia Aviation Pcl, is in talks to buy a stake in rival Nok Air, sending Nok Air's share prices up 13%. The company is considering acquiring 53% of Nok Air from billionaire Jurangkool family, who currently owns the majority stake. This move comes as Thai Airways Pcl drops its holdings in Nok Air to 15.9%. The deal, if successful, would increase Asia Aviation's stake in Thai AirAsia to 100%.

site_title: Debt is roaring back in China
summary: China's debt is rising, defying a nearly two-year crackdown on financial leverage. Leverage indicators, including bank loans, trust products, and margin-trading accounts, have been strong in 2019, with new yuan loans jumping by a record $650 billion in January. Analysts say the trend has staying power as authorities focus on shoring up the economy, rather than containing debt. China's overall leverage ratio is expected to rise relative to GDP this year, with investors cheering easier credit conditions, which have boosted the stock market and lower-rated corporate bonds.

site_title: Lady Gaga takes Oscar for best original song
summary: Lady Gaga won the Oscar for Best Original Song for her power ballad "Shallow" from A Star Is Born. At the Dolby Theatre, she thanked co-star and director Bradley Cooper, expressing her gratitude for his support. Gaga also offered a message to aspiring artists, emphasizing the importance of perseverance, discipline, and bravery in pursuing one's dreams. "Shallow" beat out songs from Black Panther, RBG, The Ballad Of Buster Scruggs, and Mary Poppins Returns, marking Lady Gaga's first Oscar win.

site_title: Australian, NZ shares rise as Trump delays tariff deadline
summary: Australian shares rose 0.4% on Monday, driven by US President Donald Trump's delay of the planned tariff increase on Chinese imports, boosting investor sentiment. The S&P/ASX 200 index rose to 6,191.10, with mining stocks leading the gains, including BlueScope, BHP Group, and Fortescue Metals Group. The delay was seen as positive news, and commodity prices, such as copper, also rose. New Zealand's benchmark index rose 0.1%.

site_title: TEE International plans to sell 28% stake in unit
summary: TEE International plans to sell 28% stake in its subsidiary, TEE Land, to Top Capital Securities Pte Ltd at an indicative price of between S$0.179 and S$0.201 per share. The proposed sale is conditional on the execution of a definitive sale and purchase agreement and is targeted to be completed by April 30, 2019. The sale is part of TEE International's strategic review, which began after it received proposals from various interested parties. A term sheet has been entered into, which is non-binding and intended to outline the basic terms of the transaction.

site_title: Oscars red carpet: old school glamour, loads of pink, stylish men
summary: The 2019 Oscars red carpet saw old school glamour, metallic gowns, and a trend of pink dresses, with many celebrities opting for bold and stylish outfits. Notable looks included Glenn Close's glittering gold gown, Regina King's strapless white Oscar de la Renta dress, and Lady Gaga's elegant black Alexander McQueen ensemble. The event also showcased women rocking suits, with actresses such as Melissa McCarthy and Awkwafina pairing trousers with gowns. Male celebrities, including Jason Momoa and Billy Porter, also made a statement with their outfits, with Porter's tuxedo gown being a standout moment.

site_title: Raffles Medical earnings rise 0.4% to S$71.1m for FY2018
summary: RAFFLES Medical Group posted a net profit of S$71.1 million for FY2018, a 0.4% increase from FY2017. Revenue rose 2.4% to S$489.1 million, driven by a 6% increase in healthcare services revenue. The group announced a final dividend of 2.50 Singapore cents per share and plans to grow revenue and remain profitable in 2019 despite anticipated startup losses for Raffles Hospital Chongqing. Construction of Raffles Hospital Shanghai is expected to be completed in Q4 2019.

site_title: Frasers Property's indirect associated company to acquire Golden Land for 19.75b baht
summary: FRASERS Property Limited's indirect associated company, Frasers Property (Thailand) Public Company Limited (FPT), is making a conditional voluntary tender offer (VTO) for Golden Land Property Development plc's issued securities for approximately 19.75 billion baht (S$851.9 million) in cash. FPT aims to expand into adjacent businesses and scale its operations, enhancing its earnings and return on equity. The combined platform is expected to generate revenue in excess of 20 billion baht and total assets above 80 billion baht post-transaction.

site_title: Brokers' take: Venture pops after slight earnings beat for Q4
summary: VENTURE Corp shares rose 7% to S$17.25 after posting full-year results that beat lowered street expectations, with core profit for the fourth quarter slightly beating year-on-year expectations. Analysts attributed the growth to new product introductions, inventory expansion, and margin expansion. DBS analyst Carmen Tay said Venture's evolving business mix and increasing contributions from test, measurement, medical, and life science segments are likely to drive margins higher ahead.

site_title: Olivia Colman: two times a queen, and now film royalty
summary: Olivia Colman won the Academy Award for Best Actress for her role as Queen Anne in "The Favourite". The 45-year-old British actress, known for her roles in "The Crown" and "Broadchurch", took home the award in a major upset, beating Glenn Close and other notable actresses. Colman's performance was praised for its punch and brought a forgotten monarch to life. She will now star as Queen Elizabeth II in the upcoming season three of "The Crown".

site_title: Malaysia shares open flat on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened flat on Monday, rising 0.01% to 1,722.34. The index saw 85.3 million lots traded, with 151 gainers and 59 losers. Volume was worth RM41.3 million.

site_title: Khaw Boon Wan breaks arm; Vivian Balakrishnan to act as transport minister for Singapore-Malaysia talks
summary: Singapore Transport Minister Khaw Boon Wan fractured his left arm in a fall and is on extended medical leave, with Vivian Balakrishnan appointed Acting Minister for Transport during bilateral negotiations with Malaysia. Balakrishnan will oversee discussions on transport matters, with senior ministers assisting him. Khaw is expected to resume duties after several weeks, and a Parliament debate on transport spending plans will continue with Balakrishnan's involvement.

site_title: Chinese firm behind the 'Amazon Coat' hits jackpot in US, eschews China
summary: Chinese entrepreneur Kevin Chiu's company, Orolay, has experienced significant success with its affordable puffer jackets, dubbed the "Amazon Coat," after being sold on Amazon.com. Chiu's company made $5 million in sales last month and expects $30-$40 million this year, largely due to Amazon's measures that facilitate sales by overseas vendors. This has raised concerns among US sellers on Amazon and experts warn of a threat to brick-and-mortar retailers from the influx of small, Chinese brands.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Best World, Raffles Medical, Venture, Allied Tech, Chip Eng Seng
summary:
Here's a 100-word summary of the article:

Several Singapore stocks experienced significant changes in trading on Monday. Best World International resumed trading after a trading halt due to concerns over its business practices. Raffles Medical Group posted a net profit of S$71.1 million for 2018, while APTT announced a 81.5% drop in its distribution per unit. Sarine Technologies reported a 84.8% drop in its fourth-quarter net profit. Dasin Retail Trust beat its forecast with a slight increase in its distribution per unit. Allied Technologies raised concerns with its auditors, and Chip Eng Seng Corp more than doubled its profits in the fourth quarter.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Monday; STI up 0.1% to 3,273.16
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.1% to 3,273.16 on Monday, driven by gains from CapitaLand and other active stocks, while Lippo Malls Indonesia Retail Trust plummeted 10.87% after heavy trading. The market saw 46.3 million securities worth S$97.1 million change hands. This marks the second consecutive day of gains, with the STI up 0.4% on Thursday.

site_title: Aussie rises after Trump delays China tariffs; yuan at 7-month high
summary: US President Donald Trump delayed increasing tariffs on Chinese goods to March 1, citing "substantial progress" in trade talks. The Australian dollar rose 0.4% and the yuan strengthened 0.3% to a 7-month high against the US dollar. The Japanese yen eased 0.1% and the euro gained 0.1% in early Asian trade. Trump also announced a planned summit meeting with Chinese President Xi Jinping to conclude an agreement, assuming further progress in trade talks. Market reaction was largely limited, with focus shifting to global economic fundamentals.

site_title: Broker's take: Maybank upgrades Hi-P International to 'hold' as 'worst appears over'
summary: Maybank upgraded Hi-P International to "hold" from "sell" due to management's belief that pricing pressure issues are over. The research unit expects earnings growth for FY2019 to be limited, but raised its estimated earnings by 59-67% and target price by 79% to S$1.22. Hi-P International's core Patmi rose 14.4% in the fourth quarter, driven by stronger-than-expected volumes and margins, despite a 35.2% year-on-year decline in the same period. The company expects lower net profit in the first quarter, but remains confident in delivering similar revenue and sales numbers in 2019.

site_title: Europe facing 'winds of xenophobia', Spain's Sanchez warns
summary: Spain's Prime Minister Pedro Sanchez warned Europe of the threat of "winds of xenophobia" as he marked 80 years since the flight of 475,000 Spaniards to France after Francisco Franco's takeover. Sanchez urged Europeans to resist xenophobia, citing recent desecration of Jewish graves in France and the dispute over migrants arriving by sea. He also visited the graves of two Republican leaders, highlighting his efforts to honor Franco's victims and move the former dictator's remains from an opulent mausoleum.

site_title: Oil prices firm on hopes for US, China trade deal
summary: Oil prices rose on Monday as Washington and China appeared to edge closer to a trade deal, dampening fears over global economic growth. International Brent crude oil futures rose 14 cents to $67.26 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude futures climbed 11 cents to $57.38 a barrel. Analysts cited optimism over a potential trade deal, reduced global oil supply, and US energy firms cutting oil rigs as supporting factors. President Trump delayed US tariff increases on Chinese goods, further boosting crude prices.

site_title: China's tech firms are mapping pig faces
summary: Chinese tech firms are using facial and voice recognition technologies to monitor and care for pigs, aiming to prevent a deadly swine disease that has killed nearly 1 million pigs in China. The systems track pigs' faces and vital statistics, and can detect sickness and predict ovulation time. While some companies claim these technologies can help farmers reduce costs and improve pig health, experts question the effectiveness and practicality of these solutions, citing the need for a comprehensive database of pig faces and the potential for manipulation or error.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on US-China trade deal hopes
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Monday due to optimism over a US-China trade deal, lifting US shares. The Nikkei 225 index gained 0.59% and the Topix index rose 0.58%. This positive sentiment was also seen in US shares, which edged to fresh records despite ongoing tariff uncertainty.

site_title: China's Xiaomi unveils 599 euros smartphone, sees growth in Africa
summary: China's Xiaomi unveiled a 599-euro smartphone that can take advantage of faster 5G mobile networks, targeting a lower price than analysts expected from rivals like Samsung. The company aims to drive 5G adoption among normal consumers, making it more affordable. Xiaomi is also expanding into the African market, seeing growth potential after accelerating migration from 3G to 4G in countries like India.

site_title: R Kelly has not posted bail, still jailed: lawyer
summary: Singer R. Kelly remains in detention after failing to post $1 million bail, despite a Chicago judge setting the amount. His lawyer, Steve Greenberg, stated that Kelly's wealth is mismanaged due to poor deals and contracts. Kelly was jailed on Friday on charges of sexually abusing four victims, including three minors, between 1998 and 2010.

site_title: Australian PM makes climate change pitch as election looms
summary: Australian Prime Minister Scott Morrison pledged A$2 billion over 10 years to lower greenhouse gas emissions, addressing climate change ahead of elections. He claims Australia will meet its Paris Agreement goal of 26-28% emissions reduction by 2030. The new Climate Solutions Fund targets small projects, while the opposition Labor Party aims for 45% emissions cut and A$10 billion in funding for large-scale renewable projects.

site_title: US to announce 'concrete steps' for Venezuela crisis on Monday: official
summary: US Vice-President Mike Pence will announce "concrete steps" and "clear actions" to address the Venezuela crisis on Monday, meeting with regional leaders in Bogota, Colombia. The US has blocked convoys of aid at the Venezuelan border, and Pence will meet with Venezuelan opposition leader Juan Guaido. The US aims to empower Guaido, who has been recognized as the country's interim president by Western leaders. Pence's speech may include new sanctions if the aid convoy is met with violence. The US has considered military force to support Guaido.

images.alt_text: US Vice-President Mike Pence is set to announce "concrete steps" and "clear actions" to address the Venezuela crisis when he meets on Monday with regional leaders in Bogota, Colombia, a senior US administration official said.

site_title: Uber in talks to sell India food-delivery business
summary: Uber is in talks to sell its food-delivery business in India to rival Swiggy, according to a person familiar with the negotiations. The talks are progressing, and a deal could be sealed within weeks. Uber entered India's competitive food-delivery market in 2017 but has struggled to gain traction against established players like Swiggy and Zomato. The move follows Uber's retreats from ride-hailing businesses in China, Russia, and Southeast Asia as the company prepares for a public offering later this year.

site_title: Indonesia to ease trading rules to lure mom-and-pop investors
summary: Indonesia's stock exchange plans to revise its trading rules, cutting the minimum trading price for shares from 50 rupiah and lowering the minimum order size from 100, to attract more retail investors and boost volumes. The move aims to deepen financial markets and develop the retail market. Volumes on the stock market have climbed 23% on average since the settlement cycle was pruned in November, and daily turnover has jumped 17%. The revisions are expected to bring high-value shares to retail investors and increase retail participation.

site_title: Tickled Media to expand into e-commerce with focus on mums
summary: Tickled Media, the startup behind parenting portal theAsianparent, plans to launch an e-commerce venture targeting Asian mothers later this year. The e-commerce platform will focus on the company's existing core audience and will be loss-making for about four years. The venture will complement theAsianparent's existing online community offerings, which already have 13 million monthly active users. Tickled Media's CEO, Roshni Mahtani, expects the e-commerce platform to partner with existing e-commerce giants in South-east Asia and will not compete directly with them.

site_title: Singapore dollar's winning streak faces toughest test yet
summary: The Singapore dollar's three-month winning streak faces its toughest test yet due to dimming global growth prospects. A strong inflation report could ensure the currency's advance remains on track, while a slowdown in China and global trade tensions signal weakness in the local dollar. The Monetary Authority of Singapore is expected to make a policy decision in April, with traders weighing the signals from domestic demand and inflation against global headwinds.

site_title: What's on the table at the second Trump-Kim summit?
summary: The second Trump-Kim summit is set to take place in Hanoi, Vietnam on February 27-28, with denuclearization of the Korean peninsula and easing sanctions on North Korea as key priorities. The US wants a comprehensive agreement, while North Korea seeks a phased approach. The summit aims to build on the progress made in the first meeting, but a deal's likelihood remains uncertain. Key issues include verification mechanisms for denuclearization and the pace of sanctions relief. A successful summit would be a significant step towards reducing tensions between the US and North Korea.

site_title: P2P lender Validus eyes Singapore banks as new partners
summary: Singapore's largest peer-to-peer lending platform, Validus Capital, is set to partner with local banks to provide financing for small- and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs). The platform, which assesses SMEs for financing using trade data and creditworthiness, has already matched $180 million in loans and is working with seven large corporates to provide financing to their vendors. Validus aims to have banks lend directly to SMEs through its platform, addressing the lack of financing options for these businesses.

site_title: British PM May signals she is ready to fight on
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May signaled her determination to continue leading the country despite struggling to secure Brexit and criticism from her own party. She expressed her commitment to both Brexit and her domestic agenda, stating there is still more work to be done to fulfill her promise to make Britain work for all its citizens. Despite reports of her potential departure, May refused to give a date for her exit and instead vowed to pursue her agenda, including key decisions on the National Health Service and future economic partnerships with the EU.

site_title: Sarine Technologies Q4 profit falls 84.8% to US$93,000
summary: Sarine Technologies reported a 84.8% decline in Q4 net profit to US$93,000 due to weak industry conditions and reduced capital equipment sales. The company is temporarily reducing its dividend policy for 2019 to one US cent every six months. Revenue declined 5.8% to US$12.2 million, while gross profit fell 11% to US$7.5 million. Despite lower overall expenses, the company expects adverse sentiments to persist in 2019 due to the diamond industry's midstream issues.

site_title: LG unveils dual-screen 5G smartphone and touts biometric breakthrough
summary: LG Electronics unveiled a dual-screen 5G smartphone, the V50ThinQ, with independent screens for watching films and browsing the internet. The phone also features biometric breakthroughs, including a 3D facial recognition system and vein scanning technology for secure unlocking. The G8ThinQ model uses light sensors to scan the user's hand or face without touching the screen. LG aims to revive flagging sales with these innovative features, set to be released in the first half of the year with no announced prices.

images.alt_text: LG product evangelist David Montanya told a launch event it would be harder to 'spoof' than the FaceID feature used in Apple's iPhone X because the vein structure in a user's hand has less than one chance in a billion of being the same as anyone else's.

site_title: Anger as UK's May asks for yet more time to amend Brexit deal
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May asked for more time to amend her Brexit deal, prompting outrage from business leaders and MPs. She suggested parliament may not vote on the text until 17 days before the UK's scheduled departure from the EU on March 29. The move drew criticism, with Labour's Brexit spokesman Keir Starmer calling it "the height of irresponsibility." Business leaders also expressed dismay, warning of potential economic disruption if a deal is not reached.

site_title: Huawei takes fight with US over spying fears to top mobile fair
summary: Huawei unveiled a new foldable smartphone, the Mate X, at the Mobile World Congress in Barcelona, amidst the US campaign to bar it from developing 5G wireless networks due to spying fears. Huawei denies any espionage, stating it adheres to laws and regulations in countries where it operates. The company's 5G equipment is seen as more advanced than rivals, with Huawei 12 months ahead in implementing 5G technology, posing a challenge to countries seeking to quickly deploy 5G networks.

site_title: Money FM podcast: The Hot Seat: What pro sports can teach us about digital transformation
summary: A Money FM podcast, "The Hot Seat", discusses digital transformation through the lens of professional sports. Mark Bunting, Rackspace chief marketing officer, shares examples of successful digital transformation in sports, such as the use of data analytics and digital platforms to enhance fan engagement. The conversation highlights the potential for sports to drive innovation and digital transformation in various industries.

site_title: Bond traders brace for March madness as US debt cap returns
summary: US Treasury traders are bracing for a potential "March madness" as the debt ceiling is set to be reinstated on March 1, with the government facing a potential funding crisis. The 10-year yield has remained stable, but traders are cautious ahead of Congressional testimony from Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell and US Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer. The Bank of America Merrill Lynch MOVE Index has fallen, indicating reduced market volatility, but experts warn that the situation could become volatile if Powell's comments are perceived as dovish.

site_title: New Zealand locks the doors from the inside
summary: New Zealand has implemented a ban on foreigners buying existing homes, effective in August 2018, to curb soaring home prices and push native buyers into the market. The move comes as the country faces a severe housing shortage, with median home prices in Auckland rising nearly 65% between 2008 and 2018. The ban aims to address concerns that wealthy foreign investors are driving up prices, but its effectiveness remains uncertain, with some arguing that the restrictions on the free market and xenophobia are misguided.

site_title: Emperor Akihito urges Japan to open up and build sincere ties with the world
summary: Japan's Emperor Akihito marked the 30th anniversary of his enthronement, calling for the country to open up and forge sincere ties with the world. In a speech, he emphasized the need for Japan to establish its position with wisdom and build relations with other countries with sincerity, particularly in light of its complex wartime legacy with neighboring countries. Akihito, who will abdicate on April 30, stressed the desire of his fellow Japanese for peace and recalled the need to remember the horrors of war.

site_title: Intel says its 5G modem chips will not appear in phones until 2020
summary: Intel's 5G modem chips will not appear in mobile phones until 2020, according to the company's executives. Sample 5G modem chips will be shipped to customers this year, but consumer products will not be available until 2020. This raises the possibility that Apple's iPhone with 5G capabilities may not be released in 2019, contradicting earlier reports. Intel's CEO Bob Swan plans to pursue other lines of business, including selling modems to carmakers, and the company will not generate patent licensing revenue from its 5G technology.

site_title: Kushner Cos buys portfolio of apartments for US$1.15b
summary: Kushner Cos, a US property company owned by Jared Kushner, has acquired a $1.15 billion portfolio of 6,030 apartments across 16 properties in Maryland and Virginia. This marks the firm's largest purchase in over a decade and signals its return to its roots in multifamily complexes. The deal comes after Kushner Cos sold suburban apartments in 2007 to finance the purchase of a Manhattan office tower. The company has been transitioning away from New York City and back to its roots in sprawling multifamily complexes.

site_title: Good chance of bullish trend continuing for STI in 2019
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) is expected to continue its bullish trend in 2019, driven by improved investor sentiments and anticipation of progress in US-China trade talks. Despite a 6.5% decline in 2018, the STI has rebounded strongly since January, supported by better-than-expected earnings results and a potential interest rate hike by the US Federal Reserve. The 50-day SMA crossing the 200-day SMA is seen as a bullish signal, and the index is trading near key levels that could influence its short-term performance.

site_title: Japanese classics are the hottest bet in car collecting right now
summary: Japanese classic cars are gaining popularity and value in the car collecting market, with some models selling for over $100,000. The Toyota Supra, Mazda Cosmo, and Acura NSX are among the most sought-after models, with prices increasing by 18.1% and 38.8% in the past three and five years, respectively. The rise is attributed to millennials who are finally able to afford their childhood heroes, and the thrill of owning a car that was featured in video games and posters. Experts predict this trend will continue, with other Japanese-branded cars also gaining value.

site_title: Bull run in US markets could stick around a while longer
summary: US stocks rose for the ninth consecutive week, driven by optimism over a potential trade deal. Despite disappointing economic data, investors remained hopeful as China's top trade representative extended a visit to Washington to continue talks. The rally could continue unless spoilers from special investigator Robert Mueller or trade negotiators appear. This upward momentum could carry into this week, with shares of companies like Singtel and Q&M Dental Group poised for potential gains.

site_title: Trump dangles 'major power' carrot as Kim begins trek to summit
summary: US President Donald Trump said North Korea's Kim Jong Un could become a "major power" if it relinquishes its nuclear arsenal, as Kim began a 4,000km train journey to the Vietnam summit. Trump will meet Kim in Vietnam next week, following their Singapore summit last June, which led to little concrete progress on North Korea's nuclear program. Trump's top diplomat Mike Pompeo tempered expectations, saying progress is needed for tangible results. The summit's outcome is uncertain, with observers warning that a "dud" could occur unless concrete commitments on denuclearization are made.

site_title: Armani presents a Rhapsody in Blue repertoire
summary: Veteran designer Giorgio Armani presented his Rhapsody in Blue Autumn/Winter 2019 collection at Milan Fashion Week, showcasing sleek and elegant looks in darker tones with accents of blue. The collection featured short jackets with round collars, pencil coats, and shiny blousons, with prints on suits and knotted trousers. Men's looks included midnight blue tailored suits, while women's wear included strapless tops and feminine florals. The show concluded with Armani walking out onto the catwalk, holding a model's hand, to loud applause.

site_title: How two brothers built a music school empire in Singapore
summary: Aureus Academy, founded by US-born brothers Lawrence and Julius Holmefjord-Sarabi, is expanding its music school empire in Singapore with a new conservatory. The academy offers a three-year diploma program and a six-month professional certificate, and plans to offer a Bachelor's degree in music. It also provides full scholarships to students who commit to teaching at Aureus, with employment opportunities available. The company aims to build a pipeline of talent for overseas expansion, with plans to open branches in Hong Kong, the Middle East, Indonesia, and China.

site_title: Uber said to be in talks to sell India food delivery business
summary: Uber is in talks to sell its food delivery business in India to Swiggy, a rival company, following a two-year presence in the country's competitive food-delivery market. The negotiations are progressing, with a potential deal within weeks. Uber has struggled to compete with Swiggy and other leading players, including Zomato, in the Indian food-delivery sector. This move comes after Uber's retreats from its ride-hailing business in China, Russia, and South-east Asia as the company prepares for a high-profile public offering later this year.

site_title: China's pledge to buy more US soybeans surprises traders
summary: China agreed to buy an additional 10 million metric tons of US soybeans, surpassing traders' expectations, according to Agriculture Secretary Sonny Perdue. This move comes as part of a possible trade deal between the two countries, with China proposing to buy $30 billion worth of US agricultural products annually. The purchase signals "good faith" from China, contradicting earlier market expectations of corn purchases. The announcement was made by Perdue on Twitter, beating the US Department of Agriculture's statement.

site_title: China deleveraging is dead as US$34t debt habit roars back
summary: China's deleveraging efforts are effectively over, with leverage indicators rising sharply in 2019, driven by increased bank loans, trust-product issuance, and margin-trading accounts. Despite a shift in focus from containing debt to shoring up the economy, analysts warn of potential risks to financial stability. China's total debt is expected to rise relative to GDP this year, but investors are optimistic about easier credit conditions, with yields on lower-rated corporate bonds dropping and the stock market surging.

site_title: F&B industry fears looming 'correction'
summary: The food and beverage (F&B) industry in Singapore is facing a potential "correction" due to declining consumer spending, lower foreign worker quotas, and rising price competition. Despite a 1.2% growth in fast-food takings, other segments like restaurants, caterers, and cafes saw a decline in real terms. The lowered foreign worker quota, from 40% to 35% by 2021, may further impact the industry, with companies potentially leaving the market or expanding overseas. Experts warn that those unable to adapt will face significant challenges.

site_title: The 'Huawei issue' hangs over mobile industry's biggest show
summary: The Mobile World Congress (MWC) in Barcelona is set to be overshadowed by the ongoing US-China stalemate over Huawei, with the Chinese telecom giant and the US government vying for influence among European politicians and industry leaders. Despite EU opposition to US demands to ban Huawei, the US government is bolstering its presence at the conference, while Huawei will focus on showcasing its technology and engaging with government officials. The event, which attracts 100,000 industry professionals, will also feature the latest gadgets, including foldable phones and 5G smartphones, amidst dealmaking and discussions on 5G deployment and antitrust rules.

site_title: Missoni glitters with a sparkling line
summary: Missoni's Milan Fashion Week show featured a 1970s-inspired Autumn/Winter 2019 collection with shimmering and sparkling elements. The line included wide-leg trousers, satin-like jumpsuits, glitter lame, and sparkling pierrot collars. The fashion house incorporated its signature flamed ziz-zag pattern and other prints, including mosaic-like and wavy designs, into the collection. The show's artistic director, Angela Missoni, aimed to connect the past and present through the use of color and patterns, resulting in a visually striking and nostalgic collection.

site_title: Gear up to be transformed
summary: Tightening foreign worker hiring in Singapore's services sector will impact firms, particularly in food & beverage and retail industries, which rely heavily on foreign workers. Experts suggest that automation, digital upskilling programs, and strategic workforce planning are key to transforming the sector and addressing manpower challenges. The government's progressive tightening of foreign manpower policy through the Dependency Ratio Ceiling will take two years to be fully implemented, allowing the sector to identify ways to deepen capabilities. Companies can mitigate the effects of a skills shortage by adapting staff attraction policies, investing in local training, and adopting flexible staffing arrangements.

site_title: China's January LNG imports rise to record high
summary: China's liquefied natural gas (LNG) imports surged to a record high in January, reaching 6.58 million tonnes, a 27.8% increase from the previous year. This rise is attributed to higher residential heating demand during the winter, following China's shift to gas heating. This marks the highest LNG imports since December, when they also reached a new high.

site_title: MIT completes private placement; Singtel commences buyback mandate
summary: MIT completes a private placement, raising S$201 million, with S$197.8 million used to refinance an acquisition and S$3.2 million for fees and expenses. The manager also issued new units, changing the percentage level of Mapletree Dextra's holdings in MIT. Singtel commenced its share buyback mandate, buying back 370,672 shares for S$1.11 million. Nine stocks conducted share buybacks, totaling S$10 million, with Singtel and Keppel Reit leading the tally.

site_title: S-Reits stand to gain this year as markets turn in their favour
summary: Singapore-listed real estate investment trusts (S-Reits) are poised to gain this year due to dovish signals from the US Federal Reserve, global macro uncertainties, and a tightening supply in commercial, hospitality, and industrial sectors. Analysts predict a 8% rise in the FTSE ST Reit Index since the Fed Chairman's interest rate comments, and expect further compression in yield spreads. This could lead to increased acquisitions, new listings, and IPOs, benefiting investors seeking safe-haven assets.

site_title: Surprise China default upends beliefs on official aid
summary: A Chinese state-backed borrower, Qinghai Provincial Investment Group Co, defaulted on a dollar bond payment, contradicting assumptions that officials would intervene to prevent defaults by companies linked to local authorities. The missed payment on a $300 million bond due in 2020 indicates limits to government support for high-leverage borrowers in industries with excess capacity. This may renew predictions for local government financing vehicle (LGFV) defaults, posing a significant risk to the Chinese financial system.

site_title: Brexiteer MPs could vote for May's deal to ensure Brexit date isn't extended
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May has delayed a vote on the UK Withdrawal Deal from the European Union, initially set for Wednesday, to March 12. The delay is due to further meetings in Brussels to secure changes to the deal, which could influence Brexiteer MPs to vote in favor of the deal to avoid an extension of the Brexit deadline.

site_title: Saving lives and losses through Disaster Tech crowdsourcing
summary: The Prudential's community investment arm, Prudence Foundation, and Singapore-based funders' network, AVPN, launched the Disaster Tech Innovation Programme to limit harm from natural disasters. The programme aims to raise awareness of innovative technology solutions to protect lives before, during, and after disasters. It will host a competition for for-profit and non-profit organizations to crowdsource Disaster Tech solutions, with a total grant pool of $150,000. The initiative supports the UN Sustainable Development Goals, specifically Goals 11 and 13, and seeks to foster partnerships and cross-sector collaboration in disaster preparedness and risk mitigation.

site_title: Stablecoins promise steady crypto, but questions about reliability remain
summary: Stablecoins, a type of virtual currency pegged to traditional currencies, have gained popularity as a more steady alternative to volatile cryptocurrencies. The total value of stablecoins in circulation has more than doubled to $3 billion over the past year, with 26 stablecoins currently existing and 28 in development. Despite their advantages, stablecoins have raised questions about their reliability, with concerns over the centralised nature and issuing entity of some stablecoins. Companies like JPMorgan Chase are exploring the use of stablecoins, and some analysts see them as a potential solution to the volatility of cryptocurrencies, allowing for more stable transactions and use cases.

site_title: VW warns of challenges, in tough year ahead
summary: Volkswagen warned of a challenging year ahead due to increased inventories and supply bottlenecks caused by new emissions testing rules. The company expects vehicle deliveries to rise slightly and group revenues to increase by 5% in 2019. Despite this, Volkswagen's 2018 operating profit came in at 13.92 billion euros, below forecast. The company aims to achieve an operating return on sales of 6.5-7.5% for the passenger cars division and the group.

site_title: Best World to conduct independent review of business and accounting practices
summary: Best World International, a Singapore-based skincare company, has hired an independent reviewer to scrutinize its business and accounting practices amid concerns over the challenges in tracking sales of its DR's Secret line in China. The company, which derives 66% of its revenue from China, has clarified its payment terms and accounting treatment for its franchisees, stating that it is not responsible for their accounting and sales records. The independent review's findings will be published and reported to the audit committee and Singapore Exchange RegCo, and auditors Ernst & Young will conduct a site visit at some BWL Lifestyle Centers to ensure the occurrence, completeness, and measurement of revenue.

site_title: Nominations open for Brands for Good 2019
summary: The Brands for Good 2019 awards platform is back, recognizing businesses that use intellectual property to create positive impact in the workplace, community, and environment. Over 200 participants attended the launch, with more than 1,000 expected to participate in the awards ceremony in September. The platform aims to support companies in their innovation journeys through the Brands for Good Innovation Bursary, offering S$1,000 to 100 companies. The awards ceremony will also feature a youth challenge segment, where 50 Asian youths will pitch business ideas addressing real-world problems.

site_title: UK may ban Persimmon from help-to-buy programme: Times report
summary: The UK government may ban Persimmon Plc from the extended Help to Buy program due to allegations of poor standards and hidden charges. Housing Secretary James Brokenshire is concerned about the company's behavior regarding leasehold structures and construction quality. Persimmon has faced criticism for its use of leasehold structures and high executive pay, including a £75-million bonus package. The government is reviewing Persimmon's participation in the program, which offers interest-free loans for new home purchases.

site_title: Focus on US-China talks, release of key macro data
summary: US-China trade talks will continue this week, with meetings extended by two days ahead of a March 1 deadline. US President Donald Trump is set to meet North Korean leader Kim Jong-un in Hanoi, Vietnam, and is likely to meet Chinese President Xi Jinping in March. The US will release key macro data, including Q4 GDP figures and personal consumption expenditure price index figures on Thursday. Investors will watch for comments from Trump during Asia trading hours, and regional markets may trade cautiously unless an extension to the US tariff truce is confirmed.

site_title: POSH narrows Q4 net loss on smaller impairment charges
summary: POSH narrowed its Q4 net loss to US$79.99 million, compared to a restated net loss of US$194.9 million in the same period last year. The company booked a smaller impairment loss of US$49.5 million on fixed assets, down from US$108.3 million in the prior year. Revenue increased 6% year-over-year to US$65.99 million, driven by improved performance in the offshore maintenance segment. Despite increased activities in this segment, the company cited ongoing oversupply pressure on vessel utilization and charter rates.

site_title: Indonesia asks India to cut palm oil tariffs in exchange for sugar imports
summary: Indonesia has asked India to cut its tariff on refined palm oil to 45% to match Malaysia's levy, in exchange for market access for Indian sugar imports. Trade Minister Enggartiasto Lukita made the request during a meeting with Suresh Prabhu in New Delhi. Indonesia, the world's largest palm oil producer, currently imports raw sugar from Thailand and Australia, but is willing to open up market access for Indian sugar. India has responded positively to the request, which could increase Malaysia's market share in Indian palm oil imports.

site_title: In Helsinki, they hang Michelin stars in the bathroom
summary: Helsinki, Finland has added a new Michelin-starred restaurant, Ask, to its growing dining scene, bringing the city's total to six Michelin-starred restaurants. This increase is a notable contrast to neighboring cities like Stockholm and Copenhagen, which have seen rising prices and reservation difficulties due to their Michelin-starred reputations. Helsinki's approach, however, has allowed its best restaurants to maintain availability and a more local focus, with chefs aware of the mistakes made by the now-defunct Chez Dominique.

site_title: Thai insurtech Sunday bags US$10 million Series A funding led by Vertex Ventures
summary: Thai insurtech startup Sunday has secured $10 million in Series A funding led by Vertex Ventures Southeast Asia and India. The 1.5-year-old platform offers customizable non-life insurance products through an AI-driven risk-prediction model, targeting small and medium enterprises. Sunday aims to expand to Southeast Asian markets, including Singapore, Malaysia, and Indonesia, with its integrated platform set to change insurance pricing and claims payouts. The funding will be used to expand its data team and conduct research and development.

site_title: Warning issued over attacks on key Internet infrastructure
summary: The Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers (Icann) has warned of a significant risk to key parts of the internet infrastructure, threatening the global system of web traffic. This comes after large-scale attacks on the infrastructure. Icann declared the ongoing and significant risk, affecting domains on which websites reside. The warning is a result of an emergency meeting, highlighting the vulnerability of the internet's critical components.

site_title: Design Studio widens Q4 loss on one-off cost overruns
summary: Design Studio Group reported a widened net loss of S$13.75 million in its fourth quarter, compared to a restated net loss of S$3.36 million the same period last year. The loss was due to one-off costs of S$7.5 million, including manufacturing overruns and closure of underutilized showrooms in Malaysia and China. Despite a 12.2% increase in fourth-quarter revenue to S$43.1 million, the company's net loss widened due to the higher costs.

site_title: Parisians wake up to coffee-fuelled urban mushroom magic
summary: In Paris, urban agriculture is gaining popularity as a means of recycling organic waste from cities. Coffee grounds from local brasseries are being used to produce oyster mushrooms through a process that involves mixing the grounds with cardboard and wood chips, then incubating them in a dark space with mushroom spores. The resulting mushrooms are harvested and sold, with the used grounds then becoming compost and being reused to produce more mushrooms. This trend aims to reduce waste and promote a circular economy, with around 20 tonnes of coffee grounds collected monthly in and around Paris.

images.alt_text: Mushrooms growing in bags filled with coffee grounds. Two tonnes of oyster mushrooms can be produced from 20 tonnes of coffee grounds.

site_title: R&B crooner R. Kelly charged with sexually assaulting teenage girls
summary: R&B singer R. Kelly, 52, was charged with aggravated sexual assault of four people, including three teenage girls, in a 10-count Cook County Circuit Court indictment. The charges follow a Lifetime documentary series that accused Kelly of sexual misconduct and abuse. Kelly denies the allegations, but faces a maximum sentence of 70 years in prison if convicted. A 40-minute videotape allegedly showing Kelly performing sexual acts with a 14-year-old girl was given to prosecutors by attorney Michael Avenatti, who is representing two alleged victims.

site_title: EY probed in Denmark as Swedbank hires firm in laundering review
summary: EY is being probed in Denmark over its involvement in a money laundering review at Swedbank AB, following a report that the lender was involved in suspicious transactions. The investigation started in October after Danske Bank A/S admitted to handling $230 billion in suspicious funds between 2007 and 2015. Swedbank has acknowledged it also handled suspicious transactions and is launching an independent review. The scandal has led to significant losses for Danske and raises concerns about the Nordic banking system's involvement in money laundering.

site_title: UBS ignored whistleblower warnings in French tax case: judgement
summary: UBS faces a 4.5 billion euro penalty for breaking French tax laws after being warned by employees for at least six years. Whistleblowers reported concerns over soliciting new business at golf tournaments and other events, breaching French regulations. The bank denied wrongdoing, but financial regulators expressed concerns over the thoroughness of internal investigations. UBS staff, including a former legal department director, raised concerns in 2003 and 2006, but the bank claimed these warnings were "unsubstantiated gossip."

site_title: It's hard to get excited about soy acres when trade questions loom
summary: US farmers and analysts are uncertain about soy acreage forecasts due to ongoing trade negotiations between the US and China. The US government released forecasts, but the data will be heavily influenced by the outcome of trade talks. Rich Feltes, director of market insights, stated that trade questions overshadow discussions about plantings and weather at the annual US government outlook forum. The uncertainty surrounding trade negotiations will impact forecasts for soy acres and stockpiles.

site_title: Dasin Retail Trust posts slight beat to Q4 DPU
summary: DASIN Retail Trust posted a slight beat to its Q4 distribution per unit (DPU) of 1.83 Singapore cents, beating the forecast by 0.9%. The distribution yield is 9.09%, exceeding the forecast yield of 8.99%. The trust's net property income fell 18% to S$11.6 million due to lower revenue from asset enhancements and higher property operating expenses.

site_title: With eye on election, Modi begins distributing cash to farmers
summary: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi has launched an income support programme for small farmers ahead of the general election due by May, distributing 2,000 rupees (S$37.9) to those holding 2 hectares of land. The programme aims to double farmers' income by 2022 and has proposed spending 750 billion rupees this fiscal year. The move comes as crop prices fall and fertiliser costs increase, with farmers facing high debt and rising rural unemployment. The programme benefits about 120 million small farmers and is funded by the federal government.

site_title: UK's Labour is moving closer to backing second Brexit referendum: senior lawmakers
summary: Labour Party in the UK is moving closer to supporting a second Brexit referendum, with senior lawmakers stating it could happen as soon as this week. The party's deputy leader Tom Watson said they are "getting closer" to backing a second referendum, while Labour finance spokesman John McDonnell expressed a "high possibility" of a redrafted amendment that could pass. This move comes as Prime Minister Theresa May seeks to negotiate changes to her Brexit deal with Brussels, and could pose a dilemma for Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn, who has kept the option of a second referendum "on the table".

site_title: N. Korea warns US sceptics as Kim heads for Vietnam for summit with Trump
summary: North Korean leader Kim Jong Un warned US President Donald Trump not to listen to critics disrupting talks on improving ties, as he traveled to Vietnam for a second summit with Trump on February 24, 2019. The two leaders aim to discuss denuclearization of the Korean peninsula, but critics, including US Democratic senators and security officials, have warned Trump against cutting a deal that would do little to curb North Korea's nuclear ambitions. The summit is seen as a rare historic opportunity for improved relations and world peace.

site_title: Microsoft workers demand it drop US$480m US Army contract
summary: Microsoft employees are demanding the company cancel a $480 million contract with the US Army to supply augmented reality headsets, citing ethical concerns. The employees, who organized a petition, want Microsoft to develop a public policy for its technology use and an external review board to enforce it. This move comes after worker pushback led Alphabet Inc to cancel a similar Pentagon contract. Microsoft President Brad Smith previously stated the company remains committed to assisting the military and will engage in advocating for responsible use of AI and other technologies.

site_title: Vitol expects oil prices to rally further
summary: Vitol, the world's largest independent oil trader, expects oil prices to rally further due to OPEC output cuts, problems in Iran and Venezuela, and a shortage of low-quality heavy crudes. CEO Russell Hardy states that oil supply will be tight until the third quarter, with refiners paying high premiums for heavy-sour grades. The heavy-light crude mismatch is benefiting OPEC giants and could lead to lower gasoline prices, but truckers may face challenges. Vitol forecasts a 1.1 million barrel per day growth in global oil demand in 2019, and expects US production to surge in the fourth quarter, potentially challenging OPEC's supply and demand balance.

site_title: North Korea's Kim to make official visit to Vietnam in 'coming days'
summary: North Korean leader Kim Jong Un is set to make an official visit to Vietnam in the coming days, ahead of a summit with US President Donald Trump on February 27-28. Kim is expected to travel by train to Hanoi, where he will meet Trump, and Vietnam has increased security measures in anticipation of the visit. The two leaders' first summit last year produced a vague commitment to denuclearization, with hopes for more concrete outcomes this time around. The visit marks an unprecedented move by Vietnam to host a high-profile North Korean leader.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights report covers the week's tanker and dry bulk market, with a focus on West Australia/China shipments, rates, and market trends. Capesize rates hovered around $5.00 for 7 March onward cargoes, while Tubarao/Qingdao rates reached the upper $12.00 range. Timecharter trading was largely absent, with a few ships fixed for specific routes. Panamax rates improved, with standard Kamsarmaxes in the low $12,000s and low $200,000 for eco builds. Supramax rates saw a wide spread between Atlantic and East trades. The Baltic Handysize Index climbed 38 points, with rates slowly improving. The tanker market saw a firm sentiment, with VLCC rates increasing and Suezmax rates easing. Aframax rates were also steady, while clean rates dropped.

site_title: Brands boycott YouTube, but they can't quit Google
summary: Several high-profile brands, including Walt Disney Co. and Nestle SA, have paused their ads on YouTube after a blogger demonstrated how the platform can be used to forge networks of people engaged in child exploitation. Despite the boycotts, advertisers have found workarounds to stay on the platform, such as striking deals with influential creators. YouTube has responded by disabling comments on tens of millions of videos featuring children and reporting accounts that made predatory comments to police, but the platform has resisted calls for more drastic action.

site_title: Trump says could include Huawei and ZTE in trade deal
summary: US President Donald Trump said he may include Chinese telecommunications companies Huawei and ZTE in a trade deal currently being negotiated between the US and China. The Justice Department has charged Huawei with violating US sanctions and stealing robotic technology from T-Mobile. ZTE was previously prevented from buying US components due to similar charges, but has since paid fines and replaced its board. It's unclear how ZTE could be involved in a trade agreement, and US officials are not discussing dropping charges against Huawei.

site_title: Branson's Virgin Galactic takes another step toward space tourism
summary: Virgin Galactic successfully conducted a test flight with a passenger on board, reaching an altitude of 55 miles above Earth, marking a significant step towards suborbital space tourism. The flight, piloted by David Mackay, was part of a series of tests to prepare for commercial flights, with hundreds of spectators, including CEO George Whitesides, watching from the ground. The company, led by billionaire Richard Branson, aims to offer space tourism with a 90-minute flight costing $250,000, with over 600 people from 58 countries having paid deposits.

site_title: No more MOUs! Lighthizer tweaks trade terminology after dispute with Trump
summary: US Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer has changed the terminology used in trade talks with China, replacing "Memorandum of Understanding" (MOU) with "trade agreement." This move comes after President Donald Trump expressed his dislike for MOUs, calling them "a waste of time." The change was made after Trump expressed dissatisfaction with the MOUs, which had been drawn up in six critical areas to form the outline of a potential trade pact. The US and China are in trade talks, with Lighthizer stating that from now on, the focus will be on "trade agreements."

site_title: US may slap new sanctions on Venezuela if aid convoys blocked: official
summary: The US may announce new sanctions on Venezuela if humanitarian aid convoys are blocked by the Venezuelan military, according to a senior administration official. The convoys, aimed at providing aid to the country, are planned for this weekend. US Vice President Mike Pence will meet with Western Hemisphere leaders in Bogota, where aid pledges could be boosted or new sanctions could be taken. The official stated that violence or negative reactions from the Venezuelan military could lead to increased sanctions, including closing the international financial circle.

site_title: Fed to keep open mind in review of strategy, tools, Clarida says
summary: The Federal Reserve will conduct a broad review of its monetary policy framework this year, led by vice chair Richard Clarida. The review aims to assess current practices and consider new tools to combat future downturns. Clarida stated that the Fed will keep an open mind during the review and make the results public in the first half of 2020. The review will focus on the Fed's flexible inflation-targeting approach, bond-buying programs, and communications around policy. Any changes to the framework will aim to enhance the Fed's ability to achieve its dual-mandate objectives.

site_title: Oil hits 2019 highs on US-China trade hopes, but US output weighs
summary: Oil prices reached 2019 highs on Friday, with Brent crude futures reaching $67.73 a barrel, driven by hopes of a US-China trade deal. US crude production surged to a record 12 million barrels per day, offsetting Opec's production cuts. Despite this, Goldman Sachs expects non-Opec supply to grow, with demand expected to grow by 1.4 million barrels per day in 2019, leading to an average Brent price of $60-$65 per barrel.

site_title: Best World to hire independent party to review business and accounting practices
summary: Best World International is hiring an independent reviewer to scrutinize its business and accounting practices in China, following concerns over tracking sales of its DR's Secret premium skincare products. The company, which derives 66% of its revenue from China, has faced challenges reconciling upfront sales figures with underlying consumer demand. An independent review will be published and reported to its audit committee and the Singapore Exchange RegCo, with auditors Ernst & Young also conducting site visits at BWL Lifestyle Centers operated by franchisees.

site_title: NY governor orders probe into Facebook access to data from other apps
summary: New York Governor Andrew Cuomo ordered a probe into Facebook's access to personal data from other apps after a report by The Wall Street Journal revealed the company collects sensitive user data, including health information, without users' knowledge or consent. The report found that apps share user data with Facebook, and the company can access data even when users are not signed in or have no Facebook account. The investigation will be conducted by New York's Department of State and Department of Financial Services.

site_title: Warning issued over attacks on internet infrastructure
summary: The Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers (ICANN) has issued a warning over attacks on internet infrastructure, citing an "ongoing and significant risk" to key parts of the system. ICANN chief technology officer David Conrad stated that targeted attacks have increased, with no previous incidents comparable to the current threat. The warning aims to harden defenses and protect the internet infrastructure.

site_title: US: Wall St trims gains as US, China struggle over gaps in trade issues
summary: US stocks trimmed gains on Friday after US officials said the US and China still have issues to resolve in their ongoing trade talks. Despite progress in talks, China's resistance to US demands for specific steps to end forced technology transfers and certain policies has hindered negotiations. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.36% to 25,944.67, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also posted gains, but fell short of reaching a ninth consecutive week of gains.

site_title: Twitter co-founder Evan Williams stepping down from board
summary: Twitter co-founder Evan Williams is stepping down from the company's board at the end of February. Williams, 46, has been on the board since 2012 and previously served as CEO, chief product officer, and chairman. He credits the company's growth during his 13-year tenure and thanks co-founders Jack Dorsey and Biz Stone for their contributions. The move comes as Twitter faces competition from Facebook and aims to improve its user base and conversation. Williams will continue to serve as CEO of web publisher Medium Corp.

site_title: Time's Up CEO resigns after son accused of sexual misconduct
summary: Lisa Borders, CEO of Time's Up, resigned after her son, Garry "Dijon" Bowden Jr, was accused of sexually misconducting a woman who had sought a "healing session" with him. The woman claimed he touched her genitals, kissed her neck, and brushed his penis against her body. Borders stepped down after a woman shared her story on Facebook, and Time's Up issued a statement supporting survivors of sexual abuse and harassment, while respecting the woman's right to own her story. Borders had taken the decision to resign after being informed of the allegations.

site_title: Trump picks Canada envoy Kelly Craft as UN ambassador
summary: US President Donald Trump announced the nomination of Kelly Craft, his envoy to Canada, as the next US ambassador to the United Nations. If confirmed by the US Senate, Craft would fill the vacant post since Nikki Haley's departure. Trump praised Craft's representation skills, stating she will lead the US at the highest level.

site_title: Avarga swings into Q4 loss on bigger forex loss, absence of one-off gain
summary: AVARGA Ltd, a paper manufacturer, reported a net loss of S$3.78 million in the fourth quarter of 2018, reversing from a year-ago net profit of S$465,000. The loss was driven by a higher forex loss of S$4.6 million and the absence of a S$2.4 million one-off gain from extinguishing subordinated notes. Revenue declined 10% to S$329 million. The company's Q4 loss marked a significant turnaround from the previous year's profit.

site_title: Gold prices whipsaw on US Fed posture
summary: Gold prices surged to a 10-month high last week, only to be whipsawed by market sentiments on the possibility of additional US rate hikes in 2019. Despite positive signals from US-China trade negotiations, heightened risk appetites eroded bullion appeal. The precious metal remains fundamentally supported by softer growth prospects and looming market risks. Gold prices are poised for a short-term bearish correction, with key support levels at $1,316.00 and $1,302.00.

site_title: Mueller report not coming next week: senior US Justice official
summary: US Special Counsel Robert Mueller's 21-month investigation into Russian interference in the 2016 US elections will not be completed next week as expected, according to a senior US Justice Department official. The report, which also focused on possible obstruction of justice, will not be delivered to the Department of Justice during the week of Feb 28. The Justice Department may announce that Mueller has given his report to Attorney General William Barr, who will review the findings and submit a summary to Congress. The report's release timing and whether it will be made public remain unclear.

site_title: Trump's economy "a little under" 3% growth goal: Fed
summary: The US economy grew "a little under" 3% in 2018, falling short of President Trump's target, according to the Federal Reserve. Tax cuts and policies had a waning impact, while trade and the federal deficit widened. Employment growth remained strong, but consumer spending and business investment declined. The Fed attributed the growth to a "noticeable pickup" from recent years, but warned of headwinds that could carry over into 2019. The White House had forecast 3% growth for 2018 and 2019, but the Fed does not share this view.

site_title: Sevak stuck on SGX watch-list until June
summary: Sevak, an IT solutions company, will remain on the Singapore Exchange's (SGX) watch-list until at least June 2019 after the market regulator deferred its review of the company's application to exit the list. Despite three years of pre-tax losses, the company has turned profitable with a net profit of S$3.7 million for fiscal 2018. However, concerns over Sevak's stock trading activity have been raised by SGX RegCo, which has urged caution when trading the company's shares.

site_title: US housing market facing slowdown as home sales sink to 3-year low
summary: US home sales dropped 1.2% to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 4.94 million units in January, the lowest level in over three years. Existing home sales were down 8.5% from a year ago, and the median existing house price increased 2.8% to $247,500. This suggests a further slowdown in the US housing market, which has been stymied by rising mortgage rates, land and labor shortages, and tight inventory.

site_title: Democrats move to block Trump's border emergency
summary: US Democrats introduced a resolution to block President Donald Trump's national emergency declaration for border wall construction, which they claim has no valid rationale. The measure, expected to clear the House and Senate, faces uncertain prospects in the Republican-controlled Senate. Trump vowed to veto the measure, which requires a two-thirds majority to override. The emergency declaration sparked fierce debate and lawsuits, with some Republicans expressing concern about Trump's unilateral power grab.

site_title: Allied Tech's ex-CFO flags concerns with auditors, sponsor
summary: Former CFO Andrew Wong, who left Allied Tech 2 months into his role, raised concerns with auditors and sponsor about expenses classification, documentation processes, and an audit of Asia Box Office, a company investment. The board is now discussing the issues with the sponsor and auditors, with more updates to follow. Wong's resignation marks the fourth major departure at Allied Tech in 12 months, and shares fell 7.14% after the announcement.

site_title: Aussie flag flying high
summary: The HSBC World Women's Championship, Asia's leading female golf tournament, is returning next week with a strong field, including defending champion Michelle Wie. Australian ace Minjee Lee discusses what it takes to win the $1.5 million event, billed as 'Asia's Major'. This year's tournament promises to be as competitive as ever, with many top golfers vying for the top spot.

site_title: SPH Golf extends reach into China
summary: SPH Golf has expanded its reach in China, offering members access to over 100 courses at preferential rates through the Gaotoo golf booking mobile app. This move aims to tap into China's growing golf market.

site_title: China's January home price growth at 9-month low as confidence dips
summary: China's home prices grew at a 9-month low of 0.6% in January, according to data from the National Bureau of Statistics. This marks 45 straight months of price increases, but monthly gains are slowing, with 58 of 70 cities reporting higher prices. Despite this, prices are still up 10% on a year, driven by strong demand. Analysts say uncertainties from the US-China trade war have turned investors bearish, but the current price gain is within a healthy range. Local authorities may loosen property policies this year to stabilize sentiment.

site_title: Hong Kong's pent-up property demand heralds price rebound
summary: Hong Kong's property market is expected to rebound, with prices potentially rising 10-30% this year, driven by pent-up demand, slower interest rate rises, and optimism over a trade deal. Total transaction volumes jumped 120% in January, and analysts forecast a 5% rise in 2019. Despite concerns about a sustained drop in prices, policymakers face challenges in easing public discontent over rising costs and asset bubble risks. Analysts attribute the rebound to fundamental shortages and the accumulation of pent-up demand.

site_title: HRnetGroup eyes expansion into new markets
summary: HRnetGroup, a Singapore-listed recruitment firm, is expanding into new markets including Vietnam, the UK, and Australia with S$22 million and S$100 million allocated for expansion plans. The company posted a record-high full-year net profit of S$48.2 million, driven by strong business momentum and growth from China. HRnetGroup aims to increase its regional delivery capability, with a goal of surpassing 50% gross profit from North Asia in three years. Despite challenges from political uncertainties and trade tensions, the company remains committed to its expansion efforts.

site_title: Europe: Margins in focus as results drive big swings in European stocks
summary: European stocks rose marginally on Friday, driven by strong company results, including a 17.8% gain for Sopra Steria and a 11.9% jump for chipmaker ASM International. However, Elekta's 13.5% decline and a weak earnings report from Kraft Heinz weighed on the sector. Margin pressure remains a concern, with the gap between revenue beats and earnings beats reaching an eight-year high. The STOXX 600 and Germany's DAX rose 0.2 and 0.3% respectively, with the food and beverage sector being the worst-performing.

site_title: Malaysia's consumer prices fall for first time since 2009
summary: Malaysia's consumer prices fell 0.7% in January, the first decline in nearly a decade, driven by lower fuel costs. However, economists say deflation is unlikely to be sustained and will not impact monetary policy. The decline was largely due to a sharp drop in retail fuel prices. Despite this, the country's central bank is not expected to cut rates, as inflation is expected to pick up in the second quarter. The decline is considered temporary, and prices are likely to revert back upwards.

site_title: Banks stung by Q4 market volatility
summary: Singapore's three major banks, OCBC, UOB, and DBS, reported weaker-than-expected results in the fourth quarter, citing market volatility and mark-to-market losses. OCBC's net profit fell 11% to S$926 million, while UOB's rose 7% to S$916 million. DBS's net profit increased 10% to S$1.32 billion. The banks also signaled slower loan growth and margin expansion for 2019, with DBS expecting a mid-single-digit loan growth and OCBC guiding for a low to mid-single-digit growth.

site_title: US-China extend trade talks as deadline looms
summary: US President Donald Trump announced a trade summit with Chinese leader Xi Jinping is likely to occur in March at his Mar-a-Lago resort in Florida. The talks were extended through Sunday as negotiators aim to reach a deal ahead of a deadline next week. Trump expressed optimism about a positive outcome, with analysts predicting the two sides will agree on mutual agreements, such as increasing US exports and intellectual property protections. However, tougher issues like China's industrial strategy remain uncertain, with Beijing proposing significant increases in US energy and agricultural imports.

site_title: The many-faceted martini
summary: The Atlas Bar in Singapore offers a modern take on the classic martini, with head bartender Jesse Vida explaining the principles behind the drink. A good martini consists of three steps: the martini conversation, choosing between gin and vodka, and the execution of building the drink with perfect temperature and dilution. Atlas' classic martini is stirred, not shaken, and garnished with an olive or lemon twist. The bar's extensive gin selection, inspired by the 1920s-1940s European lobby bars, has earned it a spot on the World's 50 Best Bars List and a "vintage martini" option using gin from the decade of choice.

site_title: Airports: a flight to safety?
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Privatized airports have delivered attractive total returns to shareholders, with an average annual return of 18% over the last 10 years. Some airports, such as Copenhagen and Malta International, have achieved returns of up to 30% and 20% respectively due to efficient asset use and high profit margins. Leverage and dividend payments also contribute to airport returns, with some airports paying out over half of their profits as dividends. Monopolies with pricing power and recurring income make airports an attractive investment opportunity, especially in uncertain market conditions. Airports are considered a stable and certain investment.

site_title: Patients die as Venezuela's politicians fight over medical aid stuck at border
summary: A humanitarian crisis in Venezuela has escalated as politicians fight over medical aid stuck at the border. The aid, including food and medicine, has been held up for nearly two weeks, leaving patients with dire consequences. The Venezuelan government, led by President Nicolás Maduro, has blocked the aid, calling it a "Trojan horse" aimed at overthrowing his government. The opposition, backed by the US, has vowed to get the aid through, but critics say the focus on toppling Maduro is overshadowing humanitarian needs. The crisis has put thousands of patients, including those with life-threatening conditions, at risk of death.

site_title: Billion-dollar manager says now's the time to sell risky assets
summary: Billion-dollar portfolio manager Ariel Bezalel of Jupiter Asset Management has become increasingly cautious, recommending investors sell high-risk assets and seek shelter in safer US Treasuries amid a global economic slowdown. Bezalel attributes the recent "bounce" in high-yield assets to a bear-market rally, citing the world's excessive debt and China's limited policy stimulus. His Dynamic Bond fund has reduced its exposure to high-yield assets, now at 20%, and is preparing for a potential global recession.

site_title: LMIRT slashes Q4 payout
summary: Lippo Malls Indonesia Retail Trust (LMIRT) has slashed its Q4 payout to 0.3 Singapore cents per unit, down from 0.79 cents last year, due to "challenging conditions" including a weaker rupiah and higher income tax costs. The trust reported a 61% year-on-year decline in distributable income and a 10.5% drop in net property income. LMIRT used internal cash resources and an unsecured term loan to refinance debt and incurred higher realised currency losses. The trust's full-year DPU fell to 2.05 Singapore cents from 3.44 cents last year.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Genting Singapore maintained a "buy" rating with a target price of S$1.54 due to concerns over slowing gaming revenues being partially priced in. ST Engineering upgraded to "add" with a target price of S$4.08, driven by the acquisition of MRAS and a strong order book, but faces risks from the US-China trade war.

site_title: Saudi Aramco signs US$10b China refinery deal
summary: Saudi Aramco has signed a $10 billion deal to partner with China's Norinco to develop a refining and petrochemical complex in Panjin, China. The joint venture, Huajin Aramco Petrochemical Co, will include a 300,000-barrels-per-day refinery and a 1.5-million-metric-tonnes-per-year ethylene cracker. The complex is expected to start operations in 2024, with Aramco supplying up to 70% of the crude feedstock. The deal aims to boost Saudi Arabia's market share in China and diversify its economy.

site_title: Razer CEO backs Echo Base, a startup with mission to disrupt traditional real estate
summary: Razer CEO Tan Min-Liang has backed Echo Base, a startup aiming to disrupt traditional real estate development with AI, IoT, and other next-gen technologies. Echo Base, led by real estate investment banker Bryan Lim, will focus on smart buildings and integrated developments in Asia-Pacific and global gateway cities. The platform has secured funding from Boustead Projects and Moor House Capital, with Razer's new South-east Asian headquarters being its maiden project. Echo Base also secured its first smart city project, with a goal to provide next-gen services for smart buildings and cities.

images.alt_text: Minister Heng Swee Keat (centre) was the guest of honour at the groundbreaking of Razer's new S-EA HQ. (From left): Ng Lang (JTC); Tan Min-Liang (Razer); Beh Swan Gin (EDB); and Kiren Kumar (EDB) at one-north.

site_title: Reits
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

US mortgage rates rose for the first time in five weeks, affecting the real estate market. A Q3 wave of condo launches in Singapore may test demand for prime projects above S$3,000 psf. Manhattan rents reached a record high, with more increases expected. In the UK, homebuyer demand rebounded to a six-month high. New World is selling China property assets after securing a loan deal. WeWork secured new tenants and filled space at its Singapore location, post-bankruptcy. These developments indicate a shift in the global real estate market, with rising mortgage rates and increasing demand for luxury properties.

site_title: New blood, fresh faces in SGA national squads
summary: The Singapore Government Agencies Council (SGA) has announced new blood and fresh faces in its national squads. This move is seen as a response to the competitive nature of the organization, with the aim of improving individual performance and overcoming challenges. The change is intended to bring in new energy and motivation, ultimately driving success for the SGA.

site_title: Demographics, tech and sustainability are key trends for sovereign wealth funds to watch: UBS-IMD white paper
summary: Sovereign wealth funds should incorporate demographic shifts, technology, and sustainability into their investment frameworks, according to a UBS-IMD white paper. Demographic changes may lead to a redistribution of wealth across generations, influencing consumption patterns and investment opportunities. Technology's disruptive nature requires SWFs to quickly identify disruptors and avoid permanent losses. Climate change is also a key driver of sustainable strategies, particularly for commodity-based SWFs. A combination of top-down and bottom-up approaches may be necessary to effectively incorporate these macro trends into investment frameworks.

site_title: Penang theme park group heads for Catalist debut
summary: Sim Leisure Group, a Penang theme park developer, plans to list on Catalist on March 1 with an initial public offering (IPO) of 26.4 million shares at S$0.22 apiece. The IPO will value the group at S$29.5 million, with gross proceeds of S$5.8 million used to redeem outstanding shares. The IPO will put about one-fifth of the company in public hands, with founder Sim Choo Kheng holding 78.4% of the shares. The group plans to expand into China and South-east Asia with new theme parks.

site_title: UIC posts higher FY18 profit on fair-value gains
summary: United Industrial Corp (UIC) reported a 5% year-over-year increase in full-year profit to S$313.37 million, driven by fair-value gains on investment properties. Revenue from property trading declined 49% to S$87 million, while hotel operations and technology operations saw increases of 4% and 26% respectively.
