site_title: Budget 2019: What's in store for businesses, individuals
summary: Malaysia's Budget 2019 announced the Merdeka Generation Package and Bicentennial Bonus, but few tax measures for businesses and individuals. The corporate income tax (CIT) rate remains unchanged, and CIT rebates are no longer available after 2019. The personal income tax (PIT) rate also remains unchanged, with the Not Ordinary Resident (NOR) Scheme being scrapped. The goods and services tax (GST) system sees no significant changes, but the GST Import Relief for travellers is tightened. The government aims to build resilience in the GST system and raise public awareness of the new rules.

site_title: Lalamove raises US$300m in Series D funds to expand in Asia
summary: Lalamove, a logistics service provider, has raised US$300 million in Series D funds, led by Hillhouse Capital and Sequoia China. The fresh funds will be used to enhance technological capabilities, expand into India, and enter new businesses such as car sales. Founded in Hong Kong in 2013, Lalamove operates in 11 cities in Asia and has registered three million drivers and served over 28 million users. The company aims to expand into many more cities in Asia, with a strong focus on India, and differentiate itself from competitors through technological innovation and quality service.

site_title: Australian drivers can show off their personalities with emojis on licence plates
summary: Australian drivers can soon add emojis to their licence plates, starting in March. The Royal Automobile Club of Queensland has welcomed the option, which costs between A$100 and A$500 per plate. The addition aims to allow drivers to express their personality, with various emojis available. However, some residents have expressed concerns about the cost and potential safety risks, with some fearing the emojis could attract unwanted attention. The move is seen as a way to add a touch of personality to licence plates, with some drivers already placing orders for the new designs.

site_title: Roxy-Pacific's Q4 net profit falls 27% on lower revenue from property development
summary: Roxy-Pacific Holdings reported a 27% year-on-year drop in net profit to S$5.93 million for Q4 2018, primarily due to lower revenue from property development. Revenue fell 29% to S$30.83 million, mainly due to delayed revenue recognition from Trilive and Straits Mansions. For FY2018, net profit decreased 22% to S$23.87 million. The company plans to launch four remaining development sites and continues to monitor market conditions.

site_title: Hynix plans to spend US$107b building four memory chip plants
summary: SK Hynix plans to invest US$107 billion in building four memory chip plants in South Korea, starting in 2022. The plants will produce DRAM and next-generation chips, complementing existing domestic factories. The investment aims to maintain competitiveness in the face of Chinese efforts to become a leading chipmaker. The plan also intensifies an arms race with China, which has been aggressively encouraging chipmaking investment. Over 50 domestic and foreign suppliers will join the site, with the chipmaker leaving market conditions to determine production capacity.

site_title: US, China outline deal to end trade war as March 1 deadline nears
summary: US and China officials have started outlining commitments in principle on the most contentious issues in their trade dispute, marking significant progress towards ending a seven-month trade war. Negotiators are drawing up six memorandums of understanding on structural issues such as forced technology transfer, intellectual property rights, and currency, with a March 1 deadline to reach an agreement. The US seeks structural changes to China's economy, while China agrees to alleviate trade imbalances, but core demands remain to be resolved.

site_title: Barclays posts lower-than-forecast 2018 profit
summary: Barclays reported a lower-than-forecast attributable profit of £3.5 billion for 2018, due to a £150 million provision against Brexit losses and challenging trading conditions. The bank's investment bank saw a 15% increase in profit to £2.6 billion, while core capital ratio fell to 13.2%. Barclays also set aside £150 million for Brexit-related losses, and plans to return more capital via dividend increases and buybacks. CEO Jes Staley faces pressure from activist investor Edward Bramson to re-evaluate the bank's strategy.

site_title: A life Less Ordinary
summary: Dana Lam, former president of AWARE, has distilled decades of wisdom into a new stage play titled Still Life. The two-person play, starring Lam and Jean Ng, reflects on her life, relationships, and creative processes, offering a unique summation of a life fully-lived. The play is produced by Checkpoint Theatre and runs from Feb 28 to Mar 10 at TheatreWorks.

images.alt_text: Still Life.

site_title: Wilmar's Q4 profit hit by US$139m impairment on Australian milling business
summary: Wilmar International's Q4 profit plummeted 51.9% to US$201 million, largely due to a US$139 million impairment loss from its Australian milling business, largely attributed to a slump in sugar prices. Higher losses from a Chinese swine fever outbreak and lower commodity prices also weighed on earnings. The company's tropical oils segment posted a 30% jump in pre-tax profit, while the downstream businesses benefited from lower feedstock costs. Despite this, Wilmar's earnings sank 5.7% for the full year to US$1.1 billion.

site_title: Shell-PetroChina spat holds up Aussie project
summary: Royal Dutch Shell and PetroChina are in a dispute over gas sales pricing at their Arrow Energy joint venture in Australia's Surat Basin, holding up development of the country's largest coal seam gas resource. PetroChina, eager to cut losses on its loss-making Arrow Energy investment, wants to maximize its interests by developing the gas for domestic and export markets. Shell, however, is prioritizing its role as operator of the QCLNG liquefied natural gas plant, which is the biggest potential customer for the gas. The dispute is holding up final approvals, with Shell hoping to secure approval in time to deliver first gas in 2021.

site_title: Spotlight on Basel
summary: The Basel/World watch fair is underway, featuring luxury watch brands showcasing their latest creations. Omega launched a limited edition Seamaster watch celebrating Singapore's Bicentennial with a unique design. Urwerk introduced the UR-105 CT Maverick with a wandering hour complication, priced at $90,450. De Bethune unveiled a DB28 Kind of Gold USA Limited Edition with a patented moon-phase mechanism. Other notable releases include Romain Gauthier's Prestige HMS Stainless Steel, Ulysse Nardin's Classico Jade, H Moser & Cie's Pioneer Tourbillon, and F P Journe's Titalyt Elegante, which boasts a revolutionary electromechanical movement.

site_title: Cousin of Wilmar CEO becomes executive director
summary: Teo La-Mei, 59-year-old cousin of Wilmar CEO Kuok Khoon Hong, was appointed as an executive director of the company. She has been the group's legal counsel since 2009 and owns 132,000 shares, representing a 0.002% stake. The board believes she will enhance the company's core competency and contribute positively.

site_title: In tight labour market, reducing CPF rates based on age needs a rethink
summary: In Singapore, the Tripartite Workgroup on Older Workers is set to release recommendations on retirement and re-employment age, as well as Central Provident Fund (CPF) contribution rates for older workers. A ruling party advocacy group has suggested equalizing CPF contribution rates with those of younger workers, citing improved retirement adequacy and fair pay. Despite past concerns from employers, a majority of business leaders now support equalizing CPF contributions, citing a tighter labor market and demographic trend of an aging population. The government has offered support measures to help firms adjust to tighter foreign worker quotas, and may provide similar aid if CPF contribution rates are equalized.

site_title: ERA expanding drive to cater to Asia-Pacific's wealthy
summary: ERA Realty Network is launching "Plush," a service tailored for wealthy buyers in the Asia-Pacific region. The service aims to become the market leader in the region by providing a personal, one-stop service. ERA agents must meet a minimum requirement of brokering S$5 million sales every two years and earning S$200,000 in commissions annually to join the program. The company plans to expand its organization in Singapore and the region, with a focus on asset management, trust creation, and estate planning.

site_title: Foreign worker quota cuts hit sectors beyond F&B, retail
summary: The Singapore government's foreign worker quota cuts for the services sector will disproportionately affect hotels, entertainment, food services, real estate services, and logistics firms, with a reduction from 40% to 38% and then 35% foreign worker dependency ratio ceiling. The aim is to boost productivity and reduce labor reliance. However, industries like logistics face a labor crunch, and automation may not be enough to mitigate the impact. Some sectors, like retail, were initially mentioned as "labor-intensive" but are not on the list.

site_title: Tighter foreign worker rules an effort at making labour market sustainable: Chan
summary: Singapore's Minister for Trade and Industry Chan Chun Sing has announced a "surgical" tightening of foreign worker rules aimed at making the labour market more sustainable. Quotas for foreign workers in service industries will be lowered, and the government will guide firms towards being more "manpower-lean". Chan emphasized the need for a smooth trajectory and long-term benefits, while maintaining Singapore's neutrality and openness to the US and China. The move is part of a broader effort to attract foreign talent and businesses, particularly in industries like artificial intelligence and financial technology.

site_title: First Sponsor to buy control of Germany hotel for 49.5m euros
summary: Singaporean property firm First Sponsor plans to acquire controlling shares of the Westin Bellevue Dresden hotel in Dresden, Germany, for approximately 49.5 million euros. The acquisition is expected to be completed by mid-2019, with estimated transaction costs included. The 340-bedroom hotel will undergo refurbishment, with estimated costs exceeding 10 million euros. The deal aims to boost First Sponsor's recurrent income and diversify its geographical portfolio.

site_title: Aramco to enter JV with China's Norinco during Arab royal's visit
summary: Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman is visiting China, where he will sign preliminary deals with state-owned Norinco to invest in two oil refining and petrochemical complexes. The deals aim to bolster Saudi Aramco's market share in China and help the kingdom regain its position as top oil exporter to the country. The visit also aims to strengthen economic ties between Saudi Arabia and China, following a diplomatic crisis over journalist Jamal Khashoggi's murder.

site_title: Meet the S$588,888 BMW
summary: BMW's new 8 Series Coupe has been launched in Singapore with a price tag of S$588,888, including Certificate Of Entitlement. The M850i xDrive version boasts 530 horsepower and can accelerate to 100km/h in 3.7 seconds. The car features all-wheel drive and four-wheel steering for stability and agility. BMW's managing director described the 8 Series as the "most luxurious sports car" in the brand's portfolio, with a convertible version due for launch this year. The launch marks a luxury-driven year for BMW in 2019, with the X7 and 7 Series also on the horizon.

site_title: Scientists dress horses as zebras to solve puzzle
summary: Scientists at the University of California, Davis, have solved a long-standing puzzle about the function of zebra stripes. By dressing horses in zebra coats and observing horse flies, they found that the high contrast between black and white stripes tricks the fly's low-resolution vision, causing it to be startled and unable to land. This is likely due to an optical illusion similar to the barber pole, where diagonal stripes appear to move in false directions, making it difficult for the fly to judge distance and landing. The study aims to understand the exact mechanism behind this effect.

site_title: Singapore home prices not set for 'big bump': CapitaLand
summary: Singapore home prices are unlikely to experience a rapid rebound due to the government's property curbs, according to CapitaLand's CFO Andrew Lim. Despite a 71% profit increase in the quarter, home prices posted their first decline in six quarters in the last three months of 2018. Lim stated that a 5% increase in home prices would be a good year for the market, suggesting a slow recovery. The government's measures, including higher stamp duties and loan-to-value rules, have limited the market's growth.

site_title: PC maker Lenovo's Q3 profit beats expectations
summary: Lenovo, the world's largest PC maker, reported better-than-expected quarterly results, with a 8.5% increase in revenue to $14.04 billion. Net profit rose to $233 million, beating analyst estimates. Despite a bruising Sino-US trade war, Lenovo's shares surged 11.4% and reached three-year highs. CEO Yang Yuanqing emphasized the company's focus on the premium market and growth in China, while warning that further trade tensions would affect all multinationals. Lenovo's global PC market share rose to 24.6%.

site_title: US-China trade war a drag on Hi-P earnings
summary: Hi-P International, a Singapore-based contract manufacturer with Chinese factories, reported a 24.9% year-on-year decline in net profit to S$44.8 million due to the US-China trade war. Revenue fell 10.2% to S$441.9 million, citing uncertain economic conditions and declining market demand. The company is aggressively seeking new projects and customers, particularly in new regions and industries such as automotive and medical segments. Full-year net profit fell 16.9% to S$100.9 million.

site_title: Weak profit outlook leads to Nissan's first debt rating cut in a decade
summary: Nissan's debt rating was cut to A- by S&P Global Ratings, the first downgrade in a decade, due to concerns over slowing sales and the aftermath of the Carlos Ghosn scandal. The company reduced its full-year earnings forecast after missing analysts' estimates and has been struggling to ease tensions with partner Renault SA. The rating firm believes Nissan will find it difficult to restore its profitability over the next two years, citing severe business circumstances in the automotive industry.

site_title: US business spending on equipment weakening
summary: US business spending on equipment weakened in December, with new orders for key capital goods falling 0.7% and shipments rising 0.5%. This moderation in business investment suggests a further slowdown in economic growth, supporting the Federal Reserve's "patient" stance on raising interest rates. The reports also highlight weakness in global growth, trade tensions, and uncertainty regarding Britain's departure from the EU, which could crimp economic growth.

site_title: Trade between EU and Singapore crosses 100b euros; further boost expected from FTA
summary: Singapore and the EU have surpassed a 100 billion-euro mark in trade, with EU exports to Singapore growing 11.7% and imports up 4.8% in 2018. The EU-Singapore free trade agreement (EUSFTA) is expected to boost economic relations, removing customs duties and creating a transparent framework for investment. Industry watchers expect local businesses to gain from the landmark deal, with estimated growth in EU exports to Singapore of 3.6% and Singapore's exports to the EU of 10.4% over a 10-year period.

site_title: US existing home sales fall sharply to 3-year low
summary: US existing home sales plummeted to a 3-year low in January, falling 1.2% to 4.94 million units, according to the National Association of Realtors. This marks the lowest level since November 2015, surpassing analysts' expectations. The median existing house price rose 2.8% to $247,500, the smallest increase since February 2012. Existing home sales have been weak due to rising mortgage rates, land and labor shortages, leading to tight inventory and expensive homes.

site_title: Sembcorp Industries posts 10% fall in Q4 profit
summary: Sembcorp Industries reported a 10% fall in Q4 net profit to S$106 million, down from S$118 million in the same period last year. The decline was attributed to the marine business, which experienced low overall business volume and impacted overhead costs. Despite this, the company's multi-business strategy provided resilience, and shares closed unchanged at S$2.66. For full-year 2018, net profit fell 9% to S$347 million, with the marine business recording a net loss of S$48 million.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Frencken Group nearly doubled its earnings in the fourth quarter, with net profit of S$11 million, driven by a 40% revenue rise to S$175.7 million. Compact Metal Industries' shares will be suspended from trading on Feb 28 as part of a restructuring. Low Keng Huat, co-founder of Low Keng Huat construction engineering, passed away at 85. World Class Global reported a full-year net profit of S$23.2 million, while Mun Siong Engineering reported a fourth-quarter net loss of S$2.88 million.

site_title: World Class Global turns a profit in FY2018, but no dividend forthcoming
summary: World Class Global, a Catalist-listed real estate group, reported a net profit of S$23.2 million for FY2018, reversing a loss of S$9.03 million in the previous year. The company recognized S$442 million in revenue, mainly from the settlement of its Avant and Australia 108 projects. Despite this, no dividend was recommended, as the board chose to retain cash for future growth. The company expects significant contributions from the Australia 108 project and plans to launch new projects in Melbourne and Brisbane.

site_title: Engie launches venture arm to help Asia-Pacific energy startups
summary: French energy giant Engie has launched Engie Factory Asia-Pacific, a venture arm focused on supporting energy startups in the Asia-Pacific region. The arm aims to provide industry expertise and funding to help startups develop practical solutions in green mobility, smart cities, energy efficiency, and renewable energy. Engie Factory has already received over 80 startup responses and plans to collaborate with teams in South-east Asia and Australia. The venture arm is based in Singapore, where Engie's Asia-Pacific headquarters is also located, and will offer a co-working space for startups and experts.

site_title: Facebook starts global conversation in Singapore
summary: Facebook is launching a year-long process to design a global body in Singapore to review and make decisions on content moderation, with the aim of increasing transparency and accountability. The board, which will consist of up to 40 global experts, will have the power to overrule Facebook's content decisions and recommend changes to policies. The board's decisions will be binding, and it will be tasked with ensuring that Facebook strikes a balance between giving people a voice and keeping people safe from abusive, harmful, or false content.

site_title: European telcos face slow domestic growth, high investments
summary: European telecoms companies, including Deutsche Telekom, Orange, and Telefonica, expect modest profit growth of up to 3% in 2019 due to competition and investments in 5G networks and fibre broadband. Despite forecasts, investors may be skeptical about the sector's performance, as years like 2019, with 5G spectrum auctions and other capital expenditure competing with shareholder payouts, are challenging. The companies are also spending on broadband fibre to combat strong cable competitors and face competition from low-cost rivals.

site_title: Trade war prompts ECB fears of longer slowdown
summary: European Central Bank policymakers expressed concerns over a prolonged slowdown in the eurozone economy due to trade conflicts, prompting fears of a longer soft patch. The ECB has limited room to intervene, with recent growth-boosting measures leaving interest rates stuck at historic lows. The bank's January meeting showed a unanimous agreement that the slowdown is deeper and more broad-based than anticipated, with price growth short of the target of just below 2.0%. The ECB may drop hints about its next steps at the next meeting, but no quick policy changes are expected.

site_title: Can Japan save the petrol engine?
summary: Japanese carmakers, including Mazda and Infiniti, are investing in new technologies to improve combustion engines, potentially saving them from extinction. Mazda forecasts that only 16% of cars will be battery-powered or hydrogen fuel cells by 2035, suggesting that refining combustion engines could significantly reduce CO2 emissions. Infiniti's VC-Turbo engine and Nissan's Serena e-Power demonstrate advancements in variable compression technology, allowing for efficient and high-performance engines. Despite tightening emissions standards and potential bans on fossil fuel cars, Japanese carmakers believe combustion engines will remain a significant contributor to CO2 reduction for decades to come.

site_title: US: Wall St opens lower after grim economic data
summary: US stocks opened lower on Thursday after disappointing economic data, with the Dow Jones falling 32.03 points, or 0.12%, to 25,922.41. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also declined, as investors tracked US-China trade talks, which showed progress on some issues.

site_title: A taste of Bangkok style at JAM in Dempsey
summary: JAM, a Thai-inspired restaurant in Dempsey, Singapore, offers a stylish yet homey dining experience. The menu, created by ex-Lolla chef Ming Tan, focuses on uncomplicated flavors and textures, with dishes like addictive "cookies" and luxe fried chicken. The restaurant's decor, inspired by luxury Thai developer Sansiri, features eclectic decor and comfortable seating. With a rating of 7, JAM is a promising dining option for those seeking a taste of Bangkok-style cuisine in a relaxed atmosphere.

site_title: Aussie $ whipsawed by jobs surge, rate forecast
summary: The Australian dollar surged after a strong jobs report, jumping to US$0.7207 before falling to US$0.7155 as Westpac predicted interest rate cuts in August and November. The jobs report showed 39,100 new jobs and a 65,400 increase in full-time employment, maintaining a seven-year low unemployment rate of 5.0%. Westpac chief economist Bill Evans predicted rate cuts to cushion the economy, which contradicts the Reserve Bank of Australia's stance of keeping rates on hold.

site_title: Stay or leave? Carmakers confront hard Brexit choices
summary: Aston Martin and Vauxhall, among other carmakers, are navigating the uncertainty of Britain's exit from the EU. While some companies, like Nissan, are scrapping plans to build vehicles in the country, others, such as Aston Martin, are investing in new plants to prepare for a potential no-deal Brexit. Vauxhall is also preparing to produce new commercial vans, citing the potential for increased market share. The UK's exit from the EU poses conflicting decisions and opportunities for brands, with some companies seeking to minimize disruption and others viewing the situation as a chance to adapt and grow.

site_title: Being around smart people makes us smarter
summary: Amazon's decision to cancel its New York City plans in 2019 highlights the city's failure to create a thriving high-tech ecosystem, missing its chance to host the company's headquarters for the second time. This echoes the 1994 experience, when a young Jeff Bezos chose Seattle due to its concentration of engineers, programmers, and venture capitalists. Research suggests that being around smart people improves creativity, productivity, and innovation, with cities that attract innovative firms experiencing agglomeration effects. New York's loss of Amazon's tech jobs and foregone agglomeration benefits will have long-run consequences, with the city's high-tech sector expected to suffer in the coming years and decades.

site_title: Huawei plan to fix British security fears due in H1 this year
summary: Huawei plans to present a comprehensive plan to address British security concerns by the end of the first half of this year, following criticism of its slow response. The plan aims to resolve technical and supply-chain issues that exposed national telecom networks to security risks. Huawei has committed to achieving "trustworthiness" in eight key areas and will spend over $2 billion globally to address the concerns. The plan's completion is seen as crucial for Huawei's prospects in the UK, where it is a key player in the 5G network market.

site_title: India needs spur to growth amid low inflation outlook - minutes
summary: India's Reserve Bank of India (RBI) needs to boost economic growth amid a low inflation outlook, according to the minutes of its February monetary policy meeting. The RBI's monetary policy committee (MPC) unanimously agreed to move the policy stance to 'neutral' from 'calibrated tightening', and most members voted for a 25 basis points rate cut. The committee cited a benign food outlook and projected headline inflation below 4% as reasons for the decision, which is expected to provide flexibility to address challenges to sustained growth.

site_title: UAE signs 20b dirhams in military contracts as Yemen war heightens scrutiny
summary: The UAE awarded 20 billion dirhams (S$7.36 billion) in military contracts during a defence show, amid scrutiny over its role in Yemen's devastating war. The majority of the deals were awarded to international companies, including US firms Lockheed Martin and Raytheon. The UAE has increased its military purchases from other countries, including Russia, Turkey, Pakistan, and South Africa. The move may benefit other countries, as increased scrutiny of Western arms sales to Saudi Arabia and the UAE could lead to more business opportunities.

images.alt_text: The United Arab Emirates awarded 20 billion dirhams worth (S$7.36 billion) of military procurement contracts during a defence show this week, at a time when arms sales to the country are under scrutiny due to its role in Yemen's devastating war.

site_title: Lyft sets crucial date in race to IPO
summary: Lyft is set to start trading on the Nasdaq in early April, aiming to beat its rival Uber to the public market. The ride-hailing company, founded in 2007, plans to list with a valuation between $20 billion and $25 billion. Lyft's roadshow will take place the week of March 18, and the company has selected JPMorgan Chase to lead its public offering. This will be the first time a ride-hailing company goes public, with Lyft seeking to avoid being overshadowed by Uber.

images.alt_text: Lyft is preparing to start trading in early April. It is expected to list on the Nasdaq and expects to be valued at between US$20 billion and US$25 billion.

site_title: NEA calls for tender for food waste conveyance system at Tampines hawker centre
summary: The National Environment Agency (NEA) is calling for tenders to install and maintain an automated food waste conveyance system at Our Tampines Hub (OTH) Hawker Centre in Singapore. The system, expected to be operational by the end of 2019, will segregate food waste from 42 stalls and two tray-return stations, and transport it to a treatment system. The project aims to boost food waste recycling rates and reduce smells, aligning with Singapore's vision of a Zero Waste Nation and its goal of a 70% recycling rate by 2030.

site_title: Hyflux gets court order for Apr 5 scheme meeting
summary: Hyflux has secured a Singapore High Court order to hold a scheme meeting for creditors on April 5, where they will vote on a proposed rescue plan. The meeting will involve two classes of creditors: holders of perpetual preference shares (S$400 million) and perpetual capital securities (S$500 million), and medium-term noteholders, unsecured bank lenders, and other claimants (S$1.684 billion). To pass, at least 75% in value and 50% in number of creditors must approve the plan.

site_title: Male, female or X? Air passengers to get more gender options from airlines
summary: British Airways and Air New Zealand are set to introduce more gender options for LGBT+ passengers, including 'X' and 'undisclosed', following new guidance from the International Air Transport Association. Several major US airlines, such as United, American Airlines, and Delta, have already confirmed plans to offer non-binary options. The move aims to improve travel experiences for trans, intersex, and non-binary passengers who have faced discrimination when flying. Airlines are adapting to changing demographics and social norms, with experts noting that it's in their interests to show they are friendly to all types of people.

site_title: Hong Kong's central banker to step down after a decade in charge
summary: Hong Kong's Chief Executive of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority, Norman Chan, will retire on October 1 after a decade in charge. Chan, 64, led the HKMA since 2009 and has been a key advocate for the city's currency peg to the US dollar. His departure comes amid increasing uncertainty due to the slowing Chinese economy and trade war with the US. A selection panel will be formed to identify Chan's successor, with the government citing his efforts to strengthen Hong Kong's monetary and banking systems.

site_title: AI startup ViSenze bags regional partnership with Samsung
summary: ViSenze, a Singapore-based AI startup, has partnered with Samsung Electronics to use its technology in Samsung smartphones sold in South-east Asia and Oceania. The partnership allows users to connect real-life images or existing pictures to similar products available for purchase online via Bixby, a built-in AI assistant. ViSenze has received $20 million in Series C funding, which will be used to invest in working with smartphone manufacturers and consumer applications, further expanding its platform solutions that have linked over 400 million products from 800 merchants and retailers.

site_title: London's Heathrow Airport could see trade boost in no-deal Brexit
summary: London Heathrow Airport may see a trade boost if Britain leaves the EU without a deal, according to its CEO John Holland-Kaye. The airport has prepared for a no-deal Brexit by stockpiling items and is resilient to potential disruptions. Despite not hoping for a no-deal outcome, Holland-Kaye said planes will continue to move, and the EU has shown flexibility on issues like air traffic caps. The airport has seen record revenue growth and plans for a new runway are on track, set to open in 2026.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's Minister for Trade and Industry announced tighter foreign worker rules as a "surgical" move to make the labor market more sustainable. Logistics startup Lalamove raised US$300m in Series D funding to expand in Asia. Revolut, a fintech disruptor, plans a beta launch in Singapore in the coming weeks. Meanwhile, Singapore shares ended flat on Thursday, and First Sponsor is set to buy control of a German hotel for approximately 49.5m euros.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: BreadTalk's Q4 2018 earnings exceeded expectations, driven by a write-back of bonus provisions and margin improvements in the food atrium segment. The bakery segment underperformed, but the company aims to turn it around under new leadership. Sembcorp Marine's share price is undervalued despite a brighter outlook, with a strong order pipeline and potential contract wins. Analysts raise forecasts for both companies, with BreadTalk's target price set at S$0.81 and Sembcorp Marine's at S$2.40.

site_title: Compact Metal shares to stop trading on SGX from Feb 28
summary: Compact Metal Industries shares will stop trading on the SGX from February 28, following High Court approval for its restructuring. The company will transfer its shares and listing to International Cement Group, with Compact Metal becoming a wholly-owned subsidiary. The deal, approved by shareholders on January 25, will see Compact Metal Industries cease trading and its shares be delisted from the SGX.

site_title: Roxy-Pacific Q4 net profit falls 27% to S$5.93m
summary: Roxy-Pacific Holdings reported a 27% year-on-year decline in net profit to S$5.93 million for the fourth quarter ended Dec 31, driven by lower revenue from property development and property investment segments. Revenue declined 29% to S$30.83 million. For FY2018, net profit dropped 22% to S$23.87 million. The company plans to launch remaining development sites in prime districts, pending market conditions, and proposes a final cash dividend of 0.705 Singapore cent per share.

site_title: Secura Group posts FY2018 net profit of S$1.87m
summary: Secura Group, a Catalist-listed security provider, reported a net profit of S$1.87 million for FY2018, reversing a net loss of S$1.78 million in the previous year. Revenue remained steady at S$41.2 million, driven by growth in security guard contracts, homeland security, and digital forensic equipment sales. The company expects stable or improving performance in cybersecurity and security consultancy services, and plans to invest in staff training and grow its security guard business. A final dividend of 0.3 Singapore cent per share was recommended.

site_title: Low Keng Huat co-founder and chairman dies at 85
summary: Low Keng Huat chairman and co-founder Low Keng Huat has died at 85. He held the title since 1969 and was a director of Consistent Record Sdn Bhd and honorary president of Malaysia's Master Builders Association. The board stated that his "vision, leadership and invaluable contribution will be greatly missed." His son Marco and brother Lau Boon Sen are joint managing directors of the company.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets mixed at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets opened with mixed results on Thursday, with London's FTSE 100 down 0.3% and Frankfurt's DAX 30 up 0.4%. The Paris CAC 40 rose 0.1%. The divergence in markets comes as investors weigh US-EU trade talks and tariff uncertainty.

site_title: US, China sketch outlines of deal to end trade war - sources
summary: US and China officials have started outlining commitments in principle on key issues in their trade dispute, marking significant progress towards ending a seven-month trade war. The two countries are drawing up memorandums of understanding on structural issues such as forced technology transfer, intellectual property rights, and currency. Negotiators aim to reach an agreement by March 1, with the US seeking structural changes to China's economy and China looking to alleviate trade imbalances. While progress has been made, the talks could still end in failure, with the two sides differing on core demands.

site_title: Pope Francis opens summit on sexual abuse: 'Hear the cry of the little ones'
summary: Pope Francis opened a historic summit on child sexual abuse, calling it a "scourge" and urging church leaders to take concrete measures to address the issue. The meeting, attended by 190 church leaders, aims to educate pastors on the problem's depth and universality. Survivors and advocates are pushing for a policy of zero tolerance for abusive priests and bishops who cover for them, while Pope Francis emphasized the need for accountability and transparency. The summit's focus on the responsibilities of church leaders and the theme of accountability reflect the frustration with the Vatican's inability to confront the problem.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed higher on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 4.50 points to 1,730.68. The market saw a 509-397 gain-to-lose ratio. Volume reached 3.7 billion lots worth RM3 billion.

site_title: Mun Siong Engineering posts Q4 net loss, cuts dividend
summary: Mun Siong Engineering reported a Q4 net loss of S$2.88 million, down from a profit of S$698,000 previously, due to lower revenue of 9.5% year-on-year to S$12.9 million. The company attributed the decline to weak market conditions and lower job volume. For the full year, Mun Siong posted a net loss of S$3.77 million, down from a profit of S$2.17 million. The board recommended a final dividend of 0.03 Singapore cent per share, down from 0.18 Singapore cent previously, to conserve cash.

site_title: Frencken Group doubles Q4 net profit on jump in mechatronics revenue
summary: Frencken Group reported a 99.9% increase in Q4 net profit to S$11 million, driven by a 40% rise in revenue to S$175.7 million. The company's mechatronics division saw a significant jump in sales, particularly in the industrial automation segment, which saw a 548.4% increase. The company expects robust year-on-year growth in Q1 2019, driven by increased orders for storage drive production equipment. Despite a decline in semiconductor revenue, the company's earnings per share rose to 2.62 Singapore cents.

site_title: Qantas to decide on future domestic fleet next year - CEO
summary: Qantas plans to decide on replacing its domestic fleet, including 75 Boeing 737s, by the end of 2020. The airline is considering options such as the A320neo and 737 MAX families, as well as a potential new mid-sized Boeing plane. Domestic rival Virgin Australia Holdings expects to receive its first Boeing 737 MAX later this year. Qantas also plans to decide on a new long-haul jet capable of 20-hour non-stop flights between Sydney and London later this year.

site_title: Singapore shares end flat on Thursday
summary: Singapore shares ended flat on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index dipping 0.01% to 3,277.91. The bourse was weighed down by financials, with DBS and OCBC Bank sliding 1.08% and 0.86% respectively. However, some counters, such as Genting Singapore and Golden Agri-Resources, gained 0.91% and 3.85% respectively. The field was evenly matched, with 201 gainers and 190 losers, and 1.34 billion securities changing hands.

site_title: Wilmar Q4 net profit halved by impairment on Australian sugar assets
summary: Wilmar International's Q4 net profit more than halved to US$200.9 million, primarily due to an impairment on Australian sugar assets. Revenue dropped 3% to US$11.1 billion, and net profit excluding discontinued operations fell 53.4% to US$199 million. The company attributed the decline to low commodity prices and the African swine fever outbreak in China. Despite this, the board proposed a final dividend of 7 Singapore cents per share.

site_title: Engie launches strategic venture arm eyeing energy startups in Asia-Pacific
summary: French energy giant Engie has launched Engie Factory Asia-Pacific, a strategic venture arm focused on energy startups in the Asia-Pacific region. The venture arm aims to invest in and support startups in green mobility, smart cities, energy efficiency, and renewable energy. Located in Singapore, Engie Factory will provide access to industry expertise and funding, as well as co-working space and resources to help startups develop practical solutions and build their track record. Over 80 startups have applied to the venture arm, with plans to collaborate with Engie teams in South-east Asia and Australia.

site_title: Malaysia files charges, issues arrest warrant for British aide to ex-PM Najib
summary: Malaysian authorities have filed money laundering charges against British national Paul Stadlen, a former media adviser to ex-PM Najib Razak. Stadlen is accused of laundering RM14.3 million in proceeds from 1MDB, a state fund linked to Najib. The charges were filed after Stadlen failed to assist in the 1MDB probe, and an arrest warrant has been issued. Stadlen's law firm denies wrongdoing, claiming the charges are politically motivated. At least six countries are investigating 1MDB, which was founded by Najib in 2009 and allegedly siphoned billions of dollars.

site_title: Saudi Aramco to sign China refinery deals as crown prince visits -sources
summary: Saudi Aramco plans to sign preliminary deals during Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman's visit to China, investing in two oil refining and petrochemical complexes in the northeastern province of Liaoning and eastern province of Zhejiang. The deals aim to bolster Saudi Arabia's market share in China, which it has relinquished to Russia for the past three years. The investments could help Saudi Aramco regain its top oil exporter status to China.

site_title: Barclays £3.5b 2018 profit underwhelms as Brexit bites
summary: Barclays reported a lower-than-forecast £3.5 billion profit for 2018, driven by a £150 million provision for Brexit losses. The bank's investment bank saw a 15% increase in profit to £2.6 billion, while its core capital ratio fell to 13.2% due to increased dividend payouts. Barclays set aside £150 million for potential Brexit losses, following peers HSBC and Royal Bank of Scotland. The bank signaled intentions to return more capital to shareholders, but faces pressure from activist investor Edward Bramson over its strategy.

site_title: Hi-P International posts 25% fall in Q4 net profit amid US-China trade war
summary: Hi-P International, a contract manufacturer, posted a 24.9% year-on-year decline in Q4 net profit to S$44.8 million due to lower market demand and increased competition. Revenue fell 10.2% to S$441.9 million, and earnings per share dropped to 5.56 Singapore cents. The company plans to diversify its customer base and expand into new regions, including Thailand, and explore mergers and acquisitions to boost growth.

site_title: StanChart to take US$900m charge over US, UK probes
summary: Standard Chartered will take a US$900 million charge in its fourth-quarter results due to regulatory probes in the US and UK, primarily related to US sanctions violations, currency trading issues, and financial-crime controls. The charge will erode earnings and may indicate a settlement is close, with CEO Bill Winters set to unveil a turnaround plan. This move comes as global banks face soaring legal expenses, with UBS Group AG ordered to pay over US$5 billion in a tax-evasion case.

site_title: Singapore Airlines denies snooping with seatback cameras
summary: Singapore Airlines has denied allegations of installing seatback cameras on its planes, despite passengers spotting tiny lenses on their screens. The airline confirmed that some of its entertainment systems had cameras, but they were permanently disabled by the manufacturer. The cameras were intended for future developments, and the airline has no plans to enable or use them. The airline assured passengers that their data is not being collected or stored.

site_title: Genting Singapore Q4 net profit up 12% to S$150.2m
summary: Genting Singapore reported a 12% increase in net profit to S$150.2 million for its fourth quarter ended Dec 31, driven by "encouraging" performances in gaming and non-gaming segments. Earnings per share rose to 1.25 Singapore cents from 1.1 cents in the previous year. Despite economic uncertainties and competition, the company attributed the growth to its stable performance.

site_title: Australian shares led higher by Wesfarmers, jobs data; NZ also gains
summary: Australian shares rose 0.7% to 6,139.20, driven by Wesfarmers' 10.4% profit jump and robust January jobs data. The country's biggest supermarket chain, Woolworths, posted a lower-than-expected profit, but the overall economic sentiment remained positive. Meanwhile, New Zealand's benchmark index rose 0.6% as Fisher & Paykel Healthcare agreed to settle patent infringement disputes with US-based ResMed. The Australian dollar initially strengthened due to jobs growth, but later fell after Westpac forecasted rate cuts.

site_title: Sony to beef up chip business with new engineers
summary: Sony plans to assign 40% of its new engineer hires in Japan to its chip business over the next two years, focusing on growth from new applications in cars and phones. The move is part of a 600 billion yen investment in imaging sensors through 2021, aiming to drive growth as the gaming business slows. Sony will hire 320 new engineers annually, up from 250 in 2018, as it seeks to maintain its market share in imaging sensors.

site_title: Trading halt on Best World shares extended by up to two days
summary: Trading halt on Best World shares extended by up to two days for the company to finalize and release a clarification. The halt began on February 18 after a news article raised concerns about the company's sales in China. Best World assured shareholders that its business practices are ethical and compliant with laws and accounting standards. The company's shares slid 16.6% before the halt, and trading may resume by February 25.

site_title: Nike target of Twitter storm after basketball star's shoe splits
summary: Nike faced a Twitter storm after basketball star Zion Williamson sprained his knee during a game due to a shoe that split during play. The incident, which occurred during a matchup between Duke University and the University of North Carolina, sparked jokes and jeers at the No. 1 sports brand. Williamson suffered a mild knee sprain and Nike expressed concern for his recovery. This is not the first time Nike has faced issues with its basketball merchandise, as previous incidents involving LeBron James have also been reported.

site_title: Pageant-mad Philippines welcomes home Miss Universe
summary: Philippines welcomed home Miss Universe Catriona Gray with a parade through the capital, drawing thousands of fans who cheered and waved flags. The 25-year-old, who beat over 90 contestants, was treated like a heroine for her country. Gray, who works at a non-profit providing free education, was the fourth Filipina to win the pageant. She expressed pride and honor in bringing joy to her country, which has been affected by poverty, corruption, and natural disasters. The parade was held after Gray's victory in the 67th Miss Universe pageant held in Thailand in December.

site_title: China's rich are finding it harder to hide from taxman
summary: China is increasing pressure on tax dodgers, with the government revising tax codes and naming offenders. Wealthy Chinese, including movie star Fan Bingbing, are facing significant back taxes and fines. The country has also started automatically exchanging financial information with over 100 jurisdictions, making it harder for those stashing money overseas to hide. This clampdown is part of Beijing's efforts to crack down on tax evasion and generate more revenue.

site_title: Asia: Shares up on Fed outlook, Australian dollar seesaws after jobs data
summary: Asian shares rose to fresh 4-1/2-month highs on Thursday after the US Federal Reserve signaled it will be "patient" on further interest rate hikes, boosting Sino-US trade talks. The Australian dollar seesawed after strong January jobs data, while Chinese shares edged up near a half-year high. Investors are cautiously optimistic, despite lingering trade uncertainty, and expect the Fed to leave rates unchanged this year.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks build on gains at close
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.41% to 28,629.92, boosted by hopes for China-US trade talks. The Hang Seng Index extended gains despite a decline in the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index. The news of a potential trade plan outline between China and the US lifted market sentiment, driving stocks higher.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong stocks extended gains Thursday as hopes for China-US trade talks were boosted by a report the two sides were working on an outline for a plan to resolve the dispute.

site_title: The tiny dairy stock that skyrocketed to New Zealand's biggest on China demand
summary: A2 Milk Co, a New Zealand-based dairy company, has seen its market cap surge 3,000% in four years, reaching NZ$10.9 billion, making it the country's most valuable company. Revenue from China increased 50% to NZ$172 million in the first half, driving a 55% increase in net income. The company is betting on taking a bigger share of the infant-formula market from global giants like Danone and Nestle. However, analysts question the sustainability of sales via the daigou channel, citing regulatory risk and potential channel fill.

site_title: Housing dream turned nightmare spurs backlash in Australia
summary: Australia's young people are frustrated with the country's housing market, with a growing wealth gap between baby boomers and millennials. The opposition Labor party is capitalizing on this issue, pledging to curb tax breaks for property investors and scrap tax refunds for share investors to address the problem. This could lead to a change in government in May, as younger voters are increasingly disenchanted with the current system. Labor's efforts to address housing affordability and inter-generational inequality are seen as key to winning over the youth vote.

site_title: Vanuatu to give disposable diapers the flush
summary: Vanuatu plans to ban disposable diapers, citing significant pollution reduction. The ban, set to begin on December 1, aims to eliminate plastic waste and follows the country's previous ban on single-use plastic bags. Disposable diapers are lined with non-biodegradable plastic and contain chemicals that harm the environment. The move is part of Vanuatu's environmental leadership efforts, with the country already banning plastic bags and taking steps to reduce pollution. The ban is expected to disproportionately reduce plastic waste, with 450 billion nappies used globally every year.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Thursday afternoon at 3,281.33, up 0.09%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.09% on Thursday, closing at 3,281.33, driven by progress on the US-China trade front. The Straits Times Index saw 150 gainers to 148 losers, with Yangzijiang Shipbuilding and Genting Singapore leading the gainers. Financials pointed lower, with DBS, OCBC Bank, and United Overseas Bank falling. The rally follows a 5-day streak ahead of GDP data and despite ongoing US-China trade uncertainty.

site_title: Australian regulator investigates trading in pay-later stocks
summary: Australia's corporate watchdog, ASIC, is investigating share trading in buy-now, pay-later lending companies, including Afterpay Touch Group, following a confidential report to lawmakers that could lead to regulatory changes. Shares in Afterpay fell 10.6% after the report, while shares in Zip Co and Flexigroup also declined. The investigation aims to determine whether payday lenders and pay-later companies should be regulated similarly to traditional banks, which could have significant implications for the sector. ASIC executive Cathie Armour is leading the inquiry.

site_title: 11 wounded in central China knife attack
summary: A 33-year-old man with a history of mental illness attacked random pedestrians in central China, wounding 11 people with a knife. The suspect, Guo Kaibin, is in police custody. None of the injuries were life-threatening, and an investigation is underway. This incident is part of a series of recent knife attacks in China, which have targeted schools, villages, and public areas, resulting in multiple fatalities and injuries.

site_title: AccorHotels 2018 profit rises, to invest in new hospitality services
summary: AccorHotels, Europe's largest hotel company, reported an 8% rise in like-for-like operating profits for 2018, driven by cost controls and strong demand in key regions. The company plans to invest €225 million to support new initiatives in hospitality and entertainment services, aiming to break even by 2021 and exceed its 2022 Ebitda target of €1.2 billion.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares end up on US-China trade hopes
summary: Tokyo stocks ended Thursday's session marginally higher, driven by renewed hopes for progress in US-China trade talks. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.15% to 21,464.23, while the Topix index gained 0.03 points to 1,613.50. This reversal comes after earlier losses, reflecting traders' optimism about a potential trade deal.

site_title: Singapore shares decline at Thursday's open; STI down 0.16% to 3,272.99
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index declined 0.16% to 3,272.99 at Thursday's open, with 44.3 million securities worth S$100.4 million changing hands. Gainers outnumbered losers 69 to 44, led by Thai Beverage Public Co's 0.6% rise and Golden Agri-Resources' 1.9% increase. Active index stocks, including DBS Group Holdings and United Overseas Bank, fell 1.0% and 0.4% respectively.

site_title: South Korea coaches 'stole tens of thousands' from 'Garlic Girls' curlers
summary: South Korea's "Garlic Girls" curling team, Olympic silver medalists, were exploited by their coaches who stole tens of thousands of dollars of prize money. A five-week investigation by the sports ministry found the coaches had excessive control over the team's privacy, mismanaged team income, and embezzled funds. The coaches also evaded taxes and hired unqualified family members. The case will be taken to the police. The team's popularity boosted curling's popularity in South Korea, but their failure to win national trials and subsequent drop in world rankings are a result of the coaches' actions.

site_title: Asia's tumbling exports signal trade pain has room to run
summary: Asia's exports, particularly from Japan and South Korea, continue to decline amid a global trade slump. Japan's exports fell 8.4% in January, while South Korea's shipments dropped 12% in the first 20 days of February, with semiconductor exports plummeting 27%. The decline is attributed to weaker demand for Chinese goods, the US-China trade war, and a slowing global technology cycle. This contraction is expected to further hurt Japan's factory sector and South Korea's business investment, with potential further declines in exports in the second quarter.

site_title: Banking disruptor Revolut set for Singapore beta launch in coming weeks
summary: Revolut, a London-based fintech, is set to launch a beta version of its digital bank in Singapore in the coming weeks, as it seeks to expand its presence in the region. The company, which has over four million customers in Europe, plans to bring jobs and tech talent to Singapore due to its favorable regulatory environment and skilled workforce. Revolut's service relies heavily on skills such as AI, machine learning, and data science, and the company is keen to work with education bodies in Singapore to train staff.

site_title: Australian dollar whipsawed by jobs surge, rate call
summary: The Australian dollar surged after a strong jobs report, jumping to US$0.7207, before falling back to US$0.7155 as Westpac predicted interest rate cuts in August and November. The report showed jobs climbed 39,100 in January, more than twice the market forecast, with the unemployment rate remaining at a seven-year low of 5.0%. Westpac chief economist Bill Evans predicted rate cuts to cushion a potential downturn, while the Reserve Bank of Australia Governor Philip Lowe expressed confidence in the labour market.

site_title: Credit Suisse to penalise Asia bankers who quit
summary: Credit Suisse will penalize some of its top Asian bankers who quit within three years of receiving their 2018 bonuses, requiring them to repay a portion of the cash bonus. The repayment amount decreases by a third for each year after the initial year. The move aims to deter defections in a highly competitive market for private bankers serving the ultra-rich in Asia. The change is part of a broader effort by the bank to improve its performance in the region, which has been struggling with poor results in its markets operations.

site_title: SUTL Enterprise Q4 earnings drop 17% on higher expenses; to pay out 2 Singapore cents/share
summary: SUTL Enterprise Limited recorded a Q4 net profit of S$3.6 million, down 17% from the previous year due to higher expenses. Total income for the quarter increased 1%, while earnings per share dropped to 4.20 cents. For the full year, the company recorded a net profit of S$5.8 million, down 14%, and a dividend of 2 Singapore cents per share was proposed, unchanged from last year. The company attributes higher expenses to increased spending on marina projects and other business development costs.

site_title: Personality on the morning commute: Australia's emoji licence plates
summary: In Australia, motorists in north-eastern states can soon personalize their license plates with emojis, starting in March. The Royal Automobile Club of Queensland has welcomed the digital addition, while some residents, like Aroha Liebhart, are concerned about the high cost ($100-$500) and potential increased crime risks. Others, like Laura McKee, see it as a fun way to brighten up their commute. The option will feature positive emojis such as smiling, winking, and heart-eyed faces, with interchangeable plates for drivers to express their moods.

site_title: Australia employment extends bumper run in 2019, jobless rate at 7-year lows
summary: Australia's jobs market showed a robust performance in January, with 39,100 net new jobs created, exceeding market forecasts. The jobless rate remained at 5.0%, the lowest since April 2012. The unemployment rate stayed at its recent low despite an increase in the participation rate, and the underemployment rate declined to 8.1%. The strong labour market data is seen as a positive sign for wage growth and inflation, and has lifted the Australian dollar to a two-week high.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks down at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks declined at the opening on Thursday, following recent gains, amid uncertainty from the Federal Reserve's policy meeting minutes. The Hang Seng Index eased 0.22% to 28,450.00, while the Shanghai Composite Index dipped 0.05% to 2,759.94. The decline was attributed to uncertain market conditions and potential tariff uncertainty.

site_title: AF Global full-year profit tumbles 88% to S$926,000
summary: AF Global, a Singapore-listed property and hospitality company, reported an 88% drop in full-year net profit to S$926,000 due to litigation fees from a shareholders dispute. The company sold its full ownership of the Crowne Plaza London Kensington hotel, resulting in an estimated gain of S$14 million. Despite this, AF Global incurred a full-year net loss from continuing operations of S$1.06 million, with its property sector recording a pre-tax profit of S$1 million.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Sembcorp, ST Engineering, CDL, PropNex, First Sponsor
summary: Stocks to watch: Sembcorp Industries fell 10% in Q4 net profit, while ST Engineering dropped 26% due to one-off charges. City Developments plummeted 54.7% in Q4 net profit. PropNex entered a strategic collaboration with Global Alliance Property. First Sponsor plans to acquire the Westin Bellevue Dresden hotel for S$75.7 million. CSE Global returned to profit, despite a 14.2% drop in revenue. Singapore Medical Group's stake in SMG increased to 24.13% after a S$50 million investment. SBI Offshore inked a reverse takeover deal valued at US$36 million.

site_title: USP Group to sell biofuel unit in S$6m deal
summary: USP Group plans to sell its 93.09%-owned biofuel unit, Biofuel Research, to a joint venture for S$5.59 million. The deal aims to raise cash and focus on the company's marine business. USP reported a net loss of S$380,000 for the third quarter of 2018. The sale will allow the company to strengthen its financial position and explore new markets for marine products. A definitive sales and purchase agreement is expected by March 30, pending shareholder approval.

site_title: US dollar steady after Federal Reserve minutes, trade issues back in view
summary: The US dollar remained steady after Federal Reserve minutes revived expectations of a possible rate hike this year, while trade issues took center stage. The dollar index remained unchanged at 96.500. Investors shifted focus to trade tensions, particularly between the US and China, as the US-China trade negotiation deadline could be extended. The euro and yen also saw little change, while the pound dipped 0.1% due to Brexit uncertainty.

site_title: Malaysia shares open lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index fell 4.22 points to 1,721.96 at 9am on Thursday, with a trading volume of 94.16 million lots worth RM31.91 million. Gainers beat losers 128 to 57.

site_title: PC maker Lenovo returns to Q3 profit, beats estimates
summary: Lenovo, the world's largest PC maker by shipments, reported a net profit of $233 million in the December quarter, beating market expectations. Revenue rose 8.5% to $14.04 billion, driven by strong performances in its PC and Smart Device business, as well as its Data Center business. Lenovo's Mobile Business Group also recorded a pre-tax profit for the first time since its acquisition of Motorola in 2014. The result surpassed analyst estimates of $207 million.

site_title: Fitch warns of British debt downgrade on 'hard' Brexit risk
summary: Ratings agency Fitch has warned that it may downgrade Britain's debt rating due to the economic risks associated with a potential no-deal Brexit. Fitch cited "substantial disruption to UK economic and trade prospects" and put Britain's long-term debt on credit watch "negative." The review date has been accelerated to reflect the country's deteriorating economic situation. Fitch expects Britain to avoid a no-deal Brexit but warns of potential macroeconomic stress if no agreement is reached.

site_title: US, China sketching outlines of deal to end trade war: sources
summary: US and China have begun outlining commitments in principle on key trade issues, marking significant progress towards ending the seven-month trade war. The two sides are drawing up six memorandums of understanding on structural issues such as forced technology transfer, intellectual property rights, and currency. Negotiators are working towards a deal by March 1, which marks the end of a 90-day truce. While progress is being made, the talks could still end in failure, and the US is pushing for China to make specific commitments and open its financial services markets.

site_title: First Sponsor to buy control of Germany hotel for about 49.5m euros
summary: PROPERTY firm First Sponsor plans to acquire 94.9% controlling shares of the Westin Bellevue Dresden hotel in Germany for approximately 49.5 million euros (S$75.7 million). The acquisition, expected to be completed soon, will allow First Sponsor to refurbish the 340-bedroom hotel with an estimated cost of over 10 million euros. The move aims to boost the company's recurrent income stream and geographical diversification.

site_title: Shell, PetroChina spat holds up Australia's biggest coal seam gas project: sources
summary: Royal Dutch Shell and PetroChina are at odds over gas sales pricing at their Arrow Energy joint venture, hindering development of Australia's largest coal seam gas resource. The dispute, involving the $3.5 billion Surat gas resource, has stalled a planned final investment decision and first production, initially expected in 2020. The disagreement arose after the Arrow Energy venture signed a 27-year deal to supply gas to the Queensland Curtis LNG plant in 2017. The impasse has put the project's future in jeopardy.

site_title: Logistics startup Lalamove raises US$300m in Series D round to expand in Asia
summary: Logistics startup Lalamove has raised $300 million in Series D funding, led by Hillhouse Capital and Sequoia China, to expand in Asia and support its entry into India and new businesses. The company, founded in Hong Kong in 2013, has registered three million drivers and served 28 million users in 11 cities across Asia. The fresh funds will focus on technological innovation, platform matching, and quality service to differentiate Lalamove from competitors and secure a leading position in the industry.

site_title: Sinopipe enters MOU to buy China investment holding firm in reverse takeover
summary: SINOPIPE Holdings has entered into a memorandum of understanding to acquire China investment holding firm Shanxi Bibenet via a reverse takeover. The proposed acquisition, if completed, is expected to strengthen the company's financial performance and enable it to recommence operations. The deal will be valued based on a final valuation by an independent valuer and will be satisfied through the issuance of new shares. The acquisition is subject to various conditions, including completion of a restructuring exercise and approval from Sinopipe's directors and shareholders.

site_title: City Developments Q4 profit down 54.7% to S$77.9m
summary: City Developments (CDL) reported a 54.7% decline in Q4 net profit to S$77.9 million, due to impairment losses and a hotel operations segment loss. Revenue dropped 40.6% to S$788.3 million, and gross profit fell 7.4%. Despite this, the company remains confident in its strong fundamentals and Singapore's recovery prospects, citing its diversified portfolio and geographically-diversified assets. The board recommended two special dividends, and shares closed at S$9.53, up eight Singapore cents.

site_title: Sembcorp posts 10% fall in Q4 profit as marine unit drags; to pay out 2 Singapore cents/share
summary: Sembcorp Industries reported a 10% fall in Q4 profit to S$106 million, driven by a 31% decline in gross profit due to low marine business volume. The company attributed the decline to overhead cost absorption and margin from secured production floater projects. Despite the decline, the group delivered 75% profit growth excluding the marine business. A final dividend of 2 Singapore cents per share was proposed, and shares closed at S$2.66, up S$0.09.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open slightly higher after dovish Fed signals
summary: Tokyo stocks opened slightly higher, gaining 0.08% or 16.84 points to 21,448.33, following dovish signals from the US Federal Reserve. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index rose, while the broader Topix index also increased. This comes after three days of gains and amid uncertainty over US tariffs.

site_title: ST Engineering Q4 profit drops 26% to S$124.5m after one-off charges
summary: ST Engineering reported a 26% drop in Q4 net profit to S$124.5 million due to one-off charges related to portfolio rationalization and the acquisition of General Electric's MRA Systems. Excluding these charges, pre-tax profit would have been 7% higher. Revenue rose 5% to S$1.77 billion, while full-year net profit dipped 1.7% to S$494.2 million. The company declared a final dividend of 10 cents per share, unchanged from the previous year.

site_title: First Ship Lease Trust slashes Q4 losses to US$18.5m on lower impairments
summary: FIRST Ship Lease Trust reported a net loss of US$18.5 million in Q4 2018, down from US$33.9 million in the same period last year, due to lower impairment charges on four product tankers and three container ships. Turnover decreased 6.8% year-over-year to US$18.5 million. Loss per unit was down to 2.91 US cents, and the trust's full-year losses narrowed to US$19 million. The new board will continue working to turn the trust around, but no distribution is recommended due to challenging industry conditions.

site_title: EU countries back copyright reforms aimed at Google, Facebook
summary: The European Union has endorsed a copyright reform aimed at forcing Google and Facebook to pay publishers for news snippets and filter out copyright-protected content on YouTube and Instagram. The overhaul, which requires licensing agreements with rights holders, has been approved by EU diplomats, but five countries have refused to back the deal, citing concerns it could hinder innovation and competitiveness. The next step is a vote by a committee of lawmakers, followed by a parliamentary vote before the changes can become law.

site_title: Accrelist sets up Penang unit in medical aesthetics expansion
summary: Accrelist, a Catalist-listed company, has set up an indirect subsidiary in Penang to expand its medical aesthetics business. The incorporation, funded internally, is not expected to impact the group's net tangible assets and earnings per share. Accrelist Medical Aesthetics (Penang) Sdn Bhd, 99% owned by Accrelist, has a paid-up share capital of RM100. The subsidiary is led by Malaysian doctor Ong Kuok Tjun, who will be the resident doctor.

site_title: US Coast Guard officer arrested for mass murder plot
summary: A US Coast Guard officer, Christopher Paul Hasson, 49, has been arrested on firearms and drug charges after espousing white supremacist views and drafting a target list of Democratic politicians and media figures. Hasson, a lieutenant in the US Coast Guard, seized a powerful arsenal from his home in Maryland, including 15 guns and over 1,000 rounds of ammunition. Prosecutors say Hasson identified as a "White Nationalist" and advocated for "focused violence" to establish a white homeland, citing inspiration from Norwegian mass murderer Anders Breivik.

site_title: Fire kills at least 56 in Bangladesh capital: official
summary: A devastating fire broke out in apartment buildings and chemical warehouses in Dhaka, Bangladesh, killing at least 56 people and injuring 45. The blaze, which began around 10:40pm, quickly spread due to the highly flammable chemicals stored in the buildings. Fire officials say the search is ongoing, and the number of bodies may increase. This is the second major fire tragedy in Dhaka, following a 2010 fire that killed over 120 people.

site_title: Crunch time as high-level US-China trade talks resume
summary: US-China trade talks resumed with eight days left before a March 1 deadline, with top officials from both sides meeting to bridge the gap between the two largest economies. Despite President Trump's claims of "very well" progress, analysts say concrete signs of progress have been scarce, and a deal is unlikely to meet Trump's most far-reaching goals. The talks aim to address US demands for China to reverse industrial policy and reverse trade imbalance, with potential concessions on intellectual property theft and investment. A failure to reach an agreement could pose an embarrassment for the US ahead of the election cycle.

site_title: Qantas Airways half year profit takes a hit from higher fuel costs
summary: Qantas Airways reported a 19% drop in half-year profit to A$780 million due to higher fuel costs. The airline's international business was significantly impacted by a "rapid rise" in fuel costs, increasing by A$219 million during the half. Despite a 6% rise in revenue to A$9.21 billion, Qantas expects its full-year fuel bill to be 21% higher than last year, at A$3.90 billion. The company plans to return A$500 million to shareholders through dividends and share buybacks.

site_title: Trump threatens tariffs on EU if no trade deal reached
summary: US President Donald Trump threatened to impose tariffs on European auto imports if a trade deal is not reached, following a Commerce Department report labeling EU car imports as a national security threat. Trump stated that if negotiations fail, "we'll do that." The threat comes amid renewed tensions between the US and EU over trade.

site_title: May hails Brexit talks 'progress' but no breakthrough
summary: Prime Minister Theresa May stated that she has made "progress" in Brexit talks with the EU, despite no major breakthrough. The talks focused on the "Irish backstop" issue, which has been a sticking point for Brexiteers. May met with European Commission president Jean-Claude Juncker and urged EU officials to offer guarantees on the backstop to convince skeptical MPs. The EU has ruled out legally binding changes to the backstop, and May's Brexit Minister Stephen Barclay will return to Brussels on Thursday to continue negotiations.

site_title: Japan manufacturing shrinks for first time since 2016 amid trade war: PMI
summary: Japan's manufacturing activity contracted for the first time in two-and-a-half years in February, with the Flash Markit/Nikkei Japan Manufacturing Purchasing Managers Index (PMI) falling to 48.5 from 50.3 in January. This marks the first time the index has fallen below the 50 threshold since August 2016. The decline in manufacturing activity is attributed to shrinking domestic and export orders, as well as a China slowdown and the global trade cycle losing steam. Business confidence in Japan also soured for the first time in over six years.

site_title: New Zealand advisory group recommends country introduce capital gains tax
summary: A New Zealand tax working group recommends introducing capital gains tax to ensure fairness and balance in the tax system. The group suggests taxing capital gains from residential rental properties, as well as land, buildings, business assets, intangible property, and shares. New Zealand currently does not tax capital gains except in specified instances. The government will consider the report and release a response in April.

site_title: Oil settles 1% higher on hopes of market rebalance, trade deal
summary: Oil prices rose over 1% on Wednesday, reaching their highest level this year, as hopes for market rebalancing emerged. Top producers, including Opec and Russia, agreed to cut oil supply by 1.2 million barrels per day. US sanctions on Iran and Venezuela also contributed to reduced crude availability on the global market. Despite supply disruptions, expectations of inventory builds in the US and increased shale production suggest prices may stabilize or rise further, with Brent futures expected to average $67 by the fourth quarter.

site_title: Europe: Sainsbury's sinks but Lloyds, trade hopes lift FTSE 100
summary: The FTSE 100 index rose 0.7% as Lloyds gained 4.7% after announcing a share buyback and dividend increase, while optimism over US-China trade talks lifted spirits. Sainsbury's lost 18.5% after regulators objected to its Asda takeover deal, wiping £1 billion off its market value. Other retailers, including Morrisons, fell. The FTSE 250 also rose 0.7%, with miners and financials boosting the index.

site_title: Ride-hailing firm Lyft plans to file for IPO as soon as next week: source
summary: Lyft plans to file for an initial public offering (IPO) as soon as next week, targeting a valuation of $20 billion to $25 billion. The ride-hailing company, currently the No. 2 player, aims to list its shares on the Nasdaq market and begin marketing shares in a roadshow the week of March 18. This may put Lyft ahead of its larger rival Uber in the IPO race. Lyft has been working with several banks, including JPMorgan Chase, to lead its IPO, which will test whether the money-losing business can withstand wider investor scrutiny.

site_title: SBI Offshore inks reverse takeover term sheet
summary: SBI Offshore has inked a binding term sheet for a reverse takeover valued at US$36 million, with third-party businessman Chan Kern Ming set to acquire the company. The deal could see SBI Offshore's shares triple in an issuance to Chan, with earn-out payments of up to US$14 million based on future profits. The Singapore Exchange Regulation has given the company until Feb 28 to justify its listing status, but the board believes the proposed acquisition will generate a sustainable revenue stream. The deal must be approved by shareholders at an extraordinary general meeting.

site_title: Keppel O&M delivers jackup rig under sale-and-leaseback deal
summary: Keppel Offshore & Marine (Keppel O&M) has delivered a jackup rig, Cantarell IV, to Mexican driller Grupo R under a sale-and-leaseback agreement. FELS Asset, a Keppel subsidiary, purchased the rig for US$179 million and will lease it back to Grupo R on a five-year bareboat charter at competitive rates. The rig, equipped with RigCare digital solutions, will work on offshore wells in Mexico starting in early May. The deal is expected to have no material impact on Keppel's financials.

site_title: US: Stocks edge up after dovish Fed minutes
summary: US stocks rose on Wednesday, edging up 0.2% after Federal Reserve minutes signaled a dovish stance on monetary policy. The Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 gained 0.2%, while the Nasdaq Composite Index rose less than 0.1%. The Fed minutes hinted at caution towards further interest rate hikes, citing a potential slowdown in US growth. Investors also await key trade talks between the US and China, and a potential EU trade deal. Despite concerns, analysts expect the stock market to continue rising, citing a large amount of cash on the market.

site_title: Microsoft says discovers hacking targeting democratic institutions in Europe
summary: Microsoft has discovered cyber attacks targeting democratic institutions, think tanks, and non-profit organizations in Europe, with 104 employee accounts compromised between September and December 2018. The company's Threat Intelligence Center and Digital Crimes Unit detected the hacks, which targeted employees in Belgium, France, Germany, Poland, Romania, and Serbia. Microsoft will offer a cyber security service to several European countries to close security gaps.

site_title: Samsung launches folding smartphone, first 5G handset
summary: Samsung has unveiled the Galaxy Fold, a folding smartphone with a 4.6-inch display that unfolds to a 7.3-inch tablet. The device, priced at $1,980, is the first 5G handset and features AI-enhanced software, wireless charging, and a large screen for multitasking. The company also announced its new Galaxy S10 line, including a 5G model, and introduced a range of wearable tech devices, including a smartwatch and earbuds. The launch comes as the smartphone market experiences its worst-ever decline, with Samsung aiming to rev up demand with innovative devices.

site_title: US housing sector in a slump, but unlikely to cause recession
summary: The US housing sector is experiencing a slump, but it's unlikely to cause a recession. Housing has been in a recession since 2020 and has never fully recovered. The sector's volatility and sensitivity to interest rates contribute to its significant impact on the business cycle. While home sales and prices have been sluggish, construction and pent-up demand from young adults suggest the sector will remain stable. The US has experienced 11 recessions since WWII, with housing being a key factor in 9 of them. Despite a mixed outlook, housing's role in the economy suggests it will not be the cause of a recession.

site_title: SembMarine posts fourth quarter net earnings of S$6m
summary: SembCorp Marine reported a fourth-quarter net profit of S$5.9 million, a 95% decrease from the previous year, but beat analyst expectations. The company's turnaround efforts appear to be paying off, with stabilizing offshore rig utilization and improved day rates. Revenue for the quarter grew 0.2% to S$913.2 million, driven by the rig and floaters segment. Full-year revenue increased 61% to S$4.9 billion. Analysts see signs of recovery, but note the company's high net gearing ratio and the need for selective new orders to conserve cash.

site_title: E-commerce tax: not in Budget, but on the horizon
summary: Singapore's e-commerce tax, initially announced in last year's budget, was not included in this year's budget, sparking concerns about its implementation. The tax authority is still working on determining taxable revenues and designing a mechanism that is both comprehensive and equitable.
