A multilateral approach to e-commerce taxes is being advocated by the OECD, with Singapore likely keeping an eye on the outcome of public consultations. The exclusion of the e-commerce tax from the budget has raised concerns about the potential impact on small and medium-sized enterprises and multinational companies.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Influence: Michelle Zatlyn, Co-founder & COO, Cloudflare
summary: Michelle Zatlyn, Co-founder and COO of Cloudflare, discusses her company's mission to "help build a better internet" and its growth to over 13 million internet properties in its network. Founded in 2009, Cloudflare aims to improve internet security and accessibility. Zatlyn shares her personal journey in Silicon Valley, highlighting Cloudflare's impact on the tech industry.

site_title: China's yuan rally seen short-lived despite trade optimism
summary: China's yuan rallied to 6.7252 per dollar, its highest level in over two weeks, on optimism over US-China trade talks. However, analysts warn that the currency's appreciation may be short-lived, with some predicting a ceiling at around 6.6-6.7 per dollar. Experts believe that a further rally is unlikely due to China's slowing growth environment and lack of room for excessive currency strength.

site_title: Vietnam fast becoming haute new market for luxe property
summary: Vietnam has emerged as a lucrative market for luxury property, with the country's real estate sector experiencing rapid growth due to its fast-paced economy and favorable business environment. The nation's GDP has averaged over 6% per year for the past 20 years, attracting overseas investors and well-heeled domestic buyers. Luxury condominium prices in Ho Chi Minh City have increased 17% to an average of $5,518 per square meter, with forecasts predicting a 10% rise by early 2020. Developers are shifting their focus to the affluent, with Novaland Group's latest project, The Grand Manhattan, offering high-end apartments starting at $6,000 per square meter.

site_title: US has early lead in race to 5G wireless tech, says report
summary: The US is leading the global race to 5G wireless technology, with a projected 9% of mobile data connections in North America by 2022, compared to 4% in Asia. Cisco's annual mobile Virtual Networking Index report attributes the US lead to early policies supporting 5G deployment. The report predicts the US will have the largest share of 5G devices by 2022, with North America accounting for most of the 422 million devices worldwide. A head start in 5G penetration could determine which countries shape the technology's innovations and economic benefits.

site_title: Lagerfeld's heirs apparent emerge at Chanel and Fendi
summary: Karl Lagerfeld's death at 85 has left a void at both Chanel and Fendi. Virginie Viard, Lagerfeld's long-time collaborator and creative director of accessories at Chanel, has been formally nominated as the new creative director. Fendi, owned by LVMH, will instead rely on Silvia Venturini Fendi, a member of the brand's founding family, to fill the role. Both women are set to unveil their respective collections in Paris, marking a new era for the fashion houses.

site_title: Federal Reserve says US growth easing as global risks rise
summary: The Federal Reserve believes US economic growth will slow down this year due to rising global risks, including trade tensions and uncertainty about the economic outlook. The central bankers, citing the waning stimulus from the 2017 tax cuts and slower global growth, expect GDP to decrease somewhat from last year's pace. The Fed raised interest rates four times in 2018 but kept rates on hold in January due to uncertainty, and officials are now unsure about their next move, indicating a wait-and-see posture.

site_title: Danske thrown out of Estonia after country is drawn into probe
summary: Danske Bank has been forced to leave Estonia after the country's financial watchdog deemed the bank's operations there "not acceptable" due to a $230 billion money laundering scandal. Danske announced it would withdraw from the entire Baltic region and Russia, including its operations in Lithuania. The move comes after a formal investigation by the European Banking Authority and amid criminal investigations by the US Justice Department. The scandal has led to fines and a class-action lawsuit against Danske, with its shares tumbling 50% over the past year.

site_title: Ford to close Brazil plant, exit S America truck business
summary: Ford is closing its oldest factory in Brazil and exiting its heavy commercial truck business in South America, affecting over 2,700 jobs. The factory, which has operated since 1967, will cease production of trucks and the Fiesta small car. The move is part of Ford's global restructuring plan, which aims to end losses worldwide and is expected to cost over $11 billion. The closure is a blow to Brazil's automotive industry and the far-right government, which is battling high unemployment. Ford remains committed to South America, where it expects to focus on its core car business.

site_title: Lloyds bank 2018 profit jumps 27% despite Brexit uncertainty
summary: Lloyds Banking Group reported a 27% surge in 2018 profits to £3.87 billion, driven by lower mis-selling costs and a resilient UK economy. Pre-tax profit rebounded 13% to £5.96 billion. Despite Brexit uncertainty, the bank remains optimistic, with a 5% dividend hike and a proposed £1.75 billion share buyback. Total PPI mis-selling claims cost £19.425 billion, down from £1.65 billion in 2017. The bank's strategy aims to deliver for customers amidst uncertain EU withdrawal negotiations.

site_title: Saudi Prince sees value in US$100b investment in India
summary: Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman announced a potential $100 billion investment in India over the next two years, amid tensions between India and Pakistan. The prince expressed willingness to share intelligence with India to combat terrorism, following a militant attack in Kashmir. India and Pakistan signed memoranda of understanding valued at $20 billion to support Pakistan's economy. The visit aims to expand commercial relations and strengthen cooperation on counter-terrorism, naval, and cybersecurity.

site_title: Committee opposes appointing Renault chairman to lead Nissan board: sources
summary: An external committee tasked by Nissan to improve corporate governance opposes appointing Renault Chairman Jean-Dominique Senard as Nissan's board leader, citing potential conflict of interest. The committee considers alternatives, including appointing an external chairman or limiting the chairman's responsibilities. Renault's 43% ownership of Nissan and Senard's expected appointment to Nissan's board may stoke concerns at Renault and the French government, which has expressed a desire for the chairmanship to be held by the same person.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: BreadTalk acquired the remaining 50% interest in its Thai joint venture BTM Thailand from The Minor Food Group for 160 million baht (S$6.96 million). Spackman Entertainment Group appointed new executives, including John Ko Jihwan as CEO. CSE Global reported a net profit of S$5.06 million in the fourth quarter, reversing an earlier loss, despite a 14.2% decline in revenue.

site_title: Who says Singapore talents don't push the creativity envelope?
summary: Singaporean talents are making a name for themselves in various creative fields. Avant-garde floral designer John Lim, conceptual Asian designer Priscilla Shunmugam, and young chef Desmond Shen are among those pushing boundaries and gaining international recognition. Pastry chefs Ben Goh and Chong Koo Jee have also competed internationally and excel in their profession. Spatial designers like ASolidPlan are doing the same in interior design and architecture. These individuals are redefining the creative scene in Singapore and raising the bar for their respective fields.

site_title: Long, difficult road ahead for Venezuela as calls for reform gather pace amid economic disaster
summary: Venezuela's economic disaster continues, with a loss of real GDP greater than most war-torn countries during WWII and inflation expected to reach 10 million%. The country's oil output has fallen to 700,000 barrels per day, and food scarcity has led to widespread famine. The regime's attempts to regulate the economy have failed, and the government's brutal crackdown on dissent has further worsened the situation. With the international community recognizing Juan Guaidó as the legitimate president, Venezuela faces a long and challenging road ahead to rebuild its economy and restore basic services, including humanitarian aid and food supplies.

site_title: Timely emphasis on cybersecurity as a new pillar of total defence
summary: Singapore's 2019 Budget allocates 30% of expenditure to defence, security, and diplomacy, with a focus on cybersecurity as a new pillar of Total Defence. The government recognizes cyberwarfare as a potential theatre of war and will work to bolster its cyber defence capabilities. This move acknowledges the growing threat of cyberattacks, which can cause significant damage without immediate retaliation, and aims to prepare Singapore for the changing nature of warfare. The government's resolve to tackle cyber defence is seen as a demonstration of its commitment to staying ahead in the digital age.

site_title: IMDA to make telco bills more transparent
summary: The Infocomm Media Development Authority (IMDA) in Singapore plans to introduce new rules to make telco bills more transparent, requiring a breakdown of charges and expiry dates for end-users' bills. The proposed changes aim to promote transparency and avoid billing disputes, benefiting consumers and service providers. The IMDA also proposes to extend prohibitions on mid-contract changes and cut regulatory burdens on licensees, while seeking public consultation on the new converged competition code until April 17, 2019.

site_title: Tax break mitigates diesel duty hike - but cushion is temporary
summary: Singapore's diesel excise duty was doubled to S$0.20 per liter in the 2019 Budget, but the government introduced a diesel road tax rebate to mitigate the impact. The rebate is set to expire, and analysts warn that the move may not be the last attempt to reduce diesel use. Industry players, including logistics companies, expect temporary relief, but caution against relying too much on relief measures. Some companies are already exploring alternative fuel options, such as electric or biofuel-powered lorries, and are seeking government subsidies to support the transition.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow
Transport and logistics companies are thankful for the diesel road tax rebate to help mitigate the unexpected hike in diesel excise duty announced in Monday's Budget.

site_title: iFast Q4 bottom line up 46% to S$2.6m
summary: iFast Corporation posted a net profit of S$2.6 million for its fourth quarter, a 46% gain from the previous year, driven by a ONE-OFF gain from the sale of an online insurance platform and improved profits from operations in Singapore, Hong Kong, and Malaysia. Revenue dipped 0.7% to S$28 million, primarily due to a global selldown in equity markets. The company targets breaking even from its China operations by 2021 and proposes a final dividend of 0.9 Singapore cent per share.

site_title: Property downturn blamed for slump among Australia's major supermarkets
summary: Australia's Woolworths Group Ltd reported a lower-than-expected first-half profit due to a prolonged slump in consumer sentiment, attributed to a sharp property downturn. Sales and profit margins were impacted by subdued spending, with liquor earnings dropping 6.4% and supermarket sales growth lagging 2.3% compared to Coles Group Ltd. The company expects this environment to persist, sending shares down 6.4% to a two-month low.

images.alt_text: Woolworths says cool weather in Australia's east hurt ice-cream and water sales, contributing to a slowdown in the pace of quarterly sales growth.

site_title: Great Eastern Q4 profit falls 68% to S$137m on market volatility
summary: Great Eastern reported a 68% fall in Q4 net profit to S$137m due to market volatility. Despite a 5% increase in insurance operating profit, the company registered a S$45.4m loss in shareholders' fund investments. Total weighted new sales fell 30% and new business embedded value dropped 7%. The board proposed a 50c final dividend per share. CEO Khor attributed the challenges to interest rate hikes and global economic concerns, but remains positive on long-term growth potential.

site_title: Globetrotters power into Singapore
summary: The Harlem Globetrotters, a professional basketball team, will play an exhibition match in Singapore on April 5 at the Indoor Stadium in Kallang. This marks their first appearance in Singapore since 2009. The team, known for its extensive travels, has visited 120 countries and territories, and is considered ambassadors of goodwill. Founded in the 1920s as the Chicago GlobeTrotters, the team has played matches throughout the year and promises an entertaining occasion for players and fans alike.

site_title: PropNex to take over agents from China Real Estate unit
summary: PropNex Realty has entered a strategic collaboration with a unit of China Real Estate Group (CREG), absorbing salespeople from Global Alliance Property (GAP). GAP will discontinue its real estate agency business, and its staff will transfer to PropNex. The collaboration aims to give PropNex greater strength in marketing major projects and capture close to half of the residential market share. PropNex's CEO, Ismail Gafoor, said the move will add value to property developers and provide greater opportunities for salespersons.

site_title: Keeping the peace in US-China talks
summary: US-China trade talks are nearing an agreement on punitive tariffs, with China committing to an additional $1 trillion in imports from the US over six years. The talks aim to keep the economic contest peaceful, with both sides recognizing the long-term benefits of a mutually beneficial exchange of goods and services. Despite disagreements on technology transfer and government subsidies, leaders are under pressure to resolve the dispute, with US stock and bond markets reacting positively to recent concessions. A bilateral trade relationship is crucial for both countries, but the US must balance its desire for free trade with safeguarding domestic jobs.

site_title: Singapore's energy players to feel heat of carbon tax only marginally
summary: Singapore's introduction of a S$5-tonne carbon tax this year will marginally affect the energy sector, with analysts estimating a less than 10% impact on companies such as Sembcorp Industries and Keppel Corp. The tax will primarily affect power generation facilities that produce over 25,000 tonnes of greenhouse gas emissions annually. Companies are expected to pass on the increased costs to consumers, leading to a small rise in electricity prices, estimated at 0.9%. The move is seen as a sustainable step towards reducing carbon emissions, with some companies already taking steps to reduce their carbon footprint.

site_title: SHS warns of possible project default on financing woes
summary: SHS Holdings, a Singapore-based construction firm, warns of possible project default on its delayed solar power project in Bangladesh due to financing woes. The project, worth US$21.7 million, faces a termination of key agreements if required financing is not obtained on time. SHS has already invested US$3-8 million and is exploring alternative financing options, with the current deadline set for October 2019. The company is also seeking an extension of the deadline, citing land issues, regulatory approvals, and weather conditions as reasons for the delays.

site_title: OrangeTee transforming into 'TechProp' company
summary: OrangeTee & Tie, a Singaporean real estate agency, is transforming into a "TechProp" company, aiming to disrupt itself to survive in the digital age. Unlike proptech firms, which focus on specific functions, TechProp companies, like OrangeTee, will transform their entire business to leverage innovation, build new skills, and participate in the ecosystem. The company has announced partnerships with DBS Bank, KPMG Business School, and MVL Foundation, and is launching two technology initiatives: Auto-Website and Newsfeed. This transformation aims to provide a better experience for customers, increase revenue, and reduce costs.

site_title: BNP Paribas seeking RMs in Asia as it mulls over Indonesia push
summary: BNP Paribas is hiring relationship managers in Asia as part of a strategy to expand its onshore private banking presence, with a focus on Indonesia. The bank aims to boost assets under management in Asia to $120 billion by 2020, from around $100 billion now. BNP Paribas is also considering establishing onshore operations in India and Taiwan, in addition to its existing presence in Singapore and Hong Kong. The move reflects the bank's desire to be in the "Tier 1 division" of wealth management and capitalize on the growing wealth generated in Indonesia.

site_title: China Everbright Water net profit up 32% to HK$676m on higher revenue
summary: China Everbright Water's net profit rose 32% to HK$676.5 million for 2018, driven by higher revenues from construction, operation, and finance. Revenue grew 33% to HK$4.8 billion, with construction revenue increasing by HK$698.9 million. The company proposed a final dividend of S$0.005 per share, up from S$0.0049 last year.

site_title: MAS, EU body jointly address interest rate swap rules
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and the European Commission have agreed on joint rules for interest rate swap trading platforms, aiming to boost liquidity and help companies hedge currency risks. This common stance will connect two markets, promoting collaboration and reducing risks.

site_title: Multi-party derivatives trading reshape legacy structures
summary: Decentralized technologies are reshaping the derivatives trading market, offering increased transparency and independence. Legacy structures, dominated by large institutions, have perpetuated systemic issues of inequity and mistrust. Multi-party smart contracts, facilitated by blockchain technology, allow peer-to-peer exchanges and direct interaction among participants, excluding the need for a central authority. This enables democratic alternatives to traditional market conditions, promoting financial inclusion and reducing costs, complexity, and information asymmetry.

site_title: Electric cars lone bright spot in China auto industry
summary: China's auto industry saw a slump in overall sales for seven straight months, with total passenger car sales dropping 18% to 2.02 million units in January. However, electric car deliveries more than doubled to 85,000 units, driven by a rush before government subsidies for zero- and low-emission vehicles are scaled back in 2020. The growing demand for electric vehicles is prompting carmakers to boost production and add new models, with Tesla set to accelerate its push in China and compete with global brands and local manufacturers.

site_title: Swedbank behind 40b kronor in suspect transfers: report
summary: Swedbank AB, the largest Nordic lender, faces allegations of money laundering after Swedish broadcaster SVT reported that 50 customers transferred approximately 40 billion kronor (S$5.8 billion) between Swedbank and Danske Bank from 2007 to 2015. Swedbank has identified suspicious transactions and reported them to the police, but denies involvement. The bank's shares fell 7.3% after the report, shaving about US$1.5 billion off its market value. This latest scandal adds to the growing controversy surrounding Danske Bank, which is facing a US$230 billion scandal and potential billions in fines.

site_title: Reits sector gets big boost from lifting of sunset clause on tax exemption
summary: Singapore's Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat has removed the sunset clause for tax exemption on Singapore-listed Reits (S-Reits) and Reits Exchange-Traded Funds (Reits ETFs) distributions, extending it to Dec 31, 2025. This move is expected to boost the Reits sector, with analysts praising the extension of tax concessions, including a 10% concessionary income tax rate for non-resident investors. However, some experts, particularly from the aircraft leasing sector, question whether the tax concessions are sufficient to encourage listings, citing the sector's capital-intensive nature and cyclical industry.

site_title: US$929m funding for California high-speed rail project cancelled
summary: The US Transportation Department has cancelled $929 million in federal funds for California's high-speed rail project, citing the state's failure to make reasonable progress. The funds were awarded by the Obama administration, and California has already received $2.5 billion. Governor Gavin Newsom has vowed to fight for the funds, calling them "California's money." The project, initially planned at $77.3 billion, has faced cost hikes, delays, and management concerns. California can challenge the government's action, and President Trump has called for the state to return the funds.

site_title: Russian hackers targeted European research groups, says Microsoft
summary: Microsoft revealed that Russian hackers targeted over 100 email accounts at European research groups, including think tanks and NGOs focused on election security, nuclear policy, and foreign relations, ahead of May elections. The attacks, part of a broader online campaign, aim to disrupt opponents of Russian President Vladimir Putin. Microsoft's findings demonstrate the continued spread of this campaign, which has been ongoing since 2018.

site_title: DBS to merge retail equities trading into bank by year-end
summary: DBS, Southeast Asia's largest bank, plans to transfer its retail equity trading under DBS Vickers to the bank by the end of the year, integrating the business into its wealth management platform. The move aims to provide a one-stop platform for customers to access banking, brokerage, and wealth management solutions. DBS Vickers will maintain its broking licence and focus on institutional trading, while employees will be offered new roles in the bank. The integration is part of a strategy initiated six years ago, driven by growing demand for a holistic wealth proposition.

images.alt_text: Jimmy Ho, president of the Society of Remisiers, says subsuming stockbroking under the banks diminishes professionalism

site_title: COEs end mostly higher in latest tender
summary: In the latest Singaporean COE tender, most certificates ended higher, with cars up to 1,600cc and 130bhp selling at $26,301, and larger vehicles at $35,403. Motorcycle premiums fell to $3,689. Industry experts expect premiums to decrease once the current order bank is fulfilled, likely after the Singapore Motorshow.

site_title: Cathay Pacific profit to double estimates
summary: Cathay Pacific Airways Ltd has projected a profit of HK$2.3 billion (S$396.2 million) for 2018, exceeding analyst estimates and marking the end of two straight years in the red. The airline's turnaround plan, which included cost-cutting and revenue-boosting measures, has paid off. Shares surged nearly 9% on Wednesday following the announcement.

site_title: Burberry shirt featuring a noose for drawstrings creates furore
summary: Burberry faced backlash after a hooded sweatshirt with a rope tied into a noose, resembling a noose used in racist lynching imagery, was showcased at London Fashion Week. The design was intended to be nautical, but observers condemned it as insensitive to suicide and racism. Burberry apologized, removed the sweatshirt from its collection, and pledged to take steps to prevent similar incidents in the future. The incident follows a string of fashion brands facing criticism for products perceived as racist or insensitive, including Gucci and Prada.

site_title: Is America becoming a four-party state?
summary: The US is facing a deepening divide within its two major parties, potentially leading to a four-party system in the 2020 election. The Democratic Party is split between "redivide-the-pie" and "grow-the-pie" Democrats, with the latter advocating for business-friendly policies and the former pushing for greater economic equality. The Republican Party is also divided, with a "limited-government-grow-the-pie" faction and a "hoard-the-pie" far-right faction. This divide is reflected in the recent debate over the Green New Deal and Trump's declaration of a national emergency on the Mexico border, which has sparked outrage in both parties and may lead to a more complex and nuanced electoral landscape.

site_title: Palladium tops US$1,500 as shortage ignites rally
summary: Palladium prices surged to a record high of US$1,500.36 an ounce, driven by a global shortage of supply and stringent emissions controls in the automotive industry. The metal's rally, extending for a seventh monthly gain, is set to continue despite concerns about durability. Analysts attribute the shortage to reduced car sales in China and tightening emissions legislation, which outweighs the weakness in global auto sales and the growing threat of electric vehicles.

site_title: Independent centrist party likely as Tory 'remainers' boost anti-Brexit ranks
summary: A UK centrist Independent Party is likely to form, with 22 members, to fight for a Brexit extension and reasonable deal. Three Conservative MPs and one Labour MP have quit their parties to join the group, which could merge with 11 Liberal Party members. The move comes as Brexit negotiations stall, causing economic stagnation and public disenchantment. The group's strong "Remainer" stance may lead to a second referendum or Brexit extension if the Conservative Party fails to secure a deal.

site_title: HK to partially develop controversial Fanling golf course for housing
summary: Hong Kong's government has approved a plan to partially develop the 170-hectare Fanling golf course for public housing, taking back less than a fifth of the land. The move aims to address the city's severe housing shortage, but has been met with opposition from international golfing stars and the Hong Kong Golf Club. The plan will allow 32 hectares of the venue to be turned into public housing, while the rest will continue to operate as a golf course.

site_title: Yuan hits 3-week high on trade deal optimism
summary: The Chinese yuan reached a three-week high after the US pressed Beijing to prevent a sharp weakening of its currency as part of any trade deal. The US dollar paused ahead of the release of monetary policy minutes, while the euro slipped 0.1% to US$1.1334. The yuan rose 0.4% to a three-week high of 6.7168, driven by optimism over the US-China trade talks. The dollar edged higher to 96.591, below a two-month high, as investors awaited cues on US monetary policy.

site_title: Hanoi barber makes headlines with free Trump-Kim haircuts
summary: A Vietnamese barber is offering free haircuts in honor of the upcoming summit between US President Donald Trump and North Korean leader Kim Jong Un. The barber, Le Tuan Duong, is giving away haircuts to resemble Trump's and Kim's distinctive styles. The promotion, which runs until February 28, has been met with a mix of enthusiasm and criticism, as North Korea is sensitive to any perceived insults to its "supreme leadership". The barber, who lost family members in the Vietnam War, expressed support for the summit and hopes to promote peace.

images.alt_text: To Gia Huy, 9, and Le Phuc Hai, 66, let world leader signature styling go to their heads with their new looks after being coiffed a la North Korean leader Kim and US President Trump in a salon in Hanoi, Vietnam, on Tuesday.

site_title: STI up on active day for local stocks
summary: Singapore stocks rebounded on Wednesday with the Straits Times Index (STI) gaining 0.57% to 3,278.38 points, driven by a 6.33% surge in Sembcorp Marine and gains in Sembcorp Industries, Keppel Corp, and CapitaLand. DBS fell 0.08% after revamping its retail stock-brokerage operations and exploring alternative models. The market's recovery was attributed to higher oil prices, which lifted optimism in oil and gas-related companies.

site_title: Huawei issue opens rift between US and European mobile carriers
summary: US mobile carriers and European counterparts disagree over security threats from Chinese equipment maker Huawei. The GSMA, a London-based wireless industry group, urged European lawmakers not to ban Huawei, while the CTIA, a Washington-based group, stated that the GSMA's views do not represent all US wireless operators or regions. This rift highlights a US-Europe divide on the issue ahead of a conference.

site_title: Ruthless meth networks keep Myanmar hooked
summary: Myanmar is believed to be the largest source of methamphetamine, with locals struggling with its grip. The country's Shan State is the epicentre of production, with a network of local armed groups and transnational trafficking gangs fueling the multi-billion dollar industry. Meth use is rampant, with nearly every household affected, and users, including children as young as nine, are consuming the drug at alarming rates, with prices plummeting to 10 US cents per pill, making it accessible to a wider population. The crisis is considered a "public health disaster" by the UN Office on Drugs and Crime.

site_title: UBS ordered to pay record 4.5b euros in French tax trial
summary: A Paris court ordered UBS to pay a record 4.5 billion euros in a French tax trial, finding the bank guilty of helping wealthy French clients stash funds in undeclared Swiss accounts. The court also fined UBS 3.7 billion euros and added 800 million euros in compensation to the French government. UBS plans to appeal the ruling, which delays payments until higher courts make a final decision.

site_title: Will Lagerfeld's pet feline Choupette inherit his millions?
summary: Karl Lagerfeld, the late fashion designer, had reportedly ensured that his pet cat Choupette would inherit a significant portion of his estimated $200 million fortune. Choupette, an eight-year-old Burmese cat, has been part of Lagerfeld's life since 2011 and has enjoyed a luxurious lifestyle, including her own personal bodyguard and maids. Lagerfeld had previously hinted that he had written Choupette into his will, valuing her fortune at at least $3 million.

site_title: US: Wall St opens flat
summary: US stocks opened flat on Wednesday, despite a handful of downbeat earnings reports, amid ongoing trade talks between the US and China. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 19.06 points, while the S&P 500 opened lower by 0.71 points. The Nasdaq Composite gained 3.54 points to reach fresh records.

site_title: Glencore brings the end of thermal coal a step closer
summary: Glencore, the world's largest thermal coal supplier, has announced plans to cap its production at around 145 million tonnes a year for the foreseeable future, citing increasing pressure from investors to back away from the dirtiest emissions. The move follows engagement with investors participating in the Climate Action 100+ initiative, which aims to promote climate action. Glencore's decision is seen as a step towards the decline of thermal coal, with prices already falling and wind and solar power becoming increasingly competitive. The company's planned output cap is expected to maintain for decades, but the industry's future remains uncertain as investors and insurers increasingly divest from coal.

site_title: CHA to invest S$50m in SMG, increasing stake to 24%
summary: CHA Healthcare Singapore has entered into a share purchase agreement to invest S$50 million in Singapore Medical Group (SMG), increasing its stake from 6.86% to 24.13%. CHA will purchase 83 million shares at S$0.605 apiece, becoming SMG's controlling shareholder. Additionally, CHA is extending a convertible loan of S$10 million, which could result in the issuance of 23.6 million new shares. The investment aims to pursue earnings-accretive opportunities across the region.

site_title: Sunvic Chemical to form panel to probe into guarantees for 222.5m yuan in loans
summary: Sunvic Chemical Holdings has appointed a special investigative committee to probe corporate guarantees totaling 222.5 million yuan (S$44.3 million) for loans extended by its subsidiaries to other companies. The committee will review the guarantees provided by Yixing Yinyan and Jiangsu Jurong, and temporarily suspend the rights of their legal representatives. The moves come after letters of demand were issued in relation to the guarantees, which were extended at the request of borrowers and their banks to facilitate loan grants. The investigation aims to determine why the guarantees were extended in the first place.

site_title: CHA takes larger stake in SMG to grow healthcare partnership
summary: Singapore Medical Group (SMG) and CHA Healthcare Singapore have deepened their partnership, with CHA increasing its stake in SMG from 6.8% to 24.1%. The move expands their combined healthcare networks to be a key player in women's health in Asia-Pacific. CHA will become SMG's controlling shareholder after buying 83 million shares for S$50 million. The two groups plan to focus on women's health and fertility businesses, with ambitions to become a global player in the industry, potentially scaling up to the mainboard in the next couple of years.

site_title: Thai police seek to prosecute leader of anti-junta party popular with young
summary: Thai police are seeking to prosecute Thanathorn Juangroongruangkit, leader of the Future Forward Party, for a speech criticizing the ruling junta posted on Facebook just before a general election. The case, under the Computer Crime Act, could result in five-year jail sentences. The party denies the charge, calling it a "rush" ahead of the election. The ruling junta's efforts to retain control over politics have raised concerns among young voters and opposition parties.

site_title: North Korea's US envoy arrives in Hanoi ahead of Trump-Kim summit
summary: North Korea's special envoy, Kim Hyok Chol, has arrived in Hanoi ahead of a summit between US President Donald Trump and North Korean leader Kim Jong Un on February 27-28. Kim Hyok Chol met with US counterpart Stephen Biegun earlier this month to discuss denuclearization. The summit aims to address progress since their June summit in Singapore, where they agreed on vague denuclearization terms. Observers hope for more concrete outcomes to avoid the summit being dismissed as a publicity stunt.

site_title: Grab launches pet-friendly transport service GrabPet in beta
summary: Grab has launched its pet-friendly transport service, GrabPet, in beta, allowing pet owners to book a ride on-demand with their animal companions on board. The service, which charges a minimum fare of S$14, caters to pets approved by the Agri-Food and Veterinary Authority of Singapore, except for birds. The service insures the animals on board and has specific pet-handling guidelines for drivers. Grab has received feedback from pet owners, who had previously signed an online petition urging the company to continue a similar service after Uber's exit from Singapore.

site_title: Britain yet to decide on 5G security policy -official
summary: Britain has not yet decided on its security policy for 5G networks, with the country's National Cyber Security Centre (NCSC) head Ciaran Martin stating that equipment from Huawei, a Chinese telecoms equipment maker, is subject to strict oversight. Despite concerns over Huawei's relationship with the Chinese government, the NCSC has not found evidence of hostile activity. The government will complete its analysis later this year, with a policy decision to be made then. Huawei has pledged to address technical issues, but acknowledged it would take some years to do so.

site_title: Saudi prince sees "useful returns" from expected US$100b investment in India
summary: Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman has expressed interest in investing over $100 billion in India over the next two years, citing opportunities in various fields. The investment is seen as a move to strengthen diplomatic ties between the two countries amid tensions with Pakistan. The prince also emphasized the need for cooperation on counter-terrorism and agreed to share intelligence with India to tackle extremism and terrorism. This comes as Saudi Arabia seeks to expand its commercial relations with India and counter its strained ties with the West.

images.alt_text: In a joint press appearance after talks with Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi,Crown Prince Mohammed Bin Salman said terrorism was a common concern and Saudi Arabia was ready to share intelligence with India to tackle it.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: China Real Estate Group unit transfers 7,500 salespersons to PropNex Realty. COE prices ended mostly higher, with a healthy order bank despite smaller supply. Keppel delivers a jackup rig to Grupo R in a sale and leaseback deal. Singapore property prices are unlikely to rebound rapidly due to government curbs. IMDA plans to regulate telco bills for transparency. Singapore shares closed 0.6% higher, ahead of the US Fed's minutes release.

site_title: Ghosn's new lawyer, 'the Razor', takes aim at Nissan and prosecutors
summary: Carlos Ghosn's new lawyer, Junichiro Hironaka, has dismissed the charges against the ousted Nissan chairman, calling them an internal company matter. Hironaka, nicknamed "the Razor," criticized Japan's judicial system for keeping Ghosn in jail, stating that the charges should have been handled as an internal matter. Ghosn remains in detention, facing allegations of financial misconduct and breach of trust, and his lawyers are preparing for pre-trial discovery meetings. Despite his new lawyer's combative style, experts say Ghosn's chances of an acquittal remain low due to Japan's strict criminal justice system.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares ended higher on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 19.62 points to 1,726.18. Volume reached 3.8 billion lots worth RM3.3 billion. Gainers outpaced losers 724 to 252.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Two brokerages, DBS Equity Research and CapitaLand, have reaffirmed their "buy" ratings for Sasseur Reit and CapitaLand, respectively, citing their exposure to the fast-growing Chinese outlet mall industry and attractive yields. DBS Research raised its target price for Sasseur Reit to S$0.97, while CapitaLand's target price remains at S$4.18. The analysts highlight potential upside risks from inorganic growth strategies, but note key risks include slower-than-expected tenant sales growth for Sasseur Reit and negative rent reversions for CapitaLand.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets rise at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets rose at the start of trading on Wednesday, with London's FTSE 100 index up 0.2% and the eurozone's DAX 30 and CAC 40 indices adding 0.3% and 0.2% respectively. The rally was driven by gains in mining and healthcare shares, while US-EU trade talks were also in focus. The US stock markets also reached fresh records, despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: More transparency sought for foreign worker criteria
summary: Singapore businesses are calling for greater transparency in the government's criteria for foreign workers with "specialised skills in demand globally." The government's lack of clarity has led to frustration among firms, with some failing to secure approvals for foreign talent despite meeting minimum criteria. HR consultancies speculate that emerging, deep tech areas such as engineering, machine learning, and cloud computing are in high demand. The government has proposed a case-by-case approach, but businesses are urging for more details and a streamlined process to attract top talent.

images.alt_text: Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat said in his Budget speech on Monday that additional manpower flexibility can be applied for firms to bring in foreign talent, on a case-by-case basis, provided that they still face a shortage after having given fair consideration to Singaporeans.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks finish on a high
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 1.01% on Wednesday, driven by investors' optimism over a potential US-China trade agreement. The Hang Seng Index reached 28,514.05, while the Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indexes also gained. The gains follow recent rallies in other Asian markets, despite ongoing US-EU trade uncertainty.

site_title: Singapore shares close 0.6% higher on Wednesday
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.6% on Wednesday, closing at 3,278.38, ahead of the US Fed's minutes release. Sembcorp Marine led the gains, up 6.33%, while Singtel rose 1.67%. DBS fell 0.08% after revamping its retail stock brokerage operations. The Straits Times Index gained 18.58 points, with 1.35 billion securities worth S$1.12 billion changing hands.

site_title: New Spackman CEO sets sights on growing non-production revenue
summary: Spackman Entertainment Group, a South Korean entertainment producer listed on the Catalist, has appointed new CEO Ko Jihwan, who aims to transform the company's business model and boost revenue through non-film production. Ko, 44, previously led Greenlight Content Co, and plans to rejuvenate the company's stock valuation and price. The new management includes Na Kyoungwon as COO and president, Ng Siew Ling as group financial controller, and Jasmine Leong as general manager and head of investor relations. The company's stock ended flat at S$0.025, awaiting its unaudited results release on Feb 28.

site_title: Beacons of light for Asean manufacturers
summary: A World Economic Forum (WEF) study identifies 16 "lighthouses" in Asean manufacturing that can guide others on harnessing 4th Industrial Revolution (4IR) technologies. These lighthouses have successfully adopted emerging technologies like advanced analytics and cloud computing, boosting productivity and value creation. Asean manufacturers can capture US$216-627 billion in 4IR rewards by 2025, but only 13% have begun digital transformation due to obstacles such as unclear business cases and cybersecurity concerns. To succeed, Asean manufacturers must adopt common attributes like embracing technological megatrends, collaboration, and upskilling.

site_title: CapitaLand taking step back from Singapore housing sector unless price is good
summary: CapitaLand, a Singapore-based property developer, plans to re-evaluate its presence in the Singapore housing sector unless it can secure favorable prices. The company posted a 71.2% rise in net profit to S$475.7 million in Q4, driven by better operating performance and gains from asset recycling. CapitaLand's CEO, Lee Chee Koon, stated that the company will consider participating in Singapore residential projects only if it can secure good returns. The company will focus on conserving capital for opportunities, including its proposed S$11 billion acquisition of Ascendas-Singbridge.

images.alt_text: CapitaLand group CEO Lee Chee Koon says the group will continue to be disciplined with asset recycling.

site_title: CSE Global returns to the black with Q4 net profit of S$5.06m
summary: CSE Global, a technology solutions provider, reported a net profit of S$5.06 million in Q4 2018, reversing a prior loss of S$37.3 million. Revenue fell 14.2% year-on-year to S$100.1 million, but "other operating costs" dropped by 79.2% due to previously recorded impairment charges. The company expects an improvement in financial performance for 2019, driven by increased market activities and stable pricing. A final dividend of 1.5 Singapore cents per share is recommended, totaling 2.75 cents per share.

site_title: HG Metal opens cut-and-bend fabrication plant in Myanmar
summary: HG Metal Manufacturing has opened a cut-and-bend fabrication plant in Myanmar, capable of producing 4,000 tonnes of steel per month. The plant, located in Yangon, is a 5-acre site and was invested in by HG Metal, Singapore, and Myanmar partners with a total investment of US$12 million. The plant will cater to the demand for structural steel in infrastructure and high-rise building projects, with an estimated monthly demand of 60,000 tonnes in Yangon alone.

site_title: Three MPs quit UK governing party over Brexit
summary: Three UK Conservative MPs, Anna Soubry, Heidi Allen, and Sarah Wollaston, quit the party over Brexit, citing its "dismal failure" to stand up to pro-Brexit factions. They join eight former Labour MPs to form the Independent Group, leaving the Conservatives six votes short of a majority in parliament. The move follows an eighth MP's resignation from Labour over anti-Semitism allegations, and comes as the UK's Brexit saga continues to divide the government and opposition.

site_title: IMDA plans to regulate for more transparent telco bills
summary: The Infocomm Media Development Authority (IMDA) plans to introduce new rules to make telco bills more transparent, requiring service providers to include a breakdown of charges and details on complimentary services. The agency also proposes to boost consumers' understanding of contractual terms and extend the prohibition on "detrimental" mid-contract changes. The new converged competition code aims to promote competition, consumer protection, and regulatory clarity, with a public consultation period set to close on April 17, 2019.

site_title: China Real Estate Grp unit to transfer real estate salespersons to PropNex Realty
summary: PropNex Realty has entered a strategic collaboration with Global Alliance Property (GAP), a subsidiary of China Real Estate Group (CREG), to transfer its salespersons. Under the deal, GAP will discontinue its real estate agency business while PropNex will continue to develop properties in China. The partnership aims to capture nearly half of the residential market share and enhance marketing capabilities. Over 7,500 GAP salespersons will join PropNex, leveraging training and support programs, and benefiting from the company's 19-year track record in the industry.

site_title: Huawei launches cloud services business in Singapore
summary: Huawei launches its cloud services business in Singapore, aiming to be one of its largest outside of China. The company will provide 24/7 technical support and AI capabilities, serving startups and major industries in the Asia-Pacific. Huawei Cloud will also launch a skill training and recruitment plan to provide employment opportunities and professional training programs for talent. This expansion follows Huawei Cloud's recent launches in Hong Kong, Russia, Thailand, and South Africa, and the opening of 40 availability zones in 23 geographic regions.

site_title: Oriental Group to apply for winding-up after bailout talks collapse
summary: Oriental Group, a Singapore-listed steel trader, will apply for winding-up after bailout talks with potential investors collapsed. The company has been under judicial management since 2017 and was reprimanded in 2018 for misconduct. Trading in its shares is suspended. The company will file necessary applications to discharge the judicial management order and wind up within the extended timeframe set by the Singapore High Court.

site_title: MAS, European Commission work on common approach to derivatives trading obligations
summary: Singapore's Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and the European Commission are collaborating on a common approach to derivatives trading obligations, aiming to deepen economic ties between the two regions. The joint effort seeks to add liquidity to fragmented markets and help businesses hedge currency risks. The move supports the Group of 20's (G-20) reforms, allowing trading venues to support derivatives trading on both sides. This cooperation may enable European and Singaporean firms to continue using derivatives platforms in either market, despite ongoing global reforms.

site_title: Cathay Pacific sees 2018 profit beating expectations, shares surge
summary: Cathay Pacific Airways reported a profit of about HK$2.3 billion (S$396.1 million) for 2018, exceeding analyst estimates of HK$1.1 billion. The airline attributed the surprise profit to improved revenue management and capacity growth, despite competitive pressures. Passenger airfare prices rose, and cargo business also performed well. Cathay's transformation plan to cut costs and boost revenue is expected to continue, following a similar turnaround strategy pursued by Singapore Airlines.

site_title: Seoul: Shares close at 4-month high on foreign buying; won rises
summary: South Korean stocks reached a four-month high on February 20, 2019, due to foreign buying and a weaker dollar. The benchmark KOSPI index rose 1.09% to 2,229.76, driven by gains from IT heavyweights like Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix. Foreign investors purchased 430.9 billion won worth of shares, the largest daily net purchase in almost four weeks, boosting the Kospi 9.2% for the year. The won also strengthened against the dollar, closing at 1,123.5 per dollar.

site_title: Money Hacks Season 2: Step-by-step tips for HDB flat sellers in today's market
summary: Sisters Rhonda and Race Wong from Ohmyhome, a leading online real estate platform, provide step-by-step tips for HDB flat sellers in Singapore's current market. Key steps include registering an Intent To Sell on the HDB portal, checking data for accurate pricing, and ensuring a minimum five-year occupation period. The duo also discuss the benefits of using their platform, including access to ready buyers and sellers, and potential cost savings on agent commissions.

site_title: Australia shares falter on weak earnings; NZ up
summary: Australian shares fell 0.2% on Wednesday, despite gains in resource stocks, due to weak earnings from retailers and property developers. Woolworths, Wesfarmers, and Coles Group posted lower-than-expected profits, while Crown Resorts and Stockland Corporation warned of a prolonged slump in consumer sentiment. In contrast, mining giants BHP Group and Rio Tinto rose, lifting the mining sub-index to a 7-year high. New Zealand's benchmark index rose 0.27%, driven by a2 Milk Company's record profit.

site_title: Talent investor Entrepreneur First raises US$115m for global deep-tech fund
summary: Entrepreneur First (EF), a London-based talent investor, has raised US$115 million for its global deep-tech fund, led by top institutional investors in the US, Europe, and Asia. The fund aims to invest in over 2,200 individuals worldwide, creating over 300 venture-backed companies over the next three years. The investment will free EF from constant fundraising, allowing it to focus on global expansion and talent development. EF's Singapore fund stands at S$16 million, which will cover cohorts until May 2019, with plans to invest out of a new vehicle from the sixth cohort onwards.

site_title: Countries in the Asia Pacific showed the greatest differences in download experience: Opensignal Study
summary: A recent Opensignal report found that countries in the Asia Pacific exhibit the greatest differences in 4G download speeds, with some experiencing speeds up to 30 Mbps faster than a few hours prior. Countries like Singapore (45.4 Mbps) and South Korea (47.1 Mbps) have the fastest speeds, while others, such as Thailand (8.2 Mbps) and Indonesia (8.6 Mbps), lag behind. The study, which analyzed 77 countries, collected over 3 billion individual measurements daily from smartphones worldwide.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close higher for third straight session
summary: Tokyo stocks rose for a third consecutive session, driven by a solid performance on Wall Street and hopes for progress in US-China trade talks. The Nikkei 225 index gained 0.60% to close at 21,431.49, while the Topix index rose 0.43% to 1,613.47. Investors were encouraged by the resumption of US-China trade talks, with US President Donald Trump saying the talks were "going very well". This boost was accompanied by gains in individual stocks, including SoftBank Group and Mitsui and Co, while Honda fell after announcing plant closures.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Wednesday afternoon at 3,271.44, up 0.36%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.36% to 3,271.44 on Wednesday, driven by gains in Sembcorp Marine, Keppel Corp, and Sembcorp Industries. The Straits Times Index gained 11.64 points, with 202 gainers outnumbering 124 losers. The full-year earnings beat expectations for Sembcorp Marine boosted its shares, while higher oil prices lifted Keppel Corp. The rally comes ahead of GDP data and despite ongoing US-EU trade talks and tariff uncertainty.

site_title: App-based delivery men highlight India's growing gig economy
summary: India's growing gig economy is highlighted through the rise of app-based food delivery services, providing a lucrative source of income for thousands of young drivers, mostly men, who work long hours and often miss meals. However, concerns arise over workers' rights and job security due to their status as independent contractors, with labor laws not applying to them. Analysts estimate the gig economy could grow to $30 billion by 2025, but experts call for government regulation to improve working conditions for these workers.

site_title: Lloyds Bank brushes off Brexit fears with bumper dividend, buyback plan
summary: Lloyds Banking Group reported a 24% rise in net profits to £4.4 billion in 2018, despite weaker-than-expected growth. The bank plans a £4 billion dividend and £1.75 billion share buyback, maintaining its core capital ratio at 13.9%. CEO António Horta Osório expressed confidence in the UK economy's resilience, citing record employment and GDP growth. Impairments increased by 18% to £937 million, but no provision was made for Brexit-related risks, unlike rivals HSBC and Royal Bank of Scotland.

site_title: Keppel delivers jackup rig to Grupo R in sale and leaseback deal
summary: Keppel Offshore & Marine (Keppel O&M) has delivered a jackup rig, Cantarell IV, to Grupo R in a sale and leaseback deal. Grupo R purchased the rig for $179 million and will lease it back to Keppel FELS, a subsidiary of Keppel O&M, on a bareboat charter for five years at competitive day rates. The rig will work in offshore Mexico, supporting an integrated drilling contract for Pemex, starting in early May.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2019: What's the impact on your business?
summary: The Singapore Budget 2019 was recently announced, with its impact on businesses still being analyzed. However, a separate article discusses various global economic and business news, including the potential impact of US tariffs on the Asian garment industry, a significant slowdown in China's GDP growth, and the UK economy shrinking for the second month. Additionally, Citigroup predicts a 1,150 target for MSCI's global equity index by mid-2026 and Thailand's Thaksin Shinawatra is confident of his daughter's suspension being cleared by the court. These events and predictions are unrelated to the Singapore Budget 2019.

site_title: Singapore startup Haulio launches mobile platform, inks MOU with Yang Kee Logistics
summary: Singapore startup Haulio has launched a mobile platform, Haulio Connectivity System (HCS), to enhance data standardization, efficiency, and collaboration among container haulage companies, clients, and drivers. The app, available on Android and iOS, offers greater visibility and reduced manual paperwork. Haulio has also signed a memorandum of understanding with Yang Kee Logistics to integrate their resources, aiming to resolve traditional pain points in the logistics industry and generate significant synergies. The combined platforms are expected to drive technological sophistication and attract the younger generation to the aging industry.

site_title: Hot stock: SembMarine shares rise despite Q4 profit tumble
summary: SembCorp Marine's Q4 profit fell 94.9% to $5.9 million, but shares rose 5.7% due to beating analysts' expectations. Full-year net losses reversed from a profit of $260.2 million. Analysts from DBS and OCBC maintain a "hold" rating but increase fair value estimate to $1.73. Traders attribute the stock's rise to institutional buy orders and rising oil prices, which could support SembMarine's stock price. A potential merger with Keppel Corp is also seen as a catalyst.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open with gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.74% in early trading on February 20, 2019, after US President Donald Trump hinted at extending a deadline for wrapping up a China-US trade deal, sparking optimism. The Hang Seng Index climbed 209.97 points to 28,438.10, while the Shanghai Composite Index added 5.41 points to 2,761.06.

site_title: COEs end mostly higher in latest tender
summary: Singapore's latest Certificate of Entitlement (COE) tender saw mostly higher prices, with cars up to 1,600cc and 130bhp ending at $26,301, commercial vehicles at $26,914, and open COE at $36,667. Motorcycles premium decreased to $3,689. Industry experts expect premiums to decrease once the current order bank is fulfilled, following last month's Singapore Motorshow.

images.alt_text: Certificates of entitlement (COE) ended mostly higher in the latest tender on Wednesday (Feb 20) as motor dealers continued to clear a healthy order bank in the face of a smaller COE supply.

site_title: Japan govt, Fukushima operator told to pay over nuclear disaster
summary: A Japanese court has ordered the government and Tokyo Electric Power Co (TEPCO) to pay nearly $4 million in damages to residents who fled their homes after the 2011 Fukushima nuclear meltdown. This is the fifth time the government has been ruled liable for the disaster. Presiding judge Ken Nakadaira stated that the government and TEPCO "could have avoided the accident" if they had taken measures against the tsunami. The ruling is part of ongoing lawsuits seeking compensation from the government for the disaster.

site_title: Sunvic Chemical to form panel to probe further into guarantees for 222.5m yuan in loans
summary: Sunvic Chemical Holdings has appointed a special investigative committee to probe corporate guarantees provided for loans totaling 222.5 million yuan (S$44.3 million) to two companies, following letters of demand from creditors. The company's subsidiaries, Yixing Yinyan and Jiangsu Jurong, had extended these guarantees, with Yixing Yinyan's guarantee extended at the request of the borrower and its bank to facilitate a loan from Yixing City Futao Rural Micro Credit Co. The company has temporarily suspended the rights of its subsidiaries' legal representatives and clarified that the guarantees were not authorized by the board at the time.

site_title: Carros Project Management clinches JTC site in Kranji for S$5.1m
summary: Carros Project Management Pte Ltd has won a tender to develop an 0.77-hectare industrial site in Kranji for S$5.1 million under the Industrial Government Land Sales (IGLS) programme. The site, zoned B2, has a lease of 20 years and a gross plot ratio of 2.5 ha. This award comes after the site was initially launched in 2017 but was not awarded due to a low bid. The company will use the site for its project management business.

site_title: Asia: Markets, currencies boosted by trade optimism
summary: Asian markets and currencies rose due to optimism over US-China trade talks. The yuan gained 0.7% following a US call for China to stabilize the currency as part of any agreement. Hong Kong led gains, while Seoul, Singapore, and Taipei also rose. The upbeat mood boosted investor confidence to buy higher-risk currencies, lifting the South African rand and Australia's dollar. Meanwhile, hopes for changes to the UK's Brexit deal with the EU boosted the pound.

site_title: Amazon's 'collaborative' robots offer peek into the future
summary: Amazon has deployed hundreds of advanced collaborative robots at its Staten Island order fulfillment center, which has increased efficiency and productivity. The robots, paired with human workers wearing high-tech vests, can transport thousands of items and have reduced the time to fulfill orders from over a day to less than an hour. Amazon's chief technologist, Tye Brady, believes this partnership is the key to future human productivity and job growth, contrary to concerns that automation will lead to job losses. The company has created over 300,000 new jobs since acquiring robotics maker Kiva in 2012.

images.alt_text: Hundreds of orange robots zoom and whiz back and forth like miniature bumper cars - but instead of colliding, they're following a carefully plotted path to transport thousands of items ordered from online giant Amazon.

site_title: Hong Kong to take back part of biggest golf course for homes
summary: Hong Kong's government has endorsed plans to reclaim 32 hectares of the Hong Kong Golf Club's site in Fanling to build homes, addressing the city's housing shortage. The move aims to boost supply and alleviate the shortage, which is estimated to be over 1,200 hectares. The decision balances housing needs with the need to host international golf tournaments, as the site has been leased for $413,000 annually. The plan is part of a broader effort to tackle the city's residential housing crisis.

site_title: China Everbright FY18 profit grows 32%; to pay out 0.5 Singapore cent/share
summary: China Everbright Water's net profit rose 32% to HK$676.5 million in FY18, driven by higher revenues from construction, operation, and finance. Revenue grew 33% to HK$4.8 billion, while earnings per share reached HK$0.256. The company proposes a final dividend of S$0.005 per share, up from S$0.0049 last year. Net asset value per share declined slightly to HK$2.98, and the company expects stable growth in the water environment management sector.

site_title: Cleantech startup SensorFlow raises US$2.7m in series A round led by Pierre Lorinet
summary: SensorFlow, a Singapore-based cleantech firm, has raised US$2.7 million in series A funding led by Pierre Lorinet. The company, which provides an energy management solution for hotels, has now raised a total of US$3.5 million. The funds will be used to expand globally, targeting 800,000 smart hotel rooms by 2022. SensorFlow's solutions have delivered up to 30% energy savings and 40% reduction in maintenance costs. The company aims to partner with hotels and developers to champion energy efficiency and make smart green hotels a standard practice in the industry.

site_title: Malaysia nears deal with China to revive US$20b rail project
summary: Malaysia is nearing a deal with China to revive a US$20 billion East Coast Rail Link project, with talks led by Daim Zainuddin nearing completion. China is willing to reduce the project's price tag and Malaysia is seeking to balance attracting investment with its anti-corruption drive. The deal comes as Malaysia seeks to ease tensions with China, following a conciliatory tone from Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad last month. Discussions aim to scale down the project size and cost, with the Foreign Minister stating that the project is not cancelled until a settlement is reached.

site_title: Malaysia shares open higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 6.30 points to 1,712.86 at 9am on Wednesday, with volume reaching 40.08 million lots worth RM19.93 million. Gainers outpaced losers 128 to 42, contributing to the market's opening higher.

site_title: Samsung bends over backwards to rev smartphone desire
summary: Samsung is set to unveil new flagship smartphones, including a foldable model with a screen that can be closed like a book, at its Galaxy Unpacked event in San Francisco. The company aims to boost the stagnant smartphone market and compete with Apple, which has not pursued folding screens for its iPhones. Analysts expect trade-offs with the technology, including a potential increase in thickness and price, but see it as an opportunity for Samsung to establish a new category and gain premium market share.

images.alt_text: Samsung on Wednesday is expected to unveil new flagship smartphones including one with a screen that can fold closed like a book as it seeks to boost the moribund market.

site_title: Ex-Najib bodyguard faces deportation from Australia after losing asylum appeal
summary: A former bodyguard of Malaysia's former prime minister Najib Razak, Sirul Azhar Umar, faces deportation from Australia after losing an asylum appeal. Sirul, who fled to Australia in 2014 while on bail, was one of two bodyguards sentenced to death in Malaysia for the 2006 murder of Mongolian national Altantuya Shaariibuu. Australia is expected to delay his deportation until Malaysia abolishes the death penalty. Sirul maintains his innocence, claiming he was ordered to carry out the killing.

site_title: Australia's Fortescue says lacks capacity to 'materially' boost iron ore output near-term
summary: Australia's Fortescue Metals Group stated it lacks the capacity to "materially" boost iron ore output in the near term due to bottlenecks in its ore processing facilities. The company cited a dam tailings burst in Brazil as a factor contributing to uncertainty over global supply. Fortescue's CEO, Elizabeth Gaines, emphasized that while there isn't immediate capacity to add significant volumes, the company would explore opportunities to increase production in the long term.

site_title: Singapore property not set for 'big bump', CapitaLand says
summary: Singapore property prices are unlikely to stage a rapid rebound, according to CapitaLand's finance chief Andrew Lim. Home prices posted their first decline in six quarters in the last three months of 2018 due to government-imposed property curbs. A 5% increase in home prices would be a good year for the market, but a "big bump up" is not expected anytime soon. CapitaLand's profit rose 71% to S$475.7 million in the quarter ended Dec 31, driven by asset sales and property revaluations.

site_title: Palladium tops US$1,500 as shortages ignite record-breaking rally
summary: Palladium prices surged to a record high of US$1,500.36 an ounce, driven by a global shortage and increasing demand for emissions control materials. The metal has advanced 45% in the past year, with a seventh monthly gain. A global deficit is expected to widen, prompting users to lease material from ETF holders. Analysts question the rally's durability, citing weakening car sales in China and the growing threat of electric vehicles.

images.alt_text: Palladium burst above US$1,500 to hit a record, extending a powerful rally driven by an acute shortage of supply as car manufacturers scramble to get hold of the material to meet stringent emissions controls.

site_title: Malaysia to extradite ex-Goldman banker after local 1MDB cases
summary: Malaysia will extradite former Goldman Sachs banker Roger Ng to the US after he completes local court proceedings. Ng faces additional charges linked to 1MDB, a troubled state fund, and is accused of conspiring to launder $6.5 billion in bond sales. A Malaysian court ruled Ng's extradition pending an order from the home ministry. Ng's case is set for March 18, and prosecutors are seeking his extradition in relation to his role in the 1MDB scandal. The extradition is likely to be delayed due to priority given to Ng's local cases.

site_title: BNP Paribas hiring relationship managers in Asia as it mulls Indonesia push
summary: BNP Paribas is hiring relationship managers in Asia as part of a strategic move to capture assets and growth in the region. The French bank plans to boost assets under management in Asia to $120 billion by 2020, with Indonesia being a key target for onshore private banking operations. This move follows existing domestic wealth operations in India and Taiwan, and offshore services in Singapore and Hong Kong. The bank aims to "be in the tier-one division" and expand its presence in the region.

site_title: iFast Q4 earnings up 46% to S$2.6m
summary: iFast Corporation's fourth-quarter profit surged 46% to S$2.6 million, driven by its Singapore, Hong Kong, and Malaysia operations. Revenue fell 0.7% to S$28.0 million due to rising interest rates and weaker growth in China. The company proposed a 0.9 Singapore cent final dividend, bringing the total FY2018 dividend to 3.15 Singapore cents per share, a 4.7% increase. Full-year net profit rose 41.7% to S$10.9 million, with earnings per share increasing to 4.10 Singapore cents.

site_title: SHS warns of possible default on solar plant project on financing woes
summary: SHS Holdings' 50-megawatt solar power project in Bangladesh is at risk of default and termination due to financing woes. Construction has been delayed, and the company may only recover $3-8 million of the $21.7 million invested. Funding of up to 70% of the project's cost is required, and SHS is exploring alternative financing options. The project's deadline has been pushed back by over a year, and the company is seeking another extension. If a default is triggered, SHS will only recover a fraction of its investment.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Wednesday, STI up 0.4% to 3,273.99
summary: Singapore shares opened higher on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) gaining 0.44% to 3,273.99. The index saw 32.9 million shares worth S$57.9 million change hands, with Thai Beverage being the most actively traded counter. Gainers outnumbered losers 74 to 31, with stocks like Sembcorp Marine, UOL, and CapitaLand also experiencing gains. The rally comes ahead of GDP data and follows a 5-day rally in the market.

site_title: Amid trade talks, China urges US to respect its right to develop, prosper
summary: China's top diplomat, State Councillor Wang Yi, urged the US to respect its right to develop and prosper during trade talks, stating that cooperation is the correct choice for both countries. Wang emphasized that China's development is in the world's interest and that the US should recognize this. China's doors to the outside world will open wider, and the country is committed to reform and opening up to meet its development needs. The US delegation, led by former US national security adviser Stephen Hadley, is negotiating trade deals worth $200 billion, with tariffs set to rise to 25% by March 1 if no agreement is reached.

site_title: Democrats warn Trump may rush nuclear transfer to Saudis
summary: US lawmakers are investigating whether President Trump is rushing to sell sensitive nuclear technology to Saudi Arabia to please corporate supporters, who could profit from the deals. Whistleblowers have warned of conflicts of interest and potential federal criminal statutes. The House Committee on Oversight and Reform has asked the White House to turn over documents related to a meeting between Jared Kushner and Saudi Arabia's Mohammed bin Salman. The committee fears Saudi Arabia could use US nuclear technology to build a bomb, heightening tensions with Iran.

site_title: AI startup ViSenze raises US$20m in Series C funding
summary: ViSenze, an e-commerce AI startup, has raised US$20 million in Series C funding co-led by Gobi Partners and Sonae IM. The funding will help the company expand its partnerships with smartphone manufacturers and consumer apps. ViSenze's AI technology enables visual search and shopping recommendations, with over 400 million products linked to its global affiliate network. The company has a steady annual revenue growth rate of over 200% and has tripled its employee headcount in the last three years.

site_title: Australian wage growth still tepid but private sector catches up
summary: Australian wages grew 0.5% in the fourth quarter, slightly slower than the third quarter, but private sector wage growth surged to 2.5%, the highest in five years. Annual wage growth remained steady at 2.3%, above a recent trough of 1.9%. Private sector wage growth in healthcare, education, and financial services drove the increase. The Reserve Bank of Australia is unlikely to raise interest rates, citing steady wage growth and a slowing property market, with markets predicting a 50% chance of a rate cut later this year.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on Wednesday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Wednesday, supported by gains on Wall Street and optimism over US-China trade talks. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.28% to 21,362.75, while the Topix index gained 0.23%. The positive start follows two days of gains, driven by solid US market performance and traders brushing off new Trump threats.

site_title: Bernie Sanders launches second run for US president
summary: Senator Bernie Sanders has launched his second bid for the US presidency, targeting President Donald Trump as a "racist" and "pathological liar." Sanders, a self-described democratic socialist, aims to run a grassroots campaign with a focus on healthcare for all, raising the minimum wage, and combating climate change. He joins a crowded field of Democratic candidates vying for the nomination to run against Trump in 2020.

site_title: Trump says US-China trade talks 'going very well'
summary: US President Donald Trump stated that trade talks with China are "going very well" despite no deal being reached after the third round of negotiations in Beijing. Trump indicated that the March 1 deadline for raising tariffs could be extended, potentially averting a more significant increase in punitive import tariffs on US$200 billion in Chinese goods. Senior officials are set to hold another round of talks on Thursday and Friday, aiming to achieve "needed structural changes in China" to address US trade concerns.

site_title: BBR warns of 2018 loss
summary: Construction and engineering group BBR Holdings expects to report a net loss for 2018, citing a 31.6% revenue decline to S$90.2 million. The company attributed the slowdown to lower revenue from general construction and specialised engineering, as well as a lack of revenue from property development. BBR reported a net profit of S$3.8 million for the three months ended Sept 30, 2018, with a share of results from joint ventures contributing to the gain. The company will provide further details when announcing its 2018 results.

site_title: Stocks to watch: DBS, SembMarine, CapitaLand, Great Eastern, Mapletree Industrial Trust
summary: DBS Bank is revamping its retail stock-brokerage operations and exploring alternative models for its broking arm DBS Vickers. Sembcorp Marine reported a 94.9% drop in net profit for the fourth quarter due to low business volume and impairment of assets. Meanwhile, CapitaLand, Great Eastern, and Mapletree Industrial Trust are not mentioned as seeing new developments in the article.

site_title: Europe: Shares slip from October highs as banks weigh
summary: European shares declined on Tuesday, with the Stoxx 600 index falling 0.2% after a disappointing update from HSBC and a rally fueled by optimism about a possible Sino-US trade deal. The banking sector was the worst performer, with HSBC dropping 4% and Bank of America Merrill Lynch downgrading its rating for the stock. Autos and mining stocks managed to end slightly up, while Italian banks fell around 1% due to weak industrial data. A new round of US-China trade talks was underway in Washington.

site_title: Alabama newspaper editor under fire after calling for KKK revival
summary: Alabama newspaper editor Goodloe Sutton sparked controversy after publishing an editorial calling for the revival of the Ku Klux Klan. The editorial, which appeared in The Democrat-Reporter, suggested the Klan could be used to counter Democratic plots to raise taxes in Alabama. Alabama Senator Doug Jones called for Sutton's resignation, labeling the editorial "disgusting." Sutton defended his views, stating that the Klan "didn't kill but a few people" and implying they were not violent until necessary. The editorial sparked widespread outrage and calls for Sutton's removal.

images.alt_text: Goodloe Sutton, publisher and editor of The Democrat-Reporter, wrote the editorial that appeared in last week's edition of the weekly newspaper in Linden, Alabama.

site_title: May heads to Brussels for Brexit crisis talks
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May heads to Brussels for Brexit crisis talks, despite EU leaders' refusal to renegotiate the deal she agreed to in December. With five weeks to go until Brexit on March 29, May is seeking legally binding changes to the backstop, a contentious part of the withdrawal agreement. EU leaders have warned that there will be no reopening of the agreement, and economists warn of a chaotic exit that could wreak havoc on both Britain and the EU.

images.alt_text: British Prime Minister Theresa May on Tuesday prepared to head to Brussels for talks on the Brexit crisis, even though EU leaders have refused any renegotiation of the deal she agreed with them in December.

site_title: UK to expand drone no-fly zones near airports next month
summary: The UK government is expanding drone no-fly zones near airports, increasing the distance from 1km to 5km, starting March 13. The move aims to protect airports from malicious drone use, following disruptions at Heathrow and Gatwick airports. The government will also give police powers to stop and search people suspected of using drones maliciously, and access electronic data stored on drones with a warrant. The new zone will better prevent drone-related disruptions, although existing laws already prohibit flying within 1km of an airport boundary and endangering an aircraft with a drone is punishable by up to five years in prison.

site_title: BreadTalk buys out JV partner in Thailand for 160m baht
summary: BreadTalk buys out its joint venture partner in Thailand, The Minor Food Group (MFG), for 160 million baht (S$6.96 million) to acquire the remaining 50% interest in BTM Thailand. The joint venture was established in 2014 to operate BreadTalk outlets in Thailand and expand the brand. BreadTalk now holds 100% interest in BTM Thailand, which has roughly 50 branches in the country.

site_title: Japan's exports fall most in 2 years as Asian shipments weaken
summary: Japan's exports declined 8.4% in January, the largest annual drop in over two years, amid slowing global demand and trade frictions. The decline was driven by a 17.4% drop in exports to China, Japan's largest trading partner, and a 13.1% drop in shipments to Asia. US-bound exports rose 6.8% led by car shipments, while imports from the US rose 7.7% due to increased crude oil imports. The trade surplus with the US narrowed to $4.5 billion.

images.alt_text: Japan's exports posted their biggest decline in more than two years in January, adding to concerns about slowing global demand and trade frictions as business confidence softens and orders for the country's machinery goods fell sharply.

site_title: Redas explains why some cooling measures need to be revised
summary: Singapore's Real Estate Developers' Association (Redas) has called for revisions to the property cooling measures, citing the need for more dialogue between the government and property stakeholders. Redas's new president, Chia Ngiang Hong, suggests revising the timeframe for completing project sales and the remissible additional buyers' stamp duty (ABSD) for developers. The ABSD was increased to 25% last July, which has led to developers exhausting their inventory at the same time, contributing to land price escalation.
