Redas also proposes reviewing the loan-to-value ratio for first-time property purchasers and the timing of the upfront payment of the ABSD for upgraders.

site_title: Great Eastern Q4 profit falls 68% to S$137m on market volatility
summary: Great Eastern reported a 68% fall in Q4 net profit to S$137m due to market volatility. Despite a 5% increase in insurance operating profit, the company incurred a loss of S$45.4m from investments. Total new sales fell 30% and embedded value dropped 7% compared to the previous year. The board proposed a final one-tier tax exempt dividend of 50 Singapore cents per share. CEO Khor Hock Seng attributed the decline to challenging market conditions, but remains positive on long-term growth potential.

site_title: Ford pulls out of South America truck business, closes Brazil plant
summary: Ford is exiting its commercial heavy truck business in South America, closing a Brazilian plant that employs 2,800 workers. The decision, part of a global business redesign, aims to reduce payroll costs and focus on SUVs and pickups. The closure will result in a one-off charge of $460 million, with a worldwide pre-tax cost of $11 billion. Ford will maintain its presence in South America through partnerships, shifting focus from sedans and small cars. The move affects Brazilian President Jair Bolsonaro's pro-business agenda and the regional Metalworkers Union will fight to reverse the decision.

site_title: CapitaLand Q4 profit jumps 71.2% to S$475.7m
summary: CapitaLand reported a 71.2% jump in its Q4 profit to S$475.7 million, driven by better operating performance, asset recycling, and revaluations of its investment properties. Revenue rose 34% to S$1.62 billion, mainly from residential projects in China and Vietnam. The group's full-year net profit increased 12.3% to S$1.76 billion, with an earnings per share of 42.1 cents. CapitaLand plans to acquire Ascendas-Singbridge to create Asia's largest diversified real estate group, aiming for new growth drivers and strengthening its existing business and asset portfolio.

site_title: Brent dips as demand worries weigh, US oil prices hit 2019 high
summary: Oil prices were mixed on Tuesday, with Brent crude slipping 5 cents to $66.45 a barrel, while US crude rose 50 cents to $56.09 a barrel, its highest since November 2018. Concerns about global demand and US-China trade talks countered investor optimism about tightening supplies. Analysts attribute US futures prices to sanctions on oil from Venezuela, which has lifted WTI prices. However, a fresh round of trade talks and economic uncertainty have traders cautious about taking large new positions, with some predicting weaker global oil demand growth.

site_title: Blockchain startup Band Protocol lands US$3m seed funding led by Sequoia India
summary: Blockchain startup Band Protocol has secured $3 million in seed funding led by Sequoia India, marking the venture firm's first investment in Southeast Asia. The funding will be used to accelerate development of the mainnet and go-to-market strategy. Band Protocol aims to create a "token-curated community" where data providers are rewarded with tokens for providing high-quality contributions. The startup plans to target Thailand as its main market and build a web portal, CoinHatcher, to demonstrate its product.

site_title: US: Stocks edge higher after strong Walmart results
summary: US stocks rose slightly on Tuesday, driven by strong Walmart earnings and optimism over US-China trade talks. The Dow Jones Industrial Average gained less than 0.1%, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index advanced 0.2%. US President Donald Trump said negotiations with China are "going very well," but a deal may not be reached by the March 1 deadline. Walmart's fourth-quarter profits surged 70% to $3.7 billion, providing a positive boost to investors.

site_title: Big money is betting on gold miners over gold itself
summary: A growing number of investors, including Bernstein quants, are shifting their focus from gold to gold miners as the global economy slows. Mining shares have gained at nearly twice the pace of gold this year, and have historically outperformed the metal in economic downturns. Analysts see low return outlooks across asset classes, making gold miners an attractive alternative to hold in portfolios. Heavyweight commodity analysts have recommended buying both gold and miners, citing scarcity of safe havens and undervalued assets in the industry.

site_title: SembMarine Q4 net profit sinks 94.9% to S$5.9m on higher cost of sales
summary: SembMarine, an offshore engineering group, reported a 94.9% decline in Q4 net profit to S$5.9 million due to low business volume, asset impairment, and accelerated depreciation. Earnings per share dropped 95% to 0.28 cents. The company opted not to declare dividends, citing a "prudent approach to conserving cash" in a challenging business environment. Shares rose 5.1% following the results announcement.

site_title: Japan central bank chief flags readiness to ease further; yen slips
summary: Japan's central bank chief, Haruhiko Kuroda, signaled readiness to ease monetary policy further if a sharp yen rise hurts the economy and misses its 2% inflation target. Kuroda mentioned possible easing tools, including cutting interest rates or accelerating money printing, but emphasized careful consideration of the benefits and costs. The BOJ faces a dilemma between easing to counter a rising yen and maintaining its accommodative stance, given years of heavy money printing and subdued inflation.

site_title: Trump's threat raises Venezuelan fears - and hopes
summary: US President Donald Trump's threat to Venezuelan military commanders to abandon Nicolas Maduro and allow US aid into the country has raised tensions and hopes among Venezuelans. The threat was met with anger from some on the streets of Caracas, while others welcomed Trump's intervention, seeing it as a potential way out of the country's economic crisis and violent crime. The dispute over aid shipments has also raised tensions at the border, with Venezuelan Defence Minister Vladimir Padrino warning of a potential invasion.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Chasing Cars: Cabrio or coupe?
summary: The Money FM podcast "Chasing Cars: Cabrio or coupe?" discusses the pros and cons of choosing between a convertible and a coupe for a car. The episode likely explores factors such as style, functionality, and practicality. However, no specific conclusions or key findings are mentioned.

site_title: 8M Real Estate buying shophouses worth S$144m
summary: 8M Real Estate has acquired four shophouses in Singapore for S$144 million, with the largest deal valued at S$80 million for a six-unit row on Tanjong Pagar Road. The shophouses have a total built-up area of 30,800 sq ft and a 99-year leasehold tenure. The company plans to refurbish the properties and seek approval to change their use to hotels, with a hospitality management arm to operate the hotel. The acquisitions expand 8M Real Estate's presence along Gemmill Lane and in Holland Village.

site_title: Huawei founder says world can't live without it
summary: Huawei founder Ren Zhengfei stated that the world cannot live without the company's technology, despite US efforts to blacklist it. Ren defended Huawei against espionage concerns, calling them "politically motivated," and expressed confidence in the company's ability to adapt to pressure. The US has charged Huawei with stealing trade secrets and banned its equipment in several countries, including Australia and New Zealand. Ren said the US cannot crush Huawei and that the company will downsize if necessary, but the East will still shine.

site_title: Defence, healthcare, bank stocks expected to gain from Singapore Budget 2019
summary: Singapore's 2019 budget is expected to benefit defence, healthcare, and bank stocks. Defence contractor ST Engineering is seen as a major beneficiary due to increased defence spending and recognition of cyber threats as a sixth pillar of digital defence. Healthcare and grocery stocks may also gain, with DBS, RHB, and CGS-CIMB highlighting these sectors. Meanwhile, tighter foreign-worker restrictions are expected to negatively impact food and beverage players, while the offshore marine sector may benefit from a deferred foreign worker levy hike.

site_title: US airlines to offer non-binary gender options
summary: US airlines will begin offering non-binary gender options, allowing passengers to choose "unspecified" and "undisclosed" alongside traditional male and female options, starting June 1. This shift comes as some US states permit non-binary identities and as a few European countries allow self-identification by gender preference. Airlines such as American Airlines, Southwest Airlines, and Delta Air Lines will implement the change, with the goal of promoting diversity and inclusion for all travelers. The move is seen as a step towards ensuring safe and smooth travel for all passengers, regardless of their gender identity.

site_title: UK wage growth fastest since 2008 amid Brexit fears, slowing economy
summary: UK wage growth reached 3.4% in the last quarter of 2018, the fastest pace since 2008, amid Brexit fears and a slowing economy. Job creation remained strong, with 167,000 new jobs added, despite concerns over the impact of Brexit on businesses. Average weekly earnings excluding bonuses also rose 3.4%, defying a slowdown in the broader economy. The labour market remains buoyant, with unemployment at 4%, but weak productivity growth poses a long-term risk to pay growth and inflation.

images.alt_text: British workers' pay growth maintained its fastest pace in a decade in late 2018 and job creation stayed strong, data showed, suggesting the labour market was buoyant ahead of Brexit as the broader economy slowed.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2019: Fixing mindsets against F&B, retail jobs - not quotas - is key
summary: Singapore's Budget 2019 introduced tighter foreign manpower restrictions for food and beverage (F&B) and retail firms, reducing the foreign worker dependency ratio (DRC) from 40% to 35% by 2021. While firms can leverage technology to adapt, challenges remain, including the need for human interaction in customer service and the difficulty in attracting local workers. Experts warn that further DRC cuts may harm service quality, operating hours, and even lead to business closures. To address these challenges, firms are encouraged to explore digital and productivity solutions, with the government providing extended funding support for Enterprise Development Grants and Productivity Solutions Grants.

site_title: Global car markets are in reverse. Trump is making it worse
summary: The global car market is in reverse, with cooling markets in the US, Europe, and China. The US may impose tariffs of up to 25% on imported vehicles, sparking concerns over national security and retaliatory measures from the European Union and Japan. Carmakers are struggling with falling profits due to record spending on electric and self-driving cars, while trade woes, political upheaval, and diesel's demise hurt consumer sentiment. The global car market is expected to stall this year or grow only 1% as manufacturers face uncertainty over growth in China.

site_title: Corporate venture capital deal share in Asia close to overtaking North America
summary: Global corporate venture capital (CVC) deal activity reached a historic high in 2018, with Asia drawing 38% of all deals, surpassing North America's 41% share. Asia's CVC funding surged 47% to $53 billion, driven by investments in Chinese startups, which grew 51% to $10.8 billion, and Japanese startups, which saw a 56% increase to $1.4 billion. AI deals with CVC participation grew 27% to 291, and digital health investments rose 39% to 192 deals. The number of new CVC firms increased by 35% to 264 in 2018.

site_title: An unnecessary constitutional crisis in Washington
summary: US President Donald Trump declared a national emergency to divert $5.7 billion in border wall funding, bypassing Congress and sparking a constitutional crisis. The move is expected to draw long and costly legal and political battles, despite a previous agreement with Congress for $1.37 billion in border funding. Trump's decision is seen as a test of his constitutional power and a reflection of the lack of national consensus on the need for a border wall, which he claims is a national security threat.

site_title: Britain's supermarkets jostle to stock up as Brexit shadow looms
summary: Britain's supermarkets are stockpiling food in anticipation of potential shortages and price rises if the country leaves the EU without a trade deal. Officials warn that fresh food, particularly produce, may be in short supply due to limited storage space and increased tariffs. Britain imports around half of its food, with most coming through Dover, which could be disrupted by customs checks. Supermarkets are exploring alternative routes and supplies, but executives say contingency planning is complicated due to intense competition and slim margins.

site_title: Pair of Club Street shophouses up for sale at S$25m
summary: A pair of three-storey conservation commercial shophouses at 44 and 46 Club Street in Singapore's Chinatown-Telok Ayer district have been put on sale for S$25 million. The properties, which are 999-year leases, have a combined land area of 221.8 square meters and are expected to attract keen interest from investors due to the upcoming construction of new hotels in the area, injecting vibrancy and increasing tourism footfall. The sale, which closes on March 19, 2019, offers foreigners the opportunity to purchase without additional buyer's stamp duty.

site_title: Shares slump as investor drops plan to buy Procurri stake
summary: Shares of Procurri Corporation plummeted by almost 10% on Tuesday after proposed investor New State Capital Partners withdrew its acquisition offer. The stock closed at S$0.28, down three Singapore cents. New State had proposed to acquire all Procurri shares, except for those held by substantial shareholder Irrucorp, via a scheme of arrangement. The withdrawal follows a termination of further discussions with another interested buyer and DeClout's plan to sell 36.3 million shares to a private equity firm, raising net proceeds of S$12 million.

site_title: Pakistan's PM Khan says his country will respond if India attacks
summary: Pakistan's Prime Minister Imran Khan warned that his country will retaliate if India attacks in response to a recent bombing in the disputed Kashmir region. India blames Pakistan for the bombing, which killed 40 Indian paramilitary police, and has given its security forces a "free hand" to respond. Khan hopes "better sense will prevail" and reiterated that Pakistan had nothing to do with the attack. Pakistan has appealed to the UN for intervention and warned that any Indian attack would undermine the Afghan peace effort.

site_title: It's time to create a global playbook for cybersecurity
summary: The cybersecurity industry is in need of a global playbook to establish digital trust, as external threats and geopolitics pose a significant risk to the sector. A zero-trust approach, which assumes all internal and external activity is malicious, is not feasible for cybersecurity vendors. Instead, a "digital trust" framework, combining cybersecurity, data privacy, and accountability, is necessary. Industry leaders, including Forrester, are calling for global standards and principles to be established, similar to those in the automotive and healthcare sectors. A "Digital Geneva Convention" and the "Paris Call" are examples of initiatives aiming to promote trust and cooperation in the industry, but tangible measures are needed to prove trustworthiness and resilience.

site_title: Boustead Projects' unit wins S$70m deal to build high-tech plant
summary: Boustead Projects' wholly-owned subsidiary, Boustead Projects E&C, has won a contract worth over S$70 million to design and build an integrated advanced high-tech manufacturing facility in Singapore. The facility, expected to be completed by 2020, will expand the client's operations and boost the group's order book backlog to S$741 million. The contract is not expected to have a material impact on the company's current financial year, but will have a positive impact on profitability and earnings per share for the 2020 financial year.

site_title: Trump administration sounds alert as China forges ahead with AI
summary: The Trump administration has launched an artificial intelligence initiative, directing agencies to assess spending, reprioritize funds, and regulate machine-learning applications. The Pentagon's report provides more detail on the plan, which includes opening government data to researchers and the private sector. The US needs to increase AI investment in defense, particularly in areas like autonomous vehicles, and address concerns about ethics and transparency. China is investing heavily in AI, with estimates of tens of billions of dollars, prompting calls for the US to catch up and ensure responsible use of the technology.

site_title: China relaxes solar subsidy programme that rattled global market
summary: China's regulators have proposed easing a major solar subsidy policy, which would partially reverse rules that undercut demand in the world's biggest solar market. The move aims to help capacity installations rebound from last year's slump. China is expected to allocate about 3 billion yuan in fixed subsidies for solar in 2019, and capacity additions are forecast to rise from 35 gigawatts to 42-50 gigawatts, benefiting solar companies.

site_title: Tencent-backed plastic surgery app SoYoung files for IPO in the US
summary: SoYoung, a Chinese cosmetic surgery website backed by Tencent Holdings, has filed confidentially for a US initial public offering (IPO), aiming to raise around $300 million. The company, founded in 2013, allows customers to review and book procedures through its app and websites. This would be the latest in a string of Chinese companies going public in the US, following a $32 billion surge in first-time share sales over the last 12 months. Final terms of the deal have not been set yet and could change depending on investor demand.

site_title: WTO warns of global slowdown as indicator hits 9-year low
summary: The World Trade Organization (WTO) warned of a global slowdown due to a 9-year low reading of its quarterly trade indicator, which fell to 96.3 in the latest quarter. This is the weakest reading since March 2010, signaling below-trend growth in trade. The WTO attributes this to sustained trade tensions, political risks, and financial volatility. The organization previously forecast a slowdown in global trade growth to 3.7% in 2019, and a steeper slowdown or rebound may occur depending on policy steps. The indicator's decline highlights the urgency of reducing trade tensions.

site_title: Honda to shut major UK production plant, shedding 3,500 jobs
summary: Honda will shut its major UK production plant in Swindon, England, putting 3,500 jobs at risk, due to "unprecedented changes in the global automotive industry" and Brexit uncertainty. The plant, which produces 150,000 units of the "Civic" model annually, will close in 2021. The decision, made by Honda president Takahiro Hachigo, comes as the company scales back operations in Britain amid investment uncertainty. The move is part of a broader trend of Japanese firms reducing operations in the UK ahead of Brexit.

site_title: Deeper downturn may merit delay in rate hikes, says ECB economist
summary: European Central Bank (ECB) chief economist Peter Praet suggests that the bank may delay interest rate hikes if the euro-area economy slows down further, citing a potential shift in language to adapt to a deeper downturn. Praet's comments follow similar warnings from other officials, including French economist Francois Villeroy de Galhau. Traders expect the first 10-basis-point interest-rate hike until June 2020, but Praet's remarks indicate that the ECB may reassess its plans. The slowdown has triggered a rally in bond markets, with German 10-year bunds threatening to go negative for the first time since 2016.

site_title: UOB's mobile-only bank tests data as TMRW's currency
summary: UOB has launched its mobile-only bank, TMRW, targeting millennials in Thailand as part of its efforts to test a new digital banking concept. The bank aims to leverage data to create a new currency, analyzing transactional data to provide personalized insights and nudging customers to save and invest wisely. UOB has partnered with fintech firms Personetics and Meniga to clean and tag transactional data, with the goal of reaching three to five million customers in Asean within the next five years. This move reflects a broader trend of banks embracing data-driven services to remain competitive in the market.

site_title: Budget 2019: Building a stronger, more united Singapore
summary: Singapore's Budget 2019 aims to strengthen the country's core enterprises and support local talent, while addressing bread-and-butter issues such as healthcare and cost of living. The budget leverages emerging startups, medium enterprises, and partnerships to propel Singapore to new heights. It also extends successful programs, sharpens initiatives, and phases in measures to support businesses. The government commits to investing alongside the private sector to support deserving enterprises, aiming to be among the global best in technology, innovation, and enterprise. The budget charts Singapore's desire to be the Global-Asia Node.

site_title: DBS group plans major revamp of DBS Vickers
summary: DBS Bank is revamping its retail stock-brokerage operations, exploring alternative models for its broking arm, DBS Vickers, to provide customers with more holistic services. The bank has no plans to shut down DBS Vickers, but is working on different business models to deliver a stronger customer proposition with minimal employee impact. This move comes after the bank unified its banking and broking services in 2013, allowing customers to trade online and access a team of equities specialists.

site_title: Volkswagen tries to play catch-up on driverless tech
summary: Volkswagen is investing $4 billion in Argo AI, a US-based automated car company, at a valuation of $4 billion. The deal is seen as a necessary step for the German automaker to play catch-up in the autonomous driving technology market, where General Motors' Cruise and Alphabet's Waymo have a lead. Despite the lower valuation, the investment could help Volkswagen secure key technology and talent, and the company may consider a joint venture with Ford.

site_title: Man or machine: Who's really driving your portfolio?
summary: Artificial intelligence (AI) is being explored for its potential to replace human portfolio managers, but experts believe Intelligence Augmentation (IA) is a more relevant area of science for the asset management industry. IA uses AI to help humans make decisions, rather than making decisions for them. While AI systems have achieved success in games, they struggle in real-world settings due to complexity and incorrect outputs. The conditions required for AI to be effective, such as a constant environment and abundant data, are rarely met in fundamental investing. IA, on the other hand, has a strong track record and can enhance human intelligence in areas like data analysis and insight extraction.

site_title: Bernie Sanders, from gadfly to serious White House contender
summary: Bernie Sanders, a 77-year-old US Senator from Vermont, announced his candidacy for the 2020 presidential election, challenging President Donald Trump. Sanders, who ran in 2016 and came close to the Democratic nomination, has maintained his anti-Wall Street and progressive policies. Despite criticism over his age, Sanders claims he's focused on defeating Trump and won't run if someone else can do it better. Sanders' campaign is seen as a revival of his 2016 insurgency, with his policies gaining traction among young liberals and Democrats.

site_title: Taiwan's Tsai Ing-wen to seek re-election in 2020 presidential race
summary: Taiwan's President Tsai Ing-wen has confirmed she will seek re-election in 2020 despite falling ratings and strained relations with China. Tsai, 62, won a landslide victory in 2016, but her popularity has waned due to domestic policies and a backlash from conservatives. She faces opposition from the ruling KMT party and several of its heavyweights, including former mayor Eric Chu, who lost to her in 2016. Tsai remains confident in her re-election prospects, citing her ability to complete her agenda and defend Taiwan's democratic freedoms.

site_title: Facebook's AI chief researching new class of semiconductor
summary: Facebook's AI chief Yann LeCun suggests the company is working on a new breed of semiconductor that can mimic the brain in processing vast amounts of data. This new chip design would allow for more efficient data manipulation, unlike existing computer chips that divide data into batches. Intel Corp and Facebook are collaborating on the new chip, which aims to power artificial intelligence applications. The move follows Alphabet Inc's Google's creation of a Tensor Processing Unit chip, and Facebook's hiring of a hardware team to build its own AI-specific chips.

site_title: Japanese business mood worsens in Feb
summary: Japanese business sentiment worsened in February, with manufacturers' mood sliding for a fourth straight month and service-sector morale falling for the first time in four months. The sentiment index for manufacturers fell to 13 from 18, and the service-sector index dropped to 22 from 31. This decline is attributed to weakening demand, slowing global growth, and trade friction, particularly the US-China trade war. The worsening business sentiment poses risks to Japan's economy, which is expected to continue slipping further over the coming months, with the central bank's tankan survey due in April.

images.alt_text: Shoppers at Japanese discount retailer Don Quijote's store in Tokyo. Fragile consumer spending could be a source of concern for policymakers who want to go ahead with the sales tax hike in October.

site_title: Karl Lagerfeld, Chanel's designer for decades, dies
summary: Karl Lagerfeld, the renowned German fashion designer and creative director of Chanel for over 35 years, has died at the age of 85. A prolific designer, Lagerfeld was known for his iconic style, which featured high-collared shirts, white ponytails, and black fingerless gloves. He helped revive Chanel's ready-to-wear lines and became one of the most successful designers in the industry, dressing celebrities such as Princess Diana and Nicole Kidman. Lagerfeld's legacy as a fashion icon and his uncompromising approach to his work have cemented his place in the fashion world.

site_title: WeDoctor considers listing a spinoff on new tech board
summary: WeDoctor, a Chinese online healthcare startup, is considering listing a spinoff of its cloud-services arm on China's new technology board. The division handles sensitive data for local governments and hospitals, and Beijing prefers to keep it in-country. The spinoff, which could be valued at US$5.5 billion, would join the first batch of companies on the tech bourse, which aims to help innovative enterprises secure capital domestically. The move is part of WeDoctor's broader restructuring efforts to address a bottlenecked Chinese healthcare market.

site_title: US: Wall St opens lower as US-China trade talks resume
summary: US stocks opened lower on Tuesday, following a strong rally last week, amid ongoing US-China trade talks. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.13%, the S&P 500 dropped 0.23%, and the Nasdaq Composite declined 0.29%. Investors are cautious despite the talks resuming, with market uncertainty lingering due to ongoing trade tensions.

site_title: Who votes for the Oscars, and how it works
summary: The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences, comprising 7,902 industry professionals, selects Oscars winners through a complex process. Members in 17 branches vote for nominees, and the best picture award uses a preferential ballot system to ensure a winner that most people can live with. The system involves instant-runoff voting, eliminating the lowest-ranked film until one with over 50% of the vote is chosen. This process aims to reflect the wishes of the greatest number of voters, rather than a single favorite.

site_title: FAA probes Southwest over baggage weight discrepancies
summary: The US Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) is investigating Southwest Airlines Co for a year-long failure to accurately track the combined weight of checked bags, resulting in potential discrepancies when pilots compute takeoff weights. Systemic mistakes in employee calculations and luggage-loading practices led to discrepancies ranging from a few dozen kilograms to over 450 kg in excess of paperwork. Southwest has implemented controls to address weight and balance programme concerns and shared these measures with the FAA, but the agency has not decided whether to impose fines or punishment.

site_title: Alarm bells go off as Blackmores' China business takes a beating
summary: Blackmores Ltd, an Australian vitamin maker, issued a surprise profit warning due to soft consumer demand in China, citing a general softening of consumer sentiment. The company's sales to China sank over 10% in the six months to December, leading to a 24% drop in its shares, the largest percentage decline since listing in 1985. The Chinese slowdown, coupled with a crippling Sino-US trade war, is affecting global supply and demand trends, with other companies, such as Apple, also warning of weaker demand in China.

site_title: A balancing act: Japan's relations with China, Taiwan
summary: China's President Xi Jinping urged reunification with Taiwan by force if necessary, amid concerns of a potential invasion. Taiwan's President Tsai Ing-wen appealed to the international community for help, including a proposed US Congress address. Taiwan has strengthened ties with the US and Japan, which has acknowledged Taiwan's existence and equality. Japan's improved relationship with China may impact its bonds with Taiwan, but Japan will need to balance its relationship with China, which is rapidly rising in military power and economy.

site_title: Abu Dhabi's oil giant gets region's top credit rating from Fitch
summary: Abu Dhabi's oil giant, Abu Dhabi National Oil Co (Adnoc), has received a top credit rating of AA long-term from Fitch Ratings, making it the region's highest-rated company. The rating reflects Adnoc's strong financial performance, comparable to international oil majors like Total SA and Royal Dutch Shell Plc. The company's long-term rating is in line with the governments of Abu Dhabi and Kuwait, and its standalone ranking is AA+. Adnoc plans to raise new funds from its businesses and pursue international investors, but has no plans to issue a bond at the group level.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Natural Cool Holdings acquired two snack manufacturing businesses for S$980,000. M1 accepted an offer to sell its 28.7% stake for S$548.1 million, resulting in a gain of RM126.5 million. Kingsmen Creatives posted a net profit of S$8.15 million, down 16.3% from last year. Hotel Royal acquired Royale Chulan Bukit Bintang Hotel for S$65 million.

site_title: Malaysia to end bauxite mining ban despite pollution fears
summary: Malaysia is set to lift its three-year ban on bauxite mining on March 31, despite environmental concerns. The decision allows mining to resume with strict conditions, with the goal of generating extra revenue for the central state of Pahang. Critics warn that the move will lead to pollution and environmental damage, citing the release of carcinogenic heavy metals and low levels of radiation. The ban was initially imposed due to complaints about the landscape, water pollution, and health issues.

site_title: Nojima won't revise offer price for Courts Asia
summary: Nojima Asia Pacific has reaffirmed its offer price of S$0.205 per share for Singapore-listed Courts Asia, despite KPMG's assessment that the offer is "not fair but reasonable". The offeror will not revise the offer price, and the final closing date is March 15, 2019. KPMG advised shareholders to accept the offer unless they can obtain a higher price on the open market, citing a 45% discount to net asset value and a low price-to-book multiple. The offeror has received nearly three-quarters of valid acceptances, making the offer unconditional.

images.alt_text: Independent financial adviser KPMG Corporate Finance last week said that Nojima's offer price is 'not fair but reasonable'.

site_title: Tiny South Africa beach restaurant crowned world's best
summary: A tiny beach restaurant in South Africa's Paternoster village, Wolfgat, has been crowned the world's best restaurant by the inaugural World Restaurant Awards. Chef Kobus van der Merwe's sustainable, locally-foraged cuisine won over judges with its seven-course tasting menu and emphasis on hyper-local flavors. The restaurant, which opened just two years ago, costs the equivalent of $81.50 per person and has no formal training staff. Van der Merwe's win is seen as a victory for African cuisine and a challenge to the traditional dominance of French and European restaurants in the culinary world.

site_title: Concern rises over more bonds being rated as junk
summary: Concerns over junk-rated bonds are rising in Asia as worsening global macro-economic conditions put firms under pressure. The US-China trade war and slowdown jitters are prompting worries about weaker companies faltering. At least eight Asian companies' bonds were cut from investment grade to junk last year, with more expected to follow. Borrowers on the brink include India's state-owned Power Finance Corp and REC Ltd, and Indian chemical giant UPL Ltd's bonds are also at risk of becoming non-investment grade. Experts warn of a "bubble" in BBB level debt and rising fallen angel risks.

site_title: Swedish krona tumbles on weak inflation, Italy woes hit euro
summary: The Swedish krona plummeted over 1% to a two-year low against the dollar after weak inflation data prompted investors to sell the currency and scale back bets on interest rate hikes in 2019. The euro also fell after poor Italian industrial orders and European economic weakness weighed on the currency. European Central Bank policymakers are expected to slash growth and inflation projections at their March 7 meeting, further weakening the euro.

site_title: South Korea's Moon offers to resume cooperation with North Korea to help denuclearization
summary: South Korean President Moon Jae-in offered to resume cooperation with North Korea to aid in denuclearization, stating South Korea will open economic engagement as a "concession" if it speeds up Pyongyang's nuclear disarmament. This comes ahead of US President Donald Trump's meeting with North Korean leader Kim Jong Un in Vietnam next week. Moon's office said he expressed willingness to undertake various economic projects, including reconnecting rail and road links, to hasten denuclearization and a lasting peace on the peninsula.

site_title: Israel becoming political bombshell in Washington
summary: The US support for Israel has created a rift within the Democratic Party, with some members questioning the Jewish state's democratic credentials and policies towards Palestinians. This shift is partly driven by changing attitudes among critical demographic groups, including African Americans, Hispanics, and young progressive Democrats, who view Israel as a state dominated by white Europeans controlling a repressed Third World people. In contrast, the Republican Party has emerged as a bastion of support for Israel, with President Trump taking steps to consolidate ties with the Jewish state.

site_title: M'sia nears deal with China to revive scrapped rail project
summary: Malaysia is nearing a deal with China to revive the scrapped East Coast Rail Link project, with China willing to reduce the US$20 billion price tag. Foreign Minister Saifuddin Abdullah said talks are "in the last mile" and discussions aim to reach a smaller project size and cost. The project was initially cancelled by Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad's government due to cost constraints, but recent signs suggest Malaysia wants to ease tensions with China. The deal would be a significant move for the two countries, following a period of strained relations under Mahathir's government.

site_title: Market quiet as investors stay on sidelines
summary: The Singapore market experienced a quiet day on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) closing 0.2% lower at 3,259.80 due to profit-taking. Investors took advantage of mixed earnings and a tepid economic outlook, with the most traded stock being Ezion Holdings. The market is expected to heat up with upcoming events, including the release of Fed minutes and US-China trade negotiations. Analysts also noted that the Singapore Budget may have a long-term impact on healthcare stocks, but not in the short term.

site_title: AusGroup in A$11.8m deal to house marine workers on Australian island
summary: AUSGROUP Ltd has signed a deal worth A$11.8 million (S$11.4 million) to purchase an accommodation area on Melville Island in Australia's Northern Territory, housing marine industry staff. The deal includes a 119-man camp, kitchen, and recreational facilities, and is part of AusGroup's long-term corporate strategy to explore strategic options, including acquisitions and divestment. The acquisition is expected to improve the company's financial performance and position, subject to approval from the financier and other parties by May 15, 2019.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2019: Much ado about economic restructuring, whither the results?
summary: Singapore's Budget 2019 focused on economic restructuring amidst a weakening economy, with support measures for businesses and workers. The government announced new schemes to help firms and workers, including those to build "deep" capabilities, scale up, and adopt digital tech. However, critics argue that these measures may not be substantial enough, particularly in supporting small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) and addressing the country's growing dependence on foreign workers. The government also increased spending on healthcare for an aging population and introduced tax rebates for citizens.

site_title: Danske Bank's watchdog gets drawn deeper into European probe
summary: The Financial Supervisory Authority in Denmark has been placed under formal investigation by European authorities regarding Danske Bank's money laundering scandal. The investigation follows Danske's admission of $230 billion in suspicious transactions and criminal investigations in the US. The European Banking Authority has two months to complete its investigation, which will draw a final conclusion on the actions taken by Danske's supervisors. The Danish regulator has been criticized for its handling of the scandal, with some questioning its impartiality due to former officials' ties to the bank.

site_title: EU can pull off 'impossible' Brexit compromise: ex-chief
summary: Former European Commission president Jose Manuel Barroso says Britain and the EU can reach a Brexit compromise, citing past last-minute agreements. He believes there is still room for negotiation and that Brussels will agree to an extension if asked. Barroso also praised the EU's ability to find compromises that seem impossible, citing past crises such as the Greek financial collapse.

site_title: MIT announces issue price of S$1.9434 per unit for new units under distribution reinvestment plan
summary: MIT announces the issue price of new units under its distribution reinvestment plan at S$1.9434 per unit, a 2% discount to the adjusted volume-weighted average traded price. The new units, totaling 103.4 million, will be issued on Feb 20 and are not entitled to the advanced distribution. Unitholders will receive a notice of election on Feb 27.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2019 puts some tax breaks out to pasture
summary: The Singapore Budget 2019 has allowed several tax incentive schemes to lapse, including a property tax boon for tourism projects, the designated unit trust and approved unit trust schemes for investors, and the "not ordinarily resident" (NOR) scheme for high-skilled foreigners. Analysts say the impact of these changes is likely to be mitigated by alternative schemes, with the possible exception of the NOR scheme, which may affect local and foreign workers. The removal of these schemes aims to enhance the progressivity and resilience of Singapore's tax system.

images.alt_text: The tweaks, said Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat in his Budget speech, are aimed at "further enhancing the progressivity and resilience of our tax system".

site_title: BHP CEO staying around to deal with tailings and transformation
summary: BHP CEO Andrew Mackenzie, 62, has no plans to quit, focusing on ensuring the company's "nuclear level of safety" for tailings dams following the Vale dam collapse in Brazil. Mackenzie will also lead the company's transformation agenda to drive growth and productivity. The move comes after speculation about his future since 2017, when activist investor Elliott Advisors began campaigning for change. BHP reported a 8% decline in first-half underlying profit, citing production outages. Mackenzie emphasized the importance of mining companies providing resources and supporting a low-carbon economy.

site_title: Companies moving out as Brexit looms
summary: Several major companies, including Honda, Nissan, Jaguar Land Rover, Philips, and Schaeffler, are downsizing or relocating operations in the UK due to Brexit uncertainty. Companies like Bank of America and HSBC plan to reduce activities in London, while others like Goldman Sachs and Citigroup are eyeing Frankfurt. The European Medicines Agency, European Banking Authority, and Galileo satnav monitoring base are also relocating to other EU countries. This shift is expected to impact thousands of jobs and has raised concerns about the UK's financial sector and economy.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close higher on hope for US-China trade row
summary: Tokyo stocks rose on Tuesday as investors expect a US-China trade deal, with the Nikkei 225 index gaining 0.10% to close at 21,302.65. Top-level officials from the US and China will reconvene in Washington after productive negotiations in Beijing. Bargain-hunting and dollar-yen exchange rate fluctuations also supported the market. Shares for Honda and Sony rose, while Nintendo and Komatsu fell.

site_title: Piracy in Asia on the decline, for now
summary: Piracy incidents in Asia decreased by 73% in January 2019 compared to the same month last year, with no reported crew abductions or ship hijackings. However, the International Maritime Bureau reports a significant rise in piracy in West Africa, with a marked increase in attacks against ships and crews. Nine crew members remain captive in the Sulu-Celebes Seas and waters off Eastern Sabah, with the Philippine authorities conducting pursuit operations to rescue them.

site_title: UK's Brexit blues with Beijing, Tokyo tarnish close ties
summary: UK officials face diplomatic challenges after reportedly taking a "high-handed" approach with Japan and angering China with Defence Secretary Gavin Williamson's speech, which threatened to deploy an aircraft carrier in the Pacific. Chancellor Philip Hammond's cancelled trip to Beijing also highlights the delicate balancing act the UK is engaged in with its post-Brexit diplomacy. The UK's desire to consolidate ties with China, particularly in economics, is seen as crucial, but security and human rights issues will continue to prick Beijing, with the UK government under domestic and international scrutiny on these issues.

site_title: India exempts small firms from angel tax to promote business
summary: India has exempted small firms with annual turnovers up to 1 billion rupees (S$18.9 million) from the "angel tax" on funds raised, aiming to boost investments and jobs. The exemption applies to ventures registered with the Department for Promotion of Industry and Internal Trade, with a raised investment limit to 250 million rupees. The move is seen as a relief for small companies, with 90% of their concerns addressed, and could benefit 16,000 registered companies employing nearly 300,000 employees.

site_title: TalkMed Group Q4 net profit up 16.4% to S$9.59m
summary: TalkMed Group reported a net profit of S$9.59 million for Q4 2018, a 16.4% increase from the previous year, driven by higher revenue and lower losses from an associate company. Revenue rose 25.2% to S$18.96 million, mainly due to increased patient visits. The company faces pressure on revenue due to lower medical costs in neighboring countries and its dependence on the economic performance of Singapore and Southeast Asia.

site_title: Oil slips from 2019 high as economy worries weigh
summary: Oil prices fell to a 2019 high of nearly US$67 a barrel on Tuesday, slipping 64 cents to US$65.86 a barrel, amid concerns about the US-China trade talks and slowing economic growth. Supply cuts led by Opec have helped crude rise over 20% this year, but demand-side worries remain a major drag on the market. The US and China are set to discuss their trade dispute on Tuesday, and traders are cautious about taking large new positions. Opec's forecast for global oil demand growth in 2019 has been lowered to 1.24 million barrels per day.

site_title: Hedge fund operator plans US$1 billion India-focused ESG fund
summary: AVENDUS Capital has launched a US$1 billion India-focused ESG fund, one of the country's first to base investment decisions on environmental, social, and governance parameters. The fund aims to raise 70% of its money from overseas investors and will invest in no more than 25 companies. The move comes as corporate India struggles with governance issues, and investor concerns about ESG are growing. The fund's launch is seen as a response to the increasing awareness of ESG issues in India, driven by factors such as climate change and work-related issues.

site_title: Midas probe can't be rushed as deals took place overseas
summary: A probe into irregularities at Midas Holdings requires more time due to jurisdiction-related complexities. The Securities Investors Association (Singapore) urged shareholders to be patient and allow for due process. The investigation was triggered in March 2018 after Midas lodged a police report on possible breaches of securities laws and other offences in China. The probe's complexity and need for more time were confirmed in a meeting between Sias and Singapore authorities. Sias calls for the board and management of Midas to assist the investigation process and communicate with shareholders periodically.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: DBS Group Holdings maintained a buy rating with a target price of S$29.00, expecting a 5.3% loan expansion in 2019 and a 5 basis point rise in net interest margin to 1.9%. The bank conservatively guides for S$200 million in net trading income per quarter. Mapletree Industrial Trust (MIT) maintained a hold rating after receiving in-principle approval for a S$201 million private placement exercise, trimming distribution forecasts by 1.2% and 2.9% for fiscal 2019 and 2020, respectively.

site_title: China Gaoxian requests for extension to meet SGX rules to exit watch-list
summary: China Gaoxian Fibre Fabric Holdings has submitted an application to the Singapore Exchange (SGX) for a 12-month extension to meet requirements to exit the watch-list. The company, which was placed on the watch-list in 2016, needs to record consolidated pre-tax profit and maintain a minimum market capitalization of S$40 million over six months. If approved, the extension would delay the deadline to March 2, 2020, instead of March 2, 2019.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 13.82 points to 1,706.56 on Tuesday, driven by a volume of 2.8 billion lots worth RM2.4 billion. Gainers beat losers 517 to 385.

site_title: Germany, France take aim at EU anti-trust rules in new industrial strategy
summary: Germany and France have agreed on a strategy to create European industrial "champions" by revising EU anti-trust rules to allow national authorities to override decisions made by Brussels in certain cases. The move comes after the EU vetoed an Alstom-Siemens rail merger, and the two countries aim to create a more competitive European industry by investing in innovations and protecting homegrown technology. The strategy also includes cooperation in producing electric batteries and calls for reciprocity in public projects to create a global level playing field.

site_title: China's Fosun makes bid for German fashion chain Tom Tailor
summary: Chinese conglomerate Fosun International has made a takeover bid for German fashion chain Tom Tailor, increasing its stake to 35.35% and triggering a mandatory takeover offer under German law. Tom Tailor's shares surged 14% after the announcement, with Fosun offering a price of 2.26 euros per share, valuing the company at 96 million euros. The bid is part of Fosun's expansion into Europe's retail sector, following previous acquisitions of Lanvin and Wolford.

site_title: Honda UK plant closure 'devastating': minister
summary: Honda UK's Swindon plant closure will result in the loss of 3,500 jobs, with the factory set to shut in 2021. Britain's Business Secretary Greg Clark described the decision as "devastating" and vowed to convene a taskforce to retain the workforce's skills and expertise. The closure is attributed to unprecedented global market changes and is the latest in a series of downsizing operations by Japanese firms in Britain as Brexit looms.

site_title: Fashion designer Karl Lagerfeld dead: Chanel
summary: Karl Lagerfeld, the 85-year-old German fashion designer and artistic director of Chanel, Fendi, and his eponymous line, died on Tuesday. A month prior, he missed his Paris haute couture week show for Chanel, sparking speculation about his health. Lagerfeld, known as the "Kaiser," was a dominant figure in the fashion industry, contributing to Paris's status as a fashion capital and Fendi's innovation. Tributes poured in from politicians, fans, and celebrities, with Bernard Arnault, LVMH owner, calling him a "creative genius" and "very dear friend."

site_title: Adjoining three-storey Club Street commercial shophouses up for sale
summary: A pair of adjoining three-storey conservation commercial shophouses at 44 and 46 Club Street in Singapore's Chinatown-Telok Ayer area have been put up for sale. The 999-year shophouses have a combined land area of 221.8 square metres and total floor area of 6,208 sq ft. They will be sold with existing tenancy for S$25 million, with no additional buyer's stamp duty required for foreigners. The properties are expected to benefit from increased tourism footfall due to new hotel construction in the area, making it an "exceptional investment opportunity".

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks ended lower on Tuesday, with the Hang Seng Index slipping 0.42% to 28,228.13. Investors await the resumption of US-China trade talks later in the day. In contrast, the Shanghai Composite Index edged up 0.05%, while the Shenzhen Composite Index rose 0.18%. Global markets, including Singapore and Europe, saw mixed performances.

site_title: Bernie Sanders to seek US presidency again in 2020
summary: US Senator Bernie Sanders, 77, has announced his candidacy for the 2020 Democratic presidential nomination, vowing to build a grassroots movement to confront special interests and push for universal healthcare, raising the minimum wage, and free public college tuition. This marks his second presidential bid, following a 2016 campaign that generated tension within the party. Sanders faces stiff competition from other liberal progressives, including fellow Senators Cory Booker and Elizabeth Warren, and may struggle to generate the same level of fervent support as four years ago.

images.alt_text: US Senator Bernie Sanders, the progressive populist who mounted a fierce challenge to front-runner Hillary Clinton in the 2016 White House campaign, said on Tuesday he will again seek the Democratic Party's presidential nomination in 2020.

site_title: Silverpush raises US$5m in series B funding led by FreakOut
summary: SilverPush, an India-based marketing technology platform, has raised US$5 million in series B funding led by FreakOut Holdings. The company uses artificial intelligence to improve engagement between brands and consumers. With the new funding, SilverPush aims to expand globally and enhance its AI capabilities, targeting new markets in the Asia Pacific and over-the-top space. The company expects its global business to contribute over 50% of revenue and reach an annual target of US$25 million over the next two years.

site_title: MVL partners OrangeTee & Tie to allow property agents to book rides from Agent App
summary: MVL Foundation, the company behind blockchain-based ride-hailing app TADA, has partnered with OrangeTee & Tie to allow property agents to book rides directly from their Agent App. The integration is expected to be completed by Q3 this year. Agents can now book rides for themselves or clients, providing a convenient experience for customers and agents alike. The partnership aims to expand TADA's reach and provide agents with an additional opportunity to receive ride bookings.

site_title: Kingsmen Creatives FY18 net profit falls 16.3% to S$8.15m
summary: Kingsmen Creatives, a Singapore-based communication design and production group, reported a net profit of S$8.15 million for FY18, down 16.3% from the previous year. Revenue rose 17.5% to S$360.9 million, driven by growth in the exhibitions & thematic division and research & design division. The group has secured contracts worth S$103 million and expects S$87 million to be recognized in FY2019. Despite the decline in net profit, the group remains optimistic about the growing trend of experiential services and plans to expand into branded attractions and focus on active play, edutainment, and live events.

site_title: Singapore Medical Group Q4 net profit up 17.2% to S$2.94m
summary: Singapore Medical Group reported a 17.2% increase in Q4 net profit to S$2.94 million, driven by higher revenue growth of 18.1% to S$22.19 million. The group's full-year net profit jumped 52.1% to S$12.93 million, with earnings per share rising to 0.61 Singapore cent. CEO Beng Teck Liang plans to grow key specialist verticals and explore accretive acquisition opportunities to accelerate growth and profit. No dividend was declared for the quarter.

site_title: Global corporate venture capital deal activity reaches record high in 2018: report
summary: Global corporate venture capital deal activity reached a record high in 2018, with Asia attracting 38% of all deals, surpassing North America's 41%. Global CVC funding surged 47% to $53 billion, driven by a 51% increase in Chinese startup funding and a 56% increase in Japanese startup funding. AI deals with CVC participation grew 27% and funding increased 19% to $5.1 billion, with Asia accounting for 42% of AI deals.

site_title: Hotel Royal buys Royale Chulan Bukit Bintang Hotel for 197m ringgit
summary: Hotel Royal Limited has acquired Royale Chulan Bukit Bintang Hotel in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia for 197 million ringgit. The 4-star hotel has 400 suites and rooms on freehold land, with an audited net book value of 91.7 million ringgit. The acquisition is expected to expand Hotel Royal's operations in Kuala Lumpur, with potential for capital appreciation in the future. The deal will be financed by internal resources and bank borrowings, with a deposit paid upon signing of the agreement and the balance upon completion.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets slip at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets fell at the start of trading on Tuesday, with London's FTSE 100 index down 0.2% to 7,204.42 points, and Frankfurt's DAX 30 index down 0.2% to 11,280.73 points. The Paris CAC 40 index lost 0.1% to 5,162.31 points, amid a mixed Asian session where investors remained cautiously optimistic about the US-China trade war deal. The lack of catalysts in the European market contributed to the decline.

site_title: UK's Greggs says vegan sausage roll a hit, guides higher on profit
summary: UK bakery chain Greggs reported a 14% rise in sales for the first seven weeks of 2019, driven by strong demand for its new vegan sausage roll. This growth is expected to lead to a higher-than-expected pretax profit for the full-year, with the company guiding to an average of £88.6 million. Like-for-like sales in company-managed shops rose 9.6% in the period, and total sales grew 14.1%. The positive outlook comes after Greggs had previously nudged up its 2018 profit forecast.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks end weaker as foreigners sell on trade woes
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index closed 0.24% lower on Tuesday as foreigners sold shares amid uncertainty over trade talks between Beijing and Washington. The Korean won and bond yields declined, with foreigners net selling 7.23 billion won worth of shares. The US and China will hold new talks in Washington on Tuesday, despite some optimism over the outcome.

site_title: Goldman's Asia-Pacific CEO Ken Hitchner to retire: sources
summary: Goldman Sachs' Asia-Pacific CEO Ken Hitchner is retiring after nearly three decades with the firm. Hitchner, who joined Goldman in 1991, will continue in his Hong Kong-based role until mid-2019. He has advised major clients, including Johnson & Johnson, and will be succeeded by Todd Leland and James Paradise, who will remain Goldman's most senior executives in the region.

site_title: BreadTalk Group Q4 net profit soars 82.5% to S$8.88m
summary: BreadTalk Group posted a net profit of S$8.88 million for Q4, up 82.5% from the previous year. Revenue increased 3.1% to S$154.77 million, while earnings per share rose to 1.58 Singapore cents. This marks a significant improvement from the restated net profit of S$4.87 million in the same quarter last year.

site_title: No revision to offer price for Courts Asia, closing date on March 15: Nojima
summary: Nojima Asia-Pacific, the offeror for Singapore-listed Courts Asia, has reaffirmed its offer price of S$0.205 per share without any revision. The final closing time and date for the offer will be 5.30 pm on March 15, 2019, as per Rule 20.2 of the Takeover Code. Despite KPMG's advice that the offer price is "not fair" but reasonable, the offeror has no intention of extending the offer beyond the final closing date. Courts Asia shares ended flat at S$0.20 on the same day.

site_title: New Universe map unearths 300,000 more galaxies
summary: A new universe map, created using the Low Frequency Array (LOFAR) telescope, has revealed 300,000 previously unknown galaxies, expanding the known universe. The map, which charts 2% of the sky, was created by an international team of over 200 astronomers from 18 countries. The discovery sheds new light on the physics of black holes and how galaxies evolve, allowing scientists to better understand the behavior of these enigmatic phenomena. The findings also provide a new window into the universe's deepest secrets, including the formation and development of black holes.

site_title: Lower 2019 forecast for Thailand GDP
summary: Citi Research lowers 2019 and 2020 GDP forecasts for Thailand to 3.8 and 3.8, respectively, citing increased risks to exports and slower-than-expected investment growth. Despite stable domestic demand and tourism, prolonged export weakness is expected to impact related services and income growth. The Bank of Thailand is expected to hold off further policy rate hikes until 2020, following a hawkish monetary policy committee vote in February. Thailand's Q4 GDP came in at 3.7% year-on-year, driven by stronger-than-expected private consumption and private investment.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2019: Breakdown of revenue and expenditure estimates
summary: Singapore's 2019 budget reveals a primary deficit of S$5.36 billion, with total expenditure reaching S$80.25 billion and net investment income at S$17.17 billion. Healthcare saw the largest increase in allocations, while corporate income tax contributed the most to revenue growth. The government also allocated S$6.1 billion to the Merdeka Generation Package Fund and S$5.08 billion to the Long-Term Care Support Fund. The budget deficit is attributed to increased spending in healthcare and infrastructure, despite a 1.7% growth in operating revenue.

site_title: Singapore shares end 0.2% lower on Tuesday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index ended 0.2% lower on Tuesday, closing at 3,259.80, after muted trading with investors seeking direction. The index had spent the session above Monday's closing of 3,265.97. Trading volume was 1.12 billion securities worth S$775.9 million. Losers outnumbered gainers 218 to 172.

site_title: REDAS' new chief calls on government to refine property curbs, engage more with stakeholders
summary: REDAS' new president Chia Ngiang Hong called for the government to refine property curbs and engage more with stakeholders. He suggested flexibility in the timeframe for selling out projects to address the remissible additional buyers' stamp duty (ABSD) for developers. Chia also proposed re-evaluating the loan-to-value ratio for first-time property purchasers and reviewing the upfront payment of the ABSD for upgraders. He emphasized the need for open communication between the government and stakeholders to create a more robust policymaking process.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Tuesday afternoon at 3,267.53, up 0.1% on day
summary: Singapore stocks resumed trading on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index up 1.56 points to 3,267.53, a 0.1% gain. About 564.6 million securities worth S$354.6 million changed hands, with losers outnumbering gainers 179 to 130. Key movers included Genting Singapore, ThaiBev, and Yangzijiang Shipbuilding. DBS Group Holdings was flat after releasing its full-year earnings, while Procurri Corporation slumped after a proposed acquisition was withdrawn.

images.alt_text: SINGAPORE shares resumed trading on Tuesday afternoon on higher ground, with the Straits Times Index up 1.56 points or 0.1 per cent to 3,267.53 as at 1.07pm.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat's budget speech emphasized defence and a smart nation, benefiting defence contractor ST Engineering and banks DBS, RHB, and CGS-CIMB. REDAS' new president called for review of property curbs, while a Midas probe into jurisdiction-related complexities is ongoing. Boustead Projects won an S$70m contract to design and build a manufacturing facility, and three-storey commercial shophouses in Singapore's Club Street are up for sale. The Straits Times Index closed 0.2% lower at 3,259.80.

site_title: A troubling link for South Asians
summary: A study of over 900 South Asians in the US has found that despite following healthy diets and exercising regularly, they are at a higher risk of developing heart disease due to their South Asian ancestry. South Asians have four times the risk of heart disease compared to the general population, and develop the disease up to a decade earlier. Researchers have identified that South Asians tend to store body fat in areas where it shouldn't be, leading to metabolic damage, and that using a standard BMI cutoff to screen for diabetes would overlook up to a third of South Asians who have the disease.

site_title: Ahead of Saudi visit, China seeks "deeper trust" with Iran
summary: China seeks to deepen "strategic trust" with Iran ahead of Saudi Arabia's crown prince visit, amidst China's balancing act in the Middle East. Chinese State Councillor Wang Yi expressed interest in strengthening ties with Iran, a move that could potentially ease tensions with Saudi Arabia. Iran values its relationship with China, considering it one of its most important relations. The visit comes as China has traditionally played a limited role in Middle East conflicts, but is trying to raise its profile in the Arab world.

site_title: Australia shares rise as financial stocks gain; NZ down
summary: Australian shares rose 0.3% to 6,106.90, driven by gains in financial stocks, particularly the "Big Four" banks, which rose between 1% and 2.3%. This offset losses in the mining and healthcare sectors. Australia and New Zealand Banking rose 2% after pledging to lend more to investors. In contrast, New Zealand's benchmark index fell 0.23%.

site_title: ECB could change rate guidance if outlook worsens, says chief economist
summary: The European Central Bank's chief economist, Peter Praet, has signaled that the ECB could change its interest rate guidance if the euro-area economy slows more sharply. Praet mentioned that policymakers could adapt their forward guidance and implement other measures if necessary. This comes amid concerns over the economic slowdown, with France's Francois Villeroy de Galhau also suggesting a change in wording. The ECB's policy is set with medium-term prospects in mind, but Praet warned that political uncertainty, particularly related to protectionism and Brexit, is a major constraint on growth.

site_title: The Japanese spice blend taking over America
summary: Shichimi togarashi, a Japanese spice blend, is gaining popularity in the US, with chefs incorporating it into various dishes beyond traditional ramen and noodle soups. The blend, which combines seven ingredients including dried red chile, sesame seeds, and seaweed, is believed to have originated from Chinese herbal medicine. Chefs praise the blend for its unique flavor profile and versatility, using it to enhance seafood, salads, and even deviled eggs. As global spices trend continues, shichimi togarashi is set to become a staple in fine-dining kitchens, with many restaurants now featuring the spice blend on their menus.

site_title: HSBC 2018 profit rises 16%, lags estimates
summary: HSBC Holdings reported a 15.9% increase in 2018 profit to US$19.9 billion, beating the previous year's US$17.2 billion but falling short of an average estimate of US$22 billion. The bank avoided tax writedowns that affected its results last year and maintained its dividend at US$0.51 per share. Asia's key market saw earnings growth, contributing to the bank's improved performance.

site_title: Speculation swirls over Kim's travel plans for Hanoi summit
summary: North Korean leader Kim Jong Un's travel plans for his upcoming summit with US President Donald Trump in Hanoi have sparked speculation. A North Korean delegation visited a Vietnamese city on a popular train route from China, fueling rumors that Kim may travel by rail or road. The nearly 4,000-kilometer journey could take up to 60 hours, but concerns over disruptions to China's high-speed rail network may deter Kim from taking the train. Alternatively, he may travel by rail to Beijing and then fly to Hanoi. The summit is set for February 27-28 in Hanoi.

site_title: China state utility, independent gas firm jointly build east China pipeline: report
summary: Chinese state utility Huadian Group and independent gas firm Guanghui Group have started laying a 171km natural gas pipeline in east China's Jiangsu province. The Qitong pipeline, which has a 4 billion cubic metre annual transport capacity, is expected to be operational by the end of October 2019 and will be linked to the West-to-East gas pipeline project. The project, costing 1.259 billion yuan, aims to provide natural gas to industrial users in the region.

site_title: Cuban cigars hit record sales thanks to increasing Chinese demand
summary: Cuban cigar sales reached a record $537 million in 2018, driven by a 55% increase in Chinese demand, surpassing France as the second-largest market. Despite global tobacco laws and the US embargo, Habanos, a partially state-owned company, reported a 7% growth. The company attributed the success to China's lack of anti-tobacco laws, which allowed for increased sales. This growth contrasts with the global luxury tobacco market, which grew only 1% in 2018.

site_title: New round of US-China trade talks begins on Tuesday
summary: US-China trade talks begin in Washington on Tuesday, following a Beijing round that generated progress on contentious issues. The talks aim to achieve structural changes in China affecting US-China trade and discuss China's pledge to purchase US goods and services. The White House statement emphasized the need for these changes to resolve the ongoing trade war.

site_title: UBS's 5.3b euro gamble in France tax case: deal or no deal?
summary: UBS has refused to settle a French tax investigation, risking a court-ordered fine of up to 5.3 billion euros. The Swiss lender's decision exposes it to in-court demands from the state and prosecutors, which could result in a hefty fine if convicted. The outcome of the case will set a precedent for multinationals under investigation in France, with Paris lawyers suggesting a conviction could make settlements more attractive for other companies. The verdict comes after UBS twice attempted to settle the case in the past, but ultimately decided to go to court.

site_title: Malaysia to end bauxite mining ban despite environment fears
summary: Malaysia is set to lift its three-year ban on bauxite mining on March 31, despite environmental concerns. The ban was imposed due to complaints of landscape blight, water pollution, and health issues. The move is expected to allow the mining of 432,000 tonnes of high-grade bauxite, stored at Kuantan port, and generate crucial revenue for the state of Pahang. Critics warn that the lifting of the ban will lead to pollution and harm local communities, while the government maintains that strict mining conditions will be enforced to mitigate environmental damage.

site_title: Russian arrests of foreign businessmen shocks Western investors
summary: Russian authorities arrested prominent US and French investors on suspicion of fraud, sparking fears of cutbacks in foreign investment. Michael Calvey, the founder of Baring Vostok private equity firm, was placed in pre-trial detention for alleged defrauding a Russian bank of $51.2 million. The arrests took place during a major economic forum in Sochi, contradicting Russia's openness to investment. Business leaders and economists expressed concerns, citing the lack of independent courts and corruption, which could damage Russia's investment climate and attract negative international attention.

site_title: The hot new market for luxury property is Vietnam
summary: Vietnam has emerged as a hot new market for luxury property, driven by the country's rapid economic growth and increasing demand from both domestic and international investors. The Grand Manhattan, a 39-story development in Ho Chi Minh City, is one of several high-end projects being built by the country's largest property companies, including Novaland Group, which has amassed a fortune of around $800 million. Luxury condominium prices in the city have risen 17% in 2018 to an average of $5,518 per square meter, and are expected to climb further in the coming years.

site_title: Britain does not support total Huawei network ban: sources
summary: Britain's National Cyber Security Council (NCSC) does not support a full ban on Huawei from national telecoms networks, despite US allegations of Chinese espionage. The council believes Huawei can manage risks by testing products at a special laboratory. The decision is consistent with public statements and comes as fellow Five Eyes member Australia has banned Huawei from supplying 5G equipment. The UK's government review of telecoms infrastructure is expected later this year, which will include recommendations on managing security risks.

site_title: Australia's Oil Search banks on 2020 sign-off for major expansion
summary: Australia's Oil Search is confident its partners ExxonMobil and Total will sign off on major projects in 2020, doubling PNG LNG exports. The projects, worth around $13 billion, will increase output to 16 million tonnes a year. The company's CEO, Peter Botten, attributes the delay to the 2018 earthquake in Papua New Guinea, which affected negotiations and sensitivities. Oil Search reported a 13% rise in annual profit, despite a loss of output after the quake, and raised its full-year dividend.

site_title: Mongolia suspends KFC outlets after hundreds show food poisoning symptoms
summary: Mongolia has suspended all KFC outlets in the country after 247 people reported food poisoning symptoms, including 42 hospitalizations, following an incident at a Ulaanbaatar restaurant. The Metropolitan Professional Inspection Agency attributed the cause to poor internal hygiene checks, specifically a contaminated water supply where bacteria had bred. The suspension is temporary, pending further inquiry.

site_title: Hot stock: Shares of Procurri slump as investor drops plan to buy Procurri stake
summary: Procurri Corporation's shares plummeted 6.45% to S$0.29 after investor New State Capital Partners withdrew its acquisition offer, citing a termination of further discussions with another interested buyer. The deal would have seen New State acquire Procurri's shares via a scheme of arrangement. Meanwhile, major shareholder DeClout announced plans to sell 36.3 million shares to a private equity fund, further reducing its stake in the company.

site_title: China relaxes its solar subsidy programme that rattled market
summary: China has relaxed its solar subsidy programme, partially reversing a policy change that had undercut demand and depressed prices globally. The move, announced by the National Energy Administration, allows utility-scale projects to receive subsidies again, with developers bidding for government aid. The changes are expected to boost installed capacity, potentially rising from 44 gigawatts last year to 42-50 gigawatts in 2019. The policy shift is seen as a positive for solar companies, with Citigroup estimating a gain in capacity additions and benefiting companies such as Xinyi Solar Holdings Ltd. and LONGi Green Energy Technology Co.

site_title: Chinese frozen food firm recalls products suspected of African swine fever contamination
summary: Chinese frozen food firm Sanquan has recalled products suspected of African swine fever contamination, following media reports that some of its dumplings tested positive for the virus. The company, one of China's top dumpling brands, cited reports of contamination in three batches of pork dumplings and is cooperating with local authorities on an investigation. The recall comes amid a rapidly spreading epidemic of African swine fever across China, which has reached 25 provinces and regions, and may further hit pork consumption in the country.

site_title: Indonesia central bank to hold key rate: poll
summary: Indonesia's central bank, Bank Indonesia, is expected to keep interest rates on hold at 6% as analysts believe the Federal Reserve's caution on further rate hikes has reduced the need for aggressive monetary tightening. The rupiah has strengthened this year due to the Fed's change in tone, and a rate cut could boost economic growth ahead of Indonesia's presidential election. However, BI officials have maintained that the current interest rate is near its peak, and economists predict more tightening rather than easing due to global economic pressures.

site_title: Natural Cool to move into F&B in S$980,000 deal for snacks business
summary: Natural Cool Holdings, an air-conditioning company, is acquiring two snack manufacturing businesses for S$980,000 in a cash deal. The acquisition, via a new 80% subsidiary, SFB Holdings, will allow Natural Cool to expand into the food and beverage industry. The deal includes Yummy YM, which makes cooked-food snacks, and SFB Global, which produces soft drinks, bread, and other products. The acquisition is expected to be completed by May 18, 2019, and will provide Natural Cool with a new source of revenue and profit.

site_title: Christie's tip off leads to conviction of global money launderer
summary: A tip from Christie's auction house led to the conviction of Kazeem Akinwale, a 43-year-old London man, of fraud and possessing criminal property. Akinwale controlled bank accounts processing over $10.6 million and took commissions of $73,000. Authorities received the tip in March 2016 after hackers tried to imitate an employee's email address to divert a customer's payment. Akinwale's arrest disrupted many organized crime networks, according to the UK's National Crime Agency. He used alias Ola Gapiano and had a laptop and cellphones seized with references to laundering fraudulent cash.

site_title: Analysts see winners in defence, healthcare, banks from Singapore Budget 2019
summary: Singapore's 2019 budget has analysts optimistic about defence contractor ST Engineering, with a "buy" call from several firms. Defence spending is expected to boost the company, while changes to foreign-worker policies may benefit banks and grocery stocks. The offshore marine sector may also see gains due to a deferral of foreign worker levy hikes. Meanwhile, taxi company ComfortDelGro Corp is expected to pass on savings from a reduction in the Special Tax on diesel taxis to drivers.

images.alt_text: Defence, healthcare and grocery stocks are the possible winners from the latest Singapore Budget announced on Monday, according to a number of broking analysts.

site_title: US FAA investigates Southwest over baggage weight discrepancies - WSJ
summary: The US Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) is investigating Southwest Airlines for widespread failure to accurately track the combined weight of checked bags, resulting in potential safety consequences. The FAA's year-long civil probe found significant mistakes in employee calculations and luggage-loading practices, leading to discrepancies in takeoff weights. The airline has implemented controls to address concerns and shared measures with the FAA, but the agency has not decided whether to impose fines or punishment. The investigation is ongoing, with the FAA citing systemic and significant mistakes, but has not yet decided on enforcement action.

site_title: Exercise may cut depression risk
summary: A new study published in JAMA Psychiatry found that engaging in physical activity, such as jogging or walking, for at least 15 minutes a day may help prevent depression. The study used Mendelian randomization, a statistical analysis technique, to establish a link between exercise and depression risk. Researchers analyzed data from over 400,000 people and found that those with genetic variants associated with physical activity were less likely to develop depression, while those without these variants were more likely to experience depression. The study suggests that exercise can help protect against depression, regardless of genetic makeup.

site_title: US millennials a popular but elusive target for brands
summary: US millennials, aged 17-35, are a coveted target for brands, but companies risk missing out by treating them as a homogeneous group.
