With 75 million millennials in the US, they exhibit significant diversity in values, spending habits, and demographics. Companies like Capital One and Nike have found success by tailoring their marketing to specific segments, such as "wanters" and "needers," and focusing on what matters most to consumers, rather than relying on stereotypes. By eliminating demographic approaches and focusing on individual needs, companies can create more effective messaging and build stronger relationships with millennials.

site_title: Asia: Markets extend gains on cautious trade optimism
summary: Asian markets extended gains on Tuesday, with Shanghai, Hong Kong, and Sydney rising due to cautious optimism about China-US trade talks. Top officials from the two economies will reconvene in Washington this week, despite a lack of concrete results from previous negotiations. Analysts warn that a deal is unlikely, potentially leading to a sharp unwind in markets. Oil prices remained mixed, with Saudi Arabia reportedly willing to reach $80 a barrel. The pound fell amid uncertainty over Brexit.

site_title: Sixteen states sue Trump over border wall emergency
summary: Sixteen US states, including California, Colorado, and New York, sued President Trump's administration over his national emergency declaration to fund a southern border wall with Mexico. The lawsuit claims the move violates the Constitution's Presentment Clause and Appropriations Clause, which define legislative procedures and public funds. The states risk losing funds for military projects and disaster assistance if the emergency declaration is upheld. The complaint seeks an injunction and says the declaration establishes a "constitutional crisis" and sets a "dangerous precedent" for executive overreach.

site_title: Midas probe needs more time due to jurisdiction-related complexities, authorities tell Sias
summary: The probe into Midas Holdings' irregularities in China's operations requires more time due to jurisdiction-related complexities, according to the Securities Investors Association (Sias). The investigation, triggered in March 2018, is being led by the Commercial Affairs Department (CAD) and Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS). Sias urges shareholders to be patient and calls on Midas' board and management to facilitate the investigation process and communicate updates. The complexities of gathering evidence across a foreign jurisdiction add to the time required for investigations.

site_title: Australia dollar unsettled as RBA cites significant risks
summary: The Australian dollar fell to US$0.7121 after the Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) cited significant risks to the housing market and economic outlook, potentially leading to a rate cut. The RBA minutes showed uncertainties over interest rate hikes, with a 70% probability of a quarter-point easing by year-end. The New Zealand dollar remained steady at US$0.6848. The RBA also expressed concerns over a global slowdown, including China's economy and heightened trade tensions.

site_title: New Zealand says China's Huawei hasn't been ruled out of 5G
summary: New Zealand's government is considering allowing China's Huawei to develop the nation's 5G network, despite concerns over national security risks. The country's spy agency had previously blocked Huawei equipment, but Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern said the decision is still pending and that Spark, a telecommunications company, needs to mitigate the concerns. This decision comes amid strained relations between New Zealand and China, with economic implications at stake, as the two countries have a significant trade and tourism relationship.

site_title: Singapore shares rise at Tuesday's open; STI up 0.07% to 3,268.23
summary: Singapore stocks opened stronger on Tuesday, advancing 0.07% to 3,268.23. Gainers outnumbered losers 50 to 43, with Sembcorp Marine leading the gainers. The Straits Times Index also rose 2.26 points. Active index stocks included DBS Group Holdings and Jardine Cycle & Carriage, with DBS Group Holdings up 0.1% and Jardine Cycle & Carriage down 0.1%.

site_title: Malaysia shares open higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened higher on Tuesday, rising 1.58 points to 1,694.32. The market saw 67.79 million lots traded worth RM16.65 million, with 85 gainers and 51 losers.

site_title: Young Russians seek health, highs in ice swimming
summary: Young Russians, known as "Walruses," are embracing ice swimming as a way to improve their physical and mental health. They take dips in frozen rivers and lakes, often staying in the water for just a few minutes, to boost immunity, prevent cellulite, and experience euphoria. While some health experts warn of potential dangers, the practice is also associated with mental benefits, such as a sense of cleansing and joy. The "Walruses of the Capital" club, led by trainer Natalya Seraya, trains swimmers for international competitions and promotes the practice as a way to toughen up against the cold Russian winters.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower in thin trade after US holiday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Tuesday, with the Nikkei 225 index down 0.12% and the Topix index lower by 0.10%. Investors took a wait-and-see attitude after a US holiday, with no fresh clues for trading.

site_title: Japan business mood sours, tough year seen ahead: Reuters Tankan
summary: Japan's business sentiment worsened in February, with manufacturers' mood sliding for a fourth straight month and service-sector morale falling for the first time in four months, according to the Reuters Tankan poll. The sentiment index for manufacturers fell to 13, its weakest reading since October 2016, while the service-sector index dropped to 22. Companies cited weakening demand, trade friction, and a planned nationwide sales tax hike as concerns. The outlook is expected to worsen over the coming months, putting pressure on Japan's economy, which is the world's third-largest.

site_title: Huawei founder says Huawei CFO arrest was politically motivated: BBC
summary: Huawei founder Ren Zhengfei claims the arrest of his CFO, Meng Wanzhou, was politically motivated by the US. Meng was charged with violating American sanctions against Iran, but the US Justice Department denies the charges were politically motivated. Ren asserts Huawei will "never undertake" spying activities and could downsize if the US tries to restrict its business. He also threatens to shift investments from the US to the UK if US actions against Huawei continue, despite the UK's security officials not supporting a full ban on Huawei.

site_title: Sixteen US states sue Trump over border wall emergency
summary: Sixteen US states sued President Donald Trump's administration over his national emergency declaration to fund a southern border wall with Mexico. The lawsuit claims the move violates the constitution's Presentment Clause and Appropriations Clause, giving Congress the final say over public funds. The states argue the president's decision is contrary to legislative procedures. The lawsuit was filed in a federal court in California on Monday.

site_title: Chinese traders halt Australian coal orders as customs delays pile up: sources
summary: Chinese coal traders have halted Australian coal orders due to customs delays in China, which have doubled to at least 40 days, affecting major buyers and international coal merchants. The delays have led to a sharp fall in Australian coal prices, with spot cargo prices for thermal coal exports falling by over a quarter. The restrictions seem targeted at Australia, with Chinese demand for Indonesian and Russian coal rising to make up for the shortfall.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Procurri, Nordic Group, Sasseur Reit, Vibrant Group, Natural Cool
summary: Stocks to watch: Procurri Corporation's proposed investor withdrawal, Nordic Group's reduced fourth-quarter net profit, Sasseur Reit's higher-than-expected fourth-quarter distribution, Vibrant Group's sale of its subsidiary, and Natural Cool Holdings' acquisition of two snack manufacturing businesses.

site_title: Australian grocer Coles declares war on costs after H1 profit drop
summary: Coles Group Ltd, Australia's second-largest grocery chain, reported a 14% drop in half-year net profit to A$738 million due to rising costs outpacing sales growth. The company cited a "strategic refresh" and said it would address unsustainable costs, including labor and energy expenses. Shares fell 3% after the announcement, despite a 3%% same-store sales increase driven by a successful promotion. Coles will review its strategy and provide further details in June.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks inch up in opening trade
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose slightly in the first trading session of Tuesday, driven by anticipation of progress in China-US trade talks. The Hang Seng Index increased 0.07%, while the Shanghai Composite Index added 0.19%. The Shenzhen Composite Index also rose 0.44%. The slight gains come as investors await news on the trade talks, which have been a major market influence.

site_title: Fiscal planning: matching funding with project type
summary: Singapore's Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat announced a dual approach to funding new investments, borrowing for big-ticket infrastructure projects and tapping recurrent revenue for social and security undertakings. Analysts see this as a prudent stance, enabling the financial burden to be shared across generations. The government will also implement a carbon tax and launch a Zero Waste Masterplan to combat climate change. This approach is seen as a fairer way of funding long-term projects, rather than relying on borrowing for recurrent expenditures.

site_title: Nordic Group flags 'substantially lower' Q4 profit
summary: Nordic Group reported "substantially lower" net profit for its fourth quarter due to declining profit margins, higher staff-related expenses, and one-off costs for system integration division. The company expects a lower net profit compared to the same period last year. Full-year results for fiscal 2018 remain profitable, and the company will announce its fourth-quarter results on February 22.

site_title: Huawei's founder says world can't live without it
summary: Huawei's founder, Ren Zhengfei, has defiantly stated that the world cannot live without the company's technology, citing its "more advanced" offerings. He responded to US efforts to blacklist Huawei, which has faced increasing pressure over espionage concerns and security issues. Ren dismissed the US campaign, saying "if the lights go out in the West, the East will still shine." Despite US charges of stealing trade secrets and bans in several countries, Ren expressed confidence in the company's resilience and ability to adapt.

images.alt_text: The founder of Chinese telecom giant Huawei has hit back at US efforts to blacklist the company, saying defiantly that the world cannot do without Huawei and its "more advanced" technology.

site_title: British lawmakers call on government to put an end to throwaway fashion
summary: British lawmakers recommend that fashion brands pay a penny per garment to fund better clothing waste collection, following an eight-month inquiry that highlighted the UK's high clothing waste and environmental impact. The country generates the most clothing waste per person in Europe, with 300,000 tonnes sent to landfill or incinerators annually. The proposal aims to address the issue and promote more sustainable fashion practices.

site_title: EU's Juncker expects Trump to refrain from imposing higher tariffs on cars
summary: US President Donald Trump has promised European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker that he won't impose additional import tariffs on European cars for now. A confidential US Commerce Department report is expected to recommend tariffs of up to 25% on imported autos and auto parts, but Trump's promise is seen as a commitment to avoid such tariffs. If imposed, the EU would react swiftly and potentially renege on its promise to buy more US soybeans and liquefied gas. The report's contents remain classified until Trump considers its recommendations.

site_title: Best World requests trading halt; shares fall 17% in early session
summary: Best World International, a Singapore-based skincare maker and distributor, requested a trading halt due to an announcement, with its shares falling 17% in the early session. The company's shares had soared 171% over the past 12 months, driven by strong growth in China. Analysts have questioned the accuracy of tracking the company's sales in China, citing challenges in reconciling upfront sales figures with underlying consumer demand. The Singapore Exchange had previously queried the company for unusual trading activity.

site_title: UK manufacturers warn of "catastrophic" no-deal Brexit
summary: UK manufacturers warn of a "catastrophic" no-deal Brexit, citing the country's "selfish" politicians and chaotic parliamentary proceedings. Honda is expected to shut its main UK plant, affecting 3,500 jobs, while Nissan cancelled its X-Trail production plans due to Brexit uncertainty. The Make UK association's chair, Judith Hackitt, says politicians prioritizing ideology over national interest and people's livelihoods. With the UK parliament rejecting the transition deal, time is running out to avoid a no-deal Brexit on March 29, which would lead to customs checks on British exports.

site_title: Trump tells Venezuela military to back Guaido or 'lose everything'
summary: US President Donald Trump urged Venezuela's military to support opposition leader Juan Guaido or face "losing everything" amid a humanitarian crisis. Guaido has called for the delivery of desperately needed aid, which Maduro's government has refused to allow. Trump warned that supporting Maduro would lead to "no safe harbour, no easy exit, and no way out." Guaido has set a target of 1 million volunteers to help bring in the aid, with 600,000 already registered. The humanitarian aid standoff is set to come to a head this weekend.

images.alt_text: US President Donald Trump urged Venezuela's military on Monday to accept opposition leader Juan Guaido's amnesty offer, or stand to "lose everything," as a crisis deepened over President Nicolas Maduro's refusal to let in desperately needed humanitarian aid.

site_title: Procurri loses another potential buyer as New State withdraws offer
summary: Procurri Corporation's proposed acquisition by New State Capital Partners has been withdrawn after a letter of intent was pulled back without explanation. This follows a termination of discussions with another interested buyer and comes as major shareholder DeClout plans to sell 36.3 million shares to a private equity firm, further reducing its stake in the company. Procurri's shares last traded at S$0.31 on February 15.

site_title: Honda to close UK plant in 2022, risking 3,500 jobs: reports
summary: Honda is expected to close its UK plant in 2022, putting 3,500 jobs at risk. The carmaker will retain its European headquarters in Bracknell. The decision is not attributed to Brexit, according to local MP Justin Tomlinson. This move follows other carmakers like Nissan and Ford warning of potential job losses due to the UK's departure from the EU.

site_title: Tiny South Africa beach restaurant crowned best in world
summary: A tiny beach restaurant in South Africa, Wolfgat, has been named the best in the world by the World Restaurant Awards. Chef Kobus van der Merwe, who forages daily for ingredients and makes his own bread and butter, won the award for his sustainable and locally-sourced cuisine. The restaurant, which can feed only 20 people at a time, costs a fraction of what top Parisian restaurants charge, with a seven-course tasting menu costing around $81.50. Wolfgat also won the prize for best "Off-Map Destination".

images.alt_text: Wolfgat chef Kobus van der Merwe's belief in sustainable, back-to-basics cooking won over the judges of the inaugural World Restaurant Awards in the French capital.

site_title: Boustead Projects unit wins over S$70m contract to design and build manufacturing facility
summary: Boustead Projects' subsidiary has won a contract worth over S$70 million to design and build an integrated advanced high-tech manufacturing facility in Singapore. The facility will have a gross floor area of approximately 36,300 square meters and is expected to be completed by the second quarter of 2020. This contract brings the group's order book backlog to approximately S$741 million, with no material impact on its current financial year's profitability and earnings per share. The contract is expected to have a positive material impact on the group's profitability and earnings per share for the financial year ending March 31, 2020.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2019: Foreign workers quota cut for services sector
summary: Singapore's Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat announced a surprise move to tighten foreign workforce quotas for the services sector, reducing the dependency ratio ceiling (DRC) to 38% by 2020 and 35% by 2021. The goal is to encourage companies to revamp work processes, reskill workers, and enhance the complementarities of local and foreign workers. The move comes as growth in S Pass and Work Permit holders in the services sector has been rising, and companies will be required to adjust their workforce to meet the new limits.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Coffee with Claressa: Singapore is building an electric motorcycle
summary: Singapore-based company ESG is developing an electric motorcycle through its subsidiary EST. The company aims to join the sustainable mobility movement. ESG CEO Melvin Goh and EST COO Joel Chang discussed the project in a podcast. The development of the electric motorcycle is part of ESG's efforts to contribute to a more environmentally friendly transportation sector.

site_title: Singaporeans are loving the luxury homes that foreigners cannot buy
summary: Singapore's luxury Good Class Bungalows (GCBs) remain in high demand despite restrictions on foreign buyers, with prices reaching record highs. Only locals or citizens can own these exclusive, architect-designed homes with expansive gardens and high-end amenities. Recent deals include a record-breaking S$105.3 million sale of a bungalow near the Botanic Gardens, with prices expected to rise further due to scarcity and exclusivity. The GCB market has proven resilient despite a broader cooling of the property market, and is considered a coveted trophy asset for the wealthy community.

site_title: LVMH vows new standards for crocodile farms
summary: LVMH, the world's largest luxury goods retailer, has announced new standards for crocodile farms to ensure responsible supply of crocodile skins. The company will follow criteria developed by technical experts, prioritizing species preservation, local community respect, animal well-being, and environmental protection. Three certified farms in Singapore have already met these standards, with 20 farms in Australia, Africa, and Asia to be certified by the end of 2020. This move aims to address criticism from animal defence group PETA, who previously raised concerns over treatment of crocodiles and ostriches bred for the fashion industry.

site_title: Top advisor to Canada PM Trudeau resigns amid controversy
summary: Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau's top advisor, Gerry Butts, resigned amid allegations of political interference in the SNC-Lavalin case. Butts denied accusations of applying undue pressure on former attorney general Jody Wilson-Raybould for an out-of-court settlement. Butts cited the need to avoid distractions for the government facing another election in eight months as the reason for his resignation. This move comes after Wilson-Raybould was fired and charged with perjury for refusing to drop the charges against SNC-Lavalin. Butts' resignation is seen as a significant development in the ongoing controversy surrounding Trudeau's government.

site_title: Russia's RT fumes after Facebook blocks 'wildly popular' page
summary: Facebook has blocked the popular "In the Now" page, run by Russian state TV channel RT, citing an information policy on the origin of content. The page, which had 2.5 billion views and 4 million subscribers, was accused of being financed by the Russian state in a CNN report, leading to its immediate blocking. RT editor-in-chief Margarita Simonyan denied violating any Facebook rules, saying the move was an attack on media rights. The move comes amid Facebook's efforts to improve transparency on Pages with large audiences.

site_title: Europe: Stocks hold onto four-month highs on trade talks hopes
summary: European stocks remained at four-month highs on Monday, driven by hopes of progress in US-China trade talks. The Stoxx 600 closed 0.2% higher, with gains from French car parts maker Faurecia and UK-listed Reckitt Benckiser. Chipmaker AMS also rose 3.5% after diversifying efforts. However, the autos sector fell 0.3% and casino shares declined 2.5% after a downgrade. Analysts have cut their earnings growth estimates for 2019, citing macroeconomic data disappointments.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2019: Simplifying schemes for SMEs a key focus - industry watchers
summary: Singapore's Budget 2019 introduced measures to simplify schemes for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), aiming to deepen capabilities and scale up businesses. The government will streamline existing financial schemes into a single Enterprise Financing Scheme, reducing administrative costs and improving access to funding. The budget also announced a one-stop portal for businesses to transact with authorities and increased support for digitalization and internationalization. However, critics argue that the initiatives may not be substantial enough to address the cost issue facing SMEs, particularly with expected interest rate increases this year.

site_title: Ireland expresses 'frustration' at Brexit deal delay
summary: Ireland's deputy prime minister Simon Coveney expressed frustration at Britain's continued failure to ratify a Brexit deal, with less than 40 days to go until the UK formally leaves the EU. Coveney emphasized the need for a guarantee on no hard border between Ireland and the UK, citing concerns over hundreds of millions of euros spent preparing for a no-deal Brexit. EU leaders consider the proposed deal a non-starter, and Britain's Prime Minister Theresa May is seeking rewording to secure a deal past the British parliament.

site_title: 'Kissing sailor' in iconic New York picture dies age 95
summary: George Mendonsa, the sailor in the iconic 'Kissing Sailor' photo taken in Times Square after World War II, has died at age 95. He fell at an assisted living facility in Rhode Island and had a seizure. The photo, taken by Alfred Eisenstaedt in 1945, was confirmed to be of Mendonsa using facial recognition technology. Mendonsa had previously claimed the photo was of him, but it was only recently confirmed. Greta Zimmer Friedman, the woman in the photo, died in 2016 at age 92.

site_title: A Budget to bring some cheer, and to secure Singapore
summary: The Singapore Budget 2019 focuses on long-term efforts to build and grow the nation, rather than offering one-off goodies. Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat prioritized prudence and restraint, investing $4.6 billion over three years in initiatives to enhance the economy, workforce, and society. This includes schemes to support small and medium-sized enterprises, professional conversion programs for workers, and measures to build a caring and inclusive society. The government has also maintained a significant defense budget, with plans to spend 30% of total expenditure on defense, security, and diplomacy.

site_title: Eurozone unease spikes as the single currency turns 20
summary: The eurozone is experiencing increased unease ahead of Spain's general election on April 28, which could exacerbate existing economic and political instability in the region. The country's ruling Socialist Party has a fragile legislative position, with only 84 MPs, and faces opposition from a growing number of new parties, including a far-right nationalist party. This instability is mirrored in other large eurozone economies, including Germany, France, and Italy, where stagnating growth and political pressure are contributing to a looming economic downturn. The uncertainty also raises concerns about the impact of a potential no-deal Brexit on the continent.

site_title: Singapore Budget doubles down on restructuring
summary: Singapore's Budget 2019 doubles down on economic restructuring, targeting a long-term imperative, unveiling the Merdeka Gen Package, and tackling defence and security concerns. The budget allocates $4.6 billion over three years to support firms and workers, with a focus on workforce growth and restructuring. Measures include a lowered foreign worker dependency ratio ceiling, new schemes for firms and workers, and a $100 million SME Co-Investment Fund. The government also sets aside $6.1 billion for the Merdeka Generation Package and $2 billion for a Long-Term Care Support Fund.

site_title: The Affluent Society revisited
summary: Harvard economist John Kenneth Galbraith's 1958 book "The Affluent Society" remains influential in predicting a larger public sector would emerge from private prosperity. The book argued that private spending creates artificial demand, and the public sector is underfunded, leading to economic instability. While Galbraith's vision has partially triumphed, with federal spending increasing and a welfare state emerging, it has also led to unforeseen problems, including a globalized economy vulnerable to foreign competition and economic shocks. The book's optimistic premise about the economy's robustness has proven flawed, and its predictions about the role of entrepreneurs and the impact of advertising on consumption have also been challenged.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2019: Steering through changing tides
summary: Singapore's Budget 2019 focuses on navigating economic challenges, including a slowing global economy and trade tensions. The government allocated SGD 13.2 billion for infrastructure projects and SGD 4.5 billion for healthcare initiatives. Key initiatives include a 3% increase in the Goods and Services Tax (GST) and a 2% increase in the payroll tax. The budget aims to stimulate economic growth and support vulnerable populations, while addressing the country's aging population and rising healthcare costs.

site_title: US being engulfed in a political soap opera
summary: The US is embroiled in a political crisis, with President Donald Trump declaring a national emergency to fund his border wall, sparking a constitutional crisis. Economic nationalist Trump and socialist Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez are spearheading a revolt against globalization, with Trump's wall representing a pledge to protect American jobs and Ocasio-Cortez advocating for taxes on billionaires and nationalizing the healthcare system. The crisis has led to a historic standoff between the White House and Congress, with Amazon scrapping plans for a corporate campus in New York City in response to pressure from progressive activists.

images.alt_text: Central American migrants cross the International Bridge II in Piedras Negras, Coahuila state, Mexico, on the border with the US. Mr Trump has said that he will declare a national emergency in order to build the wall on the US-Mexico border.

site_title: AusGroup to buy housing space for marine workers on Australia's Melville Island for A$11.8m
summary: AusGroup has signed a deal to purchase an accommodation area on Melville Island in Australia for A$11.8 million, which houses staff working in the marine industry. The 119-man accommodation camp, kitchen, administration building, and recreational facilities will be transferred to AusGroup without mortgage or security interests. This purchase comes as AusGroup's Northern Territory port and marine business has established a fuel distribution business in the area, marking the company's expansion in the region.

site_title: Pakistan honours Saudi crown prince after US$20b deals
summary: Pakistan conferred its highest civilian honour, the Nishan-e-Pakistan, on Saudi Crown Prince Mohammad bin Salman, a day after he signed $20 billion investment deals. The move came despite controversy surrounding his alleged role in the murder of dissident journalist Jamal Khashoggi. The crown prince left Pakistan for his next stop, India, after receiving the honour from President Arif Alvi.

site_title: S$200m fund to boost donations and S$1.1b bonus to mark Bicentennial
summary: The Singapore government has introduced two initiatives to encourage donations and support the spirit of giving back during the country's Bicentennial year. A S$200 million Bicentennial Community Fund will provide dollar-for-dollar matching for donations to institutions of a public character, while a S$1.1 billion Bicentennial Bonus will provide cash payments to eligible individuals, including low-income workers and those with specific needs. The government has also increased support for education and retirement savings, with cash top-ups for parents, students, and seniors.

site_title: Another year of S&CC rebate will cost government S$132m
summary: The Singapore government will forgo S$132 million for another year of Service and Conservancy Charges Rebate, benefiting about 930,000 households. This means households in one- and two-room HDB flats will receive rebates to offset 3.5 months of S&CC charges. Additionally, the government will top up the Public Transport Fund by S$10 million and increase cash assistance for low-income families under the ComCare Long-Term Assistance scheme and Singapore Allowance for pensioners.

site_title: Up against world's best at HSBC championships
summary: Singaporean professional golfer Amanda Tan is set to compete in the 63-woman HSBC Women's World Championship at Sentosa's New Tanjong course from Feb 28 to March 3. Tan, ranked 671, is aware of the pressure but aims to play her own game, having gained experience on the China Tour. She has been working with Australian coach Ian Triggs to improve her all-round game, particularly the short game, and enjoys playing at New Tanjong, where she achieved her best competitive score during the qualifiers.

site_title: Avoiding the Robin Hood trap
summary: Singapore's Budget 2019 aims to tackle inequality through socio-economic challenges, including rapidly greying demographics. The budget includes measures to boost competitiveness, productivity, and up- or right-skill workers, as well as enhanced fiscal transfers and long-term care support initiatives. However, policies solely focused on short-term redistribution may exacerbate social tensions. A more holistic approach is needed, incorporating schemes like KidSTART and SkillsFuture to improve social mobility and address underlying causes of inequality. The government must also consider sustainability and nuanced tax solutions to fund these efforts.

site_title: See-Mode raises US$1 million to improve stroke detection technology
summary: See-Mode, a medical imaging firm, has raised US$1 million in seed financing to improve stroke detection technology. The funding, led by Cocoon Capital, will be used to expand the team and gather clinical evidence to support the development of their technology. The company aims to fill the gap in stroke prediction by using a combination of computer vision, artificial intelligence, and computer fluid dynamics to interpret medical images. This provides doctors with data on vulnerable plaques, allowing for better stroke screening and treatment planning.

site_title: Thailand grows at best pace in 6 years, beating expectations
summary: Thailand's economy grew at its best pace in six years in 2018, with a 4.1% annual growth rate, driven by higher domestic demand and record tourism arrivals. The country's fourth-quarter GDP growth beat expectations, but the outlook may be impacted by the upcoming general election and global economic uncertainty, including Sino-US trade tensions and Brexit. Despite this, the state planning agency maintained its 3.5-4.5% economic growth projection for 2019.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2019: Two schemes to help startups scale up and tap expert know-how
summary: Minister for Finance Heng Swee Keat announced two new programmes to help Singaporean startups scale up and tap expert know-how. The Scale-up SG programme will partner private and public sectors to build new capabilities, innovate, and internationalise high-growth firms. The initiative aims to support local businesses in expanding their capabilities and global presence.

site_title: Frasers Property to buy 17.8% stake in PGIM Real Estate Fund for S$356.4m
summary: Frasers Property has agreed to acquire a 17.8% stake in the PGIM Real Estate Asia Retail Fund Ltd for S$356.4 million. The deal aims to enhance the group's portfolio, citing the suburban retail asset class's resilience across property cycles. The transaction is subject to the determination of the dividend amount for the Q4 2018 sale shares.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: ISOTeam's Q2 revenue increased 93.1% year-on-year to S$45.9 million, driven by a strong performance across all business segments. However, the company's gross margin fell to 11.5%. The broker, HB Research Institute, downgraded ISOTeam to Neutral and lowered its target price to S$0.23 due to concerns over competitive pricing and lower margins. In contrast, DBS Group Holdings maintained its Buy rating, citing a beat on net interest income and steady fees, despite a 7% quarter-on-quarter decline in Q4 net income.

site_title: Sweden's Handelsbanken appoints its first female CEO
summary: Sweden's Handelsbanken appoints Carina Akerstrom, 56, as its first female CEO, replacing Anders Bouvin at the end of March. Akerstrom has worked at Handelsbanken since 1986, focusing on expenses and digital transformation. The bank faces challenges, including a high cost-to-income ratio, Brexit exposure, and financial crime weaknesses. Akerstrom joins a growing club of women in top financial industry jobs in Sweden.

site_title: Victoria Beckham goes retro on London catwalk
summary: Victoria Beckham showcased her Autumn/Winter 2019 collection at London Fashion Week, featuring slim-fitted dresses and skirts inspired by 1970s retro styles. The collection, rich in vibrant colors and patterns, was accompanied by a statement from Beckham on modern femininity. Meanwhile, Vivienne Westwood used her catwalk to protest climate change, Brexit, and sustainability, with models addressing the issues on the runway. The event was part of London Fashion Week's 10th anniversary celebration of Beckham's brand.

site_title: Oil gains as investors grow optimistic over Opec output deal
summary: Oil prices rose for a fifth day, nearing their strongest first-quarter performance since 2011, as investors became optimistic about Opec's supply cuts. Brent futures rose 16 cents to $66.41 a barrel, while US futures rose 47 cents to $56.04 a barrel. The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (Opec) has committed to cutting output, leading to a tightening market and supporting prices. However, concerns about China's economy and US sanctions on Iran and Venezuela tempered gains, with analysts warning of potential risks from unpredictable events.

images.alt_text: Oil rose for a fifth day on Monday, on track for its strongest first quarter in eight years, thanks to a growing belief among investors that Opec's supply cuts will prevent a build-up in unused fuel, though concern over China's economy tempered gains.

site_title: The dark side of procurement
summary: Singapore's procurement process has seen a growing trend of breaches, with S$468.28 million mismanaged in 2017/2018, nearly three times higher than the previous year. The Auditor General's Office report also found a 35% increase in economic crimes and 27% of organisations reported procurement fraud. To prevent such lapses, experts recommend doing a simple eyeball test, having procedures and policies in place, and switching to a centralised procurement system. These measures can help minimise risk, improve compliance, and ensure the best practices in procurement.

site_title: Genting Road industrial building for sale at S$15.9m
summary: A freehold industrial development in Singapore's Genting Road has been launched for sale at S$15.9 million, with a land rate of S$938.44 per square foot. The 5-storey building has a gross floor area of 16,943 sq ft and houses production areas and secondary workers' dormitories. It is zoned "Industrial (B1)" and approved for use by clean and light industrial users. The property is located near several matured industrial estates and offers investors the opportunity for immediate rental income and potential for further rental yield increases.

images.alt_text: The five-storey building houses production areas on the first and third levels, and secondary workers' dormitories on the fourth and fifth floors.

site_title: BOJ urged to boost fiscal spending to reignite the economy
summary: Japan's former deputy governor Kikuo Iwata urges the Bank of Japan to boost fiscal spending to reignite the economy, citing the need for stronger measures to boost consumption and avoid inflation missing the 2% target. Iwata proposes ditching this year's scheduled sales tax hike and committing to permanent government spending boosts, financed by the BOJ. This approach, similar to "helicopter money," could directly finance government spending and boost consumption. Iwata's proposal highlights the BOJ's challenge in achieving its elusive inflation goal.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: CITIC Envirotech secured a 474 million yuan (S$94.9 million) industrial hazardous waste treatment project in Linfen City, China. HEALTHWAY Medical Corp expects to record a loss for the 2018 financial year due to clinic refurbishment and write-offs. KTMG Limited reconstituted its board after a reverse takeover, with Lim Siau Hing as executive chairman and Lim Vhe Kai as CEO. Sasseur Reit posted a higher-than-forecast fourth quarter distribution per unit, with a full-year DPU 12.6% above forecast. Vibrant Group's 60%-owned subsidiary sold its stake in DP-Master-Vibrant for S$28.1 million.

site_title: A very Greek Brexit?
summary: The UK's Brexit saga bears some resemblance to Greece's "Grexit" experience, offering valuable lessons for the final stage of Brexit negotiations. Unlike the UK, Greece is a smaller economy with weak institutions, and was not forced to leave the eurozone. Despite being threatened with expulsion, Greece remained a member of both the eurozone and the EU. This parallels the UK's decision to leave the EU, highlighting the complexities of the Brexit process and the importance of considering alternative scenarios.

site_title: Singapore Budget deficit of S$3.5 billion expected for FY19
summary: Singapore is expected to have a budget deficit of S$3.48 billion in FY19, or 0.7% of GDP, despite being the largest deficit in dollar terms since FY15. The deficit is largely due to increased spending in healthcare, defence, and environment ministries. Economists say the current government can afford to spend more, citing a surplus of S$17.9 billion over the past three financial years. The government expects total spending to increase by 1.6% year on year, with special transfers more than doubling to S$15.3 billion.

site_title: The cyborgs of Alita: Battle Angel vanquish rivals at the box office
summary: Fox's sci-fi action movie Alita: Battle Angel, directed by Robert Rodriguez and produced by James Cameron, topped the North American box office with US$27.8 million, exceeding analysts' expectations. The film's modest box office earnings, despite a budget of US$170 million, is a significant improvement over the flop Mortal Engines, also produced by Cameron. Other box office performers included The Lego Movie 2: The Second Part, Isn't it Romantic, and Happy Death Day 2U, with the weekend failing to invigorate a lacklustre year at the box office.

site_title: Euro gains as US-China trade-talk optimism boosts sentiment
summary: The euro has rallied, gaining 0.3% to US$1.1328, as optimism over US-China trade war talks boosts investor sentiment. This follows a three-month low on Friday. Riskier currencies like the Australian dollar also strengthened. Analysts expect the euro to remain vulnerable to a US-European trade dispute, while emerging market currencies were mixed. Despite the euro's gains, traders expect a weaker euro in the coming months due to slow growth and political uncertainty in the eurozone.

site_title: Pound rises as seven moderate Labour MPs quit the party
summary: Seven moderate Labour MPs have quit the party due to rising anti-Semitism and Jeremy Corbyn's Brexit policies. The pound rose slightly on hopes of a Brexit deal or another referendum. The formation of independent moderate-left Labour MPs may attract centrist Conservative MPs, potentially altering the UK's political landscape.

site_title: Five imperatives for change every business should consider
summary: Singapore retailers must rethink their business models to remain relevant in the face of changing consumer behaviors. Consumers are increasingly seeking a more fulfilling and purposeful life, empowered by technology such as artificial intelligence. To succeed, retailers must prioritize individualized user experiences, integrate with other parties for seamless customer experiences, and master the ecosystem to add value. Five key imperatives for change include challenging every assumption, focusing on the right "tribe", winning every micro-moment, delivering measurable outcomes, and mastering the ecosystem.

images.alt_text: The Design Orchard development (above) comprises a retail showcase housing over 60 home-grown labels, incubators and event spaces, reflecting a growing appetite for local products.
The Design Orchard development comprises a retail showcase housing over 60 home-grown labels (above), incubators and event spaces, reflecting a growing appetite for local products.

site_title: Trading active despite focus on Budget
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.8% to 3,265.97, driven by gains in banking stocks, with DBS Group Holdings and OCBC Bank closing 1.7% and 1.6% higher, respectively. The market was also boosted by the positive impact of US-China trade talks, with regional markets rising. However, the day's performance was tempered by weak non-oil domestic exports data, which highlighted lingering tech exports weakness. The SGX's daily average turnover reached 1.47 billion securities worth S$929.84 million.

site_title: Koh Teck Chuan joins Frasers Hospitality as CEO
summary: Koh Teck Chuan, 59, has been appointed as the CEO of Frasers Hospitality, effective from February 19, 2019. He previously served as the chief executive of MCL Land, a subsidiary of Hongkong Land.

site_title: Singapore commodity traders need to digitalise or lose out
summary: Singapore's commodities trading sector, worth US$1.2 trillion in 2017, faces a decline if it doesn't adopt digital technologies, including blockchain, to streamline and secure transactions. Traditional methods, with extensive documentation and lengthy paper trails, hinder efficiency and increase the risk of errors and inconsistencies. Blockchain technology can record transactions securely, reduce reliance on middlemen, and build trust between parties, ultimately leading to cost-savings and increased reliability. Singapore, a key trading hub, must lead the adoption of new technologies to maintain its position as a well-connected and efficient trading hub.

site_title: UK property asking prices rise by the least since 2009
summary: UK property asking prices rose by 0.2% in February, the smallest increase since 2009, according to Rightmove. This follows signs of a slowing housing market ahead of Brexit. Despite wages rising at an annual rate of over 3%, affordability remains a concern due to stretched prices and higher taxes. Analysts attribute the slowdown to Brexit uncertainty, which is expected to impact the housing market in the coming months.

site_title: China property 'stealth easing' spreads in boost to home prices
summary: China has eased restrictions on residency-permits in at least 11 cities, potentially boosting ailing property markets. This move is part of a "stealth easing" of property curbs, which have helped keep housing prices in check. The easing of restrictions could lead to increased home prices, as residents are allowed to buy more properties. The decision is seen as a strategic move to stimulate the property market, which has been struggling due to government policies.

site_title: Josephine Teo urges CPF Board to fine-tune communication
summary: Singapore's Manpower Minister Josephine Teo urged the CPF Board to improve communication with its members, particularly those nearing their Payout Eligibility Age (PEA) of 65. The current system relies on letters and yearly statements, which may lead to confusion. Teo suggested increasing in-person interactions and providing personalized advice to help members make informed decisions about their retirement payouts. The CPF Board has already started face-to-face meetings for members reaching PEA, and it is also working with other agencies to reach members.

site_title: Google, Salesforce investing in UK payments startup GoCardless
summary: Google's venture capital arm and Salesforce are investing in UK payments startup GoCardless, which has raised $75 million to fund expansion. GoCardless, founded in 2011, allows businesses to set up recurring bank payments online. The company processes $10 billion in payments annually and aims to take a larger share of the global $2 trillion payments market. The new funding will be used to open new offices and launch new features, including foreign exchange transactions and machine-learning to increase transaction success rates.

site_title: A competitive Smart Nation through a strong and united Singapore
summary: Singapore's Budget 2019 aims to build a "strong, united" nation through a competitive and smart approach. The country leverages its unified resources to harness technology for improved quality of life. This strategy aligns with Singapore's goal of being a competitive nation.

site_title: Private equity firms eye bonanza in India's residential market
summary: Private equity firms are investing heavily in India's residential real estate market, seeking opportunities in the affordable housing segment. With regulatory changes and a more dovish monetary policy outlook, PE investors are attracted to the sector's potential for an 8-10% annual return. Several firms, including Blackstone Group, Piramal Enterprises, and Brookfield Asset Management, have committed hundreds of millions of dollars to affordable housing projects. This influx of investment is expected to boost the cash-starved market, which has been hit by failed projects, credit squeezes, and a crunch in the shadow banking sector.

site_title: Citi in talks to buy Canary Wharf tower
summary: CitiGroup is in talks to buy the 25 Canada Square tower in London's Canary Wharf district, housing its European headquarters, for around £1.2 billion. The bank, which already employs 6,000 staff in the area, would move some staff from a second building to the larger tower if the deal is agreed. The purchase would be a boost for London's commercial property market ahead of Brexit, aligning with Citi's strategy of buying buildings in locations where it has and intends to retain a presence.

site_title: Under no-deal Brexit, UK bankers will need chaperones for EU clients
summary: London's investment bankers face significant challenges in a no-deal Brexit scenario, where they would need an EU "chaperone" to accompany them when pitching business to EU clients. Without a deal, banks would have to loop in EU colleagues, cold-call EU executives, and obtain a "letter of engagement" from clients to represent them in M&A discussions. This would disrupt the entire pipeline and create uncertainty, as regulators have yet to provide clear guidelines on reverse solicitation.

images.alt_text: A reflection of office buildings in a window in the City of London. Major investment banks have offices across Europe and London-based M&A staff typically liaise with their local counterparts on live deals.

site_title: How Australia's top property billionaire is exploiting the slump
summary: Australian property billionaire Harry Triguboff remains optimistic about his business despite the country's worst real estate slump in a generation. Triguboff, 85, plans to push on with expansion, even as the Sydney property market slides deeper into the doldrums. He believes he can buy land cheaper if prices fall and has built over 75,000 apartments along the east coast since his first project at age 30. Triguboff expects his rental income to remain strong and is confident in his ability to adapt to the changing market.

images.alt_text: "If prices fall, I'll buy the land cheaper," says Harry Triguboff. "As long as you don't lose your cool. You have to look at things in the longer term."

site_title: Trump's border wall faces Texas-sized backlash from land owners
summary: US President Donald Trump's border wall project is facing a significant backlash from landowners in Texas, a key battleground state. The wall's construction poses logistical challenges, including the potential to trap water on the US side, and raises constitutional concerns over eminent domain laws. At least one lawsuit has been filed, challenging Trump's emergency declaration, and property seizure laws are expected to be severely tested. The issue is particularly delicate in Laredo, where many residents are divided on the wall's merits and its impact on their community.

site_title: Changing hands
summary: Singapore's NTT DC Reit's public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed. US stocks opened lower following President Trump's fresh tariff salvo on Canada. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and operating loss for the second half of the year. London's Heathrow is considering higher fees for its £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case. OCBC's incoming CEO, Tan Teck Long, has a background as a DBS veteran. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and PBOC are deepening cooperation in green and transition finance.

site_title: India central bank to pay early 280b rupees in dividend to government
summary: India's central bank, the Reserve Bank of India (RBI), has approved an early transfer of 280 billion rupees (S$5.31 billion) in dividend to the government, emulating Turkey's central bank. The move aims to help the government fund populist pledges ahead of a national election and partly bridge a budget gap. The RBI dividend will also support an income support program for farmers, which is crucial for Prime Minister Narendra Modi's government.

site_title: Budget 2019 gives businesses extra fuel to last the transformation journey
summary: Singapore's Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat unveiled Budget 2019, emphasizing the need for businesses to adapt to global changes, including technological advancements and shifting economic gravity. The budget focuses on supporting small and medium enterprises (SMEs), with measures to enhance digital capabilities, improve access to financing, and promote talent development. Key initiatives include an expanded SMEs Go Digital Programme, a new cross-border innovation platform, and a single Enterprise Financing Scheme. The government aims to support SMEs on their transformation journey, providing them with the "extra fuel" needed to succeed in a rapidly changing economy.

site_title: January NODX falls 10.1% in its worst showing in over two years
summary: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports (NODX) fell 10.1% in January, its worst showing in over two years, due to declines in both electronics and non-electronics shipments. The drop was worse than expected, with economists forecasting a 3.5% decline and analysts anticipating a 1.6% decrease. Shipments to the top 10 markets also decreased, indicating a weak start to the year for the trade sector.

images.alt_text: Singapore's trade sector began this year on a weak note, with non-oil domestic exports (NODX) for January sliding a worse-than-expected 10.1 per cent from a year ago, as both electronics and non-electronics shipments shrank.

site_title: Saudis defend app that lets men to give women permission to travel
summary: The Saudi government's mobile app, Absher, has been defended by some Saudis on social media, despite criticism from human rights groups that it perpetuates the male guardianship system. The app requires male approval for women to travel abroad, and critics argue it restricts women's freedom. The government claims the app simplifies bureaucracy, but human rights groups say it's part of the discriminatory system. Apple and Google have faced calls to review the app, with some US lawmakers condemning the app as "unconscionable" for tracking women's travel.

site_title: Aquaculture, energy Centres of Innovation to fuel 'Asia, Global 101' ambition
summary: Singapore has introduced two new innovation centres: one for aquaculture at Temasek Polytechnic and the other for energy at Nanyang Technological University. The centres aim to support the growth and internationalisation of local enterprises in sustainability-driven sectors, addressing pain points such as water quality and plastic contamination. The move is part of Singapore's broader ambition to become "Asia 101" for multinational corporations and "Global 101" city for Asian companies ready to expand worldwide.

site_title: FY19 Singapore Budget's big transfers
summary: The Singapore Budget 2019 featured significant transfers, including a new grant of up to S$100,000 for tariff-hit businesses and increased support for workers. Deputy Prime Minister (DPM) Gan Kim Khong will visit the US for trade talks. The government also aims to establish Singapore as a global hub for advanced chip packaging and has set up a centre to advance sustainable aviation in Asia-Pacific. Additionally, graduates are advised to future-proof their careers, and workers who lack training can access support from the Singapore Business Federation (SBF).

site_title: S$8b package unveiled for Merdeka Generation
summary: Singapore has unveiled an S$8 billion package, known as the Merdeka Generation Package, to thank citizens born in the 1950s and those who became citizens by 1996 for their contributions to the country. The package, which includes subsidies for healthcare, transportation, and other expenses, will benefit around 500,000 Singaporeans. It will be funded by a new Merdeka Generation Fund, set aside S$6.1 billion, with interest accumulated over time. The package was announced by Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat in the 2019 Budget Statement.

site_title: Cold War redux : global security architecture being dismantled
summary: The Intermediate-Range Nuclear Forces (INF) Treaty between the US and Russia has been abandoned, marking a significant shift in the global security architecture. The treaty, signed in 1987, banned nuclear arms delivery systems, but its demise has led to both sides developing new missiles with ranges of 1,000 to 5,000 kilometers. China, not a party to the treaty, has built up its own missile arsenal, posing a threat to US aircraft carriers and Taiwan. The US is also expected to site new intermediate missiles in its Pacific bases, and experts fear the New START treaty may be next to go.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2019: Schemes to raise workers' skills given a welcome boost
summary: The Singapore government has introduced new measures to support workers in a competitive and technology-intensive environment. Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat announced the launch of Professional Conversion Programmes (PCPs) in blockchain, embedded software, and prefabrication, aiming to upskill workers in new growth areas. Additionally, the Enterprise Development Grant (EDG) will be extended to March 31, 2023, providing up to 70% funding for SMEs to improve operational efficiencies and internationalise. The government also introduced a new component of the Productivity Solutions Grant (PSG) to support training expenses and extended the Career Support Programme for two years.

site_title: Sasseur Reit Q4 DPU of 1.999 Singapore cents beats forecast
summary: Sasseur Reit reported a fourth-quarter distribution per unit (DPU) of 1.999 Singapore cents, beating the forecast of 1.561 Singapore cents, with distributable income of S$23.6 million. Net property income was S$31.2 million, 1.6% above forecast. The Reit's full-year DPU was 5.128 Singapore cents, 12.6% above forecast, with a portfolio occupancy rate of 95.2% in the fourth quarter.

site_title: Empty luxury flats dot Iceland's capital as slowdown looms
summary: Iceland's luxury apartment market is experiencing a slowdown, with over 20 of 38 luxury flats designed by architect Hildigunnur Haraldsdottir remaining unsold. The economy, which has been fueled by a tourism boom, is cooling, with the central bank forecasting 1.8% growth this year, the slowest pace since 2012. The housing market is also being affected by a weakening demand for short-term lets to Airbnb clients. Experts warn that the luxury market may be saturated, leading to potential price falls, and that the broader economy may not be able to withstand it.

site_title: The calm before the tax storm?
summary: Singapore's Budget 2019 did not introduce significant tax measures, with only a few corporate tax incentives extended, including for real estate investment trusts and the fund management industry. The government has left the largest contributors to its coffers untouched, including the Net Investment Returns Contribution rate and corporate income tax rate. However, the OECD's proposals to tax the digital economy could pose a threat to Singapore's tax incentive regime, which attracts multinational companies to the country. The government is closely monitoring these developments and will likely develop a response to minimize the fallout.

site_title: Trump may worsen global car market slump
summary: The global car market is experiencing a slump, with key markets including China, Europe, and the US starting the year on a weak note. The US may impose tariffs on imported vehicles, exacerbating the issue, with China reporting a 17.7% decline in car sales last month. Automakers are struggling with falling profits, record spending on electric and self-driving cars, and decreasing consumer demand due to ride-hailing and car-sharing services. Analysts predict the global market will stall this year or grow just 1%, with mature markets unlikely to see significant growth.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2019: Tighter tax rules on booze and other buys
summary: Singapore's Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat introduced tighter tax measures in the 2019 budget, including a reduced duty-free limit on liquor and overseas purchases, and a two-point increase in Goods and Services Tax (GST) from 2021 to 2025. The changes aim to fund infrastructure investments and recurrent spending in areas like healthcare, education, and security. However, experts suggest that the government may still consider implementing a GST on e-commerce, which could have a broader impact on the economy.

images.alt_text: Travellers will get less GST relief on goods bought abroad while the duty-free allowance for spirits, wine and beer is also among the changes announced.

site_title: UAE signs major missile deals with US giant Raytheon
summary: The United Arab Emirates (UAE) signed major deals worth over $1.6 billion for the purchase of Patriot missile launchers from US arms giant Raytheon. The deals, signed on the second day of an international military exhibition, come after the UAE announced a separate deal for $353 million worth of Patriot missiles. This is part of $3.2 billion in deals signed between the UAE and western companies at the expo, set to run through Thursday.

site_title: Honda to close UK car plant in 2022 with loss of 3,500 jobs - Sky news
summary: Honda is set to announce the closure of its UK car plant in Swindon, putting 3,500 jobs at risk, with the plant scheduled to close in 2022. The announcement is expected to be made on Tuesday, according to Sky News. A spokesperson for Honda declined to comment, saying it was "speculation." The move is a significant blow to the UK automotive industry and will likely have economic implications for the region.

site_title: China unveils plan to tie Hong Kong, Macau closer to mainland
summary: China unveiled a plan to link Hong Kong and Macau with cities in southern China, creating a Greater Bay Area, a high-tech megalopolis rivaling Silicon Valley. The plan aims to boost infrastructure connectivity, strengthen Hong Kong's finance sector, and turn the area into a global innovation hub. The Greater Bay Area faces challenges from diverging social, legal, and customs systems, but the plan hopes to overcome these obstacles and build a "world-class cluster of cities."

site_title: 7 UK Labour MPs quit party in split with Corbyn on Brexit
summary: Seven UK Labour MPs have quit the party in protest over Jeremy Corbyn's stance on Brexit, forming a new "Independent Group". The MPs, who include Chuka Umunna, cited Corbyn's failure to take a decisive stand against Theresa May's Brexit policy as the "tipping point" for their departure. The group aims to become a new force in UK politics, urging other politicians with doubts to join. Corbyn responded by accusing the Tories of "bungling Brexit" and expressing disappointment that the MPs could not continue working together for Labour policies.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2019: Fuel duties jacked up for diesel vehicles
summary: Singapore has doubled its fuel duty for diesel vehicles to S$0.20 a liter, effective immediately, in an effort to curb pollution from exhaust. The move comes two years after the tax system for diesel fuel was revised. To soften the financial blow, the government has introduced tax rebates, such as a S$1,800 cash rebate for diesel buses carrying schoolchildren and three years of new road tax rebates for commercial diesel vehicles. The aim is to reduce diesel demand and promote environmentally friendly engines, like electric cars, with islandwide charging infrastructure.

site_title: Wall Street closed Monday for Washington's Birthday
summary: Wall Street remained open on Monday as it was Washington's Birthday, resulting in a closed observance of the holiday. In the markets, the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reached fresh records, despite ongoing US-EU trade tensions and tariff uncertainty. Asia saw a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks, while the Singapore Stock Index (STI) closed up 0.4% on Thursday. Meanwhile, eSIM platform Airalo raised $220 million in funding, lifting its valuation past $1 billion.

site_title: DBS housing loans business takes harder hit from cooling measures
summary: DBS Bank's housing loans business saw a significant impact from cooling measures in 2018, with mortgage growth coming in shy of its original estimate of S$4 billion and revised estimate of S$2.5 billion. The bank now expects S$1.5 billion to S$2 billion in mortgage growth for 2019. Despite this, DBS reported a 10.5% year-on-year increase in net profit to S$1.319 billion in the fourth quarter, driven by loan and net interest margin growth. The bank's shares rose 1.65% to S$25.20 after the results were announced.

site_title: EU vows 'swift' riposte to threatened US auto tariffs
summary: The European Union has threatened a swift response to US plans to impose import duties on European autos, with EU spokesman Margaritis Schinas stating that the European Commission would react "swift and adequate" if duties were imposed. The US Commerce Department filed a report allowing President Donald Trump to apply duties within 90 days, targeting Germany and other European countries. The EU and US had previously agreed to no new tariffs in July, with EU President Jean-Claude Juncker trusting Trump's word.

site_title: Vibrant unit to sell 60% stake in real estate developer for S$28.1m
summary: Vibrant Group's 60%-owned subsidiary, Vibrant Properties, has agreed to sell its 60% equity interest in DP-Master-Vibrant (Jiangyin) Real Estate Development Co (DPMV) to Jiangsu Yingshi Real Estate for S$28.1 million. Vibrant Group will receive up to S$16.8 million upon completion. DPMV has completed two government-approved resettlement housing projects in Jiangsu province. The sale is expected to take place by Feb 28 and allow Vibrant Group to realize a profit over its investment in DPMV.

site_title: Britain's FT says allegations over Wirecard reporting are false
summary: Britain's Financial Times has rejected allegations that it or its reporters manipulated market reports on German payments company Wirecard, calling them "baseless and false." German authorities have opened an investigation into an FT journalist, while regulators ordered a ban on short-selling Wirecard shares, sending the stock price soaring. Wirecard has accused the FT of defamatory reporting and plans to sue. The allegations originated from investigative articles alleging accounting trickery in Wirecard's Asian operations, with regulators and prosecutors launching investigations into market manipulation.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2019: Budget deficit of S$3.48b expected for FY19
summary: Singapore's budget deficit for FY19 is expected to be S$3.48 billion, or 0.7% of GDP, marking the largest deficit since 2015. Expenditure is projected to increase by 1.6% to S$80.25 billion, mainly due to increased spending in healthcare, defence, and environment ministries. This will be offset by decreased spending in the Ministry of Transport and increased spending on public transport capacity. Total revenue is expected to rise to S$74.9 billion, with higher corporate income tax and goods and services tax collections.

site_title: Alpha Energy shareholders to vote on Mustang transactions on March 5
summary: Alpha Energy will hold an extraordinary general meeting on March 5 to seek shareholders' approval for various transactions to consolidate its working interest at the Mustang oilfield in Alaska. The firm aims to raise its working interest from 36.2% to 90.1% by acquiring shares from other working interest owners in exchange for cash, new shares, and options. The transactions include the issuance of new shares and convertible perpetual capital securities to acquire a 3.67% membership interest in Mustang Operations Centre 1.

site_title: Healthway Medical Corp expects smaller loss for FY2018
summary: Healthway Medical Corp expects a smaller loss for FY2018 compared to the previous year, mainly due to reduced operating hours in clinics undergoing refurbishment and write-offs of property, plant, and equipment. The company has refurbished 27 clinics and expects to complete the last phase over the first two quarters of 2019. The unaudited financial results for 2018 will be announced on or before March 1.

site_title: Eurosceptic forces to gain in EU elections: poll
summary: Eurosceptic forces, including Italy's Matteo Salvini and France's Marine Le Pen, are projected to gain seats in the European Parliament in May's elections. The European People's Party, a centre-right conservative group, is expected to remain the largest bloc with 183 seats, while the Socialists will retain 135 seats. The liberal group ALDE is forecast to move into third place, and the Europe of Nations and Freedom group is expected to rise to 59 seats. Overall, eurosceptic and populist forces will represent more than a fifth of the new parliament.

site_title: EU tells small businesses to brace for tax burdens in event of no-deal Brexit
summary: The European Union has warned small businesses to prepare for increased bureaucracy and costs in the event of a no-deal Brexit. Economy Commissioner Pierre Moscovici stated that checks on goods moving between the EU and UK would be introduced immediately, requiring customs formalities, duties, and import/export licenses. With just 39 days left until Brexit, negotiations between the EU and UK have stalled, raising the risk of a hard Brexit.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 3.91 points to 1,692.74 on Monday, with a trading volume of 2.8 billion lots worth RM1.7 billion. Gainers outpaced losers 446 to 378.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: The Singapore government announced its 2019 budget, allocating S$6.1 billion for the Merdeka Generation Fund, aimed at funding the Merdeka Generation Package. The budget also includes S$4.6 billion for economic transformation and jobs, S$3.6 billion for worker support, and S$1 billion for firm capabilities. Additionally, the government will provide a CPF top-up of up to S$1,000 for eligible Singaporeans aged 50-64 and set aside S$3.1 billion for Long-Term Care Support Fund.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2019: Surplus instead of deficit for FY18; suspension of HSR, higher stamp duties cited
summary: Singapore's budget for FY18 showed a surplus of S$2.12 billion, exceeding initial estimates of a small deficit. The surplus was attributed to the suspension of the Kuala Lumpur-Singapore High-Speed Rail project and higher-than-expected stamp duty, corporate income tax, and statutory board contributions. A one-off Bicentennial Bonus of S$1.1 billion will be shared with Singaporeans. Operating revenue increased to S$73.67 billion, while expenditure decreased to S$78.99 billion, resulting in a basic deficit of S$7.02 billion.

images.alt_text: Singapore is expected to register a budget surplus of S$2.12 billion for FY18, equal to 0.4 per cent of gross domestic product (GDP), instead of a small overall deficit of S$0.6 billion as estimated a year ago.

site_title: Chinese company recalls products suspected of African swine fever contamination
summary: Chinese frozen food producer Sanquan Food Co Ltd has recalled products suspected of African swine fever contamination, following media reports of positive test results in dumplings. The company, one of China's top dumpling brands, has recalled all products suspected of contamination, cooperating with local authorities on an investigation. The epidemic of African swine fever has spread rapidly across China since August 2018, reaching 25 provinces and regions, and poses a risk to the spread to other countries through consumer food exports.

site_title: Frasers Hospitality appoints Koh Teck Chuan as CEO
summary: Frasers Hospitality has appointed Koh Teck Chuan as its new CEO, effective February 19, 2019. Koh, formerly chief executive of MCL Land, succeeds Choe Peng Sum, who retired on February 15. Choe later became senior adviser to parent Frasers Property.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks rally on trade hopes
summary: Hong Kong stocks surged on Monday, with the Hang Seng Index climbing 1.60% and the Shanghai Composite Index jumping 2.68%, amid optimism over a potential US-China trade deal. The Shenzhen Composite Index also rose 3.71%. The rally followed a 5-day streak of gains in Singapore stocks, despite US President Trump's recent threats to extend the trade war. The market optimism lifted shares in various Asian markets, including those in Singapore, the US, and Europe, as investors awaited updates on US-EU trade talks.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets dip at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets dipped at the start of trading on Monday, with London's FTSE 100 down 0.1% and the eurozone's DAX 30 and CAC 40 indices also losing 0.1%. The decline was attributed to no major economic announcements.

site_title: Singapore stocks close higher on Monday; STI up 0.8% to 3,265.97
summary: Singapore stocks closed higher on Monday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) gaining 26.23 points or 0.81% to 3,265.97. About 1.47 billion securities worth S$929.84 million changed hands, with Thomson Medical being the top gainer and Best World International the top loser. The STI has extended its 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Facebook Targeted in scathing report by British parliament
summary: A British parliamentary committee released a scathing report accusing Facebook of breaking data privacy and competition laws, calling for new regulations to rein in the technology industry. The report, which concluded after 18 months of investigation, recommends creating a British watchdog to oversee the technology industry and requiring Facebook to remove harmful content, or face fines. The report criticizes Facebook's past mistakes and argues that the company cannot hide behind its platform status and maintain that it has no responsibility in regulating content. Facebook acknowledged past mistakes and expressed willingness to "meaningful regulation."

site_title: CITIC Envirotech wins 474m yuan industrial hazardous waste treatment project in Shanxi
summary: CITIC Envirotech has secured a 474 million yuan industrial hazardous waste treatment project in Linfen City, Shanxi province, China. The project, valued at S$94.9 million, involves designing, constructing, and operating a hazardous waste treatment plant and incineration facility. The project company, Novo Envirotech, will be formed by CEL and Shandong Zhengtian Environmental Technology Co, with CEL holding an 80% share. The project is expected to be completed in 18 months, funded through internal resources and bank financing.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2019: Quick Takes
summary: Singapore's Minister for Finance Heng Swee Keat delivered the 2019 budget, focusing on sustainability, security, and innovation. Key measures include a 9% GST increase between 2021 and 2025, a 50% personal income tax rebate for middle-income earners, and a reduction in goods import duties for travelers. The government also aims to promote digital skills, re-skilling the workforce, and supports small businesses through customized programs. The budget aims to balance fiscal sustainability, caring for the elderly, young, and poor, while ensuring a sustainable future for Singapore.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2019: CPF top-up of up to S$1,000 for eligible Singaporeans aged 50 to 64 in 2019
summary: Singapore's Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat announced a CPF top-up of up to S$1,000 for eligible Singaporeans aged 50-64 with less than S$60,000 in retirement savings. About 300,000 will benefit, mainly women who left the workforce early. This is on top of the Merdeka Generation Package, five-year MediSave top-ups, and GST Voucher benefits. The government also provides additional support for education, including a S$150 top-up for parents and up to S$500 for those aged 17-20. The measures aim to support low-income households.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2019: Doubling down on restructuring, S$1.1b Bicentennial Bonus
summary: Singapore's Budget 2019 aims to support economic restructuring, with a focus on helping workers and firms build capabilities. The government expects to spend S$4.6 billion on economic measures, including a S$1.1 billion Bicentennial Bonus for citizens born in the 1950s. The services sector will see a reduction in foreign worker dependency, while existing schemes for small and medium enterprises will be extended. The government also plans to invest in defence, security, and diplomacy amid global geopolitical uncertainty, and sets aside S$6.1 billion for a Long-Term Care Support Fund.

images.alt_text: Economic transformation was one of the long-term imperatives flagged by Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat in his Budget speech in Parliament on Monday.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2019: Singapore to invest more to tackle climate change
summary: Singapore's government has announced plans to invest more to address climate change and rising sea levels. A carbon tax will be implemented to reduce emissions, while a Zero Waste masterplan will review food, e-waste, and packaging waste management. Minister for Finance Heng Swee Keat emphasized the need for each generation to contribute to infrastructure costs, with the carbon tax serving as a signal to reduce emissions and adopt energy-efficient practices. The measures are part of Singapore's efforts to tackle climate change and protect itself against its impacts.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2019: 50% personal income tax rebate capped at S$200
summary: Singapore's Minister for Finance Heng Swee Keat announced a 50% personal income tax rebate capped at S$200 for the year of assessment 2019. The rebate aims to benefit middle-income earners, with the S$200 cap intended to maximize the benefits. This move was part of the 2019 budget, aiming to support the country's economy.

site_title: Path laid for establishment of regional trademark registration system
summary: Delegates from ASEAN member states discussed a feasibility study for a regional trademark registration system, aiming to reduce registration time and create greater certainty for businesses operating in the region. The study will consider legal infrastructure, operational set-up, and fee structures, among other factors. A regional trademark system is expected to foster new investments and improve the ease of doing business in ASEAN, with the goal of promoting regional integration of intellectual property regulation. The EU-funded Arise+ IPR programme will conduct the study, which is part of a series of activities to promote regional integration.

images.alt_text: (Left-Right) ARISE+ IPR Deputy Project Leader, Tiago da Trindade Geurreiro; DIP Thailand Deputy Director General Nusara Kanjanakul; EU Delegation to Thailand Trade Counsellor, Isabelle de Stobbeleir; and ARISE+ IPR Project Leader, Ignacio de Medrano Caballero

site_title: Singapore Budget 2019: S&CC rebate costing S$132 million set aside
summary: Singapore's government has allocated S$132 million for the Service and Conservancy Charges (S&CC) rebate, benefiting about 930,000 eligible households. The rebate will provide S&CC rebates of 1.5 months and 3.5 months, respectively. Additionally, the Public Transport Fund will be topped up by S$10 million to help commuters with transport expenses.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2019: Surplus instead of deficit in FY18, one-off Bicentennial Bonus to be paid
summary: Singapore's FY18 budget results in a surplus of S$2.12 billion, or 0.4% of GDP, due to the suspension of the Kuala Lumpur-Singapore High-Speed Rail project and higher-than-expected collections from stamp duties, corporate income tax, and statutory board contributions. A one-off Bicentennial Bonus of S$1.1 billion will be paid to Singaporeans, including lower-income individuals and parents with school-going children. Lower expenditure on the postponed HSR project will be partly offset by increased spending on healthcare, trade, and industry, and education.

site_title: Saudi prince starts Asia trip pledging US$20 billion for Pakistan
summary: Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman announced a $20 billion investment in Pakistan, including a $10 billion oil refinery in Gwadar, and a deal to provide crude oil and petroleum products on delayed payments. The investment aims to boost energy needs and create a "great future" for both countries.
