Prince Mohammed made the announcement during a two-day trip to Islamabad, where he met with Prime Minister Imran Khan. The agreements were signed in the energy and agriculture sectors, marking a significant development in Saudi-Pakistan ties at a time of strained relations with the West.

images.alt_text: Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman said his country plans to invest a whopping US$20 billion in Pakistan as he began a swing through Asia at a time when Saudi Arabia's ties with the west have waned.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2019: Diesel excise duty doubled to 20 cents per litre
summary: Singapore's Minister for Finance Heng Swee Keat announced a diesel tax increase, doubling the excise duty to 20 cents per litre, effective immediately. To mitigate the impact, the government will provide a 100% road tax rebate for one year and partial rebates for two years for commercial diesel vehicles. Additionally, cash rebates of up to S$3,200 will be offered for diesel-run buses ferrying school children. The government also permanently reduced the annual special tax on diesel taxis and diesel cars by S$850 and S$100, respectively.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2019: Singapore expects to pay out more than S$200m a year in Community Health Assist Scheme subsidies
summary: Singapore expects to pay out over S$200 million annually in Community Health Assist Scheme (CHAS) subsidies, as Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat announced plans to extend the program to cover all Singaporeans from chronic conditions, regardless of income. The government aims to provide subsidies for common illnesses to lower to middle income Singaporeans and extend subsidies for complex chronic conditions. The CHAS program, introduced in 2012, currently has over 97% of existing cardholders with access to multiple clinics within 10 minutes of their homes.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2019: More funding support to send Singaporeans abroad for working experience
summary: Singapore's government has introduced a Global Ready Talent programme to support young Singaporeans in gaining working experience abroad through overseas internships with Singapore firms. The programme offers enhanced funding support to students and provides opportunities for high-growth firms to send experienced Singaporeans to key markets. The government also aims to build global partnerships and collaborate with innovation centres, including the nine "nodes" established under the Global Innovation Alliance.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2019: FY2019 budget position expansionary, with basic deficit of S$7.1b
summary: Singapore's 2019 budget remains expansionary with a basic deficit of S$7.1 billion, or 1.4% of GDP, Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat announced. This is due to a S$2.7 billion increase in forecasted deficit from FY2018. The government expects a total expenditure of S$80.3 billion, with S$6.1 billion allocated for the Merdeka Generation Package and S$5.1 billion for long-term care support. The government has sufficient fiscal surplus to fund the deficit, with no draw on past reserves.

site_title: Burberry's Tisci brings contrasting Britain to London catwalk
summary: Burberry's creative head Riccardo Tisci showcased his Autumn/Winter 2019 collection "Tempest" on London's catwalk, blending contrasting elements of streetwear and traditional British elegance. The show featured models in oversized jackets, faux fur, and Burberry's signature check print, with a color palette of beige, orange, and bold accents. Tisci drew inspiration from his 1990s London days, highlighting the country's contrasts between structured and rebellious styles, and positioning the collection as a celebration of freedom and inclusivity for the modern era.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2019: Enterprise Singapore to launch Scale-up programme for startups
summary: Enterprise Singapore to launch Scale-up SG programme, partnering private and public sectors to support startups and smaller companies in scaling up and expanding into international markets. The programme will provide customized assistance, financing options, and technology adoption support. Additionally, a pilot of an Innovation Agents programme will be launched to advise firms on innovation and technology commercialization opportunities. This move aims to improve access to private capital for startups and small-medium enterprises, with the goal of fostering smart, patient capital to drive firm growth.

site_title: OCBC rolls out digital token to replace hardware security tokens
summary: OCBC Bank has introduced a digital "soft" token, OCBC OneToken, to replace hardware security tokens and reduce SMS OTPs. Since its launch in January, over 25% of digital customers have activated the token, with more than 2 million transactions performed using the digital token. The digital token allows customers to access digital banking services on-the-go and on their desktop, eliminating the need for hardware tokens and OTPs. The move is expected to save the bank S$25 million in five years, with seamless and secure authentication.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2019: S$20/mth more for Singapore Allowance and monthly pension ceilings
summary: The Singapore government has announced an increase in the Singapore Allowance and monthly pension ceilings by S$20 a month each, benefiting approximately 9,300 pensioners. The new amounts are S$320 and S$1,250 respectively. This move aims to support government pensioners who draw lower pensions.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2019: S$200m for Bicentennial Community Fund, S$1.1b for Bicentennial Bonus
summary: Singapore has allocated S$200 million for a Bicentennial Community Fund and introduced a S$1.1 billion Bicentennial Bonus. The fund will match donations to institutions of a Public Charterer, while the bonus will provide up to S$300 in cash to lower-income Singaporeans, including 1.4 million recipients. Additionally, lower-income workers receiving Workfare Income Supplement payments will receive an extra 10% of their payment, with a minimum of S$100. The measures aim to give back to society as the country commemorates the Singapore Bicentennial.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2019: Singapore to spend S$4.6b over next 3 years on economic transformation and jobs
summary: Singapore's Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat announced a S$4.6 billion spending plan over three years to support economic transformation and jobs. S$3.6 billion will focus on helping workers thrive amid industry disruptions, while S$1 billion will aid firms in building deep enterprise capabilities. The minister emphasized the importance of supporting both companies and workers, as stronger companies provide better jobs and skilled workers make them stronger. Singapore aims to position itself as a Global-Asia node of technology, innovation, and enterprise.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2019: Singapore to tighten GST import relief, alcohol duty-free concession
summary: Singapore's Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat announced changes to the country's GST import relief and alcohol duty-free concession for travelers. The GST relief for short-term travelers will decrease to S$100 (previously S$150 for 48 hours or less) and S$500 (previously S$600 for more than 48 hours). The alcohol duty-free concession will be reduced to two liters (previously three liters) for travelers arriving in Singapore from April 1, 2019. The changes aim to increase tax revenues amidst rising international travel.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2019: Workfare Income Supplement to be enhanced at S$206m more annually
summary: Singapore's Workfare Income Supplement (WIS) will be enhanced, costing an additional S$206 million annually, to support nearly 440,000 workers. The qualifying income cap will rise from S$2,000 to S$2,300 per month, and maximum annual payouts will increase by up to S$400. The enhanced program aims to provide higher payouts, particularly for older workers, with those aged 60 earning S$1,200 per month receiving up to 30% of their wages. The total cost of the program will approach S$1 billion annually.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2019: S$6.1b Merdeka Generation Fund to be set up
summary: Singapore's government will set aside S$6.1 billion for a new Merdeka Generation Fund, supporting the Merdeka Generation Package (MGP) worth S$8 billion over the lifetimes of approximately 500,000 seniors. The fund will cover projected costs, including subsidies for healthcare, transport, and community activities. Key benefits include a one-time S$100 top-up, annual MediSave top-up, and MediShield life premium subsidies. Eligible seniors, aged 60-69, will receive these benefits, regardless of income, starting from this year until 2023.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2019: More funding for re-hiring of older Singaporeans
summary: Singapore's government will top up the Special Employment Credit (SEC) Fund by S$366 million, extending the SEC and Additional SEC schemes by another year until Dec 31, 2020. The schemes aim to support employers in hiring older Singaporean workers, with the government seeking to help them earn more, save more, and have greater peace of mind during retirement.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2019: SMEs Go Digital programme to be expanded
summary: Singapore's government plans to expand the SMEs Go Digital programme, launched in 2017, to guide small- and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) on digital technologies and skills training. The programme will now include industry digital plans for accountancy, sea transport, and construction, with more sectors to be added later. The government will also introduce cost-effective, pre-approved digital solutions for artificial intelligence and cybersecurity, offering up to 70% funding support. A cross-border innovation platform, Business sans Borders, will be jointly piloted by the Monetary Authority of Singapore and the Info-communications Media Development Authority.

site_title: Indonesian presidential hopefuls vow energy self-sufficiency through palm
summary: Indonesian presidential hopefuls Joko Widodo and Prabowo Subianto vowed to achieve energy self-sufficiency through increased use of bioenergy, particularly palm oil, to reduce costly oil imports. Widodo plans to implement a B100 programme, aiming to boost palm oil production to 30% of total production, while Subianto proposed using millions of hectares of degraded land to cultivate palm sugar. Both candidates agreed to control Indonesian natural resources and increase the role of small farmers in the biodiesel supply chain, aiming to replace fuel imports within three years and narrow Indonesia's current account gap.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2019: Automation Support Package extended by 2 years
summary: Singapore's government has extended the Automation Support Package (ASP) by two years, aiming to support companies in deploying large-scale automation. The package provides up to 50% funding for qualifying automation costs, a 100% investment tax allowance, and loan financing options for SMEs and non-SMEs. Since its launch in 2016, the ASP has helped over 300 companies automate their operations and boost productivity.

site_title: Singapore-based startup Bigo Technology eyes expansion, to open regional centres in India, Mid-East and US
summary: Singapore-based Bigo Technology plans to open regional centers in India, the Middle East, and the US by the end of 2019, investing over $500 million. The company aims to create over 1,000 jobs in India and 200 jobs for AI developers in Singapore. Bigo Technology, which has 40 patents and 60 pending patents, plans to expand its operations with 20 regional offices and four regional centers. The company's flagship live-streaming product has 200 million users, and its short video app has 20 million daily active users globally.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2019: Singapore to set aside another S$3.1b for Long-Term Care Support Fund
summary: Singapore's Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat announced in Parliament that the government will set aside S$3.1 billion for the Long-Term Care Support Fund, bringing the total to S$5.1 billion. This fund will support the CareShield Life subsidies and ElderFund, aiming to help Singaporeans with long-term care needs, particularly those who may become severely disabled. The government also plans to provide subsidies and premium support to make CareShield Life premiums affordable. The new fund will be introduced in 2020, with ElderFund launching next year.

images.alt_text: MOH has announced it would be introducing the new CareShield Life from 2020, an enhancement of current ElderShield scheme.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2019: Singapore sees over 220 venture capital deals, worth US$4.2b, a year
summary: Singapore's start-up ecosystem has seen a significant rise in venture capital deals, with over 220 deals worth US$4.2 billion per year. Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat attributed this growth to the government's efforts, including a Co-Investment Programme that has invested S$1.3 billion in small-medium enterprises (SMEs). The government plans to allocate an additional S$100 million for the SME CIP III, expecting to bring in S$200 million of additional funding. This supports the country's thriving start-up ecosystem and its goal of becoming a hub for innovation and entrepreneurship.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2019: Singapore to invest about 30% of total spend to support defence, security, diplomacy efforts
summary: Singapore's Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat announced that the government will invest approximately 30% of its total expenditure in defence, security, and diplomacy efforts. This significant allocation is seen as indispensable to protect the country's sovereignty and well-being. Heng emphasized that diplomacy and deterrence are key pillars of the government's approach, with everyone playing a role in maintaining Singapore's safety and security.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2019: Building a strong, united Singapore in a fiscally sustainable way
summary: Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat introduced Singapore Budget 2019, focusing on building a strong, united Singapore in a fiscally sustainable way. The budget aims to keep Singapore safe and secure, while transforming the economy and building a caring and inclusive society. It emphasizes the importance of openness, multiculturalism, and self-determination. The government will allocate resources to various sectors, including healthcare, education, and infrastructure, to support economic growth and social development. The budget aims to preserve Singapore's way of life and forge its own destiny.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2019: Productivity grew 3.6% a year in the past 3 years
summary: Singapore's productivity grew 3.6% per year over the past three years, exceeding the 1.6% growth from 2012-2015. Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat attributed this growth to outward-oriented sectors like manufacturing. All 23 Industry Transformation Maps have been launched, covering 80% of the economy.

site_title: KTMG, formerly Lereno Bio-Chem, reconstitutes board following completion of RTO
summary: KTMG Limited, formerly Lereno Bio-Chem, has reconstituted its board following the completion of a reverse takeover (RTO) of Knit Textile and Apparel. Lim Siau Hing has been appointed as executive chairman and CEO, with his son Lim Vhe Kai taking on the role of CEO. Ong Puay Koon and his daughter have quit, and Low Yong Heng has been appointed financial controller. The company will report financial statements on a half-yearly basis and use the Malaysian ringgit as its reporting and functional currency.

site_title: SilkAir to add non-stop flights from Singapore to Busan from May 1
summary: SilkAir, the regional wing of Singapore Airlines, will launch non-stop flights from Singapore to Busan, South Korea, starting May 1, 2019. The airline will operate four weekly flights using Boeing 737 MAX 8 aircraft, offering a "full-service experience" with in-flight meals, entertainment, and complimentary baggage allowance. This will be the first scheduled flight between Singapore and Busan, expanding SilkAir's network in Asia-Pacific.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2019: MediSave top-up of S$100/yr for next 5 years for Singaporeans aged 50 and above in 2019
summary: Singapore's Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat announced a MediSave top-up of S$100 per year for 5 years for Singaporeans aged 50 and above who do not receive the Merdeka Generation Package or Pioneer Generation Package. The goal is to help younger members of the Merdeka Generation with future healthcare expenses. The government has set aside S$6.1 billion for a new Merdeka Generation Fund for those aged 60-69.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2019: Singapore to cut services sector dependency ratio ceiling, defer foreign worker levy rates for shipyard and process sectors
summary: Singapore's Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat announced the 2019 budget, introducing two steps to reduce the services sector Dependency Ratio Ceiling (DRC) from 40% to 35% by 2021. The services sector S Pass Sub-DRC will also decrease from 15% to 10% during the same period. To support firms, the government will extend funding support for the Enterprise Development Grant and Productivity Solutions Grant until 2023. Additionally, foreign worker levy rates for shipyard and process sectors will be deferred for another year. The government aims to calibrate policies based on productivity progress and foreign worker inflows.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2019: More support for Centres of Innovation
summary: Singapore's government will continue to invest in Centres of Innovation, with a focus on promoting aquaculture and energy efficiency. The Centres of Innovation in Aquaculture at Temasek Polytechnic and Energy at Nanyang Technological University aim to improve food resilience and develop innovation in energy efficiency, renewable energy, and electric mobility. The initiatives are part of the government's efforts to support innovation and entrepreneurship in key sectors.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2019: Singapore to launch new Professional Conversion Programmes for new growth areas
summary: Singapore's Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat announced the launch of new Professional Conversion Programmes (PCPs) in blockchain, embedded software, and prefabrication to prepare workers for new growth areas. The PCPs aim to ensure workers benefit from enterprise transformation. The Career Support Programme will also be extended for two years, providing wage support for employers to hire eligible Singaporeans. Investments in career support measures reached S$1.1 billion in 2017, with 48% of residents participating in training in 2018, and over 76,000 job seekers finding employment through the Adapt and Grow initiative.

site_title: ONE Championship promotes Teh Hua Fung to group president
summary: ONE Championship has promoted Teh Hua Fung to group president, succeeding his previous roles as chief financial officer and chairman of Greater China. Teh, a taekwondo black-belt holder, brings over 20 years of experience from TPG Capital and Harvard Business School. Chatri Sityodtong, chairman and CEO of ONE Championship, praised Teh's leadership and contributions to the organization, stating he is "full of gratitude and appreciation" for his efforts.

site_title: North Korea faces 'historic turning point', says state media ahead of summit
summary: North Korea is poised for a "significant, historic turning point" ahead of its second summit with US President Donald Trump on February 27-28 in Hanoi, Vietnam. State media emphasizes the importance of economic sanctions being lifted in exchange for concrete denuclearization steps. The US team's offer has sparked anticipation, with Trump expressing confidence in Kim Jong Un's capabilities. North Korea is seen as a rising socialist nation, and the country's economy is expected to play a crucial role in determining the summit's outcome.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2019: MHA to set up science and technology agency by year-end
summary: Singapore's Ministry of Home Affairs plans to set up a science and technology agency by the end of 2019 to enhance the Home Team's capabilities. The agency will focus on developing technologies to support operational needs and strengthen the Home Team's mission of safeguarding Singapore. The private security industry has also been investing in technology, with Certis redesigning its processes to incorporate Big Data and artificial intelligence. This move aims to bolster the Home Team's ability to counter security threats.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Monday afternoon at 3,263.71, up 0.7% on day
summary: Singapore stocks resumed trading on Monday afternoon, with the Straits Times Index (STI) up 0.7% to 3,263.71 points. Approximately 830 million securities changed hands, with Renaissance United being the most actively traded stock. The rally follows a 5-day streak ahead of GDP data and despite US trade uncertainty.

site_title: Australian garbage collector joins firms hit by propery downturn
summary: Australian garbage collector Bingo Industries Ltd reported a decline in first-half building-waste growth due to a property market downturn, joining other firms feeling the impact. The company's shares plummeted 45% amid weaker construction activity, tighter lending, and higher taxes on foreigners. Industry trends show a slowdown in construction approvals and squeezing retailers as consumers tighten up. The property downturn is expected to remain weak, with several firms, including McGrath Ltd and REA Group Ltd, posting losses or forecasting slower growth.

site_title: Carousell cuts fraud rate by 44% over past year, to launch new features this week
summary: Carousell, an online marketplace, has achieved a 44% decline in its fraud rate over the past year, with only 0.031% of transactions being fraudulent. This decline was attributed to improvements in product and engineering, human resources, and collaboration with authorities to increase consumer education. The company has also launched new features, including CarouPay Protection, which allows users to freeze funds in case of disputes, and a star rating system to rate various aspects of deals.

site_title: Trump's border wall faces Texas-size backlash from land owners
summary: US President Donald Trump's border wall faces significant backlash from landowners in Texas, particularly in the border town of Laredo. The project's logistics and constitutional implications are raising concerns, with many landowners fearing eminent domain laws will be used to seize their property. The state's Republicans, who support border security, are also uneasy about the government's assertion of presidential authority. Several lawsuits have been filed, including one by the Public Citizen, challenging the Trump administration's emergency declaration.

site_title: Best World requests trading halt pending announcement; shares fall 17% in early session
summary: Best World International, a skincare maker and distributor, requested a trading halt pending an announcement on Monday morning, with shares falling 17% in the early session. The company has been queried by the Singapore Exchange for unusual trading activity nine times since 2016, but denied any knowledge of unannounced information. Despite a 171% surge in shares over the past 12 months, driven by growth in China, the halt follows a 16.6% drop in shares before trading was halted.

site_title: Frasers Property to buy 17.8% stake in PGIM Real Estate Retail Fund for estimated S$356.4m
summary: Frasers Property Limited has entered into a conditional sale and purchase agreement to acquire a 17.8% stake in PGIM Real Estate Asia Retail Fund Ltd for approximately S$356.4 million. The acquisition is subject to the determination of the dividend amount payable for the fourth quarter of 2018. The deal aims to enhance Frasers Property's portfolio of investment properties and grow recurring income sources in the suburban retail sector. Completion of the acquisition is conditional upon consent from the Bermuda Monetary Authority and board approval from the fund.

site_title: Empty luxury flats dot Reykjavik as Iceland braces for slowdown
summary: Iceland is experiencing a slowdown in its luxury housing market, with hundreds of empty apartments dotting the city of Reykjavik. The country's housing market has been fueled by historically low mortgage rates, but a recent report suggests the market is leveling off. The government has identified a shortage of 8,000 affordable homes, which continues to fuel resentment among residents. Economists warn that the luxury market may experience a price drop, which could impact the broader economy.

site_title: Thai economic growth strengthens in Q4 but election could impact 2019 pace
summary: Thailand's economy grew at 4.1% in 2018, its highest pace in six years, driven by higher domestic demand and record tourism arrivals. The state planning agency maintained its 2019 economic growth forecast of 3.5-4.5%, despite cutting its export growth outlook to 4.1%. The forecast may be impacted by the upcoming election and potential political uncertainty, with analysts citing variables such as Sino-US trade tensions and Brexit.

site_title: Foreign government behind cyber attack on Australian lawmakers, PM says
summary: Australian Prime Minister Scott Morrison stated that a cyber attack on lawmakers was likely carried out by an unidentified foreign country, specifically mentioning China, Russia, and Iran as suspects. The attack, which breached the networks of major political parties, occurred ahead of the May election. Morrison assured there was no evidence of election interference. The attack was detected by Australia's cyber intelligence agency, and lawmakers were advised to change their passwords.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2019: Building Singapore as a Global-Asia node of technology, innovation and enterprise
summary: Singapore's Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat announced a five-year Research, Innovation and Enterprise 2020 plan with a budget of S$19 billion to position the city-state as a Global-Asia node of technology, innovation, and enterprise. The plan has three thrusts: investments in research and innovation, investments in people, and building global partnerships. This move aims to capitalize on the shift in economic gravity to Asia and the convergence of technologies. Singapore seeks to become a hub for global MNCs and Asian companies looking to expand into Asia's growing markets.

site_title: Australia's Westpac sees Q1 profit slide as property downturn gathers
summary: Australian bank Westpac reported a decline in Q1 profit due to a downturn in the housing market, but its shares rose after higher mortgage rates improved profit margins. The bank's cash earnings were A$2.04 billion for the three months to end-December, with net interest margins rising despite a rise in mortgage delinquencies. Westpac's decision to raise mortgage rates without a change in the central bank rate paid off, and analysts say the bank is keeping expenses under control.

images.alt_text: Australian No. 2 lender Westpac Banking Corp reported an apparent decline in December-quarter profit on Monday amid a downturn in the housing market, but its shares rose after the company said higher mortgage rates fattened profit margins.

site_title: SoftBank invests in Mubadala's new US$400m European tech fund: FT
summary: SoftBank has invested nearly half of the US$400 million European tech fund launched by Abu Dhabi's Mubadala Investment. The fund, aimed at backing European startups, will invest between US$5 million and US$30 million. Mubadala will use the fund to support technology-focused startups in Europe, with operations set to begin in a new London office. This move marks SoftBank's involvement in Mubadala's venture capital efforts, with the Japanese company providing significant funding to support European startups.

site_title: Carmakers to face more pain as sales in China continue to slide
summary: China's car sales continued to decline in January, falling 17.7% year-on-year to 2.02 million units, marking the seventh straight monthly drop. The decline adds pressure on automakers, with sales growth uncertain due to waning demand in Europe and North America. The Chinese government's efforts to spur car demand have been unsuccessful, and manufacturers are shifting focus to electric vehicles amid stringent environmental policies. The first half of 2019 is expected to see downward pressure on sales, with carmakers revising their annual targets and reducing production plans in China.

site_title: Singaporeans loving the luxury homes foreigners can't buy
summary: Singapore's luxury homes, known as Good Class Bungalows (GCBs), remain in high demand despite restrictions on foreign buyers. Only locals or those with citizenship can own these exclusive, high-end homes, which often feature expansive gardens and unique architectural designs. Prices have reached record highs, with recent sales exceeding S$100 million. The scarcity and exclusivity of GCBs have made them a coveted trophy asset among the wealthy community, with the market proving resilient despite a broader property market slowdown.

site_title: Buyback spree alive in India as state firms join tech majors
summary: India's tech sector is continuing its buyback spree, with seven weeks into 2019 seeing 24 companies, including state firms, announce or complete plans to buy 170.5 billion rupees of their own stock. This compares to 545 billion rupees in 2018, driven by improving liquidity, declining share values, and a slowing global economy. State-run firms, including Coal India and Oil India, are also joining the trend to return excess funds to the government in a tax-efficient manner.

site_title: Malaysian palm oil prices seen steady in 2019 - MPOC
summary: Malaysian palm oil prices are expected to remain steady in 2019 at an average of 2,303 ringgit (S$765) a tonne, according to the Malaysian Palm Oil Council. Global palm oil production is projected to rise by 3 million tonnes, with Malaysia and Indonesia as leading producers. Malaysian output is expected to rise to 20.2 million tonnes, while Indonesian production is forecast to reach a record high of 42.8 million tonnes. Palm oil exports in 2019 are also expected to increase due to rising demand from key importer India.

site_title: Australia, New Zealand dollars fly to 1-1/2 week highs on risk rally
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars surged to 1-1/2 week highs on Monday due to hopes of a Sino-US trade war resolution and expectations of expansionary global monetary policy. The Australian dollar reached a high of US$0.7154, while the New Zealand dollar jumped to US$0.6884 for its fifth consecutive gain. Strong loan growth in China and potential interest rate cuts from the Federal Reserve also fueled the rally.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks rally at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose over 1% at the open on Monday, driven by hopes of a trade deal between China and the US. The Hang Seng Index jumped 1.35%, while the Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indices also increased. The rally followed positive sentiment from the US, where the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reached fresh records despite trade uncertainty. The gains come as traders brush off new Trump threats to extend the stocks rally.

site_title: Trade war boogeyman hangs over giant US toy show
summary: The US-China trade war has impacted the US toy industry, particularly those manufacturing putty and arts and crafts items, with 85% of toys sold in the US being made in China. Despite this, superhero action figures and most best-selling toys remain unaffected. Industry representatives express uncertainty, but some companies, like Hasbro, are shifting production to other markets, such as the US, Mexico, and Vietnam. Experts consider US tariffs on finished toys "highly unlikely" and believe the current trade conflict won't fundamentally change China's position in the US toy market.

site_title: Asia: Markets rally on growing trade deal hopes
summary: Asian markets rallied on Monday, driven by growing hopes for a US-China trade deal. Despite no deal ending talks in Beijing, investors are optimistic about a memorandum of understanding ahead of a meeting between US President Donald Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping. The rally was also fueled by a strong lead from Wall Street, bipartisan efforts to avert a US government shutdown, and the Federal Reserve's dovish tone on interest rates. Markets across the region, including Tokyo, Hong Kong, and Shanghai, rose, with high-yielding currencies also gaining value against the dollar.

site_title: Stocks to watch: DBS, Hyflux, iX Biopharma, Frasers Property, Challenger, Courts
summary: DBS Group Holdings reported a 10% increase in net profit to S$1.32 billion for the fourth quarter, despite weakness in treasury markets income. Hyflux CEO Olivia Lum volunteered to contribute her entire stake in the company as part of a restructuring plan. iX Biopharma sold its entire stake in Chemical Analysis for S$12 million. Frasers Property acquired a 17.8% stake in PGIM Real Estate Asia Retail Fund for S$356.4 million. Challenger reported a 2% decrease in net profit to S$5.7 million for the fourth quarter.

site_title: Singapore shares rise at Monday's open; STI up 0.83% to 3,266.56
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.83% to 3,266.56 on Monday, driven by news that the US and China may be making progress on trade negotiations. Gainers outnumbered losers 113 to 39, with DBS Group Holdings and OCBC Bank leading the gainers. Thai Beverage Public Co and Capitaland Commercial Trust also saw significant increases. The rally follows a 5-day streak of gains ahead of GDP data release.

site_title: No Amazon? No problem for New York tech boom
summary: New York City's tech boom is expected to endure despite Amazon's potential pullout from its Queens campus. Google plans to double its workforce in the city, while Facebook, Apple, and Uber are expanding their presence. Local companies are also thriving, and tech is no longer confined to Midtown South. The finance sector remains dominant, but the city's efforts to diversify its economy have paid off, with tech playing a crucial role in the local economy. The tech boom has helped New York City rebound from past economic downturns, and its impact is expected to continue.

site_title: Oil hits 3-month high on Opec cuts, US sanctions on Iran, Venezuela
summary: Oil prices surged to a 3-month high, reaching US$56.13 per barrel for US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude oil futures, and US$66.78 per barrel for international Brent crude futures. The price increase was driven by Opec-led supply cuts and US sanctions on Iran and Venezuela. The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (Opec) agreed to cut output by 1.2 million barrels per day to prevent a supply overhang. Traders also cited hopes for a US-China trade deal resolution as supporting factors.

site_title: Japan frets over 'nightmare scenario' as Trump meets Kim again
summary: Japan is concerned about a "nightmare scenario" if US President Donald Trump's second summit with North Korean leader Kim Jong Un fails to address Japan's security concerns. The US has agreed to suspend joint military exercises with South Korea, which Japan sees as a potential US pull-back. Japan wants to maintain a hard line on international sanctions against North Korea and ensure the regime gives up all its fissile material. The country's security under a 1960 treaty with the US is at risk, with Kim's short- to medium-range rockets posing a significant threat to Japan.

site_title: iX Biopharma to sell Chemical Analysis unit for A$12.5m
summary: iX Biopharma has agreed to sell its Chemical Analysis unit to Eurofins Australia New Zealand Holding for A$12.5 million, resulting in net proceeds of about S$11.75 million. The disposal will help the company repay bank borrowings, fund marketing and product development, and scale up manufacturing capacity. The sale will also narrow loss per share and net loss, with a net gain of about S$10.4 million. The disposal aligns with the company's focus on its core business, pharmaceutical and nutraceutical development, and will enable stronger growth in these areas.

site_title: Ericsson says Huawei ban wouldn't deprive Europe of 5G equipment
summary: Ericsson's CEO Borje Ekholm says EU operators won't be left without 5G equipment due to Huawei ban. Despite US restrictions, Ericsson is already deploying 5G equipment and plans to meet demand when needed. Finnish rival Nokia also claims it can upgrade 4G equipment to 5G, citing 18 commercial 5G radio contracts. The main hurdle to 5G adoption in Europe is the lack of licensed spectrum, not a lack of technology.

site_title: Portugal's PM reshuffles government ahead of European elections
summary: Portugal's Prime Minister Antonio Costa reshuffled his government ahead of European Parliament elections in May. Costa replaced Infrastructure and Housing Minister Pedro Marques, who is stepping down to lead the Socialist Party's European list. Three new ministers and eight junior ministers were appointed, taking office on Monday. The move comes as the government faces a no-confidence vote by the CDS party, which is unlikely to succeed due to its small representation in parliament.

site_title: Blockchain startup Band Protocol raises US$3m seed round led by Sequoia India
summary: Blockchain startup Band Protocol has secured US$3 million in seed funds led by Sequoia Capital India, marking the venture firm's first blockchain investment in Southeast Asia. Founded in 2017, Band Protocol aims to create a "token-curated community" where users are rewarded with crypto tokens for participating in data curation. The funds will be used to accelerate development of its mainnet and go-to-market strategy. Sequoia India principal Pieter Kemps praised the team's technical skills and strategic approach, taking a long-term view on the blockchain scene.

site_title: DBS Q4 net profit rises 10% to S$1.32b; sees high single-digit income growth for 2019
summary: DBS Group Holdings reported a 10% increase in net profit after one-off items to S$1.32 billion for the fourth quarter, driven by healthy business momentum and higher interest rates in Singapore and Hong Kong. Annualized earnings per share rose to S$2.01, and the bank announced a final dividend of 60 cents per share, bringing the full-year payout to S$1.20 per share. For 2019, DBS CEO Piyush Gupta expects high single-digit income growth, driven by mid-single-digit loan growth and continued net interest margin improvement.

site_title: US agency submits auto tariff report probe to White House
summary: The US Commerce Department submitted a "Section 232" national security report to President Donald Trump on Sunday, which could lead to steep tariffs on imported cars and auto parts. The report's contents have not been disclosed, but auto industry officials expect tariffs on fully assembled vehicles or technologies related to electric and automated vehicles. Trump has 90 days to decide on the recommendations, which are expected to provoke a sharp backlash from the industry.

site_title: Vietnam posts US$816m January trade surplus: customs
summary: Vietnam posted a trade surplus of US$816 million in January, exceeding the government's previous estimate of a US$800 million deficit. Exports rose 12.4% to US$22.1 billion, while imports increased 4% to US$21.3 billion. The largest export earners were smartphones, garments, and electronic home appliances, while key imports were electronics, machinery, and fabrics.

site_title: Australian PM gets poll boost amid tough stance on refugees
summary: Australian Prime Minister Scott Morrison's hard-line stance on refugees has boosted his bid for re-election, according to a new opinion poll. The ruling coalition now trails Labor by 2 percentage points, with 49% to 51%. Morrison's stance on asylum seekers, including a proposed law allowing doctors to evacuate sick detainees, has narrowed the gap from 8 points two months ago. The poll comes ahead of a national election due by May, with Morrison vowing to strengthen Australia's maritime border protection and claiming the new laws will not embolden people smugglers.

site_title: Malaysia shares open higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 5.08 points to 1,693.91 at 9:01am on Monday, with volume reaching 105.84 million lots worth RM30.96 million. Gainers beat losers 149 to 52, marking a positive start to the week.

site_title: Trump aide predicts 'hundreds of miles' of border wall by 2020
summary: US President Donald Trump's emergency declaration allows "hundreds of miles" of border wall construction, with Stephen Miller predicting around 200 miles by September 2020. The move, which Trump invoked to bypass Congress' funding, has sparked criticism from Democrats, rights groups, and some Republicans. California and other states are likely to file lawsuits against the project, and a resolution to block the action in Congress is uncertain. Trump is expected to veto any such resolution.

site_title: Australia's corporate regulator appeals Westpac court decision
summary: Australia's corporate regulator, the Australian Securities and Investments Commission (ASIC), has appealed a court decision that found Westpac Banking Corp did not breach its licence when it asked customers to shift their superannuation savings into the lender's accounts. The Federal Court had previously ruled that Westpac and its funds management division had failed to treat customers honestly, but the ASIC is seeking greater clarity on whether the bank broke its licence. The appeal aims to ensure the regulator's concerns are heard and to clarify the bank's obligations.

site_title: Singapore January non-oil exports fall 10.1% for worst showing in over 2 years
summary: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports (NODX) fell 10.1% in January, the largest decline in over 2 years, due to a 15.9% year-on-year drop in electronic product exports. The decline was attributed to contractions in exports of personal computers, disk media products, and integrated circuits. Economists warn of a potential seasonal low for electronics, but also point to broader weakness in external demand, particularly in petrochemicals. Despite this, the government is maintaining its growth forecasts for NODX at 0-2% for 2019.

site_title: Venezuela's Guaido calls for 'million volunteers' in aid standoff
summary: Venezuelan opposition leader Juan Guaido has called for a million volunteers to confront a government blockade preventing humanitarian aid from reaching the country. The aid, mostly from the US, has been stockpiled near the border with Colombia. Guaido aims to reach the volunteers by February 23, a month after he declared himself acting president. Despite Maduro's claims of a "political show" and US invasion, Guaido's efforts aim to bring aid to the country, where an imploding economy has driven 2.3 million Venezuelans to migrate and hyperinflation has made scarce food and medicine unaffordable for many.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on Monday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Monday, with the Nikkei 225 index rising 1.55% or 324.31 points to 21,224.94. The rally was driven by hopes for progress in US-China trade talks. In other markets, the S&P 500 and Nasdaq in the US also reached fresh records, despite tariff uncertainty. Meanwhile, Asia's stocks were boosted by mining and healthcare stocks, with Europe's markets also seeing gains.

site_title: Shell sets limit to how clean oil output can be in climate push
summary: Royal Dutch Shell has set targets to reduce its net carbon footprint by half by 2050 and has become the first oil major to include scope three emissions in its targets and reporting. Scope three emissions include indirect emissions from products consumed by others, accounting for 85% of Shell's overall carbon intensity. The company plans to achieve this goal through renewable energy investments, alternative fuels, and a shift towards natural gas. Shell will also set short-term targets every year, with a revised remuneration policy linking executive pay to climate performance.

site_title: UK airline flybmi collapses under fuel costs, Brexit pressures
summary: UK airline flybmi collapses under fuel costs and Brexit pressures, ceasing operations and filing for administration. The airline blamed spikes in fuel and carbon costs and uncertainty over Brexit for its financial difficulties. It operated 17 aircraft on 25 European routes and had 376 employees. The airline's parent company cited the inability to secure post-Brexit flying contracts and the uncertainty of future prospects as major factors in its collapse. The airline advised customers to seek refunds from credit card companies or booking websites.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary:
The Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights report covers the tanker and dry bulk market for the week of February 10-16, 2019. Key findings include: 
Capesize rates remained stable despite reduced Brazil exports, with higher bunker prices negating any increase in owners' returns. Panamax rates improved in the Pacific due to increased mineral volume, while Supramax and Handysize indices rose. Tanker rates surged in the US Gulf, with VLCC rates increasing to $6.65 million for a trip to South Korea.

site_title: Amazon's pullout is a blow to New York City's tech momentum
summary: Amazon's planned $3 billion corporate campus in Queens, New York, was scrapped after fierce opposition from local politicians and community organizers. The move is seen as a blow to the city's tech industry, which had been growing and was expected to cement New York's status as a top tech hub. The city had touted its diversity of talent and connections with established industries to attract Amazon. Despite Amazon's decision, other major tech companies such as Google, Twitter, Facebook, Uber, and Apple have a presence in the city, and the city's tech sector remains strong.

site_title: ECB rate move hinges on economic downturn's duration: Villeroy
summary: The European Central Bank's decision on its first post-crisis rate hike is uncertain due to the eurozone's slowdown, according to ECB policymaker Francois Villeroy de Galhau. The bank aims to keep interest rates at current record lows through the summer, but recent data may reduce chances for a hike after summer. Villeroy said the ECB will scrutinize economic data to determine if the slowdown is temporary or more durable, with a focus on domestic demand in Germany, France, and Spain. Policymakers will meet on March 7 to review growth and inflation projections.

site_title: MOE to unveil 'significant' effort to get Singaporeans learn for life
summary: Singapore's Ministry of Education (MOE) is set to unveil a significant effort to improve the education system, with a third thrust to be added to existing initiatives. The new thrust aims to help children from disadvantaged homes and will be a multi-year effort. The changes are being made in consultation with other fourth-generation leaders and are based on the principles of the SkillsFuture movement. The MOE has already introduced measures to reduce exam load and provide vocational and technical skills training.

site_title: Dovish Fed talk sends dollar lower, euro up
summary: The US dollar dropped 0.1% against a basket of six rivals after San Francisco Federal Reserve Bank president Mary Daly expressed doubts about a 2019 interest rate hike, citing a slowdown in economic growth and muted inflation. This dovish stance bolstered the euro, which rose 0.05% against the dollar. The euro had fallen to a three-month low earlier in the day, but rebounded as investors became more optimistic about the Fed's intentions. The dollar index fell to 96.901, marking a second week of losses.

site_title: Earnings in focus; TSH Corp completes RTO
summary: TSH Corp completes its reverse takeover (RTO) by the owners of Sloshed! Pte Ltd, acquiring a multi-concept chain of pubs and bars, spirits, wines, and liquors. The acquisition was completed on February 12, 2019, following a series of agreements and resolutions. Key individuals involved include Teo Kok Woon, non-executive non-independent director and controlling shareholder, and Chua Khoon Hui, CEO and executive director. The RTO marks a significant milestone for TSH Corp, which now operates five outlets under four different F&B concepts.

site_title: Money FM podcast: The Hot Seat: How does blockchain technology boost the supply chain?
summary: A Money FM podcast discusses how blockchain technology boosts supply chains. The episode highlights the benefits of using blockchain, including increased transparency, reduced counterfeiting, and improved tracking. Key companies, such as Grab and PwC, are also exploring AI and blockchain innovations. The conversation emphasizes the potential for blockchain to transform supply chain management and create more efficient, secure, and transparent systems.

site_title: Bankers are sick of choosing sides between Qatar and Saudi Arabia
summary: Bankers are re-evaluating ties with Qatar after Saudi Arabia's aggressive actions and policy changes, including the delay of Aramco's IPO. Executives from HSBC, Goldman Sachs, and other global banks are intensifying efforts to repair relations with Qatar's finance ministry and sovereign wealth fund. Decreasing tensions and the potential for lucrative deals in Qatar are encouraging bankers to normalize their activity with Doha. Qatar's finance minister and sovereign wealth fund are welcoming overtures from banks that are not aligned with Saudi Arabia, while maintaining cautiousness towards Saudi-aligned banks.

site_title: China-US trade talks 'making a final sprint': Chinese state media
summary: Chinese state media expressed cautious optimism over US-China trade talks, citing "step-by-step" progress after a week of discussions. US Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer and Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin met with President Xi Jinping, affirming progress made in previous talks. The talks are set to continue in Washington next week, with US duties on $200 billion in Chinese imports set to rise to 25% if no deal is reached by March 1. Both sides must work together to overcome obstacles and reach a mutually acceptable agreement.

site_title: The Opec+ oil deal is standing on one wobbly leg
summary: The Opec+ oil deal is showing signs of instability, with Saudi Arabia bearing a larger burden than expected, while Russia has failed to meet its pledged production cuts. Saudi Arabia reduced its output to 10.213 million barrels a day in January, exceeding its target, but announced plans to cut further to 9.8 million barrels a day in February, its lowest level since 2015. Russia, meanwhile, only managed a 42,000 barrel cut in January, far short of its target. The deal's future is uncertain, with the Opec+ group likely needing to extend its output restraint amid soaring US production and weakening global demand growth.

site_title: Upcoming figures for home sales, durable goods under scrutiny
summary: US stocks rose for the eighth straight week, driven by optimism over a grand bargain between the US and China and low Treasury yields. Despite weak economic data, including a 1.2% contraction in retail sales and a rise in unemployment tallies, investors attributed the reports to the government shutdown. A potential trade deal between the US and China could lead to a rally in the stock market, with some predicting a 5-10% rise in the S&P 500. However, resistance from the Democratic Congress and concerns about the impact on global growth remain.

site_title: Tin Men takes a shine to potential of IoT startup Overdrive
summary: Tin Men Capital, a Singapore-based venture firm, has invested $2.9 million in IoT startup Overdrive, a company that develops software to track and analyze data from moving assets. Overdrive has gained traction with clients in Singapore, Malaysia, Thailand, and the Philippines, and has seen its annual recurring revenue increase four times in the last two years. Tin Men Capital's involvement has helped Overdrive expand into new markets, including the commodities sector, where the startup has a first-mover advantage. The firm expects Overdrive to reach a milestone of building a customer success team within two years.

site_title: Bitter pill to swallow despite Olivia Lum's sweetener to small investors
summary: Hyflux has proposed a rescue deal to small investors, offering an implied recovery rate of 10.6% of their original investment, comprising a cash recovery of 3% and 7.6% implied equity value. This is less than the minimum 24.7% recovery rate expected by senior unsecured creditors. The deal involves forfeiting shares by Hyflux's boss Olivia Lum and board of directors to favor small investors, who will receive S$900 million in debt swapped for S$27 million in cash and a 10.26% equity stake. The deal still faces uncertainty, with a scheme meeting scheduled for April 5 to vote on the plan.

site_title: Tighter labour market, rising life expectancy and need for resources
summary: Singaporeans living longer, with average life expectancy set to reach 85.4 years by 2040, pose a challenge for the country's ageing workforce. Experts argue that raising CPF contribution rates for older workers could help them stay active and relevant in the job market, but it may also add to the cost borne by employers. Some believe a progressive approach, where rates are restored at specific ranges according to job responsibilities, could be feasible. Others advocate for a single CPF rate for all employees, regardless of age, to promote fairness and equality.

site_title: Sales of DR's Secret in China: Best World's best-kept secret?
summary: Best World International, the parent company of DR's Secret, has seen its shares soar 171% over the past 12 months, driven by strong growth in China. However, analysts have found it challenging to verify key sales data due to the company's unique business model in China. Best World has a limited direct-selling licence, but its skincare products are not sold through direct selling, instead, they are distributed to drugstores. The company's China subsidiary brings products into China, and franchisees pay upfront for inventory, allowing Best World to recognize revenue upfront.

site_title: Dialysis device startup Advent Access soothes kidney patients' pain
summary: Advent Access, a Singapore-based medical device startup, is developing a dialysis device called av-Guardian that guides a needle to a vein for hemodialysis treatment, reducing the risk of pain and wear and tear on the vein. The device, which is on the verge of CE mark approval, aims to enable patients to needle themselves, a significant step towards freeing them from nurses and infrastructure. Advent Access has also acquired a commercialized solution, Vwing Vascular Needle Guide, and is targeting the global dialysis market, which is expected to grow rapidly due to the increasing prevalence of kidney failure.

site_title: Singapore Life buys payments app amid fintech consolidation
summary: Singapore Life, an insurer, acquired the assets of payments app Yolopay, including its mobile application Canvas, for less than S$2 million. Canvas allows parents to control their children's pocket money and track expenses. The acquisition is part of Singapore Life's strategy to expand into wealth solutions and target parents looking for insurance. The company aims to integrate the app with public transport and existing mobile wallets. This move is seen as a tactical initiative to broaden Singapore Life's services in the finance space amid fintech consolidation.

site_title: Duterte signs bills to ease inflation, boost central bank powers
summary: Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte signed key economic bills to ease inflation and boost the central bank's powers. The measures include removing rice import caps, expanding the central bank's powers, and a partial tax amnesty. The rice law is expected to reduce inflation by about one percentage point, addressing the 6.7% inflation rate in September and October. The bills, signed on Friday, will take effect 15 days after publication, with the central bank's expanded powers aimed at strengthening the financial system.

site_title: SMEs must plug into digital economy to spur Singapore's economy: Iswaran
summary: Singapore's Minister for Communications and Information S Iswaran emphasized the importance of small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) plugging into the digital economy to drive growth. SMEs contribute 65% of Singapore's employment and 49% of its economy, making it critical for them to adapt to digital technologies. The government's digital readiness programme targets individuals and businesses, aiming to increase access to e-government services and boost productivity levels. Iswaran stressed the need for SMEs to "plug into the digital economy" to make a noticeable impact on the country's growth.

site_title: Thai GDP could give baht rally further boost
summary: Thailand's economy is expected to show robust growth, with data set to reveal a 3.6% annual growth rate in the fourth quarter, its 12th consecutive quarter of above 3% growth. This could further boost the Thai baht, which has outperformed regional peers this year, rising 4% against the dollar. A strong domestic economy, current-account surplus, and less vulnerability to external factors, including the US-China trade war, are key drivers of the baht's strength, according to analysts.

site_title: Lyft to woo investors with fast US growth in IPO race with Uber
summary: Lyft plans to pitch investors on its fast US growth, highlighting a 5% increase in US market share to 40%, surpassing Uber's market share. The ride-hailing company aims to become the first publicly listed company in the US with this growth. Lyft's IPO is seen as a competitive move against Uber, which has been the leader in the ride-hailing market.

site_title: EU flags come down in Brexit Britain
summary: The European Union flag is becoming less popular in the UK, with orders for the flag dropping by 90% since the country voted to leave the bloc in 2016. In contrast, orders for the Union Jack have increased by 75% since last summer. Experts attribute this trend to a desire for increased British identity and a decrease in latent patriotism. The EU flag was previously flown at government buildings, but this may change once the UK leaves the EU.

site_title: Theresa May to speak to every EU leader in bid to break Brexit deadlock
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May is urging Conservative MPs to unite over Brexit as she speaks to every EU leader this week. Following a disappointing parliamentary defeat, May called the vote "disappointing" but vowed to continue seeking changes to her EU divorce deal. She urged her party to "move beyond what divides us" and make compromises necessary to secure a deal. May's efforts come as Britain is due to leave the EU on March 29, with fears of a potential no-deal Brexit.

site_title: Singapore O&G posts lower Q4 profit on impairment
summary: Singapore O&G, a healthcare provider, reported a lower Q4 net profit of S$23,200 due to a goodwill impairment of S$2.8 million. Excluding the impairment, net profit would have been S$2.8 million, a 39.9% year-on-year increase. Revenue lifted 10.6% to S$8.8 million, driven by growth in Obstetrics & Gynaecology and Cancer-related segments. The group's full-year net profit increased 7.5% to S$9.1 million, driven by revenue growth of 16%.

site_title: Handbrake applied on the US dollar rally
summary: The US dollar has hit a six-month low against the Singapore dollar, reaching 1.3442 on January 31, 2019, due to the US Federal Reserve's dovish stance on monetary policies. However, prices have recovered in February due to escalating trade tensions between the US and China. Despite recent short-term gains, the downtrend remains intact, with prices trading below key support levels and technical indicators, such as the Stochastics Oscillator, affirming a continued downward trajectory. The US Federal Reserve's potential shift to looser monetary policies and muted inflation pressures in the US economy further support the bearish outlook.

site_title: Australia's TEG eyes Singapore as launchpad to S-E Asia
summary: TEG, an Australian ticketing and data analytics company, is launching Ticketek Singapore, listing events in Singapore, Malaysia, Philippines, Australia, and New Zealand. Managing Director Brendon Bainbridge sees Singapore as a "sophisticated and influential market" and a key launchpad for expansion into the wider South-east Asian region, aiming to capitalize on the country's large and growing market.

site_title: Markets wait on trade talk, Fed updates
summary: Markets await updates on trade talks and the Federal Reserve's meeting minutes, with Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat set to deliver the Budget 2019 speech in Singapore. The US and China continue trade talks, with progress reported but no comprehensive deal expected until H2 2019. The Fed is expected to maintain its patient stance, with a possible halt to the balance sheet run-off as early as this year. The Singapore dollar may receive a boost if trade figures surprise to the upside, while investors will scrutinize the FOMC minutes for rate hike indications.

site_title: Tensions rise at Air France-KLM over fate of Dutch unit's CEO
summary: Tensions rise at Air France-KLM over the fate of KLM's CEO Pieter Elbers, who has the support of managers and staff, but the new CEO Ben Smith wants to streamline management as part of an overhaul. A demonstration of support by over 25,000 employees and Dutch officials has sparked a revolt, with the Dutch government backing Elbers. Smith wants to join the KLM supervisory board and bring the carrier closer to Air France, but this move is opposed by some departments. The situation reflects long-simmering tensions between the French and Dutch carriers, which joined in a 2004 merger.

site_title: Starbucks to launch first all-day dining cafe in China
summary: Starbucks is launching its first all-day dining cafe in Shanghai, China, as part of its effort to revitalize growth in the country. The cafe will feature fresh Italian food and follows a slower growth period for the company in China, with transactions down 2% in its first quarter. China is expected to become a key market for coffee retailers due to low per-capita consumption and rising middle-class affluence. This move aims to "play the long game" in China, according to Starbucks China CEO Belinda Wong.

site_title: Citigroup CEO gets US$24m as compensation in 2018
summary: Citigroup CEO Michael Corbat received a 4.35% raise in 2018, bringing his total compensation for the year to US$24 million. His total compensation included a base salary of US$1.5 million, cash bonuses of US$6.75 million, equity awards of US$7.88 million, and long-term performance-based pay of US$7.88 million.

site_title: Govt introduced Net Investment Returns in 2009
summary: The Singapore government introduced the Net Investment Returns (NIR) framework in 2009, allowing it to spend up to 50% of the expected long-term real rate of returns on its relevant assets. This framework includes the Government Investment Corporation (GIC) and Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and was expanded to include Temasek in 2016.

site_title: Amazon places big bet on aspiring Tesla rival Rivian
summary: Amazon has invested $700 million in Rivian Automotive, a US electric pickup truck startup, in its biggest bet on the automotive sector. Rivian aims to produce a mass market electric pickup and is valued at $3-4 billion. The deal aims to bolster Amazon's logistics network with delivery vehicles and comes as Tesla struggles to stabilize production. Rivian plans to begin selling its R1T pickup by the end of 2020, with CEO RJ Scaringe citing a skateboard platform design for stability and storage.

site_title: Stock's volatility draws nine SGX queries in two years
summary: Best World, a Singapore-listed company, has been queried by the Singapore Exchange's surveillance team nine times since 2016 for unusual trading activity, with its shares surging 8.57% in one day without obvious news. The company's active lendable value has never exceeded 5.08% of its free float, averaging at 1.88% over the last two years. This suggests that shareholders, mostly controlled by founders Dora Hoan and Doreen Tan, do not lend their shares for short selling, despite the financial benefit.

site_title: Singapore's 3 banks celebrate CNY in style
summary: Singapore's three major banks, DBS, OCBC, and UOB, hosted large-scale Chinese New Year events, celebrating the Year of the Pig. UOB raised over S$1.67 million for local charities, while OCBC showcased SMEs and offered eco-friendly activities. DBS featured a lion dance, performances by a local charity, and a sustainability-focused dinner. The events aimed to promote giving and community spirit, benefiting local charities and organizations.

site_title: Qatar's real estate market faces reality check ahead of World Cup
summary: Qatar's real estate market is facing a reality check ahead of the 2022 FIFA World Cup. The market is expected to flood with new supply, putting pressure on prices, which have already declined by 10% in residential and 20% in office sectors. The Gulf boycott has reduced demand, while lower oil prices have contributed to a regional downturn. Despite this, Qatar plans to increase residential and office space by 50% and 40% respectively, partly due to expected demand from the World Cup.

site_title: Uber narrows losses, growth slows on the road to IPO
summary: Uber narrowed its quarterly loss to $865 million, down from $1.1 billion a year earlier, while revenue grew 25% to $3 billion. The company reported a 43% increase in full-year revenue to $11.3 billion and a 15% decrease in annual loss to $1.8 billion. Despite growth, Uber's growth slowed, and the company remains private as it prepares for a stock market debut. CEO Dara Khosrowshahi has promised greater transparency amid a wave of misconduct scandals.

site_title: Lee Radziwill, Jackie Kennedy Onassis's younger sister, dies at 85
summary: Lee Radziwill, the younger sister of Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis, has died at the age of 85, according to US media reports. She was a witness to history in the White House and had a star-studded life, marrying a prince and befriending notable figures such as Andy Warhol and Truman Capote.

site_title: Trump's border wall 'emergency' faces first legal challenge
summary: A nonprofit organization, Public Citizen, has filed a lawsuit to block President Trump's plan to divert $8 billion from the federal budget to fund his border wall, citing it as an abuse of executive power. The case, the first of many expected, challenges Trump's declaration of a national emergency, arguing it's not a response to an actual emergency but rather a long-running disagreement between the president and Congress. The lawsuit claims Trump's action is unconstitutional and will be challenged by state attorneys general and Congress.

site_title: Global Premium Hotels puts 23 hotels on market at S$1.4b
summary: Global Premium Hotels (GPH) is selling its 23 hotels, mostly under the Fragrance brand, at an indicative price of S$1.4 billion. The portfolio includes 21 Fragrance hotels and two Parc Sovereign hotels, spread across prime locations. GPH chairman James Koh said the group will consider offers only if the buyer takes all properties, and he expects interest from buyers. The hotels have been on the market since the second half of last year, with no takers yet, but Koh attributed this to the lack of interest in piecemeal sales rather than a lack of interest in the entire portfolio.

images.alt_text: GPH chairman James Koh, also founder, chairman and CEO of Fragrance Group, said it had received 'a couple of offers'. The properties have been on the market since the second half of last year.

site_title: DeClout selling 36.3m Procurri shares for S$12m
summary: DeClout, a Catalist-listed company, has agreed to sell 36.3 million Procurri shares to Novo Tellus PE Fund 2 for S$0.33 per share, raising S$12 million in net proceeds. The sale represents a 3% premium over the previous market price. DeClout plans to use the funds to repay borrowings and fund merger and acquisition activities. This sale follows a previous sale of 48 million Procurri shares in January for S$15.2 million, resulting in an accounting gain of S$0.5 million on the remaining shares.

site_title: Big investors shed tech stocks as markets tumbled last quarter
summary: Big investors, including those of the world's top tech giants, significantly reduced their bets on tech stocks in the last quarter, following a market downturn. Despite being a popular investment choice last year, sentiment shifted as investors dumped their shares. This reversal marks a significant change in the market's sentiment towards tech stocks, highlighting the volatility of the tech industry.

site_title: US-China trade talks to resume next week, Trump hints at extension
summary: US-China trade talks are set to resume next week in Washington, with the US and China reporting progress in five days of negotiations in Beijing. US President Donald Trump said he may extend the March 1 deadline for a deal and keep tariffs on Chinese goods from rising, but also stated that he would be "honoured" to remove tariffs if an agreement can be reached. The two countries agreed to a memorandum of understanding on trade and economic issues, with Chinese Vice Premier Liu He and US Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer leading the talks in Washington.

site_title: Porsche warns UK buyers of possible 10% hard Brexit price hike
summary: Porsche AG's UK unit has warned customers of a possible 10% price hike for imported cars if the UK makes a hard Brexit and their vehicle arrives after March 29. This move, a precautionary step, aims to allow customers to plan ahead. Customers who placed deposits before January 17 are unaffected. Porsche's decision highlights the potential ripple effects of a no-deal Brexit on the automotive industry, with the company importing all vehicles from EU states.

site_title: AusGroup seeks a balanced portfolio
summary: AusGroup, a construction and marine services provider, aims to achieve a balanced portfolio by diversifying its clients between the resources and liquefied natural gas (LNG) sectors. The company has secured several construction contracts in Australia's lithium sector, driven by the surge in demand from the lithium-ion battery industry. AusGroup's order book is comprised of tier one customers, including BHP, Rio Tinto, and Chevron Australia. The company expects to capture more opportunities in the lithium industry, with its CEO, Shane Kimpton, predicting five years of growth ahead.

site_title: Hyflux CEO to contribute entire stake to restructuring plan
summary: Hyflux CEO Olivia Lum has agreed to contribute her entire 267 million shares to the company's restructuring plan, which aims to overcome financial distress. The plan includes distributing preference shares and perpetual capital securities to all other holders upon completion. A consortium led by the Salim Group and Medco Group will take a majority stake in the company with a $391 million investment. The restructuring plan, which includes a scheme meeting, is scheduled to be heard in the Singapore High Court on Feb 21. This move is part of the company's efforts to overcome financial struggles after an ill-timed expansion into the energy business.

site_title: Millennium & Copthorne expects Brexit-led hiring crunch
summary: Millennium & Copthorne Hotels, a luxury chain with seven London properties, expects a hiring crunch due to Brexit, citing rising labour costs and sluggish demand. EU workers, which account for nearly half of its London workforce, are particularly affected. The company's performance was hampered by Brexit-related pressures, including a 7.4% decline in London RevPAR, and a partial closure of one of its hotels for refurbishment. This marks the first signals from listed firms in the hospitality industry to report Brexit-related workforce challenges.

site_title: Oasis Terraces mall opens in Punggol
summary: Singapore's Oasis Terraces mall in Punggol officially opened, marking the first of six new-generation neighbourhood centres developed with residents' feedback and the Housing and Development Board (HDB) as the landlord. The seven-storey mall features 106 shops, a 24-hour fitness centre, and a supermarket that stays open till 11pm, integrated with transportation nodes and sustainable features. The development is part of HDB's plan to upgrade 110 existing neighbourhood centres, with five more set to open in the next few years, including Buangkok Square in Hougang and Canberra Plaza in Sembawang.

images.alt_text: The mall, which is next to Oasis LRT station, is the first neighbourhood centre to have an integrated polyclinic and childcare centre, as well as sustainable features such as motion-sensor lighting and solar panels.

site_title: Trump says Japan's Abe nominated him for Nobel Peace Prize
summary: US President Donald Trump stated that Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe nominated him for the Nobel Peace Prize for his work with North Korea. Trump claimed Abe showed him a five-page letter nominating him for the prize, citing Japan's newfound "good" and "safe" feeling after North Korean ballistic missile launches ceased. However, the Japanese Defense Ministry's annual white paper described North Korea as still posing a "grave and imminent" threat. Trump and North Korean leader Kim Jong Un are set to hold a second summit on February 27-28 in Hanoi.

site_title: Singapore's trade crosses S$1 trillion for first time in 4 years
summary: Singapore's trade has crossed the S$1 trillion mark for the first time in 4 years, reaching S$1.1 trillion in 2018, driven by a 9.2% increase. However, growth is expected to ease to 0-2% in 2019, according to Enterprise Singapore. Non-oil domestic exports (NODX) growth slowed to 4.2% in 2018, and is expected to moderate further. The International Monetary Fund (IMF) projects a global economic slowdown, citing US-China tariffs and tightening financial conditions.

site_title: US stocks: Dow climbs for 8th straight week amid trade optimism
summary: US stocks rose for the 8th consecutive week, driven by optimism over US-China trade talks. The Dow Jones Industrial Average jumped 1.7% to 25,883.25, while the S&P 500 advanced 1.1% to 2,775.60. US President Donald Trump expressed confidence in trade negotiations, despite a government shutdown averted by a spending bill. The tech-rich Nasdaq Composite Index also rose 0.6% to 7,472.41, with broad-based gains in the Dow.

site_title: Structuring philanthropy to do more good
summary: Billionaire philanthropists, including Laura and John Arnold, are restructuring their giving to use limited-liability corporations (LLCs) instead of foundations, citing a need for more control over their philanthropic efforts. The shift is driven by the limitations of foundations, which can be restrictive in pursuing certain goals, such as impact investing and direct lobbying. By forming an LLC, the Arnolds and others can maintain flexibility and transparency while pursuing their philanthropic priorities, including politics and advocacy. This trend is expected to continue as a new generation of philanthropists seeks more control over their giving.

site_title: Ayondo shares in limbo pending clarity over unit's compliance with UK authority
summary: Ayondo, a social trading platform, is facing uncertainty over its UK subsidiary's compliance with the Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) due to a disagreement between auditors KPMG and Ernst & Young over the calculation of a key financial metric. If KPMG's views are adopted, it would negatively impact the subsidiary's financial strength. Ayondo plans to inject fresh capital into the subsidiary through a deal with BUX Holding to address concerns. Trading in Ayondo shares remains suspended pending clarity.

site_title: MTI: 2019 growth could slow to below mid-point of forecast range
summary: The Singapore economy experienced a slowdown in 2018, with a 3.2% growth rate, and is expected to cool further in 2019, potentially below the mid-point of the forecast range of 1.5% to 3.5%. The slowdown is attributed to global uncertainties, including Brexit and trade tensions, as well as a softer-than-expected slowdown in China. The manufacturing sector expanded by 7.2% in 2018, while the services sector grew by 3% and construction contracted. Relief measures in the upcoming Budget and the Monetary Authority of Singapore's policy meeting in April are being closely watched.

site_title: Reits
summary:
Here's a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

US mortgage rates have risen after five straight weeks of declines. A Q3 wave of condo launches in Singapore is expected to test demand for prime projects above S$3,000 psf. Manhattan rents have hit another record, with more increases anticipated. Goldman Sachs acquired 262 billion won hotel and retail assets in Seoul. UK homebuyer demand has rebounded to a six-month high, according to an index. New World Group is selling China property assets after securing a loan deal. WeWork has secured new tenants and filled more space at 21 Collyer Quay in Singapore.

site_title: Offer price for Courts 'not fair but reasonable', says KPMG
summary: KPMG has described Nojima Corp's offer of 20.5 Singapore cents for each Courts Asia share as "not fair but reasonable from a financial point of view". The offer price is at a 45.3% discount to the net asset value per share and a 0.55 times price-to-book multiple, falling outside comparable company ranges. Despite a 65% slump in share prices over the past 18 months, the offer is deemed reasonable due to the company's recent net loss and low trading volume. Courts' directors have recommended shareholders accept the offer.

site_title: Cisco invests S$25m in cybersecurity centre and first S-E Asian co-innovation hub in S'pore
summary: Cisco has invested S$25 million in a cybersecurity centre and co-innovation hub in Singapore, marking its first South-east Asian hub. The centre focuses on cybersecurity and the Internet of Things, aiming to address growing cyber threats in Asia. The move is supported by Singapore's Economic Development Board and aims to "close the key talent gap" in areas such as data analytics and managing SOCs. The hub will partner the government, industry players, and universities to address cybersecurity threats and promote Singapore's position as a global cybersecurity hub.

images.alt_text: Cisco's Singapore office has grown from a regional business headquarters into a hub to address growing cyber threats in Asia, according to Irving Tan.

site_title: Mercedes C-Class Cabriolet review: Convertible bond
summary: The Mercedes-Benz C 180 Cabriolet review highlights the car's appeal as a convertible despite its compromises. The car features a seamless roof-folding mechanism and a wind deflection system, providing a comfortable driving experience. However, it is heavier than the Coupe model, resulting in less urgency in acceleration and less precise handling. The ride is also less serene over poorly surfaced roads.
