The BBC's Americas bureau editor, Paul Danahar, criticized the lack of intervention by law enforcement, and the White House Correspondents' Association condemned the attack, calling for the president to make clear that violence against reporters is unacceptable.

site_title: Europe: Shares rise on trade talks optimism; Michelin inflates autos
summary: European shares rose 0.5% on Tuesday, driven by optimism around US-China trade talks and signs of a potential compromise to avoid a US government shutdown. Automotive stocks surged 2.9% after Michelin's better-than-expected results and operating profit pledge.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Chasing Cars: Pretty in red
summary: Money FM podcast "Chasing Cars" presents a Chinese New Year Special Edition, featuring picks for cars that look best in red. Hosts Julian Kho and Claressa Monteiro discuss their top choices, but no specific cars are mentioned in the provided article.

site_title: Debenhams secures £40m lifeline as it seeks financial and product revamp
summary: Debenhams secured a £40m lifeline from lenders to address its £360m debt amid dwindling sales. The company also struck a sourcing partnership with Li & Fung Ltd to boost quality and anticipate trends. Analysts suggest a company voluntary arrangement or debt restructuring may be the only way to cut rent bills and remain current on obligations. Debenhams shares rose 42% after the news, but the company still faces significant challenges in its financial and product revamp efforts.

site_title: DBS partners SMU on sustainability initiative
summary: DBS Bank has partnered Singapore Management University (SMU) on a sustainability initiative, committing over S$1 million. The DBS-SMU Sustainability Initiative will offer a major in sustainability, fund research, scholarships, and community engagement. The university's Lee Kong Chian School of Business will launch the major in 2019, supporting academics, businesses, and students focused on real-world sustainability challenges.

site_title: Airbus to give update on A380 shutdown plans: sources
summary: Airbus is nearing a decision to halt production of the A380 superjumbo, citing weak sales and stalled engine talks with Emirates. The company may provide an update on its plans during its full-year earnings on February 14. Airbus hopes to broker a deal with Emirates to switch part of its order to smaller models, while also securing a few last-minute A380 orders from British Airways. The fate of the A380, which has been in doubt since a key order from Emirates fell through, is expected to be decided by the Airbus board, which meets on Wednesday.

site_title: US: Stocks jump as shutdown, trade fears recede
summary: US stocks surged on Tuesday as President Donald Trump downplayed the chance of another government shutdown and hinted at delaying new tariffs on Chinese imports. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 1.5%, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also gained 1.3% and 1.5% respectively. Trump's comments came as the third round of trade negotiations with China were set to resume, with no new tariffs set to be imposed beyond March 1.

site_title: HDB launches 3,739 flats in first sales exercise of 2019
summary: The Housing and Development Board (HDB) launched 3,739 flats in its first sales exercise of 2019, comprising 3,162 Build-to-Order (BTO) flats and 577 Re-Offer of Balance Flats (ROF). Prices start from S$95,000 for a two-room flexi flat in Jurong West and S$523,000 for a four-room flat in Kallang Whampoa. Applications for BTO flats close next Monday, while ROF applicants can apply without specifying a preferred flat type or town.

site_title: HPH Trust posts Q4 net loss of HK$12.11b on huge impairment losses
summary: Hutchison Port Holdings Trust (HPH Trust) posted a net loss of HK$12.11 billion for Q4 2018 due to impairment losses of HK$12.29 billion. Excluding the losses, the trust would have recorded a net profit of HK$182.8 million. Revenue rose 5% to HK$3 billion, driven by a surge in US cargoes ahead of the US-China tariff. The trust's net asset value per unit fell to 3.07 HK cents, and it declared a distribution per unit of 8.48 HK cents.

site_title: Hyflux extends deadline to file proofs of claims to March 1
summary: Hyflux has extended the deadline for creditors and stakeholders to file their proofs of claims to March 1, up from the original February 15 deadline. The water treatment firm is undergoing debt restructuring. The new deadline allows for a two-week extension to facilitate the process ahead of scheme meetings.

site_title: Walmart, Google-backed Deliv end online grocery partnership
summary: Walmart and logistics firm Deliv have ended their same-day grocery delivery partnership, a setback for the retailer in its bid to compete with Amazon. The partnership, which began in 2018, struggled due to issues with order processing, with drivers often waiting 40 minutes or more to collect orders. Walmart cited the complexity of store operations and low order volumes as reasons for the decision. The retailer still partners with seven delivery firms, including DoorDash and Postmates, and plans to expand same-day grocery delivery to 1,600 US stores this year.

site_title: Tencent investment in Reddit sparks censorship worry in some users
summary: Reddit has raised $300 million at a $3 billion valuation, with a $150 million investment from Chinese technology giant Tencent. The funding will be used for international expansion and digital ad platform enhancements. The investment has sparked concerns about censorship, as Reddit is banned in China and some users have posted images of banned content, including Winnie the Pooh, in protest. Reddit co-founder Alexis Ohanian is married to tennis star Serena Williams and the site boasts over 330 million monthly users.

site_title: Thailand suspends TV channel linked to Thaksin ahead of poll
summary: Thailand's telecoms regulator suspended the operating license of Voice TV, a TV channel linked to ousted former Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra, citing national security concerns ahead of the March 24 general election. The suspension is due to two programmes that spread information causing public confusion and divisiveness. This move comes amid concerns over the junta's attempts to crack down on opponents. Voice TV's owner, Thaksin's children, has been shut down twice previously, and the channel's chief executive plans to appeal and demand damages.

site_title: Infrastructure players look for another Budget boost
summary: Singapore infrastructure players are seeking a budget boost to support regional infrastructure development. A national infrastructure bank or import-export bank could be a key solution, according to Boustead Singapore's senior vice-president Keith Chu. The government's Infrastructure Asia initiative, launched last year, aims to grow the regional infrastructure sector, but more stimulus is needed to encourage Singapore companies to take on outbound projects. The government may also consider a project preparation and capacity development fund to support smart cities and water and waste management projects. SMEs are also a key issue, with experts calling for better support and digitalization efforts.

site_title: China state-owned rail-car maker eyes Washington contract
summary: China's state-owned rail-car maker, China Railway Rolling Stock Corp (CCRC), is considering bidding for a $1 billion contract to build new rail cars for the Washington DC Metro, amid concerns over cybersecurity risks and economic conflicts. CCRC has a history of securing major US contracts, but its ties to the Chinese government have raised concerns among Metro board members and experts. The US and China have been at odds over cybersecurity and economic issues, with China accused of using connected technology for malicious purposes.

site_title: Yoma's bond issue: Baht what about Singapore?
summary: Yoma Strategic issued 2.2 billion Thai baht (S$95 million) bonds last month, choosing Thailand over Singapore for debt financing. The decision is attributed to Thailand's undervalued share price, allowing for lower equity financing costs. The bonds offer a 3.38% fixed rate and a 5-year tenor, making them more attractive than taking a loan from a bank in Myanmar at double-digit rates. The Singapore bond market still maintains its liquidity and appeal to foreign issuers, but Yoma's unique circumstances, including existing business ties with Thailand, made Thailand a more suitable destination for debt financing.

site_title: Work on final WTC tower may start without signed tenant
summary: Silverstein Properties, the developer of the World Trade Center, may begin construction on its final skyscraper, 2 World Trade Center, without a signed tenant. The 2.8 million-square-foot office building was started but halted due to a lack of a primary tenant. With a stronger US economy and leasing progress at neighboring towers, chairman Larry Silverstein believes it's a good time to start construction, which could be completed by 2022 or 2023. This marks the culmination of Silverstein's redevelopment efforts, which also built Towers 3, 4, and 7.

site_title: Climate change risks US bases, fuels social disorder: top admiral
summary: US military Admiral Philip Davidson warned that climate change will fuel social disorder and threaten US military bases, citing recent ecological disaster events. He concurred with the US intelligence community's assessment of climate change as a global threat. The Admiral expressed concern about the impact of climate change on the Indo-Pacific region, where US military operations are concentrated. This warning highlights the growing concern about the intersection of climate change and national security.

images.alt_text: Climate change and a deteriorating environment are likely to fuel social disorder and could threaten some US military bases, a top admiral said on Tuesday.

site_title: More fuel challenges ahead that need to be resolved
summary: The global sulphur cap implementation is facing numerous challenges, including the need to address fuel compatibility issues, the availability of compliant fuels, and the potential for teething problems during the transition. The International Maritime Organization (IMO) must finalize draft guidelines and agree on sulphur testing and verification procedures, while port state control authorities must also develop a clear approach to handling fuel non-availability reports (FONARs). The shipping industry is also preparing for further changes, including a 40% efficiency improvement by 2030 and a 50% reduction in greenhouse gas emissions by 2050.

site_title: Market dilemma: Goldilocks or bust?
summary: Investors are experiencing market turmoil as assets move erratically, with no clear indication of whether the "Goldilocks" economy is back or a recession is near. The US dollar is surging, small-cap stocks are performing well, and industrial metals are rising as global consumer demand slows. The shift in market sentiment has led to increased interest in dollar asset diversification, particularly in Asia. Experts predict massive growth in ETFs driven by retail investors in the region. Despite the uncertainty, the S&P 500 has reached a record high, with productivity gains seen as key to unlocking wealth creation.

site_title: Using fee war to redefine the ETF industry
summary: WILL RHIND, leader of GraniteShares Gold Trust, is redefining the ETF industry with a fee war, forcing down fees paid by investors. His fund's assets have grown to $458 million, up from $12 million a year earlier, after cutting fees to $1.749. Rhind aims to make his product stand on its own, saying "big companies get used to doing things in a certain way. But I think in the next 10 years it's going to be drastically different." This move is seen as a response to SPDR Gold MiniShares, launched by the World Gold Council, and has boosted GraniteShares' value.

site_title: Woman sues Lime after e-scooter mishap leaves her daughter in a vegetative state
summary: A 28-year-old security guard, Ashanti Jordan, is suing Lime after she suffered a catastrophic brain injury and is now in a persistent vegetative state after colliding with a car on a street in Fort Lauderdale, Florida. Jordan was following Lime's app instructions to ride on the street, despite the city allowing e-scooters on sidewalks. The lawsuit claims Lime's app encouraged users to break the law, leading to accidents. This incident comes after a 21-year-old was killed in a similar accident involving a Lime scooter in Texas, and raises concerns about the health risks associated with e-scooters.

site_title: Mobile payments have positive impact on business growth
summary: Mobile payments are increasingly displacing cash as the preferred means of settling transactions worldwide. By 2019, nearly 2.1 billion consumers globally used mobile wallets, with China accounting for over 60% of the world's mobile payment users. A study in Singapore found that the introduction of QR code technology to the PayLah! mobile wallet led to a doubling of transactions in both number and value, with a significant impact on small businesses and startups, including a 7% increase in debit and credit card sales for new ventures and 11% for new stores. This highlights the positive impact of mobile wallets on business growth, driving consumer traffic, consumption, and generating beneficial spillover effects.

site_title: JTC food factory goes on sale with S$18m guide price
summary: A JTC detached food factory in Singapore is on sale by private treaty at a guide price of S$18 million. The 16,234 sqm property, which includes a warehouse, production area, and office space, is being sold due to its owner's decision to sell its business. The factory is located in the "Chin Bee" Food Zone, surrounded by key food suppliers and manufacturers. The sale is expected to attract interest from the food and beverage industry, with the upcoming Enterprise MRT Station adding to its appeal.

site_title: Berlin chats with US on LNG imports while buying from Russia
summary: Germany will discuss importing liquid natural gas (LNG) from the US to reduce its dependence on Russian gas, amid concerns over the Nord Stream 2 pipeline's impact on European energy security. Economy Minister Peter Altmaier will meet US Deputy Energy Secretary Dan Brouillette on Tuesday, proposing regulatory changes to allow easier LNG imports. The move comes as eastern EU states and the US express concerns that the pipeline undermines their security, while Chancellor Angela Merkel has dismissed such fears, describing the project as "purely business".

site_title: A ray of sunlight at the end of the Venezuelan tunnel
summary: Venezuela's inflation rate, calculated at 139,839% per year, is the highest in recorded history, with the country's episode lasting 27 months. The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has forecasted 10,000,000% inflation for 2019, but the author argues this is exaggerated. The US has declared an economic embargo on Venezuela's state-owned oil company, Petróleos de Venezuela, and Venezuela has devalued its currency, the bolívar, in an attempt to align it with the black market rate. This move suggests a shift in the country's economic trajectory, with the black market premium turning negative, indicating a potential end to the country's economic death spiral.

site_title: Dollar set for biggest winning streak in two years
summary: The US dollar is on track for its longest winning streak in two years, with a nine-session gain, as investors seek safe-haven assets amid US-China trade talks and a tentative deal to avoid a US government shutdown. The dollar's value rose to 97.063, its highest level since February 2017, after the Fed signaled it would be "patient" before raising interest rates again. Economic data in Europe has deteriorated, and Brexit concerns have weakened the euro and pound, contributing to the dollar's surge.

site_title: Singapore condo resale prices down 0.3% in Jan: SRX
summary: Singapore's condo resale market cooled for the second consecutive month in January, with non-landed private residential resale prices down 0.3% from the previous month, according to SRX Property. This follows a 0.6% drop in December. Over 60 new private projects are set to be launched in 2019, indicating potential weakness in the private resale market.

site_title: Why a forward-looking Budget is needed
summary: Singapore's 2019 budget aims to maintain macroeconomic stability and address emerging challenges. With the country's economy growing at 2.79% per year, the government will focus on pre-emptive measures, such as prudent regulations and market cooling measures. The budget will also prioritize urbanization, investing in smart urban solutions and promoting e-commerce and digitalization. Key areas of expenditure include healthcare, education, and infrastructure development, while the government will work to strengthen its financial resources and promote micro-economic efficiency. The budget aims to ensure a resilient and sustainable business environment and address the impact of global trade protectionism.

site_title: HIV data leak: judgment call whether to disclose breach to affected persons and public, says Health Minister
summary: Singapore's Health Minister Gan Kim Yong stated that the government's decision on disclosing the HIV Registry data breach in 2016 was influenced by the lack of evidence the information had been disseminated to the public and the sensitivity surrounding HIV status.

site_title: Dedicated body to level up corporate governance standards
summary: Singapore has established a permanent, industry-led body to "level up" corporate governance standards and practices. The 18-member Corporate Governance Advisory Committee (CGAC) was unveiled by the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and will act as an advocacy body, advising on corporate governance issues and providing recommendations to strengthen investors' confidence in the capital markets. The CGAC will not hold regulatory powers but will identify risks to corporate governance and monitor international trends. Its role is to promote good corporate governance practices and uphold Singapore's reputation as a trusted international financial centre.

site_title: Malaysia to double palm oil used in transport biodiesel to 20% in 2020
summary: Malaysia aims to double the palm oil content in transport biodiesel to 20% by 2020 to cut record stockpiles and boost prices. The government also plans to raise the palm oil content in biofuel for the industrial sector to 10% from 7% starting next July. This move is expected to lift the use of palm oil in biofuels to 1.3 million tonnes annually. The government plans to set up a biofuel stabilisation fund to manage the price of biofuels, similar to Indonesia's export levy fund.

site_title: A hard Brexit will not fundamentally impair UK-Singapore trade: Chan Chun Sing
summary: Singapore's Ministry of Trade and Industry (MTI) assesses that a hard Brexit will not fundamentally impair UK-Singapore trade, according to Minister for Trade and Industry Chan Chun Sing. Three scenarios were presented, including one where the UK and EU agree on a withdrawal agreement, and another where the UK leaves the EU without a deal, which would not impact the trading relationship between the two countries. MTI will continue to work with Singapore firms to address near-term disruptions and strengthen trade and investment relations with the UK.

site_title: Singapore bourse dips on weak retail sales data
summary: The Singapore bourse ended the day down 0.16% due to weak retail sales data, which showed a 6% year-on-year decline in December and a 0.7% slump for 2018. The Straits Times Index fell 5.12 points to 3,201.15.

site_title: Theresa May seeks more time from MPs to hold Brexit talks
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May asked MPs to grant her more time to renegotiate the Brexit deal with the EU, just weeks before the March 29 departure date. She emphasized the need for lawmakers from all parties to back the deal, citing the need to pass further legislation to prepare for Britain's exit. May also hinted at the possibility of seeking an extension to the Article 50 exit negotiation period if the deal is not approved, and promised to speed up the ratification of the deal if time is too short.

site_title: Shanghai Turbo Enterprises board control challenge fails
summary: Shanghai Turbo Enterprises' board control challenge fails after shareholders voted against the removal of non-executive director Daniel Liu Danjun and the appointment of four new directors. The decision was made at an extraordinary general meeting, following a requisition by shareholder Zhang Ping. The company plans to file an appeal against the Singapore High Court's dismissal of its application to restrain former executive director Liu Ming from requisitioning or convening EGMs. This move comes as Shanghai Turbo continues its legal battle with Liu Ming, who was voted off the board in April 2017.

site_title: NTUC calls for higher wage supplements for younger low-wage workers
summary: NTUC has called for higher wage supplements for younger low-wage workers under the Workfare Income Supplement (WIS) scheme. Currently, payouts increase with age, but NTUC assistant secretary-general Zainal Sapari suggests making payouts the same across age groups based on income. He also recommends raising the cash component of the payout to 80% and increasing the monthly income ceiling to qualify for the scheme. The NTUC also wants to extend the mandatory progressive wage model to more sectors to address income inequality.

site_title: The yield curve explained: Is it predicting recession?
summary: The yield curve, which compares the interest rates of long- and short-term US Treasury bonds, has inverted, signaling a potential recession. This has occurred five times in the last four decades, preceding each recession. Despite the inversion, Schroders' economists do not expect a recession in 2019, citing a gradual slowdown in US growth. They predict interest rates could peak at 2.75% and believe the US economy is heading towards a moderate growth period, similar to the past decade. The yield curve inversion is just one leading indicator of a potential recession, and other factors will influence the Fed's response.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Mapletree Industrial Trust proposes a private placement of 90.44 million new units, valued at S$175 million, to refinance an acquisition and cover placement fees. Swissco Holdings' subsidiaries have had their schemes of arrangement approved, and Advance SCT has been renamed Citicode Ltd. Hiap Hoe expects a loss for the fourth quarter of FY2018 due to fair value changes. The Singapore public offer for NTT DC Reit was oversubscribed 9.8 times, and Creative Technology warns of potential revenue shortfall and operating loss.

site_title: Security tokens can shape future of wealth management in SE Asia
summary: Security tokens are digital representations of ownership over real assets, such as funds, equity, debt, or physical assets, and can provide superior access and liquidity through blockchain technology. The concept of security token offerings (STOs) backed by real assets is expected to shape the future of wealth management in Southeast Asia, particularly for young, digitally savvy, and affluent investors. With the potential to democratize access to over $100 trillion of illiquid assets, security tokens can improve liquidity, reduce settlement time, and increase transparency in the asset management industry.

site_title: Australia cattle giant warns of 'extreme losses' from floods
summary: Australia's largest cattle company, Aster, has warned of "extreme losses" due to record-breaking floods in Queensland state. Heavy rains over two weeks have resulted in over 300,000 cows being drowned or washed away, after five years of drought. The floods have turned parched land into vast mud swaths, bogging down weakened cattle.

site_title: Oil up on Opec cuts and sanctions against Venezuela, Iran
summary: Oil prices rose amid Opec-led supply cuts and US sanctions on Iran and Venezuela, with US West Texas Intermediate crude futures at $52.69 per barrel and International Brent crude futures at $61.89 per barrel. However, analysts expect US supply surges and economic growth concerns to keep markets in check, with some predicting a potential economic slowdown and oversupply in the US.

site_title: CBRE appoints new Singapore MD, S-E Asia chairman and chief operating officer
summary: CBRE has appointed Pauline Goh as chairman for South-east Asia, focusing on client accounts, and Moray Armstrong as managing director of the Singapore business. Vikram Kohli has taken over as chief operating officer for the entire South-east Asia region. The appointments come as the company aims to grow its business in Singapore and the region, with Armstrong highlighting opportunities to expand advisory services and harness innovation in proptech.

site_title: Freehold commercial building for sale with S$25m guide price
summary: A freehold four-storey commercial building near Jalan Besar MRT station in Singapore is up for sale with a guide price of S$25 million. The property, 7 Hindoo Road, has a 15m wide frontage and a gross floor area of about 13,970 sq ft. With commercial zoning, foreigners are eligible to purchase, and the sale does not impose additional buyer's stamp duty or seller's stamp duty. The building's layout and ceiling height make it suitable for various uses, including food-and-beverage businesses, showrooms, and medical suites, subject to authorities' approval.

site_title: Frasers Property's Q1 net profit jumps 76% to S$145.6 million
summary: Frasers Property posted a 76.1% increase in Q1 net profit to S$145.6 million, driven by residential development sales in Australia and China, as well as an enlarged recurring income asset base. Revenue rose 44.7% to S$1.08 billion.

site_title: SIAS's Hyflux rap: A wake-up call for corporate Singapore
summary: The Securities Investors Association (Singapore) has issued a strongly-worded statement to Hyflux Ltd's board, calling for answers on the company's financial position and future plans. The association has asked 33 questions, including those regarding the company's remuneration package, asset valuations, and board awareness of financial issues. This move comes as part of a broader push for improved corporate governance in Singapore, following the incorporation of the Singapore Exchange regulatory entity SGX Regco and the revision of the Singapore Code of Corporate Governance.

site_title: Egypt dangles incentives to draw more investors to its energy industry
summary: Egypt is finalizing a new oil and gas contract to attract more foreign investment, offering incentives for exploration in undeveloped areas. The contract aims to improve the cost-recovery process, making it faster, less bureaucratic, and more efficient. The government plans to launch a new bid round in the Red Sea this quarter and award over a dozen concessions. The overhaul is part of a broader plan to liberalize Egypt's energy industry, with the goal of becoming a gas re-exporting hub on the doorstep of Europe.

site_title: Zilingo reportedly near 'unicorn' status after US$226m Series D round
summary: Zilingo, a Singapore-based fashion and lifestyle products platform, has raised US$226 million in a Series D funding round led by Sequoia Capital, valuing the company at US$970 million. The funds will be used to invest in infrastructure and technology to digitize the fashion and beauty supply chain and expand in key markets. Revenue grew four times in the last 12 months, and the company aims to cut out middlemen in the supply chain and make it more tech-enabled. Zilingo plans to list in the future, with its CEO stating that the company is "definitely think[ing] of ourselves as a company that will be profitable soon and can potentially consider an IPO."

site_title: Valuetronics Q3 profit up 2.6% on lower income tax expense
summary: Valuetronics Holdings reported a 2.6% increase in third-quarter net profit to HK$59.7 million, driven by a 24.2% decline in income tax expense. Revenue fell 7.5% to HK$729.6 million, mainly due to a 26.4% decrease in its consumer electronics segment. The company attributed the decline to weaker performance from its smart lighting products. Despite the uncertainty caused by trade tensions, Valuetronics expects to remain profitable for the 2019 financial year.

site_title: Interfaith champion Siti Noor Mastura named Singaporean of the Year
summary: Siti Noor Mastura, 29, a champion for interfaith work, has been named Singaporean of the Year 2018 for her efforts through non-profit organisation Interfaith Youth Circle and Back2Basics, which delivers free halal groceries. She beat 10 finalists for the award, now in its fourth year.

site_title: Annual retail sales fall for the first time in five years
summary: Singapore's retail sales fell 0.7% in 2018, marking the first annual decline in five years, according to the Department of Statistics. Analysts attribute the drop to a slowdown in the economy and declining car sales, with stricter emissions rules kicking in in 2018. Retailers' full-year performance was also affected by a worse-than-expected festive period, with sales sliding 6% in December. Experts warn that support for retail will depend on the local labour market, and a weaker labour market could lead to a sharper decline in 2019.

site_title: Frasers Property Q1 net profit jumps 76%
summary: Frasers Property reported a 76.1% increase in Q1 net profit to S$145.6 million, driven by sales of residential development projects in Australia and China. Revenue rose 44.7% to S$1.08 billion, boosted by contributions from UK business parks and Singapore investments. Earnings per share increased to 4.74 Singapore cents, while no dividend was declared. CEO Panote Sirivadhanabhakdi stated plans for new property launches in Singapore and Australia, as well as enhancing investment property performance.

site_title: Trump orders US administration to prioritise AI
summary: US President Donald Trump has ordered the US administration to prioritize artificial intelligence, but the executive order stops short of specific funding or a detailed strategy. The American AI Initiative aims to fuel AI innovation, devoting federal resources to help the US stay competitive with China, which is investing heavily in AI. Experts say the move is timely but lacks clear implementation, and a comprehensive AI strategy is needed to address issues like digital free trade and data collection policies.

site_title: Saudi king reaffirms support for Palestinian state
summary: Saudi King Salman reaffirmed the kingdom's commitment to an independent Palestinian state with east Jerusalem as its capital during a meeting with visiting Palestinian President Mahmud Abbas. The pledge comes ahead of a US-led conference on Middle East peace and security, where US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo is expected to offer hints of the US proposals. The conference, scheduled for Poland, has toned down the agenda to focus on broader Middle East issues, with US President Donald Trump's son-in-law Jared Kushner set to make a rare speaking appearance.

site_title: Widening snowstorm, freezing rain to snarl travel in eastern US
summary: A widening snowstorm with freezing rain is causing travel disruptions in the eastern US, with hundreds of flight cancellations and school closures reported. The storm, expected to reach New York and Boston, could bring up to 30cm of snow and 10cm of ice in some areas. The National Weather Service warns of the danger of snow changing to freezing rain, leading to accidents. Over 1,600 flights have been cancelled, and New Jersey Governor Phil Murphy has declared a state of emergency ahead of the storm.

site_title: The catastrophic costs of a Brexit brain drain
summary: The UK's withdrawal from the European Union may lead to a significant brain drain, as top professionals, including bankers, doctors, and academics, leave London in search of better opportunities. This phenomenon is reminiscent of the 17th-century Edict of Nantes, which forced Huguenots to flee France, resulting in a catastrophic loss of human capital for the country. History suggests that countries with the highest-skilled workers will have an advantage in the 21st-century technology race, and the UK's departure from the EU may ultimately harm its economic and international influence.

site_title: Insurance new business premiums up a modest 3% in 2018
summary: Singapore's life insurance industry saw modest growth in 2018, with total weighted premium increasing 3% to S$4.19 billion, despite market uncertainty and volatility. Sales of single-premium linked plans fell 64% and CPF-included single-premium products fell 62%. Total sum assured rose 7% to S$140 billion, bridging the protection gap. However, health insurance premiums rose 13%, and insurers continue to face underwriting losses due to rising claims. The industry is adapting to changing market conditions, with a focus on providing solutions to meet Singaporeans' insurance and savings needs.

site_title: Russia expects to recover far less from 'bad bank' assets
summary: Russia is drastically reducing its estimate of assets it expects to recover from a "bad bank" set up after the collapse of three major lenders. The central bank initially hoped to recover 40-60% of the value of 2 trillion roubles (S$41.35 billion) assets transferred to Trust Bank, but new calculations are expected to reveal a much lower recovery rate.

site_title: First US coal plant in years to open where no options exist
summary: The University of Alaska Fairbanks is set to open the first US coal-fired plant in years, a 17-megawatt generator built for $245 million near the state's only coal mine. The plant's opening in April is a rare bright spot for US coal miners, who have seen 18 coal plants close in 2018 and are expected to lose 14 more this year. The project is an isolated situation, with analysts stating that the future of power in the US does not include coal, and the plant's emissions are expected to be lower than its predecessor.

site_title: US job openings jump to record 7.3 million in December
summary: US job openings surged to a record high of 7.3 million in December, surpassing the previous high since 2000. This increase, led by vacancies in construction, accommodation, and food services, may signal a labor shortage. The job openings rate rose to 4.7% from 4.6% in November, while hiring rose to 5.9 million. Economists expect job growth to slow to 150,000 per month this year due to a growing scarcity of workers.

site_title: US home-price gains slow in Q4 as inventory jumps
summary: US home prices rose 4% to a median of $257,600 in Q4, but at a slower pace than the previous quarter. Inventory jumped 6.2% to 1.55 million homes available for sale, contributing to slower sales. Purchases declined in all four regions, with the West experiencing a 14% drop. Despite price increases in 92% of markets, only 14 metropolitan areas saw double-digit gains, down from 18 in Q3.

images.alt_text: Home-price gains in the US slowed in the fourth quarter as more listings flooded onto the market.

site_title: SBS Transit posts record earnings; hikes dividend
summary: SBS Transit, a subsidiary of ComfortDelGro, has reported a 70% surge in net profit to S$80.1 million for the 12 months to Dec 31, 2018, driven by government bus contracts. Revenue rose 16.1% to S$1.38 billion, while operating costs increased 13.6%. The company has recommended a final dividend of 7.1 Singapore cents a share. Its total equity rose 10.9% to S$498.4 million, and it posted a net cash inflow of S$27.4 million. SBS Transit expects public transport revenue to continue growing, with bus turnover expected to be higher due to new government contracts.

site_title: It's not xenophobia that links the 'new populists'. It's hypocrisy
summary: The article argues that the common trait among populist politicians, including Donald Trump, Viktor Orban, and Marine Le Pen, is not xenophobia or nationalism, but rather hypocrisy. These leaders are not genuine representatives of the people, but rather con artists who profit from the Western system. They use populist rhetoric to manipulate public sentiment and advance their own interests, rather than genuinely addressing the concerns of their constituents. The article suggests that this hypocrisy has been overlooked by many analysts and that a deeper understanding of their motivations is necessary to understand their actions.

site_title: US small business confidence falls to more than two-year low
summary: US small business confidence has fallen to its lowest level in over two years, according to the National Federation of Independent Business. The Small Business Optimism Index dropped 3.2 points to 101.2 in January, the weakest reading since November 2016. This decline coincides with growing uncertainty over the economic outlook, partly due to the longest partial shutdown of the federal government in history. The uncertainty index jumped 7 points, with small business owners expressing concerns about recession risk and future sales growth.

site_title: TSH shares end 18% lower following completion of RTO
summary: TSH Corp, a Singapore-based company, completed a reverse takeover (RTO) by the owners of Sloshed!, a pub and liquor group, and listed on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) on its first day of trading. TSH shares ended 18.42% lower at 31 Singapore cents, down seven cents. The company has a market capitalization of approximately S$13.5 million. CEO Chua Khoon Hui stated that the listing will enhance visibility and access to capital markets, supporting the company's growth plans.

site_title: Xiaomi, Meituan among dual-class stocks to join MSCI indexes
summary: Nine companies with dual-class shares, including Xiaomi and Meituan, will join the MSCI All-Country World Index, effective February 28. The addition comes after MSCI temporarily blocked such firms in 2017 and 2018. The inclusion of Chinese companies Tencent Music Entertainment Group and others, alongside US firms KKR & Co and Altice USA, aims to allow companies with weighted voting rights to stay in the benchmarks. The move aims to balance corporate governance advocates' concerns with supporters' arguments that such shares enable long-term focus.

site_title: Next autumn looks sexy and colourful
summary: New York Fashion Week showcased vibrant autumn and winter trends, with designers like Prabal Gurung, Longchamp, and Christian Siriano presenting bright and sexy collections. Gurung drew inspiration from Nepal, featuring colorful prints and sari draping, while Longchamp emphasized leather and short skirts. Siriano, a champion of diversity, stunned the audience with evening gowns and featured curvy model Ashley Graham as the showstopper. Meanwhile, Federico Pignatelli is pushing for a models' "bill of rights" to protect their rights and fair pay.

images.alt_text: No monochromatics or tone-on-tone ensembles (left) - purple or mustard yellow and turquoise, red and pink - women should use their imagination in Prabal Gurung's world. At Longchamp (centre), designer Sophie Delafontaine kept it classy but sexy - embracing pleated short skirts, black studded leather and lots of looks in black and white. Curvy model Ashley Graham (right) closed the show in a transparent silvery confection by Christian Siriano as the audience cheered. Siriano worked his magic, unveiling a series of evening gowns in silver, black, white and deep blue.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher on trade hopes, progress to avert govt shutdown
summary: US stocks opened higher on Tuesday as lawmakers reached a deal to avoid a government shutdown and US-China trade talks showed optimism. The Dow Jones rose 98.92 points, the S&P 500 gained 12.81 points, and the Nasdaq Composite increased 50.95 points. The positive start comes despite ongoing trade uncertainty and President Trump's recent threats to extend the tariffs. Investors are cautiously optimistic about the potential for progress in US-China talks.

site_title: Indian lawmakers urged to summon global heads of Facebook, other tech giants
summary: Indian activists have petitioned a parliamentary panel to summon the heads of Facebook, Google, and other tech giants, including WhatsApp and Instagram, to discuss tax compliance, data privacy, and safeguarding citizens' rights. The petition comes ahead of India's elections, where Prime Minister Narendra Modi is seeking re-election. The panel has previously summoned Twitter chief Jack Dorsey, and the global heads of tech firms are expected to be questioned about their policies and practices in India. The move aims to increase scrutiny on social media companies and curb misinformation.

site_title: UK must regulate power of Facebook over news: report
summary: The UK government should regulate Facebook's power over the news industry, according to a report. The Cairncross Review recommends that companies like Google and Facebook promote quality journalism and be subject to regulatory scrutiny. The report also suggests measures to support local and investigative reporting, such as value-added tax relief, subsidies, and an independent Institute for Public Interest News. The UK's Department for Digital, Culture, Media and Sport is considering how to sustain high-quality journalism in a changing market.

site_title: Japan among 40 nations to back UN draft regulation on braking systems
summary: Forty countries, including Japan, have agreed on a UN draft regulation for advanced emergency braking systems (AEBS) for new cars and light commercial vehicles starting early 2020. The regulation will impose strict requirements for automatic braking at speeds up to 60 km/h to save lives in urban settings. There will be no obligation to retrofit older vehicles. The regulation aims to reduce crashes and save lives, with the system activating the brake to stop a crash and not drive.

site_title: Shanghai Turbo Enterprises board control challenge fails
summary: Shanghai Turbo Enterprises' board control challenge has been unsuccessful. Shareholders voted against the removal of director Daniel Liu Danjun and the appointment of four new directors. The company intends to file an appeal against a Singapore High Court ruling that blocked a former executive director, Liu Ming, from requisitioning a general meeting to remove directors or take control of the company. The outcome may impact the company's management and direction.

site_title: DHL hires hundreds of customs staff to prepare for no-deal Brexit
summary: Deutsche Post DHL has hired hundreds of customs staff to prepare for a potential no-deal Brexit, with new tariffs and clearance procedures expected to be imposed on March 29. The company is recruiting 50 new workers a week to process customs paperwork at its hubs, recognizing the importance of customs in a no-deal scenario. CEO John Pearson stated that DHL would be more ready than others if a no-deal Brexit were suddenly announced, as the company transports goods between the EU and Britain by air and road.

site_title: Mnuchin in Beijing for crunch US-China trade talks
summary: US Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin arrived in Beijing for high-level trade talks with China, aiming to strike a deal by March 1. Mnuchin will be joined by US Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer and World Bank nominee David Malpass. Chinese officials, led by Vice Premier Liu He, will also participate in the negotiations. The talks follow a three-month suspension of US tariffs on $200 billion of Chinese imports, which was put in place to allow for negotiations. Global economic concerns have raised pressure on policymakers to reach a deal.

site_title: May asks MPs for more time to hold Brexit talks
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May asked MPs for more time to renegotiate the Brexit deal with the EU, citing the talks' "crucial stage" and the need to protect workers' and environmental rights. She promised a series of parliamentary votes on February 27 if the government fails to secure changes by then. May reiterated that a customs union is not the solution to securing agreement, and expressed confidence that a deal can be reached that MPs can support, allowing for a Brexit departure date of March 29.

site_title: JTC food factory goes on sale with S$18m guide price
summary: A JTC detached food factory in Singapore has been put on sale by private treaty at a guide price of S$18 million. The property, located near the future Enterprise MRT Station, has a land area of 16,234 square metres and a 60-year lease with approximately 14 years remaining. The factory is zoned as "Business 2" and features modern office space, warehouses, and loading bays. The sale is expected to attract interest from the food and beverage industry due to its proximity to key suppliers and manufacturers.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary:
Here's a 100-word summary of the article content:

Brokers have initiated buy recommendations for ESR-REIT and Manulife US Real Estate Investment Trust. ESR-REIT is expected to benefit from its sponsor strength and economies of scale, with a 1-3% improvement in industrial sector rents and occupancy. Manulife US Reit's share price rallied due to concerns over its tax structure, and brokers maintain a "buy" call with a target price of US$0.92. Both stocks offer attractive yields and have potential for re-rating through mergers and acquisitions. The brokers' target prices are based on a 5-year dividend discount model and are 10-170 basis points higher than their peers.

site_title: Thailand suspends TV channel linked to ex-PM Thaksin ahead of poll
summary: Thailand's National Broadcasting and Telecommunications Commission suspended the operating licence of Voice TV, a TV channel linked to ousted former Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra, citing national security concerns. The suspension comes weeks ahead of the March 24 general election, where Thaksin's followers will compete against pro-military Prime Minister Prayuth Chan-ocha. The regulator cited two programmes on Voice TV as causing public confusion and divisiveness, and the channel's chief executive has vowed to appeal and seek damages.

site_title: Saudi business is about to get more complicated for EU banks
summary: The European Union is set to tighten controls on illicit financial flows, requiring EU banks to apply additional checks on clients from 23 countries, including Saudi Arabia, Panama, and the US Virgin Islands, deemed high-risk for terrorist financing and money laundering. The European Commission will sign off on the list, which will be subject to continuous monitoring and revisions. EU banks will need to gather more background information and verify the legitimacy of conducted business with these countries, following a string of money-laundering cases involving major banks.

images.alt_text: The move, to be announced by EU Justice Commissioner Vera Jourova, follows a string of money-laundering cases involving some of the bloc's biggest banks, highlighting shortcomings in the EU's framework.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets open brightly
summary: Europe's stock markets opened brightly on Tuesday, driven by optimism over US-China trade talks and a potential Washington shutdown deal. London's FTSE 100 rose 0.4%, while the Paris CAC 40 and Frankfurt's DAX 30 jumped 0.8% and 1.0%, respectively. This follows a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks, where investors seem to be brushing off new Trump threats. The focus remains on US-EU trade talks and the potential for a fresh economic boost.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks edge up at close
summary: Hong Kong stocks edged up 0.10% on Tuesday, driven by investors' hopes for US-China trade talks and a potential deal to avert a US government shutdown. The Hang Seng Index rose to 28,171.33, while the Shanghai Composite Index gained 0.68% to 2,671.89. The Shenzhen Composite Index also increased 1.20%. The gains were seen as a positive sign for the region's markets, which have been influenced by US-China trade tensions and uncertainty.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's retail sales dropped 6% in December, resulting in a 0.7% full-year decline. The city-state also established its first permanent advocacy body for corporate governance. Meanwhile, various companies, including Hyflux and Mapletree Industrial Trust, announced significant developments, such as debt restructuring and private placements. Globally, countries like Vietnam and Malaysia reacted to US tariff announcements, while China's GDP growth is expected to slow, and the UK economy shrank for the second consecutive month.

site_title: Barclays may use buyback to mute raider attack, analysts say
summary: Barclays may unveil plans to increase shareholder payouts in response to activist Edward Bramson's criticism of its investment-banking performance. Analysts expect the bank to return surplus capital to improve returns, potentially through a 500-million-pound buyback. Barclays' investment bank is expected to report lackluster results, with trading revenues forecast to decline. The bank may also need to make an "incremental Brexit uncertainty top-up" to its impairments. Barclays' earnings report is set for Feb. 21, and the bank's capital return strategy is expected to be a key aspect of the announcement.

site_title: The remote island sitting on US$58b of gold and copper
summary: A mining company, Bougainville Copper Ltd (BCL), claims interests in a Pacific island's copper and gold reserves worth US$58 billion, but its rights are threatened by proposed legislation that could grant mining leases to a new company. The Panguna mine, which was shut in 1989 amid clashes that killed 20,000 people, could reopen after seven to eight years and US$5 billion to US$6 billion in investment. The proposed changes to mining law come as Bougainville moves towards an independence referendum, which may seek new revenue streams.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Tuesday afternoon at 3,202, down 0.13% on day
summary: Singapore stocks declined 0.13% to 3,202.00 as of 1:03pm on Tuesday, with 186 losers outweighing 129 gainers. The most actively traded stock, Rex International, gained 2.22%. The Straits Times Index (STI) had previously rallied 0.4% on Thursday.

site_title: Singapore forms advocacy body to level up corporate governance standards
summary: Singapore has established its first permanent industry-led body, the Corporate Governance Advisory Committee (CGAC), to promote good corporate governance practices and strengthen investors' confidence in the city-state's capital markets. Chaired by Singtel's Bobby Chin, the 18-member committee will identify risks, advocate for good governance, and monitor international trends. The CGAC will not have regulatory powers and will work closely with existing regulators to uphold corporate governance standards.

site_title: Tokyo's Nikkei closes up 2.61% on cheap yen, shutdown deal
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei 225 index rose 2.61% to 20,864.21 following reports that US lawmakers agreed to avoid a government shutdown, and the market benefited from a cheaper yen. The broader Topix index also increased 2.16% to 1,572.60. The gains come amid ongoing US-EU trade talks and a rally in Asian stocks.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks climb on improved risk appetite; won edges higher
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index rose 9.74 points, or 0.45%, to 2,190.47 on Tuesday, driven by improved risk appetite and eased political uncertainties from the US. The Korean won edged higher, while bond yields rose. Gains in electric shares, including Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix, contributed to the market's upbeat tone. The Kospi is up 6.8% so far this year.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Tuesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 1.15 points to 1,687.41. The market saw a gainers-to-losers ratio of 425 to 406, with 2.7 billion lots traded worth RM2 billion.

site_title: Japan's Olympic poster girl Ikee diagnosed with leukaemia
summary: Japan's Olympic swimmer Rikako Ikee, 18, has been diagnosed with leukaemia, according to a tweet by the athlete. Ikee, known for her record six gold medals at the Asian Games, had been training in Australia when she felt unwell and returned to Japan for further tests. She confirmed she will withdraw from the Japanese championships in April and will focus on treatment, aiming to beat her illness and compete at the Tokyo Olympics.

site_title: Australia, NZ shares firmer on US-China trade hopes
summary: Australian shares rose 0.3% on Tuesday, supported by positive signals from US-China trade talks and firm earnings guidance from Macquarie Group. The S&P/ASX 200 index reached 6,079.1. New Zealand's benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index also posted its fifth straight gain, rising 0.8%. Shares of CSL Ltd, Santos Ltd, and Origin Energy Ltd advanced, while the Reserve Bank of New Zealand's survey showed business managers forecast softer annual inflation in the next two years.

site_title: Singapore stocks end 0.2% lower on Tuesday
summary: Singapore stocks closed 0.2% lower on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index at 3,201.15, as 1.15 billion securities worth S$969.22 million changed hands. Losers outnumbered gainers 210 to 184. Notable movers included Ezion Holdings (up 4.44%) and Rex International (up 0.4%). The decline follows a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, with investors brushing off new Trump threats to extend stocks rally.

site_title: Samsung reaches settlement over 'exploding' washing machines
summary: Samsung Electronics has reached a settlement in a class-action lawsuit over 2.8 million "exploding" washing machines recalled in the US in 2016. The faulty appliances were recalled due to the top detaching from the washing machine chassis, posing a risk of injury. The lawsuit claimed some of the washers were "exploding." Samsung will provide rebates, refunds, or reimbursements to those covered by the settlement. This settlement comes after Samsung faced several reputation blows, including a recall of its Galaxy Note 7 smartphone due to exploding batteries.

images.alt_text: Samsung Electronics has reached a settlement in a class-action lawsuit over 2.8 million "exploding" washing machines recalled in the US, the South Korean company said on Tuesday.

site_title: SGX daily turnover up 18% to S$986m in January
summary: SGX's daily turnover increased by 18% to S$986m in January, a 26% decline from the same period last year. Total turnover for the month was 29% higher month-on-month but 26% lower year-on-year. The Straits Times Index gained 4% in January, while the market capitalization value of listed companies stood at S$963.98 billion. Derivatives market volume increased, with commodities derivatives seeing significant improvements, while exchange-traded funds saw a decline.

site_title: CBRE's Moray Armstrong now S'pore MD, Pauline Goh to become South-east Asia chairman
summary: CBRE appoints Pauline Goh as chairman for South-east Asia, focusing on nurturing and growing strategic client accounts. Moray Armstrong becomes managing director of the Singapore business, succeeding Vikram Kohli. Armstrong, who led CBRE's Advisory & Transactions team, will focus on leveraging innovation and proptech to drive growth. The appointments aim to capitalize on Singapore's importance as a regional hub, with Goh citing Armstrong's local market knowledge and relationships as key strengths.

site_title: Norwegian sport retailer XXL scraps dividend after profit tumble
summary: XXL, Norway's largest sports retailer, suspended its dividend after reporting a 65% drop in fourth quarter core earnings. Earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, and amortization (EBITDA) fell to 115 million Norwegian crowns, down from 332 million. The company cited deep discounting and agreed with its lending consortium to not pay dividends or buy back shares until the fourth quarter of 2019 at the earliest. XXL aims to distribute at least 40-50% of net profit in dividends.

site_title: Australia cattle giant warns of 'extreme losses' from floods
summary: Australia's largest cattle company, Australian Agricultural Company Ltd (AACo), has warned of "extreme losses" after record-breaking floods in Queensland state, where over 300,000 cows were drowned or washed away. Four AACo properties were "severely impacted" and the company expects "material" losses on one 30,000-head station. The floods, which dumped a year's worth of rainfall in just a week, have also affected the country's 25-million strong cattle herd, with an estimated one in 40 animals killed.

site_title: Ghosn's disputed pay triggers US$83m charge for Nissan
summary: Nissan Motor Co. took a $83 million charge related to the compensation of jailed former Chairman Carlos Ghosn, citing preliminary findings of alleged financial misconduct. The charge, part of a larger $9.2 billion yen payment, is part of Nissan's efforts to reeling from Ghosn's shock arrest and plummeting vehicle sales. The company slashed its operating profit forecast to 450 billion yen, below analysts' estimates, and lowered its vehicle sales forecast to 5.6 million. Ghosn's arrest has intensified pressures on CEO Hiroto Saikawa, who is trying to ease tensions with partner Renault.

site_title: SIA to add third daily service to Osaka in April
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) plans to add a third daily service to Osaka's Kansai International Airport in April, aiming to meet growing demand for travel between Singapore and Japan. The new flights are subject to regulatory approvals and will be available for sale starting progressively. The national carrier currently operates two daily flights, with the third service to begin on April 27.

site_title: HPH Trust posts Q4 net loss of HK$12.11b on recognition of impairment losses
summary: Hutchison Port Holdings Trust (HPH Trust) reported a net loss of HK$12.11 billion in Q4 2018 due to the recognition of non-cash impairment losses of HK$12.29 billion. Excluding the impairment losses, the trust would have recorded a net profit of HK$182.8 million. Revenue for the quarter increased 5% to HK$3 billion, driven by a 10.9% increase in container throughput at its Shenzhen terminal. The trust's net asset value per unit declined to 3.07 HK cents, and it ended unchanged at S$0.35.

site_title: Russia's GDP growth, at six-year high, raises durability question
summary: Russia's GDP growth reached a six-year high in 2018, with a 2.3% increase, exceeding expectations of 1.5-2.0%. However, economists say this growth is unsustainable due to one-off factors such as increased construction and inventory levels, and a decline in real disposable incomes among households. The growth is not indicative of a broader economic trend, and experts predict a slowdown in 2019. The government's goal to bring Russia's economy into the world's top five by 2024 remains uncertain without a significant increase in household incomes.

site_title: New Zealand's central bank could be the next to turn dovish
summary: New Zealand's central bank, the Reserve Bank of New Zealand (RBNZ), is expected to hold its cash rate steady at 1.75% but may signal an increasing possibility of a rate cut due to global growth concerns. Traders have bet on a 90% chance of a rate cut by November, and economists expect the RBNZ to move to a neutral stance by pushing forecasted rate hikes further into the future. The decision comes as the global economy slows and central banks become more cautious, with the US Federal Reserve pausing rate increases and Australia's Reserve Bank abandoning its tightening bias.

site_title: How a 27-year-old CEO built a near US$1b fashion startup in South-east Asia
summary: 27-year-old Ankiti Bose, CEO of Zilingo, a Singapore-based fashion startup, has successfully raised US$226 million from investors, valuing the company at US$970 million. Founded in 2014, Zilingo provides an online platform for small merchants in South-east Asia to build scale, with revenue growing 12 times in 2018. Bose, a rare female founder in the global startup world, aims to capitalize on the region's rapid smartphone adoption and rising incomes, with plans to expand into new areas and launch in Australia.

site_title: Indian airline sector to shrink losses by two-thirds next year-CAPA India
summary: India's airlines are forecast to cut cumulative losses by two-thirds in the 2020 financial year, with low-cost carriers returning to profitability. Estimated losses for 2020 range from $550 million to $700 million, down from $1.7 billion in 2019. Domestic air traffic is expected to rise 14-16% and international traffic 10-12% as the Indian fleet expands. Low-cost carriers are expected to post a combined profit of $100-150 million, while full-service carriers will rack up $700-800 million in losses.

site_title: Asia: Markets rise on trade hopes, weak yen
summary: Asian markets rose on Tuesday as investors awaited key US-China trade talks and a weak yen boosted exporters. Initial trade talks are underway in Beijing, with top-level negotiations set for Thursday and Friday. The dollar has strengthened, lifting Japanese exporters and leaving the yen at its weakest level in six weeks. US senators announced a deal to avoid a new government shutdown, while the British pound rebounded after dismal GDP data. Markets were also lifted by a tentative deal to avert a new government shutdown, with some countries, such as Hong Kong and Sydney, gaining ground.

site_title: China will abolish permits for opening bank accounts by companies by end-2019
summary: China's central bank announced it will abolish permits for companies to open bank accounts by the end of 2019, in line with a state council directive to reduce administrative red tape. This move aims to simplify the process and increase business efficiency.

site_title: Singapore condo resale prices down 0.3% in January: SRX
summary: Singapore's condo resale market cooled for the second straight month in January, with non-landed private residential resale prices down 0.3% from the previous month. Year-over-year, prices rose 6%, but overall prices are down 1.6% from their peak in July 2018. Resale volumes also dropped 1.1% in January, with an estimated 529 units sold. Experts attribute the slowdown to growing geopolitical uncertainties, rising interest rates, and property cooling measures, suggesting the private resale market may not have reached its bottom.

site_title: Tentative deal reached to avoid new US government shutdown
summary: US congressional negotiators reached a tentative deal on border security funding, averting a potential partial government shutdown. The agreement, reached in principle, would fund border security programs through September 30, but does not include funding for a US-Mexico border wall. The deal is expected to be finalized by Wednesday, with lawmakers aiming to pass legislation by Friday to avoid a government funding lapse. The agreement was made possible after President Trump agreed to reopen the government for three weeks to allow for negotiations.

site_title: Philippines Dec trade deficit narrows to 3-month low as imports dive
summary: The Philippines' trade deficit narrowed to a three-month low in December, dropping 5.5% to $3.75 billion, as imports tumbled 9.4% to $8.5 billion. Imports of capital goods declined 33.3%, while exports shrank 12.3% to $4.72 billion. The drop in imports is attributed to the government's infrastructure program and lower oil prices, which are expected to boost domestic consumption. Economists predict a rebound in imports in the coming months, but the trade gap is expected to remain relatively wide.

site_title: New Delhi hotel fire kills 17
summary: A fire at the Hotel Arpit Palace in central Delhi killed 17 people, including a child, on Tuesday. The blaze broke out on the top floor of the four-storey hotel, where wooden panelling hindered evacuation. The fire was extinguished after a lengthy operation involving 25 fire engines. Authorities are investigating the cause, which has raised concerns over fire safety in India. This incident is the latest in a series of fire disasters in the country, with similar incidents reported in Mumbai in 2017 and 2019.

site_title: Refilled new spirits after RTO, TSH opens at 38 Singapore cents
summary: TSH Corp, a newly formed company, opened at 38 Singapore cents on its first day of trading following a reverse takeover by Sloshed! owners. The company, which was previously a consumer electronics firm, acquired Sloshed!'s pubs, bars, and spirits business. However, its shares plummeted 15.8% to 32 Singapore cents within the first hour. TSH Corp has a market cap of around S$13.5 million.

site_title: China's consumption growth likely to slow further in 2019: commerce ministry
summary: China's consumption growth is expected to slow further in 2019, according to a commerce ministry official, citing periodic weak car sales and housing-related spending as contributing factors. Despite this, retail sales are forecast to remain steady and relatively fast-paced. This slowdown in consumption growth may put pressure on policymakers, who are already grappling with a slowing China economy.

site_title: Kering's Gucci joins peers in defying China fears
summary: Luxury goods group Kering's Gucci defied concerns of waning demand in China, with comparable sales rising 24.2% in the fourth quarter. Gucci's sales growth, though slower than previous months, still outperformed most fashion brands. The brand's 28.1% comparable sales growth and record 39.5% margins in 2018 have raised questions about Kering's reliance on Gucci. Despite a potential 1.4 billion euro tax bill, Kering disputes the claim and the amount, citing dynamic sales among its Chinese clientele. Gucci remains one of the luxury world's fastest-growing brands.

images.alt_text: Luxury goods group Kering joined competitors in defying concerns of waning demand in China, as momentum at its powerhouse Gucci slowed slightly in the fourth quarter but still outperformed most other fashion brands.

site_title: Hong Kong, crossroads of the criminal wildlife trade
summary: Hong Kong has emerged as a critical hub for the global wildlife trade, with its unique geography and economic system facilitating the smuggling of endangered species such as pangolins. The territory has seen a significant increase in seizures of pangolin scales and carcasses, with over 43 metric tons seized between 2013 and 2017. Despite efforts to combat the trade, Hong Kong's reluctance to crack down on organized crime and its long history as a center for traditional Chinese medicine and wildlife trade have hindered progress. Conservationists argue that reducing local consumer demand for legal products is key to reducing Hong Kong's role in the illegal wildlife trade.

site_title: Singapore retail sales slide 6% in December for full-year 0.7% drop
summary: Singapore's retail sales declined 6% in December, resulting in a 0.7% drop for the full year. Excluding motor vehicles, sales fell 3% in December, while online transactions accounted for 5.5% of total retail sales. Medical goods and toiletries were the only major segment to post higher sales, up 1.8%. Department stores, watches, and jewellery saw significant declines, while furniture and household goods, clothing, and food vendors experienced modest gains. Petrol stations and food services also reported growth, with food services receipts rising 1.2% year-over-year.

site_title: Knot sounds alarm over the impact of Dutch house-price swings
summary: Dutch central bank Governor Klaas Knot warned of the risks of large swings in property prices, citing the need for action to prevent damage to the Netherlands' economy. The country's housing market has surged due to low interest rates, scarce supply, and a growing economy. Knot called for more rental homes for middle-income households and lower loan-to-value ratios for mortgages to take pressure off prices. He argued that exuberant price fluctuations have a strong impact on household consumption, potentially leading to a deeper economic downturn in times of recession.

site_title: AI system spots childhood disease like a doctor
summary: A Chinese AI system has been developed that diagnoses childhood diseases as accurately as doctors, with a 95% accuracy rate in diagnosing respiratory infections and sinusitis, and 90-97% accuracy in diagnosing less common diseases such as asthma and meningitis. The system, which can process vast amounts of data, learns and improves like humans, but has unlimited capacity for data processing and storage. Experts say the technology has the potential to improve healthcare by assisting clinicians in making rapid and accurate diagnoses, but will not replace doctors.

site_title: Palm oil firms seeing solid export trend: DBS
summary: Regional palm oil plantation companies are seeing a solid export trend, with January's exports reaching 1.68 million metric tons, up 14% year-on-year and 21% month-on-month. This offset a 3.9% month-on-month decline in output, still up 9.5% year-on-year. Analysts from DBS Group Research expect exports to ease in February due to Chinese New Year holidays but rebound in March, driven by attractive CPO prices.

site_title: IPS Securex lands US$1.2m airport bird deterrent contract
summary: IPS Securex has secured a US$1.16 million contract for an integrated radar surveillance and bird strike deterrent solution for a government-linked entity in South-east Asia. The contract, expected to be completed within six months, will not significantly impact the company's earnings per share or net tangible assets per share for the year ending June 30, 2019. This marks a culmination of months of planning and marketing efforts by IPS Securex, which plans to expand its project track record for this solution to other airports in Asia.

site_title: PODCAST: Top 5 step-by-step tips for HDB flat buyers in today's market (Money Hacks, Ep 34)
summary: Sisters Rhonda and Race Wong from Ohmyhome discuss their top 5 step-by-step tips for HDB flat buyers in Singapore's current market. They emphasize the importance of calculating affordability, considering financing options, and using apps to guide the buying process. They also advise young couples to think long-term and consider bigger flat sizes. The tips are designed to make housing transactions simpler, faster, and more affordable in Singapore.

site_title: HDB launches 3,739 flats in first sales exercise of 2019
summary: The Housing and Development Board (HDB) launched 3,739 government flats in its first sales exercise of 2019, including 3,162 Build-to-Order (BTO) flats and 577 Re-Offer of Balance Flats (ROF). Prices start from S$95,000 for a two-room flexi flat and S$523,000 for a four-room flat. Applications close on February 18, with the next BTO launch scheduled for May. This is the first tranche of 15,000 flats to be released in 2019.

site_title: Indonesia poultry stocks may keep soaring on supply woes, CIMB says
summary: Indonesia's poultry industry is expected to continue its upward trend due to a chicken shortage, driven by the government's ban on antibiotic use in chicken feed. The supply of chicks is projected to drop to 3 billion in 2019, leading to higher day-old-chick prices. This has boosted shares of major poultry companies, including PT Charoen Pokphand Indonesia, PT Malindo Feedmill, and PT Japfa Comfeed, with gains of up to 140% last year. Analysts predict a record profit for CP Indonesia and sustained growth for the industry until 2Q19.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares start Tuesday with losses
summary: Hong Kong stocks began trading on Tuesday with losses, following Wall Street's lead as investors await US-China trade talks. The Hang Seng Index fell 0.23%, while the Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.13%. The losses come amid ongoing US-China trade tensions, which have affected global markets.

site_title: Adopt an olive tree - and breathe new life into Spanish village
summary: A Spanish village, Oliete, is experiencing a resurgence in population thanks to an innovative "Adopt an Olive Tree" scheme. For 50 euros annually, 2,500 sponsors receive photos and olive oil from their adopted trees, helping to revive over 7,000 centuries-old olive trees in the area. The project has created jobs, attracted new residents, and prevented the village from dying out, with the local school remaining open for another 10 years. Similar projects have taken off in other depopulated regions of Spain, offering a new opportunity for young people to live in the countryside.

site_title: Cathay Pacific to close crew base in Toronto as part of revamp
summary: Cathay Pacific Airways Ltd is closing its cabin crew base in Toronto as part of a business review, potentially affecting 120 workers. The Hong Kong-based airline is seeking to reduce HK$4 billion in expenses and has offered a voluntary early retirement package to employees in Japan. Cathay Pacific plans to recruit more than 1,000 cabin crew in Hong Kong this year and has also announced improved in-flight meal services and flights to more destinations. The airline's transformation programme, started in 2017, aims to address fierce competition from Chinese airlines and low-cost carriers.

site_title: New Zealand 2-year inflation expectations ease to 2.02% in Q1
summary: New Zealand's two-year inflation expectations eased to 2.02% in Q1, down from 2.03% in the previous quarter. This is the first time expectations have fallen in the survey since 2018. In contrast, expectations for the coming year slowed to 1.82% from 2.09% in the previous quarter. The Reserve Bank of New Zealand's quarterly survey aims to gauge business managers' forecasts for inflation.

site_title: DBS partners SMU on sustainability initiative
summary: DBS Bank and Singapore Management University (SMU) have partnered on a sustainability initiative, committing over S$1 million to promote and grow sustainability. The program will offer a major in sustainability, funding research, scholarships, and community engagement. The initiative also involves up to 10 social enterprises and provides students with project-based learning opportunities. Two DBS fellowships and two scholarships will be established to attract and retain research scholars and support students pursuing sustainability careers.

site_title: Sakae swings into the red with Q2 loss
summary: Sakae Holdings reported a net loss of S$545,000 for the second quarter of fiscal 2019, down from a net profit of S$99,000 the previous year. Revenue declined 39.6% to S$11.2 million, while cost of sales and labour costs decreased accordingly. The company attributed the loss to a streamlining of operations, resulting in a 22.4% reduction in administrative expenses and a 14% decrease in labour costs. Despite a decrease in gross profit, the group's gross profit margin increased by 11.4% to 62.5%.

site_title: Australia: Shares higher, led by Macquarie Group; New Zealand up
summary: Australian shares rose 0.4% on Tuesday, driven by optimism over Sino-US trade talks and Macquarie Group's reaffirmed profit growth outlook. The S&P/ASX 200 index rose to 6,087.40, with major banks and healthcare stocks also gaining. New Zealand's benchmark index rose 0.7%, led by Fisher & Paykel Healthcare and Fletcher Building. Iron ore prices rose on supply concerns, supporting miners.

site_title: Light rail collision in Paris suburb injures 12
summary: A light rail collision occurred in a Paris suburb on Monday evening, injuring 12 people, including one in critical condition. The accident happened between two stations in Issy-les-Moulineaux, with two trams colliding and one derailing. The cause of the accident is unknown. Accidents on the busy suburban tramline are rare, and this incident is the first of its kind in two decades.

site_title: Tencent investment in Reddit sparks censorship worry
summary: Reddit raised $300 million at a $3 billion valuation, with $150 million from Tencent, sparking concerns about censorship. The funding will be used for international expansion and ad platform enhancements. Users protested, sharing banned images, including those of Winnie the Pooh, referencing China's online censorship. Reddit, founded by Alexis Ohanian, has over 138,000 communities and 330 million monthly users, and plans to compete with Facebook and Google in the digital ad market. The investment has raised concerns about Reddit's potential vulnerability to censorship under Tencent's ownership.

site_title: Trump wants to meet with Xi 'very soon' over trade war
summary: US President Donald Trump wants to meet with Chinese President Xi Jinping "very soon" to end the trade war, according to White House adviser Kellyanne Conway. Negotiators from the two countries are set to meet in Beijing this week, with Trump seeking deeper reforms from China to address structural issues. The March 1 deadline looms, and if no deal is reached, Trump has threatened to double tariffs on $200 billion in Chinese imports. A meeting at Trump's Mar-a-Lago resort in Florida is possible, but a breakthrough remains uncertain.

site_title: Freehold city fringe commercial building up for sale with S$25m guide price
summary: A freehold four-storey commercial building at 7 Hindoo Road, Singapore is up for sale with a guide price of S$25 million. The property has a 15m wide frontage, 3,519 sq ft land area, and 13,970 sq ft gross floor area. Zoned for commercial use, it currently houses a retail shop and offices. Potential uses include food and beverage, showroom, and medical suites, subject to authorities' approval. The building has column-free layouts, generous ceiling heights, and lift access, offering flexibility for various commercial uses.

site_title: Malaysia shares open higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 2.26 points to 1,690.82 at 9am on Tuesday, with gains beating losses 113 to 57. Volume reached 33.82 million lots worth RM15.92 million.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on cheaper yen
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Tuesday, driven by a cheaper yen and optimism over US-China trade talks. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.63% and the Topix index gained 0.50%. The benchmark indices reached 20,460.46 and 1,547.05, respectively. The rally follows a global trend, with the US S&P 500 and Nasdaq also hitting fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Berlin woos US in Europe gas battle
summary: Germany is hosting US Deputy Energy Secretary Dan Brouillette in talks on importing natural gas, amid concerns over the under-construction Nord Stream 2 pipeline's impact on European energy dependence on Russia. Germany aims to diversify its energy supply, and Economy Minister Peter Altmaier will unveil policy changes to allow easier imports of liquid natural gas (LNG). The US and some Eastern EU member states, including Poland and the Baltic nations, have expressed concerns that the pipeline undermines their security, while Chancellor Angela Merkel has dismissed such fears as "purely business."

site_title: iX Biopharma sinks deeper into the red with S$3.7m Q2 loss
summary: iX Biopharma reported a net loss of S$3.7 million for Q2 2019, down from S$3.2 million a year ago, with loss per share at 0.6 Singapore cents.
