Total revenue declined 12% to S$1.5 million, while gross profit fell 60% to S$231,000. The company attributed the decline to preparations for a nationwide launch, which required significant investments in product development and laboratory testing.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Tuesday, STI up 0.1% to 3,209.85
summary: Singapore stocks opened higher on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) gaining 0.1% to 3,209.85. The market was evenly matched, with 54 gainers and 51 losers, after 51.6 million shares worth S$79.3 million changed hands. Singtel fell 0.98% and Mapletree Industrial Trust declined 2.96%. The rally comes ahead of GDP data and follows a 5-day winning streak.

site_title: Fashion platform Zilingo raises US$226m in series D round led by Sequoia
summary: Fashion platform Zilingo has raised US$226 million in a series D funding round led by Sequoia Capital, bringing its total fundraising to US$308 million. The funds will be used to integrate and digitize the fashion and beauty supply chain and expand in key markets. Revenue grew four times in the last 12 months. Zilingo, founded in 2015, provides supply chain capabilities to fashion merchants, helping them access manufacturers across Asia. The investment marks a significant milestone for the startup, which has rapidly transformed its original ideas into a platform company serving a multi-hundred billion dollar market.

site_title: British cabinet ministers believe PM May preparing to resign: report
summary: British cabinet ministers believe Prime Minister Theresa May is preparing to resign this summer, allowing her to influence the next prime minister, according to The Sun. This comes after May's original Brexit deal was rejected by lawmakers in January, who demanded changes to the treaty. Britain is set to leave the EU on March 29.

site_title: Hyflux extends deadline to file proofs of claim to March 1
summary: Hyflux has extended the deadline for creditors and stakeholders to file proofs of claim to March 1, from February 15, to facilitate debt restructuring. Holders of the company's notes and securities who do not file a proof will be deemed authorized. The company has made proof forms available online and set up a support hotline for queries. This extension aims to be "administratively efficient" and allow the restructuring agreement to be implemented, according to Hyflux's group executive vice-president.

site_title: Singapore AI startup 6Estates raises Series B funding led by GDP Venture
summary: Singapore-based AI startup 6Estates has raised Series B funding led by Indonesia-focused GDP Venture. The company plans to use the funding to further develop its proprietary cognitive data intelligence solutions and expand globally. 6Estates' revenue has quadrupled in the last 12 months, driven by demand from Fortune 500 companies, and has secured finance intelligence projects in China. The company will establish an office in Indonesia and expand its team of machine learning and data scientists. Co-founder Luan Huanbo stated that 6Estates is exploring AI applications in trade finance and capital markets.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Valuetronics, Mapletree Industrial Trust, Oxley, Vicom, F&N
summary: Valuetronics Holdings reported a 2.6% increase in third-quarter net profit to HK$59.7 million, driven by revenue growth from its industrial and commercial electronics business. Mapletree Industrial Trust is proposing a private placement of 90.44 million new units to raise S$175 million. Oxley Holdings slid 33% in its second-quarter net profit to S$45.2 million, while Vicom rose 30.9% to S$34.7 million. Fraser & Neave increased its first-quarter net profit by 47.5% to S$37.9 million.

site_title: Mapletree Industrial Trust to raise at least S$175m in private placement
summary: Mapletree Industrial Trust (MIT) plans to raise at least S$175 million through a private placement of 90.44 million new units, mostly to refinance the acquisition of 18 Tai Seng Street. The new units will be sold at an issue price between S$1.935 and S$1.990 per unit, representing a discount of 4.65% to 1.94% to the volume-weighted average price. The trust intends to use S$172.1 million to refinance the acquisition, with the remaining S$2.9 million for fees and expenses.

site_title: The Florence Residences to preview this weekend
summary: The Florence Residences, a 1,410-unit development in Kovan, Singapore, will preview starting February 16, 2019. Indicative starting prices are S$678,000 for one-bedroom units and S$2.449 million for five-bedroom units. The project, formerly Florence Regency, features smart home features and appliances, and will include 128 facilities grouped into 12 "clubs" offering a range of lifestyle activities. The development is expected to benefit from the nearby Cross Island Line and is part of a wave of en bloc deals in Singapore, with 50-60 new launches expected in 2019.

site_title: Loans for dentures? New Fed governor said her bank helped
summary: Federal Reserve Governor Michelle Bowman revealed that her former bank, Farmers & Drovers Bank, provided loans for dentures, a unique form of financing. Bowman, who joined the Fed board in November, described the bank as financing basic needs of community members. She also noted the strong US economy, with solid jobs data, wage growth, and inflation near the Fed's 2% target, stating the economy is in a good place and inflation is close to target.

site_title: Air New Zealand flight to Shanghai turned away on Taiwan reference: Stuff
summary: An Air New Zealand flight to Shanghai was forced to return to Auckland after its documentation included a reference to Taiwan, which China views as a separate entity. The issue dates back to 2018, when China warned airlines to remove references to Taiwan. Air New Zealand did not resolve the issue before the flight, leading to its temporary deployment hiccup. China's foreign ministry cited news reports blaming the flight's authorization to land in China. The incident highlights the ongoing diplomatic tensions between China and Taiwan.

site_title: 'Lego' movie disappoints at North American box office
summary: The animated film "The Lego Movie 2: The Second Part" debuted at the North American box office with a disappointing US$34.7 million, below estimates and industry predictions, despite a high production budget of US$100 million. It took the top spot, beating out "What Men Want" and "Cold Pursuit." Other films, including "The Upside," "Glass," and "Aquaman," rounded out the top 10. The underwhelming performance raises questions about the series' long-term viability.

site_title: No-deal Brexit will not 'fundamentally impair' UK-Singapore trade: MTI
summary: Singapore's Ministry of Trade and Industry (MTI) assesses that a no-deal Brexit will not "fundamentally impair" trade between the UK and Singapore, with the potential for a future trade agreement based on the EU-Singapore Free Trade Agreement (EUSFTA). The EUSFTA ratification and implementation are on track, unaffected by Brexit. MTI will work with Singapore companies to address any near-term disruptions, and the UK is considered an important economic partner.

site_title: Japan's Osaka in shock split with tennis coach Bajin
summary: Naomi Osaka has split from her tennis coach Sascha Bajin, just weeks after winning the Australian Open. The decision comes after over a year of working together, with no reason given. Osaka, the world number one, thanked Bajin for his work and wished him well, while Bajin also expressed gratitude and admiration for Osaka's achievement. The split ends a successful partnership that saw Osaka rise from 72 in the world rankings to the top of the women's rankings and win her first Grand Slam title at the US Open.

site_title: Metech Q2 loss widens to S$377,000 after exiting e-waste business
summary: Metech International reported a net loss of S$377,000 for the second quarter, widening from S$107,000 a year ago, after discontinuing its e-waste management business. Revenue from its supply chain management business rose 31.5% to S$22.1 million. The company posted a profit after tax of S$57,000 from continuing operations, up 90% year-on-year. The loss from discontinued operations was S$423,000.

site_title: Rap sees landmark Grammy wins after years of snubs
summary: Cardi B made history at the 2019 Grammys, becoming the first woman to win Best Rap Album for her album "Invasion of Privacy". Childish Gambino also won Song and Record of the Year, marking a milestone for rap music. The second consecutive year saw black hip-hop artists dominate nominations, with many artists taking home major wins, suggesting a shift in the Recording Academy's recognition of pop culture's most groundbreaking work.

site_title: Living by identity politics? Die by it too
summary: The Democratic Party in Virginia is facing a crisis after the unearthing of skeletons in the closets of top leaders. Governor Ralph Northam, a liberal and low-key figure, was accused of wearing blackface in a medical school yearbook, a practice considered racist and offensive. The accusations led to calls for his resignation, which would have been replaced by his lieutenant governor, Justin Fairfax. However, Fairfax was also accused of rape, and a fourth candidate, Attorney General Mark Herring, was found to have worn blackface. The controversy has raised questions about the party's commitment to racial equality and has created a political mess that may tarnish the Democratic narrative.

site_title: Australia's Macquarie Group raises FY profit forecast
summary: Macquarie Group, Australia's largest investment bank, has raised its full-year profit forecast by 15% to 10% growth, driven by higher revenue from market-facing businesses and strong performance by its commodities platform. New CEO Shemara Wikramanayake attributed the boost to the bank's "annuity-style businesses" and its "well-positioned" delivery of superior performance in the medium term. The bank's asset management business saw a 2% decline in assets under management, while its common equity tier 1 capital ratio increased to 10.8%.

site_title: Oil prices dip; slow progress in trade talks counters Opec cuts
summary: Oil prices dropped on Monday, with Brent crude falling 59 cents to $61.51 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude falling 31 cents to $52.41 a barrel, as US-China trade talks resumed despite Opec's supply cuts. The resumption of talks, combined with US President Donald Trump's decision not to meet with Chinese President Xi Jinping before the March 1 deadline, raised uncertainty about a trade deal. A rising US dollar also weighed on oil prices, making them more expensive for holders of other currencies.

site_title: Trumps orders government to prioritise artificial intelligence
summary: President Donald Trump has ordered the US administration to prioritize artificial intelligence, citing the need to maintain US leadership in the field amid growing concerns that China will overtake the US. The American AI Initiative executive order calls for increased federal resources to fuel AI innovation, but lacks specific funding and a detailed strategy. Experts say the move is timely but uncertain in its implementation, and that more comprehensive AI policies are needed to address the challenges posed by China's significant investments in AI.

site_title: Europe: Shares bounce back as trade talks resume
summary: European shares rose 0.9% on Monday as investors regained optimism over trade talks between Beijing and Washington. Despite a cautious Wall Street opening, banks and financials led the gains, while shares of companies like Just Eat, Airbus, and Imperial Brands also rose. Analysts cautioned that a favorable outcome is not guaranteed, and the market's optimism may be volatile.

site_title: French presidential aide quits as Benalla scandal deepens
summary: French President Emmanuel Macron's special advisor Ismael Emelien is quitting in late March or early April amid the Benalla scandal. Emelien denied his departure was related to the scandal, but his exit follows other high-profile departures from the Elysee. The scandal surrounding former security chief Alexandre Benalla, who was sacked for beating demonstrators, continues to unfold, with renewed scrutiny over his involvement in brokering security contracts with Russian oligarchs. French prosecutors have opened a corruption probe into one of the contracts, and Benalla remains under investigation.

site_title: SoftBank fund invests big in self-driving deliveries
summary: SoftBank's Vision Fund invests nearly $1 billion in Nuro, a Silicon Valley startup developing self-driving delivery vehicles. The US$940 million funding brings the company's total funding to over $1 billion, with investors including Greylock Partners and Gaorong Capital. This investment comes as interest in robotic delivery surges among companies, including retail giant Amazon. The move aims to further develop Nuro's technology and expand its operations in the rapidly growing self-driving delivery market.

site_title: US: Stocks end mixed as China trade talks begin
summary: US stocks ended mixed on Monday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average down 0.2% and the S&P 500 up 0.1%. Markets eyed the start of US-China trade talks, which began in Beijing ahead of a March 1 deadline that could lead to additional US tariffs. Despite progress made in talks last month, recent comments have raised concerns about the impact on global growth. Meanwhile, lawmakers in Washington sought to resolve a budget impasse before Friday to avoid a possible government shutdown.

site_title: iPhone shipments in China plunge as Huawei tightens grip
summary: Apple's Chinese smartphone shipments declined an estimated 20% in the final quarter of 2018, with the overall Chinese market contracting 9.7%. The decline was attributed to a slowing economy, lengthy replacement times, and the iPhone's high price tag. Chinese rivals like Huawei, Xiaomi, and Oppo overtook Apple, with Huawei's unit shipments soaring 23.3%. Apple ranked fourth in the country, behind Oppo and Vivo, and Xiaomi fifth. The decline marks a significant shift in the global smartphone market, where innovation has slowed and local rivals are eroding Apple's share.

site_title: Playing field 'still favours big Australian banks'
summary: Bendigo and Adelaide Bank, a mid-sized Australian bank, criticized the Royal Commission's failure to address competition issues with the country's four largest banks. The bank's shares fell 6% after posting a 2% decline in first-half cash earnings, citing higher funding costs and lower lending volumes. CEO Marnie Baker expressed disappointment that the commission's recommendations did not address competition and a level playing field, making it hard for smaller banks to compete with the big four.

site_title: Venezuela's financial accountability authority probes Guaido
summary: Venezuela's financial accountability authority has opened an investigation into opposition leader Juan Guaido's income, alleging he received money from international and national bodies without justification. Guaido, recognized as interim president by around 50 countries, could face a fine or disqualification from public office if found guilty. The investigation comes as Guaido steps up his challenge to President Nicolas Maduro's authority, with a humanitarian aid standoff playing out over the border with Colombia.

site_title: Valuetronics Q3 profit up 2.6% to HK$59.7m on lower income tax expense
summary: Valuetronics Holdings reported a 2.6% increase in third-quarter net profit to HK$59.7 million, driven by a 24.2% decline in income tax expense. Revenue fell 7.5% to HK$729.6 million, mainly due to a 26.4% decrease in its consumer electronics segment. The company attributed the decline to weaker performance in smart lighting products and expects to remain profitable for the financial year ending March 31, 2019, despite exploring diversification into North America and South-east Asia.

site_title: Can 'Big Brother' technology clean up palm oil's image?
summary: Major palm oil users, including Nestle, Unilever, and Mondelez, are testing satellite technology to track deforestation and improve sourcing practices. The monitoring systems aim to target people cutting down trees in producing countries like Malaysia and Indonesia, but their effectiveness is disputed. Some say the technology is not enough to stop deforestation, while others worry boycotting unsustainable palm oil drives bad practices elsewhere. The industry faces pressure to meet a 2020 pledge of zero net deforestation, and companies are exploring ways to implement responsible sourcing practices, including online data sharing and supplier suspensions.

site_title: Singapore - bright spot among global investors and funds
summary: Singapore's fund management hub is gaining strength amidst global uncertainties, with investors seeking stability and reliability. The island nation's economic and political stability, ease of business, and favorable regulatory and tax framework are attracting international funds. The recently introduced Singapore Variable Capital Company (VCC) Bill and tax incentives for resident funds are expected to drive growth, with increased competition among asset managers and a rise in tech innovations. Singapore's position as a tech and innovation hub for the region is expected to benefit from the growth of the fund management industry, with a positive outlook for the sector.

site_title: UK posts slowest growth in six years as Brexit looms
summary: The UK economy grew at its slowest pace in six years in 2018, with a 1.4% gross domestic product growth, down from 1.8% in 2017. Brexit uncertainty has gripped the country, with businesses on edge ahead of its scheduled departure from the EU on March 29. The parliament rejected a Brexit deal, and the government seeks more time to secure EU concessions. A no-deal Brexit could put 600,000 jobs worldwide at risk, including 103,000 in Germany.

site_title: Two major Chinese borrowers miss bond payments: sources
summary: Two major Chinese borrowers, China Minsheng Investment Group Corp and Wintime Energy Co, have missed bond payments, highlighting the risks in China's credit market. China Minsheng failed to repay a 3 billion yuan bond on Feb 1, while Wintime Energy, which defaulted last year, missed a debt repayment plan. The developments suggest government efforts to smooth the market aren't benefiting all firms, with companies struggling to roll over debt despite recent easing measures. The missing payments could rank among China's biggest failures, totaling 232 billion yuan in debt.

site_title: Erdogan demands halt to illegal building
summary: Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan has demanded a halt to illegal construction in Turkey following the collapse of an apartment building in Istanbul, which killed 21 people. The building, with 43 registered residents, was constructed without permits, and the government is under fire for its "zoning amnesty" program, which allowed the registration of 13 million non-code compliant buildings. Erdogan vowed to take "necessary" steps to address the issue, citing "serious problems" with illegally constructed buildings.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Coffee with Claressa: On Record - Warren Fernandez
summary: Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) editor-in-chief Warren Fernandez discusses his career and experiences on the Money FM podcast "Coffee with Claressa". Fernandez answers questions from the public and shares insights on his tenure at SPH and The Straits Times. He also touches on various industry trends, including the impact of tariffs on the global economy and the growth of e-commerce in Asia. Fernandez's conversation offers a glimpse into his leadership and perspective on the media industry.

site_title: Euronext raises Oslo Bors bid to US$790m to push out Nasdaq
summary: Euronext NV raised its bid for Oslo Bors VPS Holding ASA to US$790 million, exceeding Nasdaq Inc.'s offer of 152 kroner a share. The move aims to thwart Nasdaq's bid and put pressure on Oslo Bors' board to consider Euronext's offer. Euronext secured the support of 50.5% of Oslo Bors shareholders, while Nasdaq has commitments from 35.2% shareholders. The rival bids will be assessed by Norway's regulators, a process that could take months, to determine which company would be a better steward of Norway's stock exchange.

site_title: DBS hires Citibank Singapore CEO to head group strategy
summary: DBS hires Han Kwee Juan, a 51-year-old former Citibank Singapore CEO, as group head of strategy and planning, effective April. Han will report to CEO Piyush Gupta and join him as a "Citi lifer" who has transitioned to DBS. He spent 27 years at Citibank, leading various businesses, and will be a member of the group management committee. This move aims to supplement DBS' leadership bench with external talent and gain new perspectives.

site_title: China's holiday spending slows, underlining tough start to 2019
summary: China's holiday spending slowed, with 1.01 trillion yuan spent over the week-long Chinese New Year holiday, a 8.5% increase from last year but the slowest since 2011. Frugal consumers, weakened by economic slowdown and debt, drove the decline, with household consumption expected to be sluggish. Online shopping surged 43% on JD.com, while tourist spending rose 8.2% to 513.9 billion yuan, with Hong Kong and Macau being top overseas destinations.

site_title: Private residential market still holds appeal
summary: Singapore's private residential market has remained stable despite global uncertainties, with demand from buyers seeking prime locations and pent-up demand from en bloc sales. The market is expected to continue attracting buyers, particularly those looking for wealth preservation and diversification. Rents are anticipated to improve in 2019, with a moderation in supply and sustainable economic growth. Executive Condominiums and Good Class Bungalows remain popular, while co-living spaces are expected to gain popularity among digital nomads. Overall, private residential property prices are likely to remain stable, with potential upside risks from economic shocks and rising interest rates.

site_title: Recasting portfolios for late-cycle shifts
summary: JP Morgan Asset Management's 2019 Long Term Capital Market Assumptions report projects a late-stage US business cycle, with rising risk of recession. Asset class returns are expected to be modest, with global equities remaining relatively unchanged and US fixed income experiencing improved returns. The report cautions against traditional mean-reversion assumptions, as structural shifts in global markets may not be captured by such frameworks. Investors are advised to focus on secular themes, such as technology and alternative assets, and consider a variety of risk metrics to navigate late-cycle shifts.

site_title: More skills training aid on the way for SMEs
summary: Senior Minister of State for Trade and Industry Koh Poh Koon announced plans to introduce new initiatives to encourage small and medium enterprises (SMEs) to send workers for skills training, with funding support, in the upcoming Budget and Committee of Supply. The existing Model Factory Initiative, launched in 2017, has seen 137 projects undertaken, with 4,000 professionals from 1,500 companies attending Workforce Skills Qualifications courses since 2008. Koh emphasized the importance of digitization and research and development for SMEs to remain competitive globally.

site_title: Stitching together new initiatives to expand the family business
summary: Joe's Tailoring, a Singaporean bespoke tailoring house, is expanding its product line to cater to a younger clientele, with plans to double revenues to S$2 million in FY18/19. The family-owned business, led by Joseph Koh, has introduced bespoke jeans, shoes, and women's apparel, and has gained a significant following on social media. Koh's children are learning the trade and are expected to take over the business in the future. The company aims to establish boutiques in Melbourne or London within the next year and remains committed to using high-quality natural fabrics.

site_title: Ikea accelerates services drive as competition stiffens
summary: Ikea is accelerating its services drive amid increasing competition. The Swedish furniture giant bought TaskRabbit in 2017 to offer assembly services for its flat-pack furniture. Ikea aims to attract busy millennials like teacher Jessica Reznik, who prefer not to assemble furniture themselves. This move is part of Ikea's strategy to complement its core business and compete with online retailers and DIY enthusiasts.

site_title: Are new technologies replacing routine jobs?
summary: New technologies, particularly artificial intelligence (AI), are increasingly replacing routine jobs in accounting and bookkeeping, allowing business owners and advisers to focus on strategic, analytical functions. Cloud accounting platforms have incorporated AI and machine learning to automate transactions, freeing up time for advisory work such as forecasting and long-term planning. Accounting firms in Singapore and Hong Kong are adopting apps to improve operational efficiency, with those adopting data automation apps generating 99.5% more revenue and growing nearly three times faster than the industry average. To remain relevant, accountants must develop skills beyond accounting, such as strategic thinking and business acumen, and leverage complementary apps to deliver complex advisory services.

site_title: Bank stocks lift STI in quiet day
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.13% to 3,206.27 on a quiet trading day, driven by gains from Singapore's three local banks: DBS, UOB, and OCBC. Despite a depressed start, the banks' stocks recovered after lunch, with DBS up 0.25%, UOB up 0.4%, and OCBC up 0.44%. The banks are set to release their full-year 2018 earnings soon, with analysts expecting results to be broadly in line but warning of potential return on equity disappointment for DBS.

site_title: Siemens lands S$111m deal to supply power systems for 2 MRT extensions
summary: Siemens has secured a S$111 million contract to supply power systems for the 2 MRT extensions in Singapore, Circle Line Stage 6 and the North East Line extension. The deal includes the delivery of alternating and direct current electrification equipment, an overhead conductor rail, and the expansion of Kim Chuan Depot in Singapore. The projects are expected to be completed by 2023 and 2025, respectively, and will enhance rail connectivity and accessibility in the country.

site_title: Time to steer taxi, ride-hail industry toward meaningful structural changes
summary: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) is proposing regulations for ride-hailing companies, aiming to level the playing field with traditional taxi operators and promote innovation while protecting consumers. The proposed licensing regime and ban on driver-exclusivity conditions are seen as steps towards creating a more symmetrical service and safety standard. The LTA is also seeking feedback on improving safety and reviewing rules on fare setting, including dynamic surge pricing. The regulator should prioritize transparency and a robust consumer protection framework to ensure a fair and equitable situation.

site_title: In HK, China insists, the chief executive is more equal
summary: Hong Kong Chief Executive Carrie Lam has faced opposition from the Chinese government over her attempt to extend anti-corruption legislation to cover her office. Beijing has deemed the proposal unacceptable, citing the chief executive's appointment by the central government and their special constitutional status. Lam had promised to amend the Prevention of Bribery Ordinance to cover the chief executive in her 2017 election manifesto, but Beijing's stance has stalled the reform efforts.

site_title: Companies must be future-ready to thrive in machine era
summary: Singapore's workforce must adapt to an automated future, with companies, leaders, and policymakers needed to implement measures such as retraining and educational system transformation. A recent Deloitte Insights article suggests that AI can be a force for good when employed productively, and that it can create new job opportunities. To achieve this, Singapore's SkillsFuture Initiative programme and flexible work economy can support displaced workers. Companies must also redefine work and invest in emerging technologies to maintain economic prosperity and create diverse jobs.

site_title: F&N's Q1 profit rises 47.5%
summary: Fraser & Neave (F&N) reported a 47.5% increase in net profit to S$37.9 million for its first quarter, driven by a higher share of associated companies' profits. Revenue rose 0.4% to S$464.4 million, with growth in its beverages business, despite a 8.4% drop in the printing and publishing business. Dairies' revenue was flat, but profit contribution increased due to strong performances in Malaysia, Singapore, and Thailand. The company's earnings per share and net asset value per share also rose.

site_title: Chan Chun Sing: Asean can learn from Middle-East woes
summary: Asean and Singapore can learn from the Middle East's unstable situation by having cohesion to avoid being a platform for proxy contests by major powers. The region's strategic location and energy resources make it a battleground for extra-regional powers. Asean should work together to remain connected to the world, including major powers, and be a neutral platform for engagement. Minister for Trade and Industry Chan Chun Sing emphasized the importance of understanding global interests and being relevant to them, drawing parallels between the Middle East and South-east Asia as strategic locations.

site_title: Will North Korea and China give Trump big wins?
summary: US President Donald Trump is seeking two significant foreign wins in February, including a breakthrough trade deal with China and a second summit with North Korean leader Kim Jong-un. Negotiations between the US and China, led by Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin and Chinese Vice-Premier Liu He, are ongoing, with a March 2 deadline approaching. A deal could provide stability in the world economy and limit damage to the international trade system. However, tensions between the US and China remain mixed, with security and political relations also at risk, and Trump's "America First" agenda may not be fully fulfilled until later in his term.

site_title: Changing hands
summary:
Here's a 100-word summary of the article content:

Global markets experienced fluctuations, with the US stock market opening lower due to fresh tariffs on Canada. In Singapore, NTT DC Reit's public offer was oversubscribed 9.8 times. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue and operating loss below targets. London's Heathrow is considering higher fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case. OCBC announced Tan Teck Long as its new CEO, replacing DBS veteran. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and PBOC signed a cooperation agreement on green and transition finance.

site_title: APAC Realty deepens presence in Indonesia, Thailand
summary: APAC Realty, a Singapore-based real estate player, has deepened its presence in Indonesia and Thailand by acquiring the ERA master franchisor for Indonesia and taking a direct ownership of the Thailand ERA master franchise through a partnership. The deals, worth S$13.85 million and S$4.42 million respectively, will see APAC Realty provide a loan of up to S$9.43 million to ERA Indonesia and take a majority stake in the company. The move aims to implement ERA Singapore's project sales business model, generating stronger margins and increasing ERA Indonesia's reported net profit.

site_title: Staying ahead of the game
summary: Lance Gokongwei, CEO of JG Summit Holdings, aims to lead the Philippine-based business group as the foremost player serving a growing Asian middle class. As the only son of billionaire John Gokongwei Jr, Lance has been groomed for the role, taking over as CEO in 2018. Under his leadership, JG Summit has expanded into various sectors, including food, airlines, and telecommunications, with a market capitalization of $12.2 billion. Gokongwei emphasizes the need for constant reinvention, digital capabilities, and sustainability to stay ahead in a rapidly changing business landscape.

site_title: Firms gloomier about H1 2019, BT-SUSS survey finds
summary: Firms in Singapore are gloomier about business prospects in the first half of 2019, according to a quarterly Business Times-Singapore University of Social Sciences (BT-SUSS) Business Climate Survey. Foreign firms reported worsening net balances, with sales and new business declining by 31% and 24% respectively. Local firms, however, saw slight improvements in sales and profits. Small firms were more optimistic about business prospects in the first half of 2019, with a net balance of +3% compared to large firms' -23%. The survey attributed the gloominess to global uncertainty, including the ongoing trade war between the US and China, and slowing growth prospects.

site_title: Positioning Singapore for future challenges
summary: Singapore's economy is at a crossroads, with a GDP growth forecast of 3.5% for 2019, slightly softer than expected. Despite this, the government's fiscal health is strong, with a possible surplus of $0.7 billion in the FY2018 budget. Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat has stated that the 2019 Budget will focus on keeping Singapore safe and secure, enabling workers to learn new skills, and boosting expenditure in key areas like infrastructure, healthcare, and education. Key initiatives include a sugar tax, tax relief for individuals paying Medishield Life premiums, and targeted help for low-income households. For companies, the government will provide support for digital transformation, innovation, and financial schemes to help small enterprises overcome difficulties.

site_title: Oxley second quarter earnings down 33%
summary: Oxley Holdings reported a 33% decline in net profit for the second quarter ended December 31, 2018, to S$45.2 million, mainly due to lower revenue from a UK development project. Revenue and gross profit also fell 12% and 33% respectively. The group has launched eight development projects in Singapore, selling over 1,700 units and securing S$1.9 billion in sales. Oxley accepted a letter of intent to sell its hotels for S$950 million and has sold several projects, including No 4 and No 5 of Dublin Landings.

site_title: Painting a mixed picture
summary: A panel of asset managers from HSBC Bank discussed major themes for 2019, including global economic growth, trade tensions, and market volatility. Deepak Khanna, Head of Wealth Development, emphasized the need for investors to be adaptable and prepared for uncertainty. He noted that 2019 would be a year of mixed signals, with both positive and negative trends influencing the market. Khanna advised investors to focus on long-term strategies and diversify their portfolios to navigate the uncertain economic landscape.

site_title: Najib's lawyer announces postponement of 1MDB trial
summary: Malaysia's Court of Appeal has postponed the trial of former Prime Minister Najib Razak pending an appeal over a lower court's ruling to transfer charges related to the multibillion-dollar 1MDB scandal. The trial was originally set to begin on Tuesday but has been delayed until the appeal is heard. Najib, who faces 10 charges of corruption and money laundering, has pleaded not guilty and claims the charges are politically motivated. The postponement is a blow to the government of Mahathir Mohamad, which had promised to bring those involved in the scandal to justice.

site_title: Budgeting on their terms
summary: Singapore's Budget 2019 has been released, focusing on budgeting on one's terms. The government aims to enhance the lives of Singaporeans through various initiatives, including a centre for sustainable aviation in Asia, improved employment rates, and support for tariff-hit businesses. The budget also highlights the importance of future-proofing careers and offers assistance for workers with limited resources. Key areas of focus include education, employment, and economic development, with the goal of creating a more sustainable and prosperous future for Singapore.

site_title: CapBridge offers private equity investments from S$5,000
summary: CapBridge, a Singapore-based global private syndication platform, has launched "Preferred Access", allowing individual accredited and expert investors to access private equity investment opportunities at a minimum of S$5,000. The platform provides a cost-efficient way for growth companies to tap global private capital while remaining privately held. The first company to participate in the program is a US-based healthcare equipment company. The partnership with Wholesale Investor boosts the platform's global scalability, offering access to key markets across Asia and Australia.

site_title: Kazakhstan delays listing of state oil firm as UK IPO market stalls
summary: Kazakhstan has delayed listing its state oil firm KazMunayGaz as an initial public offering (IPO) beyond 2019 due to tepid investor appetite, largely caused by uncertainty over Brexit, US political tensions, and the US-China trade war. The decision is also attributed to a global economic slowdown. The IPO was part of the country's broader plan to privatize state-owned companies and reduce the state's presence in the economy to 15% by 2021.

site_title: Optimism despite geopolitical woes
summary: Asia ex-Japan equities remain optimistic despite geopolitical risks, with strategists recommending overweight calls on the region's equities and fixed income assets. The US/China trade conflict and weaker China economy pose a significant overhang, but market sentiment is buoyed by the US Federal Reserve's "extended pause" and improving US-China trade talks. The IMF has downgraded its global growth forecast, but strategists expect Asia ex-Japan equities to benefit from attractive valuations and foreign investor positioning. Key strategists, including Credit Suisse, Bank of Singapore, and UBS, recommend a growth-at-a-reasonable price strategy and tactically overweight Asian and global equities.

site_title: New Australian regulations loom for tech giants
summary: Australia's competition watchdog, the ACCC, warns that new regulations are needed to protect independent journalism from the impact of digital platforms like Google and Facebook. Chairman Rod Sims states that these tech giants' market power has had a devastating effect on Australian news media. The ACCC aims to protect the future of independent journalism through these regulations, which are expected to be introduced soon.

site_title: SGX rejects 8Telecom's bid to issue new shares
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) has rejected 8Telecom's bid to issue new shares, including those intended for partial acquisitions of China Commodity Market and China Commodity Centre. The company had applied for 16 million new shares for the acquisitions and 16.88 million new shares for another deal, but both applications were rejected by the bourse regulator. SGX has requested 8Telecom to disclose steps to recover an aggregate loan of S$2.06 million from the two Chinese companies. 8Telecom is in discussions with the companies to revise the acquisition terms.

site_title: How EU leaders can prevent a no-deal Brexit
summary: European Union leaders can prevent a no-deal Brexit by removing the March 29 deadline, allowing for more time to negotiate a satisfactory agreement between the UK and EU. This approach would neutralize British Prime Minister Theresa May's threat of a no-deal Brexit and eliminate the need for concessions on the Irish border and trade agreements. By removing the deadline, EU leaders can give both sides time to seek a national consensus and decide on their future relationship with Europe.

site_title: The Ghosn effect? Nissan, Renault unveil first results post-crisis
summary: Nissan and Renault are set to release their earnings reports, which are expected to reveal the financial impact of the Carlos Ghosn scandal. Nissan's operating profit is forecast to fall 10% to its lowest in five years, while Renault's operating profit is expected to decline 8.8%. The companies are struggling with sluggish sales in China and the US, and are facing increased competition from Volkswagen and Toyota. The alliance partners are also dealing with the uncertainty of Brexit and stricter emission regulations. Nissan's CEO, Hiroto Saikawa, is pushing to rebalance the alliance to give his company more say in strategic decisions.

site_title: Manulife US Reit Q4 DPU up 7.7% on acquisitions
summary: Manulife US Reit (MUST) posted a 7.7% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.53 US cents in Q4, driven by acquisitions of office buildings in 2018. Net property income rose 38.4% to $25.5 million, with portfolio occupancy at 96.7% and a weighted average lease expiry of 5.8 years. The Reit's adjusted DPU for 2018 rose 3.6% to 6.05 US cents, and it is exploring options to refinance its upcoming loan maturing in July.

site_title: Swiss franc slumps in mini 'flash-crash'; dollar up on trade angst
summary: The Swiss franc experienced a mini "flash-crash" in Monday's Asia session, plummeting by one percent to 1.0095 before recovering to trade 0.2 percent stronger. The move was attributed to thin liquidity and no material news, with analysts downplaying the event. The dollar rose as investors sought safe-haven currencies amid concerns over a global economic slowdown and US-China trade tensions, with the Swiss franc down 0.2 percent at 1.002 francs per dollar.

site_title: SkillsFuture looks for new ways to measure outcomes of training
summary: SkillsFuture Singapore is expanding its efforts to measure the outcomes of training courses to increase transparency and inform policy decisions. The agency has conducted a training quality and outcomes measurement survey, with 80% of respondents indicating that training helped them. A longitudinal study with the Ministry of Trade and Industry found that training under the Singapore Workforce Skills Qualifications system led to higher employment rates for unemployed individuals. SkillsFuture plans to release more details and expand its work-learn programs, including bootcamp-style courses and a National Centre of Excellence for Workplace Learning.

site_title: Indonesian mall developer raises funds for expansion
summary: NWP Retail, an Indonesian shopping mall developer backed by Warburg Pincus, has completed a $200 million fundraising to drive expansion across the country. The company, which has grown from four seed projects to 33 developments since 2015, aims to double its projects over the next two to three years. The funding round was led by the Korean Teachers' Credit Union, Citic Securities One-Belt-One-Road Fund, and Warburg Pincus, and will support the development of modern multitenant shopping malls in key Indonesian cities.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Hyflux received over 30 queries from the Securities Investors Association Singapore regarding its CEO's remuneration and board accountability. The company is preparing responses to be published on its corporate website. UNUSUAL's third-quarter net profit rose 21.7% to S$3.1 million, driven by increased revenue. SAKAE Holdings reported a loss of S$545,000 in its second quarter, while HEALTH MANAGEMENT INTERNATIONAL's net profit declined 28% to RM11.3 million.

site_title: London banker sues UOB for 'unfair dismissal', alleges race discrimination
summary: A former London-based official at United Overseas Bank (UOB) Ltd is suing for unfair dismissal, alleging he was denied a new job due to alleged race discrimination. Daniel Smith, who worked at UOB for 23 years, claims a manager stated a South-east Asian candidate was a better "fit" for a role, and minutes of the meeting were altered after he questioned the comment. Smith was subsequently let go from his position.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Venture Corporation is expected to report Q4 2018 net profit of S$101 million, in line with consensus estimates. The company's strong shipments, especially in Retail Store Solutions and Test & Measurement/Medical segments, are expected to boost margins. However, a key client, Illumina, has flagged a back-loaded 2019, and Phillip Morris's IQOS device faces concerns in Japan. SIA Engineering's lower operating expenses and core earnings continue to weaken, with lower revenue from airframe and fleet management. The outlook is negative, with the company's core operations facing challenges from longer maintenance intervals and lighter work content.

site_title: Yoma Strategic buying 65% stake in Myanmar restaurant chain
summary: Yoma Strategic Holdings is acquiring a 65% stake in Myanmar restaurant chain Yankin Kyay Oh Group of Companies for approximately 19.4 billion kyat (S$17.1 million). The acquisition, funded by internal resources, is based on the company's current and projected earnings as of September 30, 2018. This marks a significant investment in Myanmar's restaurant industry, with YKKO being one of the largest chains in the country.

site_title: Pilots' strike leaves China Airlines passengers stranded in Asia
summary: A pilots' strike at China Airlines has left thousands of passengers stranded in Asia, with over 60 flights scrapped since February 8. The strike, which began due to pilot fatigue, has resulted in a 10% loss of scheduled operations for the Taiwanese carrier. The airline is demanding more pilots for long-haul flights, while the union is citing working conditions as a major issue. The strike highlights the shortage of skilled air crew in the Asia-Pacific region, which is expected to double in the next two decades.

site_title: SilkAir picks Thomson Aero Seating for cabin revamp
summary: SilkAir, the regional arm of Singapore Airlines, has partnered with Thomson Aero Seating to upgrade its Boeing 737 MAX 8 fleet ahead of a merger with SIA. The upgrades, starting from May 2020, will feature new lie-flat business class seats and retrofitted in-flight entertainment systems in both business and economy classes. The move aims to align SilkAir's products and services with SIA's, with a full re-branding and service delivery expected following the merger, currently without a confirmed date.

site_title: First Reit slides 4.39% after analyst downgrade to 'sell'
summary: First Reit's units fell 4.39% to S$1.09 after OCBC Investment Research downgraded the counter to "sell" citing uncompelling valuations and concerns over its main revenue contributor, Lippo Karawaci. The Reit's trailing 12-month returns are down 10% due to concerns over Lippo Karawaci's liquidity risks and potential divestment of its 10.6% stake in First Reit. Analysts expect this could impact First Reit's visibility over longer-term rental income.

site_title: Vicom posts 31% rise in net profit; proposes special dividend
summary: Vicom, a vehicle inspection firm, reported a 30.9% increase in net profit to S$34.7 million for its full year ended Dec 31, 2018. Revenue rose 3.1% to S$100.1 million, driven by higher business volumes. The company proposed a final dividend of 23.17 cents and a special dividend of 8.62 cents per share, totaling 31.79 cents. Net asset value rose to S$1.7016, and earnings per share improved to 39.15 cents. The company expects its vehicle testing business to remain stable, with plans to introduce new services in the non-vehicle testing business.

site_title: Netflix's Roma takes Bafta glory
summary: Netflix's film "Roma" won the top two awards at the 2019 Bafta film awards, taking home Best Film and Best Director for Alfonso Cuaron. The film also boosted its Oscar hopes. "The Favourite" won Best Actress for Olivia Colman and Best Supporting Actress for Rachel Weisz. Rami Malek won Best Actor for his portrayal of Freddie Mercury, while Mahershala Ali won Best Supporting Actor for his role in "Green Book".

site_title: Mall or park? Crowded Bangkok's last open space stirs lively debate
summary: A Bangkok green space, the Makkasan site, is at the center of a heated debate between communities, conservationists, and developers over its redevelopment. The 80-hectare site, currently home to a train station and warehouses, is the last remaining open space in the city. Authorities plan to study the best use of the land, considering demands for a park, museum, and commercial developments. The decision will balance the need for green space with the site's high economic value, with some warning that the city's character and heritage will be lost if it is redeveloped.

site_title: Thai election panel disqualifies princess as PM candidate
summary: Thailand's election panel disqualified Princess Ubolratana Rajakanya Sirivadhana Barnavadi, the king's sister, from running for prime minister due to her royal status being "above politics" and "politically neutral". The decision came after the princess accepted the nomination of the Thai Raksa Chart party, a populist movement linked to ousted ex-premier Thaksin Shinawatra. The move broke with tradition and sparked concerns about the royal family's influence in politics, with King Maha Vajiralongkorn stating that members of the royal family should remain "above politics".

site_title: Trendy time
summary: The SIHH watch fair showcased the latest trends in watchmaking for the new year, featuring unique timepieces from Vacheron Constantin, Audemars Piguet, Hermes, IWC, and Panerai. Notable releases include Vacheron Constantin's Les Cabinotiers Grand Complication Phoenix with 15 complications, Audemars Piguet's new Royal Oak Offshore Chronographs in camouflage colors, and IWC's Big Pilot Watch Constant-Force Tourbillon Edition "Le Petit Prince" with a constant force tourbillon mechanism. Additionally, Panerai's Submersible Chrono "Guillaume Nery" Edition was unveiled, designed for professional divers.

site_title: UOB targets emerging affluent customers with personalised investment services
summary: UOB is targeting emerging affluent customers with personalized investment services at its new wealth banking branch in Singapore. The bank will offer investment advisory tools and connect customers with investment advisors, typically reserved for private banking clients. This move aims to cater to younger, high-net-worth individuals seeking tailored investment guidance.

site_title: Steve Cohen has cut the price of his NYC apartment by 60%
summary: Billionaire Steve Cohen has reduced the asking price of his NYC apartment by 60%, from $115 million to $45 million. The 9,000 sq ft, five-bedroom duplex in One Beacon Court has been on the market for years, with previous price drops of over $70 million. Cohen's price cut comes after a six-year decline in the apartment's value, with a 2005 purchase price of $24 million. The sale is seen as a sign of the market adjusting to the changing luxury real estate landscape.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher as US-China trade talks restart
summary: US stocks opened higher on Monday as trade talks between the US and China resumed in Beijing. The Dow Jones rose 0.15%, the S&P 500 gained 0.17%, and the Nasdaq Composite rose 0.40%. This comes amid ongoing efforts by lawmakers to avoid a government shutdown.

site_title: Singapore banks likely to post record earnings for full year 2018
summary: Singapore banks are expected to announce record full year 2018 earnings, driven by modest loans growth and higher margins. Analysts anticipate higher dividend payouts from United Overseas Bank and OCBC Bank. The upcoming Q4 results will also provide insights into the banks' 2019 prospects, amid concerns about economic growth this year.

site_title: Thirsty for whisky
summary: Whisky sales have surged as investors seek to boost their portfolios, with some rare bottles fetching high prices. According to Whisky Invest Direct, an eight-year-old Scotch whisky has an average historical return of 11.8% per annum, making it a favorable investment option. However, rare whiskies can be counterfeited, with laboratory tests revealing that around £41 million worth of whisky is fake. Experts warn investors to thoroughly research before buying, and whisky makers emphasize the importance of enjoying and savoring the drink, rather than hoarding it as an investment.

site_title: Taking stock and looking ahead
summary: Lance Gokongwei, the 30-year-old CEO of JG Summit, is set to become chairman of the Philippine-based conglomerate after his uncle James Go steps down. Gokongwei has led the company's food business, Universal Robina, to regional success, and his airline, Cebu Pacific, is the country's largest budget carrier. He emphasizes the importance of technology in his business strategy, partnering with Hong Kong's Oriente to offer on-demand loans via a mobile application. Experts predict continued volatility in the market, with equities remaining a viable option for investors.

site_title: Made-in-Britain mozzarella on the rise as Brexit looms
summary: Made-in-Britain buffalo mozzarella is gaining popularity in the UK ahead of Brexit, with Laverstoke Park Farm in Hampshire producing the cheese. Owned by former Formula One champion Jody Scheckter, the farm's mozzarella is made from the milk of a herd roaming the green hills of southern England. The cheese is hoping to dethrone Italian mozzarella in the UK market, where 190% tariffs imposed on Italian goods could benefit domestic producers.

site_title: SGX rejects Nutryfarm's 90m yuan acquisition amid concerns over foreign ownership workaround
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has rejected Nutryfarm International's 90 million Chinese yuan (S$18 million) acquisition of a 45% stake in tech company First Linkage due to concerns over a contractual workaround to address foreign ownership restrictions. The market regulator raised questions about the legitimacy of the business structures used to comply with foreign ownership rules. This decision marks a significant setback for Nutryfarm's acquisition plans.

site_title: Education a means to 'save the country'
summary: Lance Gokongwei, son of Philippine business magnate John Gokongwei Jr, expresses concerns about his children's immersion in business. Unlike his father, who spent his childhood in his father's office, Gokongwei admits his children have less interest in business. He believes education is key to saving the country and credits his philanthropic efforts, through the Gokongwei Brothers Foundation, with focusing on STEM and technical-vocational education. Gokongwei sees wealth as a privilege that comes with responsibility, and aims to keep his children grounded.

site_title: France agrees 'strategic' pact with Qatar
summary: France and Qatar signed a "strategic dialogue" agreement on security and economic cooperation, marking a "new phase" for the two countries. The deal was signed by Qatar's Mohammed bin Abdulrahman Al-Thani and France's Jean-Yves Le Drian in Doha. The agreement aims to strengthen ties between the two nations, which have been affected by Qatar's diplomatic rift with Saudi Arabia and its allies.

site_title: Saudi Arabia would need oil at US$80-US$85 a barrel to balance budget - IMF
summary: Saudi Arabia would need oil priced between $80-$85 a barrel to balance its budget this year, according to IMF official Jihad Azour. The country's breakeven oil price depends on various factors, including oil production and non-oil revenues. With crude oil prices currently at around $62 a barrel, Saudi Arabia's public finances have been impacted, but its debt is not a concern due to tight bond spreads and high foreign exchange reserves. The government plans to increase state spending to boost the economy, but balancing the budget by 2023 remains its top priority.

site_title: No-deal Brexit 'could cost 600,000 jobs worldwide': study
summary: A study by the IWH institute found that a no-deal Brexit could put 600,000 jobs worldwide at risk, with Germany being the hardest hit, affecting 103,000 jobs. France's service sector would also be significantly impacted, with 50,000 jobs under threat. The study's authors noted that workers may not be laid off, but rather see their hours cut or jobs created in new markets. The study's findings come as the UK's exit date from the EU approaches on March 29.

site_title: India parliament panel says to summon Twitter chief on Feb 25
summary: India's parliamentary panel has decided to summon Twitter CEO Jack Dorsey on February 25 to discuss citizens' rights on social media. The panel chairman, Anurag Thakur, stated that Dorsey did not attend a hearing earlier and sent junior executives instead, which is seen as a breach of parliamentary privilege. The summons comes amid scrutiny of social media companies ahead of India's elections, where Prime Minister Narendra Modi is seeking re-election. Twitter has declined to comment on the summons, amid allegations of left-wing bias on its platform.

site_title: British PM May to make Brexit statement on Tuesday - spokesman
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May is set to make a statement on Tuesday to update lawmakers on her Brexit talks, ahead of a parliament vote on her next steps. This follows a week of talks with EU leaders to win changes to the Brexit deal. The statement will provide an update on her Brexit talks, which come as the UK economy shrinks for the second month in a row, further exacerbating concerns about the impact of Brexit on the country's economy.

site_title: Thai King's sister is formally barred from running for Prime Minister
summary: Thailand's election commission has formally disqualified Princess Ubolratana Rajakanya Sirivadhana Varnavadi, the king's sister, from running for prime minister due to her royal status and the king's opposition to her candidacy. The decision, made after the king publicly stated that her candidacy was "improper and highly inappropriate," means the Thai Raksa Chart Party will not be able to field a candidate for prime minister. The commission is also considering dissolving the party for violating electoral law.

site_title: Thai tycoon agrees to pay fine for Bangkok Airways share trading - regulator
summary: Thai billionaire Prasert Prasarttong-osoth and two other major shareholders of Bangkok Airways have agreed to pay a fine of nearly US$16 million for share price manipulation. The Securities and Exchange Commission found the trio traded shares among themselves between 2015 and 2016, affecting the airline's share price and trading volume. Prasert resigned as CEO of Bangkok Airways and Bangkok Dusit Medical Services, while his daughter and another executive also stepped down. The regulator barred them from holding directorships and executive positions at listed companies for two years.

site_title: EU begins process to hit Cambodia's with trade sanctions
summary: The European Union has begun an 18-month process to potentially suspend Cambodia's duty-free trade access under the "Everything but Arms" (EBA) regime due to concerns over human rights and democracy. The decision, which could lead to the suspension of Cambodia's special status, was triggered after elections maintained Prime Minister Hun Sen in power. The EU aims to ensure Cambodia improves its human rights record before making a final decision. The process will involve monitoring and talks with the Cambodian authorities before a report and potential withdrawal of trade preferences.

site_title: EU's Barnier says clarity on Brexit has to come from London
summary: EU's Michel Barnier says clarity on Brexit must come from the UK, stating that the Withdrawal Agreement is not open for renegotiation. Despite this, Barnier expressed readiness to rework the political declaration on future EU-UK ties to better explain the accord and its backstop. With the UK's exit day on March 29 looming, Barnier urged the British side to find a positive majority to move forward. The EU remains committed to the agreement, but Barnier emphasized that the UK must take the lead in finding clarity on the Brexit process.

site_title: F&N Q1 net profit up 47.5%
summary: Fraser & Neave (F&N) posted a 47.5% increase in Q1 net profit to S$37.9 million, driven by a higher share of associated companies' profit. Revenue inched up 0.4% to S$464.4 million, with Beverages and Dairies segments contributing to the growth. The group's associate company, Vinamilk, showed stronger performances in core markets, while Printing and Publishing revenue decreased due to lower print and distribution volume.

site_title: Singapore shares climb 0.1% on Monday
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.1% on Monday, with the Straits Times Index reaching 3,206.27. Financials led the gain, with DBS Group Holdings, United Overseas Bank, and OCBC Bank increasing 0.25%, 0.4%, and 0.44% respectively. The market saw a relatively balanced performance, with 196 decliners to 190 gainers, and a turnover of 1.55 billion securities worth S$1.06 billion.

site_title: Paul Scholes appointed manager of Oldham
summary: Former Manchester United and England midfielder Paul Scholes has been appointed as manager of Oldham Athletic, a fourth-tier English football club, on a one-and-a-half-year deal. Scholes, 44, is taking on his first managerial role after supporting the club as a boy during his entire playing career at Old Trafford. Owner Abdallah Lemsagam described Scholes as a man with a "hunger to succeed" and said the appointment brings "footballing knowledge" to the club.

site_title: Facebook expanding fact-checking in India before election
summary: Facebook is expanding its fact-checking network in India ahead of the country's general election due by May, taking seven partners, including the India Today Group. This move aims to quell the spread of misinformation in its biggest market by users. Facebook also recently tightened rules governing political advertisements in India to increase transparency.

site_title: Survival of the fittest
summary: The asset and wealth management (AWM) industry in Asia-Pacific is experiencing significant changes, driven by shifting market dynamics and growing wealth in the region. PwC forecasts Apac assets under management (AUM) to reach $29.6 trillion by 2025, creating opportunities for international asset managers to establish onshore activities. However, challenges such as geopolitical issues and trade tensions will persist. The industry is expected to be shaped by five core trends: regional inter-connectivity, integrating technology, digital identities, blockchain, and a rise in digital banks, which will require AWM players to navigate the new normal and take risks to survive.

site_title: China upbeat on US trade talks, but South China Sea tensions weigh
summary: US-China trade talks are set to begin, with the US pressuring China to reform its intellectual property treatment of American companies. The talks follow last month's failed negotiations and a March 1 deadline for increasing tariffs on $200 billion worth of Chinese imports to 25%. Tensions between the US and China remain high, with recent incidents including US warships sailing near disputed islands in the South China Sea. Chinese officials express hope for a good outcome, while US President Trump has indicated he will not meet with Chinese President Xi Jinping before the deadline.

site_title: Malaysian court postpones ex-PM Najib's corruption trial pending appeal
summary: A Malaysian court postponed the corruption trial of former Prime Minister Najib Razak pending an appeal, halting the trial of the former leader over charges related to a multibillion-dollar 1MDB scandal. Najib's lawyers filed an appeal over a lower court's ruling to transfer some charges, and the Court of Appeal agreed to postpone the trial until the appeal is heard. The postponement is seen as a blow to the government, which had reopened 1MDB probes and promised swift justice.

site_title: UOB sued by former London branch employee for race discrimination
summary: A former United Overseas Bank (UOB) employee, Daniel Smith, is suing the bank for unfair dismissal and race discrimination after being denied a new job due to his non-Asian background. Smith, a 23-year veteran, claims a manager told him he wasn't a "good fit" because he wasn't Asian, and the minutes of the meeting were altered to justify the decision. UOB's lawyer disputes the claim, stating the other candidate was better qualified. The case could result in a payout of up to £84,000 if proven.

site_title: Mall or park? In crowded Bangkok, 'last' open space stirs debate
summary: A 80-hectare green space in central Bangkok, the last remaining open space in the city, is at the center of a heated debate between communities, conservationists, and developers. The Makkasan area, owned by the State Railway of Thailand, is slated for redevelopment, with proposals ranging from a park to a mall and commercial developments. Critics argue that the space should be preserved for its historic and architectural value, while authorities claim the area is needed for accessibility and liveability. The decision will test Bangkok's commitment to sustainable development and its ability to balance the needs of its growing population.

site_title: Armoured van driver disappears in France with one million euros
summary: A 28-year-old armoured cash delivery van driver disappeared in France with an estimated one million euros, leaving behind an open van and two unharmed colleagues. The incident occurred in Aubervilliers, a suburb of Paris, on Monday morning. An inquiry has been opened by France's anti-gang squad, and the driver's whereabouts are currently unknown. This is the latest in a series of high-profile heists, with the last major incident occurring in 2009 when a driver escaped with 11.5 million euros.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed higher on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index increasing 2.04 points to 1,688.56. The index saw 489 gainers and 351 losers, with a total volume of 2.6 billion lots worth RM1.7 billion.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks edge higher; Sino-US talks in focus
summary: South Korean shares closed slightly higher on Monday as trade talks between the US and China began in Beijing. The Kospi stock index rose 0.17% to 2,180.73, while bond yields fell. The US dollar rose 0.91% against the Korean won, which was steady against the dollar. The US and China's trade talks follow a recent round of negotiations in Washington without a deal.

site_title: Vicom posts FY18 profit rise, announces special dividend
summary: Vicom Ltd posted a 30.9% rise in net profit to S$34.7 million for FY18, driven by higher business volumes and an "other income" of S$7.7 million from the sale of a property. Revenue increased 3.1% to S$100.1 million. The company proposed a final dividend of 23.17 cents per share, including a special dividend of 8.62 cents. Vicom's shares closed unchanged at S$6.10, and the company expects its vehicle-testing business to remain stable despite a slowing Singapore economy.

site_title: The slow boat to Brexit oblivion is leaving soon
summary: The UK is set to leave the European Union on March 29, 2019, without a deal in place to maintain open borders and trade. This uncertainty is causing chaos for British exporters, with some companies shipping goods weeks ahead of the deadline to avoid potential delays or disputes over customs duties. Others are air freighting goods to avoid the risks, while some see a potential benefit in a no-deal Brexit scenario if the pound depreciates, making their goods cheaper for foreign buyers. The UK government is prioritizing avoiding disruption to global trading relationships.

site_title: The new Picasso? Meet Ai-Da the robot artist
summary: British artist Ai-Da, a robot created by Engineered Arts, is set to debut as the world's first "AI ultra-realistic robot artist." With a bionic hand and a prosthetic head, Ai-Da will draw and paint, and engage with audiences as a performance artist. Equipped with cameras in her eyeballs and a "RoboThespian" body, she will mimic human expressions and movements. Ai-Da's inaugural exhibition, "Unsecured Futures," is scheduled for May at the University of Oxford, with sketches to be displayed in London in November, raising questions about the potential of robots in creative fields.

site_title: Oxley Q2 net profit down 33%
summary: Oxley Holdings reported a 33% decline in net profit for the second quarter ended Dec 31, 2018, to S$45.2 million, due to lower revenue contribution from a project in the UK. Revenue dropped 12% to S$355.5 million, and gross profit fell 33% to S$46.4 million. The decline was attributed to lower margins from the UK development project.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Senior Minister of State for Trade and Industry Koh Poh Koon announced extra support for Singaporean SMEs to encourage worker training. Ex-Citibank CEO Han Kwee Juan joined DBS as group head of strategy and planning. UOB was sued by a former London branch employee for alleged race discrimination. Singapore shares rose 0.1% on Monday, with the Straits Times Index gaining 4.23 points to 3,206.27. Meanwhile, Vietnam was surprised by the US tariff announcement and sought a lower rate, while China's GDP growth is expected to slow, raising pressure on policymakers.

site_title: Indonesian entertainers protest law on 'pornography', blasphemy in music
summary: Indonesian entertainers have protested a draft law banning blasphemous and "pornographic" music content, which critics say could stifle freedom of expression. Over 100 protestors gathered in Bogor, near Jakarta, against the proposed law, which would impose onerous requirements on musicians and potentially jail or fine those who fail to comply. The bill's vague wording has raised concerns about its potential misuse by authorities, with over 270,000 people signing an online appeal to scrap the legislation. The law aims to strengthen Indonesia's entertainment industry, but many see it as a threat to artistic freedom.

site_title: Swiss say Bombardier trains still not meeting expectations
summary: Swiss Federal Railways (SBB) expressed disappointment with Bombardier trains, stating they have yet to meet expectations. The Canadian company is working to correct issues, including software improvements and maintenance on problematic doors. SBB has delayed taking new trains from Bombardier until existing ones are fixed, raising concerns about future deliveries under a $1.89 billion contract. The issue is described as a "painful forceps delivery" that both companies aim to resolve for a 40-year operational lifespan.

site_title: Europe: Shares recover from 1-week low as trade talks resume
summary: European shares rose 0.7-0.8% on Monday, rebounding from a one-week low, driven by gains in mining and banking stocks. China's trade talks with the US resumed, but tensions remained high over a US Navy mission through the South China Sea. The STOXX 600 index led the gain, with heavyweight mining stocks like Glencore, Rio Tinto, and BHP rising around 1%. Banks also benefited, with Banco BPM up 3.3% after disclosing capital requirements. The recovery was seen as a relief for investors, who had been concerned about the impact of US tariffs on the region's trade.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks rise as mainland trade resumes
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose Monday as mainland Chinese markets reopened after the Lunar New Year week. The Hang Seng Index gained 0.71%, and the Shanghai Composite Index rose 1.36%. The US stock market also saw gains, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edging to fresh records despite ongoing trade tensions. The rally is attributed to US officials gearing up for key trade talks with Beijing.

site_title: Australia shares dragged down by financials; NZ gains
summary: Australian shares fell 0.2% on Monday, weighed down by declines in banks and healthcare stocks. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 6,060.8. Resource stocks, including BHP Group and Rio Tinto, rose 1.8% on Chinese iron ore futures hitting record highs. Financial stocks fell 1.2% and healthcare stocks declined 1.7% after a Royal Commission inquiry opened. New Zealand's benchmark index rose 0.4% on gains from A2 Milk Company and Fisher & Paykel Healthcare.

site_title: The most narcissistic exercise equipment ever
summary: The Mirror, a 52-inch home exercise equipment, has gained popularity among celebrities and fitness enthusiasts. The device, which retails for $1,495, transforms into a virtual fitness studio offering live classes, personalized feedback, and on-demand workouts. The company, founded by Brynn Putnam, a Harvard-educated former ballet dancer, has raised $38 million and sells $1 million worth of devices per month. Luxury hotels and high-end gyms have also adopted the technology, with users averaging 2.2 devices per household. The Mirror aims to become users' third screen, with plans for personal training, sports prep, and more.

site_title: Peru's environmental watchdog reports tailings spill from Southern Copper mine
summary: Peru's environmental watchdog, OEFA, is investigating a tailings spill from Southern Copper's Cuajone mine into the Torata River, approximately 535 miles southeast of Lima. The spill occurred due to heavy rainfall and has stopped, according to the company. The incident occurred in an area already affected by heavy rains, resulting in at least five deaths and hundreds of homes damaged. The OEFA will determine the cause of the spill, responsibility, and its impact.

site_title: Apple's iPhone shipments plunge in China as Huawei tightens grip
summary: Apple's Chinese smartphone shipments plummeted 20% in the final quarter of 2018, a decline of about twice the overall market contraction of 9.7%. The slowdown was attributed to a slowing economy, longer replacement times, and the iPhone's high price tag. Chinese rival Huawei, however, saw a 23.3% surge in shipments, solidifying its lead in the market. The decline marks a significant retreat for Apple in China, where it once drove its growth.

site_title: The next wave of 'unicorn' start-ups
summary: A new wave of "unicorn" start-ups, worth $1 billion, is emerging in Silicon Valley, driven by software solutions for specific industries such as agriculture, finance, and life sciences. These companies, which have raised significant funding, are growing rapidly and may become the next unicorns. Examples include Benchling, a software company for molecular biology labs, Farmers Business Network, which provides data analysis for farmers, and Zola, a wedding planning platform popular among millennials. Other startups, such as Checkr and Earnin, are building businesses around the gig economy and serving millennial women.

site_title: Hyflux preparing responses to SIAS' queries on renumeration, accountability
summary: Hyflux confirmed receiving over 30 queries from the Securities Investors Association Singapore (SIAS) on remuneration and accountability, and is preparing responses to be published on its website. The queries, sent by SIAS chief David Gerald, raised concerns over the company's financial position, valuation, and board operations. Gerald questioned the justification of key executives' remuneration and the board's handling of operational faults and defaults in Hyflux's main assets. The company will respond to the queries to help investors make an informed decision regarding the restructuring.

site_title: Indonesia rate hikes unlikely despite widening current account deficit: Citi
summary: Indonesia's central bank is unlikely to hike its policy rate further due to foreign exchange supply from capital inflows covering the widening current account deficit. The deficit widened to 3.6% of GDP in the fourth quarter of 2018, but Citi economist Helmi Arman expects it to fluctuate towards 3% in Q1 and 2% in the second half of the year. The focus on growth preservation ahead of the April elections may lead to a more favorable exchange rate.

site_title: China iron ore rises to record on concerns over Brazilian supply
summary: China's iron ore futures reached a record high of 652 yuan (S$130.60) a tonne on Monday, driven by concerns over a potential decline in Brazilian supply following a fatal dam accident at a Vale SA mine. The Brazilian government ordered Vale to stop using eight dams, affecting 9% of its annual iron ore output, and analysts expect a widened supply gap to push up prices. This increase is also linked to China's steelmaking city Tangshan imposing production restrictions to improve air quality.

site_title: Ex-Citibank Singapore CEO Han Kwee Juan joining DBS as group head of strategy and planning
summary: DBS Group Holdings announced that former Citibank Singapore CEO Han Kwee Juan will join the bank as group head of strategy and planning in April. Han, who spent 27 years with Citibank, will report to CEO Piyush Gupta and be a member of the group management committee. This move is seen as a strategic addition to DBS's leadership, allowing the bank to gain from new perspectives and supplement its bench with external talent.

site_title: TPG raises US$4.6b for Asia-focused private equity fund
summary: TPG has raised over US$4.6 billion for its Asia-focused private equity fund, exceeding its previous pool of capital by 40% and its largest in the region. The firm has already committed 40% of the fund to 12 companies, including Du Xiaoman and Healthscope Ltd's Asian pathology business. This is part of a trend of record-breaking capital raises by Asia-focused buyout funds, with Bain Capital and Blackstone Group also raising significant funds in recent months.

site_title: Broker's take: Jefferies upgrades CDL to 'buy' amid property sector headwinds
summary: Broker Jefferies has upgraded City Developments (CDL) from "hold" to "buy", citing decent take-up for the developer's recent property launches and improved hotel operations. Analyst Krishna Guha raised his target price to S$12, citing a 1.31% gain in CDL's share price. Guha attributes the upgrade to strong take-up rates for CDL's recent projects, hotel revenue growth, and a diversified portfolio. He expects the trend to bode well for 2019 projects and for CDL to mitigate weakness in business segments through recurring revenue growth.

site_title: CapBridge offers investors access to private equity investments at smaller ticket sizes
summary: CapBridge, a Singapore-based private syndication platform, has launched "Preferred Access", enabling individual accredited and expert investors to access private equity investments at smaller ticket sizes (S$5,000). The platform allows users to view investment deals and co-invest with professional investors. The partnership with Wholesale Investor boosts global scalability, providing access to key Asian and Australian markets. This move enables growth companies to access global private capital efficiently, while remaining privately held.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Monday afternoon at 3,182.36, down 0.61%
summary: Singapore stocks fell 0.61% to 3,182.36 at 1:05pm, with 198 losers outnumbering 123 gainers. Key stocks, including DBS Group Holdings and Singtel, declined 0.53% and 0.98% respectively. The losses came ahead of pivotal US-China trade talks in Beijing, with 923.21 million securities worth S$456.01 million changing hands.
