The article suggests that the fuss over prawns may stem from a desire for someone to take care of this task, and that having someone toil away while others reap the rewards is not a bad deal after all.

site_title: SIA Engineering's Q3 profit dips amid challenging environment
summary: SIA Engineering reported a 40% decline in Q3 net profit to S$33.1 million due to lower share of profits from associated and joint venture companies. Revenue dropped 5.6% to S$255.9 million, while operating profit fell 15.4% to S$15.9 million. The company expects a challenging operating environment and will focus on its transformation journey and investments in technologies to drive sustainable growth.

site_title: Longtime Nintendo bull slashes target, says Switch console has peaked
summary: A Nintendo analyst, Hirotoshi Murakami, has downgraded his target price for the company's stock by 44% to 26,400 yen, citing concerns that the Switch console's earnings have peaked. The downgrade follows a recent cut in Nintendo's shipment outlook and a sharp drop in profit from its 3DS handheld gaming device. This marks the end of Murakami's four-year recommendation to buy the stock, which would have resulted in a negative one-year return of 34%. The downgrade is the latest blow to Nintendo's shares, which have tumbled 29% last year due to concerns over the Switch's cannibalization of 3DS sales.

site_title: Ikea mulls greener strategy
summary: Ikea is testing a new "circular economy" approach by leasing furniture to customers, with the option to upgrade and refurbish old pieces for other users. The trial in Switzerland aims to reduce waste and encourage reuse, as the company seeks to move away from its traditional model of selling products that are often used briefly and discarded. This approach could limit waste and provide an incentive for companies to make more durable products, with the goal of reducing the environmental impact of consumer goods.

site_title: Garuda in talks with Gojek to provide logistics support
summary: Indonesia's national carrier Garuda is in advanced talks with ride-hailing app Gojek to provide logistics support, enabling easier delivery of goods across the country's 17,000 islands. The partnership aims to help Gojek overcome logistics challenges and expand its e-commerce services. Garuda is developing new e-commerce and logistics technology, which will be used to transport goods ordered via Gojek's app. An agreement is expected to be finalized within the next few months, marking a significant step for both companies.

site_title: Australia's central bank steps up warning on housing, cuts growth forecasts
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) has cut forecasts for domestic growth to 3% this year and 2.7% through 2021, citing a sharp downturn in the property market as a significant uncertainty. The central bank also predicted underlying inflation will stay below its 2-3% target band through to June 2021. The downbeat outlook led to a downgrade in interest rate forecasts, with a full 25 basis point cut to 1.25% expected later this year, and a small chance of further easing next year.

site_title: Investing in China could be very rewarding in 2019
summary: Investors looking to China in 2019 face uncertainty due to the country's trade dispute with the US and slowing economy. Despite this, some areas of the economy remain robust, such as retail sales, and corporate performance is starting to improve. Valuations of Chinese companies have fallen, making them attractive to selective stockpickers. The author believes that investing in China could be rewarding in 2019, citing past success in the Year of the Pig in 2007, and is optimistic about the potential for progress in trade talks between the US and China.

site_title: Remittance fintech TransferWise's head of Asia-Pac expansion leaves
summary: TransferWise's head of Asia-Pacific expansion, Lukas May, has resigned as part of the company's international expansion out of the UK. May's role focused on establishing relationships with commercial banks and central banks in the region. His departure is the latest in a series of high-profile changes at the billion-dollar fintech firm.

site_title: US 30-year mortgage rates fall to 10-month low
summary: US 30-year mortgage rates fell to a 10-month low of 4.41% in the week ended Feb 7, according to Freddie Mac data. This decline is attributed to concerns about weakening domestic growth and the Federal Reserve's signal to pause interest rate hikes. The drop in borrowing costs is expected to boost US home sales this spring, which is typically a busy time for the housing industry. Mortgage rates have been lower than 4.4% since April last year, and are similar to rates a year ago but with more consumer bargaining power.

site_title: Asian investors hold the most bullish outlook for 2019
summary: Asian investors remain optimistic about the market and economy, with 62% expecting positive returns over the next 10 years, compared to 51% for the short-term. Despite concerns about trade, politics, and healthcare costs, investors are more resilient and have a long-term positive outlook. In fact, 85% of business owners in South-east Asia and 79% in Greater China are positive about their businesses, with female business owners being the most optimistic. Investors are also bullish about investment returns, with 60% expecting positive returns over the next six months.

site_title: Singapore shares close flat on Friday
summary: Singapore shares closed flat on Friday, with the Straits Times Index rising 1.40 points to 3,202.04. The market saw 222 losers and 150 gainers, with Ezion Holdings being the most actively traded stock. Financials like DBS Group Holdings, OCBC Bank, and United Overseas Bank also saw slight drops. The rally is seen as a precursor to upcoming GDP data, with investors maintaining a positive outlook despite tariff uncertainty and split Fed views.

site_title: Gold stumbles on US dollar vigour
summary: Gold prices fell this week due to a strong US dollar, which increased interest-bearing assets' appeal. Despite this, the precious metal remains fundamentally supported due to a flagging global economy and heightened geopolitical risks. Global central banks may pause monetary policy tightening, potentially supporting gold prices. A bearish correction is possible, but a resumption of upward momentum is expected as risk-off sentiments prevail. Key resistance levels are at $1,325 and $1,316, while support is at $1,298.

site_title: Citibank Singapore CEO Han Kwee Juan resigns
summary: Citibank Singapore CEO Han Kwee Juan has resigned after nearly three decades with the bank, citing no reason for his departure. He will be replaced by Vikas Kumar, head of cards and personal loans at Citibank Singapore, as interim country business manager. Han Kwee Juan held various senior roles across the bank, including head of retail banking and consumer banking. He will leave the bank after a 27-year career, during which he championed innovation and contributed to the development of a skills future framework.

site_title: At Ritual, a big push to go global
summary: Ritual, a Singapore-based boutique gym, is expanding globally with franchises in South Africa, Brazil, Switzerland, Spain, and the US. The company has 22 gyms planned for 2019, with branches in countries such as Los Angeles and Zurich. Ritual's franchising model is successful due to franchise owners' motivation to execute projects and maintain quality standards, as well as the company's rigorous auditing and support processes. The gym's 20-minute HIIT workout concept remains consistent worldwide, and flexibility is key to its sustainability, with classes available every 30 minutes.

images.alt_text: In Singapore, Ritual has branches at Raffles Place, Holland Village and Robinson Road. There are plans now to open two more gyms here.
In Singapore, Ritual has branches at Raffles Place, Holland Village and Robinson Road. There are plans now to open two more gyms here.

site_title: Chinese businessman denies reported justification for Australian visa cancellation
summary: Chinese businessman Huang Xiangmo denied Australian authorities' claims that he was denied residency due to suspected foreign interference and unfit for residency. The decision to revoke his visa came after intelligence agencies concluded he could undertake "acts of foreign interference." Huang rejected the assessment, calling the decision "profoundly disappointing" and "unfounded speculations." The move comes amid strained ties between Australia and China, which have been seeking to repair relations since 2017.

site_title: Sony stock jumps after first-ever share buyback announcement
summary: Sony Corp announced its first-ever major share buyback worth 100 billion yen (S$1.23 billion), helping its stock recover from a recent downturn. The move was seen as a response to lacklustre earnings, and follows SoftBank Group Corp's own share buyback announcement earlier in the week. The buyback aims to boost investor confidence and support the company's long-term growth.

site_title: Rixsky business
summary: The article discusses the mispronunciation of the term "asterisk" in English-speaking countries, often being referred to as "asterix" due to the popular French comic book series Asterix. The author attributes this confusion to the comic book's influence, suggesting that the mispronunciation stems from the Gaulish warrior's name, Obelix, whose name is also often mispronounced as "obelix". The author proposes that the term "asterisk" should be referred to as "star sign" to avoid confusion, drawing inspiration from other languages' more sensible naming conventions.

site_title: Malaysia shares close lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed 6.87 points lower on Monday, at 1,686.52. Volume reached 248 million lots worth RM1.7 billion. Gainers outnumbered losers 407 to 344.

site_title: Trump says he will not meet Xi before trade deal deadline
summary: US President Donald Trump announced he will not meet with Chinese President Xi Jinping before a March 2 trade deal deadline, raising concerns about the US-China trade agreement. The decision reverses Trump's previous plan to meet with Xi, and a face-to-face meeting is unlikely due to the tight deadline. The US has threatened to increase tariffs on $200 billion of Chinese goods to 25% if a deal is not reached, which could further escalate the trade war and inflict economic damage on both countries. A deal without a meeting is considered unlikely, with analysts viewing the lack of a formal meeting as a bad sign.

images.alt_text: Mr Trump and Mr Xi at the G-20 Summit in Buenos Aires, on Dec 1, 2018. Trump administration officials have offered mixed signals and cautious optimism about how the negotiations have been going.

site_title: The Philippines central bank keeps policy rate on hold; more focus on domestic liquidity
summary: The Philippines' central bank, Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas (BSP), kept its benchmark interest rate at 4.75% as expected, while cutting inflation forecasts for 2019 and 2020. The BSP is now focusing on domestic liquidity, with Deputy Governor Diwa Guinigundo warning of potential tightening liquidity due to a planned retail bond offering. Economist Noelan Arbis expects 300 basis point of reverse repo rate cuts, potentially lowering the rate to 15% by the end of the year.

site_title: CAD seeking documents on certain bank transactions from Mercurius Capital Investment
summary: Mercurius Capital Investment received a letter from the Singapore Commercial Affairs Department (CAD) seeking documents related to two bank transactions in January 2016, linked to the company's former children's clothing business. The CAD has not disclosed the subject of the investigation or possible offence. Mercurius stated it will cooperate fully with the CAD and that the investigation does not affect its current core business of property investment and development. The company's shares closed at 2.7 Singapore cents on February 1, 2019.

site_title: Jaguar's China woes push Tata Motors shares to its lowest level in a decade
summary: Tata Motors shares plummeted to a decade-low after the company wrote down its US$3.9 billion investment in Jaguar Land Rover due to China's slowdown, technological disruptions, and rising debt costs. The decline, 30% on an intraday basis, is the largest since 1993 and follows Jaguar Land Rover's struggles with a shift away from petrol and diesel vehicles, as well as Brexit uncertainty. The parent company's net loss was 270 billion rupees (S$5.1 billion) in the three months through December.

site_title: Mercurius Capital Investment receives order from CAD to provide documents, information
summary: Mercurius Capital Investment has received a letter from the Commercial Affairs Department (CAD) seeking documents and information related to two bank transactions in January 2016, linked to the company's disposed children's clothing business. The company will cooperate fully with the investigation, stating its operations are not affected and will continue as normal.

site_title: Lereno Bio-Chem revises completion date for acquisition of Knit Textile and Apparel
summary: LERENO Bio-Chem has revised the completion date for its acquisition of Knit Textile and Apparel to February 28, from the previously set date of February 11. The acquisition, valued at approximately S$26.4 million, is part of the company's reverse takeover attempt. Knit Textile and Apparel is a private company specializing in contract manufacturing of apparel, primarily in Malaysia and Cambodia, and is expanding into upstream textile production. This marks the third RTO attempt by Lereno Bio-Chem since its designation as a cash company in 2015.

site_title: Renault ex-chairman Ghosn to reimburse Versailles palace for cost of 2016 wedding
summary: Renault's former chairman Carlos Ghosn plans to reimburse the Chateau de Versailles for the estimated 50,000 euros (S$76,800) cost of his 2016 wedding party. The move comes after Renault disclosed that Ghosn may have improperly used a sponsorship deal to host the event. The palace will compensate the carmaker, while Ghosn remains in a Tokyo prison on allegations of financial crimes. Renault started its own investigation after Ghosn's arrest, which is "starting to get results," according to French Finance Minister Bruno Le Maire.

site_title: My life in theatre
summary: A renowned theatre director reflects on the rapid blurring of global boundaries in the arts. Having lived and worked in various countries, he notes that experimental theatre has brought together Western and Eastern approaches, resulting in a fusion of styles. This trend is also seen in the intersection of disciplines, such as pop music and classical forms. The director's current role at LASALLE College of the Arts in Singapore aims to further this fusion, and he believes the city-state has tremendous potential for artistic innovation, with a thriving performing arts scene and a supportive government.

site_title: Singapore police raid Wirecard office following FT reports
summary: Singapore police raided Wirecard's office on Friday following FT reports alleging fraud and creative accounting. The raid comes after Wirecard shed $10 billion in value since the reports were published, with the company rejecting the allegations as defamatory. Wirecard has pledged cooperation with the investigation, but CEO Markus Braun claims no evidence of criminal misconduct has been found. The company has also announced plans to sue the Financial Times for "unethical reporting."

site_title: Seoul: Stocks fall over 1% on signs of intensifying trade tensions
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index fell 1.20% on Friday, closing at 2,177.05, due to intensifying Sino-US trade tensions. US President Donald Trump stated he won't meet Chinese President Xi Jinping before a March 1 deadline, fuelling concerns. The won was steady, while bond yields fell. The Kospi weakened 1.2% for the week, snapping four consecutive weekly gains.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's Court of Appeal upheld an order for Commerzbank to pay Long Well S$41 million for breaching agreements. Procurri Corporation terminated discussions with a second interested buyer, and TSH Corporation completed a reverse takeover to enter the pub and bar business. Resources Prima and Ang Liang Kim agreed to extend the completion date for a convertible loan pact. Singapore shares closed flat, with the Straits Times Index up 0.04% to 3,202.04.

site_title: Gold rush still has legs after recent pullback
summary: Gold prices have pulled back after hitting an eight-month high, but experts say the asset still has room to rally in the near to medium term due to global volatility. The US Federal Reserve's dovish tone and unresolved trade tensions are factors supporting gold's ascent. Analysts expect the metal to reach $1,350 in the near term, with some predicting a potential surge to $1,400 if central banks ease monetary policy or geopolitical tensions escalate. However, a recent coordinated dovish strike from central banks and fading enthusiasm for safe havens may limit gold's upside.

site_title: SIA Engineering's Q3 profit declines amid challenging environment
summary: SIA Engineering reported a 40% decline in third-quarter net profit to S$33.1 million, mainly due to lower profits from associated and joint venture companies. Revenue dropped 5.6% to S$255.9 million, while operating profit fell 15.4% to S$15.9 million. The company attributed the decline to one-time events and a challenging operating environment, which it expects to remain challenging. SIA Engineering shares finished 0.8% higher at S$2.52.

site_title: European stock markets slip at open
summary: European stock markets declined in opening deals on Friday, driven by doubts over US-China trade talks and the global economic outlook. London's FTSE 100 index fell 0.1% to 7,086.63 points, while the Paris CAC 40 and Frankfurt's DAX 30 indices also dropped 0.1% and 0.3% respectively. The declines were attributed to concerns over the US-China trade talks and the global economic outlook, despite some sectors such as mining and healthcare performing better.

site_title: Tokyo's Nikkei closes down over 2%
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei 225 index dropped 2.01% to 20,333.17, following a global market slide due to lowered European economic outlook and receding hopes for US-China trade talks. The Topix index also fell 1.89%. The decline was attributed to concerns over the US-China trade talks and European economic outlook.

site_title: Singapore top court upholds order for Commerzbank to pay Long Well S$41m for breaching agreements
summary: Singapore's Court of Appeal has upheld an order for Commerzbank-owned Commerzbank Asset Management Asia to pay Long Well S$41 million for breaching agreements. The dispute centered on a soured investment in Libyan oil and gas concessions in 2005. The High Court had initially ordered CAMA to pay the amount, including interest, in March 2018. The latest judgment, delivered by three judges, concludes a long-running litigation case that began in 2012. CAMA's lawyers have not commented on the ruling.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Friday afternoon at 3,196.95, down 0.1% on day
summary: Singapore stocks resumed trading on Friday afternoon, down 0.1% at 3,196.95, with about 644.1 million securities changing hands. Losers outnumbered gainers 180 to 118. Key players like Ezion Holdings and ThaiBev were trading down, while Yangzijiang Shipbuilding shares rose. The market followed a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, with investors bracing for US-EU trade talks and tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Meat giant Tyson signals potential M&A slowdown after deals
summary: Tyson Foods, the US's largest meat processor, has signaled a potential slowdown in mergers and acquisitions (M&A) after recent deals. The company's CEO, Noel White, stated that any future acquisitions would need to deliver strong financial returns and be in a strategic geographic area. Tyson has been expanding into value-added products and abroad to combat declining sales at home. The company plans to tap bond markets to finance recent acquisitions and will be "very disciplined" in its approach to future deals.

site_title: Shares of Jaguar Land Rover parent Tata Motors plunge most in 26 years after record loss
summary: Tata Motors shares plummeted 30% in Mumbai trading, the largest drop in 26 years, after the company reported a record loss of 270 billion rupees due to a writedown of its Jaguar Land Rover unit. The decline was attributed to sluggish sales in China, geopolitical uncertainty, and technological disruption. Analysts expect the company to slash its global workforce by 4,500, resulting in a one-time exceptional redundancy cost. The rating company Fitch Ratings has placed Tata Motors on negative credit watch, citing the company's exposure to a disorderly Brexit.

site_title: Hot stock: Best World extends rally, up 5% at midday break
summary: Best World International shares rose 5% at the midday break, reaching S$3.18, after averaging 1.86 million shares traded over the last 15 trading days. The company expects to report its earnings for fiscal 2018 after the market closes on February 26. Heavy trading, with 2.88 million shares changing hands in the morning session, contributed to the counter's rally.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower on Friday, STI down 0.51% to 3,184.22
summary: Singapore stocks opened lower on the last trading day of the Chinese New Year week, retreating 16.42 points, or 0.51%, to 3,184.22. Losers outnumbered gainers 80 to 45, with Thai Beverage trading down 0.5% and Ezion Holdings declining 2.13%.

site_title: Why Shanghai's new Nasdaq-style tech board may be a game-changer
summary: China's new Nasdaq-style tech board in Shanghai aims to address concerns of regulatory oversight and profitability requirements for startups, offering a registration-based system and allowing "pre-profit" companies to go public. The board, expected to launch by June, will focus on emerging industries such as high-tech equipment manufacturing, new energy, and biotechnology. This move is seen as a counter to US curbs on China's technology advancement and aims to increase domestic funding alternatives for Chinese tech startups, potentially positioning Shanghai as a competitor to Hong Kong and New York in capital-raising.

site_title: Ubolratana: the pop-singing Thai princess now plunging into politics
summary: Thai Princess Ubolratana, the 67-year-old elder sister of King Vajiralongkorn, is making her entry into politics. She has cultivated a more accessible image, embracing pop culture and reading the sentiments of ordinary Thais. Her frequent social media posts suggest sympathies with the Shinawatra dynasty, and she has been spotted with Shinawatra supporters, fueling rumors she may run as a prime ministerial candidate for a Thaksin-linked party in the upcoming general election.

site_title: Birkin bag maker Hermes says Chinese sales momentum still strong
summary: Hermes, a French luxury handbag label, reported strong sales momentum in its Chinese stores during the fourth quarter, with sales rising 9.6% at constant exchange rates. The company attributed the growth to strong demand in Asia, excluding Japan, and expects its operating margin to remain close to 34% for 2018. Hermes plans to expand its e-commerce business to other Asian countries, despite concerns over China's slowing economic growth and the Washington-Beijing trade war.

site_title: British millennials, Gen Z battle 'unfair' Brexit
summary: British millennials and Gen Z are protesting the "unfair" Brexit, with many feeling that older generations are imposing the decision on them. The 22-year-old Cambridge University student, Lara Spirit, has put her studies on hold to fight against Brexit, citing concerns about economic repercussions and loss of EU freedoms. A youth group, Our Future, Our Choice, has been formed to campaign for a second Brexit referendum, with activists arguing that young people's participation in the EU is crucial for tackling climate change and other issues.

site_title: Lenders dump Anil Ambani group shares after US$1.8b of value wiped out
summary: Lenders dumped shares of Anil Ambani group companies after a 126 billion rupee (US$1.8 billion) value drop, reducing founders' stakes by 3-8 percentage points. Creditors sold 5.5 billion shares in four firms, including Reliance Communications, which plans to file for bankruptcy, and Reliance Power, whose shares have crashed 60%. The selloff eroded the value of shares pledged as collateral, adding to the woes of Indian billionaire Anil Ambani's group.

site_title: FSL Trust units receive up to US$25m bridging loan from sponsor for tanker buys
summary: FSL Trust, a Singapore-based ship leasing company, has secured a secured, interest-bearing bridging loan of up to US$25 million from its sponsor, FSL Holdings, to partially finance the acquisition of two newbuild tankers. The loan, with a 6-month term, will be used to pay for the tankers, which were purchased for US$97.6 million. An initial drawdown of US$10 million has been made, with US$4.88 million used to pay for the tankers and US$120,000 each for working capital.

site_title: Thai king's sister named PM candidate by Thaksin-linked party
summary: Thailand's Princess Ubolratana Rajakanya, the sister of King Maha Vajiralongkorn, has been named as a prime ministerial candidate by the Thai Raksa Chart Party, a party linked to former PM Thaksin Shinawatra. This unprecedented move marks a significant shift in Thai politics, where the royal family is treated as semi-divine and apolitical. The nomination is seen as a boost for Thaksin, who lives in exile, and a blow to the Thai junta leader's efforts to return to power. The election, set for March 24, is expected to be closely watched by investors and could impact Thaksin's chances of returning to Thailand.

site_title: Italy pulling out of high speed rail link would cost it up to 4b euros: paper
summary: Italy is considering pulling out of the high-speed rail link to France, known as TAV, which could cost the country up to 4 billion euros (S$6.2 billion). The cost-benefit analysis, still secret, was sent to Paris and the European Union. A document cited by Il Sole 24 Ore, a daily newspaper, revealed the estimated cost of abandoning the project. The decision would have significant economic implications for Italy, highlighting the potential risks of backing out of major infrastructure projects.

site_title: Jaguar owner posts biggest quarterly loss in India on China car slump
summary: Tata Motors Ltd, the Indian owner of Jaguar Land Rover Automotive, reported a record quarterly loss of 270 billion rupees (S$5.1 billion) due to a slump in China's car market. The company attributed the loss to a charge stemming from the decline in China's car sales and the industry's shift away from petrol and diesel engines. Jaguar Land Rover faces challenges from Brexit uncertainty and is overhauling its China operation, cutting deliveries and launching on-site training programs.

site_title: India's Jet Airways grounds four aircraft after failing to pay lessors
summary: India's Jet Airways has grounded four aircraft after failing to make payments to lessors, with the airline struggling to pay its debt of about $1.14 billion. The move is a sign of leasing firms losing patience with the heavily indebted carrier. Jet Airways has a large fleet of mainly Boeing 737 jets sourced from over 20 lessors, and the groundings were either voluntary or forced. The airline is seeking shareholder approval to convert debt into equity and has agreed to most conditions set by Etihad Airways for a potential lifeline.

site_title: India central bank expected to cut rates again before elections: poll
summary: The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) is expected to cut interest rates again before the general election in May, according to a Reuters poll of economists. A majority of 30 out of 54 economists believe the central bank will make the same move next quarter, taking the repo rate to 6%, its lowest since the middle of last year. The rate cut would be welcome news for Prime Minister Narendra Modi's government, aiming to boost growth and lift lending.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares drop at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks dropped 1.41% on Friday, with the Hang Seng Index falling to 27,596.61, amid fading optimism on US-China trade talks and Europe's economic outlook. This follows a three-day Lunar New Year break.

site_title: Australia wields vast decryption powers before planned review
summary: Australian security agencies have begun using a new decryption law to access encrypted communications, even before a promised review, amid concerns from tech firms over national security and privacy. The law, which was rushed through Parliament in December, allows authorities to compel device makers and telecommunications firms to break or bypass encrypted communications, with refusal punishable by up to 10 years in prison. Industry groups have proposed amendments to the law, citing concerns it could undermine security and create vulnerabilities in encryption technologies.

site_title: Asia: Markets tumble on US-China talks, Europe growth
summary: Asian stocks plummeted on Friday, following Wall Street's losses, amid doubts over US-China trade talks and Europe's growth outlook. Hong Kong fell 1.2%, Tokyo 1.7%, and Sydney 0.5% as investors reacted to negative US signals ahead of Beijing talks. The European Commission slashed its eurozone growth forecast to 1.3% due to Germany's slowdown and Italian growth concerns. The US dollar strengthened, while gold and the yen edged up on the somber outlook.

site_title: Australia shares sag on miners, energy stocks; NZ up
summary: Australian shares fell 0.34% on Friday, driven by energy and mining stocks, amid resurgent US-China trade tensions. The S&P/ASX 200 index dropped 21 points to 6,071.5. Key stocks, such as Beach Energy and Rio Tinto, plummeted 10.4% and 1.8%, respectively. In contrast, New Zealand's S&P/NZX 50 index rose 0.47% to 9,176.61, with Ryman Healthcare being the top gainer. The US-China trade tensions dampened investor sentiment, leading to losses in risk-sensitive assets.

site_title: Richard Branson says he'll fly to space by July
summary: British billionaire Richard Branson plans to travel to space within the next four to five months aboard Virgin Galactic's spaceship, with the goal of reaching the 50th anniversary of the moon landing in July. Virgin Galactic, one of two companies aiming to send passengers into space, has flown 80km above the earth and is preparing for its first commercial flight. The company expects to carry six passengers along with two pilots, with costs estimated at US$35 million a month.

site_title: Renault to alert prosecutors over ex-CEO Ghosn's wedding costs
summary: Renault has discovered that former CEO Carlos Ghosn received a 50,000 euro personal benefit from a 2016 sponsorship deal with the Chateau de Versailles, where Ghosn hosted his wedding reception. Renault will alert prosecutors over the incident, two weeks after Ghosn's forced exit from the company. Ghosn's lawyer claims he paid for all his wedding expenses, but Renault's internal probe found that the carmaker was charged for the event space without Ghosn's knowledge.

site_title: Resources Prima, substantial shareholder agree to extension of time to complete convertible loan pact
summary: Resources Prima Group, an Indonesian coal miner, and substantial shareholder Ang Liang Kim have agreed to extend the deadline for completing a convertible loan pact to June 30, 2019. The pact includes submitting a trading resumption proposal, holding a general meeting for shareholder approval, and issuing shares for the conversion. The funds will be used for working capital and capital expenditure. The extension comes after the company's operations were affected by a coal hauling agreement suspension, resulting in lower-than-expected coal haulage and outstanding accounts receivable.

site_title: In election shocker, sister of Thai king named PM candidate by Thaksin-linked party
summary: Thai Princess Ubolratana Rajakanya, sister of King Maha Vajiralongkorn, was named the prime ministerial candidate for the Thai Raksa Chart Party in the March 24 general election, marking the first time a senior royal has participated in a Thai election. The move is seen as a significant shift in the country's politics, where the royal family is traditionally apolitical. The election will be the first since a 2014 coup led by former army chief Prayuth Chan-Ocha, and it may spark speculation about the chances of former premier Thaksin Shinawatra returning to power.

site_title: Thai junta chief says will run for PM in election
summary: Thai junta chief Prayut Chan-O-Cha announced he will run for prime minister in the March election, seeking to maintain the army's influence on politics. He agreed to accept the invitation from Phalang Pracharat party to nominate his name to parliament for the appointment. This move comes more than four years after a coup, as the army looks to maintain its grip on power.

site_title: New York Grand Hyatt, Trump's first big project, faces demolition
summary: US President Donald Trump's first major real estate project, the Grand Hyatt New York, is set to be demolished and replaced with a new luxury hotel and office space. The redevelopment, a collaboration between TF Cornerstone, MSD Partners, and Hyatt Hotels Corp, will feature 2 million square feet of office and retail space and enhance connectivity to the subway system. The project aims to revitalize east Midtown and potentially lure tenants away from Hudson Yards. State and city approval is required, and construction financing must be arranged.

site_title: Pine Capital injects S$189,819 into key fund management subsidiary
summary: Pine Capital, a CATALIST-listed investment firm, has injected S$189,819 into its 51%-owned subsidiary Advance Capital Partners Asset Management (ACPAM) to meet base capital requirements. To maintain the existing shareholding structure, ACPAM allotted new shares valued at S$182,574 to ACPAM CEO Tan Choon Wee, who holds 49% of ACPAM. The additional investment will allow ACPAM to remain compliant with capital requirements for fund management companies.

site_title: Malaysia shares open lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened lower on Friday, down 5.42 points to 1,687.97. Volume was 22.49 million lots worth RM10.3 million. Losers beat gainers 87 to 50.

site_title: Saudi crown prince told aide he would use 'a bullet' on Khashoggi: report
summary: Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman allegedly told an aide he would "go after Jamal Khashoggi with a bullet" a year before the journalist's killing inside the kingdom's Istanbul consulate. The conversation was intercepted by US intelligence agencies in September 2017. The prince suggested Khashoggi be brought back by force or killed if he couldn't be enticed to return. The revelation contradicts the Saudi government's earlier claims that the killing was a rogue operation. US intelligence is seeking conclusive proof linking the prince to the killing, which occurred on October 2, 2018.

site_title: Japan's modest household spending, wages growth point to fragile outlook
summary: Japan's household spending rose 0.1% in December, the first increase in four months, but wages growth was modest, with real wages up 1.4% due to winter bonuses. The underlying trends point to a fragile economic outlook, with slowing global demand and trade protectionism affecting companies' willingness to raise wages. The government's "Abenomics" stimulus policies have boosted corporate profits, but failed to fire up private consumption. The Bank of Japan faces diminished policy ammunition to fight another recession, and a scandal over faulty wage data casts doubt on the benefits of Japan's economic recovery.

images.alt_text: Japan's household spending rose slightly and higher bonus payments lifted wages in December, though the underlying trends in these two gauges showed only modest improvement and pointed to a difficult year for the economy as risks to growth increases.

site_title: Stocks to watch: TSH Corp, SingPost, Best World, Global Palm Resources
summary: TSH Corp acquired Sloshed! Pte Ltd for S$19.4 million in a reverse takeover deal. CEO Chua Khoon Hui was appointed, and CFO Ng Kim Chew took the position. SingPost was fined S$100,000 for not meeting QoS standards. Best World shares surged 8.6% to a 52-week high after an unusual price movement. Global Palm Resources Holdings expects to report a net loss for FY2018 due to decreased sales and prices.

site_title: Instagram tightens rules on self-injury images
summary: Instagram has tightened its rules on self-injury images, banning graphic content such as cutting and removing references to non-graphic self-harm from search, hashtag, and recommendation features. The move follows a review involving experts and academics to safeguard the mental health of teenagers using the platform. Instagram aims to eliminate graphic self-injury imagery while remaining a supportive community, with plans to provide counseling and resources to users who post or search for self-harm related content. The changes come after a meeting between Instagram's CEO and British Health Secretary Matt Hancock to address the issue of online mental health.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open lower on Friday
summary: Tokyo shares opened lower on Friday, dropping 1.17% or 242.05 points to 20,509.23, following a global market slide due to lowered European economic outlook and receding US-China trade talks hopes. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index and broader Topix index declined 1.05% and 1.17%, respectively.

site_title: SoftBank founder transforms US$5.5b to US$17b overnight
summary: SoftBank founder Masayoshi Son increased the market value of his company by 1.65 trillion yen (S$20.4 billion) with a plan to buy back shares worth about a third of that amount. His stock value rose by about US$4 billion, and his fortune increased by US$2.6 billion. Son used a riddle to highlight his argument that SoftBank's share price doesn't reflect the value of its business and investments. This move aims to close the gap between the company's assets and debt.

site_title: RBA slashes Australia growth forecasts as property pressures households
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) cut its economic growth forecasts to 2.5% for 2019, down from 3.25%, due to weaker consumption and property pressures affecting households. The RBA also reduced its inflation forecast by half a percentage point. The central bank attributed the changes to the impact of lower property prices on construction activity and household spending decisions.

site_title: Kellogg posts loss on strong dollar, Brexit costs; shares slump
summary: Kellogg reported a 4th-quarter loss of $84 million, or 24 cents per share, due to a strong dollar, Brexit costs, and rising raw material and freight costs. Shares plummeted 6% to $55.57. The company is investing to mitigate Brexit's potential impact, but analysts question its ability to revive top-line performance while stabilizing margins. Net sales rose 4.1% to $3.32 billion, driven by acquisitions, despite a 3% currency translation hit.

site_title: Australian parliament computer network breached
summary: Australia's parliament computer network was compromised in a security incident, with measures implemented to protect the network and its users. Officials declined to comment on the nature of the breach, stating there was no evidence that data had been accessed. All parliamentary passwords were reset, and the Australian Cyber Security Centre is investigating. There is no indication that the breach is an attempt to influence electoral or political processes. The incident is currently under investigation.

site_title: TSH completes reverse takeover to enter pub and bar business
summary: TSH Corporation has completed a reverse takeover, acquiring Sloshed! Pte Ltd, a pub and bar business, for S$19.4 million. Chua Khoon Hui has been appointed CEO and executive director, while Ng Kim Chew is the new CFO. The acquisition is expected to provide operational and income-generating businesses with growth prospects, enhancing shareholder value. A share consolidation and issuance of new shares have taken place, with consideration shares expected to be listed on the Catalist on February 12, 2019.

site_title: Singapore court blocks bond sale by Brazil pulp maker Eldorado
summary: A Singapore court blocked the sale of bonds by Brazil's pulp maker Eldorado Brasil Celulose SA, citing the need for clarification on its prospectus. The move comes after a shareholder complained to the US Securities and Exchange Commission about material inaccuracies in the prospectus. Eldorado had maintained that the information was accurate. The court's decision is the latest in a series of regulatory hurdles for the company.

site_title: National Australia Bank shares fall after CEO Thorburn departs
summary: National Australia Bank shares plummeted after CEO Andrew Thorburn and chairman Ken Henry resigned, following criticism in the Royal Commission's final report on misconduct in the financial industry. The stock fell 1.2% in early trading, closing at A$24.80. The departures come after the duo faced intense scrutiny over their handling of scandals. The news marks the latest high-profile casualty of the inquiry, which aims to restore public trust in Australia's financial sector.

site_title: Total unveils 'significant' offshore South African gas find
summary: French energy giant Total has made a significant gas discovery off the coast of South Africa, with potential quantities estimated to be around one billion barrels of gas and condensate light oil. The discovery, made on the Brulpadda prospects in the Outeniqua Basin, could boost South Africa's struggling economy and reduce reliance on imports. President Cyril Ramaphosa called the find a "game-changer" and vowed to work towards ensuring the sector is properly managed and regulated.

site_title: UK Labour's Brexit offer rebuffed by govt, welcomed by EU
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May's government has rejected Labour Party leader Jeremy Corbyn's proposal for a UK-EU customs union in exchange for supporting her Brexit plan. The proposal, made in a letter to May, includes a commitment to a "permanent and comprehensive" customs union and close alignment with the EU's single market. The Labour Party welcomed the offer, while the government stated that an independent trade policy is a key advantage of Brexit, contradicting Corbyn's proposal.

site_title: Europe: Shares fall as EU growth falters, earnings weigh
summary: European shares fell sharply, with the Stoxx 600 down 1.5% and Germany's DAX down 2.7%, due to a batch of worrying trading updates and the European Union cutting its growth forecasts. The decline was exacerbated by disappointing December industrial data and uncertainty over Brexit. Earnings season also brought concerns, with Publicis and Deutsche Bank experiencing significant declines. Market anxiety was further fueled by a report suggesting a Trump-Xi Jinping meeting was unlikely by a key deadline.

site_title: Future of Airbus's A380 superjumbo in doubt as demand fades
summary: Airbus's A380 superjumbo faces uncertain future as demand dwindles. The world's largest passenger jet, launched a decade ago, has struggled to find buyers, with Qantas's cancellation of an order for eight A380s raising concerns. Airbus has reduced production and cut jobs, and the company is now in talks with Emirates to potentially switch orders to the A350. The economics of the A380 have proven daunting, requiring airlines to fly full capacity to make a profit, leaving its future in doubt.

site_title: Remittance fintech TransferWise's head of Asia-Pacific expansion leaves
summary: TransferWise, a remittance fintech, has lost its head of Asia-Pacific expansion, Lukas May, who resigned to work on UK-Asia trade negotiations with the UK government. May, who relocated to Singapore in 2017, will hold a deputy director role at the UK Department for International Trade. His departure will divide responsibilities among the team, with a replacement expected to take over. TransferWise operates in Asia with a significant presence in Singapore, moving $1.7 billion in and out of the city-state annually.

images.alt_text: TransferWise's head of banking Lukas May has resigned.

site_title: Mattel posts surprise profit as Barbie makeover lifts sales
summary: Mattel reported a surprise fourth-quarter profit, driven by a successful Barbie makeover with diverse skin tones and attire, resulting in the doll's highest gross sales in five years. The company's cost-cutting efforts also contributed to the profit. Shares surged 19% in extended trading. The success of Barbie in the current retail environment, with a focus on female empowerment, is seen as a key factor in the company's success.

site_title: Oil drops as global economic concerns grip market
summary: Oil prices dropped 2% on Thursday due to concerns over global demand growth and the potential for a prolonged US-China trade war. Brent crude futures fell $1.06 to $61.63 a barrel, while US crude futures fell $1.37 to $52.64 a barrel. Analysts attribute the decline to uncertainty about demand, supply fundamentals, and the impact of weaker macroeconomic fundamentals. The market is also influenced by the ongoing US-China trade talks and the recent increase in US crude oil stocks.

site_title: Amazon's Jeff Bezos accuses National Enquirer publisher of blackmail
summary: Amazon CEO Jeff Bezos accused National Enquirer publisher David Pecker of extortion and blackmail, claiming the magazine threatened to publish more details and revealing photos if he stopped an investigation into his alleged relationship with TV personality Lauren Sanchez. Bezos published an email from a lawyer for the magazine's publisher, stating the magazine investigated him because of his wealth and position. Bezos chose to publish the email instead of backing down, saying personal embarrassment takes a back seat to standing up to the extortion. He questioned how many people could withstand such pressure in his position.

site_title: Procurri says second interested buyer has terminated discussions
summary: Procurri Corporation has disclosed that discussions with a second interested buyer for a possible acquisition have been terminated. The second interested buyer treated the unsolicited and non-binding expression of interest as having expired, in accordance with the terms. This news comes after Procurri received interest on February 4, 2019, from the third party for a possible voluntary general offer. The company's shares jumped 8% on Thursday following the disclosure. Shareholders are advised to exercise caution when dealing with shares and refrain from taking any action that may be prejudicial to their interests.

site_title: US Democrats unveil carbon-neutral 'Green New Deal'
summary: US Democrats unveiled the "Green New Deal," a plan to reverse climate change and eliminate all US carbon emissions within 10 years. The proposal, introduced by Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez and Sen. Ed Markey, requires transformative action across the economy. The plan is seen as a dramatic statement of intent on a sustainable path forward, with the first step being a declaration of intent. The proposal's feasibility remains to be seen, but it marks a significant shift in the country's approach to addressing climate change.

site_title: IS 'caliphate' down to 1% as final assault nears
summary: The Islamic State (IS) group's caliphate has shrunk to less than 1% of its original size, according to the US-led coalition, as a final assault nears in eastern Syria. The coalition, led by Kurdish forces, has been training and providing aerial support since September 2018. Despite halting their ground assault, IS fighters remain a potent force, using guerrilla warfare and sleeper cells to carry out periodic hit-and-run attacks. A formal declaration of victory is expected next week, with US President Donald Trump predicting a final victory announcement.

site_title: Gender funding gap grows when research pitches get personal: study
summary: A study published in The Lancet found that women are less successful in receiving research funding than men when the selection process focuses on the scientist making the pitch rather than the science presented. In a 5-year study of nearly 24,000 grant applications, the gender gap grew to 4% when assessments were based on the principal scientist's pitch, but only 0.9% when based solely on science quality. Researchers attribute the gap to potential individual or systemic biases, and the journal's editor-in-chief calls for greater efforts to achieve gender justice in health.

site_title: Trump lashes out as Democrats open probes into his taxes, Russia ties
summary: US President Donald Trump is facing intense scrutiny from newly empowered House Democrats, who have launched investigations into his taxes, real estate business, and Russia ties. The probes, which include a hearing into Trump's tax returns and questioning of his policy to separate immigrant children from their parents, are seen as a significant escalation of pressure on the White House. Trump has lashed out at the Democrats, calling the investigations "presidential harassment," and warned that they could lead to impeachment.

site_title: Amazon invests in self-driving car startup Aurora
summary: Amazon has invested $530 million in self-driving car startup Aurora, valuing the company at over $2.5 billion. The investment, led by Sequoia, will be used to speed development of Aurora's autonomous vehicle technology and strengthen its partnerships. Led by former Google and Tesla executives, Aurora aims to work alongside automakers rather than compete with them. The company, which has partnered with Volkswagen, plans to use the funding to bring self-driving cars to market. Amazon sees the technology as a way to improve employee and partner safety.

site_title: Increasing board accountability
summary: Boards of directors are facing increased scrutiny over accountability, with the emergence of new technologies and growing pressure for sustainable business practices. The Corporate Governance Council has introduced revised principles, including managing stakeholder relationships, succession planning, and board diversity. Boards must now disclose plans for stakeholder management and have a succession plan in place, as well as ensure adequate cybersecurity measures. Ultimately, effective board governance is crucial for long-term success, and boards should aim to go beyond a "review and concur" role to contribute to better governance and add value to management.

site_title: Britain's May, EU's Juncker to hold further Brexit talks by end-Feb
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May and European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker agreed to hold further Brexit talks by the end of February, following a "robust" meeting in Brussels. EU negotiator Michel Barnier will meet Britain's Brexit Minister Stephen Barclay on Monday, and May and Juncker will meet again before the end of February. The European Commission president warned that the Brexit withdrawal deal cannot be renegotiated, but expressed openness to add wording to a parallel political declaration. May urged changes to the withdrawal agreement, including a legally binding change to the backstop clause.

site_title: Andrew Thorburn quits as NAB CEO after inquiry lashing
summary: Andrew Thorburn, CEO of National Australia Bank (NAB), resigned amid a misconduct inquiry questioning his leadership in response to scandals, including accepting cash bribes for fraudulent mortgages. Chairman Ken Henry also left, following a scathing report from the Royal Commission criticizing their performance. The bank will start a global search for a new CEO and delay the sale of its MLC wealth unit until 2020.

site_title: Murdoch's News Corp posts profit amid struggles at newspapers
summary: News Corp, led by Rupert Murdoch, reported a profit of $119 million in the latest quarter, driven by gains from video subscription services and digital advertising. Revenues rose 21% year-over-year, with digital subscriptions to the Wall Street Journal reaching 1.7 million. The company attributed the results to the power of premium content and authenticated audiences in a "fact-challenged world." However, the news division's overall revenues dropped 3% due to declines in print revenue.

site_title: Boeing's smallest 737 Max faces new doubts as key buyer wavers
summary: WestJet Airlines, a major customer of Boeing's 737 Max 7, is shifting its focus to larger variants, such as the Max 8 and 10, due to fuel savings and capacity needs. The carrier is delaying deliveries of the Max 7 by two years and may convert some orders to larger variants. WestJet aims to reduce fuel consumption and achieve annual savings of up to $200 million by 2020. The shift is part of a broader trend in the narrow-body segment, with Airbus' A220 and Embraer's new models also competing for sales.

site_title: Khashoggi murder 'planned and perpetrated' by Saudi officials: UN expert
summary: A UN rapporteur has concluded that the murder of Saudi journalist Jamal Khashoggi was planned and carried out by Saudi officials. Khashoggi, a critic of the Saudi regime, was killed at the Saudi consulate in Istanbul on October 2. Evidence collected by the UN expert, Agnes Callamard, shows that Khashoggi's murder was "brutal and premeditated" and that Saudi officials were involved. The UN is calling for the international community to take action over the incident, which has brought "irreversible tragedy" to Khashoggi's loved ones.

images.alt_text: A UN rapporteur probing the murder in Turkey of Saudi journalist Jamal Khashoggi said Thursday the killing was planned and carried out by Saudi officials.

site_title: US: Wall Street sinks on fears for trade, global growth
summary: US stocks plummeted 0.9% on Thursday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling 220 points to 25,169.53, amid fears over the US-China trade dispute and European growth forecasts. The White House stated there's a "sizeable distance" between the two sides, while President Trump said a meeting with Xi Jinping won't occur before tariffs rise. The Nasdaq fell 1.2% and Twitter plunged 9.8% after quarterly results showed a shrinking global user base, while SunTrust soared 10% after announcing a $66 billion merger with BB&T.

site_title: Boost your risk positions, unwind those hedges, says JPMorgan Chase
summary: JPMorgan Chase's global strategists are shifting their risk positions, favoring equities and industrial metals, amid the Federal Reserve's pause on further tightening and a potential positive surprise from China's economy. They are closing complex hedges and lifting allocations to emerging-market stocks and bonds. The strategists see a higher prospect of 2019 being an asset-reflation year, driven by a more optimistic view on US-China trade negotiations and China's economic stabilisation.

site_title: Publicis shortfall jolts Madison Ave as ad stocks fall
summary: Publicis Groupe SA, the French owner of Saatchi & Saatchi and Leo Burnett Worldwide, reported a 0.3% drop in organic revenue in the fourth quarter, missing analyst expectations of a 2.5% gain. The decline is attributed to cuts in ad spending by consumer brands in the US, forcing the company to market itself as an online data-mining expert. Despite this, Publicis' CEO Arthur Sadoun is confident in the company's strategy and sticks by its target of 4% organic revenue growth by 2020.

site_title: All-Star Hamlet
summary: A Mandarin version of Shakespeare's classic play "The Tragedy of Hamlet" is set to run from February 15 to 17 at the Esplanade Theatre, directed by Li Liuyi and starring Hu Jun as Hamlet. The production features a star-studded cast and a stylish rotating wooden platform set designed by Michael Simon. The story revolves around Prince Hamlet's suspicions of his uncle's involvement in his father's murder to marry his mother and ascend the throne. This adaptation is a dark and moody take on the timeless classic.

site_title: Bank branches lose influence for market share
summary: Banks will need to shift their focus from branch expansion to advertising to gain market share, according to a McKinsey study. The study's senior partner, Pradip Patiath, stated that the correlation between adding branches and gaining market share has broken down. This change is attributed to a world with fewer branches, forcing banks to rely on other strategies to attract customers.

site_title: Greek hoteliers say home-renting to tourists 'out of control'
summary: Greek hoteliers express concerns over a surge in home-sharing properties for tourists, which they say is "out of control" and hurting hotels, increasing residential rents, and forcing locals from their homes. More than 70,000 properties in Greece are available for rent through home-sharing platforms, according to Grant Thornton research. This boom is affecting the hospitality industry and local communities, prompting hoteliers to call for regulation to prevent further damage.

site_title: Huawei open to European supervision: executive
summary: Huawei executive Abraham Liu says the company is open to European supervision to address concerns over cybersecurity, viewing it as a technical issue rather than an ideological one. Huawei denies harming customers' or countries' interests and claims its devices have never caused serious cybersecurity breaches. The US has urged European allies not to use Huawei equipment for 5G networks due to security risks, but some European countries, like Germany, are seeking high data security standards. Huawei is willing to accept supervision and suggestions from European governments, customers, and partners to prove its commitment to cybersecurity.

site_title: Trump says no Xi meeting expected before trade talks deadline
summary: US President Donald Trump stated that he does not expect to meet Chinese President Xi Jinping before a March 1 deadline in trade war negotiations. Trump said "not yet" when asked if a meeting had been arranged, and reiterated that a final resolution would depend on a meeting "in the near future." Despite optimism from top White House economist Larry Kudlow, a deal seems unlikely, with US tariffs set to jump sharply on Chinese goods if no agreement is reached.

images.alt_text: US President Donald Trump said Thursday he did not expect to meet his Chinese counterpart Xi Jinping before a March 1 deadline in trade war negotiations between the two economic superpowers.

site_title: India central bank delivers surprise rate cut
summary: India's central bank unexpectedly cut its benchmark interest rate by 25 basis points to 6.25% in governor Shaktikanta Das's debut policy meeting. The move, seen as a shift to provide stimulus ahead of the upcoming election, comes a week after the government unveiled an expansionary budget. The decision, which was predicted by just 11 of 43 economists surveyed, is the first Asian central bank to ease borrowing costs this year, as inflation slowed to an 18-month low of 2.2% in December.

site_title: Interest rate cut possible, says ex-Fed chief Yellen
summary: Former US Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen suggests a possible interest rate cut due to weak global growth and tighter financial conditions. Yellen likens the current situation to 2016, when she kept interest rates on hold almost a year. Her comments come after Jerome Powell's revised messaging in January, signaling the Fed's patience on policy. Yellen notes that a cut or rate hike is possible, but the Fed will rely on incoming economic data to make its decision.

site_title: Alfred E Neuman's law of budget deficits
summary: Alfred E. Neuman's Law of budget deficits proposes that there's never a good time to raise taxes or cut federal spending. Since 1961, the US federal budget has been in deficit 52 times and in surplus only five times, with all surpluses occurring at the end of economic booms. Advocates of Neuman's Law, including economists Lawrence Summers and Jason Furman, argue that this reflects the automatic increase in tax revenues and spending reductions during economic expansions.

site_title: A revolution in retail
summary: A revolution in retail is underway, with online brands moving into physical stores, blurring the lines between online and offline shopping. This "New Retail" strategy combines technology and data to create immersive customer experiences. As traditional retailers compete, this shift could transform the retail landscape. Brands that started in e-commerce are now investing in physical stores, potentially reversing fortunes.

site_title: See Clearly Now
summary: A Singaporean/Swiss couple transformed their 2012 conservation corner terrace home into a modern oasis after six years of living with a fixed timber-louvred wall. They replaced the louvres with a 8m x 3.5m glass facade from France, offering good heat and sound insulation, and allowing for natural light to filter through. The airwell was converted into a small sitting area, and the kitchen was enlarged with new glass doors and an industrial-style metal frame. The couple, who have two young children, feel they now have their ideal home, but may consider a third renovation in the future.

site_title: Targeted initiatives, collaboration needed in war on cyber crime
summary: Singapore's cyber security spending is above the global average, but experts say more targeted initiatives are needed to address macro cyber security issues. The government is urged to include grants for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), better cyber security knowledge for the wider population, and improved IT systems. Companies should prioritize cyber security and training to defend against evolving threats. Experts also suggest establishing a hotline for severe breaches, public-education initiatives, and strengthening law enforcement and prosecution of cyber attackers. These measures can help prevent breaches and create a more collaborative relationship between the private and public sectors.

site_title: Central banks prove adept at listening to stock market voices
summary: The US Federal Reserve has shifted its stance on monetary policy normalization, signaling a more dovish approach and a potential halt to balance sheet runoff earlier than initially planned. This move follows a persistent gap in projections between the Federal Open Market Committee and market expectations, as well as criticism from US President Donald Trump. The Fed aims to maintain room for additional monetary accommodation in case of a recession, while also addressing concerns over reserve balances and potential distortions in debt securities markets. The change in approach is seen as a response to market sentiment and a desire to avoid premature tightening.

site_title: Entrepreneur First steps up effort to tap Asia's pool of deep-tech talent
summary: Entrepreneur First, a London-based talent incubator, is stepping up its efforts in Asia to tap into the region's deep-tech talent and venture capital. The company has announced its first cohort of 50 entrepreneurs from its Bangalore program, with $25 million in committed funding. EF is focusing on deep-tech startups, which have the potential to scale globally, and has partnered with Hax, a venture capital-based program, to co-invest in startups and provide access to facilities in Shenzhen. The company aims to fill the gap in early-stage funding for deep-tech startups in Asia, with a total valuation of $1.5 billion for its previous investments.

site_title: Coming soon: new emojis that foster a diverse culture and emphasise inclusivity
summary: The Unicode Consortium has announced 59 new emojis, including 230 variants, to foster a diverse culture and emphasize inclusivity. The new emojis include representations of people with disabilities, interracial couples, and diverse skin tones, as well as symbols such as a guide dog, wheelchair, and hearing aid. The emojis are expected to be released later this year, with companies like Apple and Google already proposing and incorporating the new designs into their operating systems. The move aims to promote inclusivity and representation in digital communication, particularly for marginalized communities.

site_title: 'Fake' still life in US museum confirmed as real Van Gogh
summary: A still-life painting at the Fine Arts Museum of San Francisco, once dismissed as a fake, has been confirmed as a real work by Vincent van Gogh. The painting, Still Life with Fruit and Chestnuts, dated to 1886, was donated in 1960 and previously excluded from official Van Gogh catalogues. Experts from the Van Gogh Museum in Amsterdam attributed the painting as genuine, discovering a hidden portrait of a woman underneath. The museum had examined 200 works a year but added only 14 to the official oeuvre since 1988, making this the first confirmed attribution in nearly three decades.

site_title: Euro slips to 2-week low on EU growth forecast cuts
summary: The euro fell to a two-week low, down 0.2% at US$1.1332, amid the European Commission's sharp cuts to euro zone growth forecasts due to global trade tensions and growing public debt. This move complicates the European Central Bank's plans for an interest rate hike this year. The euro's decline is also linked to weaker-than-expected German industrial output and a possible rate cut in Australia.

site_title: The mirage of a global euro
summary: The euro has failed to materialize as a second global reserve currency, despite initial hopes. Its importance in global reserves and financial markets remains unchanged since its introduction 20 years ago. While the euro has a strong presence in international transactions, particularly with widespread use of euro banknotes outside the eurozone, the economics of banknote issuance have changed due to negative interest rates, making it unprofitable for the European Central Bank. The eurozone's smaller economy and declining global share also limit its potential for a larger global role.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Mind Your Business: Singapore's first gin: Tanglin Gin
summary: Tanglin Gin, Singapore's first gin, has won a Silver Award at the Cathay Pacific Hong Kong International Wine & Spirit Competition. Co-founders Charlie van Eeden and Andy Hodgson discussed the inspiration behind the gin, which is not just about geography but also reflects Singapore's cultural diversity. The conversation highlights the importance of corporate purpose and the role of the business in contributing to the community. Tanglin Gin's success marks a milestone in Singapore's spirits industry, showcasing the country's growing reputation as a hub for innovation and entrepreneurship.

site_title: Asian banks on watch with trillion-dollar Libor transition
summary: Asian banks are closely monitoring the transition to alternate reference rates, following the phase-out of the scandal-tainted London Interbank Offered Rate (Libor) by 2021. Despite global banks' preparations, Asian lenders are deemed unprepared for the impact on their balance sheets, with audit firm EY stating that many are at "phase zero." The transition may affect up to 25% of global institutions' lending portfolios, with Singapore banks taking a wait-and-see approach. The Singaporean interbank benchmark, Sibor, is expected to remain a reference rate, but its use is expected to decline in favor of the Singaporean swap offer rate (SOR).

site_title: Rise of intangibles makes it harder to value assets properly
summary: Singapore investors will face greater valuation challenges as the Singapore Exchange (SGX) considers welcoming companies with dual class shares. Intangible assets, such as brand, content, and data, now account for 87% of a company's value, making traditional valuation methods less effective. Risks associated with intangible assets, including intellectual property rights and infringement, pose significant threats to shareholder value. To mitigate these risks, investors must carefully evaluate the strength of the team and entrepreneur behind the company, as well as the company's ability to execute its long-term strategy.

site_title: Global rate shift upends Wall St's consensus for a weaker dollar
summary: Global central bankers are shifting their monetary-policy outlooks, acknowledging rising risks and holding off on tightening plans. This has led to the US dollar gaining ground, outpacing its peers, as foreign-exchange traders see the US currency as the "best of a bad lot." Despite the Federal Reserve signaling no further interest rate hikes, the dollar has gained about 0.5% since the Fed's pivot last week, fueled by the US economy's relative robustness compared to the rest of the world.

site_title: Jaguar I-Pace review: Silent and scintillating
summary: The Jaguar I-Pace is a sporty, electric SUV that accelerates to 100km/h in 4.8 seconds, making it a desirable alternative to traditional sporty SUVs. Despite its environmental benefits, the car's performance and features may appeal to drivers who prioritize speed over eco-friendliness. The article concludes that the I-Pace is a credible option for those seeking a thrilling driving experience while considering its potential to reduce carbon emissions.

site_title: Giving shoppers a seamless experience
summary: Retailers worldwide are investing heavily in digital technologies to provide a seamless shopping experience, driven by consumers' increasing demand for personalized interactions. A new report from Vertiv shows that one in four retailers are slow to adopt technologies such as IoT, cloud, and Big Data, hindering their ability to deliver integrated customer experiences. The growth of online commerce and the need for more efficient distribution centers are driving the need for increased investment in data centers, cloud hosting, and edge computing. As retailers continue to evolve, they must prioritize customer experience, data security, and operational efficiency to remain competitive.

site_title: Sino Grandness still negotiating to extend repayment of loan
summary: Sino Grandness Food Industry Group, a China-based canned vegetable and fruits producer, is in negotiations with creditor and shareholder Soleado Holdings to extend the repayment of US$22 million in debt. The company has already remitted S$34,958 for legal fees and reimbursement of costs. A regulatory approval from China is required for the repatriation of funds by way of dividend. Sino Grandness shares closed at S$0.057, up half a cent, after the announcement.

site_title: Crypto universe may be in for new round of pain: Fundstrat
summary: Cryptocurrencies are poised for another leg down, according to Fundstrat Global Advisors strategist Robert Sluymer. A proprietary gauge of market breadth shows smaller coins are at risk, and the price structure for most cryptocurrencies remains weak and vulnerable to a breakdown. Bitcoin, the most well-known cryptocurrency, is down over 80% from its 2017 high and could retest its fourth-quarter lows if it breaks below $3,100. A move above $4,200 would signal improvement. Fundstrat's advance/decline indicator is at risk of breaking to new lows, indicating a weak technical position.

site_title: Musical Journey
summary: Jon Hopkins, a renowned electronic music producer, is set to headline a show in Singapore on February 13 at the Capitol Theatre. His latest album, Singularity, released in May, explores themes of dystopian urbanity and nature through a blend of techno, piano, and ambient music. Tickets for the event are available in advance for S$78, with door prices at S$100. This marks Hopkins' return to Singapore after his latest tour, which was inspired by his experiences with meditation and trance states.

site_title: Police demand navigation app Waze stop tipping drivers off to checkpoints
summary: The New York Police Department is demanding Google's navigation app Waze stop providing users with information about the locations of sobriety checkpoints, citing it as a threat to public safety. The app's feature allows users to share locations of checkpoints, which can aid impaired drivers in evading checkpoints and encourage reckless driving. Google claims the feature helps drivers make safer decisions, but the NYPD says it puts drivers, passengers, and the general public at risk. The department plans to pursue legal remedies to stop users from sharing such information.

site_title: Home prices in London's most-desired districts at 6-year low
summary: London's most-desired districts experienced a 6-year low in home prices, with a 4.6% decline in 2018. The average price dropped by 1.5% in the final quarter, attributed to political chaos and tax hikes. The high-end house prices, particularly in prime postcodes like Chelsea and Mayfair, saw a 15% sales-tax bill, further depressing the market. The decline is linked to uncertainty about the country's political and economic future, with prices now at a five-year low.

site_title: A touch of fun at table65
summary: table65, a casual fine dining restaurant at Resorts World Sentosa, aims to bring fun to the dining experience. The restaurant features a sleek, modern design and interactive elements, such as a holographic "Welcome" message. Chef Richard Van Oostenbrugge's menu offers a range of dishes, including amuse bouche, oyster ravioli, and langoustine poached in duck fat. While the food is technically sound, it can be heavy-going and slightly alien to local tastes. The restaurant's atmosphere is convivial and relaxed, but its concept still needs refinement to truly deliver a memorable experience. Rating: 7/10.

site_title: Singapore ranks 10th on global IP Index
summary: Singapore ranks 10th globally on the US Chamber International Intellectual Property (IP) Index, down from 9th in the previous edition, with a score of 82.49% (37.12 out of 45 indicators). The country's efforts in copyright enforcement, such as blocking piracy websites and disabling access to infringing content, contributed to the score increase. However, high software piracy levels (27%) and lack of transparency in customs seizures of IP-infringing goods remain weaknesses. The US topped the index, with Japan being the only Asian nation ahead of Singapore.

images.alt_text: Singapore was ranked 10th out of 50 world economies on the latest edition of the US Chamber International Intellectual Property (IP) Index, as it slipped a place and was displaced by Switzerland.

site_title: Challenging The Raffles Myth
summary: A new exhibition at the Asian Civilisations Museum challenges the traditional perception of Sir Stamford Raffles as a hero who founded modern Singapore. Research and archaeological findings suggest that Singapore was a thriving entrepot before Raffles' arrival in 1819. The exhibition also portrays Raffles as a flawed and ambitious diplomat who manipulated others to achieve his goals, including the removal of Major-General William Farquhar. The show highlights Raffles' achievements, but also his humanity, and provides a more complex picture of the man. The exhibition runs until April 28.

images.alt_text: The famous portrait of Sir Stamford Raffles, with Java as the backdrop.
A Buddhist sculpture of Mamaki collected by Raffles in Java.
Perfectlyaligned court letter to Raffles from Sultan Mahmud Shah of Lingga.
A gamelan instrument from the era.
A Javanese mask collected by the statesman.
A trade textile from the mid-1700s.

site_title: SoftBank adds US$14b to market value as shares soar
summary: SoftBank Group Corp shares surged 17% on Thursday, adding $14 billion to its market value, following a record share buyback and a 60% jump in third-quarter operating profit. The company repurchased up to 600 billion yen of its stock, funded by the proceeds of its December IPO. SoftBank's CEO, Masayoshi Son, aims to reduce the valuation gap with a focus on its technology investments, after the company's shares fell following concerns about its ties to Saudi Arabia. The stock price is now up 36% this year.

site_title: Festive Art
summary: Parkview Museum's "Breezing Willow" exhibition, running until April 12, showcases over 100 Chinese New Year paintings from the 17th-century to the Republic of China, featuring only existing copies. The artwork highlights regional values, traditions, and aesthetics, with most images being happy and celebratory. Admission to the exhibition is free.

site_title: SingPost fined S$100,000 for failing delivery standards
summary: SingPost has been fined S$100,000 by the Infocomm Media Development Authority (IMDA) for failing to meet quality of service standards on delivering local basic letters and registered mail in 2017. The firm accepted the penalty and outlined measures to improve its service quality, including hiring additional postmen. The incident occurred when SingPost failed to deliver 99% of local basic letters within the Central Business District (CBD) by the next working day in May 2017.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Ezion Holdings, a Singaporean offshore support vessel provider, has had its stock downgraded to "hold" by DBS Group Research due to potential asset impairments and slower-than-expected revenue growth. The company has formed a joint venture with TSC Group to enhance growth prospects, but risks include a slower recovery and a drop in oil prices. In contrast, CapitaLand Retail China Trust's results were within expectations, with a 2.1% year-on-year increase in distribution per unit. The trust is maintaining its "hold" rating, citing attractive capital recycling opportunities.

site_title: My Anti-Valentine
summary: Bar Rouge is hosting an anti-Valentine's Day party at Swissotel the Stamford, celebrating singlehood with a "In Memory of Love" night on February 14. The menu features heart-shaped pizzas and cocktails, including Sweet & Refreshing and Sour & Bitter, to commemorate past break-ups. The event aims to provide a fun and lighthearted alternative for singles to celebrate their independence.

site_title: Music-streaming app Spotify transcends tunes with purchase of 2 podcast firms
summary: Spotify has acquired two podcast companies, expanding its presence in the medium that is becoming increasingly popular. The streaming service, which began over 10 years ago with the goal of making millions of songs instantly available, now signals its broader ambitions. This move follows the trend of music-streaming apps investing in podcasts, indicating a shift in their focus towards diversification and growth in the audio content market.

site_title: Fun And Frantic Forests
summary: Local emo-punk-math-rock trio Forests has released their new album "Spending Eternity In A Japanese Convenience Store," featuring big guitar riffs, tempo shifts, and screaming vocals. The nine-track record follows their 2016 debut and has been praised for its infectious energy. The album is now available on digital platforms and cassette for S$12. Forests recently completed a South East Asian tour with Japanese band Falls and plans to promote the new album in the region.
