The US dollar index was steady at 95.58, and traders trimmed expectations of a rate cut by the Reserve Bank of Australia.

site_title: HNA sells its last plot near HK's former Kai Tak airport to Wheelock
summary: HNA Group has sold its last plot of land near Hong Kong's former Kai Tak airport to Wheelock & Co for HK$3.9 billion, ending a massive residential project. This sale, along with previous deals, represents HNA's second-largest disposal in a US$20 billion selloff due to debt issues. The conglomerate originally paid HK$27 billion for the land and had envisioned a 400,000 square foot project, but it will now be redeveloped.

site_title: Australian home approvals dive as credit tightens
summary: Australian home approvals plummeted 8.4% in December, the lowest since 2013, as credit tightens and house prices slide. This follows a 9.8% drop in November, with apartment sector approvals falling 38% from the previous year. The data intensifies pressure for an interest rate cut from the Reserve Bank of Australia, amid concerns about economic growth and job losses, including a 1.7% decline in job advertisements in January.

site_title: Ex-SMRT CEO joins UBS as divisional vice-chairman
summary: UBS has appointed Desmond Kuek, former SMRT Corp CEO, as divisional vice-chairman for global wealth management, effective February 18, 2019. Kuek will be based in Singapore and report to Joe Stadler and Edmund Koh. UBS sees Kuek's diverse experience as a valuable asset in strengthening client relationships and growing the business across the Asia-Pacific. Kuek previously held roles in Singapore's Ministry of Environment and Water Resources and the Singapore Armed Forces. His appointment aims to increase client focus throughout the organization and support global wealth management leadership.

site_title: Stop pigging out, save the planet, Chinese told ahead of new year joy
summary: China is urged to eat less pork ahead of the new Year of the Pig, with environmental campaigners citing the country's high meat consumption and resulting greenhouse gas emissions. China accounts for half the world's pork consumption and is the world's biggest emitter of climate-warming gases, with livestock responsible for 14.5% of global emissions. Reducing meat consumption by half could cut emissions by 10% over the next decade, according to WildAid.

site_title: After years in doldrums, gold miners shine again
summary: Gold producers are experiencing a resurgence in interest after a series of mega deals and a late-2018 surge in bullion prices. The industry's annual conference in Cape Town has brought together executives and investors, with many expecting further deal-making activity. The gold industry's revival has been boosted by concerns over slowing global growth and expanding holdings in exchange-traded funds, leading to a rebound in gold equities. Analysts have identified companies such as Kinross Gold and Iamgold as potential targets for further deals, as the wave of activity is expected to continue.

site_title: New year tidings for Mindanao: Finally, a chance of peace for region
summary: The Muslim majority regions of the Southern Philippines have approved a referendum to create a new autonomous region, the Bangsamoro Autonomous Region in Muslim Mindanao, paving the way for a three-year transition to self-governance. The deal grants broad autonomy in exchange for demobilizing 40,000 fighters and adopting sharia law in personal, family, and property matters. A second referendum will be held to determine if seven provinces will join the new region. Despite obstacles, President Rodrigo Duterte's efforts have brought a chance of peace to the region, which has been in turmoil for generations.

site_title: Powell said to be 'coming around' to wait-and-see view on rate hikes
summary: Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis president Neel Kashkari stated that Fed Chairman Jerome Powell is "coming around" to a wait-and-see view on rate hikes, allowing the economy to strengthen before making adjustments. Kashkari emphasized the need to avoid premature rate hikes, citing a "fundamentally healthy" economy. The Fed's latest pause will help maintain this momentum, with Kashkari noting that the US economy still has room to run. This shift in perspective comes after the Fed's decision to pause interest rate increases in January, citing concerns over global growth and trade uncertainty.

site_title: Singapore's manufacturing growth at two-year low in January
summary: Singapore's manufacturing growth slowed to a two-year low in January, with the electronics sector remaining in contraction for the third month. The overall manufacturing PMI fell to 50.7, down from 51.1 in December, due to slower growth in new orders, exports, and factory output. This marked the 29th straight month of expansion, but the sector's contraction was attributed to cautious optimism for improved prospects going forward. The result complements regional weakness, with six out of seven Asean countries showing slower conditions.

site_title: Australia's central bank faces watershed week amid bad news
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) is set to hold its first policy meeting of the year amidst economic uncertainty, with investors expecting a dovish turn and potential rate cut. The RBA is under pressure due to a declining property market, with Sydney house prices falling over 10% from their 2017 peak. Global growth has also slowed, with China and Europe facing challenges. The RBA is likely to maintain its neutral stance, but the outcome could be a rate cut, which would boost the Australian share market and alleviate downward pressure on sovereign yields.

site_title: Millions take the plunge at India's religious mega festival
summary: Millions of Hindu pilgrims took part in the world's largest religious gathering, the Kumbh Mela festival, in Allahabad, India. On the most auspicious day, Mauni Amavasya Snan, devotees immersed themselves in the confluence of three rivers, believing it cleanses them of sin. Thousands of holy men and women, including the Naga Sadhus, led the mass bathing, accompanied by chanting and brandishing swords and tridents. Authorities spent $40 million to manage the huge crowds and prevent deadly stampedes, with nearly 12 million attending the inaugural bathing ritual and 120 million expected during the festival.

site_title: Changing hands
summary: NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was oversubscribed 9.8 times. Meanwhile, US stocks opened lower due to a fresh tariff salvo on Canada. Creative Technology warned of possible revenue shortfall and similar operating loss in H2. London's Heathrow plans to increase fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case. OCBC announced Tan Teck Long as its incoming CEO, replacing a DBS veteran. MAS and PBOC will deepen cooperation in green and transition finance, and Singapore stocks continued their 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Outbreak of swine fever may bury China's small pig farmers
summary: China's small pig farmers are facing financial ruin due to African swine fever, which has struck the country's largest pork-producing region. Since August, over 300,000 yuan in debt has been incurred by farmers like Zhang Shiping and Bai Fuqin, who were forced to sell pigs at a loss due to restrictions on transporting live pigs. The disease has crippled trade, leading to a sharp decline in prices, with some farms being forced to abandon pig farming altogether. Estimates suggest that production will be reduced by one-fifth this year, boosting prices and demand for cheaper imports.

site_title: Trump's failing foreign and trade policy revolution
summary: US President Donald Trump's "America first" foreign and trade policy has proven incoherent and threadbare two years into his presidency. Despite initial promises of a neo-isolationist doctrine, Trump has made few clear moves to reshape US policy. Instead, he has pursued a mix of policy incoherence and U-turns, including scrapping the Trans-Pacific Partnership and withdrawing from the Paris climate change deal. The policy has led to significant global backlash, with a median approval rating of US leadership at a new low of 30% in polls. Trump's team faces challenges in finding a clear doctrine, engaging allies, and tackling major international issues.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Hong Fok Corp's associate company Hong Fok Land International plans to buy back all of its shares at HK$0.55 per share, potentially increasing HFC's interest to over 50% and making it a holding company of HFL. The buyback offer requires approval from at least 75% of independent shareholders. In separate news, Hyflux has obtained a one-month extension to divest the Tuaspring integrated water and power plant, with a new deadline of February 28, 2019.

site_title: Maoyan Entertainment makes weak HK debut
summary: Maoyan Entertainment, China's largest movie ticketing platform, made a weak debut in Hong Kong, falling 2.7% on its IPO. The stock opened near-flat at HK$14.82 and later fell to HK$14, raising concerns about investor sentiment. The IPO raised US$250 million, below initial expectations, and valued the company at US$2.16 billion, a "down round" compared to its last funding round. This weak start may signal further down rounds in China's tech sector amid economic slowdown and US-China trade tension.

site_title: Reeling in fresh ideas from a family tradition
summary: Hai Sia Seafood, a Singaporean SME, has modernized its business under the leadership of 29-year-old deputy director Ang Junting. The company has increased its focus on research and development, with a 30% rise in capital expenditure since 2015. This has led to the launch of online products, including vacuum-sealed seafood and meal kits. Despite growing online sales, the majority of revenue still comes from supplying other businesses. The company aims to stay relevant in the local market, where strict hygiene standards and fewer competitors provide untapped potential.

site_title: Tech sector turns wary as 'chip dip' hurts sales
summary: The tech sector is experiencing a slowdown due to weakening demand for computer chips, particularly in China, where smartphone shipments fell 15% in the fourth quarter. This is attributed to a combination of factors, including decreased spending by Chinese consumers and intensifying "trade and macro concerns." Despite this, business conditions remain healthier than past slumps, thanks to reduced price competition from mergers and a strong future in emerging technologies like AI, healthcare, and 5G.

site_title: Malaysian shares close flat on Monday
summary: Malaysian shares closed flat on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 0.08 points to 1,683.61. Volume reached 103 million lots worth RM880 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 385 to 280.

site_title: Former SMRT CEO Desmond Kuek to join UBS global wealth management
summary: UBS has appointed Desmond Kuek, former CEO of SMRT Corp, as divisional vice chairman for global wealth management, effective February 18, 2019. Kuek, who stepped down from SMRT in April 2018, brings his experience as an executive, government official, and board member to the role. UBS President Edmund Koh welcomed Kuek, citing his strategic thinking and ability to drive complex businesses through innovation and transformation. Kuek will be based in Singapore and report to Joe Stadler and Edmund Koh.

site_title: Habitat for Humanity founder dies at 74
summary: Millard Fuller, 74, founder of Habitat for Humanity, died on Sunday en route to a hospital in Albany, Georgia. An autopsy is being performed to determine the cause of death. Fuller, a self-made millionaire, gave away his wealth to start Habitat for Humanity and later founded a similar organization after being fired from the Habitat board due to disputes.

site_title: Australia to overhaul regulators after landmark banking inquiry
summary: Australia's government has announced plans to overhaul its banking regulators after a landmark inquiry found widespread financial wrongdoing and systemic conflicts of interest. The Royal Commission's 76 recommendations include a new oversight authority for regulators and overhauling remuneration structures to remove conflicts of interest. The inquiry's findings, released after 11 months of revelations, included misconduct at top wealth managers and banks, with estimated losses of A$60 billion. The government has pledged to take action on all recommendations, with the opposition Labour party promising to adopt them all.

site_title: Asia stocks quiet, US dollar supported after upbeat US jobs data
summary: Asia stocks remained steady on Monday, near a four-month high, after a mixed Wall Street performance. The US dollar was supported by strong US jobs and manufacturing data, lifting yields and making it a shade higher against the yen. The US Labor Department reported a 304,000 jobs gain, the largest since February 2018, and ISM manufacturing activity numbers showed underlying strength in the US economy.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower on Monday; STI down 0.06% to 3,186.2
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.06% to 3,186.2 on Monday, with 72.9 million shares worth S$88.9 million traded. Ezion was the most actively traded counter, down 5.77% to 4.9 Singapore cents, followed by YZJ Shipbuilding and CapitaLand, which declined 1.41% and 0.9% respectively. The market opened weaker ahead of upcoming GDP data.

site_title: Malaysia shares open higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 14.79 points, or 0.88%, to 1,698.97 on Monday, with volume reaching 43 million lots worth RM30 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 132 to 43.

site_title: STI closes Monday down 0.1% to 3,184.56
summary: Singapore shares closed lower on Monday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) down 4.12 points or 0.1% to 3,184.56. Losers outnumbered gainers 169 to 148, with Pine Capital being the most actively traded stock. DBS Group Holdings gained 0.5%, while OCBC Bank and United Overseas Bank shares dropped 0.6% and 0.3%, respectively.

site_title: Ryanair to restructure, posts quarterly loss
summary: Ryanair plans to restructure into four subsidiaries, with Michael O'Leary as overall group CEO, to boost efficiency and capital allocation. The airline reported a 20 million euro quarterly loss, attributed to weaker-than-expected air fares. Despite this, O'Leary expressed confidence in the group's performance, citing the impact of lower fuel costs. Ryanair also reiterated concerns over a no-deal Brexit, which remains a "worryingly high" risk, affecting about one-quarter of its revenues.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets steady at open
summary: European stock markets remained steady at the start of trading on Monday, with London's FTSE 100 index up a fraction at 7,022 points. The eurozone saw the DAX 30 index flat at 11,180.42 points and the Paris CAC 40 dipping 0.1 per cent to 5,014.31. Trading was influenced by mining and healthcare stocks, with US-EU trade talks also on the radar.

site_title: Ezion expects Q4 and FY18 net loss on impairments of shareholder loans to JVs
summary: Ezion Holdings expects a fourth-quarter and full-year 2018 net loss due to impairments of shareholder loans to joint ventures. The company's non-current assets rose to US$1.7 billion, leading to an increase in shareholder loans. Ezion is also reviewing the fair value of its vessels, expecting a significant decrease in net asset value. The company attributed its struggles to depressed market conditions and payment delays by customers. Steps are being taken to recover outstanding amounts and regain control of vessels.

site_title: Popiah King's son Ben Goi dies of a heart attack in KL
summary: Businessman Ben Goi, son of Popiah King Sam Goi, died of a heart attack in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia on February 3, 2019, at the age of 43. His body was repatriated to Singapore and cremated at Mandai Crematorium. Ben Goi was married to former actress Tracy Lee and had a son born in May 2017. Local actors attended his wake at his house, with some declining to speak to reporters.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore shares fell 0.1% to 3,184.56 on Monday, despite a mixed global market. Wirecard's Singapore office is under investigation for alleged financial irregularities, causing the company's shares to plummet. Former SMRT CEO Desmond Kuek joined UBS global wealth management, and Maybank extended Hyflux's deadline to execute an agreement for Tuaspring. Green Build's request to delay FY18 results was rejected, and SGX will require the company to announce its results by March 1. Meanwhile, international markets were affected by US tariffs, with Vietnam and the Asian garment industry bracing for potential impacts.

site_title: Is it time to consider introducing a wealth tax?
summary: Singapore is considering introducing a wealth tax to tap into the growing wealth of Asia's super-rich individuals, who are expected to drive the region's wealth growth. However, experts argue that the tax may not be effective due to inefficiencies in collection and the potential for capital flight. Instead, the government may focus on enhancing policies to encourage the development of family offices, which could attract wealth management businesses and create economic spin-offs. The upcoming Budget could be an opportune time to explore this option.

site_title: Australia job ads fell 1.7% in Jan: ANZ
summary: Australian job advertisements in newspapers and online declined 1.7% in January, marking the first annual drop since 2015. The decline, from 171,392 ads per week in January 2018, is consistent with a loss of momentum in the economy. The ANZ's Head of Australian economics, David Plank, attributed the drop to weaker job ads, which should translate to actual hiring in the coming months, despite a tight labor market with a 5% unemployment rate in December.

site_title: Gold slips on firm US dollar, robust US jobs data
summary: Gold prices fell 0.3% to $1,314.47 per ounce, as the US dollar held steady amid upbeat US jobs and factory data. The solid jobs report reduced bets on a rate cut later this year, prompting markets to reassess interest rate hikes. US President Trump mentioned military intervention in Venezuela as an option, while US-China trade talks showed a "good vibe" with more work to be done.

site_title: Major European nations recognise Guaido as Venezuela's president
summary: Major European nations, including Spain, Britain, Austria, Sweden, and Denmark, have recognised Venezuelan opposition leader Juan Guaido as interim president, defying President Nicolas Maduro's refusal to call a new vote. The move comes after an eight-day deadline expired, with France acknowledging Guaido's right to organise an election. The coordinated action from European nations, backed by US President Donald Trump, contrasts with Russia and China's support for Maduro. The international development sets a precedent for a self-declared leader and raises tensions in the region.

images.alt_text: Spain, Britain, Austria, Sweden and Denmark recognised Venezuela's opposition leader Juan Guaido as interim president of Venezuela on Monday while France said he had the right to organise an election given the socialist government's refusal.

site_title: Money FM podcast: The Hot Seat: Budget 2019 preview with Indranee Rajah
summary: Singapore Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat will deliver the Budget 2019 statement on Feb 18. Indranee Rajah, Minister in the Prime Minister's Office and Second Minister for Finance and Education, shared a sneak preview on expected changes, but no specific details were disclosed. The budget is expected to focus on sustainable growth, economic diversification, and social welfare. Rajah emphasized the government's commitment to fiscal responsibility while also addressing pressing economic and social issues. The exact content of the budget remains a mystery until the official announcement.

site_title: Singapore police looking into reports of alleged financial irregularities at digital payments firm Wirecard
summary: Singapore police are investigating reports of alleged financial irregularities at German digital payments firm Wirecard AG, following a Financial Times report of forgery and falsification of accounts at Wirecard's Singapore office. Wirecard denied the allegations, stating no conclusive evidence of criminal misconduct by employees, and hired a law firm to review the matter. German financial regulator BaFin is also investigating for possible market manipulation.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close higher ahead of holiday
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed higher on Monday, up 0.21% or 59.47 points, ahead of a three-day break for Lunar New Year. The Hang Seng Index reached 27,990.21. The positive move was driven by a bumper US jobs report. Meanwhile, Singapore stocks notched a 5-day rally, and Asia markets largely followed suit, despite new US trade threats. The US stock market also hit fresh records, despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Stocks to watch: No Signboard, Procurri, Ezion, Green Build, Pine Capital
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

No Signboard Holdings' CEO inadvertently instructed the company to buy back shares during a trading restriction period, affecting shares that closed at S$0.15 on Jan 31. Procurri Corporation received a non-binding letter of intent for a proposed acquisition by New State Capital Partners, but has not accepted it. Ezion Holdings expects a fourth-quarter and full-year 2018 net loss due to uncertainty over joint ventures repaying shareholder loans. Green Build Technology's SGX rejected its two-month extension request for FY2018 results, which must be announced by Mar 1. Pine Capital Group's COO stepped down after assuming the role in November.

site_title: D-Day for Australian banks as bombshell inquiry report set for release
summary: Australia is set to release the final report of the independent inquiry into systemic wrongdoing in the country's financial sector, likely leading to sweeping changes and possible criminal charges. The Royal Commission's 11-month hearings exposed wrongdoing, wiping over A$60 billion from top financial stocks. Recommendations may include tougher enforcement of responsible lending laws, an end to conflicted commissions, and limits to executive bonuses. The government, led by Prime Minister Scott Morrison, is expected to adopt most of the recommendations, but is bracing for a "brutal" summary of the banks' misdeeds.

site_title: Australia corporate watchdog orders CBA unit to stop taking fees
summary: Australia's corporate watchdog, ASIC, has ordered Commonwealth Financial Planning, a unit of Commonwealth Bank of Australia, to stop charging service fees to its customers due to non-compliance with a court order. CFPL agreed not to enter new service arrangements with customers. The move comes as the financial sector faces regulatory changes following a powerful inquiry into systemic wrongdoing. The bank's financial planning arm failed to respond to concerns about fees for no service, prompting the restrictions. ASIC will monitor CFPL's transition to a new model.

site_title: British music retailer HMV receives last-minute offer: FT
summary: British music retailer HMV has received a last-minute offer from Canada's Sunrise Records to rescue the business from administration. The offer was welcomed by HMV's creditors, although financial details were not disclosed. HMV had previously called in administrators due to a worsening market for entertainment CDs and DVDs, and was the latest victim of brutal trading conditions in Britain's retail sector.

site_title: Oil prices slip, but tightening supply outlook supports
summary: Oil prices slipped on Monday, down 20 cents to $55.06 per barrel, after a 3% gain in the previous session. The drop was partly due to a tighter supply outlook, with US energy firms cutting oil rigs to their lowest in eight months. Expectations of easing China-US trade tensions also supported prices, with hopes of a trade deal between the two nations. Oil supply from OPEC fell in January by the largest amount in two years, despite Russia's oil output decline.

site_title: Hong Fok Corp could take control of associate after unit's share buyback proposal
summary: Hong Fok Corp may gain control of associate Hong Fok Land International after its unit proposes a share buyback offer. HFL plans to buy back all shares at HK$0.55 per share, potentially increasing HFC's stake to over 50%. HFC has agreed not to accept the offer, which would allow it to seek a whitewash waiver and avoid making a general offer for HFL. The buyback, financed by a loan facility, requires approval from 75% of independent HFL shareholders and cannot be rejected by more than 10%.

site_title: SeedPlus bets on Neuron Mobility to zoom ahead of e-scooter crowd
summary: SeedPlus, a venture firm, has invested S$5 million in Neuron Mobility, an e-scooter startup. Neuron, founded in 2016, produces its own scooters and operates in Singapore, Thailand, and Malaysia. The company aims to expand into the Asia-Pacific region with the fresh capital. Neuron's unique advantages include controlling its own destiny through manufacturing and optimizing scooter placement. SeedPlus believes Neuron can avoid the pitfalls of the bike-sharing industry by focusing on regulatory compliance and using data science to optimize operations.

site_title: SGX rejects Green Build's request for more time to announce FY18 results
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has rejected Green Build Technology's request for a two-month extension to announce its FY18 results, forcing the company to meet the March 1 deadline. However, the SGX granted an extra month for Green Build to hold its annual general meeting (AGM) and issue its annual report, with the new deadline of May 30 and May 16, respectively. The company cited changes in its finance team and auditors as reasons for the extension requests.

site_title: Erdogan says Turkey keeping 'low-level' contact with Syria
summary: Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan confirmed that his government maintains "low-level" contact with the Syrian regime through its spy agency, despite being a fervent critic. This is the first time he has publicly acknowledged direct talks with Damascus. Erdogan ruled out direct talks with Assad and stated that spy agencies can maintain links even if leaders do not. He also expressed hope that the US will pull its troops out of Syria soon, warning that Ankara will take action if there's a threat posed by US-backed Syrian Kurdish militia.

site_title: Procurri receives letter of intent for general offer from New State Capital Partners
summary: Procurri Corporation, an enterprise hardware supplier, has received a non-binding letter of intent from New State Capital Partners LLC for a proposed acquisition of all shares except those held by substantial shareholder Irrucorp. The acquisition, via a scheme of arrangement, is conditional on undertakings from shareholders to vote in favor, New State's due diligence, and regulatory approvals. Procurri has not accepted the LOI and is not in exclusive discussions. The consideration will be satisfied by cash, and completion is subject to various conditions.

site_title: Fed's Kashkari: Rate hike pause keeps US growth on track
summary: The US Federal Reserve's decision to pause interest rate hikes is seen as keeping the US economy on track for further growth, according to Minneapolis Federal Reserve Bank President Neel Kashkari. Kashkari described the economy as "fundamentally healthy" and said there is room to run, despite risks such as slowing growth in China and uncertainty surrounding Brexit. The Fed's dovish shift was welcomed by financial markets, with President Donald Trump also praising the decision. Kashkari emphasized that the Fed should avoid premature rate hikes to prevent an economic downturn.

images.alt_text: The Federal Reserve's decision to stop raising interest rates puts a "fundamentally healthy" US economy on track to further growth, Minneapolis Federal Reserve Bank President Neel Kashkari suggested on Sunday.

site_title: Trump sees 'good chance' of deals with North Korea, China
summary: US President Donald Trump expressed optimism about reaching deals with North Korea and China, stating a "good chance" of agreements on nuclear disarmament and trade relations. The upcoming Trump-Kim summit is set to take place in late February in Vietnam, despite differing assessments from the US Director of National Intelligence, who believes North Korea is unlikely to give up its nuclear capabilities. Trump also praised China for being "very helpful" in trade negotiations, with a March 1 deadline looming for a potential deal to avert increased US duties on Chinese exports.

site_title: Democratic candidate trusts Americans ready for gay president
summary: Democratic presidential candidate Pete Buttigieg believes Americans will judge him based on the quality of his ideas and experience, rather than his openly gay status. As the first openly gay mayor of South Bend, Indiana, and a former naval intelligence officer, Buttigieg would become the first openly homosexual president of the US if elected. He cited his past re-election victories in a conservative community as evidence that Americans are prepared to get to know him and judge him on his merits, rather than his sexual orientation.

site_title: Foreign businesses fret as China fast-tracks investment law
summary: China is fast-tracking a foreign investment law to meet US demands on trade, despite concerns from foreign businesses that the review process has been cut short. The law aims to eliminate technology transfer requirements and level the business playing field, but critics say it lacks detail and vague language could be abused. China's parliament is expected to vote on the legislation in March, with the US set to impose tariffs on China on March 1 if concerns are not addressed.

site_title: Dutch boxer who fought Muhammad Ali still riding punches in Bulgaria
summary: Former Dutch boxing champion Rudi Lubbers, 73, is receiving help after a TV documentary showed his life of poverty in Bulgaria, where he and his partner Ria have been living in a broken-down van with no electricity or sanitary facilities. Lubbers, who fought Muhammad Ali in 1973, credits the fight for making him mentally stronger. A crowd-funding campaign raised over 12,500 euros after the documentary aired, and Lubbers' son arrived in Bulgaria to help. Lubbers' health has improved, but he remains in hospital for a few more days.

site_title: Japan insurers to target China M&A in new phase after US$50b overseas push
summary: Japanese insurance companies, including Nippon Life and Tokio Marine Holdings, plan to expand their overseas acquisitions, primarily targeting China, as foreign ownership curbs are lifted. The companies have spent over $50 billion on international deals since 2014, with a focus on cushioning the impact of negative interest rates in Japan. China's relaxation of foreign ownership rules and growing middle class make it an attractive market for insurers seeking growth outside their home markets. Japanese insurers are expected to step up their search for Chinese targets in the coming years.

site_title: China's services sector moderates in January but still solid: Caixin PMI
summary: China's services sector showed a solid pace of expansion in January, with the Caixin/Markit services purchasing managers' index (PMI) falling slightly to 53.6, above the 50.0 mark. New export business rose at the fastest clip in over a year, driven by efforts to attract foreign clients. The resilience of the services sector is key to countering the ongoing slowdown in manufacturing, which has been hit by industry restructuring and trade tensions with the US. The government's policies to support domestic demand will remain crucial to the economy's prospects.

site_title: Sony drops most since 2016 on weak PlayStation 4 demand
summary: Sony's shares plummeted 8.6% to their lowest since 2016 after reporting weaker PlayStation 4 sales and lower revenue forecasts. The company sold 8.1 million PS4 consoles, down from 9 million units a year ago, and cut its fiscal year revenue outlook to 8.5 trillion yen. The decline was attributed to higher promotional and marketing costs and slower growth in the games segment. Sony's operating income in games fell 14% to 73 billion yen for the holiday quarter.

site_title: Pentagon to deploy 3,750 extra US forces to border with Mexico
summary: The US Pentagon is deploying 3,750 extra active-duty forces to the southwest border with Mexico for three months to support border agents. This brings the total number of forces to around 4,350. The deployment, announced days after a lawmaker said 3,500 troops would be sent, is in support of President Donald Trump's border security proposals, which include a wall along the US-Mexico border. The move is part of ongoing efforts to address the situation at the border, which has been a point of contention between Trump and Democrats.

site_title: Erdogan says cannot understand US 'silence' over Khashoggi murder
summary: Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan accused the US of maintaining "silence" over the murder of Saudi journalist Jamal Khashoggi, who was killed by a Saudi hit team in the Istanbul consulate in October. Erdogan stated that the Khashoggi murder is not an ordinary one and wants everything to be clarified. The case has strained relations between Turkey and Saudi Arabia, with Ankara seeking answers from Riyadh about the killing and the whereabouts of Khashoggi's body. An international inquiry is also being called for.

site_title: Upheaval looms for Australian banks
summary: A wide-ranging inquiry into misconduct in Australia's financial industry is set to release a report recommending changes to atone for wrongdoings. The Royal Commission's final report may propose breaking up financial firms, tightening lending standards, and urging tougher action from regulators. The report may also recommend financial planning be separated from wealth management and push for changes to pay and bonuses. Bank earnings could be dented by increased compliance and customer-compensation costs, potentially leading to a credit freeze and affecting the broader economy.

site_title: Singapore-centric developers, construction counters, Reits start 2019 strongly
summary: Singapore's largest developers, construction firms, and Reits with a strong focus on the city-state have started 2019 with solid returns. The five largest Singapore-focused companies reported average returns of 4.7%, 5.2%, and 7.3% in January. This positive start is attributed to a strong market and increased investor interest.

site_title: German economists propose flexible Brexit plan
summary: German economists at the Ifo Institute have proposed a flexible Brexit plan to end the deadlock. The plan would scrap the "backstop provision" and create a European Customs Association (ECA) to cover trade policy in goods. The UK would have the same voting rights as EU member states, and customs barriers on the Irish border would be eliminated. The plan aims to find a compromise between the UK and EU, with a minimum three-month extension to the March 29 withdrawal date.

site_title: 'Unprecedented' flooding to hit northeast Australia
summary: Thousands in northeast Australia are bracing for "unprecedented" flooding after relentless downpours forced a dam to be fully opened, turning streets into rivers and forcing thousands to abandon their homes. Heavy rainfall, exceeding normal levels, has caused widespread damage, with up to 20,000 homes at risk of being inundated. The region is expected to receive more than a year's worth of rain in a short period, with landslides and flash flooding reported. The Australian government has deployed military personnel to deliver sandbags to affected locals, with the Premier describing the event as a "one-in-100-year" occurrence.

site_title: UK PM May will seek 'pragmatic' solution to Brexit deal in Brussels
summary: UK Prime Minister Theresa May plans to seek a "pragmatic solution" to the Brexit deal in Brussels, aiming to overcome a parliamentary impasse. With the UK's departure from the EU looming on March 29, concerns over a disorderly "no-deal" exit persist. May will return to Brussels with a fresh mandate to renegotiate the post-Brexit border arrangements, particularly the Northern Ireland backstop. The EU has rejected reopening talks on the backstop, but prominent Brexit lawmakers are pushing for a compromise plan to find an alternative.

site_title: Reason for cheer as Wall Street welcomes best Jan in 30 years
summary: US stocks surged in January, with major indices experiencing their biggest gains in 30 years, driven by a reversal from the Federal Reserve and "better-than-feared" earnings from Apple and other companies. The Fed's shift to a more patient stance on rate hikes has boosted the market, with a weaker dollar benefiting emerging markets and exporters like Boeing. The momentum is expected to continue this week if Alphabet's earnings reports meet expectations, potentially leading to a winning streak for major indices.

site_title: honestbee gets nod to pilot new industrial space concept
summary: honestbee, a Singaporean startup, has received approval to incorporate a large-scale retail operation as part of its industrial land's ancillary use. This move suggests greater flexibility from authorities in dealing with new business models. honestbee's tech-enabled grocery and dining concept, habitat, has been launched in an industrial building and plans to expand to seven Asian markets. The approval allows for 40% of the industrial development's floor area to be used for ancillary uses, supporting innovation and technology.

site_title: Adyen, a tech firm far from Silicon Valley, is churning out billionaires
summary: Adyen, a Dutch fintech firm, is generating wealth for its founders through its streamlined card-payment transactions. Since its June 2019 initial public offering, CEO Pieter van der Does, CTO Arnout Schuijff, and former innovation director John Caspers have all become billionaires, according to the Bloomberg Billionaires Index. Adyen's success is attributed to its ability to save merchants millions of dollars, making its founders' fortunes.

site_title: Once red-hot smartphone market sees cooler trend
summary: The global smartphone market experienced its worst contraction in 2018, with worldwide handset volumes declining 4.1% to 1.4 billion units shipped. Despite this, analysts predict the smartphone era is not coming to an end, as there is no viable replacement yet. High prices and economic uncertainty are contributing factors, with consumers waiting longer to replace their devices and some opting for alternative options like wearables or head-mounted displays. Analysts expect innovations such as 5G network connectivity and foldable screens to drive upgrades this year.

site_title: Football: Sala's missing plane found, say investigators
summary: A plane carrying Argentinian footballer Emiliano Sala and his pilot, Dave Ibbotson, has been found by investigators. The plane, a Piper PA-46 Malibu, went missing on January 21 while en route from France to Cardiff, Wales. Sala was traveling to join his new club, Cardiff City, in a €17 million transfer. The wreckage was spotted on Sunday, and the Air Accidents Investigation Branch (AAIB) will issue a statement on Monday. The incident occurred approximately 20km north of Guernsey, and Sala's family had hired a private company to search for the plane.

site_title: Seeking safety, investors drop stocks and pile into bonds
summary: US and European investors pulled $15 billion from stocks and $3.7 billion from European stocks in the week to Jan 30, seeking safety in bonds amid economic uncertainty. Bonds recorded inflows of $9.4 billion, the largest since January last year, while emerging market equities and Japan saw inflows of $4.4 billion and $1.3 billion respectively. Investors are no longer extremely bearish, but risk asset rally can continue, with record-high Treasury Bill allocation.

site_title: Nissan scraps plan to make X-Trail SUV in UK factory
summary: Nissan scrapped plans to manufacture the X-Trail SUV at its UK factory, citing uncertainty over Brexit and business reasons. The decision, announced by Nissan Europe chairman Gianluca de Ficchy, is another blow to the British car industry, which saw a 46% drop in investment last year. The X-Trail model will continue to be produced in Kyushu, Japan, while other vehicles planned for the Sunderland factory remain unaffected. The company did not specify the reasons for the decision, but reportedly cited emissions regulations and reduced sales forecasts.

site_title: Asia stocks having a 'bear-market bounce', JPMorgan Asset says
summary: Asia stocks are experiencing a "bear-market bounce" according to JPMorgan Asset Management, with a 6.8% rally in January being the best start to a year since 2012. Global economic growth slowdown and a potential US-China trade deal are driving the rebound, but Jasslyn Yeo, global market strategist, warns that recession risks have increased and the rally could last only in the first half of the year. Yeo remains bullish on Asian shares excluding Japan and emerging markets in general for the first half, but cautious on India and the Philippines.

site_title: Expect XAUUSD to retrace to US$1,284-1,294 levels
summary: London gold reached its peak of $1,365.49 in April 2018, then broke the $1,300 mark in May and experienced a substantial sell-off, eventually recovering to $1,320. An analysis using Fibonacci retracement and stochastics oscillator indicates a bearish bias and suggests XAUUSD will retrace to $1,284-$1,294 levels, potentially reversing before continuing to $1,365.462.

site_title: Quiet week ahead but don't dismiss volatility
summary: Singapore stocks may experience volatility despite a quiet week ahead due to ongoing trade tensions and geopolitical risks. The Singapore manufacturing PMI report and economic data from China will provide insight into the nation's economy. Central banks in the region, including the Reserve Bank of Australia and Bank of Thailand, will also make monetary policy decisions, potentially influencing trading. Meanwhile, US earnings season continues, with companies like Alphabet and Twitter set to release earnings.

site_title: Saudi Arabia encouraged foreign workers to leave - now it's struggling
summary: Saudi Arabia is experiencing a massive exodus of foreign workers, with over 1.1 million leaving the workforce between 2017 and the third quarter of last year. The exodus reflects broader hardships and unease, particularly due to rising costs and fees imposed on dependents of expatriate workers. The departure of foreigners has added to the country's unemployment rate, which has spiked to 12.9% over the past two years, forcing the government to revise its short-term unemployment goals. The exodus also poses challenges for Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman's plan to remake the Saudi economy and create employment for Saudi citizens in the private sector.

site_title: 737 Max software was updated; pilots weren't
summary: Boeing's 737 Max software update was implemented without informing pilots, raising questions about whether potential dangers were downplayed for cost and competitive reasons. The Lion Air tragedy, which killed 189 people, highlighted the lack of pilot knowledge about the Maneuvering Characteristics Augmentation System (MCAS), a critical element of the plane's software. Boeing claimed that established emergency procedures would have allowed the crew to handle a malfunction, but many pilots are angry and concerned. The FAA is investigating Boeing's role in the crash and its certification process.

site_title: How Trump is wreaking havoc with Opec policy
summary: US President Donald Trump's actions are disrupting Opec's oil output policy, causing market volatility. Trump's tweets and sanctions on Venezuela and Iran have led to increased production, resulting in a surplus of oil in the market. Opec's attempts to cut production have been undermined by external factors, including Trump's tariffs and waivers on Iran sanctions. The group's efforts to control the market are hindered by unpredictable external factors, making it challenging to achieve the desired timing of their actions, ultimately affecting oil prices.

images.alt_text: Unexpected external factors just seem to keep cropping up and, at least recently, many of them seem to originate with Uncle Sam. This makes it difficult for Opec to get its timing right.

site_title: China's rule changes a boost for foreign investors
summary: China has announced changes to its capital markets, giving foreign investors ready access to almost all areas of the country's markets. The measures include expanding the Qualified Foreign Institutional Investor (QFII) program, allowing offshore funds to trade more types of futures and options, and enabling foreign investors to engage in margin trading and short-selling transactions. The changes are part of China's efforts to open up its financial sector and meet demands from international institutions. The moves are seen as a boost for foreign investors, potentially leading to increased investment in China's markets.

site_title: Courts Singapore launches charity arm
summary: Courts Singapore has launched Courts Charity Home, a CSR programme that organizes donations of home products to the needy and provides volunteer opportunities for staff. The partnership with local charity Care Community Services Society (CCSS) aims to bring Chinese New Year cheer to underprivileged individuals, particularly low-income elderly and children. Through the programme, Courts donated home appliances and furniture to 22 selected beneficiaries, who expressed gratitude for the support. The initiative marks Courts' 45th anniversary in Singapore and aims to make a positive impact on the community.

site_title: Luxury watch players subdued under cloud of uncertainty
summary: Luxury watch exports in Singapore have faced uncertainty, with sales dropping to record lows during the Christmas season and continuing to be slow, with retailers reporting that customers are only interested in popular models like Rolex sports watches and Patek Philippe's Nautilus and Aquanaut. Swiss watch exports to Singapore rose 0.7% to 1.11 billion Swiss francs in 2018, a slower growth than expected. Globally, Swiss watch exports jumped 6.3% to 21.17 billion Swiss francs, but the luxury market is expected to be uncertain in 2019 due to geopolitical and economic uncertainty.

site_title: Retailers in Japan fret as Chinese consumers cut spending
summary: Japanese retailers are concerned that Chinese tourists will spend less this Chinese New Year due to the slowdown of China's economic growth and the strengthening of the yen. Four major department stores in Japan reported year-on-year declines in sales of tax-free goods in January, with Isetan Mitsukoshi Holdings experiencing a 10.2% drop at three major stores in Tokyo. The Chinese government's strengthened regulations on e-commerce transactions and the yen's 3.5% gain against the Chinese yuan are cited as reasons for the decline.

site_title: Tesla Model 3 owners vent about polar vortex affecting cars
summary: Tesla Model 3 owners are experiencing frustration with their vehicles due to the polar vortex, which is affecting battery range and performance. Cold temperatures are draining batteries, with some owners reporting a 20-25 mile loss overnight and an additional 5-10 miles during daily drives. The issue is not unique to Tesla, but the door design of the Model 3, which requires a specific handle-pushing motion, is making it difficult for drivers to open the car in icy conditions. This has led some owners to question the value of their $60,000 vehicles.

site_title: Share buyback during black-out period 'a mistake': No Signboard
summary: No Signboard Holdings' executive chairman and CEO Lim Yong Sim made an "honest mistake" by instructing the company's broker to buy back shares during a trading restriction period. The company's shares jumped 24% on January 31, prompting a trading halt, and the subsequent buyback exceeded the 5% cap above the average closing price. The company has been directed to develop a comprehensive internal policy and procedure on the share buyback process and will not carry out any further buybacks until the policy is approved.

site_title: Dollar gains versus yen after US jobs, manufacturing data
summary: The US dollar rose against the yen, posting its largest one-day gain in a month, following January data showing the biggest number of US jobs created in 11 months and a rebound in US manufacturing. Despite tame wage inflation, the dollar's gains were tempered by a rise in unemployment. The report showed 304,000 jobs created, exceeding forecasts, but with weak wage growth and a seven-month peak in unemployment. The dollar index rose 0.6% against the yen, while the dollar index trading little changed at 95.579.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary:
The Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights report for last week's tanker and dry bulk market highlights a sharp fall in rates across all regions due to the Vale dam tragedy, prompting a panic among some owners and operators. Key rate drops include:

- Capesize: $13.75-$13.00
- North Atlantic: $20,000-$14,000
- East: $4.80-$9.00
- Panamax: $4,000-$10,000
- Supramax: 50% loss of value since start of the year
- Handysize: 50% loss of value since start of the year
- VLCC: $4.75 million-$6.3 million
- Suezmax: WS 70s-WS 97.5
- Aframax: WS 105-WS 87.5
- Clean: WS 127.5-WS 122.5

The market is expected to remain cautious ahead of the Chinese New Year celebrations, with rates potentially softening further.

site_title: New golf rules help speed up play
summary: New golf rules in Singapore have helped reduce playing time by 30-45 minutes per round, with an estimated 15% global decline in golfers among millennials due to time constraints. The rules, introduced to speed up play, include a 40-second limit for making a stroke, encouragement of Ready Golf in social play, and options for dropping balls in bunkers or leaving flags intact on putts. However, some golfers and caddies are adjusting to the new rules, and controversy has arisen over a penalty assessed to China's Li Haotong for violating the new alignment rule.

site_title: Japan's working mothers: When housework gets in the way
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe aims to boost the economy by increasing women in the workforce, with 67% of women currently employed. However, many women are limited to domestic roles due to an overwhelming burden at home. This imbalance hinders both individual and national ambitions, hindering progress in elevating women in the labor force.

site_title: May 'determined' to meet March 29 deadline for UK to leave EU
summary: UK Prime Minister Theresa May remains determined to deliver Brexit on March 29, despite Cabinet ministers suggesting a delay could be needed. May has promised to return to Brussels with new ideas to deliver a deal, citing Labour's Jeremy Corbyn's agreement that the Brexit deal needs changes to the Irish border backstop. However, Chief Secretary to the Treasury Liz Truss warns that negotiations will likely go to the last minute, with the threat of no deal bringing Parliament closer to a consensus and potentially softening the EU's position.

site_title: Changing attitudes towards cannabis medical properties
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) has recommended removing cannabis and its resin from Schedule IV of the 1961 drug convention, a move that could change attitudes towards the drug's medical properties and potentially encourage legalization. The WHO also clarified that CBD containing less than 0.2% THC is not under international control. The recommendations could provide countries with additional political cover to re-examine their cannabis laws. The proposals will be sent to the United Nations' Commission on Narcotic Drugs for a vote in March.

site_title: Republicans want Fannie Mae, Freddie Mac to be private companies again
summary: Senate Republican Chairman Mike Crapo has proposed allowing Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac to return to private companies, potentially altering the future of the housing finance giants. The proposal aims to establish stronger taxpayer protection, preserve 30-year fixed-rate mortgages, increase competition among mortgage guarantors, and promote affordable housing. Hedge fund billionaire John Paulson has expressed support for the proposal, which could provide a windfall for investors who have lobbied for the change. However, the proposal leaves unanswered questions and faces uncertain political will, raising concerns about the impact on the US housing market.

site_title: Big cash holdings in Europe signal unease over market outlook
summary: European fund managers are holding large cash reserves due to growing unease over market prospects, with some holding 4-5% in cash, three times more than last summer. This is the highest level since May 2017, amid concerns over a protectionist war, Brexit, and economic uncertainty. Investors are waiting for data and news on the global economy and politics before making investment decisions, with many expecting a 4% earnings growth in Europe this year.

site_title: Hong Kong eyes sea and golf courses to solve chronic housing
summary: Hong Kong is considering unusual options to address its chronic housing shortage, including building four artificial islands in its central waters, which would cost HK$500 billion. The proposal also involves converting private golf courses and a disused container terminal. However, the plan has drawn opposition from environmentalists and 49% of the public, citing concerns over the environmental impact and the city's more urgent needs. The government is exploring other options, such as developing 500,000 new homes over the next 25 years using unused farmland.

site_title: The Singapore Chinese identity has evolved: PM Lee
summary: Singaporean Chinese identity has evolved into a distinct culture, separate from Chinese communities worldwide, according to Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong. This integration is a result of the country's multicultural society, where Chinese immigrants have developed unique rituals and traditions over generations. The Singaporean Chinese identity will continue to evolve as new immigrants join, enriching the country's cultural heritage. The government hopes that new arrivals will adjust to local social norms and adopt uniquely Singaporean cultural habits.

site_title: No Signboard 'inadvertently' conducted share buyback during black out period
summary: No Signboard Holdings' CEO Lim Yong Sim inadvertently instructed the company's broker to buy back shares during a trading restriction period, exceeding the 5% share price cap. The company had held its annual general meeting on January 31 to approve the share buyback mandate, but the purchase was carried out during a black-out period. The company has directed Lim to attend directors' trainings and develop a comprehensive internal policy for the share buyback process. Shares will resume trading on Monday.

site_title: Tariffs may live on as Trump's best bet to enforce a China deal
summary: US tariffs on Chinese goods may persist even after a trade deal is reached, as the Trump administration seeks to ensure China's compliance. Former US officials argue that tariffs were a key factor in getting China to the negotiating table and that they should remain as an enforcement mechanism. Any deal would need to include "strong enforcement language" and commitments on issues such as intellectual property protection and market access. The US is still figuring out how to effectively enforce these commitments, with some officials advocating for unilateral US action and others preferring a more collaborative approach.

site_title: Pine Capital's COO quits after assuming role in Nov '18
summary: Pine Capital Group's COO, Jessie Sun May Gze, has stepped down after assuming the role in November 2018. The reasons for her departure include unresolved differences in opinions on material matters and other issues. Her last day was January 31. The board will consider responses to these issues before making a response to the sponsor's enquiries. This comes after the company's former CEO, Philip Wong, resigned in May 2018 to pursue personal interests. Tan Choon Wee is the interim CEO and executive chairman.

site_title: January IPOs felt cold blast of US government shutdown
summary: US initial public offerings (IPOs) had a dismal start to 2019, with only 60 listings raising $2.7 billion, compared to 126 listings raising over $13 billion in January 2018. The poor performance was largely due to the 35-day US government shutdown. Some companies, such as Rhinebeck Bancorp and New Fortress Energy, used workarounds to price their shares in advance. The situation remains uncertain, with Uber Technologies' planned IPO potentially affected by a renewed government shutdown, which could impact other tech IPO candidates like Airbnb and Slack Technologies.

site_title: Tired of housing bubbles, Hainan tries shift in focus
summary: China's tropical island of Hainan is shifting its focus away from housing bubbles by re-zoning a 21 sq km area for industrial use, including tourism and high-tech projects. The move exceeds the land sold to developers over the past seven years and aims to avoid another property frenzy. The local government introduced province-wide home-buying restrictions last year to curb speculation. Experts believe these restrictions will keep demand in check, reducing pressure for price increases. This policy shift demonstrates the government's determination to make better use of land and avoid another housing boom.

site_title: Phasing out coal seen costing Germany billions of euros
summary: Germany's plan to phase out coal is expected to be costly, with utilities seeking billions in compensation and states demanding tens of billions in support. The nation's decision could also lead to a 5.2 billion euro loss in cancelled carbon permit sales. Analysts estimate the actual cost will depend on how Germany interprets new European Commission rules and its willingness to shore up the trading system. The phase-out is already facing resistance from workers and utilities.

site_title: US puts squeeze on European firms doing business with Iran
summary: The US has intensified its pressure on European companies doing business with Iran, enforcing maximum economic sanctions that are affecting firms across the continent. Direct pressure from US officials, including US Ambassador Richard Grenell, has led to companies such as Siemens, Allianz, and Volkswagen exiting operations in Iran. However, many firms remain, sparking concerns about intimidation and disruption to business operations. The European effort to maintain trade with Iran is seen as mild compared to the US approach, with Iran's authorities growing increasingly frustrated with the situation.

site_title: European telecos' dilemma: Huawei or the highway?
summary: European telecoms firms face a dilemma in deciding whether to use 5G equipment from Huawei, a Chinese giant, despite US-led warnings of security threats. Huawei has become a leading supplier of 5G backbone equipment, but its equipment could be a Trojan horse for Beijing's security apparatus, according to Western states. Several operators, including Bouygues Telecom and SFR, have already begun tests with Huawei equipment, citing its superior quality. However, experts say Huawei is currently ahead of its European competitors, including Ericsson and Nokia, and that delaying the rollout could put Europe at risk of falling behind China and the US.

site_title: Why are young people pretending to love work?
summary: Young people are feeling pressured to love their jobs, with many feeling obligated to work excessively long hours. WeWork locations, a popular co-working space, promote a culture of "hustling harder" and "not stopping when you're tired." This has led some to question whether this approach is actually a recipe for burnout. The article suggests that the current work culture prioritizes endurance over genuine enjoyment, potentially harming mental health.

site_title: 'Inkjet' solar panels taking clean energy dream one step closer to reality
summary: Polish physicist Olga Malinkiewicz has developed an inkjet processing method for perovskites, a new generation of cheaper solar cells, reducing production costs and making mass production economically feasible. This breakthrough technology can produce solar panels under lower temperatures, increasing efficiency and reducing costs. Perovskite solar cells are light, flexible, efficient, inexpensive, and can be applied to various surfaces, making them a promising solution for clean energy and sustainable buildings. The technology has the potential to revolutionize access to solar power and has been recognized by experts, including Mohammad Khaja Nazeeruddin, a professor at the Federal Institute of Technology Lausanne.

site_title: Ushering in abundance and fortune
summary: Business leaders wish for the Year of the Pig to bring a more balanced approach to decision-making, focusing on innovation, workforce development, and sustainability. They hope for increased stability, peace, and cooperation globally, as well as a more positive outlook on the economy and growth prospects. Leaders emphasize the importance of embracing change, prioritizing data management, and protecting against cyber threats. They also express optimism about the potential for growth and development, particularly for small and medium-sized enterprises, and hope for government support in enabling their expansion.

images.alt_text: John Bittleston, Founder & Chair, Terrific Mentors International Pte Ltd

site_title: Experts work to decode enigma of Fed balance-sheet pivot
summary: The Federal Reserve's decision to pivot on shrinking its $4 trillion balance sheet has sparked confusion among investors, with experts struggling to decode its implications. The gentler-than-expected unwind reduces the likelihood of policy makers losing control of interest rates, but its effects on various markets and metrics, such as repurchase agreements and Treasury bills, remain uncertain. Market veterans expect a material impact on the repo market, with rising repo rates forcing other short-term rates higher, but some analysts predict the Fed may become a buyer of bills to keep the balance sheet steady.

site_title: Who is responsible for billing inaccuracies?
summary: The Australian banking royal commission's final report is set to be released on February 4, 2019, investigating widespread misconduct in the financial services sector. The interim report criticized regulators for allowing bad conduct to go unpunished and identified issues in lending and financial advisory practices. The report also highlighted the need to overhaul the ethical culture of the Australian financial industry. A global trend of increasing regulatory scrutiny is also underway, with regulators in major financial centers implementing new senior management accountability regimes.

site_title: Brookvale Park's owners to get en bloc hongbao as sale is approved
summary: A sale order has been granted for Brookvale Park condo, allowing owner Hoi Hup Sunway to redevelop the site. The redevelopment plan includes extending Sunset Way to connect to Clementi Road, providing an alternate route for residents. The new development will feature 660 units, up from 160, and is expected to cater to couples and young families. The project's technical details are pending approval from authorities.

site_title: Budget to 'carry on steering economy through uncertain waters'
summary: Singapore's Budget 2019 aims to navigate global economic uncertainties through innovation, internationalization, and worker capability-building. Minister Indranee Rajah emphasized the need to support small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) and help them scale up, while also addressing technological disruption. The budget will have a social focus on education, healthcare, and volunteering, with a special emphasis on the underprivileged. The government will also consider a goods and services tax hike from 7% to 9% by 2025 to fund long-term healthcare needs.

site_title: What CEOs are saying about the possibility of a recession
summary: Several CEOs expressed caution about their companies' outlook due to slowing US demand and global weakness. Despite not forecasting a downturn, they cited potential risks of a recession and slowing growth. CEOs like Elon Musk, Darius Adamczyk, and Jonas Prising acknowledged the uncertainty but emphasized their companies' resilience. The International Monetary Fund also predicted a slowdown in global growth, and economists see a 25% chance of a US recession in the next 12 months.

site_title: Hyflux creditors asked to file proof of claims by Feb 15
summary: Hyflux creditors are urged to file their proof of claims by February 15, with the company stating that this is a requirement under Singapore's restructuring law. The deadline applies to bond, perpetual security, and preference share holders, with those who fail to file a proof risking disqualification from voting and potential payment exclusion. The company denies that the requirement is aimed at disqualifying retail investors from voting.

site_title: The joy of the junk drawer
summary: A couple binge-watches the Netflix series Tidying Up with Marie Kondo, adopting the KonMari housekeeping philosophy that encourages keeping items that spark joy and letting go of others. Despite achieving modest results, they struggle with the idea that clutter will inevitably return. Experts, including a psychologist and a home organizer, explain that accumulating objects is often driven by a desire for dopamine and a lack of attention to space. To maintain organization, a systematic approach is necessary, including categorizing possessions and finding alternative homes for items that don't spark joy.

site_title: MBS' luxury mall rings out 2018 with record revenue of US$179m
summary: The Shoppes at Marina Bay Sands (MBS) in Singapore recorded a record revenue of US$179 million in 2018, a 7% increase from the previous year. The luxury mall maintained its pole position in tourism shopping, with top spenders from China, Indonesia, Malaysia, and Vietnam. The mall's retail segment performed "exceptionally" despite the competitive retail landscape and growing e-commerce popularity. The Shoppes' occupancy rate reached 95.4% and retail tenant sales increased by 19% to US$1,898 per square foot.

site_title: Focus on getting back to banking basics at Paris Fintech Forum
summary: The Paris Fintech Forum, attended by 3,000 entrepreneurs, investors, and regulators, shifted focus away from cryptocurrency and blockchain technology due to the significant decline in their value. Instead, discussions centered on "banking basics," with a focus on building branchless lenders, traditional lending, and the use of artificial intelligence in finance. Keynote speakers, including Christine Lagarde and Francois Villeroy de Galhau, emphasized the need for stability and regulation in the industry. The event highlighted the maturation of European fintech, with notable startups like N26 and Adyen achieving significant valuations.

images.alt_text: With the top 10 crypto assets down 80 per cent in the last 12 months, many fintech pros concluded that the technology may not be ready for prime time, especially in a heavily regulated industry.

site_title: Mencast reaches debt deal with creditors; principal sums owed suspended until after restructuring
summary: Mencast Holdings, a Singapore-listed company, has reached a debt deal with its key creditors, suspending principal sums owed until the end of a restructuring period. The deal involves cutting debt by S$130 million through asset sales, with any excess funds subject to a cash sweep towards outstanding debt. The principal sums will be turned into a term loan over 24 months, with contractual interest still due. The restructuring period's details will be disclosed at a later time.

site_title: Batam aims to be manufacturing rival in Singapore's backyard
summary: Indonesia aims to reposition Batam island as a manufacturing rival to Singapore, seeking to draw $60 billion in new investments. The island, located 30km south of Singapore, has attracted $20 billion in investments since the 1970s and is home to thousands of firms producing goods from computers to oil rigs. Authorities plan to reclaim 8,000 hectares of idle land to offer to exporters or producers of import substitutes, with potential investments including those in tourism, logistics, and shipyard industries.

site_title: Cohen & Steers increases stake in PLife Reit
summary: Cohen & Steers increased its stake in Parkway Life REIT (PLife REIT) to 5.08% after purchasing 885,200 units for S$2,398,360.88 in January 2019. The REIT reported a 2.7% year-over-year increase in gross revenue for FY18, attributed to the Japan acquisition, higher yielding properties, and higher rents. The acquisition was made by Cohen & Steers Capital Management, Inc, a wholly owned subsidiary of Cohen & Steers, Inc.

site_title: Reits
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

US mortgage rates rise after five consecutive declines, while Singapore's Q3 condo launches may test demand above S$3,000 psf. Manhattan rents hit a record, with more increases anticipated. In real estate, Goldman Sachs buys hotel and retail assets in Seoul, and New World sells China property assets. UK homebuyer demand rebounds to a six-month high, and WeWork secures new tenants at 21 Collyer Quay in Singapore. These developments indicate a shift in the global real estate market, with increasing competition and changing demand patterns. The trends may impact property prices and investment strategies.

site_title: US, China hail major 'progress' but White House flags March 1 deadline
summary: US and China claim significant progress in trade war negotiations, with President Donald Trump hailing "tremendous progress" and welcoming a letter from Chinese President Xi Jinping. However, the White House emphasizes the March 1 deadline to avoid escalating tariffs, which could harm the global economy. China agreed to purchase more US soyabeans and increase imports of US goods, but details on specific measures remain unclear. US officials say the two countries are battling for future dominance in high-tech industries.

site_title: SoftBank's Vision Fund in talks to invest US$1.5 bln in Chinese used car platform: sources
summary: SoftBank's Vision Fund is in talks to invest up to $1.5 billion in Chinese used car platform Guazi.com, valuing the firm at $8.5 billion. This would be the fund's latest Chinese deal, following a $460 million investment in German used car platform Auto1. Guazi, backed by Tencent and Sequoia Capital China, has also held talks with rival Renrenche, backed by Didi Chuxing. China's used car market has seen significant growth, with used sales rising 11.5% in 2018 to 13.82 million vehicles.

site_title: Nissan scraps plan to build new X-Trail model in Britain
summary: Nissan has scrapped plans to build its new X-Trail SUV in Britain, instead producing it in Japan, citing uncertainty over Brexit and falling demand for diesel cars in Europe. The decision was made two months before the UK's scheduled departure from the EU, with Nissan citing business reasons but also expressing concerns over the UK's future relationship with the EU. The move is expected to have a significant impact on the British car industry and Sunderland factory, where hundreds of jobs were cut last year.

site_title: Need service? Talk to the room
summary: Hotels are incorporating digital assistants, such as Amazon's Alexa and Apple's Siri, to streamline guest services. The technology allows guests to control various aspects of their stay, including room lighting, temperature, and TV settings. However, the accuracy of voice recognition can be inconsistent, leading to frustration and confusion. Despite the benefits, some hotels are still refining their digital assistants to improve their functionality and guest experience.

site_title: As the A380 faces yet another crunch, airlines are moving on
summary: The Airbus A380 is facing another existential crisis as airlines move away from the double-decker plane due to its high operating costs and limited route suitability. Despite its impressive capacity, only Emirates has made the A380 a significant part of its fleet, and even that is under threat. Several airlines, including Qantas, Malaysia Airlines, and British Airways, have opted for smaller, more efficient twin-engine models, citing cost savings and better passenger experience. Airbus has acknowledged that its timing might have been ill-advised, introducing the plane a decade too soon, and is now discussing with Emirates about the future of the A380 contract.

site_title: No Signboard's Q1 loss widens to S$573,643
summary: No Signboard Holdings, a Singapore-listed seafood restaurant operator, reported a net loss of S$573,643 for Q1 2019, widening from a restated loss of S$416,366 in Q1 2018. Revenue fell 16.1% to S$5.6 million due to closure of a restaurant outlet and termination of non-performing sales contracts. The group expects to open new outlets and continues to work on brand development and overseas expansion plans. Its subsidiary, Draft Breweries Denmark, has been placed under compulsory liquidation by Danish authorities due to non-compliance with corporate filing requirements.

site_title: Wave of profit warnings leaves Chinese stocks seeking buyers
summary: A wave of profit warnings has hit Chinese stocks, prompting authorities to introduce policies to boost the downbeat equity market. Hundreds of companies issued warnings of significant losses for 2018, triggering a market downturn in Shenzhen. The China Securities Regulatory Commission unveiled rule changes to allow greater risk-taking and attract capital, amid concerns that the financial sector is stretched. The move comes ahead of the Chinese New Year break, with markets reopening on February 11.

site_title: Ex-GM of ISDN unit under probe for misappropriating funds
summary: An ex-general manager of ISDN Holdings' subsidiary, Beijing Junyizhicheng Technology Developing Co, Duan Hong Xing, is under investigation in China for allegedly misappropriating funds. ISDN filed a police report after receiving a writ of summons alleging a 9.5 million yuan loan to Duan, for which SD Beijing was a guarantor. ISDN terminated Duan's employment contract in November and appointed a new general manager. The company remains unaffected by the alleged misconduct, with no indication of misappropriation of its own funds.

site_title: NZ govt's bold plan to fix housing crisis off to shaky start
summary: New Zealand's government, led by Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern, has scrapped its initial targets for the KiwiBuild initiative, a plan to build 100,000 new homes over a decade to address the country's housing crisis. So far, only 47 of the 1,000 homes promised by July have been built, and the government now expects to have 300 new homes built by July. Critics argue that the plan has failed to meet its targets and that the country's housing shortage remains a significant issue, with over 11,600 people on public housing waiting lists.

site_title: Latest Earnings
summary:
Here is a 100-word summary of the article content:

NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was oversubscribed 9.8 times. US stocks opened lower amid President Trump's fresh tariff salvo on Canada. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall in H2, with similar operating loss as H1. London's Heathrow is considering higher fees for its £10b upgrade. An Indonesian court detained a Trafigura employee in a graft case. OCBC announced Tan Teck Long as its new CEO, replacing the current one. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and PBOC will deepen cooperation in green and transition finance. Singapore stocks had a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data release.

site_title: Will the Year of the Pig be a prosperous one for China?
summary: China is expected to continue grappling with slower growth, high debt levels, and a trade war with the US in the Year of the Pig. However, its leadership is well-placed to handle these challenges, and the country's long-term economic potential remains strong. The "Made in China 2025" program aims to shift China's industrial capabilities towards high-tech areas, avoiding the "middle-income trap." As investors, they should consider allocating to China, despite current challenges, as the country is likely to become the largest economy in the world in the long term.

site_title: Gojek raises over US$1 billion as ride-hailing giants beef up their portfolios
summary: Gojek has raised over $1 billion in its Series F funding round, valuing the company at $8-10 billion. The ride-hailing giant plans to double down on key verticals in Indonesia and strengthen its regional footprint. Industry observers say the industry is shifting from a price war to a multi-layered competitive environment, with companies focusing on offering a broad spectrum of quality services to build customer loyalty and control daily spend.

site_title: Tulip Garden succeeds in en bloc sale on fourth try
summary: Asia Radiant, a joint venture between Yanlord Land Group and MCL Land, has successfully completed the en bloc sale of Tulip Garden in Singapore for $907 million. The condominium, comprising 162 apartments and two shop units, was initially put up for sale in 2007 but was later delayed due to concerns over the number of units being planned by the buyer. The sale was finally completed after four attempts, with each residential unit owner set to receive between $4.3 million and $7.6 million, depending on unit size.

site_title: Schroders to buy wealth management arm of Thirdrock Group
summary: Schroders announced the acquisition of Thirdrock Group's wealth management arm, with operations set to merge with Schroders' existing Singapore business. The deal, undisclosed, will integrate client assets under management of about S$3 billion. Completion is expected in the second quarter of this year.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: SingHaiyi Group posted a 208% rise in net profit to S$4 million for the third quarter ended Dec 31, 2018, despite a 62% fall in revenue. Gross profit increased 24.5% to S$7.3 million due to wider margins from US property development. Viking Offshore and Marine is in discussions with potential investors to strengthen its financial position, while Noble Group's winding-up application is scheduled for Feb 8, 2019.

site_title: Aussie home prices plunge into new year, decline gathers pace
summary: Australian home prices plummeted 1% in January, down 5.6% from the previous year, with the national index falling for 13 of the past 15 months.
